text.1:
Aṃkuśā — a Śakti on the Drāviṇikā mudrā.
Br. IV. 36. 76.
text.3:
Aṃkola — a tīrtha, and its merits.
M. 191. 118-25.
text.4:
Aṃcoladvicarāḥ(c) — a kingdom watered by the R. Sītā.
Br. II. 18, 45.
text.5:
Akapi — a sage of the Tāmasa epoch.
M. 9. 15.
text.6:
Akampana — a son of Khaśā and a Rākṣasa:1 an Asura
in the sabhā of Hiraṇyakaśipu.2 1) Br. III. 7, 136; Vā. 69, 167.
2) M. 161. 81.
text.8:
Akarmaka(i) — a class of Piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 379.
text.9:
Akalmaṣa — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
M. 9. 17.
text.10:
Akāra — its significance in Oṃ;1 the source of 63
varṇas;2 the primordial svara and its place in creation.3 1) Vā. 20. 8ff.
2) Vā. 26. 28.
3) Vā. 26. 29ff.
text.11:
Akārādikṣakārāntavarṇamūrti — the house of, to the
north of Mātṛkā.
Br. IV. 36. 20.
text.12:
Akṛtacūḍa — one who has not had tonsure: his death
leaves pollution for one night; pollution after cūḍa is for
three nights.
M. 18. 3.
text.13:
Akṛtavraṇa (I) — a Brāhman invited for the Rājasūya of
Yudhiṣṭhira to officiate as a priest.
Bhā., X. 74. 9.
text.14:
Akṛtavraṇa (II) — a Paurāṇika. Learnt one of the four
Mūlasamhitas from the disciple of Vyāsa;1 a pupil of Roma
harṣaṇa; otherwise known as Kāśyapa.2 1) Bhā., XII. 7. 5, 7.
2) Vi. III. 6. 17.
text.16:
Akṛtavraṇa (IV) — the Brahman boy rescued by Paraśu
rāma, his guru, from the jaws of a tiger.1 Advised to take
courage and console his mother; condoled with him on the
loss of his parents.2 Accompanied Paraśurāma, to Mandira
for a twelve years' penance and to Mahendra for another
course of austerities. Helped Paraśurāma in his Aśvamedha
and the penance after.3 1) Br. III. 26. 3; 30. 21; 34, 8, 29; 35. 37.
2) Br. III. 37. 10;
38, 2, 35; 39. 13; 41. 15, 17; 43, 31; 44. 1, 30.
3) Br. III. 46.
3, 28; 47. 34, 59.
text.17:
Akṛtāśva — a son of Samhatāśva.
Br. III. 63. 65; M. 12, 34.
text.18:
Akriya — the son of Gambhīra. Of his wife was born
Brahman.
Bhā. IX. 17. 10.
text.19:
Akrūra (I) — a Yadu prince; welcomed Kṛṣṇa to Dvā
raka.1 The foremost of the sons of Śvaphalka and Gāndinī;
married a daughter of Ugrasena and had two sons, Devavān
and Upadeva (Deva and Anupadeva-Vi).2 Stayed in Madhu
rā (Mathurā) when the Yadus migrated.3 Once visited Brah
maḥrada.4 Kaṃsa sent for him and asked him to take in
his chariot Kṛṣṇa and Rāma to the capital for the Dhanur
yāga (‘festival of arms’) at which they were to be killed.
Returned home with this message.5 When the night passed
by, Akrūra started for the vraja of Nanda thinking all the way
of the meeting and embraces of Kṛṣṇa and Rāma who had
made friends with people of Brindāvan. Reached Gokula
by evening.6 Saw Rāma and Kṛṣṇa in fine deportment and
form, milking cows: prostrated before them in divine ecstasy.
Welcomed in the proper way by the brothers and Nanda,
Akrūra was lost in wonder, and did not feel the fatigue of the
journey.7 Gopis who came to know of Akrūra's mission called
him Krūra for taking away Kṛṣṇa from their midst.8 It was
early morning when Akrūra and the two brothers started
after morning prayers. Reaching the Yamunā, Akrūra went
to the river for a bath, asking the brothers to stay in the cha
riot. But he was surprised to see the brothers in the waters,
and at the same time in the chariot also. He also saw Hari
reclining on Śeṣa.9 Akrūra's praise of Hari.10 Con
gratulating himself on his luck to have had a darśan of Hari,
he drove Kṛṣṇa and Rāma to Mathurā before sunset.11
Invited Kṛṣṇa to his home, and the latter agreed to go to
his place only after Kaṃsavadha. Informed Kaṃsa of
Kṛṣṇa's arrival in the camp, and went back to his house.12
Attended the wrestling match.12(a Gopis took Uddhava to
Akrūra.13 Was visited by Kṛṣṇa with Rāma and Uddhava to
whom Akrūra gave a royal welcome.14 Kṛṣṇa told Akrūra
that they looked to him for guidance, and that he was their
guru. Was requested by Kṛṣṇa to go to Hastināpura to find
out the exact position of the Pāṇḍavas.15 Visited Hastināpura
and returned to Mathurā after meeting Kunti and ascertain
ing the evil intentions of Dhṛtarāṣṭṛa against the Pāṇḍavas.16
One of those stationed by Kṛṣṇa to defend the western gate
of Mathurā,17 was consulted by Kṛṣṇa on the eve of his attack
on Jarāsandha.18 A member of the Yādava sabhā.19 Satya
bhāmā refusing to part with the jewel Syamantaka (s.v.),
Akrūra suggested with Kṛtavarman to Śatadhanvan Bhoja
its seizure from Satrājita as he had failed to keep his promise
to marry his daughter to them.20 Asked by Śatadhanvan for
help against Kṛṣṇa, Akrūra refused; Bhoja Śatadhanvan
killed Satrājita, the father of Satyabhāmā, and secured
the jewel but placed it in Akrūra's custody.21 Became
afraid, after Śatadhanva's death at the hands of Kṛṣṇa and
Balarāma, and left Dvārakā. Evil portents in the city and
cessation of rains. It was said that rain fell where Akrūra
lived. Was sent for by Kṛṣṇa to return to Dvārakā; gave
his sister in marriage to Kṛṣṇa who after duly honouring
him, requested him to show the jewel in public, so that
Rāma might not misunderstand him. He did so in the
sabhā of the Sātvatas but Kṛṣṇa placed Syamantaka back
in his hand.22 Was sent back to Dvārakā after the Rāja
sūya for its defence.23 Visited Syamantapañcaka on the
occasion of the solar eclipse.24 Fought with Bhoja, deluded
by Kṛṣṇa.25 Got killed in the Yādava contest at Prabhāsa.26 1) Bhā. I. 11. 16; 14, 28.
2) Bhā. IX. 24. 15, 17, 18; Br. III.
71. 113; Vi. IV. 13. 126; 14. 7, 10; Vā. 96. 112.
3) Bhā. X. 2.
4 [].
4) Bhā. X. 28. 16.
5) Bhā. X. 36. 27-40; Vi. V. 15, 9, 12.
6) Bhā. X. 38, 1-24 Vi. V. 15. 24.
7) Bhā. X. 38. 25-43; Vi. V.
17. 2-25.
8) Bhā. X. 39. 21-26.
9) Bhā. X. 39. 32-57; Vi. V. 18.
11 and 19.
10) Bhā. X. 40. (whole).
11) Bhā. X. 41. 4-6.
12) Bhā. X. 41. 11-18.
12(a) Vi. V. 20. 28.
13) Bhā. X. 46. 48.
14) Ib. X. 48. 12-28.
15) Ib. X. 48. 29-35.
16) Ib. X. ch. 49 (whole).
17) Ib. X. 50. 20[4].
18) Ib. X. [50. (V). 8].
19) Ib. X. [52. (V).
15].
20) Ib. X. 57. 3; Vā. 96. 57, 97; Vi. IV. 13. 115-26.
21) Bhā. X. 57. 14-18.
22) Ib. X. 57. 29-41 [1-4]; Br. III. 71. 59 and
83; Vi. IV. 13. 67-90.
23) Bhā. X. 76. 7 [5] 14.
24) Ib. X. 82. 5.
25) Ib. XI. 12. 10.
26) Ib. XI. 30. 16.
text.22:
Akrūra (IV) — a son of Jayanta, married Ratnā, Śaibya's
daughter; father of eleven powerful sons.
M. 45. 27-8.
text.23:
Akrodhana (I) — a son of Tvaritāyu or simply Āyu.
M. 50. 37.
text.24:
Akrodhana (II) — a son of Ayutāyu and father of Devā
tithi.
Vā. 99. 232.
text.25:
Akṣa (I)1 — the game of dice. Ṛtuparṇa, an expert in it.
Taught the game to Nala; to be avoided by a king.2 1) Bhā. IX. 9. 17; M. 220. 8; Vā. 88. 174; Vi. IV. 4. 37;
Br. III. 63. 173.
2) M. 154. 520; 220. 8.
text.27:
Akṣa (III) — a son of Satyabhāmā and Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 71. 247; Vā. 96. 238.
text.28:
Akṣapāda — a son of Somaśarman, the avatār of the
Lord at Prabhāsa, contemporary with the 27th Vyāsa.
Vā. 23. 216.
text.31:
Akṣara (II) — an epithet of Hari — (ety.)1 is Brahma.2 1) M. 248. 39.
2) Vā. 32. 1.
text.32:
Akṣara (III) — rises out of the neck of Brahmā in the con
templation of creation.1 A system of letters formed by
Brahmā.2 1) Vā. 26. 14.
2) Bhā. XII. 6. 43-44.
text.35:
Akṣasūtra — given to Vāmana by Pulaha: adorns Agas
tya, (also Akṣamālā) (s.v.).
M. 61. 36; 245. 87.
text.36:
Akṣayavaṭa — in Gayā;1 the fruits of anna śrāddha at.2 1) Vā. 105. 45; 109. 16.
2) Vā. 111. 79 & 83.
text.38:
Akṣayāśva — one of the two sons of Saṃhatāśva.
Vā. 88. 63.
text.39:
Akṣayatṛtīyā (vratam) — the third day of Śuklapakṣa
of the month Vaiśākha. It is all the more important if Kṛt
tikā happens to be the nakṣatra of that day. A prayer to
Janārdana on that day accompanied by fasting is equal to
performing the Rājasūya.
M. 65. 1-7.
text.40:
Akṣi — a daughter of Rohiṇī and Ānakadundubhi.
M. 46. 12.
text.41:
Agaja — a son of the elephant Mṛga.
Br. III. 7. 332.
text.42:
Agamyāgamanam (Anyāṅganārati s.v.) — Bṛhaspati
tells Indra that intercourse with mother, sister, wife of pre
ceptor and uncle's wife is illegal. The last two could be
atoned for by a kṛcchra of 12 and 6 years respectively. Simi
lar cases of forbidden intercourse and their respective prā
yaścittas given. Repetition of Pañcadaśākṣarī 1008 times
after worshipping Parāśakti could remove all sins.
Br. IV. 8. 1-37.
text.43:
Agamyagāmi — goes to the naraka Śabala.
Vā. 101. 157.
text.44:
Agaru — the forest in the Kuru country between the two
mountains Candrakānta and Sūryakānta.
Vā. 45. 31.
text.45:
Agastya (I) — a son of Pulastya and Havirbhū: he was
Dahra-agni in his previous birth.
Bhā., IV, 1. 36.
text.46:
Agastya (II) — a contemporary of Kṛṣṇa and Rāma; and
a resident of Mount Malaya. Visited by Balarāma.1 Came
to Syamantapañcaka to see Kṛṣṇa.2 Called on Parīkṣit prac
tising prāyopaveśa.3 1) Bhā., X. 79. 17.
2) Ib. X. 84. 5.
3) Ib. I. 19. 10.
text.47:
Agastya (Kumbhayoni) (III) — born from a pitcher into
which Mitra and Varuṇa dropped their vīrya at the sight
of the charms of Urvaśī: a brother of Vasiṣṭha.1 Dwarfed
the Vindhyas, made a home in Laṅkā: seeing the universe
troubled by Tāraka and other Asuras caused the ocean to
dry up by drinking the waters and brought relief to the
Devas: performed tapas seated on Mount Malaya with his
wife Lopāmudrā: white in colour, with four hands, Akṣa
mālā and Kamaṇḍalu, narrated the story of Ajāmila:2 pre
sent at Rāma's abhiṣeka.2(a Visited by Paraśurāma, initiated
him to the Kṛṣṇapremāmṛtam mantra which he heard
from Śeṣa, the Nāga king. Spoke to him of the threefold
bhakti and its characteristics.3 A Brahmiṣṭha, versed in
Vaikhānasa; a Devaṛṣi, versed in Vedic literature.4
The guest of Ilvala who cooked Vātāpi for him.5
Roaming about, he found all creatures engrossed in
ignorance. Reaching Kāñcī, he prayed to Kāmākṣi and
Ekāmraśiva. Here Hayagrīva Viṣṇu appeared before him
and pointed out ways to redeem the ignorant millions. Was
entertained with the story of Śakti by Hayagrīva.6 Praised
Śiva out to ruin Tripuram.7 He who worships Agastya
becomes lord of the seven worlds.8 1) Bhā. VI. 18. 5; Br. IV. 5. 38 M. 61. 21-31; 201. 29; 202. 1.
2) Bhā., VI. 3. 35; M. 61. 17; 36-41; Br. III. 56. 53.
2(a) Vi. IV
4. 99.
3) Br. II, 32. 119; III. 34. 50; 35. 34, 41, 48; 36, 1-59;
37, 2; 56. 23.
4) M. 145. 93, 114.
5) Bhā. VI. 18, 15.
6) Br. IV.
5. 3-29; 6. 1; 39. 7.
7) M. 133. 67.
8) M. 61. 44-55.
text.48:
Agastya (IV) — married the first born daughter of King
Malayadhvaja Pāṇḍya, and had a son Dṛḍhācyuta.1 Cursed
the Pāṇḍyan king Indradyumna to become an elephant.2 1) Bhā. IV. 28. 32.
2) Ib. VIII. 4. 9-10.
text.49:
Agastya (V) — the constellation (Canopus) that moves
fast above Dhruvamaṇḍala.
Br. II. 21. 101; Vā. 50, 155.
text.50:
Agastya (VI) — a hill of that name.
M. 124. 97.
text.51:
Agastya (VII) — born of garbha; born later as Dattāli;1
(Dattoli-Vi.). residence (bhavana) at Mahāmalaya;2 relation
of, to Potṛyaṇa;3 Udayantaka Mt. brought by; and his wife.4 1) Vā. 28. 22; Vi. I, 10. 9.
2) Vā. 48. 23.
3) Vā. 59. 93, 208.
4) Vā. 108. 44, 53.
text.52:
Agastyakuṇḍam — in the Udayantaka Mt.; here eight
sages performed austerities and attained salvation.
Vā. 108. 45.
text.55:
Agastyas — a group of Rākṣasas.
Br. III. 7. 162.
text.56:
Agastyeśvaram — a tīrtha in the Narmadā.
M. 191. 15-18.
text.58:
Agāvaha — Father of four sons and a daughter.
Br. III. 71. 257.
text.59:
Agnajitī — a queen of Kṛṣṇa.
Vi. V. 28. 3.
text.60:
Agni (I) — the God of Fire also known as Hutāśana,
Havyavāhana and Vahni.1 A place sacred to Agni in the Sara
svatī which Vidura visited.2 Svāhā and her three sons are
deities presiding over Agni.3 One of the gods with power to
confer boons or pronounce curse on the world, curse on
elephants.4 On the tail of Śiśumāra.5 Invested by the Māyā
of Bhagavān, Agni does not sometimes understand his
will and work.6 A guardian of the world.7 The mouth of
Hari as embodying all Vedas.8 Is pleased with a devotee of
Hari.9 Even the powerful Agni could not digest Brāhman's
property when misappropriated.10 Identified with Hari.11
Swallowed the seed of Śiva borne by Gaṅgā as a punishment
for disturbing Umā's union with the Lord, and unable to
digest it, he discharged it into a bush of reeds (śarakānana)
where it became Kumāra.12 Goes round Dhruva.13 Pre
sented Ājagava bow to Pṛthu.14 Married a daughter of
Dakṣa.15 Worshipped in Kuśadvīpa.16 His son was Manu
Svārociṣa.17 Fought with Puloma in a Devāsura war,18 fol
lowed Indra's army against Kṛṣṇa who took away Pārijāta
from heaven. Beaten by Kṛṣṇa, he escaped alive from the
field.19 His town visited by Arjuna in search of a dead child
of a Brāhman of Dvārakā.20 1) Bhā., I. 15. 8; Br., III. 10. 24-35.
2) Bhā., III. 1. 22.
3) Ib. IV.
1. 60.
4) Ib. IV. 14. 26-27; Br. III. 7, 352.
5) Bhā., V. 23. 5;
Br. II. 23. 104.
6) Bhā., VI. 3. 14. 15.
7) Ib., VIII. 10. 26.
8) Ib.
VIII. 16. 9.
9) Ib. X. 41. 13.
10) Ib. X. 64. 32.
11) Ib. XI. 16. 13.
12) Ib. IV. 7. 64[]; VI. 6. 14; Br. IV. 15. 21; 20. 46; 26. 53.
13) Bhā., IV. 9. 21.
14) Ib. IV. 15. 18.
15) Ib. IV. 1. 48.
16) Ib. V. 20. 2.
17) Ib. VIII. 1. 19.
18) Ib. VIII. 10. 31;
19) Ib. X. [65 (V) 40];
[66 (V) 27-31].
20) Ib. X. 89. 44.
text.61:
Agni (II) — a lokapāla: Gold pleasing to Agni; worship
of;1 burning women and children in Tripura, he pleaded
that he was not a free agent, but only carrying out orders.2
The vamśa of Agni. The succession of fires and their
descendants detailed in Ch. 51 of the Matsya Purāṇa.3 The
Bhāgavata Purāṇa mentions 49 Agnis. Pāvaka, Pavamāna
and Śuci and their 45 sons together with Svāhā. All invoked
in sacrifices.4 Another classification of fires: divyam, bhau-
tikam or abyoni, and pārthivam.5 1) M. 225. 13; 266. 20, 63.
2) M. 188. 29-57.
3) Cf. Mhb.
Vana: 220. 4.
4) Bhā. IV. 1. 60-62; 7, 16.
5) Br. II. 24. 6; 21. 53. 56; Vā.
53. 5.
text.62:
Agni (III) — one of the eight Vasus, and a son of Vasu.
Wife Vasorddhāra. Draviṇaka and others are sons.1 Identi
fied with Hari.2 1) Bhā., VI. 6. 11, 13.
2) Ib. XI. 16. 13; M. 8. 4.
text.63:
Agni (IV) — married Vikeśi. Father of Ūrjja clan of
apsaras and also of Nala and Aṅgāraka, who afterwards
became a planet.
Br. II. 24. 91; III. 7. 21, 229.
text.64:
Agni (V) — an Ātreya, and one of the seven sages of
Tāmasa epoch.
Br. II. 36. 47; M. 9. 15; Vā. 62. 41.
text.65:
Agni (VI) — a son of Āgneyī and Ūru: His daughter Suc
chāyā married Śiṣṭa, son of Dhruva: Ārṣeya pravara.
M. 4. 38, 43; 196. 9.
text.66:
Agni (VII) — alias Ṛta; son of Samvatsara;1 married
Svāhā, a daughter of Dakṣa.2 1) Br. II. 13. 23.
2) Vā. 1. 76; Br. II. 9. 56; 12. 1.
text.67:
Agni (VIII) — a Marut gana of that name.
M. 171. 52.
text.68:
Agni (IX) — The eldest son and mindborn son of Brahmā
in Svāyambhuva antara;1 of Brahmā's tapas;2 one of the
eight tanus of Mahādeva,3 hymns to;4 gave rise to a family
of 49 fires.5 1) Vā. 29. 1; Vi. I. 10. 14.
2) Vā. 21. 63-4.
3) Vā. 27. 35.
4) Vā. 21. 71ff.
5) Vi. I. 10. 15-7.
text.69:
Agni (X) — (Bhūtapati) one Agni made into three by
Aila to attain the Gandharva loka in the Tretāyuga. The
Gandharvas presented him with a pot of Agni which he took
to his city to perform sacrifices. He placed it on the Araṇi
when an Aśvattha appeared to his surprise. When Aila
informed Gandharvas the latter asked him to turn the
Aśvattha thrice and get three fires with which to sacrifice.
Vā. 91. 48: 101. 21.
text.73:
Agnikā — one of the three daughters of Vikrāntā; origi
nator of the Āgneya gaṇa of the Gandharvas.
Vā. 69. 21-23.
text.74:
Agnikuṇḍa — the fire pot from which Śiva appeared to
Dakṣa.1 Rise of Tilottamā from Brahmā's agnikuṇḍa.2 1) Vā. 30. 172.
2) Vā. 69. 59.
text.76:
Agnijihva (I) — a daitya in the fifth talam (Mahātalam
Vā.).
Br. II. 20. 36; Vā. 50. 35.
text.78:
Agnijvāla — the name of a hell to which disturbers of
hermitages go;1 those fallen from their āśrama duties undergo
torments in.2 1) Br. IV. 2. 149, 174.
2) Vā. 101. 148, 171.
text.79:
Agnitīrtham — on the southern bank of the Yamunā.
M. 108. 27.
text.80:
Agnitejas — a sage of the XI epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 31.
text.81:
Agnidhra — a son of Bhautya Manu.
Vā. 100. 116.
text.82:
Agnipurāṇa — one among the Mahāpurāṇas comprises
15400 ślokas. See Agni.
Bhā., XII. 7. 23; 13. 5.
text.83:
Agnipraveśam — the custom of wife entering her hus
band's funeral pyre.
Br. III. 47. 82.
text.84:
Agnipraskandanam — diarrhoea — Yayāti caused his son
Anu to be afflicted by it.
M. 33. 24.
text.85:
Agnibāhu (I) — one of the ten sons of Svāyambhuva
Manu.
Br. II. 13. 104; M. 9. 4.
text.86:
Agnibāhu (II) — one of the ten sons of Kardama.
Br. II. 14. 9.
text.87:
Agnibāhu (III) (Bhārgava) — a sage of the epoch of
Bhautya Manu;1 a son of Bhautya (fourteenth) Manu.2 1) Br. IV. 1. 113.
2) Vā. 100. 116.
text.88:
Agnibāhu (IV) — a son of Priyavrata;1 had no inclination
for rule and was given to yoga;2 a sage of the XIV epoch of
Manu.3 1) Vi. II. 1. 7.
2) Vi. II. 1. 9.
3) Vi. III. 2. 44.
text.90:
Agnibhāsa — one of the fourteen sons of Vasiṣṭha Prajā
pati in the Cāriṣṇava antara.
Vā. 62. 46.
text.91:
Agnimāḍhaka (also Agnimāṭhara) — a pupil of Bāṣkala
was instructed the second śākhā of the Ṛgveda.
Vā. 60. 26; Vi. III. 4. 18.
text.92:
Agnimat — one who keeps up the sacred fire.
M. 16. 21.
text.93:
Agnimantras — in homas to ward off calamities to the
state.
M. 231. 11.
text.94:
Agnimātā — a second disciple of Bāṣkala, in charge of a
śākhā of the Ṛgveda.
Br. II. 34, 27.
text.95:
Agnimitra (I) — the son of Puṣyamitra Śuṅga and father
of Sujyeṣṭha;1 reigned for eight years.2 1) Bhā. XII. 1. 16; Vi. IV. 24. 34-5.
2) Br. III. 74. 151.
text.96:
Agnimitra (II) — a pupil of Bāṣkala.
Bhā., XII. 6. 54.
text.97:
Agnimukha — the name of an Asura who has his city in
the third talam.
Br. II. 20. 26.
text.98:
Agnirbāhu — a sage of the epoch of the 14th Manu (Agni
bāhu) (Burnouf).
Bhā. VIII. 13. 34.
text.99:
Agniliṅgam — from its middle Maheśvara spoke out the
Liṅga Purāṇa.
M. 53. 37-8.
text.100:
Agniva(r)cas — a sage:1 a pupil of Romaharṣaṇa.2 1) Br. II. 35. 64.
2) Vi. III. 6. 17.
text.101:
Agnivarṇa — of the (Kuśa dynasty); the son of Sudar
śana, and father of Śīghra(ga).
Bhā. IX. 12. 5; Br. III. 63. 209-10; Vā. 88. 209; Vi. IV. 4. 108.
text.102:
Agniveśya (I) — the son of Devadatta, was an incarnation
of Agni. Was known also by other names — Kānīna and
Jātūkarṇa. He was a great sage, and the originator of the
Brāhman group of Agniveśyāyana.1 (Pravara-Aṅgiras).2 1) Bhā., IX. 2. 21-22; Br. III. 47. 49.
2) M. 196. 12.
text.103:
Agniveśya (II) — a son of Śūli in the 24th dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 207.
text.104:
Agniśarma — a mānasa ṛtvik at Brahmā's yāga, created
five Agnis from his face.
Vā. 106. 34, 41.
text.105:
Agniśamāyaṇas — the originators of Kaśyapa gotra.
M. 199. 7.
text.107:
Agniṣṭut (II) — a son of Cākṣuṣa Manu.
Br. II. 36. 79, 106; M. 4. 42.
text.108:
Agniṣṭoma — a son of Manu Cākṣuṣa and Naḍvalā.
Bhā. IV. 13. 16: Vi. I. 13. 5.
text.109:
Agniṣṭomam — origin of, from the first face of Brahmā;1
performing Agniṣṭomam is equal to honouring pitṛs; done
by Vāli.2 Here the sacrifice of paśu is involved.3 1) Br. II. 8. 50; Vā. 9. 49; Vi. I. 5. 53.
2) Br. III. 7. 268; 11,
43; 15. 11.
3) M. 53. 33; 58. 53; 239. 30.
text.110:
Agniṣṇ(ṣṭ)ut — a son of Nāḍvaleya Manu.
Vā. 62. 67, 91.
text.111:
Agniṣvāttāḥ — a pitṛgaṇa dwelling in the Somapāda
region in the direction of Vaivasvata.1 Pitṛs representing
ārttavas, the name given to householders who do not per
form yajñas.2 Pitṛs in Viraja's kingdom. Their mind-born
daughter Pīvarī was married by Śuka, son of Vyāsa.3 Gave
Menā their mind-born daughter to Himavān;4 overlord of
other pitṛs.5 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 63; V. 26. 5; Vi. I. 10. 18; II. 12. 13; Br. II.
13. 6; Vā. 73. 2; 110. 10.
2) Br. II. 13. 6-7; 23. 75-77; 28. 4, 16,
19, 20 and 73; Vā. 30. 6, 27f; 52. 67-8; 56. 13-15, 68; 73. 2-4.
3) Br. III. 10. 75-80.
4) Vā. 30. 27-9, 31; 56. 13 and 68; Vi. I. 10. 19;
Br. II. 13. 31.
5) M. 14. 2; 18. 21; 19. 5; 102. 20; 126. 69; 141. 4,
13 and 16.
text.112:
Agnisambhavas — a Kanyā gaṇa born of Manu from
Ūrjā.
Vā. 69. 54.
text.113:
Agnihotram — personified as the son of Pṛśni and Savitā;1
a vedic sacrifice;2 performed by Bharata.3 Its nature and
effects.4 Performers of Agnihotra live in Pitṛyāna;5 per
formed by Śukra, Dhūminī, the sonless wife of Ajamīḍha;6
performed by Purūravas;7 the face of the personified Vedas.8
As efficacious as hearing the Viṣṇupurāṇa once.9 1) Bhā. VI. 18, 1.
2) Ib. III, 13, 36.
3) Ib. V. 7, 5.
4) Ib. VII.
15, 48.
5) Br. II. 21. 160; 30, 13; III. 14, 2; 26, 14; 35, 44; 44,
5; 66, 2; M. 124. 98.
6) M. 11, 58; 25, 34; 50, 18; 107, 16;
183, 81.
7) Vā. 91, 2; 107, 18; 77, 9.
8) Ib. 104, 83.
9) Vi. VI. 8, 30.
text.114:
Agnīdhra (I) — a Nadīputra and Dhiṣṇi agni.
Br. II. 12, 20. Vā. 29. 18, 26.
text.115:
Agnīdhra (II) — (Kāśyapa) — a sage of the epoch of
Bhautya Manu (XIVth Manu).
Br. IV. 1. 112; Vi. III. 2, 44.
text.116:
Agnīdhra (III) — a son of Svāyambhuva Manu.1 Lord
of Jambūdvīpa.2 1) Vā. 31. 17.
2) Vā. 33. 9, 11.
text.117:
Agnīṣomayama — Āpyāyanam offered to Agni, Soma
and Yama in the śrāddha; the pitṛsthānam of places pre
scribed.
M. 15. 32; 16. 33.
text.118:
Agnīṣomavidhijña — an attribute of Śiva, Agnīṣoman
representing Brahman.
Br. III. 72. 188; IV. 43. 76.
text.119:
Agnyādhānakriyā — Vedic rituals which are to begin
on Parvasandhis.
M. 141. 32.
text.120:
Agryam — a region of the Pātāla; the soil with the gold
colour.
Vi. II. 5. 2 and 3.
text.121:
Agha — an asura; friend of Kaṃsa. Appeared in the
guise of a boa-constrictor in order to devour Kṛṣṇa, his play
mates and cattle in Bṛndāvana. Thinking it to be a part of
the landscape of the Bṛndāvana, Kṛṣṇa's playmates and
cattle entered his wide-open mouth. Kṛṣṇa understood the
situation, and after a little hesitation, he also went in and
killed him by choking his throat. Agha, however, attained
salvation.
Bhā. X. 12. 13-38; 13. 4; 14. 60.
text.122:
Aghamarṣaṇa (I) — a tīrtha at the foot of the Vindhyas.
Here Dakṣa performed tapas and praised Hari with the
Hamsaguḥya.
Bhā. VI. 4. 21 & 35.
text.123:
Aghamarṣaṇa (II) — a Kauśika and a sage.1 Not to have
matrimonial alliance with Viśvāmitra and others.2 1) Br. II. 32. 117; M. 145. 112.
2) M. 198. 12.
text.125:
Aghora — the form of Maheśvara in the 32nd kalpa, all
black.
Vā. 23. 29, 76.
text.126:
Aghorakalpa — an account of, in the Bhaviṣya.
M. 53. 31.
text.128:
Aṅgāraka (I) (Mars) — an inauspicious planet; tra
verses each of the signs of the zodiac once in three fortnights.1
The planet with Skanda as presiding deity; fed by Sampad-
vasu ray of the sun, attains Lauhitam sthānam or the Lohita
region. Consists of nine rays and looks in size equal to
Bṛhaspati: Placed above Śukra at a distance of 200,000
yojanas. Also known as Lohita and Vakra.2 The first of
Planets, originally Vīrabhadra who destroyed Dakṣa's sacri
fice; son of mother Earth; fought with Soma.3 Day sacred
to.4 Vratam in honour of, conduces to health and prosperity;
the Śūdras observe it; described by Śukra in detail.5 The
tanu of Śarva (Agni) by Vikeśi.6 Born in Āṣāḍha.7 1) Bhā. V. 22. 14.
2) Br. II. 24. 48, 70, 82, 95 & 105; Vi. II.
7. 8-9.
3) M. 23. 40; 72. 16 & 23; 93. 13; 133. 20.
4) M. 193. 8-9.
5) M. 72. 5-36.
6) Br. II. 10. 78; Vā. 27. 51.
7) Br. II. 24. 82, 133.
text.131:
Aṅga (I) — the father of Vena; knew the power of
Kṛṣṇa's yoga.1 A son of Ulmuka (Kuru and Āgneyī —
Vi. P.). His wife was Sunīthā, the cruel-faced daughter of
Mṛtyu. Finding the son's conduct cruel and unbecoming,
he departed from the city.2 Once he performed the Aśva-
medha but the gods did not partake of the offerings. When
he consulted the learned assembly, was advised by it that
he could get a son by worshipping Hari. But the son born,
Vena, was so mischievous that the king abandoned the king
dom in distress. Though messengers were deputed in search
of him, his whereabouts remained untraced.3 Devoted to
Hari, sought refuge with Him.4 According to the Brah-
māṇḍa, Matsya and Vāyu Purāṇas he was the son of Ūru
and Āgneyī.5 A Prajāpati of the family of Svāyambhuva
Manu (of the Atri line. Vā.)6 1) Bhā. II. 7. 43; Vi. I. 13. 6.
2) Bhā. IV. 13, 17-18.
3) Ib.
IV. 13. 24-49.
4) Ib. IV. 21. 28; X. 60. 41.
5) Br. II. 36. 108 & 126;
Vā. 62. 92-3; M. 4. 44.
6) M. 10. 3-4; Vā. 62. 107.
text.132:
Aṅga (II) — A kṣetraja son of Bali: born of Dīrghata
mas. Father of Khanapāna (Anapāna-Vā.).1 After him
was the Aṅgadeśa.2 Father of Dadhivāhana, born without
apāna (anus).3 The last king of his line was Vṛṣasena.4 1) Bhā. IX. 23. 5 & 6; M. 48. 25 & 9; Vā. 99. 28, 85; Br. III.
74. 27, 87.
2) Vi. IV. 18. 13-14.
3) Br. III. 74. 102; Vā. 99. 100.
4) Vi. IV. 18. 29.
text.133:
Aṅga (III) (c) — An eastern kingdom. Its king got
war elephants from Devas.
Br. II. 16. 51; 18. 51; III. 7. 349; 74. 213; M. 114. 44; 121. 50;
Vā. 47. 48; 99. 402.
text.135:
Aṅga (V) — the son of Viśvajit Janamejaya and father
of Karṇa.
M. 48. 102; Vā. 99. 112.
text.137:
Aṅgada (I) — a son of Lakṣmaṇa.1 Capital Kārayana
in the Aṅgada kingdom.2 (Kārapatha-Vā.). 1) Bhā. IX. 11. 12; Vi. IV. 4. 104.
2) Br. III. 63. 188; Vā. 88.
187-8.
text.138:
Aṅgada (II) — a son of Vāli: married the eldest
daughter of Mainda; father of Dhruva.1 Present at Rāma's
abhiṣeka.2 Helped Rāma in his expedition to Laṅkā.3 Bore
the sword when Bharata carried the pādukā of Rāma.4 1) Br. III. 7. 219-20.
2) Vi. IV. 4. 100.
3) Bhā. IX. 10. 19-20.
4) Ib. IX. 10. 44.
text.139:
Aṅgada (III) — a kingdom with its capital Kārayana.
Br. III. 63. 189.
text.140:
Aṅgada (IV) — a son of Bṛhatī.
Br. III. 71. 256; Vā. 96. 247.
text.141:
Aṅgadīyā — the capital of Kārapatha deśa(?)
Vā. 88. 188.
text.142:
Aṅgadevyantaram — the residence of Hṛddevī and
others.
Br. IV. 37. 40.
text.143:
Aṅgadvīpam — a part of Jambūdvīpa inhabited by
Mlecchas.
Vā. 48. 14-18.
text.144:
Aṅganā — wife of Vāmana, the elephant.
Br. III. 7. 339.
text.145:
Aṅgabhūtam — a tīrtham sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 51.
text.150:
Aṅgārapātana — name of a hell.
Br. IV. 33. 61.
text.152:
Aṅgāravāhinī — a R. in the Bhadrāśva continent.
Vā. 43. 26.
text.153:
Aṅgāreśvaram — a place sacred to Aṅgāraka on the R.
Narmadā.
M. 190. 9; 191. 59-60.
text.154:
Aṅgiras (I) — a mānasa son of Brahmā, born of his mouth.1
Married Śraddhā, (Pitrī-Vi. P.) a daughter of Kardama.2
Father of four daughters. His two sons were Utathya and
Bṛhaspati.3 Had not yet realised the Supreme Being.4 With
his pupils visited Bhīṣma lying on his bed of arrows.5 Came
to see Parīkṣit practising prāyopaveśa.6 Married two of
the daughters of Dakṣa. These were Svadhā and Satī. His
sons were Pitṛ and Atharvāngiras. A Prajāpati.7 Once
called on Citraketu, the king of Śūrasenas, who was childless
and blessed his first queen with a son. The jealous co-wives
of the king administered poison to the baby and it died.
Finding the king and queen weeping bitterly, Aṅgiras
accompanied by Nārada came to the palace. These two
sages appeared there in avadhūta form. Aṅgiras consoled
the king and cited the story of King Bhoja.8 Went back to
Brahmaloka with Nārada.9 Was appointed by King Rathi
kara to produce sons on his wife.10 The sage presiding over
the month of Nabha.11 Was present at the anointing of
Vāmana.12 Came to see Kṛṣṇa at Syamantapañcaka.13 Went
to Dvārakā to ask Kṛṣṇa to go back to Vaikuṇṭha.14 Had
another son named Samvarta (s.v.).15 Cursed Vidyādhara
Sudarśana (s.v.) to become a reptile for mocking at him.16
Performed a sacrifice when Śarayāti explained on the rituals
of the second day.17 Stood near the wheel of the chariot
Tripurāri in defence; served Prayāga and lived in Benares;
a mahaṛṣi and mantrakṛt.18 1) Bhā. III. 12. 22, 24; Br. II. 32. 96; M. 3. 6; 5. 14; 15. 16.
2) Bhā. III. 24. 22; Vi. I. 7. 5, 7; 15. 136.
3) Bhā. IV. 1. 34-5;
M. 102. 19; 106. 17.
4) Bhā. IV. 29. 43.
5) Bhā. I. 9. 8.
6) Ib.
I. 19. 9.
7) Ib. VI. 6. 2, 19; Br. II. 37. 45; M. 167. 43; 171. 27; Vā.
1. 137; 3. 3; 25. 82; 30. 48; 65. 97-101.
8) Bhā. VI. 14. 14-30,
37-61; 15. 10; 12, 17-26 [1-4].
9) Ib. VI. 16. 26.
10) Ib. IX. 6. 2.
11) Ib. XII. 11. 37; M. 126. 10.
12) Bhā. VIII. 23. 20.
13) Ib. X. 84. 5.
14) Ib. XI. 6. 2.
15) Ib. IX. 2. 26.
16) Ib. X. 34. 13-15.
17) Ib.
IX. 3. 1.
18) M. 133. 20, 61, 67; 145. 90, 101; 146. 17; 184. 15; 192.
10; Vā. 59. 98.
text.155:
Aṅgiras (II) — a son of Ulmuka.
Bhā. IV. 13. 17.
text.156:
Aṅgiras (III) — author of Aṅgiras Kalpa; a master of
Atharva Samhitā.
Bhā. XII. 7. 4.
text.157:
Aṅgiras (IV) — one of the sages who left for Piṇḍāraka.
Bhā. XI. 1. 12.
text.158:
Aṅgiras (V) — born in Vāruṇi yajña by an oblation in
the aṅgāra (fuel) from it, and hence the name. Agni there
fore claimed him to be his son, and so Aṅgirasas became
Āgneyas. Bhāradvājas and Gautamas belong to this line;
performed penance at Amarakaṇṭaka, praised Soma and
spoke on the Śrāddha Kalpa to his son Śaṃyu at Dāruvana.1
Married Surūpā, daughter of Marīci and had ten sons.2 1) Br. II. 9. 18, 23; III. 1. 21, 39-40, 101; 13. 5; 20. 19; IV. 2.
33 and 47; Vā. 64. 2; 73, 63; 75. 56; 77. 5; 88. 7; Br. II.
27. 103.
2) Vā. 65. 105-8; M. 195. 9; 196. 1; 245. 86.
text.159:
Aṅgiras (VI) — A son of Kaśyapa; married Smṛti and
had two sons and four daughters;1 flourished in Svāyam
bhuva antara; a Devaṛṣi.2 1) Br. II. 11. 17; 9. 55; Vā. 28. 14.
2) Ib. 31. 16; 30. 86;
Br. II. 11. 17; 13. 53.
text.160:
Aṅgiras (VII) — with the sun for the months Nabho
nabha (Nabha-Vi. P.).
Br. II. 23. 9; Vi. II. 10. 9.
text.161:
Aṅgiras (VIII) — the name of Vyāsa in the fourth
dvāpara; avatār of the lord Suhotri.
Vā. 23. 126.
text.162:
Aṅgiras (IX) — one of the Ātreyas of the Raivata
antara.1 Sprung out of charcoal in which Brahmā offered
a second oblation: adopted by Agni as his son and hence
Aṅgiras called Āgneyas.2 See Aṅgiras. V. 1) Br. II. 36. 62.
2) Ib. III. 1. 40-42.
text.163:
Aṅgiras (X) — a son of Ṛṣabha, the ninth avatār of
Maheśvara.
Vā. 23. 144.
text.164:
Aṅgiras (XI) — A son of Atharva:1 known as Atharvan.2 1) Vā. 29. 9.
2) Ib. 65. 97; Br. I. 5. 70.
text.165:
Aṅgirasa (I) — a son of Āgneyi and Ūru (Kuru-Vi. P.).
M. 4. 43; Vi. I. 13. 6.
text.166:
Aṅgirasa (II) — the fourth part of Atharva Veda.
Vi. III. 6. 14.
text.167:
Aṅgirasas (I) — the name of a devagaṇa.
Br. III. 1. 50.
text.168:
Aṅgirasas (II) — the thirty-three sages, all mantrakṛts.
Vā. 59. 102.
text.169:
Aṅgirasa-Kalpa — name given to a portion of Atharva
Veda.
Br. II. 35. 62 and 82; Vā. 61. 54.
text.170:
Aṅgirasāḥ — born of Rathītara's wife and Aṅgiras.
Hence Kṣatriya-cum-Brāhmaṇa.
Bhā. IX. 6. 3.
text.171:
Aṅgirasī — a R. of Plakṣadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 4.
text.172:
Aṅgulam — is eight times a yava. For other details see
Matsya P.
12 aṅgulas: 1 vitasti.
21 aṅgulas: 1 ratni
24 aṅgulas: 1 hasta
Br. II. 7. 96; IV. 2. 121; M. 258. 18-21; Vā. 8. 102; 101.
121 and 122.
text.173:
Aṅgulīya — a pupil of Kṛta.
Br. II. 35. 53; Vā. 61. 46.
text.174:
Aṅgulīyam — rings to be presented in connection with
Vṛkṣotsava.
M. 59. 14.
text.175:
Aṅguṣṭha — gifts, receiving of gifts, homa, feeding, bali
offering, all to be done.
Vā. 79. 88.
text.176:
Acala (I) ety. — immovable, hence a mountain.
Br. II. 7. 11.
text.177:
Acala (II) — the name of Bhairava in the Kiricakra.
Br. IV. 20. 82.
text.178:
Acala (III) — the son of Mahīnetra; ruled for 32 years.
M. 271. 28.
text.180:
Acetanā — the wife of Manu.
Br. III. 1. 82.
text.181:
Acyuta (I) — a god of the Lekha group.
Br. II. 36. 75.
text.182:
Acyuta (II) — an epithet for Viṣṇu,1 ety. One who does
not fall from his place (na cyavate).2 1) Br. II. 36. 178; IV. 29. 71; 43. 70; VI. I. 11. 43. et. seq.
M. 47. 5; 245. 49. 246. 33, 60.
2) M. 248. 35.
text.183:
Acyuta (III) — the Lord of the western region and son
of Prajāpati; also known as Ketumān.
Vā. 70. 17.
text.185:
Acchoda(ka)m — the name of a lake at the foot of Can
draprabha.1 Here Acchodā, the Pitṛ-kanyā, sprang up and
was again born in Matsya-yoni;2 residence of the Apsaras
Adrikā.3 1) Vā. 47. 5-7; M. 121, 6-7.
2) Vā. 77. 76-7.
3) Ib. 73. 3.
text.186:
Acchodā (I) — the mind-born daughter of Barhiṣada
pitṛs. After her name was the Acchoda lake. Without
finding her own Pitṛs, she took as her Pitṛ, another (Amā
vasu) and consequently lost her yogic powers. Then seeing
her Pitṛs in the form of Trasareṇu, she prayed to them for
succour. They said that she would be born on the earth
on the 28th Dvāpara as the daughter of Matsya and marry
Śantanu and be mother of two seers — Vicitravīrya as well
as of king Citrāṅgada. Afterwards she would attain
the aṣṭaka place in the Pitṛ world. As the daughter of the
fisherman, she was known as Satyavatī and Matsyagandhi.1
In the form of a river rising from lake Acchodam.2 1) Br. III. 10. 54-74; Vā. 73. 2-21; M. ch. 14 (whole).
2) M. 121. 7.
text.187:
Acchodā (II) — the R. from lake Acchoda.
Vā. 47. 5-6, 7.
text.188:
Aja (I) — a name of Brahmā.
Bhā. II. 4. 19; Vā. 73. 62; 98. 54.
text.189:
Aja (II) — a son of Pratihartā and Stuti.
Bhā. V. 15. 5.
text.190:
Aja (III) — a Rudra, and a son of Bhūta and Sarūpā.
Bhā. VI. 6. 17.
text.191:
Aja (IV) — the son of Raghu, and father of Daśaratha.
(Burnouf makes Aja, son of Pṛthuśravas. But Pṛthuśravas
here is an adjective of Raghu meaning — highly renowned).
Bhā. IX. 10. 1; Br. III. 63. 184; Vā. 88. 183: Vi. IV. 4. 85-6.
text.192:
Aja (V) — the son of Ūrdhvaketu and father of Purujit.
Bhā. IX. 13. 22.
text.194:
Aja (VII) — a son of Uttama Manu.
Br. II. 36. 39; Vā. 61. 185; 62. 9. 34; Vi. III. 1. 15.
text.195:
Aja (VIII) — a Kūṣmāṇḍa Piśāca, one of the two sons of
Kapī. Had a daughter Jantudhanā.
Br. III. 7. 74-85.
text.196:
Aja (IX) — an attribute of Kumāra.
Br. III. 10. 48.
text.198:
Aja (XI) — a horse of the chariot of the moon.
M. 126. 52.
text.199:
Aja and Ajā (XII) — the one god and goddess; mystery
of; Ajā, eight letters, sixteen hands, and feet, four faces,
three knots of hair, one horned goddess — Māyā.
Vā. 20. 28-29.
text.201:
Aja (XIV) — a division of the night.
Vā. 66. 43.
text.202:
Aja (XV) — the name of a Dānava.
Vā. 68. 11.
text.203:
Aja (XVI) — the name given to Dhanvantari when he
first appeared out of the churning of the ocean for nectar.
Vā. 92. 10.
text.204:
Ajaka (I) — a son of Balāka and father of Kuśa.
Bhā. IX. 15. 3-4.
text.205:
Ajaka (II) — the son of Sunaha (Suhotra-Vā. P.,
and Sumantu-Vi. P.) and father of Balākāśva;1 ruled for
21 years (31 ? Vā.).2 1) Br. III. 66. 30; 74-126; Vā. 91. 60-61; Vi. IV. 7. 8.
2) Vā.
99. 313.
text.207:
Ajakarṇa — a son of Maya.
Br. III. 6. 29.
text.209:
Ajagavam — the name of Siva's bow (also Ājagavam).
M. 23. 37; Vā. 90. 31.
text.210:
Ajatuṅga — a place fit for performing śrāddham, noted
for the tree Virajā;1 the shadow of gods seen at the place in
parvas; the Pāṇḍavas performed śrāddham at.2 1) Br. III. 13. 48.
2) Vā. 77. 48.
text.211:
Ajana (I) — the parent of Buddha. (Añjana-Burnouf).
Bhā. I. 3. 24.
text.212:
Ajana (II) — a name of Kṛṣṇa-Hari.
Bhā. X. 3. 1 & 5; 6. 23.
text.213:
Ajanābha (c) — the kingdom of Ṛṣabha, later known
as Bhārata.
Bhā. V. 4. 3; 7. 3; XI. 2. 24.
text.214:
Ajabasta — a pupil of Kṛta.
Br. II. 35. 52.
text.215:
Ajabhūḥ — one of the nine sons of Ugrasena.
M. 44. 75.
text.216:
Ajamīḍha (I) — a son of Hastin. Had three queens of
Kuru line; Priyamedhā and other Brāhmans belonged to his
family. Father of Kaṇva and Bṛhadiṣu.1 By Nalinī he had
a son Nīla.2 Ṛkṣa was another son of his.3 Sons born
through the grace of Bharadvāja.4 1) Bhā. IX. 21. 21-22; Vā. 99. 166; Vi. IV. 19. 29-30, 33;
M. 49. 43-5.
2) Bhā. IX. 21-30; Vā. 99. 194; Vi. IV. 19. 56.
3) Bhā. IX. 22. 3; M. 50. 19. Vi. IV. 19. 74.
4) Vā. 99. 169.
text.217:
Ajamīḍha (II) — an Aṅgirasa and mantrakṛt. A Kṣa
triya-dvija.
Br. II. 32. 109; III. 66. 87; M. 145. 103; Vā. 91. 116; 59. 100.
text.219:
Ajaya — the son of Darbhaka and father of Nandivar
dhana.
Bhā. XII. 1. 6, 7.
text.220:
Ajavīthi — on the back of the Śiśumāra (s.v.)1 the
southern course. Here are three kinds of sunrise, one in
mūla and the other two in two āṣāḍhas; on its south was
Pitṛyāna: consists of three constellations — mūla and āṣā-
ḍhas — pūrva and uttara.2 1) Bhā. V. 23. 5.
2) Br. II. 21. 76 & 159; III. 3. 51; M. 124.
53-8; Vā. 1. 93; 66. 51; Vi. II. 8. 85.
text.221:
Ajasya — a son of Aṅgiras and Surūpā: a gotrakara.
M. 196. 4.
text.222:
Ajā — born of Yaśodā — Māyā (s.v);1 the energy of the
Creator — through her, Hari is spoken of in nine forms.2 1) Bhā. X. 3. 47; 13. 52.
2) Ib., XI. 9. 28; XII. 11. 31.
text.223:
Ajākarṇa — a place fit for śrāddha offering.
M. 15. 33.
text.224:
Ajāta — one of the ten sons of Hṛdīka: Father of three
powerful sons: Sudamṣṭra, Sunābha and Kṛṣṇa.
M. 44. 82-4.
text.225:
Ajātaśatru (I) — the son of Vidhisāra and father of Dar
bhaka (Arbhaka-Vi. P.).
Bhā. XII. 1. 6; Vi. IV. 24. 14-15.
text.226:
Ajātaśatru (II) — the son of Bhūmimitra.1 His reign
lasted for 25 (27?) years.2 1) Vā. 99. 317.
2) Br. III. 74. 131; M. 272. 10.
text.228:
Ajāmukhas (also Adhomukhas) — a group of piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 381; Vā. 69. 263, 267.
text.229:
Ajāmila — an old itihāsa of. A Brāhmaṇa of Kanyā
kubja, versed in śāstras and celebrated in ācāra. Once
when out to get kuśa grass, he saw a dāsī and fell in love.
Then he abandoned all his duties and discarded his wedded
wife. The dāsī became his wife. She bore him ten sons.
The last was named Nārāyaṇa best loved of his parents. At
the time of his death, when the messengers of Yama were
waiting to remove him to hell, he called out his last son by
his name Nārāyaṇa. On this, the messengers of Vīṣṇu were
on the scene and prevented Yama's men from taking the
Brāhman to hell. It was argued that pronouncing the name
of Hari at his death redeemed him of all his sins, and that
alone was the secret of Dharma. Yama heard this and
approved it. Ajāmila, thus rescued from Death, felt peni
tent, and while making tapas at Gaṅgādvāra, he cast off his
body and reached Viṣṇuloka.
Bhā. VI. 1. 20. to the end; Ib. VI. ch. 2 & 3.
text.230:
Ajita (I) — a manifestation of Hari during the epoch of
Manu Cākṣuṣa. In this period the Kṣīroda was churned and
nectar was secured.1 Praised by Brahmā.2 Advised gods to
befriend Asuras and then get amṛta by churning the ocean,
with their co-operation, to be able ultimately to prevail
against them;3 began to take part in Amṛtamathana when
the efforts of others produced no results.4 1) Bhā. II. 2. 5; VIII. 5. 9-10.
2) Ib. VIII. 5. 25-50.
3) Ib. VIII.
6. 18-25.
4) Ib. VIII. 7. 16; X. 2. 20; X. 51. 48.
text.232:
Ajita (III) — the name of Hari born in Svārociṣa epoch
from Tuṣitā.
Br. III. 3. 114.
text.234:
Ajitā (II) — the mother of devas known as Ajitas.
Vā. 67. 33.
text.235:
Ajitas (I) — a group of gods with Āyuṣmanta formed
14 gaṇas whose residence was Maharloka. From there they
go to Janaloka.
Br. III. 4. 27; IV. 1. 122.
text.236:
Ajitas (II) — a devagaṇa;1 they are Asama, Ugradṛṣṭi,
Sunaya, Śuciśravas, Kevala, Viśvarūpa, Sudakṣa, Madhupa,
Turiya, Indrayuk.2 Remembered by Brahmā.3 1) Vā. 10. 21.
2) Br. II. 9. 46; 13. 90.
3) Vā. 31. 4.
text.237:
Ajitas (III) — sons of Ajita and Ruci in the Svāyam
bhuva Manvantara.
Vā. 67. 33.
text.238:
Ajina — a son of Havirdhāna.
Br. II. 37. 24; Vā. 63. 23; Vi. I. 14. 2.
text.239:
Ajimha — a Pārāvata god.
Br. II. 36. 13; Vā. 62. 12.
text.241:
Ajīgarta — a sage who sold his second son Śunaḥśepha
to Rohita to be sacrificed in his place.
Bhā. IX. 7. 20-21; IX. 16. 30.
text.242:
Ajeya — a Pārāvata god; also a Vaikuṇṭha god.
Br. II. 36. 14 and 57.
text.243:
Ajeśa — one of the eleven Rudras.
M. 153. 19.
text.244:
Ajaikapāt (I) — a Rudra, and a son of Bhūta and
Sarūpā; the Bhūta chieftain1 one of the eleven Rudras.2 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 18; Br. III. 3. 71; Vā. 66. 69.
2) M. 5. 29.
text.245:
Ajaikapāt (II) — the agni at Śālāmukhi; see Upastheya.
Br. II. 12. 25. Vā. 29. 24.
text.246:
Ajaikapāt (III) — a muhūrta of the night.
Br. III. 3. 42.
text.248:
Añjana (I) — the son of Irāvati, the elephant of golden
colour; belonging to the fold of Vāmadeva Sāma.
Br. III. 7. 292, 327 & 339.
text.250:
Añjana (III) — Mt. a hill west of the Sitoda;1 residence
of the Uragas;2 famous for elephant forests.3 1) Vā. 36. 28.
2) Vā. 39. 59.
3) Ib. 69. 238.
text.251:
Añjana (IV) — a son of Kṛti. Father of Kurujit.
Vi. IV. 5. 31.
text.252:
Añjanā — a daughter of Kuñjara and queen of Kesari.
Loved by Vāyu, gave birth to Hanumān.
Br. III. 7. 224-5.
text.253:
Añjanāvatī — born of Añjana (elephant); two sons —
Prathitāyu and Ajaḥ; pleasant looking and well-formed
animals.
Vā. 69. 227-28; Br. III. 7. 343-4.
text.257:
Añjali — a mode of worship with both hands. He who
worships a god by raising only one hand is liable to have that
hand cut off.
Bhā. X. 22. 19[1-3].
text.258:
Añjiṣṭha — a god of the Sutāra group.
Br. IV. 1. 89.
text.259:
Ajñānam — of tamas quality and the source of all dffi
culties; the enemy to knowledge; creates a thirst for desire
(rāga). If not got rid of, one attains Tiryak-yoni.
Br. IV. 3. 41 and 49; 4. 23. Vā. 102. 62, 69.
text.260:
Aṭamāna — the son of Meghasvāti and father of Aniṣṭa
karman.
Bhā. XII. 1. 24-25.
text.261:
Aṭṭahāsa^1 — the avatār of the Lord in the 20th dvāpara
when people are fond of aṭṭhāsa in the Aṭṭahāsa hill of the
Himālayas attended by Siddhas and Cāraṇas and yogins.
Vā. 23. 190-1.
text.262:
Aṭṭahāsa (II) — a Mt. in the Himalayas where was the
avatār of Aṭṭahāsa.
Vā. 23. 191.
text.263:
Aṭṭahāsa(m) — a tīrtham sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 68; Vā. 23. 191.
text.264:
Aṭṭahasī — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 88.
text.265:
Aṭṭālakas — generally frequented by evil spirits.
Br. III. 7. 405; IV. 21. 14.
text.266:
Aṇimā (I) — an aiśvarya, one of the eight kinds;1 the first
to be attained by the yogin;2 leading to siddhi.3 1) Br. I. 2. 39; II. 29. 82; III. 3. 65; 36. 17; 67. 16; Vā. 2. 39.
2) Vā. 13. 3 and 10.
3) Vā. 57. 76; 92. 15.
text.267:
Aṇimā (II) — Siddhi devī on the 9th parvan of Cakra
rājaratha; one of Uttama siddhis.
Br. IV. 19. 4; 25. 59; 35. 104; 36. 5; 44. 108.
text.268:
Aṇu — a measurement of time. Two aṇus make one
Paramāṇu.
Bhā. III. 11. 5.
text.269:
Aṇuha (I) — the son of Vibhrāja; wife Kīrtī, daughter
of Śuka; father of Brahmadatta.
Vi. IV. 19. 43-5.
text.270:
Aṇuha (II) — Satyaka? The eldest of Nīpa's sons;
married Kṛtvī, the daughter of Śuka; father of Brahma
datta.
Bhā. IX. 21. 24-25.
text.271:
Aṇuha (III) — Married Kīrtimati, daughter of Śuka.
Father of Brahmadatta.
Br. III. 8. 94; 10. 82; Vā. 73. 31.
text.272:
Aṇuha (IV) — son of Vibhrāja; married Kṛtvī, daughter
of Śuka. Husband of Ṛcī.
M. 49. 56-7; Vā. 99. 179.
text.273:
Aṇḍa — the egg shaped universe; the vyakta-rūpa of
Viṣṇu described. See also Puruṣa.
Vi. I. 2. 54-60.
text.274:
Aṇḍam — beyond Āloka. Here are the seven conti
nents and earth surrounded by a sea of clouds.1 The golden
egglike aṇḍa emerges from Īśvara's seed and attains yoni
(prakṛti), the latter being the embodiment of Nārāyaṇa, in
a period of a thousand years. It became heaven and earth,
ākāśa being in the middle.2
The outside is covered with waters ten times the aṇḍa —
covered by tejas, — successively covered by vāyu, by ākāśa,
this by Bhūtādi; that by mahat and that in turn by avyakta
each ten times the mass of its predecessor. These are the
seven Prakṛtis. Avyakta is kṣetra and Brahmā ksetrajña.3
Brahmā born of.4
Like the moon in Kumbha rāśi at the commencement
of the Śukla pakṣa; there are several aṇḍams, each covered
by seven characteristics of Prakṛti.5 1) Br. I. 1. 43f; II. 19. 154-5, 160; 21. 24; III. 59. 27; IV. 2.
230-1.
2) M. 2. 29-32; 247. 43; 248. 1.
3) Vā. 1. 50-52; 4. 82-9;
101. 227; Br. I. 3. 26.
4) Vā. 9. 122.
5) Vā. 49. 147-51.
text.275:
Aṇḍakaṭāha — consisting of Bhūrloka, Bhuvaḥ, Suvar,
Mahar, Jana, Tapa and Satya; all in the shape of an umbrella,
each covered by ten Prakṛtis more than the preceding.1 A
shell of egg encircling the dark regions beyond the Lokāloka;
encircled by water ten times the earth in space; waters
encompassed on the outer surface by fire, fire by air; air
by sky; sky by Anger of elements; and that by intellect; the
last girt by chief principle, Ananta.2 1) Vā. 50. 78-81.
2) Vi. II. 4. 95: 7. 22-5.
text.276:
Atala 1 — a thigh of the cosmic Puruṣa; is dependent on
the loins of the Puruṣa.2 An underworld, ruled by Bala, son
of Maya.3 The fourth world of pink (pīta) soil and resi
dence of daityas like Kālanemi.4 1) Bhā. II. 1. 27.
2) Ib. II. 5. 40.
3) Ib. V. 24. 7 & 16.
4) Br. II.
20. 12, 14, 32-34.
text.277:
Atalam — an underworld of dark earth; here is the
house of Namuci, the Indra of the Asuras besides those of
Śaṅkukarṇa, Nāgas, Rākṣasas, etc. White soil.
Vā. 50. 11, 13 and 15-19. Vi. II. 5. 2, 3.
text.278:
Atikapila — a son of Jyotiṣmat, after whom the kingdom
got its name.
Vi. II. 4. 36.
text.279:
Atikāya — a Rākṣasa who was killed in the war at
Laṅkā.
Bhā. IX. 10. 18.
text.280:
Atigulma — a son of Balarāma.
Br. III. 71. 167.
text.283:
Atitānam — the name of divine Gāndharvam sung by
Hāhā and Hūhū in Brahmaloka.
Vi. IV. 1. 68.
text.284:
Atithi (I) — the son of Kuśa, Ramā's son and father of
Niṣadha: a good looking monarch.
Bhā. IX. 12. 1; Br. III. 63. 201; M. 12. 52; Vā. 88. 201;
Vi. IV. 4. 105.
text.285:
Atithi (II) — a god of Ādya group.
Br. II. 36. 69.
text.286:
Atithi (III) — honouring the guest is a kind of yāga.1
An imperative duty of a householder;2 to be entertained in
śrāddhas.3 1) Br. III. 15. 8-20; 21. 46.
2) Vi. III. 9. 15; 11. 58-70; 78,
106-110; 15. 25.
3) Vā. 79. 7-19.
text.289:
Atitejas (Paulaha) — a sage of the epoch of the 3rd
Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 80.
text.290:
Atināmā — a Paulastya, and sage of the Cākṣuṣa epoch.
Br. II. 36. 78; M. 9. 23; Vi. III. 1. 28.
text.291:
Atibala (I) — a medicinal plant used in the first bathing
of a deity.
M. 267. 14.
text.292:
Atibala (II) — a king of the Gandharvas.
Vā. 62. 188.
text.294:
Atibhānu — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Satyabhāmā.
Bhā. X. 61. 10.
text.295:
Atibāhu — a son of Svāyambhuva Manu.
Vā. 31. 17.
text.297:
Atimāya — a son of Bhaṇḍa, and a commander.
Br. IV. 21. 84; 26. 49.
text.298:
Atiratha (Karṇa) — the son of Satyakarman, found a
son discarded by Pṛthā in a basket on the banks of the
Ganges.
Vi. IV. 18. 27-8.
text.299:
Atirātra (I) — a son of Cākṣuṣa Manu and Naḍvalā.
Bhā. IV. 13. 16; Br. II. 36. 79 & 106; M. 4. 42.
text.300:
Atirātra (II) — a son of Manu and Naḍvalā.
Vi. I. 13. 5.
text.301:
Atirātram — a sacred rite (yajña) produced by the
Creator.1 Done by Kaśyapa.2 Punarvasu born in the mid
dle of the ritual of Aśvamedha;3 fruit of, by honey gift in
ceremonies;4 from the face of Brahmā.5 1) Bhā. III. 12. 40; Vā. 9. 51; 62. 67 and 91; 67. 50.
2) Br. III.
5, 4; M. 44. 65; 58, 53.
3) Vā. 96. 119; Br. III. 71, 120.
4) Vā. 79. 11; Br. III. 15. 11.
5) Br. II. 8. 52; Vi. I. 5. 55.
text.302:
Ativibhūti: the son of Khaninetra and father of Karam
dhama.
Vi. IV. 1. 28-9.
text.306:
Atyākarālagojvālas (c) — a Janapada of the Ketumāla.
Vā. 44. 12.
text.309:
Atri (I) — a son of Brahmā, born of his eyes.1 Father
of Soma, born of his eyes.2 Married Anasūyā, a daughter
of Kardama (Dakṣa-Vā.). Their son was Dattātreya (s.v.).
Taught Ānvīkṣikī to Alarka, Praḥlāda and others.3 Paid a
visit to Bhīṣma who was in his death-bed.4 Came to see
Parīkṣit practising prāyopaveśa.5 A sage.6 Was engaged
with his wife in meditation at Mount Ṛkṣa by prāṇāyāma for
the birth of a son. His praise of Trimūrtis who appeared
before him, and blessed him with three glorious sons, being
their own amśas. Accordingly Datta (Viṣṇu), Durvāsas
(Śiva), and Soma (Brahmā) were born.7 Pointed out to
Pṛthu's son, Indra running away with the consecrated horse
twice and urged him to slay him.8 Had not yet seen
the Supreme Being.9 A sage of the Vaivasvata epoch.10
Went with Kṛṣṇa to Mithilā.11 The sage who presides
over the month of Śukra12 and Śuci.13 A mantrakāra:
took Uttānapāda as his son.14 Had a daughter, a Brahma
vādinī. Visited Paraśurāma engaged in austerities.15 Wor
shipped Pitṛs by śrāddha and relieved Soma of the disease
Rājayakṣma.16 Appointed by Brahmā for creation of the
world he performed the tapas called anuttama when Śiva
saw him: acted as hotā for Soma's Rājasūya:16(a Hermitage
in the Himalayas, visited by Purūravas:17 Praised Śiva out
to destroy Tripuram.18 1) Bhā. III. 12. 22 & 24; M. 3. 6; 9. 27.
2) Bhā. IX. 14. 2-3;
Br. III. 65. 1 & 47; Vā. 1. 138; 3. 3; 30. 48.
3) Bhā. I. 3. 11; III. 24.
22. Br. II. 9. 56.
4) Bhā. I. 9. 7.
5) Bhā. I. 19. 9.
6) Ib. II. 7. 4.
Vā. 90. 1-8.
7) Bhā. IV. 1. 15-33; Vi. IV. 6. 5-6.
8) Bhā.
IV. 19. 12-15 and 21.
9) Ib. IV. 29. 43.
10) Ib. VIII. 13. 5;
Br. II. 38. 25.
11) Bhā. X. 86. 18.
12) Ib. XII. 11. 35.
13) Br.
II. 23. 5. Vā. 52. 6. Vi. II. 10. 7; III. 1. 32.
14) Br. II. 27. 104;
32. 96 & 113.
15) Br. III. 23. 4.
16) Br. III. 10. 111; Vā. 73. 63;
16(a) M. 23. 2-20.
17) M. 102. 19; 118. 62 & 77; 120. 45; 126. 7.
18) M. 133. 67.
text.310:
Atri (II) — one of the sages who left for Piṇḍāraka.
Bhā. XI. 1. 12.
text.311:
Atri (III) — the third Prajāpati Of Svāyambhuva epoch,
created by Brahmā from ahaṃ tṛtīya.
Br. I. 1. 117; 5. 70; II. 9. 18, 23; Vā. 31. 16; 34. 62; 65. 45;
Vi. V. 1. 17.
text.313:
Atri (V) — born in Vāruṇī yajña from Agni's flames;1
Had ten beautiful and chaste wives, all daughters of Bha
drāśva and Ghṛtācī. His ten sons were all known as Ātre
yas,2 also Svastyātreyas; a mahaṛṣi and a mantrakṛt. Tra
yārṣeya with Vasiṣṭha and Jātūkarṇa: a contemporary of
Vṛddha Garga.3 One of the 18 writers on architecture.
Has a place in the Viśvacakra.4 1) Br. III. 1. 21 & 44; 8. 73; M. 171. 27; 192. 10; 195. 9;
Vā. 62. 17; 64. 27; Vi. I. 7. 5, 7.
2) Vā. 70. 67-76.
3) M. 145.
90, 107-9; 197. 1 & 4; 200. 19; 229. 2 & 3; Vā. 59. 104.
4) M. 252.
2; 285-6.
text.314:
Atri (VI) — the avatār of the Lord in the 12th dvāpara
in the Haimaka forest with sons with bath and ashes.
Vā. 23. 155.
text.315:
Atri (VII) — a son of Gautama, an avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 164.
text.316:
Atrighana — a special rite in the yajñas after the cele
brated sage Atri.
Vā. 70. 73.
text.317:
Atharvan (I) — married Śānti, a daughter of Kardama.
It was he who spread yajña in the world.1 His son was
Dadhyañca who had a horse's head.2 1) Bhā. III. 24. 24.
2) Ib. IV. 1. 42.
text.318:
Atharvan (II) — a Brāhman priest invited by Yudhiṣ
ṭhira to officiate in his Rājasūya sacrifice.
Bhā. X. 74. 9.
text.319:
Atharva Veda — one of the four Vedas useful for kings.1
Rearranged by Sumantu (s.v.) under the guidance of
Vyāsa; in five parts.2 Part of Viṣṇu.3 Mantras connected
with war.4 Twenty-one Atharvas from the face of Brahmā.5 1) Bhā., X. 53. 12; Vā. 9. 51; 60. 15, 20.
2) Bhā. I. 4. 22;
XII. 7. 1; Br. II. 34. 15; Vi. III. 4. 9 & 14; 6. 8, 13-14.
3) Vi. V.
1. 37.
4) Br. IV. 20. 104.
5) Br. II. 8. 53.
text.320:
Atharvāṅgiras — name of the Veda personified, as the
son of Prajāpati Aṅgiras and Sati:1 Praise of Soma.2 To
be uttered in founding a temple.3 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 19; Vā. 65. 98.
2) Br. III. 65. 12.
3) M. 265. 28.
text.321:
Atharvāṅgīrasī — taught by Vyāsa to Sumantu.
Bhā. XII. 6. 53.
text.322:
Atharvā — a Laukikāgni; is Bhṛgu; father of Darpahā.
Belongs to Dadhyaṅgātharvaṇa category.
Vā. 29. 8, 9; Br. II. 12, 9.
text.323:
Athārvikā — 5000+980 according to Ṛṣis like Aṅgīrasa.
Vā. 61. 72.
text.325:
Aditi (I) — a daughter of Dakṣa and a wife of Kaśyapa.1
Mother of Vāmana-Hari and other gods.2 Was much con
cerned at the evacuation of Amarāvati by gods, and informed
her husband of her grief. Kaśyapa consoled her saying that
it was all Hari's māyā and everything would be rectified by
His aid. Asked to the means of approaching Hari, Kaśyapa
taught her the Payovrata. Observed the vrata for twelve
days as directed. Hari heard her prayers, promised to be
born in her womb to protect her sons, and desired that she
should keep it a secret. She soon waited on Kaśyapa and
became pregnant with Hari. Then Hari was praised by
Brahmā.3 Birth of the Lord described.4 Changed before
her into a boy-brahmacārin.5 Worshipped for food and
other things, while her sons the Ādityas are prayed to for
attainment of heaven.6 Her desire was fulfilled by Vāmana.
Pleased with his anointing, gods sent their praises to Aditi
on the exploits of Vāmana.7 Kṛṣna took back the Kuṇḍalas
which had been taken away by Naraka, and Satyabhāmā
in her Lord's company bowed to Aditi and handed over the
Kuṇḍalas. At this Aditi embraced her daughter-in-law.8
Prajāpati caused the tejas of the aṇḍam in her garbha,
and removing it at the request of gods, made it into two
pieces, and finding it weak, placed it on the lap of the Sun
god (Mārtāṇḍa): given to dharma.9 A part of Mother Earth.10
A mother goddess.11 Worshipped in housebuilding.12
Mother of the 12 Ādityas the former Jayadevas.13 Known
for strength.14 1) Bhā. IX. 1. 10; VI. 6. 25; Br. II. 33. 17; III. 3. 56, 117;
71. 200; Vi. I. 15. 124; III. 1. 42.
2) Bhā. VIII. 13. 6; VI. 6.
38-39; VI. 18. 9; X. 3. 42; M. 172. 5; 178. 20; Vā., 96. 196;
97, 23.
3) Bhā. VIII. ch. 16 & 17.
4) Bhā. VIII. 18. 1-11;
Br. III. 72. 22; 73. 75.
5) Bhā. VIII. 18. 12.
6) Ib. VIII. 18. 13-19;
II. 3. 4; M. 171. 55-8.
7) Ib. VIII. 23. 4, 21, 27; M. 244. 9-48; 245. 63;
246. 58.
8) Bhā. X. 59. 38; Ib. [65 (v) 6-10]; Vi. V. 29. 11, 35;
30 (whole).
9) Br. III. 7. 277-94, 465.
10) Br. III. 71. 238; M. 6.
1. 5; 11. 2; 47. 9; 146. 18; 154. 351; 171. 29.
11) M. 179. 15.
12) M. 253. 27.
13) Br. III. 4. 34; Vā. 66. 55; 60. 65.
14) Vā. 69. 92.
Br. II. 13. 79.
text.326:
Aditi (II) — born of Dakṣa and son was Vivasvān.
Vi. IV. 1. 6.
text.327:
Adīna — a son of Sahadeva and father of Jayatsena; a
righteous soul.
Vā. 93. 10; Vi. IV. 9. 27.
text.328:
Adṛśyantī — the wife of Śakti, and mother of Parāśara.
Br. I. 2. 12; III. 8. 91; Vā. 2. 12; 70. 83.
text.329:
Adbhuta (I) — the name of Indra of the 9th manvan
tara of the Rohita epoch.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 19-20; Br. IV. 1. 61; Vi. III. 2. 22.
text.330:
Adbhuta (II) — the son of Savanāgni (Sahasa-Br.) and
father of Vividha.
Vā. 29. 38; Br. II. 12. 41.
text.333:
Adrikā — an apsaras with whom Amāvasu sported.1
Living in the Acchoda lake.2 1) Br. III. 7. 7; 10. 57 & 68.
2) Vā. 69. 6; 73. 3.
text.335:
Adharma (I) — a son of Brahmā, born of his back.1 Had
for his wife Mrṣā.2 Three chief characteristics — pride,
luxury and intoxication.3 His son was Dambha and
daughter Māyā, both of whom were adopted later on by the
childless Nirṛti.4 Five branches of: vidharma, paradharma,
ābhāsa, upamā, and chala.5 1) Bhā. III. 12. 25.
2) Ib. IV. 8. 2.
3) Ib. I. 17. 24.
4) Ib. IV.
8. 2.
5) Ib. VII. 15. 12-14.
text.336:
Adharma (II) — wife, Himsā; sons Nikṛti, Anṛta.
(daughter Nikṛtī-Vi. P.).
Br. II. 9. 63; Vā. 10. 39; Vi. I. 7. 32.
text.338:
Adhaśśiras — the name of a hell: also Adhomukham.
He who receives bad gifts and from forbidden persons, who
lives by astrology and those who do not request for sacrifice
go to it.
Br. IV. 2. 148 & 163; Vā. 101. 147, 161; Vi. II. 6, 4 & 18.
text.339:
Adhidānta — a son of Hṛdīka.
Br. III. 71. 141.
text.340:
Adhipati — a son of Bhṛgu, and a deva.
Br. III. 1. 90; Vā. 65. 87.
text.341:
Adhipūruṣa — the title earned by Svāyambhuva Manu
for his great character.
M. 3. 45.
text.342:
Adhimāsa — the intercalary month;1 fit for piṇḍa at
Gayā.2 1) Vā. 50. 201.
2) Vā. 83. 42; 105. 18.
text.343:
Adhiratha — the son of Satkarman (Satyakarman-M.).
Once playing on the banks of the Ganges, he found a male
child in a box. It was born of Kunti and abandoned by
her. Childless, he brought him up as his son;1 also known
as Sūta.2 1) Bhā. IX. 23. 12-13.
2) M. 48. 108.
text.344:
Adhirāja — in Rājasūya, Pṛthu was anointed as.
Br. III. 8. 25.
text.345:
Adhivāsanam (also Adhivāsam) [See Pratimā] — preli
minary purification in connection with founding a new
temple.
M. 265. 49 & 52; 266. 1; 274. 57; 275. 3; 289. 11.
text.346:
Adhisā(ī)makṛṣṇa — the son of Aśvamedhādatta. A
great warrior ruling now — (sāmprataḥ) — Performed a long
yajña extending over three years at Kurukṣetra on the
Dṛṣadvatī; a Paurava; father of Nicaknu.
Vā. 99. 258, 270; Vi. IV. 21. 6-7.
text.347:
Adhisomakṛṣṇa — the son of Śatānīka — ‘the king now
ruling’: performed three great sacrifices — one for three
years at Puṣkara, the other two of two years' duration at
Kurukṣetra and Dṛṣadvatī respectively-Father of Vivikṣu.
M. 50. 66, 78.
text.348:
Adhīti — a son of Brahmā with Mantraśarīra.
Vā. 67. 6.
text.349:
Adhīṣṭa — a son of Brahmā with Mantraśarīra.
Vā. 67. 6.
text.350:
Adhṛti — a god of Ābhūtarayas group.
Br. II. 36. 55.
text.352:
Adhyavasāya — one of the two vṛttis of Mahat.
Vā. 4. 46.
text.353:
Adhvani — a son of Āpa.
Vi. I. 15. 111.
text.354:
Adhvara — an yajña; fires in, described.
Vā. 29. 41.
text.355:
Adhvaryu — one of the 16 Ṛtviks for an yajña, issued
from the arms of Nārāyaṇa of Paraśurāma's sacrifice, was
presented with the whole of the west:1 Bhṛgu was
Adhvaryu at Soma's Rājasūya.2 1) Bhā. IX. 11. 2; 16. 21; M. 167. 7; 265. 26.
2) M. 23. 20.
text.356:
Anagha (I) — the son of Upadānavī: The Vaibhrāja
king of Pāñcāla: Father of Brahmadatta.
M. 21. 11.
text.359:
Anagha (IV) — a son of Ūrja and Vasiṣṭha; a sage of
XIth epoch of Manu.
Vi. I. 10. 13: III. 2. 31.
text.360:
Anaghā — a R. of Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 26.
text.362:
Anaṅga (II) — another name of God of Love, after he
was burnt to ashes by Śiva.
M. 7. 23; 23. 30; 154. 272; 291. 32; Vā. 104. 48.
text.363:
Anaṅgadānavratam — sacred to Hari: to be begun on
Sunday when the star Hasta, Puṣya or Punarvasu was in
the ascendant: duration being 13 months: originally com
municated by Indra.
M. 70. 33-62.
text.364:
Anaṅgamadanā — a śakti devī on the 7th parvan of the
Cakrarājaratha.
Br. IV. 19. 25; 44, 124.
text.365:
Anaṅgamadanāturā — a śakti on the 7th parvan of the
Cakrarājaratha.
Br. IV. 19. 25; 44, 124.
text.366:
Anaṅgamālinī — a śakti devī on the 7th parvan of the
Cakrarājaratha.
Br. IV. 19. 26.
text.369:
Anaṅgalekhā — a śakti devī on the 7th parva of Cakra
rājaratha.
Br. IV. 19. 25.
text.370:
Anaṅgavatī — the courtesan who observed the Vibhūti-
dvādaśī-vratam and became Prītī, the co-wife with Rati, to
the Lord of Love in her next birth.
M. 100. 18 & 32.
text.371:
Anaṅgavegi — a śakti devī on the 7th parva of Cakrarāja
ratha.
Br. IV. 19. 25.
text.372:
Anaṅgā — was the Apsaras sent by Indra to ruin Hari's
tapas.
M. 61. 22.
text.373:
Anaṅgākuśā — a śakti devī on the 7th parva of Cakra
rājaratha.
Br. IV. 19. 25; 44. 125.
text.375:
Ananta (I) — the Tāmasī Kalā of Hari. Followers of
Sātvata Tantra designate him Saṅkarṣaṇa. He bears the
Earth on one of his 1000 hoods. From between his agitated
brows came out Rudra exhibiting in eleven forms. The
Nāga princes make obeisance to him for his blessings. He
wears the Vaijayantī garland. His glory is sung by Nārada
and Tumburu in the court of the Creator. Also known as
Śeṣa.1 Identified with Balarāma, the seventh son of Devakī.2
At the time of the deluge, withdraws the universe unto him
self.3 Identified with Hari;4 a Nāga;5 ety. of;6 Balarāma, an
incarnation of.7 1) Bhā III. 26. 25; IV. 9. 14; V. 25. 1-11; VII. 7. 10-11;
Vi. II. 5. 13-27; V. 18. 54.
2) Bhā. X. 1. 24; 2. 5.
3) Ib. X.
68. 46.
4) Ib. XI. 16. 19.
5) Br. IV. 20. 53.
6) M. 248. 38.
7) Vi.
V. 25. 3; 35. 3; Bhā. I. 14. 35.
text.377:
Ananta (III) — a king and the son of Vītihotra (Vīra
hotra-Vā. P.). Father of Durjaya.
Br. III. 69. 53; Vā. 94. 53.
text.380:
Anantaśayanam — a manifestation of Hari, as reposing
on Śeṣa.
M. 276. 8.
text.381:
Anantā — the wife of Svāyambhuva Manu.
M. 4. 33.
text.383:
Anapāna (II) — the son of Aṅga and father of Diviratha.
Vi. IV. 18. 15; Br. III. 74. 103.
text.385:
Anamitra (I) — a son of Yudhājit. Father of Nimna,
and Śini. A third son was Vṛṣṇi.
Bhā. IX. 24. 12-14; Br. III. 71. 20.
text.386:
Anamitra (II) — a son of Nighna: went to the forest
for penance.
M. 12. 47-8.
text.387:
Anamitra (III) — the youngest son of Mādrī and Vṛṣṇi
(Sumitra-Vi. P.). Father of Nighna, Śini, (Chini-Vā. P.)
Yudhājit, Vṛṣabha and Kṣetra.
M. 45. 2-3, 22 & 25; Vā. 96. 99; Vi. IV. 13. 9; 14. 1.
text.388:
Anamitra (IV) — a son of Mādrī.
Vā. 96. 19; Br. I. 1. 123.
text.389:
Anarakam — a Kṣetram in the Narmaḍā. After a bath
here, there is no need to fear a hell.
M. 193. 1-3; 194. 17.
text.390:
Anaraṇya (I) — the son of Trasaddasyu and father of
Haryaśva (Pṛṣadaśva-Vi. P.); killed by Rāvaṇa in his dig-
vijaya.
Bhā. IX. 7. 4; Vi. IV. 3. 17-18.
text.391:
Anaraṇya (II) — the son of Sambhūta, killed by Rāvaṇa.
Br. III. 63. 74; Vā. 88. 75-6.
text.394:
Anarvan — a follower of Vṛtra in his battle with Indra.
Bhā., VI. 10. 19, 31.
text.395:
Anala (I) — a Vasava, (Tejas) has a son Kumāra
through Svāhā. Śākha, Viśākha, and Naigameya were other
sons (see Agni). Married Śivā, daughter of Hari and had two
sons born with qualities of fire. Father of Skanda and
Sanatkumāra.
Br. III. 3. 21; M. 5. 21-5; 203. 3; Vi. I. 15. 110, 115;
Vā. 66. 20, 24.
text.397:
Anala (III) — a hill of the Rākṣasas.
Vā. 39. 53.
text.398:
Anala (IV) (Agni) — one became threefold at the
instance of Purūravas;1 the presiding deity of svarṇa or
gold;2 different kinds of;3 five kinds of, overcome by Kṛṣṇa
in Bāṇa's war.4 1) Vi. IV. 6. 94.
2) Vi. V. 1. 14.
3) Vā 53. 5.
4) Vi. V. 33. 20.
text.399:
Anala (V) — the son of Niṣadha and father of Nabhas.
Vi. IV. 4. 106.
text.401:
Anavama (Bahava — s.v) — son of Cakora and father of
Śivasvāti.
Bhā. XII. 1. 26.
text.403:
Anasūya — a Kaśyapa and a Trayārṣeya.
M. 199. 12.
text.404:
Anasūyā — the wife of the sage Atri (s.v.) and a daughter
of Kardama (Dakṣa-Vā. P. and Vi. P.). Mother of Datta,
Durvāsas, and Soma;1 mother of five Ātreyas and a daughter
Śruti.2 1) Bhā. I. 3. 11; III. 24: 22; IV. 1. 15; Vi. I. 7, 7, 25.
2) Vā.
10. 28, 31; 28. 18-9; Br. II. 9. 52 and 56; 11. 22.
text.405:
Anādṛṣṭa — a rājaṛṣi; a brother of Vasudeva.
Vā: 96. 148; Vā. 99. 127.
text.407:
Anādhṛṣṭi — a son of Śūra and Bhojā.
Br. III. 71. 149 and 189; M. 46. 3.
text.408:
Anāyu — a daughter of Dakṣa: a consort of Kaśyapa,
and a mother goddess. Fond of eating.
Br. III. 3. 56; 7. 468; M. 171. 29.
text.409:
Anāyuṣā — Had Araru and other four sons;1 mother of
diseases.2 1) Br. III. 6. 30.
2) M. 171. 59.
text.410:
Anāśakaphalam — a bath in the prescribed manner for
a month in the Pryāga; attained by (oneness with god
head).
M. 108. 2 & 14.
text.411:
Anāhitāgni — those who do not perform yajñas, as
opposed to agnihotrins.
Vā. 30. 6.
text.412:
Aniruddha (I) — One of the four forms of Hari.1 In
voked as a principal divinity. Source of all sounds (śabda-
yoni); presiding over the mind as fourth in order.2 The
supreme ruler of all senses.3 Created specially in the battle
of Lalitā with Bhaṇḍa.4 1) Bhā. 1. 5. 37; Vi. 16. 18; X. 16. 45; 40. 21; XII.
11. 21. M. 276. 9.
2) Bhā. III. 1. 34.
3) Ib. III. 26. 28; IV. 24. 36.
4) Br. IV. 29. 128.
text.413:
Aniruddha (II) — the son of Pradyumna and Rukma
vati; carried away by air by Citralekhā, to the harem of
the daughter of Baṇā at her instance. For him Bāṇa had
his arms reduced from thousand to two. Married Rocanā,
grand-daughter of Rukmin at Bhojakaṭa to which Kṛṣṇa,
Balarāma and others went. Came back to Dvārakā with
his newly wedded wife.1 Seen in a dream by Uṣā. Picture
of him drawn by Citralekhā, who made him enjoy Uṣā's
company at Śoṇitapura. Bāṇa came to know of this and
imprisoned him to the great regret of his daughter.2 Nārada
communicated the news of Aniruddha's imprisonment to
Kṛṣṇa and Vṛṣṇis. These departed to Śoṇitapura, beseiged
it, and humbled the pride of Bāṇa. The latter agreed to
set Aniruddha free and allow him to marry his daughter.
Left for Dvārakā with Uṣa.3 Famous for his speed in battle.4
Unable to recover the dead child of the Dvārakā Brāḥmaṇa.5
Father of Vajra.6 Went to Syamantapañcaka for solar
eclipse.7 Fought with Sātyaki at Prabhāsā.8 One of the
five vamśavīras.9 Mṛgaketana was a son of his: an authority
on architecture.10 1) Bhā. X. 61. 18. 23[9], 25-26 & 40.
2) Ib. X. 62. 12. 20-27, and 35.
3) Ib. X. ch. 63 (whole).
4) Ib. I. 14. 30.
5) Ib. X. 89. 31 and 41.
6) Ib. X. 90. 33, 36-7.
7) Ib. X. 82. 7.
8) Ib. XI. 30, 16.
9) Br. III. 72. 2.
10) M. 47. 23;
93. 51; 248. 49; 252. 3.
text.415:
Anila (I) — The God of Wind invoked.1 A surname of
Vāyu;2 father of Bhīmasena.3 1) Bhā. III. 6. 16.
2) Br. II. 25. 12.
3) Vi. IV. 14. 35;
Bhā. IX. 22. 27.
text.416:
Anila (II) — a Vāsava: married Śivā and had two sons
— Manojava and Avijñatagati. See Iśāna.
Br. II. 10. 80; III. 3. 21; M. 5. 21; 203. 3; Vā. 66. 20, 25;
Vi. I. 15. 110, 114.
text.417:
Anila (III) — The Vāyu Purāṇa narrated by Wind-god
with samāsa bandhas and rhythm;1 23,000 stanzas.2 1) Vā. 3. 8.
2) Vā. 104. 7.
text.418:
Anila (IV) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Mitravindā.
Bhā. X. 61. 16.
text.419:
Aniṣṭakarman — son of Aṭamāna and father of Hāleya.
Bhā. XII. 1. 25.
text.420:
Anīka — a son of first Sāvarṇa Manu
Br. IV. 1. 65.
text.421:
Anīkavān — a son of Arka Agni.
Vā. 29. 40; Br. II. 12. 43.
text.422:
Anīcakam — the continent lying round Śyāma hill.
M. 122. 23.
text.423:
Anīha — a son of Devānīka and father of Pāriyātra.
Bhā. IX. 12. 2.
text.424:
Anu (I) — a son of Svāyambhuva Manu. Knows the
power of the yoga of Hari.
Bhā. II. 7. 44.
text.425:
Anu (II) — a son of Yayāti and Śarmiṣṭhā. Refused to
part with his youth to his father.1 Became overlord of the
north part of the kingdom.2 Had three sons Sabhānara, Cakṣu
and Parākṣa.3 Cursed to die in youth suffering from
diarrhoea. Originator of several mleccha groups.4 1) Bhā. IX. 18. 33 & 41; Br. I. 1. 133; III. 68. 16-17, 51-79;
IV. M. 24. 54; 32. 10; Vi. IV. 10. 10-15.
2) Bhā. IX. 19. 22. Br. III.
68. 90; 73. 126; Vā. I. 156: 93. 17; Vi. IV. 10. 32.
3) Bhā. IX. 23.
1; Br. III. 74. 12; M. 48-10:
4) M. 33. 21-24; 34. 30.
text.426:
Anu (III) — the son of Kuruvaśa (Kuravaśa-Burnouf)
and father of Puruhotra.
Bhā. IX. 24. 5-6.
text.427:
Anu (IV) — the son of Kapotaroman and father of An
dhaka. His friend was Tumburu.
Bhā. IX. 24. 20.
text.428:
Anu (V) — (alias Vaina) a pupil of Laugākṣi.
Br. II. 35. 41.
text.429:
Anu (VI) — the son of Kumāravamśa and father of Puru
mitra.
Vi. IV. 12. 42.
text.430:
Anu (VII) — a son of Viloma and friend of Tumburu
and father of Ānakadundubhi.
Vi. IV. 14. 13-14.
text.431:
Anu (VIII) — the son of Yadu and father of three sons.
Vi. IV. 18. 1.
text.433:
Anugaṅgāprayāga(c) — lie of territory under the
Nāgas1 and the Guptas.2 1) Br. III. 74. 194.
2) Vā. 99. 383.
text.434:
Anugraha Sarga — divided into four, viparyaya, śakti,
tuṣṭi, and siddhi; accounts for vivṛtta, and the varttamāna
(present) in cycle; this is the fifth sarga or creation.
Vā. 6. 57, 67-9; 9. 117.
text.436:
Anucara — a god of the Haritagaṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 84.
text.437:
Anujīvins — officials (lit. dependents on the king) — rules
for the personal conduct of.
M. 216. 1-38.
text.438:
Anutaptā (I) — another name for R. Sukumārī of Śāka
dvīpa.
Vā. 49. 91.
text.439:
Anutaptā (II) — a R. in the Plakṣadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 19; Vā. 49. 17; Vi. II. 4. 11.
text.440:
Anutāpana — one of the 61 sons of Danu.
Bhā. VI. 6. 31.
text.441:
Anuttamam — the name of the tapas performed by
Atri (s.v.) for creation.
M. 23. 2.
text.443:
Anupadeva — a son of Akrūra and Ugrasenī.
Vā. 96. 112.
text.444:
Anuparvatam — the forest noted for padma class of
elephants between the Lauhitya and Sindhu; the name of
Yamavanam (s.v.).
Br. III. 7. 359; Vā. 69. 241.
text.445:
Anupālikā — a daughter of Vākā.
Br. III. 8. 56.
text.448:
Anumati (I) — a daughter of Śraddhā and Aṅgīras.1
Wife of Dhātā and mother of Pūrṇimā.2 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 34.
2) Ib. VI. 18. 3.
text.449:
Anumati (II) — a R. in Śālmalidvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 10.
text.450:
Anumati (III) — a śakti devī on the Ṣoḍaśapatrābja.
Br. IV. 32. 12.
text.451:
Anumati (IV) — a time in the evening of Pratipada com
prising two lavas.1 The day when one digit of the moon
is deficient, fit for making gifts.2 1) M. 133. 36; 141. 33, 40 and 51; Vā. 56. 35, 55.
2) Vi. II.
8. 80.
text.453:
Anumati (VI) — a daughter of Smṛti and Aṅgiras;1 the
name of the first pūrṇimā.2 1) Vā. 28. 15; Vi. I. 10. 7.
2) Vā. 50. 201; Br. II. 11. 18.
text.454:
Anumantā — a god of Ādya group:1 a śādhya.2 1) Br. II. 36. 69; III. 3. 16.
2) Vā. 66. 15.
text.456:
Anumlocā (I) — resides in the sun's chariot during the
month of Bhādrapada.
Vi. II. 10. 10.
text.457:
Anumlocā (II) — The apsaras presiding over the month
Nabhasya. (nabho-nabha).
Bhā. XII. 11. 38; Br. II. 23. 10; III. 7. 15.
text.459:
Anurūpamāya — a Vasu, and a son of Dharma and
Sudevī.
M. 171. 47.
text.462:
Anuvatsara — the fourth year in a five year yuga;1 is
Vāyu.2 (Yajur samhitā) ahorātrakara.3 1) Bhā. III. 11. 14; V. 22. 7; Vi. II. 8. 72.
2) Br. II. 13. 115, 119,
134; 21. 134; 28. 22; M. 141. 18; Vā. 31. 31.
3) Vā. 31.
27; 56. 20; 50. 183; Br. II. 13. 134.
text.463:
Anuvaṃśa — Devāvṛdha and his son Babhru belonged to
this line.
M. 44. 57.
text.464:
Anuvaha — the chief of the 6th vātaskandha, situated
between the planets and the Saptaṛṣimaṇḍala.
Br. III. 5. 87.
text.465:
Anuvinda — a prince of Avanti. Brother of Vinda and
and Mitravindā: Shared Vinda's (s.v) views and did not
wish his sister to be married to Kṛṣṇa as against Duryo
dhana.1 Stationed at the south gate of Mathurā by Jarā
sandhā,2 and also on the south during the seige of Gomanta.3
Son of Rājadhidevī according to the Bhāgavata.4 1) Bhā. X. 58. 30; Br. III. 71. 158.
2) Bhā. X. 50. 11[3].
3) Ib. X. 52. 11[9].
4) Ib. X. 58. 31; Vā. 96. 157; Vi. IV. 14. 43.
text.466:
Anuvṛttā — a daughter of Rṣā (Rṣi-Vā. P.); gave birth to
the class of maṇdūkas, aineya and śambaka varieties.
Br. III. 7. 414 and 418; Vā. 69. 291, 295.
text.468:
Anuvrata (II) — the son of Kṣema, ruled for 64 years.
M. 271. 25.
text.469:
Anuvratas — a class of people in Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 27.
text.470:
Anuṣaṅga — the one after sṛṣṭisarga; the second pāda of
the purāṇa;1 equal to Tretā; of 3000;2 ends with the 99th
chapter of the Vāyu.3 1) Br. I. 1. 39; II. 31. 127; III. 1. 1; IV. 4. 43; Vā. 4. 13; 65.
1-2.
2) Vā. 32. 61; Vā. 58. 126; 103. 44.
3) Vā. 100. 2.
text.471:
Anuṣṭub — a poetic metre;1 a horse yoked to the sun's
chariot;2 from the fourth face of Brahmā.3 1) Bhā. XI. 21. 41; Vā. 9. 52.
2) Vā. 51. 64; Br. II. 22. 72;
M. 125. 47; Vi. II. 8. 5.
3) Br. II. 8. 53. Vi. I. 5. 56.
text.472:
Anuhl(r)āda — a son of Kayādhu and Hiraṇyakaśipu;
wife Sūrmyā. Father of Bāṣkala and Mahīṣa;1 also of Vāyu
and Sinīvāli from whom the hālāhala gaṇa came;2 as asura
of the Vitalam. His daughter was married by Rajatanābha,
the yakṣa.3 1) Bhā. VI. 18. 13, 16: Br. III. 5. 33.
2) M. 6. 9; Vā. 67. 70,
75; Vi. I. 15. 142.
3) Br. II. 20. 26; III. 7. 119; Vā. 50. 25.
text.473:
Anūpa(c) — the kingdom got by Sūta from Pṛthu.
The people were Anūpas, a Vindhya tribe.
Br. II. 36. 172; 16. 65; Vā. 62. 147.
text.474:
Anūru — (Aruṇa) a son of Tārkṣya and Kadrū. Cha
rioteer of the sun.
Bhā. VI. 6. 22.
text.475:
Anṛtam (as opposite to satyam) when falsehood is tole
rated.1 Bali shrinks from it.2 No pātaka on five occasions:
Jest or fun, speaking to women, for a marriage, when life
is in danger, and when deprived of his wealth.3 1) Bhā. VIII. 19. 38-43.
2) Ib. VIII. 20. 2-5.
3) M. 31. 16.
text.476:
Anṛtam — son of Himsā and Adharma; father of Bhaya
and Naraka.
Br. II. 9. 63; Vā. 10. 39.
text.477:
Aneka — a son of Raucya Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 104.
text.478:
Anekakṣatrabaddha — a son of Raucya Manu.
Vā. 100. 109.
text.480:
Anenas (I) — the son of Kakustha (Paurañjaya-Bhā.)
of Pṛthu.
Bhā. IX. 6. 20; Br. III. 63. 26; Vā. 88. 25; Vi. IV. 2. 33.
text.481:
Anenas (II) — a son of Āyu and father of Śuddha.
Bhā. IX. 17. 2 and 11; Br. III. 67. 2; Vi. IV. 8. 3.
text.483:
Anaupamyā — the wife of Bāṇāsura. Illtreated by
mother-in-law and sister-in-law she was initiated into a
mantra by Nārada to control them and to be ever pleasing
to her husband. By this she left the strict path of chastity;
offered gifts to the sage who refused them on the plea of
his plenty.
M. 187. 25-52.
text.485:
Antaka (I) — surname of Yama: milkman of Pitṛs on
the earth: ety.
Bhā. VI. 10. 15; Br. II. 36. 209; M. 10. 19; 213. 6.
text.486:
Antaka (II) — a surname of Śiva.
Br. III. 3. 81.
text.487:
Antaka (III) — a son of Vasumitra, ruled for 2 years.
M. 272. 29.
text.488:
Antakāri — the tāmasic aspect of Svayambhū.
Vā. 66. 103.
text.489:
Antakāla — prescriptions for;1 yogic methods laid
down.2 1) Bhā. II. 1. 15-21;
2) Ib. H. 2. 14-23.
text.490:
Antara — the son of Pṛthuśravas; in previous births the
son of Yājña; also called Uśanas, performed 100 horse
sacrifices as king.
Vā. 95. 22, 23.
text.491:
Antarakṣaya — reference to the deluge in the Cākṣusa
antara.
M. 2. 1 and 14.
text.492:
Antaranarmadā (c) — a western country; Narmada
tribes.
Br. II. 16. 61; M. 140. 50.
text.494:
Antarikṣa (I) — a son of Ṛṣabha and Jayanti. Brother
of Bharata. A bhāgavata and sage;1 expounded to Nimi the
nature of Māyā and mentions how the pure jñāna shines as
threefold by the work of illusion.2 1) Bhā. V. 4. 11; XI. 2. 21.
2) Ib. XI. 3. 2[1-4]-16.
text.495:
Antarikṣa (II) — a son of Mura (s.v.) who went to the
field to attack Kṛṣṇa who caused the death of his father.
Bhā. X. 59. 12.
text.496:
Antarikṣa (III) — the son of Puṣkara and father of
Sutapas.
Bhā. IX. 12. 12.
text.497:
Antarikṣa (IV) — the 13th Veda Vyāsa:1 Heard the
Purāṇa from Triviṣṭa, and narrated it to Trayyāruṇi2 (Carṣi
Vā. P.) 1) Br. II. 35. 120. Vi. III. 3. 14.
2) Br. IV. 4. 62; Vā. 103. 61.
text.498:
Antari(ī)kṣa (V) — an Ādya god; a devagaṇa.
Br. II. 36. 69; Vā. 62. 59.
text.499:
Antarikṣa (VI) — the son of Kinnarāśva (Kinnara-Vā.
P.); and father of Suparṇa (Suṣeṇa — M. P.).
M. 271. 9; Vā. 99. 285; Vi. IV. 22. 5.
text.500:
Antarikṣam — the Bhuvarloka or the region between
earth and heaven.1 One account is that Yayāti made this
his abode when he was sent away from heaven;2 to be pro
pitiated as a deity in palace building.3 1) Vā. 23. 107; 24. 18; 30. 98; 47. 29; 64. 10; 101. 19;
110. 49.
2) M. 35. 4; 38. 20; 39. 11; 41. 8 & 10.
3) Ib. 268. 12.
text.502:
Antargiribahirgiras — Peoples of an eastern country.
Br. II. 16. 53; Vā. 45. 122.
text.503:
Antardhāna (I) — a surname of Vijitāśva (s.v.); got
from Indra the power of moving about, unseen by others.
Bhā. IV. 24. 5.
text.504:
Antardhāna (II) (Antarddhi) — A son of Pṛthu; wife
Śikhaṇḍinī: father of Havirdhāna, and Mārīca.
Br. II. 37. 23; M. 4. 45; Vā. 63. 22; Vi. I. 14. 1.
text.505:
Antaśilā — R. originating from the Vindhyas.
Vā. 45. 103.
text.507:
Antaḥpurādhyakṣa — Superintendent of the harem and
his qualification.
M. 215. 42; 216. 9.
text.510:
Antināra (I) — the son of Jvalanā and Auceya; wife
Manasvinī. Father of two sons and a daughter Gaurī,
mother of Māndhatṛ.
M. 49. 7-8.
text.511:
Antināra (II) — the son of Ṛteṣu and father of three
sons, Sumati and others.
Vi. IV. 19. 3-4.
text.512:
Antya — a son of Bhṛgu, and a deva.
Br. III. 1. 89.
text.513:
Antya(Janmanā) — members of the fourth caste: home
of.
M. 207. 19; 227. 54; 255. 14.
text.514:
Antyajas — to follow the vṛtti of their ancestors. Also
known Antevasāyins:1 a low caste to be abandoned:2 also
Antyayoni.3 1) Bhā. VII. 11. 30; 14. 11.
2) Br. IV. 7. 3, 8, 19 and 67;
8. 10.
3) Ib. II. 31. 40.
text.517:
Andhaka (I) — a son of Sātvata [Sātvatī (Kausalya)]:
suspected Kṛṣṇa of having taken away Syamantaka.1 A
mahābhoja who married the daughter of Kaṅka and was
father of four sons, Kukura and others.2 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 6; Br. III. 71. 1. 36, 53; Vā. 96. 2; Vi. IV.
13. 1.
2) M. 44. 48-61; Vi. IV. 14. 12.
text.518:
Andhaka (II) — son of Anu and father of Dundubhi.
Bhā. IX. 24. 20.
text.519:
Andhaka (III) — a son of Viloma, and a friend of Tum
buru: also known as Danodakadundubhi.
Br. III. 71. 118.
text.520:
Andhaka (IV) — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 82.
text.521:
Andhaka (V) — the 8th among twelve incarnations,
after the battle of that name. Here Trayambaka slew thou
sands of Asuras:1 in the Varāha Kalpa.2 1) M. 47. 44-50.
2) Vā. 97. 75.
text.522:
Andhaka (VI) — the asura killed by Śiva: Āḍi and Baka
were his sons; attempted to abduct the Devī in the presence
of Śiva in the Mahākālavana of Avanti. Smitten by Pāśu
pata, blood came out of his body, out of which were born
numberless Andhakas (s.v.) who overpowered Rudra. The
latter created a number of Mātṛs who were not enough to
meet them. Vāsudeva was thought of, and he created one
Śuṣkarevati who drank off the blood of Andhakas. On his
submission he was admitted to the group of Gaṇeśas.
M. 55. 16; 156. 11-12; 179. 2-40; 252. 5-19.
text.523:
Andhaka (VII) — an elder Yādava advised in the
council to secure the return of Akrūra; it was adopted.
Vi. IV. 13. 114-137.
text.524:
Andhakas (I) — a community of the Yādava tribe1
defending Dvārakā; at Dvāravatī their overlord was Ugra
sena.2 Praise the heroic deeds of Hari.3 Relieved by
Kamsa's death.4 Ended their lives by fighting their kins
men.5 Kṛṣṇa, an Andhaka.6 Kingdom of.7 Their line;8
fetch Balarāma and Kṛṣṇa to Dvāraka.9 1) Bhā. I. 11. 11; 14. 25; II. 4. 20; Vā. 86. 28.
2) Bhā. X. 1. 69;
39. 25; 45, 15.
3) Bhā. IX. 24. 63.
4) Ib. X. 45. 15.
5) Ib. XI. 29. 39; 30.
18.
6) Br. III. 61. 23; 71. 85 & 143-144.
7) M. 114. 36.
8) M. 44.
61. 85; 47. 33.
9) Vā. 96. 84.
text.525:
Andhakas (II) — the Asuras born of the blood of
Andhaka Asura, hit by the pāśupata of Rudra. To counter
act their evil propensities Rudra created a number of Mātṛs
who could not bring about the desired effect. Hence Vāsu
deva created a Śuṣkarevatī who brought about their des
truction by drinking off their blood.
M. 179. 7-37.
text.526:
Andhakāra (I) — a son of Dyutimat after whom the
kingdom Andhakāra came to be known.
Br. II. 14. 22, 25.
text.527:
Andhakāra (II) — the eighth battle of Devas and
Asuras.
Br. III. 72. 75 & 82; Vā. 97. 75.
text.528:
Andhakāraka (I) (c) — a kingdom of Krauñcadvīpa:
also a name of the hill in that region.
Br. II. 14. 25; 19. 67 & 72; M. 122. 81, 85; Vā. 49. 61, 67.
text.529:
Andhakāraka (II) — a Mt. in Krauñcadvīpa.
M. 122. 81; Vi. II. 4. 50.
text.530:
Andhakāraka (III) — a son of Dyutimān; after his name
a Janapada.
Vā. 33. 21, 23; Vi. II. 4. 48.
text.531:
Andhakāsuramardin — a surname of Śiva.
Br. III. 25. 12.
text.532:
Andhakūpa — one of the 28 hells. Those who do not
follow the prescribed course of life and who have no sym
pathy for the sufferings they inflict on others are subject
to affliction in this hell.
Bhā. V. 26. 7 and 17.
text.533:
Andhatāmisra — one of 28 hells. Here the person who
deceives the husband and robs him of his wife and property
is made to suffer.
Bhā. III. 30. 28 & 33; V. 26. 7 & 9.
text.535:
Andhinī — one of the five devīs on the third parva of
the Kiricakra of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 20. 9 & 38.
text.536:
Andhra (I) — born of Dīrghatamas and Bali's wife.
(Burnouf's reading — Oḍra).
Bhā., IX. 23. 5.
text.537:
Andhra (II) — the son of Dṛṣadaśva (Vṛṣadaśva-Vā. P.).
Br. III. 63. 27; Vā. 88. 26.
text.538:
Andhra (III) (c) — a Janapada under the Devarakṣitas.
Vā. 99. 385; Vi. IV. 24. 64.
text.539:
Andhras — a people of the southern country ruled for
300 years;1 a sinful tribe got purified by praying to Hari;2
defeated by Bharata.3 See Āṇdhras.4 1) Bhā., XII. 1. 22; Vā. 45. 127; 47. 44; 78. 69; 99. 268, 361.
2) Bhā. II. 4. 18.
3) Ib. IX. 20. 30.
4) M. 50. 76.
text.540:
Andhraka — the Śuṅga, ruled for 2 years.
Vā. 99. 339.
text.541:
Andhrakas — succeeded the Kaṇva dynasty of kings.
Thirty of them ruled for 456 years. Kingdom of:
Br. III. 73. 109; 74. 160, 170, 178, 197, 229-30; Vā. 98. 108;
Bhā. XII. 1. 22-28.
text.542:
Andhravākas — people of an eastern kingdom.
Br. II. 16. 53; Vā. 45. 11.
text.543:
Anna — gift of, the best of all; especially in a śrāddha:1
Annavikrayam condemned.2 1) Br. III. 16. 3, 52-5; 68, 66; Vā. 80. 55-7 (cf. Rāmā. II. ch.
103).
2) Br. IV. 8. 44-58.
text.544:
Annapūrṇā — a devī in the Cintāmaṇigṛha.
Br. IV. 36. 23.
text.545:
Annāda (I) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Mitravindā.
Bhā. X. 61. 16.
text.546:
Annāda (II) — a son of Agni Arka.
Br. II. 12. 43.
text.548:
Anya (II) — a rājaṛṣi, becoming a Brāhmaṇa.
Vā. 91. 116.
text.549:
Anyādṛk — one of the seven Maruts in the fourth marut-
gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 96-7; Vā. 67. 127.
text.550:
Anyādṛkṣas — one of the names in the fifth marutgaṇa.
Vā. 67. 128.
text.553:
Anvaṣṭakā — the ninth day in the latter half of the three
(or four) months following the full moon in Agrahāyana,
Pauṣa, Māgha, (Phālguna). The fourth month is men
tioned in the Purāṇa.
Vā. 81. 4, 5.
text.555:
Anvāhāryapacana — the particular Agni from which
Vṛtra was born.
Bhā. VI. 9. 12.
text.556:
Anvādhānakriyā — a fire rite on the conjunction of the
parvas.
Br. II. 28. 37.
text.557:
Apaḥ (I) — one of the ten branches of the Harita group
of Devas.
Vā. 100. 89.
text.558:
Apaḥ (II) — water: variations in temperature explain
ed in relation to the solar rays.
