Creator laughingly said that it was past 27 × 4 yugas since
he came there. At that time was flourishing Balarāma
whose name was suggested for his daughter's husband. On
return he found his country overrun by Yakṣas, and getting
his daughter married to Balarāma, he retired to Badari to
perform penance.1 Ruled from Kuśasthali. During his
sojourn at Brahmā's residence, the Rākṣasas captured the
capital and put to flight his younger brothers who established
smaller states then and there.2 1) Bhā. IX. 3. 29-36; M. 12. 23; Vā. 86. 26-30; 88. 1.
2) Br.
III. 61. 20-27; Vi. IV. 1. 65-96.
text.2341:
Kakupāda — a Rākṣasa in Sutalam.
Br. II. 20. 23.
text.2342:
Kakubha — a hill in Bhāratavarṣa.
Bhā. V. 19. 16.
text.2343:
Kakubhi — a daughter of Dakṣa and a wife of Dharma.
Mother of Saṃkaṭa.
Bhā. VI. 6. 4 & 6.
text.2344:
Kaklasa — a commander who aided Viṣaṅga; killed by
Vanhivāsā.
Br. IV. 25. 28 & 95.
text.2345:
Kaklivāhana — a commander of Viṣaṅga — also Kekivā
hana. Was killed by Mahāvajreśvarī.
Br. IV. 25. 28 & 96.
text.2346:
Kakṣīvaṭ (I) — a rājaṛṣi becoming a Brāhmaṇa.
Vā. 91. 117.
text.2347:
Kakṣīvat (II) — a sage who called on Bhīṣma on his
death bed.1 An Aṅgiras and a mantrakṛt; a Kṣatropeta-
dvija.2 1) Bhā. 1. 9. 7.
2) Br. II. 32. 111; III. 66. 88.
text.2348:
Kakṣīvaṭ (III) — the son born of Dīrghatamas to Bali's
slave girl: Followed his father Gautama afterwards to Giri
vraja (Giripraja-Vā. P.) and got engaged in tapas. Attained
Brahmahood at the place with his brother Cakṣus. Father
of 1000 sons known as Kūṣmāṇḍa Gautamas and Kṛṣṇāṅ
gas.1 A mantrakṛt and of the Aṅgirasa branch.2 1) Br. III. 74. 71, 95 & 99; Vā. 99. 70, 93-7.
2) M. 145. 105;
Vā. 59. 102.
text.2349:
Kakṣīvat (IV) — a pupil of Pauṣpiñji.
Vi. III. 6. 6.
text.2351:
Kakṣeyu (II) — one of the ten sons of Raudrāśva.
Vā. 99. 124; Vi. IV. 19. 2.
text.2352:
Kaṅka(u) (I) — a son of Ugrasena, and brother of
Kaṃsa; killed by Balarāma.1 His daughter was the queen
of Andhaka.2 1) Bhā. IV. 24. 24; X. 44. 40-41.
2) M. 44. 61 & 74.
text.2353:
Kaṅka (II) — a son of Devamīḍha alias Śūra, and
Māriṣā. His queen was Karṇikā and sons were Ṛtadhāman
and Jaya.
Bhā. IX. 24. 27-9. & 44.
text.2354:
Kaṅka (III) — the avatār of the Lord in the fifth dvāpara
with four sons, all yogins.
Vā. 23. 129.
text.2355:
Kaṅka (IV) — a ṛtvik at Brahmā's yajña.
Vā. 106. 36.
text.2356:
Kaṅka (V) — (Mt.) a chief hill of the Śālmalidvīpa.
Vā. 42. 50; 49. 36; Vi. II. 4. 27.
text.2358:
Kaṅkas (I) — a royal dynasty of sixteen princes noted
for their greed. See Maunas.
Bhā. XII. 1. 29.
text.2359:
Kaṅkas (II) — a tribe defeated by Bharatas. Purified of
sin by devotion to Hari.1 Heard of Kṛṣṇa going to Mithilā,
and met him there with presents.2 1) Bhā. IX. 20. 30; II. 4. 18.
2) Bhā. X. 86. 20.
text.2360:
Kaṅkā — a daughter of Ugrasena; wife of Ānaka and
mother of Satyajit and Purujit.
Bhā. IX. 24. 25 and 41; M. 44. 76.
text.2361:
Kaca — the son of Bṛhaspati; deputed by gods to learn
Samjīvinī vidyā from Śukrācārya; offered himself as a
disciple and admitted as a pupil by Śukra; conducted himself
to the satisfaction of his teacher and his daughter Devayānī
for a period of 500 years. Once while out in the woods
tending Śukra's cows, the Asuras killed him and left his
body to be devoured by dogs and jackals. The cows
returned home but not Kaca. Devayānī suspected of foul
play and reported his death. Śukra brought him back to
life.1
On another occasion he went to the woods to gather
flowers for Devayānī and this time the Asuras ground him
to pieces and mixing them with surā offered it to Śukra
who drank it. Again Devayānī persisted wanting him back
to life. This meant Śukra's death for he had to come out
by tearing open his belly. So he taught Kaca the Samjīvinī
vidyā so that he might restore him after his revival. Thus
he did and so he learnt the vidyā. After a sojourn of ten
hundred years he returned with due leave from his teacher.
Now Devayānī offered to marry him but he pointed out that
it was not proper to marry his preceptor's daughter. So
she cursed that he would not get the fruits of his vidyā
and he retorted that she would not find a Brāhmaṇa husband
but only a Kṣatriya. Returned to the gods who gave him
a share in their oblations; put to death by Vṛṣaparvan's
men.2 1) M. 25. 14-37.
2) M. 25. 38-69; chap. 26 whole; Bhā.
IX. 18. 22.
text.2363:
Kacchanīra — the Nāga presiding over the month of
Mādhava.
Bhā. XII. 11. 34.
text.2364:
Kacchapa (I) — a son of Viśvāmitra.
Br. III. 66. 69; Vā. 91. 97; Vi. IV. 7. 38.
text.2366:
Kacchapa (III) — one of the eight nidhis of Kubera.
Vā. 41. 10.
text.2367:
Kacchavīra — the sarpa who resides in the sun's chariot
during the month of Mādhava.
Vi. II. 10. 5.
text.2370:
Kañcī — in the liṅga deśa of the personified Veda.
Vā. 104. 76.
text.2371:
Kañcīpīṭham — in the waist of the personified Veda.
Vā. 104. 80.
text.2372:
Kañcī — a R. of the Ketumāla country.
Vā. 44. 18.
text.2373:
Kañcukis 1 — followed Rukmiṇī going to Devī temple;
also Kañcukadhāri.2 1) Bhā. X. 53. 41[].
2) Br. IV. 32. 3; M. 254. 23.
text.2375:
Kaṭakarma — a part of death rituals.
Vi. III. 13. 10.
text.2376:
Kaṭakṛt — a maker of mats of reeds.
Bhā. I. 3. 18.
text.2382:
Kaṭheśvaram — a tīrtham on the Narmadā.
M. 191. 63-4.
text.2384:
Kaṇāda — a son of Somaśarman, an avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 216.
text.2386:
Kaṇṭha (I) — a son of Ajamīḍha and Keśinī; father of
Medhātithi.
Vā. 99. 169-170.
text.2389:
Kaṇṭhamudgalas — the Mudgalas belonging to the branch
of Aṅgiras.
Vā. 99. 199.
text.2390:
Kaṇṭhāyanas — (the text is confused). Apparently the
four kings beginning with Navakaṇṭhāyāna are Śuṅga
bhṛtyas and were known as Kaṇṭāyanadvijas.
Vā. 99. 346-7.
text.2391:
Kaṇḍarīka — the minister of Pañcāla Brahmadatta;
remembered his previous birth as a son of Kauśika, left for
the forest to practise yoga with his brother minister.
M. 20. 24; 21. 31.
text.2392:
Kaṇḍina — a Vāśiṣṭha and a sage.
Br. II. 32. 116.
text.2393:
Kaṇḍu (I) — a sage engaged in austerities on the banks
of the Gomatī; had a daughter through Pramlocā who aban
doned the child in the midst of trees and departed. Soma
nourished it with nectar, and trees looked after her as their
baby. To get rid of the sin Kaṇḍu entered the temple of
Puruṣottama and meditated on Keśava.
Bhā. IV. 30. 13-14; Vi. I. 15. 11-54.
text.2394:
Kaṇḍu (II) — a pupil of Lāṅgali.
Br. II. 35. 48.
text.2396:
Kaṇḍū — father of thousand snakes, moveable and
immoveable having a number of heads, and flying in the
air and having different names.
Vā. 69. 68.
text.2397:
Kaṇva (I) — a son of Apratiratha and father of Medhā
tithi; Śakuntalā was brought up in his āśrama; performed
birth and other samskāras to the son born to her.
Bhā. IX. 20. 6-12 and 18; Vi. IV. 19. 5-6.
text.2398:
Kaṇva (II) — a sage and contemporary of Kṛṣṇa with
whom he went to Mithilā. Left Dvārakā for Piṇḍāraka.
Invited for Yudhiṣṭhira's Rājasūya.
Bhā. X. 86. 18; XI. 1. 12; X. 74. 7; Vi. V. 37. 6
text.2399:
Kaṇva (III) — the minister of Devabhūti Śuṅga, whom
he assassinated and usurped the throne.
Bhā. XII. 1. 19.
text.2400:
Kaṇva (IV) — An Aṅgirasa and mantrakṛt. A pupil of
Yājñavalkya.
Br. II. 32. 109; 35. 28; Vā. 59. 100; 61. 24.
text.2401:
Kaṇva (V) — a son of Ajāmīḍha and Keśinī and father
of Medhātithi.
M. 49. 46; Vi. IV. 19. 30-31.
text.2402:
Kaṇva (V) — a ṛtvik at the yāga of Brahmā.
Vā. 106. 35; 108. 42.
text.2403:
Kaṇvas — a royal dynasty after Śuṅgas; four kings in
all, ruled for 45 years.
Bhā. XII. 1. 19; M. 272. 36; Vi. IV. 24. 38, 42.
text.2404:
Kaṇvāyanadvijas — the family of Brāhmaṇas originally
from Kaṇva and his son Medhātithi. (See Wilson, Note at
p. 32).
Vi. IV. 19. 7.
text.2405:
Kaṇvāyanas — the predecessors of the Āndhra rulers;
their reign of 4 kings lasted for 45 years.
Br. III. 74. 158 & 159.
text.2406:
Kata — a Kauśika and a sage.
Br. II. 32. 118.
text.2407:
Katakas — a tribe conquered by Kalki.
Br. II. 31. 84.
text.2409:
Kathana — a Rākṣasa living in Sutalam.
Br. II. 20. 22.
text.2410:
Kathā — of Kāma and Keśava to be narrated in Mada-
nadvādaśīvrata.
M. 7. 14.
text.2411:
Kathājapa — a pupil of Bāṣkala.
Vi. III. 4. 25.
text.2412:
Kadambavana-vāsinī — a name of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 17. 34; 28. 67.
text.2413:
Kadambeśī — a name of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 17. 34.
text.2414:
Kadalī — a R. sacred to Pitṛs. Once Rāma resided on
her banks.
M. 22. 52.
text.2416:
Kadrū — a daughter of Dakṣa, wife of Tārkṣyā, and
mother of Nāgas, including Kāliya:1 according to Bṛahmāṇḍa
Vi., Vā., and Mastya P. Consort of Kāśyapa;2 known for
anger.3 1) Bhā. V. 24. 8; VI. 6. 21-2; X. 17. 4, 73.
2) Br. III. 3. 57; 7.
31, 467; M. 6. 2 & 38; 146. 19 & 22; 171. 29 & 63; Vā. 66. 55; Vi. I.
15. 125.
3) Vā. 69. 94.
text.2417:
Kadrūputra — Reference to Takṣaka in Sutalam.
Br. II. 20. 24.
text.2420:
Kanaka (II) — a son of Durmada (Durdama-Matsya P.);
father of Kṛtavīrya and three other sons, Kārtavīrya, Kṛta
varma and Kṛta.
Br. III. 69. 8; M. 43. 12; Vā. 94. 7-9.
text.2421:
Kanaka (III) — a son of Hṛdika.
Br. III. 71. 141.
text.2422:
Kanaka (IV) — a son of Bṛhati.
Br. III. 71. 256.
text.2423:
Kanaka (V) — a king who ruled over Strīrāṣṭra, Bho
jaka and other kingdoms.
Br. III. 74. 199.
text.2424:
Kanakas (I) — enjoy kingdoms of Trairājya and
Mūṣika.
Vi. IV. 24. 67.
text.2426:
Kanakanandi — a sacred place (tīrtha); a bather here
goes to heaven, relieved of all three Ṛṇas; east of the
Muṇḍapṛṣṭa hill.
Br. III. 13. 113-5; Vā. 77. 105.
text.2427:
Kanakaparvata — (Mt.) from the aṇḍa;1 ten thousand
yojanas in length, containing caves of red arsenic.2 1) Vā. 24. 75.
2) Vā. 35. 10.
text.2428:
Kanakapīṭha — a son of Pulaha and Kṣamā; wife Yaśo
dharā and son Sahiṣṇu.
Br. II. 11. 31.
text.2429:
Kanakabindu — His wife was met by Agni, and Nala
was their son.
Br. III. 7. 229-230.
text.2430:
Kanakam — Raudram metal, dear to Pitṛs.
Br. III. 1. 60; 11. 5.
text.2431:
Kanakā — R. a Mahānadī, remembered by Lomaśa per
forming penance at the Muṇdapṛṣṭa hill; fit for performance
of Śrāddha.
Vā. 108. 80.
text.2432:
Kanakāhvaya — ruled over Strirāṣṭra and Bhakṣyakas.
Vā. 99. 387.
text.2433:
Kanakeśvara — one of the forms of Brahmā in the Gaya
stone.
Vā. 106. 56; 111. 72.
text.2434:
Kanakodbhava — a son of Hṛdika.
Br. III. 71. 141; Vā. 96. 140.
text.2435:
Kanakhala — a sacred place on the Ganges, where
Garuḍa performed tapas. Here Śiva danced with a yoginī.
Bath here leads to Rudralokam.
M. 186. 10; 192. 11; 193. 69-71; Vā. 83. 21.
text.2436:
Kanakhalam — a tīrtha in Gaya; on its right side is Dak
ṣiṇamānasa.
Vā. 111. 7.
text.2437:
Kaniṣṭhas — one of the five deva-gaṇas of the 14th epoch
of Bhautya Manu. These are the seven sāmas commencing
with Bṛhat.
Br. IV. 1. 106 & 108; Vā. 100. 111-2; Vi. III. 2. 43.
text.2438:
Kanīyaka — one of the ten sons of Hṛdīka.
M. 44. 82.
text.2440:
Kandarpa — the name of the 8th kalpa
M. 290. 4.
text.2441:
Kandarpa(vīra) — an attribute of Manmatha.
Br. IV. 19. 67; 30. 54 and 85; M. 154. 250.
text.2442:
Kandukalīlā — a game with balls indulged in by girls.
Mohinī played it.
Bhā. VIII. 12. 18 & 23; M. 160. 4.
text.2445:
Kanyakā — a name of Yogamāyā.
Bhā. X. 2. 12.
text.2447:
Kanyā (II) — daughter of Kardama and wife of Priya
vrata; mother of two daughters and ten sons.
Vi. II. 1. 5.
text.2448:
Kanyā (III) — shrine of, south of Malaya hills, visited by
Balarāma.
Bhā. X. 79. 17.
text.2450:
Kanyāpuram — the harem of a palace.
Vi. V. 29. 31.
text.2451:
Kapaṭasaṃgrāma — the deceitful battle waged during
night by Asuras; also Kūṭayuddha.
Br. IV. 26. 2-10.
text.2452:
Kapardavān — an attribute of Vighneśvara.
Br. IV. 44. 66.
text.2453:
Kapardin — a name of Śiva;1 a Rudra.2 1) Br. II. 25. 68; III. 25. 12; IV. 34. 27.
2) M. 171. 39; Vi. I.
15. 122.
text.2458:
Kapāla — one of the eleven Rudras.
Vā. 66. 70.
text.2459:
Kapālam — Śiva's begging bowl; shattered into 1000
pieces at Benares by Hari's grace.
M. 183. 91-100.
text.2460:
Kapālamocana — a tīrtham sacred to śuddhi1 of Śiva at
Banaras.2 1) M. 13. 48.
2) Ib. 183. 101.
text.2461:
Kapāli — a name of Śiva: a Rudra.1 A Bhairava god;2
killed Gajāsura;3 Śiva had to become Kapāli for having
destroyed the fifth face of Brahmā, but released through
Hari's grace.4 1) Br. II. 25. 68; III. 3. 71; 25. 8.
2) Ib. IV. 19. 79; Vi. I. 15.
123.
3) M. 153. 19-68; 171. 39.
4) M. 183. 87-100.
text.2464:
Kapi (I) — Asura (?) vanquished by Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. II. 7. 34.
text.2465:
Kapi (II) — An Aṅgirasa and mantrakṛt; a Kṣatropeta-
dvija;1 a Bhārgava.2 1) Br. II. 32. 109; III. 66. 86.
2) M. 195. 33.
text.2466:
Kapi (III) — had two sons Pisācas Aja and Śaṇḍa, who
were Kūṣmāṇḍas in the previous birth; their line described.
Br. III. 7. 74-88.
text.2467:
Kapi (IV) — a god of Sukarmaṇa group.
Br. IV. 1. 88.
text.2468:
Kapi (V) — a sage of the Tāmasa epoch.
M. 9. 15.
text.2469:
Kapi (VI) — a son of Raivata Manu.
M. 9. 21.
text.2470:
Kapi (VII) — a rājaṛṣi becoming a Brāhmaṇa.
Vā. 91. 115.
text.2472:
Kapi (IX) — a son of Durukṣaya, became a Brāhmaṇa
(Matsya P. speaks of three branches of Kavi Brāhmaṇas).
Vi. IV. 19. 25, 26.
text.2474:
Kapiñjala (II) — the king of kings to the Gandharvas
in the Hemakūṭa hill.
Vā. 39. 52.
text.2475:
Kapiñjala (III) — a Mt.; between this hill and Nāga
Śaila are many fine orchards.
Vā. 38. 66-70; 42. 67.
text.2476:
Kapiñjalī (Ghṛtācī) — wife of Vasisṭha, and mother of
Indrapramati (Indrapratima — Vā. P.)
Br. III. 8. 97; Vā. 70. 88.
text.2477:
Kapittha — illustrative of the world which is compared
to the shape of an egg.
Vi. II. 7. 22.
text.2479:
Kapibhū — a Trayārṣeya; Aṅgiras and Gārgya are
Pravaras.
M. 196. 48-49.
text.2481:
Kapila (I) — the fifth avatār of Hari. Born of Kardama
and Devahūti. Had nine sisters. Taught the knowledge of
Brahman to his mother.1 A siddha.2 Propounder of tattvas.
Imparted to Āsuri the Sāṅkhya obscured by time. After
Kardama left the family, Kapila lived with his mother at
Bindusaras and instructed her on Sāṅkhya tattvas, tattva-
lakṣaṇa, the distinction of Prakṛti and Puruṣa, Aṣṭāṅga yoga,
Bhakti yoga, Kāla, attachment and consequent hell, garbha
and attachment to women and evils attending thereon,
kāmya karma and Jñāna yoga; left his mother for north.
Being worshipped by Samudra (sea) with arghya and resi
dence, he devoted his mind to yoga.3
Knew Vāsudeva's glory but could not comprehend His
māyā.4 Served as calf for Vidyadharas to milk siddhi and
vidyā.5 Attended Pṛthu's sacrifice.6 Prācīnabarhis who
retired from kingly duties came to his hermitage to perform
tapas.7 One of the twelve who knew the dharma ordained
by Hari.8 A sage who went about the world imparting
knowledge;9 would find no fault with Hara's violation of
dharma.10 King Rahūgaṇa went to visit him.11
Near by his āśrama was the consecrated horse of Sagara.
The 60,000 Sāgaras who searched for it imputed the theft to
the sage and attacked him, who in wrath burnt them down.
Met by Amśumān, he gave back the horse and said that the
Sāgaras would get redemption by the Ganges waters.12 The
four who were not victims to the sage's curse were Barhi
ketu, Saketu, Dharmarata, and Pañcavana.13 1) Bhā. I. 3. 10; II. 7. 3; VIII. 1. 6; Br. III. 63. 145 and 148.
2) Bhā. VI. 15. 13; III. 24. 16-17.
3) Ib. III. chapters 24-33; Br. IV.
40. 66; M. 3. 29; 102. 18; 171. 4 and 19.
4) Bhā. I. 9. 19; IX. 4.
57.
5) Ib. IV. 18. 19.
6) Ib. IV. 19. 6.
7) Ib. IV. 29. 81.
8) Ib.
VI. 3. 20; 8. 16.
9) Ib. VI. 15. 13.
10) Ib. VI. 17. 12.
11) Ib. V.
10. 1 and 16.
12) Ib. IX. 8. 10-29; XI. 16. 15; Br. III. 15. 15-43;
53. 17-52; chap. 54; Vi. IV. 4. 12-28.
13) Vā. 88. 147-53.
text.2482:
Kapila (II) — a son of Danu. Followed Vṛtra in his
battle with Indra. Took part in Devāsura war between
Bali and Indra.
Bhā. VI. 6. 30; 10[20]; VIII. 10. 21; Br. III. 6. 5; Vi. I. 21. 4.
text.2483:
Kapila (III) — a son of Jyotiṣman, after whom came
Kapilavarṣa.
Br. II. 14. 28 and 30; Vā. 33. 24.
text.2484:
Kapila (IV) — a Kādraveya Nāga in the third talam.
(Vitalam, Vā. P.).
Br. II. 20. 30; III. 7. 36; M. 6. 41; Vā. 50. 29; 69. 73, 219.
text.2485:
Kapila (V) — an Yakṣa who married the Rākṣasi Keśinī.
Br. III. 7. 146; Vā. 69. 12.
text.2486:
Kapila (VI) — a chief of the Vānaras
Br. III. 7. 233.
text.2487:
Kapila (VII) — a son of Vasudeva and Sugandhī; took
to penance.
Br. III. 71. 186; M. 46. 21; Vā. 96. 182-183.
text.2491:
Kapila (XI) — a son of Brahmā;1 of the eighth dvāpara.2 1) Vā. 101. 338.
2) Ib. 23. 141.
text.2492:
Kapila (XII) — a sage;1 hermitage of, on the Ikṣumatī
banks;2 King Sauvīra went to him for consultation on the
end of life;3 a part of Viṣṇu;4 Viṣṇu; in Tretāyuga to impart
knowledge.5 1) Vi. I. 22. 8.
2) Ib. II. 13. 53.
3) Ib. II. 14. 7.
4) Ib. II.
14. 9.
5) Ib. III. 2. 56.
text.2493:
Kapila (XIII) — Mt. of Kuśadvīpa surrounding the base
of Meru.
Bhā. V. 16. 26; 20. 15.
text.2494:
Kapila (XIV) — a Mt. west of the Sitoda (Meru-Vi. P.).
Vā. 36. 27; 42. 50; Vi. II. 2. 29.
text.2495:
Kapila (XV) — a Mt. north of the Mahābhadra lake.
Vā. 36. 31.
text.2496:
Kapila (XVI) — an elephant born of the Rathantara.
Br. III. 7. 335; Vā. 69. 219.
text.2497:
Kapilas — the Brāhmaṇa caste of Sālmalidvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 30.
text.2498:
Kapilakarṇika (c) — a Janapada of the Ketumāla.
Vā. 44. 11.
text.2499:
Kapilam — a kingdom in Kuśadvīpa;1 a varṣa after the
name;2 a Varṣaparvata in Kuśadvīpam.3 1) Br. II. 14. 30; 19. 59.
2) Vā. 33. 26.
3) Vā. 49. 55.
text.2500:
Kapilā (I) — a daughter of Khaśā and a Rākṣasī; After
her name came the Kāpileya gaṇa.
Br. III. 7. 138; Vā. 69. 170.
text.2501:
Kapilā (II) — a goddess enshrined at Mahāliṅga.
M. 13. 33.
text.2502:
Kapilā (III) — a R. on the south side of the Narmadā,
joining it.
M. 186. 40.
text.2503:
Kapilā (IV) — a R. in front of the Vaṭa in Gayā.
Vā. 108. 57.
text.2504:
Kapilā (V) — brown cow, gift of which is equal to hear
ing ten chapters of Viṣṇu Purāṇa;1 equal to the gift of the
whole earth.2 1) Vi. VI. 8. 54.
2) M. 191. 72.
text.2506:
Kapilāśva (I) — a son of Kuvalayāśva, who survived the
fire from Dhundhu's mouth.
Bhā. IX. 6. 23-4; Br. III. 63. 63; M. 12. 32.
text.2507:
Kapilāśva (II) — one of the three sons of Dhundhu
māra.
Vā. 88. 61; Vi. IV. 2. 42.
text.2508:
Kapileśa — the deity presiding over the river Kapilā
especially at the coming of Amā and Soma.
Vā. 108. 57.
text.2509:
Kapiloma — a son of Khaśā, and a Rākṣasa.
Br. III. 7. 134; Vā. 69. 166.
text.2511:
Kapiśā — a daughter of Krodhavaśā (Krodhā-Vā. P.)
and a wife of Pulaha. Gave birth to Piśāca groups;1 gave
birth to Kūṣmāṇḍas.2 1) Br. III. 7. 172 and 274.
2) Vā. 69. 205, 257.
text.2514:
Kapota — a dove, that attained permanent fame:1 enter
ing houses forebodes evil.2 1) Bhā. X. 72. 21.
2) M. 6. 32.
text.2515:
Kapotaroman (I) — the son of Viloman and father of
Anu.
Bhā. IX. 24. 20.
text.2516:
Kapotaroman (II) — a son of Vṛṣṇi (Dhṛṣṭa-Vi. P.) and
father of Viloman.
Br. III. 71. 117; Vi. IV. 14. 13.
text.2517:
Kapotaroman (III) — a son of Dhṛti and father of Taittiri.
M. 44. 62.
text.2520:
Kabandha (I) — killed by Śrī Rāma; an Asura in Tat
valam.
Bhā. IX. 10. 12; Br. II. 20. 16; Vi. IV. 4. 96.
text.2521:
Kabandha (II) — a pupil of Sumantu of Atharvan fame.
He imparted the Veda to two disciples Pathya and Deva
darśa (Vedasparśa,-Vā. P.) dividing it into two.
Br. II. 35. 56; Vā. 61. 50; Vi. III. 6. 9.
text.2522:
Kabandha (III) — an Asura chief in Atalam.
Vā. 50. 16.
text.2523:
Kamaṭharūpa — the tortoise avatār of Hari, being the
eleventh of incarnations. In this form the Mandara hill was
supported on his back during the churning of the ocean by
gods and Asuras.
Bhā. I. 3. 16; VIII. 7. 8.
text.2524:
Kamaṇḍalu — of Budha;1 in possession of Agastya.2
Given to Vāmana by Vasiṣṭha;3 of Brahmā, as the source of
Gaṅgā;4 of Śiva.5 1) M. 11. 55.
2) Ib. 61. 36.
3) Ib. 245. 86.
4) Vā. 55. 14;
Bhā. VIII. 21. 4.
5) Vā. 101. 273.
text.2526:
Kamalasaptamī — A vrata in honour of the Sun god.
M. 74. 3; 78 (whole).
text.2527:
Kamalā (I) — Brahmā's consort; see also Lakṣmī, Śrī.
Br. IV. 15. 37; 39. 67.
text.2529:
Kamalākṣa (I) — a Dānava who entered the ocean.
M. 61. 4.
text.2530:
Kamalākṣa (II) — a tīrtham sacred to Mahotpala.
M. 13. 34.
text.2532:
Kamlāpati (II) — a name of Viṣṇu.
Br. IV. 12. 20.
text.2534:
Kamalālaya (I) — a tīrtham sacred to Kamalā.
M. 13. 32.
text.2535:
Kamalālaya (II) — an attribute of Śrī.
Vi. I. 8. 22.
text.2537:
Kamalī — a daughter of king Reṇuka of Ikṣvāku line.
Hence Reṇukā; wife of Jamadagni; mother of Paraśurāma.
Br. III. 66. 61.
text.2539:
Kamalodbhava — is Brahmā; narrated the Viṣṇu Purāṇa
to Ṛbhu.
Br. III. 56. 37; Vi. VI. 8. 43.
text.2541:
Kampā — also Kampātarangiṇī — the sacred waters of
Kāñcī.
Br. IV. 40. 17, 40, 85, 102 and 115.
text.2543:
Kambala (I) — a chief of Nāgas in Pātāla, presides over
the month of Iṣa.1 According to the Brahmāṅda and Vāyu
Purāṇas, he was the resident of Sutalam;2 in the Prajāpati
kṣetra; used in the chariot of Tripurārī.3 Kādraveya Nāga
residing in the sun's chariot in the month of Māgha;4 in the
month of Tapa and Tapasya.5 1) Bhā. V. 24. 31; XII. 11. 43; M. 6. 39; Vā. 50. 23; 69. 70.
2) Br. II. 20. 23; III. 7. 33.
3) M. 104. 5; 106. 27; 110. 8; 133. 20.
4) Vi. I. 21. 21; II. 10. 16.
5) Br. II. 23. 21.
text.2544:
Kambala (II) — heard the Viṣṇu Purāṇa from Aśvatara
and narrated it to Elāputra.
Vi. VI. 8. 47.
text.2546:
Kambala (IV) — (Mt.) a Kulaparvata of the Ketumāla.
Vā. 44. 4.
text.2547:
Kambalabarhiṣa (barhis) (I) — a son of Andhaka.
Bhā. IX. 24. 19; M. 44. 61; Vi. IV. 14. 12.
text.2548:
Kambalabarhiṣa (II) — a son of Satyaka and the
daughter of Kāśirāja.
Br. III. 71. 116; Vā. 96. 115.
text.2549:
Kambalabarhiṣa (III) — a son of Devabāhu, (Devārha
Vā. and Matsya P.) and father of Asamañjas; a great scholar.
Br. III. 71. 142; M. 44. 83; Vā. 96. 140.
text.2550:
Kambalabarhi(ṣa) (IV) — (Kambalabarhi-Vā. P.). A
son of Marutta.
M. 44. 25; Vā. 95. 24.
text.2551:
Kambalā — a R. of the Ketumāla continent.
Vā. 44. 17.
text.2552:
Kambalāśvatara — Nāga with the sun in the months of
Māśi and Paṅguni.
Vā. 52. 21.
text.2553:
Kambuśṛṅga — a son of Raivata Manu.
Br. II. 36. 64.
text.2554:
Kamboja — (c) Its king was vanquished by Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. II. 7. 35.
text.2555:
Kayādhū — the daughter of Jambhā, and queen of
Hiraṇyakaśipu; mother of 4 sons.
Bhā. VI. 18. 12.
text.2556:
Kara (I) — (tax) not levied in Śākadvīpa;1 levied by
Sagara over the conquered;2 to be levied and taken in instal
ments; fresh taxes lead to discontent among peoples.3 1) Vā. 49. 103; 59. 124; 108. 70; Br. II. 19. 106.
2) Br. III. 49. 7;
52. 41.
3) M. 217. 3; 226. 11; 238. 14.
text.2558:
Karaka — a small water vessel. In it Manu let the fish.
M. 1. 18.
text.2559:
Karaṃka — attacked with four other commanders the
Śakti army using illusory sarpiṇī (reptiles). The Śaktis
sent out Nakulis which put an end to all reptiles.
Br. IV. 21. 77; 23. 4-98.
text.2560:
Karandama — a son of Trayīsānu and father of Marutta.
Vi. IV. 16. 3.
text.2561:
Karaṃdhama (I) — the son of Khaninetra.
Bhā. IX. 2. 25-26.
text.2562:
Karaṃdhama (II) — the noble son of Tribhānu (Trisānu
Br. and M. P.) and father of Maruta (Marutta-Br. P.).
Bhā. IX. 23. 17; Br. III. 74. 2; M. 48. 2; Vā. 99. 2.
text.2563:
Karandhama (III) — the son of Ativibhūti and father of
Āvikṣit; lived at the commencement of the Tretāyuga.
Vā. 86. 7; Vi. 1. 29-30.
text.2565:
Karañjamañjamā — a Janapada of the Ketumāla.
Vā. 44. 13.
text.2566:
Karañja tīrtham — a holy spot on the Narmadā.
M. 190. 11.
text.2567:
Karaṭaka — a brother of Balāhaka, and a commander of
Bhaṇḍa; rode on Vetāla.
Br. IV. 24. 10 and 55.
text.2569:
Karatoyā — a R. of the Bhāratavarṣa.
Vā. 45. 100.
text.2570:
Karabhājana — a son of Ṛṣabha, and a bhāgavata;
described the forms of Hari worshipped by men in different
yugas.
Bhā. V. 4. 11; XI. 2. 21: 5. 20. 42.
text.2571:
Karamerati — the daughter of Cedi king, married Na
kula, son of Niramitra.
Vā. 99. 248.
text.2572:
Karamodā — a R. from the Ṛkṣa hill.
Br. II. 16. 30.
text.2575:
Karambha(ka) (I) — the son of Śakuni. Father of
Devarāta; a bowman.
Br. III. 70. 44; M. 44. 42; Vā. 95. 43.
text.2576:
Karambhaka (II) — one of the ten sons of Hṛdīka.
M. 44. 82.
text.2577:
Karambhava — a Janapada of the Ketumāla.
Vā. 44. 11.
text.2578:
Karambhavāluka — a hell for those fallen from karma.
Br. II. 28. 84; Vā. 56. 79.
text.2579:
Karambhi — a son of Śakuni, and father of Devarāta.
Bhā. IX. 24. 5; Vi. IV. 12. 41.
text.2581:
Karava — a chief of the Vānaras.
Br. III. 7. 234.
text.2582:
Karavāṭas — a Janapada of the Ketumāla.
Vā. 44. 12.
text.2584:
Karavīra (II) — a Mt. on the south of Meru.
Bhā. V. 16. 27.
text.2585:
Karavīrapuram — sacred to Mahālakṣmi, and to Pitṛs.
M. 13. 41; 22. 76.
text.2586:
Karavīrapura — at the foot of Gomanta hill and under
a chieftain Śṛgālavāsudeva. The latter rose against Kṛṣṇa
and Rāma who occupied the city after killing him. Welcome
by its citizens. Spoils and slaves sent to Mathurā. Kṛṣṇa
and Rāma lived here for four months. Pursued by Jarā
sandha, the brothers fled to this city and after taking rest for
the night got up the hill before daybreak. Not visited by
Vasudeva by order of Kaṃsa.
Bhā. X. [52 (V) 28-42]; [53. (V) 20-21]; 52. 11 [1]; 66. [9].
text.2587:
Karāla — another term for Śiva; a Bhairava.
Br. II. 25. 68; IV. 20. 82.
text.2588:
Karālākṣa — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 78.
text.2589:
Karālāyu — a brother of Balāhaka and a commander of
Bhaṇḍa; rode on preta.
Br. IV. 24. 10, 52.
text.2591:
Karicakraratha — the chariot in which Lalitā rode at the
starting of expedition towards Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 17. 8.
text.2592:
Karivratam — the performer of, becomes king.
M. 101. 72.
text.2596:
Karuṇābhyudayam — the prayer of Bhṛgu to Śiva.
M. 193. 45.
text.2597:
Karūśa — its king Bṛhaccāpa was placed on the west of
the Gomanta hill in its siege by Jarāsandha;1 appropriated
the name Vāsudeva and sent a dūta to Kṛṣṇa to that effect;
attacked Kṛṣṇa with a gadā.2 1) Bhā. X. 52. 11[12].
2) Bhā. X. 66. 1. 78. 4.
text.2598:
Karūṣa (I) — one of the ten sons of Vaivasvata Manu.
His descendants were Kārūṣas, all Kṣatriyas and rulers of
Uttarāpatha. Respected Brāhmaṇas and dharma.
Bhā. VII. 13. 3; IX. 1. 12; 2. 16; Br. II. 38. 31; 60. 3; Br. III.
61. 2; M. 11. 41; 12. 24; Vā. 64. 30; 85. 4; 86. 2; Vi. III. I. 34;
IV. I. 7, 18.
text.2599:
Karūṣa (II) — adopted a son of Kṛṣṇa, Sucandra by
name.
M. 46. 25.
text.2601:
Karūṣas — a Vindhya tribe. Dantavaktra, as king of;1
their territory was near Suprītakavanam, an elephant
forest.2 1) Br. II. 16. 63; III. 71. 156; M. 114. 52; Vā. 45. 132.
2) Vā.
69. 239.
text.2602:
Kareṇumatī — a daughter of Cedi king; queen of Nakula
and mother of Niramitra.
Bhā. IX. 22. 32; M. 50. 55.
text.2603:
Karka — a ṛtvik at the sacrifice of Brahmā.
Vā. 106. 37.
text.2604:
Karkaṭaka — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 78.
text.2605:
Karkaṭakam — Cancer; when the sun enters this it is
Dakṣiṇāyana.
Vi. II. 8. 31.
text.2606:
Karkaśa — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 79.
text.2607:
Karkoṭa(ka) — the Nāga presiding over the month of
Puṣya.1 A Kādraveya Nāga.2 The sabhā of, in Māhiṣamati.
His son defeated by Kārtavīrya Arjuna;3 used for Tripurārī's
chariot.4 The assembly of, conquered by Kārtavīrya
Arjuna.5 1) Bhā. XII. 11. 42; M. 126. 18; Vā. 52. 17; 69. 70.
2) Br. II.
23. 17; III. 7. 34; IV. 20. 53; 33. 36; M. 6. 39; Vi. I. 21. 22.
3) Br.
III. 69. 26; M. 43. 29.
4) M. 133. 33; 163. 56.
5) Vā. 94. 26.
text.2608:
Karkoṭakeśvaram — a tīrtham on the Narmadā.
M. 191. 36.
text.2609:
Karṇa (I) — born of Kuntī as a virgin and abandoned
by her; brought up by Adhiratha; became a king and father
of Vṛṣasena.1 Pāṇḍavas defeated his army. Arjuna was
saved from Karṇa's arrows by Kṛṣṇa. Joined Duryodhana
in insulting Vidura, and was his evil adviser.2 Resented
Sāmba's action in carrying away Lakṣmaṇā but vanquished
by Sāmba. In charge of gifts in Yudhiṣtira's Rājasūya.
Joined Duryodhana's army and succeeded Droṇa as com
mander for two days, but was killed by Arjuna.3 Failed to
hit the mark in the svayamvara of Lakṣmaṇā.4 Identified
with Cakravarman, the son of Bala.5 Was called son of Sūta
as he was brought up by Adhiratha the Sūta.6 1) Bhā. IX. 23. 13-14; X. 49. 2; Vi. IV. 14. 36; 18. 28-9; V. 35. 5
and 7; 38. 16.
2) Bhā. I. 15. 15-16; III. 1. 14; 3. 13.
3) Bhā. X. 68. 5 and
9; 75. 5; 78 [95 (v) 16] & [37].
4) Ib. X. 83. 23.
5) Br. III. 6. 32.
6) Vā. 99. 118.
text.2611:
Karṇa (III) — born in after-birth as Cakravarma, the
son of Bali.
Vā. 68. 32; Br. III. 6. 33.
text.2612:
Karṇa (IV) — the son of Aṅga.
M. 48. 102-4; Vā. 99. 112.
text.2615:
Karṇaprāvarṇas — country of, watered by Nalinī.
Br. II. 18. 60; M. 121. 58; Vā. 47. 57.
text.2617:
Karṇāṭakas (Dakṣiṇa) — Inhabitants of south Karṇā
ṭaka.
Bhā. V. 6. 7.
text.2618:
Karṇikā (I) — wife of Kaṅka and mother of Ṛtadhā
man and Jaya.
Bhā. IX. 24. 44.
text.2619:
Karṇikā (II) — the tendril of the world lotus; Atri
regards it as 100 cornered, Bhṛgu as 1000 cornered, Bhā
guri, square, Vārṣāyaṇi Sāmudra, Gālava, tray-shaped, Gār
gya like braided hair and Kroṣtuki circle-like. Each had
only partial knowledge; Brahmā alone knows it entire.
Vā. 34. 58-69.
text.2622:
Kardama (I) — father of Kapīla. Married Devahūti.1
A son of Brahmā born of his shadow. A progenitor and a
yogi;2 performed in Kṛtayuga austerities on the banks of
Sarasvatī for 10,000 years; when Hari appeared before him,
he praised Him and asked for a suitable wife. Devahūti
was suggested and the Lord disappeared. Manu came with
his wife and daughter to his hermitage, and was suitably
received. Kardama agreed to marry his daughter and lead
a householder's life until the birth of children. After wed
ding, Manu and his wife returned home. Pleased at his
wife's devotion, created an aerial car artistically built and
furnished. Took his wife after her bath and dress round
the earth for a hundred years. Nine daughters were born
when according to original contract he was anxious to leave
her for woods to practise yoga. Noticing her anxiety at his
departure, he consoled her that she would give birth to Hari
who would bring solace to her. On the birth of Kapila,
Brahmā and other seers called on him; gave his daughters
in marriage, took leave of his son and retired to a life of
penance. 1) Bhā. II. 7. 3; IV. 1. 10.
2) Ib. III. 12. 27 & 56; chap. 21 to 24.
text.2623:
Kardama (II) — a son of Pulaha and Kṣamā; married
Sruti; son Śaṅkhapada and daughter Kāmyā; a Prajāpati; a
sage by tapas and a devaṛṣi;1 a pravara.2 1) Br. I. 1. 65; II. 11. 23 and 31; 32. 99; 35. 94; III. 8. 18;
10. 93; M. 145. 93; Vā. 1. 80; 3. 3; 28. 25-29; 33. 7; 38. 7; 59.
91; 61. 84; 65. 53; Vi. I. 10. 10.
2) M. 199. 16.
text.2624:
Kardama (III) — a Prajāpati: wife of Sinīvalī; had two
daughters Samrāṭ and Kukṣi, besides ten sons.1 His wife
left him for Soma. His world that of Ājya pitṛs.2 1) Br. II. 14. 7; III. 1. 53.
2) M. 15. 20; 23. 24.
text.2625:
Kardama (IV) — also Śamkhapa; a Lokapāla.
Br. II. 21. 157; M. 124. 95; Vā. 50. 206.
text.2626:
Kardamāyana — a gotrakara of Atri family.
M. 197. 1.
text.2627:
Kardamāla — in the navel portion of Gayā; bath and
śrāddha here to get rid of the debt to Pitṛs.
Vā. 112. 57.
text.2628:
Kardamālam — a tīrtham sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 77.
text.2629:
Karpaṭas — Pāṣaṇḍas who live by sheer prowess.
Vā. 78. 30.
text.2630:
Karma (I) — two-fold; Pravṛtti and Nivṛtti;1 importance
of;2 that which consists of yajña is best.3 1) Vi. I. 1. 27; VI. 4. 41.
2) Vi. I. 18. 32.
3) Vi. II. 14. 14.
text.2631:
Karma (II) — (Vedic) two-fold; Pravṛtta and Nivṛtta.1
There is another classification of Karma: Vaidika, Tāntrika,
and Miśra (mixed).2 Kṛṣṇa advised Uddhava to pursue
nivṛtta and abandon pravṛtta path.3 Karma exalted as the
source of all good and evil, and appropriate to four castes:
is done due to māyāmohan;4 does not lead to final destruc
tion of Karman.5
Seven-fold: tapas, brahmacarya, yajña, prajā, śrāddha,
vidyā and dāna. Bad karmas — five-fold: killing, theft, in
jury, drinking and lust.6 1) Bhā. VII. 15. 47-49.
2) Ib. XI. 27. 7.
3) Ib. XI. 10. 4.
4) Ib. X. 23. 50; 24. 13-14 & 18-20.
5) Ib. VI. 1. 11.
6) Br. II. 28.
75; III. 4. 5 & 24; 28. 9; IV. 5. 25; 6. 37; Vā. 56. 70.
text.2632:
Karma with Agni is kāmya, naimittika and ajasra;
should be done with detachment.7 Rebirth after death is
dependent on.8 7) Vā. 29. 44;
104. 86-96.
8) Vā. 14. 2-3, 31-42; 61. 106.
text.2633:
Karmajit — son of Bṛhatsena and father of Sṛtañjaya.
Bhā. IX. 22. 47.
text.2637:
Karmabhūmi — the earth as distinguished from
Heaven.1 Bhāratavarṣa as compared with others which
are bhogabhūmis.2 1) Br. IV. 9. 10.
2) Vi. II. 3. 22.
text.2638:
Karmayoga — Three-fold. Scriptural and not laukika.
Intended for the attached and householders. Ācāra preli
minary to karma. Karmakāṇḍa an ocean. Three kinds of
worship — vedic, tāntric, and mixed. Worship of image
through a guru and according to established rules.1 Preach
ed by Janārdana to Manu; greater than jñāna yoga; as jñā-
nam is the result of Karma; origin of Brahmā from: also
Kriyā yoga; five yajñas and 30 samskāras come under this.2
Four of Karma category — Agnihotra, silence, study and
sacrifice, when not performed properly give fear.3 1) Bhā. XI. 3. 41-55; 20. 6-7; 21. 14-15; 27. 1 & 6-9.
2) M. 52.
3-11; 258. 2.
3) M. 39. 25-7.
text.2639:
Karmaśreṣṭha — a son of Pulaha and Gatī.
Bhā. IV. 1. 38.
text.2641:
Karmāranāga — the Fifth tala or Mahātala.
Vā. 50. 36.
text.2642:
Kalana — a door-keeper of Mahākāla.
Br. IV. 32. 18.
text.2643:
Kalaśa — a Rākṣasa; his city in the Atalam.
Vā. 50. 18.
text.2645:
Kalahaṃsas — sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭri and Garuḍa.
Br. III. 7. 457.
text.2646:
Kalas (I) — sixty in number:1 a period of time;2 30 lavas
according to a calculation;3 33 kāṭhas;4 30 kalas make
a muhūrta or 160 mātras.5 1) Br. IV. 34. 70.
2) Vā. 30. 13; 70. 15; M. 34. 9.
3) Vā. 100.
216.
4) Vā. 57. 6; 100. 218; Vi. I. 3. 8; II. 8. 59; VI. 3. 6.
5) Vā. 50. 179; 93. 72; Br. II. 7. 19; 13. 14.
text.2647:
Kalas (II) — a Janapada of the Ketumāla country.
Vā. 44. 15.
text.2648:
Kalas (III) — Digits of Soma recovered by propitiating
Dakṣa:1 one-sixteenth part. 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 24; M. 34. 9; 142. 4.
text.2650:
Kalā (II) — a daughter of Kardama married to Marīci;
bore two sons, Kaśyapa and Pūrṇiman.
Bhā. III. 24. 22; IV. 1. 13.
text.2652:
Kalāpa (II) — a forest where Ikṣvāku was addressed by
Pitṛs.
Vi. III. 16. 17.
text.2653:
Kalāpagrāma — on the East slopes of the Himalayas1
noted for great sages.2 Residence of Manu. Here Devāpi [and
Puru (Manu) Vi. P.] continued their yoga practice. These
yogins would start the course of Varṇāśrama dharma again
at the end of Kali;3 watered by the Ganges.4 Devāpi and
Manu originate Kṣatriya clans in Kṛta yuga at; the race of
Manu responsible for rulers throughout the three ages, Kṛta,
Tretā and Dvāpara.5 Manu stands rooted to yoga at.6 1) Vā. 1. 189; 41. 43-6; 47, 47.
2) Bhā. X. 87. 7.
3) IX. 12. 6;
22. 17; XII. 2. 37-38; Br. I. 1. 164; III. 63. 210; 66. 7; M. 121. 49;
273. 56.
4) Br. II. 18. 50.
5) Vā. 88. 210: 91. 7: 99. 437; Vi. IV.
24. 118-121.
6) Vi. IV. 4. 109.
text.2654:
Kali (I) — born of Krodha and Hīmsā. Married Durukti
who gave birth to Bhaya and Mṛtyu.1 Personified as king
but Śūdra by birth, kicking a cow and bull. Vanquished
by Parīkṣit. Kali fell at his feet when Parīkṣit asked him
to leave Brahmāvarta. Asked for a place to reside, Parīk
ṣit appointed him to five unrighteous spheres — wine, dice,
gold, women and slaughter. Father of adharma, heroic in
the midst of children and cowardly before the valiant.2 His
rule in yugāntara described.3 1) Bhā. IV. 8. 3.
2) Ib. I. 16. 4; 17. 29-40; 18. 6-8.
3) Ib. II.
7. 38.
text.2655:
Kali (II) — a Mauneya Gandharva; a son of Brahma
dhana.
Br. III. 7. 4; Vā. 69. 3, 133.
text.2656:
Kali (III) — a son of Varuṇa and Śunādevī (Sāmudri
Vā. P.); father of Jaya and Vijaya; one wife of Kali, Surā,
mother of Mada; other wives, Tvāṣṭri, Himsā and Nikṛti;
other sons of Kali, all cannibals, Nāka, Vighna, Śadrama and
Vidhama.
Br. III. 59. 6; Vā. 84. 6-10.
text.2657:
Kali (IV) — a door-keeper of Mahākāla.
Br. IV. 32. 18.
text.2658:
Kaliṅga (I) — a Kṣetraja son of Bali; after him came
Kaliṅgas (s.v.);1 a Rākṣasa in the Atalam. (Tatvalam
Br. P.).2 1) Br. III. 74. 28 & 87; M. 48. 25; Vā. 99. 28; Vi. IV. 18.
13-14.
2) Vā. 50. 17; Br. II. 19. 18.
text.2659:
Kaliṅga (II) — (Mt.) a hill on the south of the Mānasa.
Vā. 36. 22; 42. 28.
text.2660:
Kaliṅga (III) — a southern kingdom of madhyadeśa unfit
for śrāddha; a Janapada of the Dakṣiṇāpatha. Its king was
stationed by Jarāsandha on the east gate of Mathurā, and on
the same direction during the siege of Gomanta;1 present at
Pradyumna's marriage. Advised Rukmin to vanquish
Balarāma in dice, and laughed at the latter when he was
defeated. His teeth were broken by Rāma.2 Its 32 kings.3
On its south flows the Narmadā where the hill Amarakaṇ
ṭaka is.4 In the Kṛtayuga, the first man appeared in this
country5 under Guhas.6 1) Br. II. 16. 42 & 57; III. 13. 13; 14. 33 & 80; 74. 198 & 213;
M. 163. 72; Vā. 77. 13; 78. 23; 99. 324, 386, 402.
2) Bhā. X. 50.
11[2]; 52. 11[5]; 61. 27-29; 32[1] & 37; IV. 5. 21; Vi. V. 28. 10,
15, 24.
3) M. 272. 16.
4) M. 186. 12.
5) Vā. 58. 110.
6) Vi.
III. 7. 36.
text.2661:
Kaliṅgas — a tribe born of Dīrghatamas and Bali's wife;
enlisted by Jarāsandha against the Yadus;1 people of the
Dakṣiṇāpatha.2 1) Bhā. IX. 23. 5; X. [50 (V) 3]; M. 114. 36 and 47; Vā. 45. 125.
2) Vā. 45. 125; Vi. II. 3. 16.
text.2663:
Kaliyuga — the features of the yuga, and its discontents.
Removed by hearing the story of Kṛṣṇa, as the Ṛṣis did in
the Naimiṣa forest. The source of unrighteousness.1 Form
of Hari worshipped in.2 Reflections on the conduct of
castes and observance of dharma by persons. Kali becomes
Kṛta after the avatār of Kalki. When the Saptaṛṣis traverse
Maghas, and on the day when Kṛṣṇa left the earth for
Heaven then began Kali of 1200 divine years. Grows in
strength commencing with Nanda. The actual beginning
was when Kṛṣṇa left for Vaikuṇṭha; a description of the
yuga. Worship of Hari by Kīrtana.3 Its advent was
recognised by Mucukunda from the smallness of the men,
plants, trees, etc., which he saw after he woke up from his
long sleep.4
Deterioration of Vedic dharma and rise of Pākhaṇḍas.
Incarnation of Pramati in the form of a horse who puts down
all heretics and the unrighteous.5 Predominance of here
tics and Śūdras in;6 106,000 or 360,000-duration of; its san-
dhyāmśa 1,000 years.7 Noted for theft; see Tṛṣyam;8
dānam the chief act and tamas the chief quality.9 descrip
tion of the evils of: bad rule and decay of civilization and
morality; age of man 23 years; began with Parīkṣit when
the two first stars of seven Ṛṣis were in Magha; its duration
according to the calculation of men 360,800. Then comes
Kṛta.10 1) Bhā. I. 1. 10, 16 & 21; 12. 26; 15. 36-7; XI. 5. 20, 31-42;
Vā. 58. 30-73.
2) M. 142. 17-27; 273. 49; Vā. 99. 429.
3) Bhā. XII.
chap. 2 & 3.
4) Ib. X. 52. 2.
5) Br. II. 29. 23-34; 31. 5-102; III. 14.
46. 74. 207-241; M. 144. 30-88.
6) Vā. 78. 36.
7) Vā. 32. 63;
99. 264; 102. 4. M. 273. 27-33, 45. 50.
8) Br. II. 7. 59.
9) Vā. 8.
66.
10) Vi. IV. 24. 71-96, 97, 109. 114-15.
text.2664:
Kalila — son of Soma.
Br. III. 3. 23; Vā. 66. 23.
text.2666:
Kalisparśas — a degraded Kṣatriya community.
Br. III. 63. 140.
text.2667:
Kalopanata — Music; Māruta, the presiding deity.
Vā. 86. 52.
text.2668:
Kalki — the 21st (10th Vā.) avatār of Hari, in Kaliyuga
and emperor of the world by name Pārāśraya with Yājña
valkya as Purohita. Born of a Brāhmaṇa Viṣṇuyaśas in
Śambalagrāma. His horse would be known as Devadatta.
Riding on it, Kalki would rid the earth of the unrighteous
and implant dharma again.1 Invoked;2 destroyer of Kṣa
triyas who became mlecchas by character.3 State of the
world then.4 According to the Br. Purāṇa, his name is
Viṣnuyāśas, and son of Parāśara: the tenth incarnation of
Hari, with Purohita Yājñavalkya. After rooting out
adharma with Brāhmaṇa warriors he gives up his ghost at
the confluence of the Gaṅgā and the Yamunā; in the pre
vious birth was Pramiti; would bring round all tribes and
wander the world unseen; except vegetation; his life of
25 years' duration and of Parāśara gotra; then again
adharma, disease, etc., at the end of Kali and commence
ment of the Kṛta yuga.5 Purify the Śūdras, cross the ocean
and destroy sinners. Then will follow civil strife and the
disorder of the world.6 1) Bhā. I. 3. 25; XII. 2. 18-23; M. 273. 27; 285. 7; Vi. IV. 24.
98-101.
2) Bhā. VI. 8. 19.
3) Ib. X. 40. 22.
4) Vā. 99. 390-411; 424-29.
5) Br. III. 73. 104-24; 74. 206; IV. 29. 133; M. 47. 248-62; Vā. 98.
104-17.
6) M. 54. 19.
text.2669:
Kalkivāhana — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 79.
text.2670:
Kalpa (I) — a son of Dhruva and Bhramī.
Bhā. IV. 10. 1.
text.2672:
Kalpa (III) — the period of fourteen Manus or 1000
yugas followed by pralaya;1 in the day Brahmā; in the night
Nārāyaṇa sleeping over his couch Śeṣa the thirty kalpas and
the thirty days of Brahmā. These are mixed, Tāmasa,
rājasa and sātvika2 from klipu, to introduce with intelli
gence; the fourteen samsthas Brahmā introduced and hence
kalpa;3 twenty-eight in number, each of two kalpārdhas;4
the 14 kalpas made by Brahmā and hence the name.5 1) Bhā. II. 8. 12; IV. 9. 14; XII. 4. 2-3; Br. IV. 1. 116, 173
and 210; Vi. III. 2. 50-2; VI. 3. 12.
2) M. 290. 1-16.
3) Vā. 7.
77; 21. 28ff.
4) Vā. 21. 17-18; 22. 7; 30. 231: 59. 138; 61. 54 and
102.
5) Br. II. 6. 74.
text.2673:
Kalpakavāṭi(ka) — a division of Śrīpuram.
Br. IV. 31. 67; 32. 21 & 65.
text.2676:
Kalpam — ritual literature; part of Viṣṇu.
Vi. V. 1. 37.
text.2677:
Kalpalatātmakam — a gift of ten golden creepers of a
Kalpa tree, leads one to Heaven.
M. 274. 9; 286. 1-17.
text.2678:
Kalpavarṣa — a son of Vasudeva and Upadevā.
Bhā. IX. 24. 51.
text.2679:
Kalpavṛkṣa — a divine tree;1 gift of a golden tree, leads
one to be born Rājarāja after a sojourn in Viṣnuloka;2 gave
clothes, jewels and honey in the Kṛtayuga.3 1) Br. IV. 15. 37; 28. 72.
2) M. 277. 1-22.
3) Vā. 8. 93;
106. 74.
text.2680:
Kalpavratam — leads to the world of Brahmā.
M. 101. 50.
text.2681:
Kalpaśuddhi — a part of the Purāṇas.
Vi. III. 6. 15.
text.2682:
Kalpasūtras — a branch of Vedic literature, arranged by
Lomaharṣaṇa;1 begun in Dvāpara.2 1) Br. II. 31. 14 & 24; 34. 16; Vā. 58. 14.
2) M. 144. 13-14.
text.2683:
Kalpā — a door-keeper of Mahākāla.
Br. IV. 32. 18.
text.2684:
Kalmāṣapāda (I) — a king who was cursed by Śakti in
Naimiṣa which resulted in the enmity between Vasisṭha
and Viśvāmitra.
Vā. 2. 11; Br. I. 2. 11.
text.2685:
Kalmāṣapāda (II) — another name is Mitrasaha. See
Saudāsa: son of Ṛtuparṇa.
Br. III. 63. 176; M. 12. 46; Vā. 88. 176; Vi. IV. 4. 57.
text.2687:
Kalyāṇasaptamī — in honour of the Sun for 13 months
M. 74. 2-16.
text.2689:
Kalyāṇī (II) — the goddess enshrined at Malaya hill: a
follower of Māyā.
M. 13. 36; 179. 70.
text.2690:
Kalyāṇinī — the vow of; in later kalpa changed into
Bhīmadvādaśī after being observed by Bhīmasena, the
Pāṇḍava.
M. 69. 56-7.
text.2691:
Kallola — a son of Saramā, and father of four sons.
Br. III. 7. 441.
text.2695:
Kavaṣa — a sage and father of Tura. Invited for
Yudhiṣṭhira's sacrifice; came to see Parīkṣit practising prā-
yopaveśa.
Bhā. IX. 22. 37; X. 74. 7; I. 19. 10.
text.2696:
Kavi (I) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Kālindī.
Bhā. X. 61. 14; 90. 34.
text.2697:
Kavi (II) — a son of Dakṣinā and Yajña; a Tuṣita god.
Bhā. IV. 1. 7-8.
text.2698:
Kavi (III) a son of Bhṛgu (Prāṇa — Burnouf) and
father of the great Śukrācārya.
Bhā. IV. 1. 45.
text.2699:
Kavi (IV) — a son of Prīyavrata and Barhiṣmati. Re
mained a bachelor all life, being engaged in ātmavidyā.
Bhā. V. 1. 25-26.
text.2700:
Kavi (V) — a son of Ṛṣabha and a bhāgavata. A sage
who expounded to Nimi the Bhāgavata dharma.
Bhā. V. 4. 11; XI. 2. 21, 33-43[1].
text.2701:
Kavi (VI) — a surname of Brahmā.
Bhā. VII. 9. 34.
text.2702:
Kavi (VII) — a son of Śrāddradeva and Śraddhā.
Bhā. IX. 1. 12.
text.2703:
Kavi (VIII) — a son of Vaivasvata Manu. Left kingdom
and its pleasures, and became devoted to Hari. Attained
Parabrahman at an early age.
Bhā. IX. 1. 12; 2. 15.
text.2704:
Kavi (IX) — a son of Duritakṣaya.
Bhā. IX. 21. 19.
text.2705:
Kavi (X) — is Uśīrāgni; the Agni who married Svadhā;
after him came Kāvyas.
Br. III. 10. 85; Vā. 29. 29.
text.2706:
Kavi (XI) — the father of Bhautya.
Br. IV. 1. 51.
text.2707:
Kavi (XII) — a god of Sutāra group.
Br. IV. 1. 89.
text.2708:
Kavi (XIII) — a sage of the Tāmasa epoch; a mantrakṛt.
M. 9. 15; 145. 103.
text.2709:
Kavi (XIV) — one of the seven sons of Kauśika.
B. 20. 3.
text.2710:
Kavi (XV) — the son of Urukṣava and Viśālā, became
a Brāhmaṇa, and one of the three best maharṣis among the
Kāvyas.
M. 49. 39.
text.2711:
Kavi (XVI) — a son of Śveta; avatār of the 23rd dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 205.
text.2712:
Kavis — sons of, originators of Pitṛs with forms; their
daughter Gauh belonging to dvija gaṇa.
Vā. 73. 35-36.
text.2713:
Kaviratha — son of Citraratha and father of Vṛṣṭimat
Kaviruta-Vā. P.).
Bhā. IX. 22. 40-41; Vā. 62. 18.
text.2716:
Kavyavāha — a kind of Agni.
Br. III. 11. 93.
text.2717:
Kavyavāhana — the son of Pavamāna Agni; the Agni of
Pitṛs.
Br. II. 12. 4 and 5; Vā. 29. 4, 5; 75. 56, 70; 110. 10.
text.2719:
Kavyāgni — a kind of sacred fire.
Vā. 56. 4.
text.2720:
Kavyādas — a class of Pitṛs.
Br. III. 72. 26.
text.2722:
Kaśūra — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 85.
text.2723:
Kaśeru(mat) — a division of Bhāratavarṣa.
M. 114. 8; Bhā. II. 16. 9.
text.2724:
Kaśeru — approached by Keśidhvaja to give him a
form of expiation.
Vi. VI. 6. 15.
text.2725:
Kaśmīra — a city;1 people of.2 1) Vā. 99. 402.
2) Vā. 45. 120; 47. 45.
text.2726:
Kaśyapa (I) — (Savituḥ Vidvān, Mārīci) son of Marīci
and Kalā, and husband of Diti.1 Married twelve (thirteen
Matsya P.) daughters of Dakṣa, who were Brahmavādinīs
and Loka-mātas. Married also Pulomā and Kālakā on the
advice of Brahmā. Their sons were Dānavas distinguished
for warlike qualities. 60,000 of these were killed by Arjuna
while in Heaven to please Indra.2 Aditi was another wife
of Kaśyapa, and was the mother of Vāmana-Hari. On an
appeal from her on behalf of gods exiled from Amarāvatī,
Kaśyapa taught her the payovrata to please Hari.3 Pleased
with the anointing of Vāmana.4 His tejas.5 Pleased with
Diti's Madanadvādaśivratam but did not relish her request
for a son to slay Indra but granted it under certain condi
tions.6 A sage of the Vaivasvata epoch. His descendants.7
Father of Vivasvat.8 Awarded Madhyadeśā by Paraśu
rāma.9 Visited with pupils Bhīṣma on his death-bed;10 goes
round Dhruva.11 See Diti, Indra.
A Brahmavādin and a Prajāpati. A Devaṛṣi. His sons
were Nārada and Parvata, as also Ādityas, Maruts and
Rudras.12 An amśa of Brahmā.13
When Dakṣa grew angry on account of his daughter
Kaśyapa drank Kaśya, a kind of wine;14 hence his name;
hid yoga in a cave;15 āśrama of;16 a sage by jñāna;17 place in
the Viśvacakra dāna.18 With the sun during the months
Saha and Sahasya,19 a sage of Cākṣuṣa epoch.20 1) Bhā. III. 14. 7; IV. 1. 13; Br. II. 37. 44; III. 2. 31; 3. 55;
IV. 1. 20; 2. 33. 47; M. 146. 16 & 25; 171. 30; 199. 1, 14, 19; Vā.
63. 41.
2) Bhā. VI. 6. 2, 25, 34-36; M. 4. 55; 5. 13; 6. 1-2, 44;
Vā. 65. 115-116, 157-158.
3) Bhā. VIII. 13. 6; 16. 2-25; 17. 22-3:
X. 3. 42; Br. II. 13. 79.
4) Bhā. VIII. 23. 21; M. 244. 41; 245. 82.
5) Bhā. III. 16. 35-36; 17. 2.
6) Bhā. VI. 18. 44-54: III. chap. 14
(whole); M. 7. 30-49.
7) Bhā. VIII. 8. 31; 13. 5; M. 9. 27.
8) Bhā.
IX. 1. 10; M. 11. 2.
9) Bhā. IX. 16. 22.
10) Ib. I. 9. 8.
11) Bhā.
IV. 9. 21; M. 127. 24;
12) Br. II. 27. 104; 32. 98, 112; 35. 92-95:
38. 3; III. 1. 53; 4. 34; 8. 1 and 27; M. 145. 92; Vā. 1. 138; 3. 2:
65. 53; 84. 26 and 31.
13) M. 47. 9; Br. III. 2. 105; 71. 238; Vā. 1.
138; 3. 2; 65. 114.
14) Vā. 65. 115-17.
15) Br. I. 1. 117; Vā. 83.
83; Br. III. 19. 53.
16) Vā. 37. 22.
17) Ib. 59. 90.
18) M. 285. 6.
19) Ib. 127. 17.
20) Vā. 62. 66.
text.2727:
Kaśyapa (II) — a sage and contemporary of Kṛṣṇa. In
vited for Yudhiṣṭhira's Rājasūya.1 Came to Syamantapañ
caka to see Kṛṣṇa;2 one of the sages who left for Piṇḍāraka;3
met by Takṣaka on his way to Parīkṣit.4 1) Bhā. X. 74. 9.
2) Ib. X. 84. 4.
3) Ib. XI. 1. 12.
4) Ib.
XII. 6. 11.
text.2728:
Kaśyapa (III) — a Paurāṇika who learnt mūlasamhitā
from the disciple of Vyāsa.
Bhā. XII. 7. 5 and 7.
text.2729:
Kaśyapa (IV) — the sage presiding over the month of
Saha;1 with the sun in Hemantaka.2 1) Bhā. XII. 11. 41.
2) Vā. 52. 16.
text.2730:
Kaśyapa (V) — (Ṛṣyaśṛṇga) a sage of the first epoch of
Sāvarṇi Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 11.
text.2731:
Kaśyapa (VI) — a sage of the Svārociṣa epoch.
M. 9. 8.
text.2732:
Kaśyapa (VII) — a sage resorting to Śuklatīrtha.
M. 192. 10.
text.2733:
Kaśyapakalpa — author of, a master of Atharvasamhita.
Bhā. XII. 7. 4.
text.2734:
Kaśyapapadam — in Gayā;1 performance of śrāddha at
by Bharadvāja.2 1) Vā. 109. 18.
2) Vā. 111. 49 and 58.
text.2735:
Kaśyapātmajas — Ādityas, Maruts and the Rudras.
Vā. 64. 3.
text.2738:
Kaseru — one of the nine divisions of the Bhāratavarṣa.
Vā. 45. 79, 119; Vi. II. 3. 6.
text.2740:
Kāṃsyam — fit to be a milking vessel and for a gift with
a cow.
M. 16. 26 & 32; 57. 20; 205. 2.
text.2741:
Kāka (I) — (Mt.) a hill touching the sea.
Br. II. 18. 76.
text.2742:
Kāka (II) — a bird; a vāhana of Sūcīmukha.
Br. III. 7. 455; IV. 24. 44.
text.2743:
Kākabali — the vāyasa in Aindra, Vāruṇa, Vāyavya and
Nairṛta directions.
Vā. 111. 40.
text.2744:
Kākavarṇa — son of Śiśunāga, (bha) and father of Kse
madharman. Ruled for 36 years (26 years-Matsya P.).
Bhā. XII. 1. 5; Br. III. 74. 129; M. 272. 7; Vi. IV. 24. 10. 11.
text.2745:
Kākaśilā — in Gayā, releases one from debts.
Vā. 108. 76.
text.2746:
Kākaḥṛdam — a place fit for performing śrāddha.
Br. III. 13. 85.
text.2747:
Kākiṇika — a coin of small value.
Bhā. XII. 3. 41.
text.2748:
Kākustha — the father of Gau who was married to Yati.
Br. III. 68. 13; Vā. 93. 14.
text.2749:
Kākṣivaḥ — a son of Jaṭāmāli, an avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 187.
text.2750:
Kākṣīvat — a son born to the waiting woman of Sudeṣṇā
and Dīrghaṭamas. By austerities at Girivraja, reached
Brāhmaṇahood. Father of 1000 sons by name Kauṣmāṇḍas
and Gautamas.
M. 48. 63, 84-8.
text.2752:
Kācalas — a Janapada of the Ketumāla Continent.
Vā. 44. 15.
text.2754:
Kāñcana (I) — the son of Bhīma, and father of Hotraka
(Suhotra-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 15. 3; Vi. IV. 7. 3.
text.2756:
Kāñcanakā — the capital city of Pravīra.
Br. III. 74. 184.
text.2758:
Kāñcanaprabha — a son of Bhīma the king and father
of Subdha.
Br. III. 66. 24; Vā. 91. 53.
text.2759:
Kāñcī (I) — a R. in the Ketumāla continent.
M. 44. 18.
text.2760:
Kāñcī (II) — a R. of the Bhadrā.
Vā. 43. 25.
text.2761:
Kāñcī (III) — visited by Balarāma;1 visited by Agastya;
also Vāraṇaśailendra and Ekāmranilaya. Viṣṇu Hayagrīva
appeared before Agastya.2 A Vaiṣṇava kṣetra with Śiva
Sānnidhyam. Prayers of Brahmā, to Lakṣmī and Viṣṇu
requested to reside here. Here were celebrated. Śiva's
marriage, Brahma's with Vāṇī, and Viṣṇu with Kamalā.
But Brahmā subsequently left this.3 1) Bhā. X. 79. 14.
2) Br. IV. 5. 6-10; 7-10.
3) Ib. IV. 39
(whole): 40. 16, 59, 82-91.
text.2762:
Kāṃjanakā — city and capital of Pravīra.
Vā. 99. 371.
text.2765:
Kāṇṭhāyanadvijas — the class of Brāhmaṇas from Me
dhātithi, son of Kaṇṭha.
Vā. 99. 131.
text.2766:
Kāṇva — a disciple of Yājñavalkya.
Vi. III. 5. 30.
text.2767:
Kāṇvas — a branch of Aṅgirasa;1 learnt the Vājasani
yajus.2 1) Vā. 65. 106.
2) Bhā. XII. 6. 74; M. 200. 9.
text.2768:
Kāṇvam — the sūktam of the Sama Vedins recited in
tank ritual.
M. 58. 37.
text.2769:
Kāṇvamudgalas — the Maudgalyas of the Aṅgirasa line.
M. 50. 5.
text.2770:
Kāṇvāyaṇas (I) — the clan of Brāhmaṇas from Kaṇva,
son of Ajamīḍha; a pravara of Aṅgiras.
M. 49. 47; 196. 21.
text.2771:
Kāṇvāyanas (II) — a ruling dynasty: commencing with
Vāsudeva, ruled the earth for 345 years;1 in number nine:
called Śurya bhṛtyas. These ruled from 40 to 45 years and
were Brāhmaṇas. They had their own Sāmantas.2 1) Bhā. XII. 1. 21.
2) M. 272. 33-7.
text.2772:
Kātya — a sage of the Tāmasa epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 18.
text.2773:
Kātyāyana (I) — a ṛtvik at Brahmā's yajña.
Vā. 106. 37.
text.2776:
Kātyāyanī — Image of; ten hands, three eyes, youthful,
killing Mahiṣāsura, and riding the lion.
M. 260. 55-66.
text.2777:
Kātyāyanī Vratam — was observed by the girls of the
Vraja early in the season of Hemanta. After bathing in
the Yamunā, they made a figure of the Devī with sand,
and worshipped it as the representation of the Devī for a
month. Their object was to win Kṛṣṇa as their husband.
Prayers were also sent to Bhadrakālī by rising early and
bathing in the Yamunā. To test their sincerity Kṛṣṇa saw
them one day playing in the river naked leaving their clothes
on the banks. He removed these to the top of a Nīpa tree
near by. The girls asked for the return of their clothes, and
threatened to report to the king. Kṛṣṇa asked them to receive
their clothes from him. He said that their vow was fruitless
as they bathed naked, and he returned their clothes on their
saluting him with both their arms. He then blessed them
and asked them to go back to the Vraja which they did.
Bhā. X. 22. 1-27.
text.2779:
Kādraveyas — a class of snakes with several heads men
tioned in verses;1 subject to Garuḍa; Śeṣa, Vāsuki and others
belong to this group.2 1) Vā. 52. 20; 62. 180; 69. 74; Br. III. 7. 31.
2) Vi. I. 21. 20, 21.
text.2780:
Kādrupiṅgākṣi — a Kaśyapa and a Trayārṣeya.
M. 199. 13.
text.2781:
Kānanasthalī — a fearful forest between the hills Puṣ
pakaśaila and Mahāmegha.
Vā. 38. 71-8.
text.2782:
Kānīna — the son of Devadatta alias Agniveśya. He was
the sage Jātūkarṇija (Jātukarṇa-Burnouf). He was a mani
festation of Fire God. With him originated the Brahma
kula-Āgniveśyāyana.
Bhā. IX. 2. 21-22.
text.2783:
Kāninī — a pupil of Kṛta.
Br. II. 35. 53.
text.2784:
Kānta — one of the ten branches of the Sukarmaṇa group
of devas.
Br. IV. 1. 88; Vā. 100. 93.
text.2787:
Kāntipuram — The sacred pool of, protected by Kirātas.
Br. III. 13. 95-7.
text.2788:
Kāntivratam — leads to the world of Viṣṇu.
M. 101. 45.
text.2789:
Kānyakubja — a city of Ajāmila.1 Its citizens were van
quished by Paraśurāma;2 sacred to Gaurī.3 1) Bhā. VI. 1. 21.
2) Br. III. 39. 11; 41. 39; IV. 44. 94.
3) M. 13. 29.
text.2790:
Kāpālik(n)as — a heretical sect;1 their yoga.2 1) Br. II. 31. 65; Vā. 58-64.
2) Br. II. 27. 116.
text.2791:
Kāpileyas — the Daitya-rākṣasas from the Daitya king
Kumbha.
Vā. 69. 177.
text.2792:
Kāpeya — addressed Sūta to explain creation.
Br. II. 6. 1.
text.2793:
Kāma (I) — God of Love (s.v.); born of Brahmā's heart.
Burnt by Śiva, was reborn as Pradyumna, son of Kṛṣṇa, an
aṃśa of Vāsudeva.1 Sent by Indra to spoil Nara's penance;2
to induce Śiva to marry Umā.3 For having observed Vibhū-
tidvādaśīvratam, Anaṅgavatī the courtesan became co-wife
with Rati, and her name was Prīti.4 Icon of.5 Worshipped
Śiva in Siddheśvaram and attained divinity again.6 His
arrow afflicted Brahmā who was made to love his own
daughter, cursed by Brahmā to be burnt by Rudra; when
pointed out that he only discharged his duty, he modified
the curse to be born as son of Kṛṣṇa, then of Vasu in
Bharata line, to get overlordship of Vidyādharas and finally
attain godhood; afflicted the nine devīs.7 1) Bhā. III. 12. 26; VIII. 7. 32; X. 55. [2]; Vi. V. 27. 28.
2) Bhā.
XI. 4. 7.
3) M. 154. 209-239.
4) M. 7. 13; 100. 329.
5) M. 261. 53-6.
6) M. 191. 110.
7) M. 3. 33; 4. 12-21; 23. 23.
text.2794:
Kāma (II) — a son of Samkalpa.
Bhā. VI. 6. 10.
text.2796:
Kāma (IV) — the son of Śraddhā and Dharma and father
of Harṣa (joy) through his wife Rati (Siddhi-Br. P.).
Br. II. 9. 58, 62; Vā. 10. 34, 38.
text.2797:
Kāma (V) — the Apsaras clan of Sobhayantya, originat
ed from.
Br. III. 7. 24; Vā. 69. 58.
text.2798:
Kāma (VI) — place of, in life;1 does not end in spite of
bhoga or enjoyment, but grows like fire with oblation; cf.
Rāmāyaṇa; notwithstanding old age desire to live and to
amass wealth does not go.2 1) Bhā. I. 2. 9-10;
2) Vā. 93. 95, 100.
text.2800:
Kāmakoṭigā — a name of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 18. 16.
text.2801:
Kāmakoṣṭha (ka) — also Kāmagiri. A piṭham sacred
to Kāmākṣī.
Br. IV. 40. 1; 44. 94.
text.2802:
Kāmakoṣṇī — the deity residing in Kāñcī.
Bhā. X. 79. 14.
text.2803:
Kāmagamas — gods of the eleventh epoch of Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 25; Vi. III. 2. 30.
text.2804:
Kāmagiri — a Mt. in Bhāratavarṣa; is Kāñcī, also
Kāmākṣiśilā.
Bhā. V. 19. 16; Br. IV. 39. 105.
text.2806:
Kāmadughā — a daughter of Rohiṇi gave birth to cattle
kingdom;1 had two sons.2 1) Br. III. 3. 74-5.
2) Vā. 66. 72.
text.2808:
Kāmadeva (I) — the form in which Hari reveals him
self to Lakṣmī in the continent of Ketumāla.1 Fought with
Durmarṣa in a Devāsura war.2 Overlord of all Apsaras and
Ṛtus3 (see Kāma); as part of the gift of Kalpapādapa.4 1) Bhā. V. 18. 15.
2) Ib. VIII. 10. 33.
3) Br. III. 8. 15.
4) M.
277. 6. Vā. 70. 14.
text.2809:
Kāmadeva (II) — the son of Yaśodharā (Yaśodhāri
Vā. P.).
Br. II. 11. 35; Vā. 28. 30.
text.2810:
Kāmadhenu (I) — a goddess following Revatī;1 gift of.2 1) M. 179. 73.
2) Ib. 279. 4; 106. 74.
text.2811:
Kāmadhenu (II) — Jamadagni's cow providing hospita
lity to Haihaya hosts; bound by king's servants, she kicked
off its shackles and flew in the air.
Br. III. 26. 54.
text.2813:
Kāmapāla — joined Yadus in defeating Pauṇḍraka.
Bhā. X. 66. [2].
text.2816:
Kāmarūpa (c) — the eastern country; sacred to Lalitā.
Br. IV. 44. 93; Vi. II. 3. 15.
text.2820:
Kāmalā — a goddess enshrined at Kamalālaya.
M. 13. 32.
text.2824:
Kāmaśāstra — In Sairandhri's house there were pictures
drawn according to prescriptions of Kāmaśāstra:1 a treatise
by Bābhravya, a Pāñcāla.2 1) Bhā. X. 48. [2]; M. 220. 2.
2) M. 21. 30.
text.2825:
Kāmaśiva — another name for Kāmeśvara.
Br. IV. 15. 16.
text.2827:
Kāmākṣī — the goddess enshrined in Kāñcī; Ādilakṣmī:
said to possess one eye at Kāñcī and the other at Kāsi: also
Mahālakṣmī;1 enshrined at Gandhamādana.2 1) Br. IV. 5. 7; 13. 1; 15. 35; 38. 81; 30. 5, 14 & 21; 40. 1, 16,
85-105.
2) M. 13. 26.
text.2828:
Kāmacāriṇī — a goddess enshrined at Mandara hill.
M. 13. 28.
text.2830:
Kāmikam Vratam — this seems to refer to Pāśupata-
yogam.
Br. II. 27. 127.
text.2832:
Kāminī — a group of women who came from the mouth
of Asura Bala when he yawned.
Bhā. V. 24. 16.
text.2833:
Kāmeśī — is Lalitā; one of the 15 Akṣara devīs.
Br. IV. 13. 2; 18. 15; 19. 52, 57; 37. 21.
text.2835:
Kāmeśvarī — is Kāmeśī; a nitya devī.
Br. IV. 15-35; 18. 9; 25. 56; 29. 145; 37. 33; 44. 141.
text.2837:
Kāmpilya (I) — a son of Bhramyāśva.
Bhā. IX. 21. 32.
text.2838:
Kāmpilya (II) — a fifth son of Bheda.
Vā. 99. 196.
text.2839:
Kāmpilya (III) — a son of Haryaśva.
Vi. IV. 19. 59.
text.2840:
Kāmpilyā — the capital of Samara;1 the kingdom of.2 1) Vā. 99. 176.
2) Vi. IV. 19. 40.
text.2841:
Kāmbhojas — a northern kingdom noted for horses.1
Their king Sudakṣiṇa was an ally of Jarāsandha and placed
on the East of the Gomanta hill, during its siege.2 Took
part in the Rājasūya of Yudhiṣṭhira. Their king went to
Syamanta pañcaka for solar eclipse.3 Defeated by Paraśu
rāma and by Sagara who had them fully shaved as punish
ment.4 1) Br. II. 16. 49; IV. 16. 16; Vā. 88. 122; Vi. V. 29. 32.
2) Bhā. X. 52. 11[7].
3) Ib. X. 75. 12; 82. 13.
4) Br. III. 41. 39;
48. 22 & 44; 63. 120, 134 & 138; Vi. IV. 3. 42.
text.2842:
Kāmyā — a daughter of Kardama and Śruti; married
Priyavrata; mother of ten sons equal to Svāyambhuva and
two daughters by whom Kṣatram came into being.
Br. II. 11. 32-34; 14. 44; Vā. 27-9.
text.2843:
Kāyani — a Pravara of the Bhārgavas.
M. 195. 31.
text.2844:
Kāyāvardhanam — a tīrtham sacred to Mātā, Pitṛs and
to Śiva.
M. 13. 48; 22-30; 181. 26.
text.2846:
Kāraṇa — the lord who is nirguṇa and Brahmā becomes
karṇātmā after its conjunction with Prakṛti and a saguṇa.
Vā. 49. 151. etc.
text.2847:
Kāraṇam (I) — a term for Jīva or Prāṇa.
Vā. 102. 101.
text.2848:
Kāraṇam (II) — a name for avyaktam.
Vi. I. 2. 19.
text.2849:
Kārapatha — the capital of Aṅgadiya deśa of Lakṣmaṇa's
son Aṅgada.
Vā. 88. 188.
text.2850:
Kārayana — the capital city of Aṅgada, son of Lakṣ
maṇa.
Br. III. 63. 189.
text.2852:
Kāraskaras — the kingdom of, unfit for śrāddha: a
southern tribe.
Br. III. 14. 33 and 80; M. 114. 49; Vā. 78. 23 and 69.
text.2856:
Kāru — a Mt. of the Bhāratavarṣa.
Vā. 45. 92.
text.2857:
Kārukas — unfit for śrāddha feeding.
Br. III. 15. 43; Vā. 79. 69.
text.2858:
Kārukarma — the svadarma of Śūdras.
Vi. VI. 1. 36.
text.2860:
Kārūṣa — a surname of Vṛddhaśarman, son of Karūṣa,
(who married Śrutadevā).
Bhā. IX. 24. 36.
text.2861:
Kārūṣās — descendants of Karūṣa, the son of Vaivasvata
Manu1 and, kings of Uttarāpatha; a Kṣatriya clan, the
country of.2 1) Bhā. IX. 2. 16; Br. III. 61. 2; M. 12. 24; 114. 48; Vi. IV.
1. 18.
2) Vi. II. 3. 17; IV. 14. 39.
text.2863:
Kārkoṭaka — with the sun during the month of Pauṣa.
Vi. II. 10. 14.
text.2864:
Kārtavīryārjuna — a prominent king of the lunar line.
See Arjuna.
Vi. IV. 6. 4.
text.2866:
Kārttika — Navami and Dvādaśī, as yugādis for śrāddha.
M. 17. 4.
text.2867:
Kārttikeya (Guha) (I) — a god with his vāhana as
peacock; conqueror of Krauñca of Asuras; also Kumāra;1
brought up by the Kṛttikas;2 delight to the mind of Umā;3
overheard the report given by his father to Pārvati on the sub
ject of the colour of his throat, the Nīlakaṇṭha legend, when
he was lying down on the lap of Umā on the top of the Kai
lāsa hills.4 Took part in Bāṇa's war with Kṛṣṇa and dis
abled by Garuḍa and Pradyumna.5 1) Br. II. 25. 16; III. 10. 44; 32. 23; 41. 32; 42. 6; 43. 31.
2) Vā.
41. 38; 72. 43; Vi. I. 15. 116.
3) Vā. 54. 19.
4) Vā. 54. 28f.
5) Vi. V. 33. 21 and 26.
text.2868:
Kārttikeya (II) — Kumāra, being the son of Kṛttikas;
narrates the mahātmyam of Nandi in Nandīpurāṇa,1 born
in the full moon day of the citra month and Indra made sin
into one on the fifth day and on the sixth anointed Devasenā-
pati. All important gods gave him some present or other
and praised him.2 Promised to slay Tāraka and slew him.3
Image of; 12 hands in a city, four in a Kharvaṭa and two in
a village; one of the hands has a cock; others detailed.4 1) M. 5. 27; 53. 61.
2) Ib. 159. 4. 18.
3) Ib. 160. 10-26.
4) Ib.
260. 19, 45-51.
text.2869:
Kārttikeya (III) — (Pāvaki) a sage of the Rohita epoch.
Br. IV. 1. 62.
text.2870:
Kārttikeya (IV) — a tīrtham sacred to Yāśaskari.
M. 13. 45.
text.2874:
Kārttivīrya (II) — see Arjuna.
Br. III. 28. 25; 31. 3 & 5; 32. 61; 34. 3 & 30: M. 43. 15; Vi. IV.
11. 16.
text.2877:
Kārpāsaparvata — 20 bhārams of cotton as the best gift.
M. 83. 5; 88. 1-5.
text.2878:
Kārbūram — the colour of the 14th Manu Sāvarṇi.
Vā. 26. 46.
text.2882:
Kārṣāpaṇam — a coin in common use; fines in terms of.
M. 227. 79 & 93, 197.
text.2885:
Kāla (I) — time as the phase of the Universal Spirit.1
Is Īśvara, and only rūpabheda.2 Lord of creation and des
truction; fearful to look at.3 Vanquished by Kṛṣṇa;4 makes
and unmakes things by keeping all things under control.5 1) Bhā. I. 6. 4; 11. 6; 13. 45; II. 10. 43; VIII. 17. 27.
2) Ib. III.
12. 12; 29. 4, 37 & 45; X. 51. 19.
3) Ib. IV. 12. 3; Vā. 32. 11, 22.
4) Bhā. III. 3. 10; Br. III. 3. 82; Vā. 32. 29.
5) Vi. V. 38. 55-64.
text.2886:
Kāla (II) — a name for Mṛtyu: ety. as Lord of Death;
adhidevata for Rāhu the planet;1 described as having four
faces each comprising a yuga.2 One origin of.3 1) Br. II. 36. 128; M. 93. 14; 213. 5 & 18.
2) Vā. 32. 8-67.
3) Ib. 21. 52, 73.
text.2887:
Kāla (III) — a son of Dhanva; a Vasava; a Viśvedeva.
Br. III. 3. 23, 30; M. 5. 23; 203. 4; Vā. 66. 21, 31; Vi. I. 15. 111.
text.2889:
Kāla (V) — one from Brahman; see also Avyakta.
Vi. I. 2. 14, 15 and 27.
text.2890:
Kāla (VI) — a Mt. west of the Sitoda lake.
Vā. 36. 27.
text.2891:
Kāla (VII) — division of time — Paramāṇu defined:
2 Paramāṇus make 1 Aṇu
3 Aṇus make 1 Traṣareṇu
3 Trasareṇus make 1 Truti
100 Truṭis make 1 Vedhas
3 Vedhas make 1 lava
3 lavas make 1 Nimeṣa
3 Nimeṣas make 1 Kṣaṇa
5 Kṣanas make 1 Kāṣṭha
15 Kāṣṭhas make 1 laghu
15 laghus make 1 Nāḍika
2 Nāḍikas make 1 Muhūrta
6 or 7 Nāḍikas make 1 Prahara or Yāma
4 Yāmas make 1 day or night
15 days and nights make 1 Pakṣa
2 Pakṣas make 1 māsa or a day and night
for Pitṛs
2 Māsas make 1 Ṛtu
6 months make 1 Ayanam
2 Ayanams make 1 year
1 day of Brahmā make 1 period of 14 Manus
1 night of Brahmā make 1 period of Pralaya
1 Yuga make 5 years.1
based on Sūrya.2 1) Bhā. III. ch. 11 (whole); Br. II. 24. 58; 13. 109; Vā. 50.
179-82; 97. 30-31.
2) Vā. 31. 24; 53. 39.
text.2892:
Kālaka (I) — s son of Vijvara.
Br. III. 6. 33.
text.2895:
Kālakā — a daughter of Vaiśvānara, and a wife of
Kaśyapa;1 sons were Kālakeyas.2 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 33-34; M. 6. 22.
2) Vi. I. 21. 8-9.
text.2896:
Kālakas — kings (24) contemporaneous with Śisu
nāgas (10).
Br. III. 74. 136; Vā. 99. 323.
text.2897:
Kālakāma — one of the ten Viśvedevas.
M. 203. 13.
text.2898:
Kālakūṭam — poison from the churning of ocean of milk
by gods and asuras; swallowed by Śiva.
Br. II 25. 60; III. 25-9; IV. 23. 30; M. 250. 20-60; Vā. 54.
57-9, 63 and 95.
text.2899:
Kālakeyas — sons of Marīci, a dānava; vanquished by
Rāvaṇa and by Durgā;1 their mother is Kālā.2 Asuras in the
Devakūṭa hill.3 1) Br. III. 7. 255; IV. 29. 76; M. 6. 23; Vi. I. 21. 9.
2) M. 171.
59.
3) Vā. 40. 15.
text.2900:
Kālakośakas — country of, under Maṇidhānya kings.
(Cal. Edn. Kālatoya).
Vi. IV. 24. 66.
text.2901:
Kālakrita — a Veśya form of marriage.
Br. IV. 15. 4.
text.2904:
Kālacakra (II) — is the solar system: relativity of its
movement is illustrated by the Potter's wheel. The sun
stands in relation to Kālacakra, midway between the Earth
and Heaven. Placed on the right side of Meru, the twenty
eight nakṣatras including Abhijit are fixed on this cakra.1
The seat of Mahākāla.2 1) Bhā. V. 22. 2-11; 23. 3; M. 162, 1, 19; Vi. II. 8. 4.
2) Br.
IV. 32. 7. 18-20.
text.2907:
Kālañjara — Mt. on the north base of Meru. Here was
born Bharata as deer;1 sacred to Kālī.2 Here were reborn the
seven sons of Kauśika as deer; remembering their past birth,
they practised yoga;3 sacred to Pitṛs;4 the best of hills where
Śveta took his avatār (kālam jarayiṣyāmī).5 1) Bhā. V. 16. 26; 8-30; Br. III. 13. 100; Vi. II. 2. 30.
2) M. 13.
32.
3) Ib. 20. 15; 21. 9 and 28.
4) Ib. 22. 24; Vā. 77. 93.
5) Vā. 23.
204.
text.2909:
Kālatoyaka — a northern kingdom; a tribe;1 a Janapada
of Maṇidhānya.2 1) Br. II. 16. 46; III. 74. 196; M. 114. 40.
2) Vā. 99. 384.
text.2910:
Kālatvam — Yama aspect; rajas and tamas predominate;
terminates the worlds; as dark as the sky (añjana).
Vā. 5. 28, 31.
text.2911:
Kāladaṃṣṭra — an Asura who entered the ocean.
M. 61. 4.
text.2912:
Kālanar(l)a — (Kālānala-Vā. P.) the son of Sabhā
nara, and father of Sṛñjaya.
Bhā. IX. 23. 1; Vā. 99. 13.
text.2913:
Kālanātha — Śiva assuming the form of Death.
Br. IV. 16. 12.
text.2914:
Kālanābha (I) — a son of Hiraṇyākṣa and Bhānū. A
nephew of Hiraṇyakaśipu. Took an active part in the
Devāsura battle between Bali and Indra. Fought with
Yama. A follower of Vṛtra in his battle with Indra.1 A
Saṃhikeya asura.2 1) Bhā. VII. 2. 18; Vā. 67. 67; M. 6. 27; Br. III. 5. 30; Bhā. VIII.
10. 20 and 29; VI. 10. [20]. Vi. I. 21. 3.
2) Br. III. 6. 20; Vā. 68. 19.
text.2915:
Kālanābha (II) — a son of Vipracitti.
Vi. I. 21. 12.
text.2916:
Kālanemī — a son of Virocana and father of four sons.
Kaṃsā's previous birth as Kālanemī sent his śūla towards
Hari who vanquished him with the same implement;2 resid
ing in Atalam (IV tala or gabhastalam).3 Killed by Hari in
Tārakāmaya, where he was a commander; rode on a chariot
of elephants, used illusory powers and brahmāstram in the
war; devas as prisoners of war but released by Tāraka;
attacked Hari and fell dead slain by his cakra.4
^1 Vā. 67. 76; 80; Br. III. 5. 39. 2) Bhā. X. 1. 68; VIII. 10. 56;
X. 51. 42; Vi. V. 1. 22, 23, 65.
3) Br. II. 20. 32; Vā. 50. 31.
4) Br. III. 72. 21; M. 148. 42-51; 150. 140-189; 154. 3; 160. 3 & 18; 176.
49; chaps. 177-78; Vā. 97. 22.
text.2921:
Kālamṛtyu — a servant of Mahākāla.
Br. IV. 32. 5.
text.2922:
Kālayavana — the son of Yavaneśvara, black in colour
and hard-hearted; after crowning him king, his father
retired to the woods; full of prowess he asked Nārada of
some powerful heroes and being told about Yādavas he
directed himself towards them with a big army of Mlec
chas; Kṛṣṇa met him unarmed and was pursued; seeing
him entering a cave where Mucukunda was sleeping, Kāla
entered and thinking Mucukunda to be Kṛṣṇa kicked him;
on Mucukunda waking up and looking at Kālanemi he was
burnt to ashes as there was a vow that he who would awake
Mucukunda would meet with such an end.
Bhā. X. 50. 44-9; 51. 1-12; Vi. V. 23. 5-8 and 17-23.
text.2923:
Kālacakṣu — a son of Anu.
Br. III. 74. 13.
text.2925:
Kālavandi (c) — a kingdom noted for horses.
Br. IV. 16. 17.
text.2926:
Kālavāṣita — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 77.
text.2928:
Kālaśambara — Killed by Pradyumna (see also Sam
bara).
Vi. V. 27. 3 and 20.
text.2930:
Kālasaṃkarṣaṇī — a goddess from the back part of
Nṛsimha: a follower of Vāgīśī.
M. 179. 68.
text.2931:
Kālasarpi (Kaśyapatīrtha) — a sacred tīrtham dear to
Kaśyapa, fit for śrāddha and noted for devadāruvanam.
Br. III. 13. 98-9; Vā. 77. 87.
text.2932:
Kālasūtra — one of the twenty-eight hells. Those who
treacherously behave towards Pitṛs, Brāhmaṇas, etc., are
sent to this;1 a hell under the earth: also mahāhī2 the third
hell under the earth: also known as mahāhavividhi;
haunted by a fierce serpent.3 1) Bhā. V. 26. 7 & 14; Vā. 110. 42; Vi. I. 6. 41; II. 6. 4.
2) Br.
IV. 2. 181, 184; 33. 60.
3) Vā. 101. 178.
text.2933:
Kālā (I) — a goddess enshrined at Candrabhāgā.
M. 13. 49.
text.2934:
Kālā (II) — a daughter of Dakṣa, and wife of Kaśyapa.1
Mother of Kālakeyas.2 1) M. 171. 29; Vā. 66. 54.
2) M. 171. 59.
text.2936:
Kālānala (I) — a son of Sabhānara and a Paṇḍita; and
father of Sṛñjaya.
Br. III. 74. 13; Vi. IV. 18. 2-3.
text.2938:
Kālāmra — a tree of Bhadrāśva, the juice of its fruit
protects the youthfulness of women;1 in the Sālavanam;
the juice of which makes the drinker young.2 1) Br. II. 15. 58 & 61.
2) Vā. 43. 6.
text.2939:
Kālāyani — a pupil of Bāṣkala.
Vi. III. 4. 25.
text.2940:
Kālāyasaśālā — the first prākāra of Śripuram.
Br. IV. 31. 34. 50.
text.2941:
Kālāvasthas — six according to months, aho-rātra, ṛtus,
ayanas, and years; also nimeṣa, kalā, kāṣṭhā, muhūrta and
dinakṣapa;1 fivefold, day, half-month, month, ṛṭu and
ayanam.2 1) Vā. 30. 10-14.
2) Ib. 31. 26.
text.2943:
Kālika (I) — a pupil of Kṛta.
Br. II. 35. 51; Vā. 61. 44.
text.2944:
Kālika (II) — a son of Maya.
Br. III. 6. 29.
text.2947:
Kali(a)kā (III) — a daughter of Vaiśvānara; after her
came the Kālakeya asuras.
Br. III. 6. 23-5; Vā. 68. 23.
text.2949:
Kāliṃga — the king of, present at the marriage of Anī
ruddha and advised Rukmin to invite Rāma for dice.
Laughed aloud when Rāma failed, and supported Rukmin
playing falsely. His teeth pulled out by Rāma.
Bhā. X. 61. 27-37.
text.2950:
Kāliṃgaka — a Brāhmaṇa friend of Bhīṣma hailing from
Kalinga; narrated to Bhīṣma ways by which to be free from
Yama's subjection.
Vi. III. 7-38.
text.2955:
Kālindī (I) — the daughter of the sun god; wandering
in the forest in quest of Kṛṣṇa, she expressed herself to
Arjuna who was there with Kṛṣṇa; the latter married her;
welcomed by Draupadī to Hāstinapura, she narrated to her
how she married Kṛṣṇa.1 Devī and wife of Kṛṣṇa; mother
of Śruta and other sons.2 1) Bhā. X. 58. 17-23, 29; 71. 43; 83. 11; M. 47. 14.
2) Vā. 96.
234; Vi. V. 28. 3; 32. 4.
text.2956:
Kālindī (II) — a R. of the Ketumāla country.
Vā. 44. 21.
text.2957:
Kālindī (III) — a name for Yamunā.
Vi. V. 7. 2; 18. 34; VI. 8. 36.
text.2958:
Kāliya (I) — a chief of the Krodhavaśa group of ser
pents. Got into a pool of the Yamunā, causing the death
of people who drank of the waters. Kṛṣṇa subjugated it
and ordered it to go to the sea, thus making the waters
drinkable. He assured Kālīya of freedom from Garuḍa's
hostility. Son of Kadru, Kāliya originally lived in Rama
ṇaka, and refused to give Bali to Garuḍa according to an
agreement with him. In the fight that ensued, Kāliya was
vanquished, and he resorted to the Kālindi pool where
Garuḍa could not come. But he was expelled by Kṛṣṇa.1
In the Atalam region;2 in Talvalam ?3 1) Bhā. V. 24. 29; X. ch. 16 (whole); 17. 1-12; X. 43. 26.
2) Vā.
50. 18; 69. 72.
3) Br. II. 20. 19; M. 163. 56.
text.2960:
Kāliyas — the serpents of Mahātalam.
Bhā. V. 24. 29.
text.2961:
Kālī (I) — one of the wives of Bhīmasena, and mother
of Sarvagata.
Bhā. IX. 22. 31.
text.2962:
Kālī (II) — a mother goddess, and a varṇa śakti;1 a
goddess enshrined at Kālanjara; took part in the Tārakā
maya and enveloped the whole in darkness.2 1) Br. IV. 7. 72; 44. 59 & 76.
2) M. 13. 32; 172. 19.
text.2963:
Kālī (III) — a doorkeeper of Mahākāla.
Br. IV. 32. 18.
text.2964:
Kālī (IV) — the Dāśeyī brought forth Vicitravīrya by
Śantanu.
M. 50. 45.
text.2965:
Kālī (V) — a mind-born mother;1 from the bones of
Nṛsimha.2 1) M. 179. 14.
2) Ib. 179. 26, 64.
text.2966:
Kālī (VI) — the wife of Parāśara and mother of Kṛṣṇa
dvaipāyana.
Vā. 70. 84.
text.2968:
Kālīyanāga — the venomous serpent in a pool of
Yamunā; Kṛṣṇa dived into it and was about to kill him
when on an appeal from the wives of Nāga and the Nāga
himself to do as he bade he set them free and sent them to
the sea to live there for ever. See Kāliya.
Vi. V. 7. 3 to the end; 13. 4.
text.2969:
Kāleya — an Asura who was exhausted in Amṛtaman
thana.
Bhā. VIII. 7. 14.
text.2971:
Kāleyas — Dānavas and Nāgas in Rasātala. These took
part in Devāsura war between Bali and Indra. They fought
with Vasus.
Bhā. V. 24. 30; VIII. 10. 22 and 34.
text.2972:
Kāleśvara — famous for Lalitā piṭha: a tīrtham on the
Narmadā.
Br. IV. 44. 97; M. 191. 85.
text.2973:
Kālodara (c) — an eastern kingdom watered by Hlā
dinī;1 peoples of.2 1) Br. II. 18. 55.
2) Vā. 47. 52.
text.2974:
Kālyā — a wife of Parāśara, and mother of Kṛsṇa dvaipā
yana.
Br. III. 8. 92.
text.2975:
Kāverī (I) — R. personified as one of the wives of
Havyavāhana (Śamsya) fire; Sangamam in the Narmadā,
where Kubera attained siddhi by penance to Śiva. Its great
ness described.
Br. II. 12. 14; M. 51. 13; 163. 61; 189. 2-20; Vā. 29. 130.
text.2976:
Kāverī (II) — the grand-daughter of Yuvanāśva and
wife of Janhu; mother of Suhotra. (Sunaha-Br. P.); made of
one half of Gangā.
Br. III. 66. 28-30; Vā. 91. 58.
text.2977:
Kāverī (III) — a R. of the Bhadra country.
Vā. 43. 26.
text.2978:
Kāverī (IV) — R. a mahānadi (Vā. P.) in Bhāratavarṣa;1
takes its source in the Sahya (Ṛṣyavat) hills noted for Vai
nana elephants in Drāviḍa deśa (Dakṣiṇa deśa);2 visited by
Balarāma;3 fit for śrāddha offerings, and sacred to Pitṛs.4 1) Vā. 108. 79.
2) Bhā. V. 19. 18; VII. 13. 12; XI. 5. 40;
Br. II. 16. 35; III. 7. 357; Vā. 45. 104; 77. 28.
3) Bhā. X. 79. 14;
M. 114. 23.
4) Br. III. 13. 28; M. 22. 27.
text.2979:
Kāvya (I) — a son of Bhṛgu and Divyā; also Śukra,
Uśana, the Ācārya for devas and asuras; Kavisuta and the
name of a planet; wife Gonāma, had four sons, Tvaṣṭa,
Varūtrī, Śaṇḍa, and Marka;1 the lord of Bhṛgus;2 cursed
Yayāti.3 Asuras defeated by Indra appealed to Kāvya
and resolved to go to Rasātala; Kāvya encouraged them and
said that rains, vegetation, etc., would stand completely with
them and only (1/4) with the devas; at that time the devas
appealed to him for help; but Kāvya went to Mahādeva and
learnt the mantra for their success; in the meantime he
asked them to keep quiet and perform austerities after lay
ing their weapons down. Mahādeva insisted on Kuṇḍa-
dhūma observance for a thousand years with their heads
down; while so engaged the asuras got afraid of the devas
and appealed to his mother and the wife of Bhṛgu; she
offered them shelter but finding them being killed by the
devas she resolved to deprive Indra of his place; then Indra
appealed to Viṣṇu whose body he entered; but she set on
fire the whole world of devas, when out of rage Viṣṇu killed
her; Bhṛgu cursed him to be born seven times among men;
then by power of tapas he restored his wife to life;
Śukra's religious observance so as to please him; penance
over, Maheśvara granted him three things: non-defeat
by others, lordship over wealth, and eternal life; on
this he praised Nīlalohita by many names; pleased,
Śiva disappeared; then Śukra was attracted towards Jayantī
the daughter of Indra and promised to be with her
for ten years unknown to the asuras by means of
māyā; when Kāvya returned the asuras were pleased;
but during the ten years Bṛhaspati appeared before
the asuras in the guise of Kāvya and pretended to speak to
them the mantra he had heard; the asuras accepted him;
ten years were over and a daughter Devayāni was born to
Śukra who appeared before the asuras; finding two Kāvyas
the asuras became mystified and Kāvya said that he was
Bṛhaspati in disguise; the asuras did not believe in the real
Śukra who left them in anger; soon they found out the
mistake and approached Śukra through Prahlāda and he
became pleased; then he approached Brahmā who said that
after ten yugas and in the Svārociṣa Yuga the asuras would
get back their kingdom; saying this he pointed out to two
disciples Saṇḍa and Marka equal to Bṛhaspati, and at last
the devas were defeated. Seeing the success of the asuras
Viṣnu took different avatars to put them down.4 1) Br. III. 1. 76; 68. 86; 72. 95; 73. 1, 37. Vā. 59. 90;
62. 41; 65. 74-7.
2) Vi. 70. 4.
3) Vi. IV. 10. 7.
4) Vā. 97. 94 to end and ch. 98; Br. III, 72. 96 to the end; 73.
1-64.
text.2980:
Kāvya (II) — an Aṅgirasa, and one of the seven sages
of Tāmasa Manu;1 a mantrakṛt.2 1) Br. II. 32. 98 and 104; 33. 7; 36. 47.
2) Vā. 59. 96.
text.2981:
Kāvya (III) — a son of Senājit.
M. 49. 50; Vā. 99. 173.
text.2983:
Kāvyas — a group of Pitṛs who drink Soma's Svadhā.
Their mind-born daughter is Yogotpatti; other names are
Samvatsaras, Pañcābdas, Ājyapas, being presiding deities of
Aṣtakas and others. They drink ghee.
Br. II. 23. 39 and 73-5; 28. 4, 23 and 70; III. 10. 85; M.
141. 4-16; Vā. 56. 13, 16.
text.2984:
Kāśa — a son of Śunahotra (Sutahotra-Vā. P.) (Suho
tra-Vi. P.).
Br. III. 67. 4; Vā. 92. 3; Vi. IV. 8. 5.
text.2986:
Kāśas — a kind of grass (saccarum spontanerum) best
for śrāddha purposes; significance of.
Vā. 75. 41.
text.2987:
Kāśi — son of Kāśya and father of Rāṣṭra.
Bhā. IX. 17. 4.
text.2989:
Kāśipa — a son of Kāśya.
Br. III. 67. 7.
text.2990:
Kāśirāja — the kingdom of, got rain by the presence of
Śvaphalka; daughter of (Gāndinī) married to Śvaphalka;1
a daughter Jayanti married to Vṛṣabha.2 1) Vā. 96. 103-5; Vi. IV. 13. 116.
2) M. 45. 26.
text.2991:
Kāśī (I) (c) — a kingdom of Madhyadeśa;1 a tribe;2 a
Janapada3 enlisted by Jarāsandha against the Yadus.4 1) Br. II. 16. 41; 18. 51; III. 74. 213 and 268.
2) M. 114. 35;
163. 67; 273. 73.
3) Vā. 45. 110; 47. 48.
4) Bhā. X. [50 (V) 3].
text.2992:
Kāsī (II) — capital of Pauṇḍraka invaded by Kṛṣṇa;
Pauṇḍraka on the S. of the Gomanta hill during the siege
by Jarāsandha.1 The abhicāra Agni sent by Sudakṣiṇa
returned and killed Sudakṣiṇa himself, while Viṣṇu's Cakra
burnt down the whole city.2 Its king went to Syamantapañ
caka for solar eclipse having heard that Kṛṣṇa was there.3
When the kingdom had no rains, its king gave his daughter
Gāndinī to Śvaphalka, and this resulted in plenty of
showers.4 Likened to Bhāgavata Purāṇa in its importance.5
Sages of, visited Dvārakā.6 Residence of Kāmākṣī7 the
capital of Kuśadhvaja;8 in the brows of the Veda.9 1) Bhā. X. 66. [12], 10; 52. 11 [9].
2) Ib. X. 66. 30-42; 37. 19.
3) Ib. X. 82. 25.
4) Ib. X. 57. 32. Br. III. 71. 104.
5) Bhā. XII. 13. 17.
6) Ib. X. 90. 28 [3].
7) Br. IV. 37. 15; 40. 15 and 80, 91.
8) Vā. 81. 18;
99. 402.
9) Ib. 104. 75.
text.2993:
Kāśī (III) — the mother of Sarvaga (Sarvavṛka-Vā. P.)
by Bhīmasena.
M. 50. 54; Vā. 99. 247; Vi. IV. 20. 46.
text.2995:
Kāsīpati — see (Kāśirāja): king of Kāsi who went to
aid Pauṇḍraka against Kṛṣṇa and who was so struck that
his head shot into the city; his son together with the priest
prayed to Śiva to avenge his father's murder; Śiva granted
the boon and sent a female created from fire to destroy
Kṛṣṇa whose discus was more than a metal; the dead ran
to Kāśi followed by the discus which burnt the whole city.
Vi. V. 34. 14-43.
text.2996:
Kāśeya — the son of Kāśa; king of Kāsī; father of Rāṣṭra.
Vi. IV. 8. 7.
text.2997:
Kāśeyas — a ruling dynasty of 24 rulers.
M. 272. 15.
text.2999:
Kāśmīra (maṇḍala) — became the possession of Vrātyas
and Mlecchas;1 a kingdom of the West watered by the
