Cārupada — the son of Namasyu and father of Sudyu.
Bhā. IX. 20. 2-3.
text.4747:
Cārubhadra — a son of Rukmiṇī and Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 71. 246; M. 47. 16.
text.4748:
Cārumati(hī) — a daughter of Rukminī and Kṛṣṇa; wife
of Balin, son of Kṛtavarman.
Bhā. X. 61. 24; Br. III. 71. 246; M. 47. 16; Vā. 96. 238; Vi.
V. 28. 2.
text.4749:
Cārumukhī — a daughter of the Gandharvas.
Vā. 69. 10.
text.4751:
Cāruvarman — an important Yādava; got killed in the
disturbance at Prabhāsa after Kṛṣṇa's departure to Heaven.
Vi. V. 37. 47.
text.4752:
Cāruvidya — a son of Rukmiṇi and Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 71. 246.
text.4753:
Cāruvindhya — (Cāruvinda-Vi. P.); a son of Rukminī.
Vā. 96. 238. Vi. V. 28. 2.
text.4754:
Cāruhāsa — a son of Rukmiṇī and Kṛṣṇa.
M. 47. 16.
text.4756:
Cāruhāsinī — one of Kṛṣṇa's wives.
Vi. V. 15. 35.
text.4757:
Cārvarivān — a son of Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 22.
text.4759:
Cikṣubha — a Rākṣasa killed by Lalitā.
Br. IV. 29. 76.
text.4761:
Citi (II) — (ety.) he who gathers the means for enjoy
ment.
Vā. 4. 38.
text.4762:
Citi (III) — the twins of Prajāpati in the 23rd kalpa;
Cinta came out of contemplation.
Vā. 21. 53.
text.4763:
Cittakarṣaṇikā — also Cittakarṣaṇarūpā (nitya); a Gupta
śakti.
Br. IV. 19. 19; 36. 70; 44. 119.
text.4767:
Citti (I) — another name for Śānti (s.v.).
Bhā. IV. 1. 42.
text.4770:
Citparā — Kāmākṣi the first cause, called also Antā;
then became Śuddhaparā with two hands with yogamudra
and book in them; the next was Parāpara with lotus in her
right hand and the left placed on the left thigh. This is at
Kāñcī.
Br. IV. 39. 9-14.
text.4771:
Citra (I) — a son of Vasudeva and Madirā.
Br. III. 71. 172.
text.4772:
Citra (II) — a son of Agāvata.
Br. III. 71. 257.
text.4773:
Citra (III) — a commander of Bhaṇḍa killed by Citrā.
Br. IV. 25. 99.
text.4776:
Citras — of different kinds on the walls and pillars of the
houses erected by Jamadagni's cow.
Br. III. 26. 60.
text.4777:
Citraka — a son of Vṛṣṇi; (Pṛṣṇi-Vā. P.); father of a
number of sons and daughters; brother of Svaphalka.
Br. III. 71. 102, 114; Vā. 96. 101, 113-14; Vi. IV. 14. 5-6, 11.
text.4778:
Citrakarma — a Gaṇeśa; a sculptor created a beautiful
form out of the ashes left by Madana's body burnt down by
Śiva. Thus having been restored to life he was asked to
meditate Śatarudriya in honour of Rudra. This was Bhaṇḍa
who was blessed by Śiva to rule for 6000 years.
Br. IV. 11. 30.
text.4779:
Citrakūṭa (I) — a hill in Bhāratavarṣa; sacred to Sītā
and to Pitṛs.
Bhā. V. 19. 16; Br. II. 16. 23; III. 13. 38. M. 13. 39; 52. 65.
text.4780:
Citrakūṭa (II) — a hill in Kuśadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 15.
text.4781:
Citrakūṭa (III) — R. from Ṛkṣa (Ṛṣyavanta-M. P.) in
Bhāratavarṣa.
Br. II. 16. 30; M. 114. 25; Vā. 45. 99.
text.4782:
Citraketu (I) — one of the seven sons of Vasiṣṭha.
Bhā. IV. 1. 40-41.
text.4783:
Citraketu (II) — a son of Lakṣmaṇa.
Bhā. IX. 11. 12.
text.4784:
Citraketu (III) — a son of Devabhāgā and Kamśā.
Bhā. IX. 24. 40.
text.4785:
Citraketu (IV) — a son of Jāmbavatī.
Bhā. X. 61. 12.
text.4786:
Citraketu (V) — a Sārvabhauma and king of Śūrasenas.
His queen was Kṛtādyuti; though he had a number of wives
he had no children. When he was brooding over this, there
came the sage Angiras; getting to know his mind he per
formed a ritual in honour of Tvaṣṭā and the remnant of offer
ing was given to his eldest queen, Kṛtādyutī, who brought
forth a son. Though the king was glad, his wives grew
jealous and poisoned the child to death. The king, queen
and others ceaselessly lamented. On this Angiras and
Nārada came on the scene and consoled them. Angiras
addressed him on the instability of life, illustrating it by the
story of Bhoja. Nārada instructed him into a mantropa-
niṣad. By meditating on this for seven nights, he was told,
that he would see Sankarṣana and get over the illusion relat
ing to duality. So he had his purificatory bath at the Jamunā
and was initiated into the vidyā by Nārada. By meditating
for seven days, the king became the lord of Vidyādharas. He
then praised Hari in the form of Ananta and had a darśan
of the Lord.
Once he flew in the air and saw Śiva sitting with Pār
vatī on his lap in the presence of his attendants and others.
He laughed at this, which enraged Pārvatī who cursed him
to be born an Asura. Citraketu alighted from his aerial car
and begged for pardon. After he went away, Śiva told Pār
vatī that Citraketu was a devotee of Hari, and hence his
devotee also. Therefore he deserved pardon. Pārvatī was
appeased, and Citraketu was born as Vṛtra.
Bhā. VI. Chaps. 14-17.
text.4788:
Citragu — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Satyā.
Bhā. X. 61. 13.
text.4789:
Citragupta — an Adhidevatā of the planet Ketu; Icon of,
near Yama.
M. 93. 15; 102. 23; 261. 14.
text.4791:
Citrajyoti — a Marut of the first gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 92.
text.4793:
Citrabāhu — a son of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X, 90. 34.
text.4794:
Citrabhānu (I) — a warrior son of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 90. 33.
text.4795:
Citrabhānu (II) — a name of the sun; moves in the north
of Śākadvīpa in Śravaṇa and Uttarāṣāḍha;1 begged of Kārta
vīryārjuna, the seven islands as bhikṣā and burnt them all;
father of Varuṇa (Vasiṣṭha) famous as Āpava who cursed
the king; the sun-god in the guise of a Brahmana asked for
food all the immovable property of the king to which he
agreed; Āditya was pleased with him and gave him res
plendent and useful arrows; he ate all the eastern parts of
the kingdom including the tapovana.2 1) Br. II. 21. 73, 136; Vā. 50. 128.
2) Br. III. 69. 38-47; Vā.
94. 39; 95. 3-13.
text.4796:
Citrayuddha — Kuraṇḍa as expert in;1 Aśvins and
Janārdana experts in.2 1) Br. IV. 22. 74; III. 71. 184.
2) M. 150. 201; 152. 3 and 27.
text.4798:
Citrayodhi (II) — one who does not fight a straight
battle.
Vā. 96. 181.
text.4799:
Citraratha (I) — a son of Gaya, and father of Samrāṭ;
wife Ūrṇā.
Bhā. V. 15. 14.
text.4800:
Citraratha (II) — a Gandharva who crossed the place
where the bones of a certain Kauśika lay dropped down to
the earth. After collecting and throwing them into the
Sarasvatī, he went to his home.1 He was seen sporting at
the Ganges with apsaras by Reṇukā.2 1) Bhā. VI. 8. 39-40.
2) Ib. IX. 16. 2-3.
text.4801:
Citraratha (III) — the son of Supārśvaka and father of
Kṣemādhi. He was king of Mithilā.
Bhā. IX. 13. 23.
text.4802:
Citraratha (IV) — the son of Ukta and father of Kavi
ratha.
Bhā. IX. 22. 40.
text.4803:
Citraratha (V) — the son of Dharmaratha, well known
as Romapāda. A friend of Daśaratha. As he had no children,
he adopted Śāntā, daughter of Daśaratha. Ṛṣyaśṛnga mar
ried her. Then he had a son Caturanga.
Bhā. IX. 23. 7-10; M. 48. 94; Vā. 93. 103; Vi. IV. 18. 16-18.
text.4804:
Citraratha (VI) — the son of Ruśeku (Ruṣ(ś)anku-M.
P., Vi. P.) and father of Śaśabindu.
Bhā. IX. 23. 31; Br. III. 70. 18; M. 44. 17; Vi. IV. 12. 2-3.
text.4805:
Citraratha (VII) — a son of Vṛṣṇi and a grandson of
Anamitra. Father of Pṛthu and other sons.
Bhā. IX. 24. 15 and 18.
text.4806:
Citraratha (VIII) — a Mauneya Gandharva; overlord of
the Gandharvas, Kinnaras and Vidyādharas;1 served as the
calf when the Gandharvas milked the earth in the lotus
vessel along with the Apsaras.2 1) Br. III. 7. 3; 8. 10; IV. 20. 50; M. 8. 6; Vā. 69. 2; 70. 9.
2) Br. II. 36. 221.
text.4807:
Citraratha (IX) — a son of Agāvaha.
Br. III. 71. 257.
text.4809:
Citraratha (XI) — the son of Raśādu; performed several
sacrifices; became later known as Śaśabindu; had 10,000
sons of whom six were famous with names beginning in
Pṛthu.
Vā. 95. 17-18, 20-21.
text.4813:
Citrarepha — a son of Medhātithi of Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 25.
text.4814:
Citra(r)lekhā (I) — a companion of Bāṇa's daughter,
Ūṣā; daughter of Kumbhāṇḍa minister to Bāṇa; heard
from Ūṣā of her dream about a certain prince, and being an
artist drew pictures of gods and men. Ūṣā identified Ani
ruddha as her lover. Citralekha travelled by air to Dvārakā
and carried Aniruddha to Ūṣā's harem at Śoṇitapura un
noticed by any.
Bhā. X. 61. 23[9]; 62. 14-23; Vi. V. 32. 17-30; 33. 5.
text.4815:
Citralekhā (II) — an Apsaras in the sabhā of Hira
ṇyakaśipu; rescued along with Urvaśī from the Asura Keśin
by Purūravas.
M. 161. 75; 24. 23.
text.4816:
Citravatī (I) — a daughter of Agāvaha.
Br. III. 71. 257.
text.4820:
Citraśāla — painting and pictures in Tripuram.
M. 130. 16.
text.4821:
Citrasānu — a Mt. in east half of Puṣkaradvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 110; M. 123. 13; Vā. 49. 107.
text.4822:
Citrasena (I) — a son of Manu Devasāvarṇi.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 30.
text.4823:
Citrasena (II) — the son of Nariṣyanta and father of
Dakṣa.
Bhā. IX. 2. 19.
text.4824:
Citrasena (III) — a Gandharva with the Hemanta sun.
Br. II. 23. 17; Vā. 52. 17. 96. 248.
text.4825:
Citrasena (IV) — a son of Agāvaha.
Br. III. 71. 257.
text.4826:
Citrasena (V) — a son of the fourth Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 94.
text.4827:
Citrasena (VI) — a son of Ruci XIII Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 104; Vā. 100. 108; Vi. III. 2. 41.
text.4828:
Citrasena (VII) — a Mauneya Gandharva king in
Kailasa;1 resides in sun's chariot2 during Mārgaśīrṣa month. 1) Vā. 41. 21; 69. 1.
2) Vi. II. 10. 13.
text.4829:
Citrasvana — the Rākṣasa presiding over the month
of Śuci.
Bhā. XII. 11. 36.
text.4830:
Citrā (I) — a rock on the Himalayas near the river
Puṣpabhadrā; sacred to Lalitā.
Bhā. XII. 8. 17; Br. IV. 44. 97.
text.4831:
Citrā (II) — a daughter of Vasudeva and Rohiṇī; came
to see Kṛṣṇa and Satyabhāma returning from Indra's court.2
^1 Br. III. 71. 165; Vā. 96. 163. 2) Bhā. X. [67 (v) 50]; M.
46. 12.
text.4832:
Citra (III) — a name of a constellation;1 śrāddham on
that day gets good children.2 1) Vā. 82. 8.
2) Br. III. 18. 7.
text.4834:
Citrāngada (I) — a Kṣatriya son of Śantanu and a fisher
woman Satyavatī; was killed in a battle by a Gandharva
by name Citrāngada.
Bhā. IX. 22. 20-21; Br. III. 10. 70; M. 14. 17; Vā. 73. 19;
Vi. IV. 20. 34-5.
text.4835:
Citrāngada (II) — a Gandharva who killed Citrāngada,
a son of Śantanu.
Bhā. IX. 22. 20; Vi. IV. 20. 35.
text.4836:
Citrāṅgī — one of the four queens of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 12. 13.
text.4837:
Citrotpalā — a R. from the Ṛkṣa (Ṛṣyavat).
Br. II. 16. 31; M. 114. 25.
text.4838:
Cidi — a son of Kauśika after whom came the famous
line, the Caidyas.
Br. III. 70. 39; Vā. 95. 38.
text.4839:
Cidvahni — the Agni dug of Cintāmaṇi gṛha; it burns
with no fuel; the hotā and hotri are Kāmeśvara and Mahā
devī.
Br. IV. 36. 24.
text.4841:
Cintā — came out when Brahmā was in contemplation.
Vā. 21. 54.
text.4842:
Cintāmaṇigṛha — of Lalitā; by its side was one built by
the architects to Mantrinī when she visited Lalitā; here the
mātaṅgakanyakās sport and dance.1 The abode of Cakra
rāja and lying at a distance of seven yojanas to Śṛṅgāraśāla;
surmounted by gopuras in hundreds on all sides.2 On its
different sides were Cidvanhi, Cakrarājaratha, Geyacakra,
Kiricakra, Hari, Gaṇapati, Śiva, Sarasvatī, Mahādevis, the
residences of Mantrinātha and Daṇḍanātha. In its midst
was Binducakra with a number of Śaktis. There was also
what is known as Sarvajña yantarā. This Cintāmaṇigṛha
was located in the middle of Śripaṭṭaṇa. Its walls and
pillars, all of Cintāmaṇi.3 1) Br. IV. 31. 86.
2) Ib. 35. 70, 104.
3) Ib. 36. 1, 33.
text.4843:
Cibilaka — the son of Lambodara and father of Megha
svāti.
Bhā. XII. 1. 24.
text.4844:
Cibuṇikā — a queen of Varṣaṛtu.
Br. IV. 32. 29.
text.4846:
Cīna — (c) a northern kingdom;1 unfit for śrāddha;2
people of.3 1) Br. II. 16. 7; 18. 46; 31. 83.
2) M. 16. 16.
3) Vā. 47. 42;
58. 83.
text.4847:
Cīnamaru — (c) the kingdom watered by the R. Cakṣu
Br. II. 18. 46; Vā. 47. 44.
text.4848:
Cīnāṃśuka — the silk of the Shin country.
M. 154. 276.
text.4851:
Cūḷikas — a tribe;1 kings of.2 1) Vā. 45. 121.
2) M. 50. 76.
text.4852:
Cekitāna (I) — was stationed by Jarāsandha on the East
gate of Mathurā.
Bhā. X. 50. 11 [2].
text.4853:
Cekitāna (II) — a son of Śrutakīrti.
Br. III. 71. 157; Vā. 96. 156.
text.4854:
Ceḍaviḍā — a daughter of Tṛṇabindu married to Viś
ravas and became mother of Kubera.
Bhā. IX. 2. 31-32.
text.4856:
Cetanā — released by Indra in the sacrifice.
Vā. 65. 81.
text.4857:
Cetasa — one of the names of the fifth Marutgaṇa.
Vā. 67. 128.
text.4858:
Cedi (I) (c) kingdom of;1 the name of Vasu's kingdom.2 1) Bhā. VII. 1. 13; IX. 22. 6; 24. 39; Vi. IV. 14. 44.
2) Vā.
93. 26; 99. 114.
text.4859:
Cedi (II) — the son of Uśika; (Kaiśika-Vi. P.). Father
of Caidya and others.
Bhā. IX. 24. 2; Vi. IV. 12. 39.
text.4860:
Cedis — were enlisted by Jarāsandha against Yadus.
Bhā. X. [50 (v) 2].
text.4861:
Cedipa — a son of Uparicara and king of Cedi.
Bhā. IX. 22. 6.
text.4864:
Caitya (I) — funerary mound; found in Ayodhyā; its
trees as frequented by Piśācas;1 a householder to avoid
Caitya.2 1) Bhā. IX. 11. 27; Br. III. 7. 415; Vi. III. 12. 13.
2) Vi. III.
11. 122.
text.4865:
Caitya (II) — a Marut of the first gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 92.
text.4866:
Caitra (I) — one of the nine sons of Svārociṣa-Manu.
Br. II. 36. 19; Vi. III. 1. 12.
text.4867:
Caitra (II) — a Paulastya and a sage of the Tāmasa
Manvantara.
Br. II. 36. 48.
text.4869:
Caitramāsa — a Manvantarādi for śrāddha, and good for
vratas like the Madanadvādaśi; best for military expedition.
M. 7. 10: 17. 6: 54. 8; 56. 3; 60. 33; 240. 5.
text.4870:
Caitraratha (I) — a pleasure garden of Devas and Indra
to which went Kardama and Devahūti.1 In the Candra
prabha hill. Here Urvaśī met Aila.2 In the Mandara hill;3
in the east4 of Ilāvṛta. 1) Bhā. III. 23. 40; V. 16. 14; IX. 14. 24; M. 27. 4; Vi. IV. 6. 48.
2) Br. II. 18. 7; III. 7. 102; 66. 6.
3) M. 83. 31; 121. 8; 131. 48.
4) Vā.
36. 11; 42. 15; 47. 6; 69. 137; 91. 6. Vi. II. 2. 25.
text.4871:
Caitraratha (II) — acted as calf when the Gandharvas
and Apsaras milked the earth.
M. 10. 24.
text.4872:
Caitraratha (III) — a tīrtham sacred to Madotkaṭa.
M. 13. 28.
text.4873:
Caitrarathī (also Bindumatī) — the daughter of Śaśa
bindu and wife of Māndhāta; had 10,000 younger brothers;
righteous, fair and chaste; mother of three sons Purukutsu,
Ambariṣa and Mucukunda.
Br. III. 63. 70; Vā. 88. 70-2.
text.4874:
Caitrā — the wife of Jyāmagha; gave birth to Vidarbha.
M. 44. 32 and 36.
text.4876:
Caitrogni — a sage of the Tāmasa epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 18.
text.4877:
Caidya (I) — a son of Yudhiṣṭhira's aunt and Dama
ghoṣa and brother of Dantavaktra. Both were once attend
ants on Hari and born on earth by the curse of Brahmanas.
It happened thus. Once Sananda and other sons of Brahmā
went to Viṣṇuloka and were prevented by them, as door
keepers, from entering Vaikuṇṭha. Hence they were cursed
to be born as Asuras. They were born as Hiraṇyakaśipu and
Hiraṇyākṣa, then as Rāvaṇa and Kumbhakarṇa, and now as
Caidya and Dantavaktra.1 Hated Kṛṣṇa, beaten by him in
svyamvara. An ally of Jarāsandha, he was stationed at the
eastern gate of Mathurā. Kṛṣṇa directed his attack against
Caidya. The fight and end of Caidya.2
His name was proposed by Rukmiṇi's elder brother for
marriage. Went to Kuṇḍina ready to marry Rukmiṇī; dis
tressed at her being taken away by Kṛṣṇa and his friend
Rukmi's defeat; he was consoled by Jarāsandha and returned
to his city.3 An enemy of Kṛṣṇa, he attained yoga at the
Rājasūya. He attained Hariloka through hatred. (See
Śiśupāla).4 Married Śrutaśravas who gave birth to Sunita.5 1) Bhā. VII. 10. 35-46.
2) Ib. I. 10. 29; X. 50. 11 [2], 20-24.
[1-15].
3) Ib. ch. 52. (whole); 53. 14-16; 54. 10-17.
4) Ib. III.
2. 19; VII. 1. 13-15 and 30.
5) M. 46. 6.
text.4880:
Caidyoparicara — a son of Kṛmi. Known also as Vasu.
His wife was Girīkā, mother of seven sons.
M. 50. 26.
text.4884:
Cola (I) — a son of Āṇḍira after whom was named the
the Coladeśa.
Br. III. 74. 6; M. 48. 5.
text.4885:
Cola (II) — one of the four sons of Janāpīḍa; his
kingdom Colāḥ.
Vā. 99. 6.
text.4886:
Colas (I) — a degraded Kṣatriya clan.
Br. III. 63. 140; M. 114. 46.
text.4888:
Colaka — the dress covering the image of Sun god.
M. 261. 4.
text.4892:
Cyavana (I) — a sage1 who was invited for Yudhiṣṭhira's
Rājasūya.2 Came to see Kṛṣṇa at Syamantapañcaka.3 Went
with him to Mithilā.4 Came to see Parīkṣit practising prā
yopaveśa.5 1) Bhā. VI. 15. 14.
2) Ib. X. 74. 7.
3) Ib. 84. 3.
4) Ib. 86.
18.
5) Ib. I. 19. 9.
text.4893:
Cyavana (II) — a son of Śukra and Paulomi;1 when he
was engaged in tapas he was covered by an anthill. His
eyes were seen through two holes therein. Once Sukanyā
who came there with her father saw two luminous objects
in the anthill and pierced them with a thorn. This resulted
in blood flowing from the eyes. The king asked the sage's
pardon and offered his daughter in marriage to him. Having
married a princess, the sage requested Aśvins who were on
a visit to him, to make him a youth. They advised him to
bathe in a siddha lake nearby. He thus found himself
thoroughly changed. With him Sukanyā enjoyed life. Her
father came there some time after and was not aware of the
change in the sage's form. He took him to be a paramour
and scolded his daughter. When he came to know the fact
he was much pleased. In the yajña performed Cyavana
offered soma to Aśvins who were so far denied a share, being
physicians. Indra resented this and wanted to kill Cyavana.
But the latter's act was accepted by all as a precedent.2
Father of Āpravānam and Dadhica.3 1) Br. III. 1. 92; Vā. 86. 2, 23.
2) Bhā. IX. 3. 2-26; Br. II.
32. 98; III. 8. 31; 21-36; 61. 2.
3) Br. III. 1. 93.
text.4894:
Cyavana (III) — the son of Mitreyu and father of
Sudāsa.
Bhā. IX. 22. 1. Vā. 99. 207. Vi. IV. 19. 70-71.
text.4895:
Cyavana (IV) — the son of Suhotra the righteous and
father of Kṛtin (Kṛtaka-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 22. 5; Vā. 99. 217; Vi. IV. 19. 79.
text.4896:
Cyavana (V) — a Rākṣasa residing in the third talam
(Vitalam-Vā. P.).
Br. II. 20. 28; Vā. 50. 27.
text.4897:
Cyavana (VI) — a Ṛṣi and mantrakṛt, cursed that the
hundred sons of Kṛtavīrya would meet with death.
M. 68. 9; 145. 92 and 99.
text.4898:
Cyavana (VII) — a son of Bhṛgu; a gotrakara, and a
Pravara.
M. 195. 15 and 28, 29.
text.4900:
Cyavana (IX) — a son of Gokarṇa, an avatār of the
16th dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 173.
text.4903:
Cyavanaāśrama — in Gayā where are Vaikuṇtha, Loka
daṇḍa, Gṛdhrakūṭa and Śoṇaka.
Vā. 108. 73.
text.4904:
Chagala (I) — (Chagalas); one of the sixteen classes of
Piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 376.
text.4905:
Chagala (II) — a son of Mundīśara avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 211.
text.4906:
Chatra (I) — the seven worlds, white in colour, are one
above the other umbrella-like.
Br. II. 21. 19; III. 49. 23; 55. 15; IV. 37. 35.
text.4907:
Chatra (II) — the white umbrella as insignia of royalty
given to Kāmeśvara by Viṣṇu; lofty as the sky.1 Kauravas
threatened Ugrasena to deprive him of that.2 1) Br. IV. 15. 23; 17. 1; Vi. II. 13. 96.
2) Vi. V. 35. 14.
text.4909:
Chandas — Vedic metres as steeds of the sun's chariot;1
as part of Viṣṇu.2 Seven in number — names given. 1) Bhā. II. 6. 1; Vi. II. 8. 5.
2) Vi. V. 1. 37; Br. I. 5. 19.
text.4910:
Chandaka — a kind of temple with a number of towers.
M. 269. 32 and 49.
text.4911:
Chandajas (I) — are 33 Devas, constituting three ganas,
Yāma, Ajītas and Śaktas with their chief Indra;1 drink the
nectar of the moon until the Caturdaśi, and on the Pañcadaśi
the Pitṛs drink of the rest.2 1) Br. II. 13. 91.
2) Vā. 56. 25.
text.4912:
Chandajas (II) — the gods of the Cākṣuṣa epoch; also
known as Sādhyas.
Br. III. 3. 9.
text.4913:
Candanas — a group of 33 Devas who drink the moon's
kalas in the dark half of the month.
Br. II. 28. 26.
text.4914:
Chandāmsi — the Vedas — Ṛg, Yajus and Sāma;1 Gāya
tri and others, sons of Vinata;2 created by Vāmadeva;3 served
as vessel for sages milking the earth.4 1) Vā. 3. 16.
2) Br. II. 7. 30.
3) M. 247. 7.
4) Br. II. 36. 104.
text.4915:
Chandoga — a Sāmaga; Sāmans in connection with
the rituals in founding a new temple.
Bhā. XII. 6. 53; M. 93. 133; 265. 28; Vā. 83. 54.
text.4916:
Chandogas — a Devagaṇa; 33 are distinguished among
them.
Vā. 31. 5.
text.4918:
Chando(u)gha — the chanting of the Vedas, being prac
tised in a hermitage.
Br. III. 21. 46.
text.4919:
Chāga — the goat, as the riding animal of Agni; its flesh
pleasing to Pitṛs.
M. 148, 83; 17. 32.
text.4920:
Chāgala — a peak on the top of the Himalayas where
Śveta the sage-lord appeared with four disciples in the
Vārāha kalpa.
Vā. 23. 116.
text.4921:
Chāgalāṇḍam — a tīrtham sacred to Pracaṇḍā and to
Pitṛs.
M. 13. 43; 22. 72.
text.4922:
Chāyā (I) — a daughter of Viśvakarman,1 a servant
maid of Samjñā engaged by the latter for her husband. Hence
wife of the sun God without his knowledge and mother of
Śanaiścara and Tapatī during the absence of Samjñā as a
horse. Her sons were Śrutaśrava and Śrutakarma or
Sāvarṇi Manu and Saturn respectively; illtreated Samjñā's
children. Yama protested and was cursed to lose his legs.
He reported to his father who said that they would be
restored after some time. Then he asked Chāyā why she
showed difference between her sons and she spoke the
truth. The sun God flew into a rage and demanded
Tvaṣtā to give up his daughter. He showed the place where
Sarvajñā was and Tvaṣtā reduced his tejas. On seeing her,
Śukra came through his nostrils from which were born the
Aśvins or Nāsatya and Dasra.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 13. 8 and 10. M. 11. 5-9; 248. 73; Vā. 84. 39-77.
2) Br. III. 59. 32-77; IV. 35. 47; Bhā. VI. 6. 41.
text.4923:
Chāyā (II) — the mind-born wife of Sṛṣṭi and mother of
five sons.
Bhā. II. 36. 97-98.
text.4924:
Chāyā (III) — the wife of Puṣṭi and mother of five sons,
Prācīnagarbha, Vṛṣaka, Vṛka, Vṛkala and Dhṛti.
Vā. 62. 83.
text.4926:
Chidradarśī — a son of Kauśika in previous birth, born
as Cakravāka in Mānasa.
M. 20. 18.
text.4928:
Chinnakarṇa — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 87.
text.4929:
Jagat — the universe as issuing from the mind and body
of Brahmā;1 Agniṣomātmakam2 born of Viṣṇu and abides in
Viṣṇu.3 Spatial description of; its relation to Īśvara and
other creations.4 1) Bhā. III. 12. 27.
2) Br. III. 72. 50; Vā. 97. 51.
3) Vi. I.
1. 4, 31.
4) Vā. 49. 156-86.
text.4930:
Jagat-sṛṣṭi — Evolution of Tattvas, etc. When the Śaktis
did not attend to their function of creation, the Lord with
Śaktikālā entered into twenty-three tattvas by dividing him
self into three parts — adhyātma, ādhidaiva, and ādhibhauma
with tenfold prāṇa, Agni as his mouth, Varuṇa as tongue,
Aśvins as nostrils, etc. Then came the four varṇas. At
first five varieties of Ajñāna were created, viz., andhatāmisra,
tāmisra, mahāmoha, moha, and tamas. Ashamed of these
sinful creations, Brahmā created seers like Sanaka, Sananda,
etc. They also did not proceed with the work of creation
as was desired. So Brahmā grew angry and down came
Rudra from the midst of his eye-brows. He was assigned
places and women. Finding his creation intolerable, Brahmā
sent him away for penance, and produced ten mind-born
sons, Maricī, Atri and others, and a daughter Sarasvatī. Then
came the Vedas and other literature. Further the Creator's
body got into two halves — one Svāyambhuva and the other
Śatarūpa. These were parents of two sons and three
daughters. Their descendants filled up the whole of the
earth. Another account of creation.
Bhā. III. 5. 27-36; 6. (whole); 12. (whole); 20. 12 ff.
text.4931:
Jagatī — a metre;1 a horse of sun's chariot;2 with Gāyatri
Tṛṣṭub;3 from the face of Brahmā.4 1) Bhā. III. 12. 45; XI. 21. 41; M. 125. 47; Vā. 9. 50; 31. 47.
2) Br. II. 22. 72; Vi. II. 8. 5.
3) Vā. 51. 64.
4) Br. II. 8. 52; 13. 145.
text.4934:
Jagannātha — an attribute of Viṣṇu.
Vi. V. 33. 41.
text.4935:
Jaṅgas — (c) a Janapada of the Ketumāla country.
Vā. 44. 14.
text.4936:
Jaṭāmāli — the avatār of the Lord of the 19th dvāpara
in the Jaṭāyu hill of the Himālayas with four sons, all
engaged in Maheśvara yoga.
Vā. 23. 186-8.
text.4937:
Jaṭāyu (I) — a son of Aruṇa and Gṛdhri (Syeni-Vā. P.)1
brought forth sons Kaka, Gṛdhra and Aśvakarṇi; king of
vultures and younger brother of Sampāti;1 father of Karṇi
kāra and Śatagāmi;2 Dahanakriya of, done by Rāma;
attained release by satsanga.3 1) Br. III. 7. 447-48.
1) Br. III. 7. 447-48.
2) M. 6. 35-6.
3) Bhā. IX. 10. 12; XI.
12. 6; Vā. 69. 326-7.
text.4938:
Jaṭāyu (II) — Mt. a hill in Himālayas, the birth-place of
Jaṭāmāli of the 19th dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 186.
text.4939:
Jaṭī (I) — a group of heretics.
Br. III. 14. 40.
text.4940:
Jaṭī (II) — a name of Vighneśvara.
Br. IV. 44. 70.
text.4941:
Jaṭhara — a Mt. on the East of Meru;1 connects Nīla and
Naiṣadha hills.2 1) Bhā. V. 16. 27; Vā. 35. 8; 42. 20.
2) Vi. II. 2. 41.
text.4942:
Jatu — a son of Sudhanvan (Jantu.).
Vi. IV. 19. 82.
text.4943:
Jatugṛham — the house of lac arranged by Duryodhana
to burn down the Pāṇḍavas.
Vi. IV. 13. 70.
text.4944:
Jatunābha — the son of a Yakṣa and father of Maṇivara.
Vā. 62. 183.
text.4947:
Jana — the fifth loka from where are born people; from
root janana;1 two crores of yojanas from Maharloka.2 1) Br. II. 19. 156; 21. 22; 35. 153 and 206; III. 1. 15-16; M.
61. 1; 184. 23; Vā. 100. 127; 101. 17.
2) Vā. 101. 140, 208.
text.4948:
Janaka (I) — (king of Mithīlā) one of the twelve sages
who knew the nature of the dharma ordained by Hari. Son
of Nimi, born by churning his dead body and hence known
Mithila. He was Vaideha, born of a videha. He founded the
city of Mithilā. His son was Udāvasu. Father of Sītā.1 In
his sacrifice Yājñavalkya won a prize for learning while
Śākalya was humbled for pretended superiority. Father-in
law of Rāma.2 In the Aśvamedha Yajña of his, Sākalya was
ruined on account of his conceit by taking part in a disputa
tion; Janaka wanted to know the best among the learned
assembled and set apart 11,000 crores, much gold, villages
and servants to be given as present to him; in the disputa
tion each took part but Yājñavalkya ultimately threw out
the challenge. Sākalya questioned this and put to him a
number of questions which were all answered. Yājñavalkya
in his turn put him a single question, a wrong reply to it
inviting instantaneous death; Sākalya agreed, and unable to
answer his question, was gathered to his ancestors;3 told by
the sage Asita what the Earth narrated to him about the
ignorance of kings who without subduing themselves, try to
subdue others.4 1) Bhā. VI. 3. 20; IX. 13. 13-14; X. 71. 9; Vā. 89. 2; Vi. IV. 5.
22-4; 13. 103.
2) Br. II. 34. 33-68; III. 37. 22; 64. 2;
3) Vā. 60.
32-62; 89. 5; Vi. III. 18. 85-90.
4) Vi. IV. 24. 127-136.
text.4949:
Janaka (II) — king of Videhas, and an ally of Balarāma.
Welcomed Balarāma to his capital.
Bhā. X. 57. 24-26.
text.4950:
Janaka (III) — a son of Viśākhayūpa and father of Nan
divardhana.
Vi. IV. 24. 5-6.
text.4951:
Janapadas (I) — get deserted and desolate in Kali;1 are
left in a state of arājaka.2 1) Vā. 88. 187.
2) Br. II. 31. 50, 97; III. 50. 5; IV. 5. 4.
text.4952:
Janapadas (II) — the seven of Krauñcadvīpa viz., Uṣṇa,
Pīvara, Andhakāra, Muni, Dundubhi, Kuśala and Manuja.
Vā. 33. 23.
text.4953:
Janamejaya (I) — the first of the four sons of Parīkṣit
and Irāvatī.1 Father of Śatānīka.2 Finding that the death of
his father was predicted to be by the snake Takṣaka, he per
formed a sarpa yāga to destroy all snakes. All except Tak
ṣaka came, the latter being sheltered by Indra. At this Tak
ṣaka and Indra were invoked together. Advised by Bṛhas
pati to refrain from the cruel yāga, Janamejaya agreed; with
the aid of Tura, the priest, he performed Aśvamedha and
other sacrifices;3 cursed by Vaiśampāyana he made Yājña
valkya his Brahmā in a sacrifice.4 Introduced Vājasane
yaka and became known as Trikharvi.5 Put to trouble Loha
gandha, the son of Gārgya out for mischief and was cursed
by Gārgya.6 King of Sudeśa and a Kaurava; highly righte
ous. After anointing his son on the throne he went into
the woods for penance.7 1) Bhā. I. 16. 2; Br. III. 68. 20.
2) Vi. IV. 20. 1; 21. 2-3.
3) Bhā. IX. 22. 35-38; XII. 6. 16-28; M. 6. 42.
4) M. 50. 57-60.
5) Vā. 99. 229, 250-4.
6) Ib. 93. 21.
7) M. 50. 61-5.
text.4954:
Janamejaya (II) — the son of Sumati; with him ended
the Vaiśāla line.
Bhā. IX. 2. 36.
text.4955:
Janamejaya (III) — a son of Pūru and father of Pra
cīnvat.
Bhā. IX. 20. 2; M. 49. 1; Vā. 99. 120. Vi. IV. 19. 1.
text.4956:
Janamejaya (IV) — the son of Sṛñjaya, and father of
Mahāmanas (Mahāśila-B. P.).
Bhā. IX. 23. 2.
text.4957:
Janamejaya (V) — the son of Somadatta, and father of
Sumati (Prumati-Br. P.).
Br. III. 61. 16; Vi. IV. 1. 57-8.
text.4958:
Janamejaya (VI) — a son of Puramjaya and a Rājaṛṣi;1
father of Mahāśāla.2 1) M. 48. 12-3; Vā. 99. 15.
2) Vi. IV. 18. 5-6.
text.4959:
Janamejaya (VII) — a son of Bṛhadratha, entitled Viś
vajit.
M. 48. 102.
text.4960:
Janamejaya (VIII) — a son of Bhallāṭa; served Ugrā
yudha in his tapas; saved Nīpas when they were led by Yama
at the behest of Ugrāyudha by fighting Yama, and earned his
appreciation and muktijñāna from him as a result. Wife
Dhūminī and son Yavīnara.
M. 49. 59-70; Vā. 99. 182.
text.4961:
Janamejayas — 100 in number; according to the M. P.
and Vā. P. 80 in number.
Br. III. 68. 20-26; 74. 267; M. 273. 71-3; Vā. 99. 454.
text.4962:
Jana(loka) — a divine world,1 the world of Varuṇā1a as
the face of Virāṭ,2 and a part of Puruṣ.3 Its inhabitants.4
Here was in ancient times a discussion about brahmavāda,
on the occasion of a sacrifice performed by Brahmā;5 at a
distance of 2 crores of yojanas from Maharlokam;6 during
Pralaya the Devas go from Maharloka to this.7 (See also
Jana). 1) Bhā. VIII. 20. 34.
1a)Vā. 7. 28; 23. 84; 24. 3; 49. 149; 61. 129;
65. 17.
2) Bhā. II. 1. 28.
3) Ib. 5. 39.
4) Ib. III. 11. 29.
5) X. 87.
8-9.
6) Br. IV. I. 123; 2. 13-15, 139. Vi. II. 7. 13-14.
7) Br. I. 6. 28.
Vi. VI. 3. 29.
text.4963:
Janastambha (I) — the son of Śāntidevā and Vasudeva.
Br. III. 71. 180.
text.4965:
Janasthāna — here Rāma vanquished a host of Rāk
ṣasas;1 and performed the work of gods.2 1) Br. III. 63. 195.
2) Vā. 88. 194.
text.4966:
Janāpīḍa — a son of Śarūtha; had four sons, Pāṇḍya,
Keraḷa, Cola, and Kulya.
Vā. 99. 5-6.
text.4967:
Janārdana — a name of Vāsudeva;1 Viṣṇu who took the
form of Hayagrīva and appeared before Agastya at Kāñcī;2
as brother of Devī put down the Hiraṇyas in the
Bhaṇḍa-Lalitā war;3 as Kalki put down the Hūṇas, Yava
nas, etc;4 in the form of Pitṛs in Gayā;5 became black due to
poison;6 becomes Brahmā, Viṣṇu and Śiva affected by the
qualities of satva, rajas and tamas;7 manifestation and forms
described.8 1) Vā. 96. 51; 106. 54.
2) Br. II. 19. 180; 25. 56-7; III. 71. 78
and 93; 73. 87; IV. 5. 8, 14; 9. 28, 47, 64; 12. 21; 15. 14.
3) Br. II.
29. 103, 133.
4) Br. II. 39. 49.
5) Vā. 108. 85, 89; 109. 24 and 34.
6) Vā. 54. 59.
7) Vi. I. 2. 61-7.
8) Vi. I. 22. 23-72; III. 8. 11; 18. 35.
text.4969:
Janu — one of the two Piśācas, who met Yakṣa, the son
of Khaśā.
Vā. 69. 113.
text.4970:
Jantu (I) — a son of Purudvat and Bhadrasenā, the Vai
darbhi. Wife of Aikṣvākī, and son Sātvata.
M. 44. 45-6.
text.4971:
Jantu (II) — a son of Somaka; was killed (before he got
an heir? Ajamīḍha and Dhūmini had to start the line again).
M. 50. 16-19; Vā. 99. 209.
text.4972:
Jantudhanā — a daughter of Yātudhāna,1 married by
Aja? (Yakṣ-Vā. P.), one of the sons of Khaśā; originator of
Yātudhāna clan; hairy in every part.2 1) Br. III. 7. 85.
2) Vā. 69. 124.
text.4974:
Janmadinam — birthday as, fit for Gayāpiṇḍa.
Vā. 105. 18.
text.4975:
Janmeśvaram — a tīrtham sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 42.
text.4976:
Jahnu (I) — a great king, son of Hotraka, (Suhotra
Vā. P.) and Keśinī (Kauśikā-Vā. P.); while he was
performing a sacrifice the Gangā flowed through his
yajñavāṭa; enraged at it he drank the waters; so Gangā
became his daughter and came to be known as Jāhnavī;
married Kāverī, the grand-daughter of Yuvanāśva; and
had a son Sunaha (Suhotra-Vā. P.) by her; father Puru,
Sumantu-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 15. 3; Br. III. 66. 25-30; Vā. 1. 142; 91. 54-60; Vi.
IV. 7. 3-7.
text.4977:
Jahnu (II) — eldest son of Somaka.
Bhā. IX. 22. 1; Vi. IV. 19. 72.
text.4978:
Jahnu (III) — a son (descendant?) of Kuru, and father
of Suratha.
Bhā. IX. 22. 4 and 9; Vā. 99. 217, 230; Vi. IV. 19. 78; 20. 2.
text.4979:
Jahnugaṇa — originated from the son of Aṣṭaka, son of
Viśvāmitra.
Vā. 91. 103.
text.4980:
Japas — a group of gods of Uttama epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 4.
text.4981:
Japayajñas — for Brahmans only;1 for the wise.2 1) Vā. 57. 50.
2) Ib. 16. 22.
text.4983:
Jamadagni (I) — a sage of the Vaivasvata epoch;
(Bhārgava); a son of Ṛcīka and Satyavatī; to attain a son
for himself and for Gādhi, he made a caru to be taken both
by his wife and mother-in-law, the latter to get a Kṣatriya
and the former a Brāhmaṇa; then he entered the forest for
penance; by mistake the caru intended for the mother was
taken by the daughter and vice-versa; Ṛcīka understood the
mistake and told his wife that a cruel son would be born to
her; she implored him to give her a good son; Jamadagni,
born to her; produced by eating (jama) the Vaiṣṇavāgni.1
Entertained Arjuna (Haihaya) with the help of his Kāma
dhenu. The king desired to own her; but on being refused,
he took her away by force. She was recovered by his son
Paraśurāma who killed Arjuna. Regretted his son's action
in killing the king and found fault with Reṇukā his wife who
saw Citraratha. He asked his other sons to kill their mother
but they declined. Paraśurāma killed them and his mother
to please his father but he requested that they might come
back to life to which the sage agreed. But the sons of
Arjuna took vengeance and slew the sage in the presence
of Reṇukā. Through the prowess of his son, Jamadagni
got back his body and became the seventh in the Ṛṣimaṇ
ḍala2 Married Reṇukā, daughter of Reṇu the youngest son
was Rāma. According to the Vāyu Purāṇa Reṇuka is also
known as Kāmali and is said to be the daughter of the
Ikṣvāku, Suveṇu. Vasumat and others were elders to
Rāma.3 Officiated in Brahmā's place in the sacrifice of
Hariścandra;4 a mantrakṛt;5 a Bhārgava gotrakara.6 1) Bhā. VIII. 13. 5; Br. II. 32. 105; 38. 27; M. 9. 28; 126. 21;
Vā. 32. 46; 65. 93; 91. 67 and 85-86. Vi. IV. 7. 32-6.
2) Bhā. IX.
chh. 15 and 16.
3) Ib. IX. 15. 11-13; Vā. 91. 86.
4) Bhā. IX.
7. 23.
5) Br. III. 21 1; M. 145. 99.
6) M. 195. 15 and 29.
text.4984:
Jamadagni (II) — a mantrakṛt and a sage; with the sun
in Māgha and Phālguna.2
^1 Vā. 59. 96. 2) Ib. 52. 20; Vi. II. 10. 16; III. 1. 32.
text.4985:
Jamadagni (III) — a son of Ūru and of Bhṛgu gotra;1
Jamadagni Bhārgava, one of the seven sages.2 1) Vā. 64. 25.
2) Ib. 100. 10.
text.4988:
Jambu — the tree at Ilāvṛtam in the Himālayas.
Br. II. 17. 12; 19. 29; III. 22. 37; 27. 17; IV. 43. 17.
text.4990:
Jambukākṣa — a commander of Bhaṇḍa to aid Viṣaṅga;
was killed by Nīlapatākā.
Br. IV. 21. 80; 25. 29, 98.
text.4991:
Jambulā — a R. of the Bhāratavarṣa.
Vā. 45. 100.
text.4992:
Jambū — (Jāmbūnadam) a river of juice of celestial
rose apple tree flowing from the top of Merumandara into
Ilāvṛta. The earth on its two banks yields fine gold jāmbū
nada from which jewels are made in heaven; source of
jambu;1 R. from Candraprabha2 in colour like a butterfly.3 1) Bhā. V. 16. 19-20; Vā. 35. 26-30.
2) Br. II. 18. 69.
3) Vā.
46. 30.
text.4993:
Jambū (Jambūdvīpa) — occupies the central position of
the globe in the form of a lotus leaf, in extent a 100,000
yojanas. There are nine continents demarcated by moun
tain ranges. In the middle is situated Ilāvṛta, at whose
middle portion stands Meru. Some say that eight extra
countries were attached to it by the sons of Sagara who dug
into the earth on all sides in search of sacrificial horse. This
dvīpa is surrounded by salt sea.1 Contains many janapadas,
cities, mountains, rivers, nine bhuvanas, salt ocean, six
varṣaparvatas and two oceans — east and west. Divided into
nine parts among the sons of Āgnīdhra;2 from the jambu
tree.3 1) Bhā. I. 12. 5; V. 1. 32; 16. 5-7; 19. 29-30; 20. 2; M. 83. 32;
113. 7; 122. 2; 284. 2; Vā. 11. 84; 33. 11 and 45; ch. 34. Vi. II. 3. 28.
2) Br. II. 17. 24, 30; 15. 8 to the end; 14. 11, 43 and 52; Vi. II. 1. 12;
2. 23-25.
3) Vā. 46. 25.
text.4994:
Jambūdvīpa — people of, described. See Jambū.
Vā. 46. 25-37.
text.4995:
Jambūnadī — R. of honey, containing gold.
Vā. 35. 29; 47. 66.
text.4996:
Jambūmārga — a tīrtha with forest near Citrakūṭa;1
sacred to Pitṛs,2 fit for śrāddha;3 here was born Bharata.4 1) Br. III. 13. 38.
2) M. 22. 21.
3) Vā. 77. 38.
4) Vi. II.
13. 33.
text.4997:
Jambūrasavati — R. in Ilavṛtam. (perhaps Jambū, s.v.).
Br. II. 17. 22.
text.4998:
Jambha(ka) (I) — father of Kayādhū, and chief of
Asuras. Took part in the 6th Devāsura war between Bali
and Indra. Fought with Vṛṣā-Kapi. Hearing that Bali had
fallen dead Jambha riding on a lion attacked Indra and dis
abled his elephant. He then turned towards Mātali who
brought a chariot to Indra's aid. But his head was cut off
by Indra's vajra.1 Led Tāraka's army in a chariot of
100 lions; fought with Yama, Kubera, Janārdana and others
but was finally killed.2 1) Bhā. VI. 18. 12; VIII. 10. 21-32; 11. 13-18; Br. III. 6. 10;
72. 81 and 105; Vā. 97. 103.
2) M. 47. 72; 148. 42-54; chh 150-53;
245. 12. Vi. IV. 6. 14; V. 14. 14.
text.4999:
Jambha (II) — a son of Bhāṣkala.
Br. III. 5. 38.
text.5000:
Jambha (III) — a son of Virocana, and father of four
sons.
Vā. 67. 76.
text.5002:
Jambhana — also Jṛmbhaṇa; a commander to aid
Viṣaṅga was killed by Vijayā.
Br. IV. 25. 29.
text.5003:
Jaya (I) — an attendant in Vaikuṇṭha cursed by Sanaka
and others to be born as an Asura. The curse was confirmed
by Hari, who, however, consoled him and Vijaya (s.v.). His
fall.1 In the Devāsura war with Bali, he attacked Bali's fol
lowers.2 1) Bhā. III. 16. 2, 26-37.
2) Ib. VIII. 21. 16.
text.5004:
Jaya (II) — a son of Vatsara and Svarvīthi.
Bhā. IV. 13. 12.
text.5005:
Jaya (III) — a sage of the epoch of the tenth Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 22; 21. 16.
text.5006:
Jaya (IV) — a son of Śruta (Suśruta-Br. P. and Vā. P.),
and father of Vijaya.
Bhā. IX. 13. 25; Br. III. 64. 22; Vā. 89. 21; Vi. IV. 5. 31.
text.5007:
Jaya (V) — a son of Purūravas and Ūrvaśī, and father
of Amita.
Bhā. IX. 15. 1-2.
text.5008:
Jaya (VI) — a son of Viśvāmitra.
Bhā. IX. 16. 36.
text.5009:
Jaya (VII) — a son of Sañjaya and father of Krta.
Bhā. IX. 17. 16-17; Vā. 93. 8. Vi. IV. 9. 26.
text.5010:
Jaya (VIII) — a son of Samkṛti and a great warrior.
With him came to an end the Kṣatravṛddha line. (Burnouf
makes Kṣatradharman his son. The term is only an epithet
of Jaya).
Bhā. IX. 17. 18.
text.5011:
Jaya (IX) — a son of Manyu.
Bhā. IX. 21. 1.
text.5012:
Jaya (X) — a son of Yuyudhāna and father of Kuṇi.
Bhā. IX. 24. 14.
text.5013:
Jaya (XI) — a son of Kanka and Karṇikā.
Bhā. IX. 24. 44.
text.5014:
Jaya (XII) — a son of Bhadrā.
Bhā. X. 61. 17.
text.5015:
Jaya (XIII) — a name of Arjuna (Pāṇḍava).
Bhā. X. 72. 47.
text.5016:
Jaya (XIV) — a nāga of the fifth or Mahātalam.
Br. II. 20. 37; Vā. 50. 36.
text.5018:
Jaya (XVI) — a son of Jāmbavān.
Br. III. 7. 302.
text.5019:
Jaya (XVII) — a son of Kali and grandson of Varuṇa.
Br. III. 59. 7; Vā. 84. 7.
text.5020:
Jaya (XVIII) — a son of Vijaya; father of Haryaśvaka.
Br. III. 68. 9; Vā. 93. 9.
text.5021:
Jaya (XIX) — a son of Sṛñjaya, and father of Vijaya.
Br. III. 68. 8.
text.5024:
Jaya (XXII) — the Vedavyāsa of the 18th dvāpara.
Vi. III. 3. 15.
text.5025:
Jayas — Jayadevas in the guise of Hṛadas;1 lakes in
the Kuru country;2 in the Svāyambhuva epoch.3 See
Jayadevas. 1) Vā. 67. 32.
2) Br. II. 18. 72-73.
3) Ib. III. 3. 65.
text.5026:
Jayakārī — a name of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 13. 2.
text.5027:
Jayatsena (I) — the son of Ahina, father of Samkṛti.
Br. III. 68. 10.
text.5028:
Jayatsena (II) — a son of Sārvabhauma1 and father of
Ārādhita.2 1) M. 50. 36; Vā. 99. 231.
2) Vi. IV. 20. 4.
text.5029:
Jayatsena (III) — a son of Adīna and father of Samkṛti.
Vā. 93. 10; Vi. IV. 9. 27.
text.5031:
Jayadevas — are twelve in number created by Brahmā,
bodies of mantra used in yajñas; these are Darśa, Paurṇa-
māsa, Bṛhadya, Rathantaram, vitti, vivitti, ākūti, kūti,
vijñāsā, vijñāta, manas and yajña. These were again born
as Jitas in the Svayambhuva epoch. Brahmā asked them to
observe household duties and yajñas, but they took to jñāna.
The enraged creator cursed them to undergo seven vṛttis.
They were born in turn as Ajitas, Tuṣitas, Satyas, Haraya,
Vaikuṇthas, Sādyas, and Ādityas.
Br. III. 3. 5-7; 4 (whole).
text.5032:
Jayadratha (I) — the son of Bṛhadkāya and father of
Viśada.
Bhā. IX. 21. 22-23.
text.5033:
Jayadratha (II) — the son of Bṛhanmanas and father of
Vijaya. His wife was Sambhūti.
Bhā. IX. 23. 11-12; Vā. 99. 111; Vi. IV. 18. 22-23.
text.5034:
Jayadratha (III) — the king of Sindhu and an ally of
Jarāsandha; was stationed at the north gate of Mathurā, and
on the east during the siege of Gomanta; served Duryo
dhana's army.
Bhā. X. 52. 11[6]; 50. 11[7]; 78. [95 (v) 16]; Vi. V. 38. 16.
text.5035:
Jayadratha (IV) — a son of the second Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 72.
text.5038:
Jayadratha (VII) — a son of Bṛhadkarman and father of
Viśvajit.
Vi. IV. 19. 34.
text.5039:
Jayadhvaja — a son of Kārtavīrya Arjuna and father of
Tālajangha;1 a Mahāratha who reigned at Avanti;2 known
also as Vaikarta.3 1) Bhā. IX. 23. 27-28; Vā. 94. 50; Vi. IV. 11. 21-22.
2) Br. III.
41. 13; 47. 66; 69. 50.
3) M. 43. 46.
text.5040:
Jayanta (I) — a son of Marutvati and Dharma; an amśa
of Vāsudeva, otherwise known as Upendra.
Bhā. VI. 6. 8.
text.5041:
Jayanta (II) — a son of Indra and Śacī; attacked Asura
followers of Bali. Identified with Hari.
Bhā. VI. 18. 7; VIII. 21. 17; XI. 5. 26; Br. III. 6. 24; Vā. 68. 24.
text.5043:
Jayanta (IV) — the city founded by Nimi near the āśrama
of Gautama.
Br. III. 64. 1-2; Vā. 89. 2.
text.5044:
Jayanta (V) — one of the eleven Rudras.
M. 5. 30.
text.5045:
Jayanta (VI) — a consort of Kīrti and who left him for
Soma (s.v.).
M. 23. 25.
text.5046:
Jayanta (VII) — a son of Vṛṣabha and Jayantī; father of
Akrūra.
M. 45. 26; Bhā. I. 14. 28.
text.5047:
Jayanta (VIII) — a Vināyaka, to be worshipped in house
building.
M. 183. 63; 253. 23 and 40; 255. 8; 266. 43.
text.5048:
Jayanta (IX) — Mt. a kulaparvata of the Ketumāla.
Vā. 44. 4.
text.5049:
Jayantam — a tīrtham sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 73.
text.5051:
Jayantī (I) — Bestowed by Indra in marriage to Ṛṣabha.
Mother of a hundred sons among whom was Bharata.
Bhā. V. 4. 8-9.
text.5052:
Jayantī (II) — the night on which Kṛṣṇa was born.
Br. III. 71. 205; Vā. 96. 201.
text.5053:
Jayantī (III) — daughter of Indra, sent by her father
for the service of Śukra during his Dhūmravrata for
1000 years; rendered him services; pleased with her Śukra
lived with her for ten years, as her husband;1 the result of
this was the birth of Devayānī.2 1) Br. III. 72. 150, 156; 73. 3; Vā. 97. 149; 98. 3.
2) M. 47. 114-88;
Br. III. 1. 86.
text.5054:
Jayanti (IV) — a goddess enshrined at Hastināpura; a
mother-goddess.
M. 13. 28; 179. 13; Vā. 1. 153.
text.5055:
Jayantī (V) — the wife of Vṛṣabharāga and daughter of
Kāśī.
M. 45. 26.
text.5056:
Jayavighnam mahāyantram — made by Viśukra to out
wit the hosts of Lalitā; its effect was the stupefaction of all
the Śaktis and making them speak irrelevantly of the leaders
and minister for war; destroyed by Gaṇanātha Gajānana.
Br. IV. 27. 24 and 54.
text.5057:
Jayasena (I) — a son of Hina (Ahīna B), and father of
Samkṛti.
Bhā. IX. 17. 17-18.
text.5058:
Jayasena (II) — the son of Sārvabhauma and father of
Rādhika.
Bhā. IX. 22. 10.
text.5059:
Jayasena (III) — married Rājadhidevī who became
the mother of two sons, Āvantyas.
Bhā. IX. 24. 39.
text.5061:
Jayā (II) — a moat equal to 12 oceans.
Vā. 47. 70.
text.5062:
Jayā (III) — a companion of Pārvatī.
Br. IV. 40. 33.
text.5064:
Jayā (V) — a goddess enshrined at Varāhaśaila; a
mother-goddess;1 Icon of; to be propitiated before building
palaces.
^2 Ib. 260. 19; 268. 10 and 21. 1) M. 13. 32; 179. 13 and 71.
text.5065:
Jayavāha — an Yakṣa; a son of Devayānī.
Br. III. 7. 128.
text.5066:
Jayātīrtham — a lake in the Kuru country; sacred to
Pitṛs.
M. 22. 49; 121. 70.
text.5068:
Jara (II) — a son of Vasudeva.
Br. III. 71. 187. M. 46. 22.
text.5071:
Jara (V) — a hunter who aimed a shaft at Kṛṣṇa in
ignorance. He was awarded heaven.
Bhā. XI. 30. 33-38; Vi. V. 37. 68-73.
text.5072:
Jaradgavam sthānam — a vīthī in the Madhya mārga.
M. 124. 52 and 57.
text.5075:
Jaraṃdharā — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Satyabhāmā.
Br. III. 71. 247.
text.5076:
Jaraṃdharā — a daughter of Satyabhāmā.
Br. III. 71. 248.
text.5077:
Jarā (I) — a Rākṣasi who picked up the two parts of
Bṛhadratha's son and gave them life — the future Jarā
sandha (s.v.).
Bhā. IX. 22. 8; X. 50. 21; 71. 3; 72. 42.
text.5079:
Jarāsandha (I) — born to Bṛhadratha in two parts and
cast away by the mother. Jarā (s.v.) joined them together,
saying in sport ‘Live, Live’. It was Jarāsandha. He was
father of Sahadeva.1 King of Magadha and father-in-law of
Kamśā who married his daughters Asti and Prāpti; acted as
Kamśā's guru in his wicked plans. Heard of Kamśā's death
from his widowed daughters and resolved to destroy all
the Yādavas. He besieged Mathurā with twenty-three akṣau-
hinis, stationing at the four gates king of Kalinga and
others. Drums were sounded as a call to arms. Told Kṛṣṇa
that he was a boy unfit to fight him and asked Rāma to meet
him in battle. Rāma challenged him on the western gate.
Finding all his army followers killed, Jarāsandha attacked
Rāma. When the latter was about to bind him with ropes,
Kṛṣṇa asked that he be set free. Jarāsandha went home
greatly distressed. Three months after, Jarāsandha collected
another huge army of twenty-three akṣauhinis, encamped at
Yamunā banks and slept that night. Kṛṣṇa divided his
army into three divisions and attacked the enemy on all
sides by surprise. All Jarāsandha's followers took to flight
leaving all their belongings which were presented to Ugra
sena.
Then he called on Bāṇa at his city Śoṇitapura soliciting
his help against the Yadus. Bāṇa's welcome and offer to help;
with this force he again besieged Mathurā. Fight between
him and Rāma. Defeat of Kumbhāṇḍa and retreat of Kūpa
karṇa and other soldiers of Bāṇa to their city. Jarāsan
dha's return to the city.2
Felt angry at Śṛgāla's end and led another expedition
to Mathurā. Defeat and return. In this way he led seven
teen expeditions. During the eighteenth expedition a cer
tain Yavana sent by Nārada besieged the city.3 Jarāsandha
attacked the Yadus going to Dvārakā after vanquishing the
mlecchas by the formation of Makaravyūha when Kṛṣṇa
destroyed it by throwing a big tree on it. Rāma also gave
them mighty blows. Then he turned upon two brothers who
were unarmed and who ran to Pravarṣaṇa hill. Jarāsandha
followed them and burnt the hill by besieging it from all
sides. The brothers leaped into the plains and regained
Dvārakā, but were taken by their enemies to be burnt dead.
His defeat at Kṛṣṇa's hands during the svayamvara of Ruk
miṇī is mentioned. Arrival at Kuṇḍina; went to Śiśupāla
and comforted him that all was due to fate, and returned to
his city.4 His defeats were recalled by Kṛtavarman.5 He
had his capital at Girivraja, where thousands of kings were
kept imprisoned.6 A preliminary to Yudhiṣṭhīra's rājasūya
was to kill Jarāsandha. Finding him unconquered and also
devoted to Brahmaṇas, Kṛṣṇa, Bhīma and Arjuna went to
him in Brahmana's guise and asked for meals. Jarāsandha
understood them to be Kṣatriyas and still recalled Bali giv
ing the earth to Hari in a Brahmana's guise. So he offered
to give his head. Then Kṛṣṇa and his two friends revealed
themselves and invited him to battle. He refused to fight a
coward who left Mathurā for a sea-girt-city, nor with un
equal Arjuna. But he agreed to fight with Bhīma. Then
battle continued for 27 days and Bhīma felt despondent.
Kṛṣṇa gave him a hint by tearing a twig behind. So Bhīma
pulled him down and tore him to two pieces from head to
foot.7 One of those who failed to hit the fish in the svayam-
vara of Lakṣmaṇā.8 1) Bhā. I. 15. 9; IX. 22. 7-8; M. 50. 31-32; 271. 18; Vi. IV. 19.
83-4; 23. 2-3.
2) Bhā. X. 36. 35; 50 (whole); also ch. 50 Vijaya
(whole); chaps. 51-52 (V) Vi. V. 48 (whole).
3) Bhā. X. [53 (v)
22-24]; 50. 42-44; Vi. V. ch. 22.
4) Bhā. X. 52 (whole); 53. 17 and
[34], 57; 54. 9-17; [56 (v) 6]; Vi. 26. 3 and 7; 37. 26.
5) Bhā. X. 57.
13.
6) Ib. X. 60. 18; 70. 23-24, 29.
7) Ib. 71. 2[1], 3-4; 72. 15-47;
73. 31; 76. 2; Vā. 93. 27.
8) Bhā. X. 83. 23; Br. III. 68. 28; 74. 108.
text.5080:
Jarāsandha (II) — a son of Nabhasa; a powerful con
queror of all Kṣatriyas.
Vā. 99. 226-7.
text.5081:
Jarāsaṃdha (III) — of the family of Sahadeva, the
Bṛhadrathas known as Māgadheyas.
Vā. 99. 294.
text.5082:
Jaroṃdhaka — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Satyabhāmā.
Br. III. 71. 247.
text.5083:
Jalada (I) — a son of Havya, after whom came Jalada
varṣa.
Br. II. 14. 17-18; Vā. 33. 16.
text.5085:
Jalada (III) — a son of Bhavya of Śākadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 60.
text.5086:
Jalada(varṣa) — after the name of Jaladā;1 centring
round the Udaya hill in Śākadvīpam.2 1) Br. II. 14. 17-18. Vā. 33. 17.
2) Br. II. 19. 91; Vā. 49. 85.
text.5087:
Jaladhāra (I) — a Mt. of Śākadvīpa from Vāsava; draws
water always from rain.
Br. II. 19. 85-86; M. 122. 9; Vā. 49. 79.
text.5088:
Jaladhāra (II) — a continent of Udaya hill.
M. 122. 20.
text.5089:
Jaladhi — see Varuṇa, who gave garland to Devī on the
eve of her war campaign.
Br. IV. 29. 84.
text.5090:
Jalaprastha — a Māgadha measure of 13 palas; four of
these water measures equal to one nālikoccaya or ghaṭa;
peculiar to the Māgadha country.
Br. IV. 1. 217; Vā. 100. 220; Vi. VI. 3. 8.
text.5091:
Jalapriyā — a goddess enshrined at Śivalinga.
M. 13. 33.
text.5092:
Jalam — as a deity with its adhīdevata Bhava; worship
ped in founding a new temple.
M. 265. 39 and 41.
text.5093:
Jalaṃdhama — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Satyabhāmā. See
Jarandhama.
M. 47. 17.
text.5097:
Jalādhāra — a Mt. of Śākadvīpa; perhaps Jaladhāra
(s.v.).
Vi. II. 4. 62.
text.5098:
Jalādhipa — see Jalam; to be worshipped in house
building.
M. 253. 26.
text.5100:
Jalāśin — a son of Svāhā.
Vi. I. 10. 15.
text.5101:
Jaleyu — one of the ten sons of Raudrāśva.
Bhā. IX. 20. 4; Vā. 99. 124.
text.5103:
Jaleśvara — a tīrtham in the Amarakaṇṭaka hill of
Kalinga, fit for piṇḍatarpaṇam. When Śiva was burning
Tripura ruthlessly, Bāṇa appeared with a linga on his head
when the Lord blessed him with life. Hence the sanctity of
the place.
M. 186. 15-38; 187. 3-52; Ch. 188 (whole).
text.5104:
Jaleṣu — a son of Raudrāśva.
Vi. IV. 19. 2.
text.5105:
Jalpa — a sage of the Tāmasa epoch.
M. 9. 16.
text.5110:
Jaṣadhvaja — the God of Love with fish standard; also
Jaṣaketu, Makaradhvaja.
M. 154. 209 and 283.
text.5111:
Jahu — a son of Puṣpavat.
Bhā. IX. 22. 7.
text.5113:
Jāṃgalas — (c) a kingdom of Madhyadeśa and a tribe.
Br. II. 16. 40; Vā. 45. 109; M. 114. 34.
text.5114:
Jājali (I) — a disciple of Pathya. He is said to have
attained siddhi at a certain place on the western sea. This
spot the Pracetasas chose for their siddhi;1 a Śrutaṛṣi.2 1) Bhā. XII. 7. 2; IV. 31. 2; Vā. 61. 52.
2) Br. II. 33. 2; 35. 59;
III. 36. 5.
text.5116:
Jāji — one of the eight Saubhāgyams.
M. 60. 8.
text.5117:
Jāñjili — a Ṛtvik at Brahmā's yāga.
Vā. 106. 34.
text.5118:
Jāṭhara — the fire originating in waters; this exists in
the men's bellies and cannot be put out by waters; burns
without fuel; it has no jvāla or glow.1 Father of Vidvān
agni.2 1) Br. II. 24. 12; Vā. 53. 8, 10.
2) Br. II. 12. 34.
text.5119:
Jātakakovidās — astrologers foretold the future of
Parīkṣit at his birth.
Bhā. I. 12. 19-29.
text.5120:
Jātakarmā — birth-ceremonial, done by Nanda to
Kṛṣṇa;1 Buda's birth-ritual, as also of Vāmana-Kṛṣṇa;2 of
Sagara.3 1) Bhā. X. 5. 1-16; Br. III. 42. 43; 50. 24; 63. 133; Vi. III. 10.
4-15; 13. 2.
2) M. 24. 5-7; 245. 66; 275. 18.
3) Vi. IV. 3. 36.
text.5121:
Jātambi — a Kaśyapa and a Trayārṣeya.
M. 199. 13.
text.5122:
Jātarūpa — the region of adharma, and of Kali.
Bhā. I. 17. 38.
text.5123:
Jātavedas — the Agni born of araṇis, as son to Pūrū
ravas.
Bhā. V. 20. 16-17; IX. 14. 46.
text.5124:
Jātavedaśilā — near Vṛsakūpa; a holy fire taking people
to heaven.
Vā. 77. 43.
text.5125:
Jātavedasam — a sūktam of the Yajurvedins to be
recited in tank ritual.
M. 58. 35.
text.5126:
Jātismara — the sage who narrated the dialogue between
Yama and his servant to the Kālingaka Brahmana.
Vi. III. 7. 9 and 13.
text.5127:
Jātūkarṇa (I) — the Vedavyāsa of the 28th dvāpara.1
Heard the Viṣṇupurāṇa from Pramati (Parāśara-Vā. P.).2 1) Vi. III. 3. 19.
2) Vā. 103. 66; Vi. VI. 8. 49.
text.5128:
Jātūkarṇa (II) the purohita when Veda-Vyāsa was
born.
Vā. 98. 93.
text.5129:
Jātūkarṇa (III) — the grandson's son of Vasiṣṭha.
Vā. 1. 10.
text.5131:
Jātūkarṇya (I) — the name of Vyāsa of the 27th dvā-
para; Somaśarma, the avatār of the Lord. (See Jātukarṇi).
Vā. 23. 214.
text.5132:
Jātūkarṇi(ya) (II) — learnt the Br. Purāṇa from Parā
śara and in his turn taught it to Dvaipāyana;1 a Vedavyāsa;2
a contemporary of Vedvyāsa;3 exclusion of mutual alliances
among Jātukarṇi, Vasiṣṭha and Atri.4 1) Br. II. 1. 10-11; 35. 124.
2) Bhā. III. 73. 93; Vā. 23. 214.
3) Br. IV. 4. 66.
4) M. 47. 246; 200. 19.
text.5133:
Jātūkarṇya (III) — (Jātūkarṇa-Br. P.); see Kānīna; a
disciple of Śākalya. Imparted the Samhitā with nirukta to
Balāka, Paija and others.
Bhā. IX. 2. 21; XII. 6. 58.
text.5134:
Jātudhi — Mt. a divine mountain in the Uttaradeśa; the
residence of siddhas and sādhus.
Vā. 41. 66; 42. 71.
text.5136:
Jānapadas — country people; treated with love by
Pṛthu;1 were provided with seats in the wrestling enclosure
of Kamsā.2 1) Bhā. IV. 17. 2; 21. 6; M. 220. 15.
2) Bhā. X. 36. 24.
text.5137:
Jānujaṃgha — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
Br. II. 30. 49. Vi. III. 1. 19.
text.5138:
Jāhnavī — Gangā, as the daughter of Janhu, the royal
sage;1 wife of Śamtanu.2 1) M. 104. 13; 110. 7; 183. 73; Vā. 91. 58.
2) Vā. 99. 239.; Vi.
IV. 20. 33; VI. 2. 4.
text.5139:
Jābāla(i) (I) — a pupil of Yājñavalkya;1 of Pathya.2 1) Br. II. 35. 29; M. 198. 4.
2) Vi. III. 6. 11.
text.5140:
Jābāli (II) — visited Paraśurāma, performing penance.
Br. III. 23. 4.
text.5141:
Jābāli (III) — an Arṣeya pravara of Angiras.
M. 195. 38.
text.5142:
Jāmadagni (I) — the sixth human incarnation of Viṣṇu
with Viśvāmitra as purohita in the 19th Tretāyuga;1 with
the Śiśira sun;2 served the Godāvarī tīrtham.3 1) Br. III. 73. 91; M. 47. 244; Vā. 88. 135.
2) Br. II. 23. 20.
3) M. 22. 58.
text.5143:
Jāmadagni (II) — the Bhārgava, who slew the Saimhi
keya gaṇa.
Vā. 68. 22.
text.5144:
Jāmadagnyam — a tīrtham on the Narmada. Here
Indra became lord of gods.
M. 194. 35-6.
text.5145:
Jāmalajā — one of the ten daughters of Raudrāśva.
Vā. 99. 125.
text.5146:
Jāmā — a daughter of Dakṣa married to Dhama; her sons
were Navavīthis on the three paths.
Br. III. 3. 2, 33.
text.5147:
Jāmī — a daughter of Dakṣa, and one of the wives of
Dharma. Mother of Svarga (nāgavithi-Vā. P.).
Bhā. VI. 6. 4 and 6; Vā. 66. 34; Vi. II. 15. 105-7.
text.5149:
Jāṃdhi — a Mt. on the base of Meru; north of the Mahā
bhadra lake.
Bhā. V. 16. 26; Vā. 36. 32; Vi. II. 2. 29, 44.
text.5150:
Jāmbavatī — the daughter of Jāmbavān given in mar
riage to Kṛṣṇa (Vāsudeva). She claimed Syamantaka as her
śulka.1 Mother of Sāmba and three sons and a daughter.2
Welcomed by Draupadī to Indraprastha, she narrated to her
how she married Kṛṣṇa.3 Mother of the daughters Bhadrā
vatī and Sambodhinī.4 1) Bhā. X. 56. 32; 57. 41 [3]; 1. 11. 17. Br. III. 7. 301; 71. 49.
242-50; Vā. 96. 47, 233; Vi. IV. 13. 55, 63; 15. 35; V. 28. 4; 30. 35.
2) Bhā. III. 1. 30; X. 61. 12; 63. 1; M. 46. 26; 47. 14, 18; Vi. V. 32. 2.
3) Bhā. X. 71. 42; 83. 10.
4) Vā. 96. 241.
text.5151:
Jāmbavān (Ṛkṣa) — the son of Rakṣā and Prajāpati
(also Jāmbavat) — The Lord of Ṛkṣas who celebrated
Vāmana's victory over Bali.1 The same person is said to
have been an ally of Rāma.2 Killed the lion that killed
Prasena (s.v.) and took the Syamantaka (s.v.) to his child.
Kṛṣṇa and his citizens traced the footsteps of Prasena, which
led them to the cave of Jāmbavān. Kṛṣṇa fought with the
latter for twenty-eight days Jāmbavān acknowledged his
defeat and praised Hari. He bestowed his daughter Jāmba
vatī and the jewel on Kṛṣṇa.3 Attained salvation by sat-
sanga;4 present at Rāma's abhiṣeka.5 1) Bhā. VIII. 21. 8; Br. III. 7. 300-4; Vi. IV. 13. 32-58.
2) Bhā.
IX. 10. 19 and 44.
3) Bhā. X. 56. 14-32; Br. III. 71. 35; M. 45. 7-8,
12-6; Vā. 96. 34.
4) Bhā. XI. 12. 6.
5) Vi. IV. 4. 100.
text.5152:
Jāmbūnadam — gold formed from the earth on the
banks of the river Jambū largely used by celestials.
Bhā. V. 16. 20-21; Br. II. 17. 30-31; Vi. II. 2. 23.
text.5153:
Jāmbūnadī — a R. in Jambūdvīpa famous for gold.
Vi. II. 2. 21.
text.5154:
Jāradgavāvīthi — consists of Jyeṣṭha, Viśākha and Anu
rādhā in the middle path.
Br. III. 3. 50; Vā. 66. 50.
text.5156:
Jālaṃdh(a)ra — a tīrtham sacred to Lalitā;1 sacred to
Viśvamukhī and the Pitṛs.2 1) Br. IV. 44. 95.
2) M. 13. 46; 22. 64.
text.5157:
Jālaṃdhara Pīṭham — in the breasts of the personified
Veda.
Vā. 104. 80.
text.5158:
Jālavāsinī — a Devī and wife of Kṛṣṇa.
Vā. 96. 234.
text.5159:
Jāleśvaram — one of the eight places sacred to Śiva in
Benares.
M. 181. 28.
text.5160:
Jāhnavī — the wife of Śaṃtanu, mother of Devavṛta.
M. 50. 44-5.
text.5163:
Jita (I) — one of the five sons of Yadu.
Vā. 94. 2.
text.5164:
Jita (II) — a sage of the XII epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 44.
text.5165:
Jitas — the Jayadevas of the Svāyambhuva epoch;1 sons
of Brahmā.2 1) Br. III. 3. 8; Vā. 66. 8.
2) Vā. 31. 4.
text.5166:
Jitavrata — a son of Havirdhāna.
Bhā. IV. 24. 8.
text.5169:
Jiṣṭa — one of the ten branches of the Sukarma devas.
Vā. 100. 94.
text.5170:
Jiṣṇu — a name of Arjuna.
Bhā. I. 16. 1 ff.; Vā. 25. 39; 30. 99; 62, 49; 97. 3.
text.5172:
Jinadharma — alien to Veda; of Hetuvāda; induced
by Bṛhaspati Indra overcame Raji's sons.
M. 24. 47-8.
text.5173:
Jīmūta (I) — a son of Vyoma and father of Vikṛti
(Vimala-M. P.).
Bhā. IX. 24. 4; Br. III. 70. 41; M. 44. 40-41; Vā. 95. 40;
Vi. IV. 12. 41.
text.5174:
Jīmūta (II) a son of Vapuṣmān after whom came a
kingdom.
Br. II. 14. 32, 33; Vā. 33. 28, 29; Vi. II. 4. 23, 29.
text.5176:
Jīmūta (IV) — a Mt. that entered the sea from fear of
Indra.
M. 121. 75.
text.5177:
Jīmūtam — a region of Śālmalidvīpa adjoining the Balā
haka hill.
Br. II. 19. 44; Vā. 49. 40.
text.5178:
Jimūtas — clouds of the Āgneya type without lightning;
under the control of Pravāha air.
Br. II. 22. 36; Vā. 51, 5, 31.
text.5179:
Jīrakam — one of the eight Saubhāgyams.
M. 60. 27.
text.5180:
Jīva (I) — is Guru planet.
M. 93. 10 and 16; Vā. 111. 5.
text.5181:
Jīva (II) — the vital prāṇa; Lord lives in every
creature like the ākāśa, all-pervading in respective pots.
Vā. 102. 101.
text.5182:
Jīvan — months of Nabha and Nabhasya.
Br. 1. 13. 9; Vā. 30. 8.
text.5184:
Jīvas — four classes born of sveda, aṇḍa, udbhija and
jarāyu; and Jīvātma subject to Iśvara is one view.
M. 1. 31; 3. 28.
text.5186:
Jṛmbhana — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 80.
text.5187:
Jṛmbhini — a Śakti on the second parva of the Kiri
cakra; in one of the eight quarters of the sixth parva.
Br. IV. 20. 6, 38, 57, 84; 34. 62.
text.5188:
Jetā — one of the 20 Amitābha gaṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 16; Vā. 100. 16.
text.5189:
Jaigīṣavya (I) — Taught yoga to Viṣvaksena; wife
Aparṇā, a daughter of Menā; got his siddhi at Benares.
Bhā. IX. 21. 26; M. 13. 9; 180. 57.
text.5190:
Jaigīṣavya (II) — the son of Śatśalāka (Śataśilaka) mar
ried Ekapāṭala, a daughter of Himavān; mind-born sons
Śankha and Likhita.
Br. III. 10. 20-21; Vā. 72. 18-19.
text.5191:
Jaigīṣavya (III) — the avatār of the Lord in the 7th dvā
para with four sons.
Vā. 23. 138.
text.5192:
Jaigīṣavya (IV) — a Ṛtvik at the sacrifice of Brahmā.
Vā. 106. 36.
text.5194:
Jaitra (I) — a servant of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 71. 12.
text.5195:
Jaitra (II) — the chariot of Kṛṣṇa, that entered the sea
before he left for Heaven.
Vi. V. 37. 51.
text.5196:
Jaimini (I) — a pupil of Vyāsa in charge of Sāma Veda
(Chandogasamhitā). Was invited for Yudhiṣṭhira's Rāja
sūya. His disciple was Hiraṇyanābha;1 a Śrutaṛṣi who
taught his son Sumantu;2 an authority on Yoga.3 1) Bhā. I. 4. 21; IX. 12. 3; X. 74. 8; XII. 6. 53 and 75. Vā. 60.
13, 18; 61. 26; Vi. III. 4. 9.
2) Br. II. 1. 13; 34. 4 and 13; 35. 48;
III. 33. 7; 35. 3; Vi. III. 6. 1-2.
3) Vā. 88. 207; Vi. IV. 4. 107.
text.5198:
Jaivantyāyani — an Arṣeya pravara of Bhārgavas.
M. 195. 37.
text.5201:
Jyāmagha (I) — a son of Rucaka (Puravṛt-Vi. P.)
banished out of the land by his elder brothers who
were kings; surrounded by Brahmans he lived in a fearful
forest in peace; soon he set out with a chariot and a flag
towards the kingdom on the Narmadā single-handed
and reached the hill Ṛkṣavān; his wife was Saivya,
but they had no son. In the battle he won victory,
and soon got a daughter, whom he called Śnuṣā, (daughter
in-law) adding to his wife that the son to be born
would be her husband; the son was Vaiśa, the Vidarbha, who
married Snuṣā, and got two sons, Kratha and Kauśika;1 his
line.2 1) Bhā. IX. 23. 35-39. Br. I. 1. 22. III. 70. 29-49; M. 44. 28-36.
Vā. 1. 144; 95. 28-36. Vi. IV. 12. 11-36.
2) Vā. 95. 36-47.
text.5202:
Jyāmahāni — a pupil of Lāngala.
Br. II. 35. 48.
text.5203:
Jyeṣṭha — one of the 20 Amitābha gaṇas.
Vā. 100. 17.
text.5204:
Jyeṣṭha sāma — a sūkta of the Sāma Veda to be recited
at the Śrāddha or in installing an image.
M. 17. 38; 58. 36; 95. 30; 265. 27.
text.5205:
Jyeṣṭha sāmaga — fit for Śrāddha feeding.
Vā. 83. 54. Vi. III. 15. 2.
text.5206:
Jyeṣṭhā (I) — constellation on the left shoulder of Śiśu
māra;1 Śrāddha performed that day gives one overlordship.2 1) Bhā. V. 23. 6. Vā. 66. 50.
2) Br. III. 18. 9.
text.5207:
Jyeṣṭhā (II) — an evil spirit.
Bhā. X. 6. 28; Br. IV. 19. 73.
text.5209:
Jyeṣṭhās — Prajāpatis born of Brahmā's ears.
Vā. 65. 58.
text.5210:
Jyoti (I) — a R. of Śālmalidvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 46.
text.5212:
Jyoti (III) — a son of Vasiṣṭha and a Prajāpati of the
Svārociṣa epoch.
M. 9. 9.
text.5214:
Jyoti (V) — one of the twenty Sutapa gaṇas.
Vā. 100. 14.
text.5215:
Jyoti (VI) — a sage of the Tāmasa epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 18.
text.5216:
Jyotirgaṇa vivecana (jyotirgaṇavicintana) — reckoning
and research in astronomy with the help of the Śāstras,
experience, observation, and comparison; physical eyes,
science, waters, writing and counting are essential instru
ments in this science.
Br. II. 24. 152; Vā. 53. 123.
text.5217:
Jyotirdhāman — one of the seven sages of Tāmasa epoch;
a Bhārgava.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 28. Br. II. 36. 47.
text.5218:
Jyotiṣa — the science of Astronomy begins in Dvāpara;1
a part of Viṣṇu;2 attributed to Garga who learnt it from
Śeṣa.3 1) M. 144. 22; Vā. 66. 52.
2) Vi. V. 1. 37.
3) Bhā. X. 8. 5;
Br. II. 21. 36; 22. 3; III. 5. 80; Vi. II. 5. 26.
text.5220:
Jyotiṣka — a peak of Meru full of precious stones; here
Ādityas, Vasus, Aśvins, Guhyakas, Yakṣas, other sages,
Apsaras, all worship Paśupati besides Nandi and Gangā.
Vā. 30. 81-92.
text.5222:
Jyotiṣmat (I) — a boundary hill in Plakṣadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 4.
text.5223:
Jyotiṣmat (II) — one of the ten sons of Kardama and
king of Kuśadvīpa which he divided among his seven sons,
Udbhijja, Veṇumān, Vairatha, Lavaṇa, Dhṛti, Prabhākara
and Kapila.
Br. II. 14. 9, 27-28.
text.5224:
Jyotiṣmat (III) — a name in the first Marut gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 92; Vā. 67. 123.
text.5225:
Jyotiṣmat (IV) — (Bhārgava) a sage of the Rohita
epoch.
Br. IV. 1. 63. Vi. III. 2. 23.
text.5226:
Jyotiṣmat (V) — one of the ten sons of Svāyambhuva
Manu.
M. 9. 5; Br. II. 13. 104.
text.5227:
Jyotiṣmat (VI) — a grandson of Svāyambhuva Manu;
consecrated for Kuśadvīpa.
Vā. 31. 18; 33. 9, 12.
text.5228:
Jyotiṣmat (VII) — a son of Priyavrata and king of Kuśa
dvīpa.
Vi. II. 1. 8, 13.
text.5229:
Jyotiṣmatī — R. a tributary of the Sarasvatī, flows from
Varcovan lake.
Br. II. 18. 66. M. 121. 65; Vā. 47. 63.
text.5230:
Jyotiṣmanta — a Devagaṇa with Yama as their lord;
Vasus.
Br. III. 1. 52. M. 5. 20.
text.5231:
Jyotsnā (I) — a R. from the Sarayū (or Mānasa?).
Br. II. 18. 71.
text.5232:
Jyotsnā (II) — a kala of the moon.
Br. IV. 35. 92.
text.5233:
Jyotsnā (III) — a tanu of Prajāpati; men created from it
were all delightful beings; of satva quality.
Vā. 9. 20; Br. II. 8. 21.
text.5234:
Jyotsnā (IV) — a R. from the Śveta.
Vā. 47. 68.
text.5236:
Jyotsni — a Śakti on the Soḍaśa patrābja.
Br. IV. 32. 11.
text.5237:
Jvaram — the effulgence of Maheśvara, as divided among
created beings.
Vā. 30. 298-305.
text.5239:
Jvara (II) — 2 different kinds of, Vaiṣṇava, Māheśvara.
Vi. V. 33. 14-18.
text.5240:
Jvalanā — the wife of Aneyu (Riveyu-Vā. P.) and a
daughter of Takṣaka; mother of Antīnara.
M. 49. 6-7; Vā. 99. 128.
text.5241:
Jvālā (I) — (Aṅgāraka) a class of piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 377.
text.5242:
Jvālā (II) — after the conquest of the three worlds by
Viṣṇu, the Devas, including Brahmā praised him; Brahmā
was the creator while Viṣṇu was the creator and destroyer
of worlds; during their discussion there was a jvālā in the
north which spread over all the worlds out of which came
Linga which went on growing. To see its beginning and
end both agreed to go above and below respectively; they
went on for 1000 years; it was beyond reckoning; hence both
praised Śiva for light; Śiva said that Brahmā was the right
hand and Viṣṇu his left hand and disappeared.
Vā. 55. 17-61.
text.5243:
Jvālāmālinikā — an Akṣara Devi;1 killed Trīkarṇika, a
commander of Bhaṇḍa.2 1) Br. IV. 19. 59.
2) Ib. 25. 98; 37. 35.
text.5247:
Jharjara — a son of Hiraṇyākṣa.
Vi. I. 21. 3.
text.5249:
Jñānam — nature and value of;1 superior to sannyāsa;2
two-fold;2a freedom from desire and enmity; leads to renun
ciation or tyāga; leads to yoga;3 fourteen-fold; the eleven of
guṇaśarīra and buddhi, citta, and ahankāra; does not see
separately; knows himself; there is, or there is not.4 diffi
culties to attain;5 the path of.6 1) Bhā. XI. 19. 1-27.
2) Vā. 91. 114-15.
2a)Vi. VI. 5. 61.
3) Br. IV. 3. 40, 55; 5. 27.
4) Vā. 102. 61, 75, 107, 123. Vi. I. 22. 46-9.
II. 12. 43-4.
5) Vā. 58. 21; 59. 54.
6) Ib. 104. 15.
text.5251:
Jñāna yoga — for the ascetic and the detached. A true
jñāni forgets himself;1 resultant of Karma Yoga.2 1) Bhā. XI. 20. 6-7; 28. 9 and 31.
2) M. 52. 5-11.
text.5253:
Jñānī — a God of the Rohita gaṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 85.
text.5254:
Ṭaṅkaṇās — the horses of Ṭankaṇa country.
Br. IV. 16. 16.
text.5257:
Ṭavargamaṇḍiṭākāra — also Vimalā and Sarasvatī on the
Sarvarogahara cakra.
Br. IV. 37. 5.
text.5259:
Ḍākini (I) — an attendant on Śiva.
Br. III. 41. 30.
text.5260:
Ḍākinī (II) — a Śakti on the fourth parva of Kiricakra.
Br. IV. 20. 16.
text.5264:
Takṣa (I) — a son of Bharata, founded Takṣaśīla in
Gāndhāra.
Bhā. IX. 11. 12; Br. III. 63. 190; Vā. 88. 189; Vi. IV. 4. 104.
text.5265:
Takṣa (II) — a son of Vṛka and Durvārkṣī.
Bhā. IX. 24. 43.
text.5266:
Takṣaka (I) — a serpent chief; (nāga) of Sutalam
and of the Krodhavaśa group.1 Caused the death of
Parīkṣit in consequence of the curse of the Brahmaṇa's son.
Parīkṣit was informed beforehand by Śuka and was not
afraid.2 Met the sage Kaśyapa on his way to Parīkṣit's
place.3 When Janamejaya began his sarpa satra (yāga),
Takṣaka sought shelter of Indra, and this resulted in Indra's
fall;4 served as calf for Nāgas to derive poison from the
earth.5 The Nāga presiding over the month of Śukra;6 on
the neck of Śiva; an ear ornament of Śiva.7 Shaken by
Hiraṇyakaśipu;8 lived in the Niṣadha hill;9 sent along with
others to fight Prahlāda;10 a Kādraveya;11 in the sun's cha
riot in the month of Suci.12 1) Bhā. V. 24. 29; Br. II. 17. 34; 20. 24; III. 7. 32; M. 6. 39; 8. 7.
Vā. 39. 54; 50. 23; 54. 91; 69. 69.
2) Bhā. I. 12. 27; 18. 2 and 37;
19. 4; IX. 22. 36; XII. 5. 10; 6. 5.
3) Ib. XII. 6. 11-12.
4) Ib.
XII. 6. 16-23.
5) Ib. IV. 18. 22; Br. III. 8. 13; IV. 20. 53; 33. 36;
36. 212; M. 10. 19.
6) Bhā. XII. 11. 35.
7) Br. II. 25. 88; M. 154.
444.
8) M. 163. 56: 114. 83; 126. 7; 133. 33.
9) Vā. 46. 34; 52. 6.
10) Vi. I. 17. 38.
11) Ib. I. 21. 21.
12) Ib. II. 10. 7.
text.5267:
Takṣaka (II) — the son of Prasenajit and father of
Bṛhadbala.
Bhā. IX. 12. 8.
text.5268:
Takṣaka (III) — the father of Jvalanā (s.v.).
M. 49. 6; Vā. 99. 128.
text.5269:
Takṣaśilā — the capital of Takṣa, the son of Bharata.
Br. III. 63. 191; Vā. 88. 190.
text.5270:
Taṅgaṇa — an E. tribe; a hilly country.
Vā. 45. 120, 135; 47. 44.
text.5271:
Taḍāgavidhi — Rules for the construction of tanks, wells,
temples, at the auspicious hour: the ritual connected with
these described; result equals that of performing Agniṣṭoma,
Vājapeya and other sacrifices.
M. Ch. 58.
text.5273:
Taṇḍika — a son of Haryanga; had the white elephant
for his vāhana.
Vā. 99. 108.
text.5275:
Tatvas — twenty-three in number. For the sake of
creation the Supreme Being associates with Kālaśakti and
makes these twenty-three principles active.1 Twenty-four
also in number.2 Sometimes twenty-five.3 1) Bhā. III. 5. 2-4; M. 3. 29.
2) Br. III. 19. 64.
3) Ib. IV. 8. 33.
text.5277:
Tatvadarśa — a sage of the epoch of the thirteenth
Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 31; Vi. III. 2. 40.
text.5278:
Tatvadarśī (I) — (Pauleya) a sage of the Raucya epoch.
Br. IV. 1. 102.
text.5280:
Tatvadarśī (III) — a son of Sudaridra, an aged Brahmana
of Pāñcāladeśa.
M. 21. 3.
text.5281:
Tatvam — the one truth which could not be attained
even by the mind (Veda).
Vā. 102. 127.
text.5282:
Tatvalam — the first world;1 dark soil;2 residence of the
Asuras like Namuci and Mahānāda, the Rākṣasas, Nāgas
etc.3 1) Br. II. 20. 11.
2) Ib. II. 20. 13.
3) Ib. II. 20. 15-20.
text.5284:
Tatvasamhitā — a treatise attributed to Kardama
(Kapila). It treats of twenty-four principles and the
twenty-fifth was Kāla.
Bhā. III. 21. 32; 26. 11-16.
text.5285:
Tathya — was born to help Māndhāta.
Vā. 98. 90.
text.5286:
Tanapa (c) — a Janapada of the Bhadra country.
Vā. 43. 21.
text.5289:
Tantija — one of the sons of Kṛṣṇa given to Kanaka.
Vā. 96. 189.
text.5291:
Tantimāla — one of the sons of Kṛṣṇa given to Kanaka.
Vā. 96. 189.
text.5292:
Tantra — Āgama śāstra in which yogins were learned;1
prescribes rules for the worship of Hari;2 known in Dvāpara
yuga,3 deals with the vibhūtis of Hari.4 1) Bhā. I. 3. 8; IV. 24. 62; Vā. 104. 86.
2) Bhā. XI. 3. 47.
3) Ib. XI. 5. 28 and 31; 27. 26.
4) Bhā. XII. 11. 4 and 20.
text.5293:
Tantriṇi — an attendant on Sangīta yogini holding a vīṇa.
Br. IV. 17. 46.
text.5294:
Tandrā — a Kalā of Rudra.
Br. IV. 35. 96.
text.5295:
Tanmātra — ‘rudimentary, undifferentiated, subtle ele
ments from which a gross element is produced.’
M. 3. 22-26; Vā. 4. 52.
text.5296:
Tanva of Svāyambhuva — rajas, tamas and satva, differ
ent in different times; Brāhmi, Pauruṣi and Antakāri; or Pra
jāpatya, Raudri and Vaiṣṇavi.
Vā. 66. 86-102.
text.5297:
Tapa (I) — a part of Vibhu.
Br. III. 4. 24.
text.5298:
Tapa (II) — one of the twenty Sutapa gaṇas.
Br. IV. 1. 14; Vā. 100. 14.
text.5300:
Tapa (IV) a God of Rohita gaṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 85.
text.5303:
Tapa (VII) — one of the Mukhya gaṇa.
Vā. 100. 18.
text.5304:
Tapa (VIII) — a son of Raucya Manu.
Vā. 100. 108.
text.5305:
Tapa (IX) — (also Tapoloka) a celestial world,1 form
ing the forehead of Virāṭpuruṣa; the sixth loka, the resi
dence of Ṛbhu, Sanatkumāra and others, originators of Man
vantaras; each of them resides conjointly with yoga, tapa
and satya; four crores of yojanas above Janaloka; the resi
dence of the celestial Vairājas; above it, the Satyaloka or
Brahmaloka.2 1) Bhā. II. 1. 28; VIII. 20. 34; XI. 24. 14; M. 61. 1; 184. 23.
2) Vā. 101. 17, 37, 211; 101. 208; Vi. II. 7. 14-15.
text.5306:
Tapa (X) — the month of Māśi, (Feb.-Mar.) sacred to
Pūṣa.
Bhā. XII. 11. 39; Vā. 30. 9; 50. 202.
text.5307:
Tapa (XI) — the essence milked by Bṛhaspati from
cow-earth in the vessel of the Veda; practised by Yayātī;
greater than sacrifices.1 Fasting and restraint lead to vai
rāgya; other features are celibacy, prayer and silence.2 1) M. 10. 17; 35. 15-17; 143. 33-40; Vā. 57. 121-5.
2) Vā 57.
116-17; 59. 41.
text.5308:
Tapatī (I) — a daughter of Sūrya and Chāyā. Married
Saṃvaraṇa, and became the mother of Kuru; became the
river.
Bhā. VI. 6. 41; IX. 22. 4; VIII. 13. 10; M. 11. 9, 39; Vi. III.
2. 4.
text.5309:
Tapatī (II) — a R. sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 32.
text.5310:
Tapana — the Sun whose daughter is Yamunā.
M. 108. 23; 110. 5.
text.5311:
Tapaśri — a queen of Śiśira.
Br. IV. 32. 39.
text.5312:
Tapasūrmī — one of the twenty-eight hells for misbe
haviour of man or woman.
Bhā. V. 26. 7 and 20.
text.5313:
Tapasya (I) — Phālguna, the month sacred to Kratu.
Bhā. XII. 11. 40; Br. II. 13. 11. Vā. 30. 9.
text.5314:
Tapasya (II) — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
M. 9. 17.
text.5315:
Tapasvinī — the third daughter of Bhangakāra, married
to Kṛṣṇa.
Vā. 96. 55.
text.5316:
Tapasvī (I) — a sage of the epoch of the twelfth Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 28.
text.5317:
Tapasvī (II) — a son of Cākṣuṣa Manu.
Br. II. 36. 79, 106; M. 4. 41.
text.5318:
Tapasvī (III) — is Kaśyapa; a sage of the epoch of the
fourth Sāvarṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 92.
text.5319:
Tapasvī (IV) — a son of Manu and Naḍvalā.
Vi. I. 13. 5.
text.5320:
Tapasvī (V) — a sage of the XII epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 35.
text.5321:
Tapā — an adopted son of Vastāvana.
Vā. 96. 190.
text.5322:
Tapojani — a Deva of the Rohita group.
Vā. 100. 90.
text.5324:
Tapodyuti — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
M. 9. 17.
text.5325:
Tapodhana (I) — (Paulastya): a sage of the epoch of
the 4th Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 92.
text.5326:
Tapodhana (II) — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
M. 9. 17.
text.5327:
Tapodhana (III) — a sage of the XII epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 35.
text.5328:
Tapodhana (IV) — a son of Bhṛgu, the avatār of the
Lord.
Vā. 23. 149.
text.5329:
Tapodhṛti (I) — (Bhārgava) a sage of the epoch of
the 4th Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 93.
text.5330:
Tapodhṛti (II) — a sage of the XII epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 35.
text.5331:
Tapobhogi — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
M. 9. 18.
text.5332:
Tapomūrti (I) — a sage of the epoch of the twelfth
Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 28; Vi. III. 2. 35.
text.5333:
Tapomūrti (II) — (Angiras): a sage of the epoch of
the 4th Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 92.
text.5334:
Tapomūrti (III) — a sage of the X epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 27.
text.5335:
Tapomūla — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
M. 9. 17.
text.5336:
Tapoyogi — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
M. 9. 18.
text.5337:
Taporāti (I) — (Paulaha): a sage of the epoch of the
4th Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 92.
text.5338:
Taporāti (II) — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
M. 9. 17.
text.5339:
Taporāti (III) — a sage of the XII epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 35.
text.5340:
Tapoloka — see also Tapa.
Bhā. II. 5. 39; Vā. 7. 30; 24. 3; 49. 149; 61. 132 and 177.
text.5341:
Taptakumbha — (Taptakuṇḍa-Vi. P.); a hell, into
which fall disloyal government servants, dealers in horses,
gaolers, and women, those who have sexual intercourse with
sisters, preceptor's wife, incestuous offenders, murderers of
Kṣatriyas and Vaiśyas and slayers of royal emissary.
Br. IV. 2. 147, 156; Vā. 101. 146, 154; Vi. II. 6. 2 and 9-10.
text.5342:
Taptaloka — a hell into which fall those who deal in
horses, guardians of prisoners, sellers of chaste ladies and
those who abandon bhaktas and companions.
Vā. 101. 154; Vi. II. 6. 11.
text.5343:
Tama (I) — (lokapṛṣṭha): a kind of hell: persons fallen
from Varṇa and Āśramadharma find this hell.
Br. IV. 2. 150, 177-78; Vā. 101. 149, 179; Vi. II. 6. 4.
text.5344:
Tama (II) — equated with ajñāna or ignorance, bound
by three fetters; to think that which is not eternal as eternal,
to regard happiness in one's difficulties, to regard one's own
self which is not his own, and to regard that as pure which
is impure;1 fourfold, with Tāmasi vṛtti, the lowest.2 1) Br. IV. 3. 33-38.
2) Ib. 3. 53.
text.5346:
Tamasā — a R. from the Rkṣavat in Bhāratavarṣa.
Br. II. 16. 30; M. 114. 25; 163. 64; Vā. 45. 100, 136.
text.5347:
Tamisrā — a Śakti on the Ṣoḍasapatrābjā.
Br. IV. 32. 11.
text.5349:
Tamoliptam — the vimāna with faces on all sides on
which rode Tiraskarṇikā.
Br. IV. 24. 75.
text.5351:
Tamgaṇās — an eastern country;1 a hill tribe.2 1) Br. II. 16. 51.
2) Ib. II. 16. 67.
text.5352:
Tampoṭṭa — a war-musical instrument; others are
Bheri, Missāṇa, and Paṇavānaka.
Br. IV. 24. 14.
text.5353:
Tambu — a son of Śārngadevā and Vasudeva.
Vā. 96. 177, 249.
text.5354:
Tamburas — a forest tribe of the Vindhyas.
Br. II. 36. 145.
text.5355:
Taraṅgiṇī — a R. flows through the Uttarakuru country
and falls into the north ocean.
Vā. 42. 76-7.
text.5357:
Tarasvī — a Yādava; a son of Sāmbā.
Vā. 96. 252.
text.5358:
Taruvalkala — barks of trees to cover nakedness;
applied to harassed subjects living in the mountain valleys
in degenerate times.
Vi. IV. 24. 96.
text.5359:
Tarka (I) — came to see the Trivikrama form of Hari.
Bhā. VIII. 21. 2.
text.5361:
Tarja — a son of Auttama Manu.
M. 9. 12.
text.5362:
Tarṣa — a son of Vāsanā and Arka; a Vasu.
Bhā. VI. 6. 13.
text.5363:
Talaka (I) — a son of Āndhra Hāleya, and father of
Purīṣabhīru.
Bhā. XII. 1. 25.
text.5364:
Talaka (II) — a pupil of Kṛta.
Br. II. 35. 51.
text.5366:
Talaśabdam — slapping of arms in defiance by Kṛṣṇa on
seeing the asura Ariṣṭa as a bull.
Vi. V. 14. 8.
text.5367:
Talā — one of the ten daughters of Raudrāśva.
Vā. 99. 126.
text.5368:
Talātala — an underworld, being the residence of Asura
Maya who won the grace of Śiva and moved about without
fear of the Sudarśana;1 residence of Prahlāda.2 1) Bhā. II. 1. 26; V. 24. 7 and 28.
2) Br. II. 20. 12-14, 25-31.
text.5369:
Tavarga — the two sides of the navel of the Veda.
Vā. 104. 72.
text.5370:
Tāḍ(ṭ)akā — wife of Sundā (Mārica-Vā. P.) and mother
of Mārīca;1 was killed by Rāma2 1) Br. III. 5. 36; Vā. 67. 72.
2) Vi. IV. 4. 88.
text.5371:
Tāṇḍi — exclusion of marriage alliances among Angiras
and Maudgalyas.
M. 196. 44.
text.5372:
Tāntrika — a mode of worship but different from the
Vaidika or Vedic path;1 the Tāntrika concept of Hari.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 6. 9.
2) Ib. XII. 11 (whole); Br. IV. 2. 108.
text.5373:
Tāntrikī Dīkṣā — as different from the Vaidika, in the
mode of prayer to Hari.
Bhā. XI. 11. 37; 27. 7.
text.5375:
Tāpatrayam — three pains; ādhyātmika (bodily and
mental pain), ādhibhautika (natural but incidental pain)
and ādhidaivika (superhuman); each is multiplied in
thousands.
Vi. VI. 5. 1-9.
text.5376:
Tāpanīya — a pupil of Yājñavalkya.
Br. II. 35. 29.
text.5378:
Tāpaseśvaram — Here to the wonderment of a hunter,
a deer which fell in water due to dread was taken to the world
above.
M. 191. 102-4.
text.5380:
Tāpī (I) — a R. in Bhāratavarṣa rising in the Vin
dhyas;1 visited by Balarāma.2 1) Bhā. V. 19. 18; Br. II. 16. 32; M. 114. 27.
2) Vā. 45. 102; Bhā.
X. 79. 20.
text.5381:
Tāpī (II) — a R. rises from the Ṛkṣa hill.
Vi. II. 3. 11.
text.5382:
Tāmarasā — one of Atri's wives.
Br. III. 8. 76.
text.5383:
Tāmasa (I) — a son of Priyavrata, and a Manvantara
adhipati.1 The fourth Manu and brother of Uttama. He
had Pṛthu and nine other sons. During this epoch the
gods went by the name of Satyakas, Haris, etc. Triśikha
was Indra. Jyotirdhāmā and others were the seven sages.2
Brother of Raivata.3 For different names of Gods, sages and
Indra in this epoch;4 represents ukāra;5 twenty-seven gaṇas
of Gods mentioned in this epoch — Supāra, Haraya, etc. Śibi
was Indra; Nara and Khyāti, his sons.6 1) Bhā. V. 1. 28; Vi. III. 1. 24.
2) Bhā. VIII. 1. 27-28.
3) Ib.
VIII. 5. 2.
4) Br. II. 36. 3, 42-50; M. 9. 15.
5) Vā. 26. 36; 62. 3.
6) Vi. III. 1. 6, 16-19.
text.5384:
Tāmasa (II) — the quality of Bhūtādi swallowed by
Mahat of which Buddhi is the guṇa.
Vā. 102. 19-20.
text.5385:
Tāmasamanvantara — four gaṇas; each of 25 devas;
sages; sons.
Vā. 62. 37-43.
text.5386:
Tāmasa sarga — in this epoch were created sons of Himsa
and of Adharma.
Vā. 10. 38-45.
text.5388:
Tāmasī (II) — one of the three mātras of Om, the
Praṇava.
Vā. 20. 2.
text.5389:
Tāmasī (III) — a R. of the Ketumālā country.
Vā. 44. 17.
text.5390:
Tāmasī (IV) — (Kālā, Prajākṣayakari);1 possessed by
Bhava.2 1) Vā. 66. 85, 89. 100.
2) Ib. 66. 101-5.
text.5391:
Tāmasī (V) — also known as Pūtanā; wife of Sadrama.
Vā. 84. 12.
text.5392:
Tāmasī vṛtti — that which is at the bottom; four-fold; no
belief in the Veda, Śiṣtācāra, non-observance of Varṇāśrama
and of Dharma śāstras.
Vā. 102. 54, 70-73.
text.5393:
Tāmisra — a hell among the twenty-eight in number.
Here are put to torments, those who lay hands on another's
property, children and women.
Bhā. III. 30. 28; IV. 6. 45; V. 26. 7-8; Vi. I. 6. 41; III. 11. 104.
text.5394:
Tāmbūla — offered to Hari in Payovrata.1 Offered by
the merchants of Mathurā to Kṛṣṇa and his brother;2 used by
Trivakrā before she met Kṛṣṇa;3 offered to Brahmana ladies,
who were not widows, in the Devi temple just before the
marriage of Rukmiṇī;4 given by Kṛṣṇa to Brahmanas;5
offered to Kucela by Kṛṣṇa;6 offered to Hari by Indrasena;7
to be offered to Tripurasundari during worship.8 1) Bhā. VIII. 16. 41.
2) Ib. X. 42. 13.
3) Ib. X. 48. 5.
4) Ib. X.
53. 48; 61. 6.
