5) Ib. X. 70. 13: 73. 26.
6)Ib. X. 80. 22.
7) Ib. X.
85. 37; XI. 27. 43.
8) Br. IV. 43. 13.
text.5395:
Tāmbūladhāri — an attendant on the king.
M. 215. 15.
text.5396:
Tāmra (I) — a son of Mura (s.v.).
Bhā. X. 59. 12.
text.5398:
Tāmra (III) — a son of Satyabhāmā and Kṛṣṇa.
M. 47. 17; Br. III. 71. 247.
text.5399:
Tāmratapta — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Rohiṇī.
Bhā. X. 61. 18.
text.5400:
Tāmrapakṣa — a son of Rohiṇi and Kṛṣṇa.
Vi. V. 32. 2.
text.5401:
Tāmraparṇa (I) — the elephant of the sāma fold.
Br. III. 7. 337.
text.5402:
Tāmraparṇa (II) — one of the nine divisions of Bhārata
varṣa.
M. 114. 8; Vi. II. 3. 6.
text.5403:
Tāmraparṇī (I) — a R. of the Kulācala hill in Bhārata
varṣa,1 and in Drāviḍa.2 Visited by Balarāma;3 from the
Malaya Hills flowing through sandal wood regions; famous
for pearls and conch; fit for śrāddha offerings;4 sacred to
Pitṛs;5 flows towards the southern ocean; at its confluence
with the ocean are produced conches, shells and pearls.6 1) Bhā. IV. 28. 35; V. 19. 18.
2) Ib. XI. 5. 39.
3) Ib. X. 79. 16.
4) Br. II. 16. 36; III. 13. 24-7; IV. 33. 52; Vi. II. 3. 13.
5) M. 22.
49; 114. 30.
6) Vā. 77. 24-5.
text.5404:
Tāmraparṇī (II) — a daughter of Satyabhāmā.
Br. III. 71. 248; Vā. 96. 240.
text.5405:
Tāmrapātram — (Tāmram) copper vessel for ceremo
nial purposes; fit for gifts.
M. 7. 12; 58. 13; 59. 8; 61. 45; 206. 15; 279. 7; 288. 11;
Vā. 74. 1.
text.5407:
Tāmralipta(ka) — the territory under King Devarakṣita;1
an eastern country and tribe; a Janapada of the east.2 1) Vi. IV. 24. 64.
2) Br. II. 18. 51; III. 74. 197; M. 114. 45;
121. 50; 163. 72; Vā. 45. 123; 99. 385.
text.5409:
Tāmravarṇa — a Mt. near Patanga in the southern
direction.
Vā. 38. 8.
text.5410:
Tāmravarṇa(ṇi) (I) — a division of the Bhāratavarṣa.
Br. II. 16. 9; Vā. 45. 79.
text.5411:
Tāmravarṇī (II) — a R. of the Malaya hills.
Vā. 45. 105.
text.5412:
Tāmravarṇi (III) — name of an elephant; son of Puṣpa
danta.
Vā. 69. 221.
text.5413:
Tāmraśāla — copper hall; of Lalita's Śrīpura — square in
shape spreading to seven yojanas. There was Kalpakavā
ṭika between this and Kāmśyaśāla full of beautiful and
fragrant trees.
Br. IV. 31. 66.
text.5414:
Tāmrā (I) — one of Kaśyapa's wives. Her progeny
were hawks, vultures, eagles, curlews, geese, śukīs and
others;1 daughter of Pulaha;2 mother of Apsarasas.3 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 26-27; M. 6. 2 and 30; Vā. 69. 325-26. Vi. I. 15.
125; 21. 14-17.
2) Br. III. 3. 56; 7. 445 to 448; 69. 325.
3) M. 146.
18; 171. 29 and 60.
text.5415:
Tāmrā (II) — Wife of Vasudeva; her son was Sahadeva.
M. 46. 16.
text.5416:
Tāmrā (III) — a daughter of Dakṣa and wife of
Kaśyapa.
Vā. 66. 54.
text.5417:
Tāmrābha — Mt. south of the Mānasa;1 the residence of
Kādraveya Takṣaka.2 1) Vā. 36. 23.
2) Vā. 39. 54.
text.5419:
Tāra (II) — a God of the Harita gaṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 85.
text.5420:
Tāraka (I) — an Asura; took part in a Devāsura battle
between Bali and Indra.1 Fought with Guha in a Devāsura
war.2 Lust after more territory.3 Escaped to the ocean
and gave trouble by coming out often.4 Slain by Nandin.5
City in the third tala named after him.6 1) Bhā. VIII. 10. 21.
2) Ib. VIII. 10. 28; M. 61. 38.
3) Bhā. XII.
3. 11.
4) M. 61. 4; 129. 5; 131. 22; 136. 34 and 67.
5) M. 138. 43-4.
6) Br. II. 20. 26.
text.5421:
Tāraka (II) — a son of Danu,1 and a friend of Bhaṇḍa.2 1) Br. III. 6. 7; M. 6. 19; Vā. 50. 26; 68. 7; Vi. I. 21. 5.
2) Br.
IV. 30. 39.
text.5422:
Tāraka (III) — from Tāraṇa or that which takes good
men across to next world.
M. 128. 34 and 56.
text.5423:
Tāraka (IV) — a son of Vajrānga and Varāngī who
troubled the Devas and destined to be killed by a baby of
seven days; relieved his mother (Tāraka) from sorrows and
hence the name; ety. was crowned king of the Asura world;
did penance at the Pāriyātra cave when Brahmā granted his
wish to be killed by a lad of seven days. All Lokapālas
served him. He wanted to vanquish Hari and set out with
Grasana as commander. The flag of makara was hoisted.
Indra's report to Bṛhaspati.1 The war in which he was
killed by Kumāra.2 1) M. Chh. 146-149; 160. 25-6; Br. IV. 11. 7.
2) Br. III. 10. 49;
IV. 30. 103; Vā. 72. 47.
text.5425:
Tārakamaṇḍala — extent of, west to east five thousand
yojanas; above it are the slow moving Saura, Angira and
Vakra; under it are the Sun, Moon, Budha and Bhārgava
which revolve swiftly.
Vā. 53. 70-4.
text.5426:
Tārakavidhi — by worship of Mukti and Vāmana, the
two boats to cross the ocean of Samsāra.
Vā. 108. 37.
text.5427:
Tārakā — Sunītī, the mother of Dhruva, known as.
Vi. I. 12. 94.
text.5428:
Tārakāmaya (I) — A Devāsura battle in Kṛta yuga;
Tārā's (Tārakā, Bṛhaspati's wife) abduction by Soma,
was the ground for war between the Asuras and the Suras.
Śukra joined Soma while Śiva and Indra took up Bṛhas
pati's cause.1 Here Viṣṇu killed Kālanemi, and Indra, Viro
cana, son of Prahlāda; (Virocana was killed by Viṣṇu in the
guise of Indra-Vā. P.). After the war there was a famine
when Vasiṣṭha helped the people with fruits and roots;2 the
fifth battle in which Virocana was blessed with eternal life by
Śiva;3 ended with the intervention of Brahmā who gave Tārā
back to Bṛhaspati.4 1) Bhā. IX. 14. 4-7; Br. III. 5. 32; M. 129. 16; 172. 10; Vā. 67.
69; 70. 81; 90. 33.
2) Br. III. 8. 88; 65. 34; 72. 20-21, 74; M. Chh. 173
178.
3) Vā. 97. 21, 74 and 80.
4) Vi. IV. 6. 16-19.
text.5429:
Tārakāmaya (II) — the fifth of the twelve Kolāhalas.
Indra killed Virocana, son of Prahlāda.
M. 47. 43-9.
text.5430:
Tāragraha — above Nakṣatramaṇḍala; below this Budha
moves.
Vā. 101. 31, 132.
text.5431:
Tāramandram — the high and low strains of a song;
sung by Kṛṣṇa.
Vi. V. 13. 16, 56.
text.5432:
Tārā (I) — the wife of Bṛhaspati, and abducted by Soma.
Of this union was born Budha. Through Brahmā's influ
ence she was restored to her husband; (came back to Bṛhas
pati after a battle between the Devas and the Dānavas).
Bhā. IX. 14. 4-8, 13-14; Br. III. 65. 29; M. 23. 30-47; 24. 3;
Vā. 90. 28-35, 43. Vi. IV. 6. 10-33.
text.5434:
Tārā (III) — a daughter of Suṣeṇa and queen of Vāli; her
son was Aṅgada.
Br. III. 7. 219.
text.5435:
Tārā (IV) — also Toraṇeśvari and Tārāmbikā; a Śakti
living in the midst of waters that could be crossed only by
boats of different sizes.
Br. IV. 35. 12-24, 58; 36. 16; 44. 80.
text.5436:
Tārā (V) — the goddess enshrined at Kiṣkindhaparvata.
M. 13. 46.
text.5437:
Tārā (VI) — one of the ten branches of the Harita group
of Devas.
Vā. 100. 89.
text.5438:
Tārāpati — Lord of the stars; the moon.
Vā. 41. 58.
text.5439:
Tārāpīḍa — a son of Candrāvaloka of the Sūryavamśa.
M. 12. 54.
text.5440:
Tārkṣa — (Tārkṣya-Vā. P. and Vi. P.): Senāni with the
Sun in Hemanta.
Br. II. 23. 18; Vā. 52. 18.
text.5441:
Tārkṣya (I) — (also Tārkṣa) — see Garuḍa.1 Married
four daughters of Dakṣa. These were Vinatā, Kadrū,
Patangī, and Yāminī, who were mothers of birds, snakes, etc.2
Tārkṣyasuta inimical to serpents.3 Invoked for protection
on the ground.4 1) Bhā. III. 2. 24; 17. 22.
2) Ib. VI. 6. 2, 21-22.
3) Ib. VII. 8. 26.
X. 17. 7; 37. 4; 59. 7.
4) Ib. X. 6. 23; 17. 7; M. 126. 19; 167. 53.
text.5442:
Tārkṣya (II) — the Yakṣa presiding over the month of
Satra. (Tārkṣi Br. P.);1 resides in the chariot of the sun
during the month of Mārgaśīrṣa.2 1) Bhā. XII. 11. 41.
2) Vi. II. 10. 13.
text.5443:
Tāla (I) — span, employed in describing measurement
in iconography; nine tālas generally for deities, dānavas and
kinnaras; measurement made usually by the middle finger.
Br. I. 7. 97; M. 258. 16 and 75; 259. 1-2; Vā. 8. 103.
text.5444:
Tāla (II) (c) — kingdom watered by the R. Cakṣa.
Br. II. 18. 46.
text.5445:
Tāla (III) — a hell into which falls one, who murders a
Kṣatriya or Vaiśya or Brahmana, or one who defiles a precep
tor's bed.
Br. IV. 2. 146; Vā. 101. 146, 153; Vi. II. 6. 2.
text.5449:
Tālaketu (I) — a Dānava with Manuṣya dharma;1 station
ed at the northern gate of the Śūnyaka city with ten Akṣau
hiṇis.2 1) Br. III. 6. 16; Vā. 68. 16.
2) Br. IV. 22. 25.
text.5450:
Tālaketu (II) — the palm tree as the banner of Bala
deva.
Vi. IV. 1. 95.
text.5451:
Tālagrīva — the Asura who was stationed at the western
gate of the Śūnyaka city with ten Akṣauhiṇi soldiers.
Br. IV. 22. 24.
text.5452:
Tālajaṃgha (I) — the son of Jayadhvaja and father of
one hundred sons (Tālajanghas — Vītihotra being the
elder). The Tālajangha line came to an end by Aurva's
power.1 Afraid of Paraśurāma he escaped to the Himalayas
and returned after peace was restored. Led an expedition
to Ayodhyā whose king Phalgutantra fled with his wife and
child;2 defeated Bāhu, but was defeated by his own son,
Sagara.3 1) Bhā. IX. 23. 28; M. 43. 47; Vā. 88. 122; 94. 50.
2) Br. III.
69. 51; 47. 67, 78.
3) Vi. IV. 3. 26, 40-1.
text.5453:
Tālajaṃgha (II) — a commander of Kuṭilākṣa.
Br. IV. 29. 16-18.
text.5454:
Tālajaṃghas — a class of Kṣatriyas defeated by Sagara;1
the collective name of the 100 sons of Tālajangha and a
Haihaya clan; of them five gaṇas could be distinguished;
Vītihotra, Bhoja, Avantya, Tuṇḍikera and Tālajangha.2 1) Bhā. IX. 8. 5; 23. 28.
2) Br. III. 48. 23-5; 63. 120 and 134;
69. 51-3; M. 43. 48; Vā. 94. 51-2.
text.5455:
Tālajaṃghaka — the Asura stationed at the eastern gate
of the Śūnyaka city with ten Akṣauhiṇi soldiers.
Br. IV. 22. 22.
text.5456:
Tālabhuja — the Asura stationed at the southern gate of
the Śūnyaka city with ten Akṣauhiṇi soldiers.
Br. IV. 22. 23.
text.5457:
Tālavanam — a grove of palms near Brindāvana where
lived the demon Dhenuka who was killed by Rāma and
Kṛṣṇa.
Vi. V. 8. 1-3; 9. 1.
text.5460:
Tigma — the son of Urva and father of Bṛhadratha.
Vi. IV. 21. 13.
text.5461:
Tigmaketu — a son of Vatsara and Svarvīthī.
Bhā. IV. 13. 12.
text.5463:
Titi — a Śakti on the Nāga patra.
Br. IV. 32. 17.
text.5464:
Titikṣā — a daughter of Dakṣa and a wife of Dharma;
gave birth to Kṣema.
Bhā. IV. 1. 50 and 52.
text.5465:
Titikṣu — the righteous; a son of Mahāmana and father
of Ruśadratha.1 (Uśadratha: Br. P; Bṛhatratha: M. P.); a
king of the East.2 1) Bhā. IX. 23. 2 and 4; Vā. 99. 18; Vi. IV. 18. 8, 11; Br. III.
74. 17 and 24.
2) M. 48. 15, 22.
text.5466:
Titikhya — the Śūdra caste of Krauñcadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 53.
text.5468:
Tithi — an Ārṣeya pravara of Bhārgavas.
M. 195. 38.
text.5469:
Timi (I) — one of the wives of Kaśyapa; gave birth to
aquatic animals.
Bhā. VI. 6. 26.
text.5470:
Timi (II) — the son of Dūrva, and father of Bṛhadratha.
Bhā. IX. 22. 43.
text.5472:
Tiraskaraṇikā(mbā) — a Daṇḍanāthā, attacked Balā
haka and his brothers; rode on Tamolipta vimāna. Aimed
at them the Mohana arrow which created darkness all round;
wore on her neck a garland of the severed heads;1 (this
Daṇḍanī) all Śaktis praised.2 1) Br. IV. 24. 74, 98.
2) Ib. IV. 24. 103; 36. 25.
text.5473:
Tiryak — the origin of the different creatures described.
Vā. 69. 298-303.
text.5474:
Tiryakjyoti — one of the names in the first Marut gaṇa.
Vā. 67. 123.
text.5475:
Tiryakyoni — sixfold; to take birth and undergo all diffi
culties.
Vā. 102. 72.
text.5476:
Tiryaksrota — at the beginning of creation and when
the whole was enveloped in darkness a cross current passed
in and resulted in a second universe: 28 parts, 11 senses,
9 udayas, 8 stars; light in as also out; this resulted in
sātvika.
Vā. 6. 41-7, 56.
text.5477:
Tiryā — a daughter of Krodhā, the wife of Pulaha.
Br. III. 7. 172.
text.5479:
Tilam — seasamum1 much liked by Piśācās;2 dear to the
Pitṛs;3 Havis of, in a śrāddha;4 dealer in, goes to hell;5 fit for
gifts in vratas.6 1) Br. II. 7. 144; Vā. 74. 5; 101. 162; 105. 12.
2) Br. III. 7. 389,
409.
3) Ib. III. 11. 5.
4) Ib. III. 14. 11; 16. 17; 19. 3.
5) Ib. IV. 2.
164.
6) M. 7. 15; 15. 34; 82. 18; 83. 5; 87. 1; 187. 27-34; 217. 38;
239. 22.
text.5480:
Tilācala — one of the Viṣkambha hills round Meru; con
tinent of Uttara Kurus and Sāvītra vanam.
M. 83. 23 and 34.
text.5481:
Tilottamā — the Apsaras1 presiding over the month of
Iṣa (Māgha and Phālguna-Vā. P.); born out of the fire
altar of Brahmā;2 resides in the Sun's chariot in the month
of Māgha; cursed by Aṣtāvakra.3 1) Bhā. XII. 11. 43; Br. II. 23. 22; III. 7. 6; IV. 33. 20; M. 13.
53; Vā. 52. 22; 69. 5.
2) Vā. 69. 59.
3) Vi. II. 10. 16; V. 38. 73
and 77.
text.5482:
Tiṣṭha — the eleventh Vyāsa, the avatar of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 151.
text.5483:
Tiṣya (I) — a constellation. Important for śrāddha.
Bhā. XII. 2. 24; Br. III. 18. 4; Vā. 82. 5.
text.5484:
Tiṣya (II) — (a yuga of Bhāratavarṣa); see also Kali
yuga.
Br. II. 16. 69; 31. 30; M. 273. 61; Vā. 24. 1; 32. 40; 58. 30-73.
text.5485:
Tīkṣṇaśṛṅga — a commander of Bhaṇḍa to aid
Viṣaṅga;1 was killed by Sarvamangalikānityā.2 1) Br. IV. 21. 80; 25. 29.
2) Ib. IV. 25. 98.
text.5486:
Tīrtha — a righteous person fit to receive a dāna.
Vā. 91. 111.
text.5487:
Tīrthayātrā — a custom of going on pilgrimage. Vidura
undertook one.1 Not fruitful to the unfaithful,2 of Gādhi;
rules that one should not ride in a vehicle but walk;3 of
Arjuna.4 1) Bhā. I. 13. 1.
2) Br. III. 13. 135-6; 66. 43; IV. 9. 7.
3) M.
106. 3; 112. 20.
4) Ib. 244. 3.
text.5488:
Tīrtharāja — the Lord of the holy waters; Prayāga, to
honour which is to honour the Lord of the waters.
M. 109. 15.
text.5489:
Tīrthavatī — a R. of Krauñcadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 21.
text.5490:
Tīrthaśrāddha — prescriptions for;1 merits of; rituals at
different sacred places of Gayā; could be done at any time
in the presence of any with no āvāhana; the performer
must observe celibacy, live on one meal a day, take bed on
the earth and be truthful and pure to get full merits.2 1) Vā. 110. 28-66.
2) Ib. 105. 37-41.
text.5491:
Tīrthasnānam — going on pilgrimage for sacred baths.
Vi. III. 9. 12.
text.5492:
Tīrthādi — sacred places of pilgrimage; as frequented
by Piśācas;1 śrāddhas at; enumeration of a number of them
for śrāddha offerings.2 First Gurutīrtham, then Dhyāna
tīrtham, and lastly Brahmatīrtham,3 Paraśurāma went about
to purify himself;4 names of about 100 Tīrthas given.5 1) Br. III. 7. 405; 9. 42; M. 17. 11.
2) Br. III. 13 (whole);
M. 15. 17.
3) Br. III. 22. 6; 24. 39.
4) Ib. IV. 5. 4.
5) M. Ch. 22;
83. 10.
text.5494:
Tukṣaya — an Angīrasa and Mantrakṛt.
Br. II. 32. 109.
text.5496:
Tuṃgabhadrā — a R. in Bhāratavarṣa from the Sahya
hill; sacred to Pitṛs.
Bhā. V. 19. 18; Br. II. 16. 35; Vā. 45. 104; M. 22. 45; 114. 29.
text.5497:
Tuṇḍakośa — (Tuṇḍakeśa-Vā. P.); a Rākṣasa; son of
Khaśa.
Br. III. 7. 135; Vā. 69. 167.
text.5498:
Tuṇḍikera — a Vindhya tribe; one of the five classes
(gaṇas) of the Haihayas;1 on the other side of the Vindhyas.2 1) Br. II. 16. 65; III. 69. 53; Vā. 94. 52.
2) Vā. 45. 134.
text.5499:
Tuburā — a forest tribe of the Vindhyas;1 to be conquer
ed by Kalki.2 1) Br. II. 36. 145.
2) Ib. III. 73. 108.
text.5500:
Tumura — a tribe, on the other side of the Vindhyas.
M. 114. 53; Vā. 45. 133.
text.5501:
Tumba — a son of Tumba; had two sons.
Br. III. 71. 258.
text.5504:
Tumbāvarcā — a son of Tumba.
Br. III. 71. 258.
text.5505:
Tumburā — a Niṣāda tribe; on the other side of the
Vindhyas.
Vā. 62. 124; 45. 133.
text.5506:
Tumburu (I) — an expert in divine music; had two
daughters Manovatī and Sukeśā;1 a friend of Candrodaka
dundubhī.2 A Gandharva disciple of Nārada, came with
the sage to see Yudhiṣṭhira, and returned to heaven with
him;3 sang with Nārada the glories of Ananta;4 praised
Hiraṇyakaśipu when he became the overlord of all worlds.5
Sang the praise of Kṛṣṇa when he held the Govardhana;6
presiding over the months of Madhu and Mādhava.7 His two
daughters were celebrated as Pañcacūḍas;8 residing in the
Sun's chariot in the months of Caitra and Madhu.9 1) Vā. 69. 47, 49.
2) Ib. 96. 117.
3) Bhā. I. 13. 37 and 59.
4) Ib. V. 25. 8.
5) Ib. VII. 4. 14.
6) Ib. X. 25. 32; 27. 24.
7) Ib.
XII. 11. 33; Br. II. 23. 4.
8) Ib. III. 7. 9; IV. 20. 50 and 101.
9) Vā. 52. 3; 36. 47; Vi. II. 10. 3.
text.5507:
Tumburu (II) — a friend of Anu, son of Kapotaroma.
Bhā. IX. 24. 20.
text.5508:
Tumburu (III) — a friend of Andhaka.
Br. III. 71. 118.
text.5509:
Tura — the son of Kāvaṣa, and Purohita of Janamejaya.
Bhā. IX. 22. 37.
text.5510:
Turaga — a white horse came out of the churning of the
ocean; claimed by the Sun god.
M. 250. 3; 251. 3.
text.5511:
Turanya — a horse of the Moon's chariot.
Vā. 52. 53.
text.5512:
Turasitas — a people of the Narmadā region.
Vā. 45. 129.
text.5513:
Turāsaṅgam — a Tīrtham on the Narmadā.
M. 191. 29.
text.5514:
Turīya (I) — a name of Brahmā (s.v.).
Bhā. XI. 15. 16.
text.5515:
Turīya (II) — (Turiya Indrayuk?-Br. P.); a Deva (a
jita).
Br. II. 13. 94; Vā. 31. 8.
text.5516:
Turuṣka — frank incense of white colour for dhūpa of
the Pitṛs.
Br. III. 11. 69.
text.5517:
Turuṣkaka — (Tuṣkaras-Br. P.; Turuṣkāra-Vā. P.) —
Fourteen kings among them, see Maunas.
Bhā. XII. 1. 30; Vi. IV. 24. 53.
text.5518:
Turvasu (I) — a son of Yayāti and Devayānī; refused to
part with his youth to his father; he was therefore cursed to
have no issue and to live a king among the wicked and low
tribes and Mlecchas; became overlord of the Mlecchas in the
western part of the kingdom. His son was Vahni.1 His line
became merged with the Paurava line, during the time of
Marutta.2 Equal to Viṣṇu; father of Garbha; Yavanas take
their origin from him,3 got the south-east of the kingdom,
when his father retired to the forest.4 1) Bhā. IX. 18. 33 and 41; 19. 22; 23. 16; M. 24. 53; Vā. 93. 16.
2) Br. III. 68. 16, 40, 50; 73. 126; 74. 1 and 4; M. 33. 9-11; Vā. 99. 1-4.
3) M. 32. 9; 34. 30; 48. 1.
4) Vā. 93. 39-44, 89.
text.5519:
Turvasu (II) — a son of Devayānī and Yadu?
Br. I. 1. 132; Vā. 1. 141.
text.5520:
Tulasī — sacred to Hari;1 on the chest of Viṣṇu.2 1) Bhā. I. 19. 6; V. 3. 6; X. 30. 7; XI. 30. 41.
2) Br. IV. 9. 80-2;
17. 74.
text.5523:
Tulāpuruṣa — Weighing in balance; one of the 16 mahā
dānas; rules detailed. The gift takes one to the world of
Viṣṇu or Indra.
M. 274. (whole); 275. 2.
text.5524:
Tulyārci — a son of Lāngalī of the 22nd Dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 200.
text.5525:
Tuvara — a tribe belonging to the Vindhya region.
Vā. 62. 124.
text.5526:
Tuṣāra (I) — a dynasty of 14 rulers, ruled for 105 years
[500 years (Vā. P.)] after the Yavanas; reigned for 7000
years?
Br. III. 74. 172-6; M. 273. 19, 21; Vā. 45. 118; 47. 44; 58. 83;
98. 108; 99. 360. 362.
text.5527:
Tuṣāra (II) (c) — a northern kingdom;1 14 kings of it
ruled for 105 years after the Yavanas.2 1) Br. II. 16. 47; 18. 46; 31. 83.
2) M. 121. 45; 144. 57.
text.5528:
Tuṣitas — a class of Devas, sons of Kratu and Tuṣitā,
twelve in number, being sons of Dakṣiṇā. Flourished in the
Svāyambhuva epoch.1 They were also Jayadeva gods of the
Svārociṣa epoch.2 They were the same as Jayadevas of the
Svāyambhuva.3 Thirty-three in number, belong to the
Sumanasa group of the 4th Sāvarṇa Manu;4 Gods also of the
Cākṣusa epoch known as Ādityas.5 These are the twelve
Ādityas of the Vaivasvata epoch;6 known as Prāṇakhyas in
the Yajñas. 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 8.
2) Ib. VIII. 1. 20; Br. II. 36. 7-12; M. 9. 9. Vā.
66. 8; 67. 35; 90. 34.
3) Br. III. 3. 8 and 19; 4. 28; 65. 35.
4) Ib. IV.
1. 87.
5) M. 6. 3-12.
6) Vi. I. 15. 127. 131-32; Ib. III. 1. 10.
text.5529:
Tuṣitā (I) — the wife of Vedaśiras and mother of Vibhu.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 21.
text.5530:
Tuṣitā (II) — the wife of Kratu and mother of the Tuṣita
gods in the Svārociṣa epoch;1 gave birth to Viṣṇu by name
Ajita in that epoch.2 1) Br. II. 36. 8; Vā. 62. 8; 67. 35.
2) Br. III. 3. 11-15.
text.5531:
Tuṣitā (III) — the mother of Yajiṣa in the Svārociṣa
epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 37.
text.5533:
Tuṣṭā — a R. in Śālmalidvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 46.
text.5534:
Tuṣṭi (I) — a daughter of Dakṣa, and a wife of Dharma,
gave birth to muda. (Santoṣa-Vā. P. and Vi. P.).
Bhā. IV. 1. 49 and 51; Br. I. 9. 49, 59; Vā. 10. 25. 34: 55. 43;
Vi. I. 7. 23 and 28.
text.5535:
Tuṣṭi (II) — a son of Vasudeva and Madirā.
Br. III. 71. 172.
text.5536:
Tuṣṭi (III) — a Śakti on the fourth Parvan of the Geya
cakra.
Br. IV. 19. 71; 44. 71.
text.5537:
Tuṣṭi (IV) — a Kalā of the moon.
Br. IV. 35. 92; M. 23. 24.
text.5538:
Tuṣṭiman — a son of Ugrasena.
Bhā. IX. 24. 24; Br. III. 71. 133.
text.5540:
Tūrya — generally a war-musical instrument; employed
on auspicious occasions, and in temples;1 sounding of bugles
in a wrestling match;2 finding Cāṇūra declining, Kamsa stop
ped the sounding of the drum when the Devas sounded
divine music.3 1) Bhā. I. 11. 18; M. 149. 2; 163. 105; 192. 28.
2) Vi. V. 20. 30.
3) Vi. V. 20. 71-3.
text.5544:
Tṛṇabindu (I) — a king and the son of Bandhu. (Budha
Vi. P.). His queen was Alambuṣā. Father of a number of
sons and a daughter Ceḍavīḍā.1 (Ilavilā-Vi. P.). Lust after
more territory.2 Lived at the commencement of the third
Tretāyuga. His daughter was Draviḍā. Many kings of
Viśāla ruled by his grace.3 Begot an Apsaras, Ālambuṣā, a
son Viśāla who began the Vaiśāla line of kings which ended
with Sumati.4 1) Bhā. IX. 2. 30-31; Br. III. 8. 36-7; 61. 10; Vi. IV. 1. 46-7.
2) Bhā. XII. 3. 10.
3) Vā 86. 15-16, 22.
4) Vi. IV. 1. 48-9, 59.
text.5545:
Tṛṇabindu (II) — the 27th Veda Vyāsa, learnt the Br.
Purāṇa and the Vāyu Purāṇa from Somaśuṣma and narrated
the former to Dakṣa.
Br. II. 35. 123; IV. 4. 64-65; Vā. 103. 64.
text.5546:
Tṛṇabindu (III) — a sage who got freed from a curse at
Ṛsitīrtham on the Narmadā.
M. 193. 13.
text.5547:
Tṛṇabindu (IV) — the Veda-Vyāsa of the 23rd (24th
Vi. P.) Dvāpara; Śveta, the avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 203; Vi. III. 3. 17.
text.5548:
Tṛṇabindu (V) — the son of Dama and a king at the
beginning of the third Tretāyuga in the 11th Manvantara;
had a daughter Iḍivilā, who was married to Paulaśtya.
Vā. 70. 30-1.
text.5549:
Tṛṇaṃjaya — heard the Br. and Vāyu Purāṇas from
Kṛtamjaya and narrated the former to Bharadvāja.
Br. IV. 4. 63; Vā. 103. 63.
text.5550:
Tṛṇāvarta — an Asura friend of Kamsa; created a whirl
wind which covered all Gokulam with dust and took the baby
Kṛṣṇa high in the sky. Kṛṣṇa caught hold of his neck and
the demon, unable to bear his weight, fell down dead to the
wonder of all Gopas and Gopīs.
Bhā. X. 2. 1; 7. 20-32; 26. 6; 46. 26; Br. IV. 29. 124.
text.5551:
Tṛṣṇā, also Tṛṣā — implications of, with regard to life
and death;1 annihilation of, leads to mokṣa;2 no end of.3 1) Br. III. 68. 101; IV. 3. 42, 59.
2) Ib. IV. 3. 71.
3) Vi. IV. 10. 24.
text.5552:
Teja (I) — a son of Bala and grandson of Nārāyaṇa.
Br. II. 11. 4.
text.5553:
Teja (II) — comes out of the subtle element, sparśa
(touch) of Vāyu or wind; its qualities are sound, touch and
form.
M. 3. 24.
text.5554:
Teja (III) — one of the twenty Sutapa Gaṇas.
Vā. 100. 15.
text.5555:
Teja (IV) — of the burning universe in Pralaya; similes
used for colour.
Vā. 100. 161.
text.5556:
Teja (V) — swallows the waters — all mouthed; its qua
lity is prakāśaka or light which Vāyu eats up; vanishes like
the flame in the wind.
Vā. 102. 10-12.
text.5557:
Tejasa — the son of Sumati and father of Indradyumna.
Br. II. 14. 64; Vi. II. 1. 36.
text.5561:
Tejovatī (II) — the name of the Agni sabhā on the second
inner slope of Meru, throwing effulgence on all sides; there
live sages and seers bowing down to Agni.
Vā. 34. 78-85.
text.5562:
Tejovratam — a vow incumbent on kings; to behave like
the different Lokapālas.
M. 226. 9.
text.5565:
Taijasasarga — the fourth creation of the Arvaksrota.
Vā. 6. 56.
text.5566:
Taittiri — a son of Kapotaromā and father of Nala, known
as Nandanodara dundubhi.
M. 44. 62.
text.5568:
Taittirīya — Yajus-śākha; when Yājñavalkya vomitted
the Yajus due to a misunderstanding with his Guru, the other
sages who were pupils of Vaiśampāyana became transformed
into Tittirā birds and received those portions of the Yajur
veda. Hence the name Taittirīya.
Bhā. XII. 6. 64-5; Br. II. 35. 75; Vi. III. 5. 13; Vā. 61. 66.
text.5572:
Toṭakam — a Chandas in which Bāṇāsura prayed to Śiva
who blessed him with immortality.
M. 188. 66 and 72.
text.5573:
Tomara — an eastern hill tribe;1 an eastern kingdom;2
country of the, watered by the Nalinī.3 1) Br. II. 16. 51; M. 121. 58; Vā. 45. 120; 47. 56.
2) Br. II.
16. 68.
3) Ib. II. 18. 59.
text.5574:
Toyā (I) — a R. from the Vindhyas.
Br. II. 16. 33; M. 114. 28; Vā. 45. 103.
text.5575:
Toyā (II) — a R. of the Śālmalam.
Vā. 49. 42.
text.5577:
Tośata — a people on the other side of the Vindhyas.
Vā. 45. 133.
text.5578:
Tośala(ka) — a Malla friend consulted by Kamsa. He
had his seat allocated in the arena; was killed by Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 36. 21; 42. 37; 44. 27; Vi. V. 20. 79-80.
text.5580:
Toṣa — a son of Dakṣiṇā and a Tuṣita God.
Bhā. IV. 1. 7-8.
text.5581:
Tauleya — an Ārṣeya pravara of Angiras.
M. 196. 6.
text.5582:
Tyāga — is to look on the useful and the useless equally;
renunciation from affection, desire and difficulty; giving up
of all Karmas and having an equal eye on good and evil;1
result of Jñāna or knowledge; gives the result of Karma, but
difficult to achieve;2 leads to Vairāgya.3 1) Vā. 59. 53.
2) Br. IV. 3. 45.
3) Vā. 102. 66.
text.5584:
Traya — group of three: varṇa loka, etc.
Vā. 97. 33.
text.5585:
Trayambaka (I) — Śiva;1 his riding animal Vṛṣabha,2
followed by the Naiṛṛta clan of Rākṣasas;3 one of the eleven
Rudras; the eighth of twelve incarnations who slew Asuras in
the battle of Andhaka;4 sacrifice to, by Puroḍāśa made in
Kapālas; Gāyatrī, Triṣṭub and Jagati are present as three
means of the Puroḍāśa;5 with ten arms in Śivapura; his
weapons are Paṭṭiśa, bow, trident, and sword; Gandharva
leaders entertain him with music; the bull is there, and
Skanda and others form the sabhā; sculptures of Dig Devas
in the columns of the palace.6 Ambakas are the yonis of
Vanaspati, king of trees;7 curse of Dakṣa to be born as
Prācetas in the Cākṣuṣa Manu epoch.8 1) Br. II. 27. 69; Vi. I. 15. 122.
2) Br. III. 72. 82; 74. 51.
3) Ib. III. 7. 141.
4) M. 5. 29; 47. 50; 191. 120.
5) Vā. 31. 46-8;
40. 20.
6) Ib. 101. 255. 292, 323.
7) Br. II. 9. 4.
8) Ib. II. 13.
41, 144.
text.5586:
Trayambaka (II) — Kubera whose followers were of the
Rākṣasa gaṇa Naiṛṛta, many branches of which gaṇa were
worshippers of Śankara;1 killed all in Tripura.2 1) Vā. 69. 173.
2) Vā. 97. 82; 99. 51.
text.5587:
Trayambaka vratam — the vow that leads to the world of
Śiva.
M. 101. 67.
text.5588:
Trayaṃśa — a son of Vipracitti.
Vi. I. 21. 11.
text.5589:
Trayī (I) — a daughter of Savitā.
Bhā. VI. 18. 1.
text.5590:
Trayī (II) — A Vidyā;1 symbolical of Devī;2 said to be the
body of Hari;3 forbidden to women, śūdras and fallen
Brahmanas;4 issued from Brahmā;5 one Veda became three
for Purūravas at the commencement of the Tretāyuga;6
unknown to Puṣkaradvīpa.7 1) Vā. 49. 118; 59. 36; 61. 167; 67. 27; Vi. V. 10. 27.
2) Vi. I.
9. 121.
3) Ib. II. 11. 11; III. 18. 15.
4) Bhā. I. 4. 25.
5) Ib. III.
12. 44.
6) Ib. IX. 14. 48-49.
7) Br. II. 19. 122; 32. 40; 35. 195;
III. 4. 24; Vi. II. 4. 83.
text.5591:
Trayīsānu — the son of Bhānu, and father of Karan
dama.
Vi. IV. 16. 3.
text.5592:
Trayuṣaṇa — a son of Uruksava and Vīśālā; became a
Brahmana.
M. 49. 39.
text.5593:
Trayodaśi — as a Śakti resident in Śodasapatrābja.
Br. IV. 32. 15.
text.5594:
Trayodeva — by the agitation of the guṇas or qualities
three gods with body came into being; the Rajas is Brahmā,
Tamas Agni and Satva, Viṣṇu; the first had the duty of
creation, the second Kāla and the third Udāsīna; these are
three worlds, three Vedas and three fires, one dependent on
the other; by their joint action the world progresses;
(Advaita): three functions of Prajāpati as creator, destroyer
and protector.
Vā. 5. 14-16 and 30-31.
text.5595:
Trayyāruṇi (I) — a son of Duritakṣaya (Duritakṣaya
Vi. P.) and a Paurāṇika.
Bhā. IX. 21. 19; XII. 7. 5; Vi. IV. 19. 25.
text.5596:
Trayyāruṇi(a) (II) — the Veda Vyāsa of the fifteenth
Dvāpara.1 Heard the Purāṇa from Antarikṣa and narrated
it to Dhanamjaya.2 1) Br. II. 35. 120; Vi. III. 3. 15.
2) Br. IV. 4. 62.
text.5597:
Trayyāruni (a) (III) — the son of Tridhanvā and father
of Satyavrata.
Br. III. 63. 76; M. 12. 37; Vi. IV. 3. 20-1.
text.5602:
Trasad(d)asyu (II) — (Trasadas-Vā. P., Br. P.) son of
Narmadā and Purukutsa, and father of Anaraṇya.
Bhā. IX. 7. 4; Br. III. 10. 98; Vā. 73. 49; 88. 74; Vi. IV. 3.
16-17.
text.5603:
Trasaddasyu (III) — a Mantrakṛt and of the Angirasa
branch.
Br. II. 32. 108; Vā. 59. 99.
text.5604:
Trasareṇu (I) — an atom;1 the visible speck floating in
the sun, seen as the sun shines through a window: a measure
ment.2 Padmarajas;3 eight times the Paramāṇu.4 1) Bhā. III. 11. 5.
2) M. 258. 17.
3) Vā. 101. 119.
4) Br.
III. 10. 59; IV. 2. 119.
text.5605:
Trasu — a son of Ranti and a great charioteer.
Vā. 99. 129.
text.5608:
Trikakut — the son of Śuci; also known as Dharma
sārathi. Father of Śāntaraya.
Bhā. IX. 17. 11-12.
text.5609:
Trikakuda — a Mt. near Kakudman the collyrium of
which is fit for Pitṛs and Śrāddha; in it are a burning pit Jāta
vedasśilā as also a Tīrtha, where the seven seers had bathed
and a temple with a Nandi invisible to the unrighteous;
besides golden Yūpas.
Br. III. 11. 67; 13. 58; M. 121. 15; Vā. 47. 13; 77. 57-64.
text.5610:
Trikaṇṭaka — (Trikarṇaka ?) a commander of Bhaṇḍa
to aid Viṣaṅga;1 was killed by Jvālā mālinikā.2 1) Br. IV. 25. 29.
2) Ib. IV. 25. 98.
text.5612:
Trikumārikam Jagat — the whole universe is said to be
pervaded by the three daughters of Himavān, Aparṇā, Eka
parṇā and Ekapāṭalā, all eternal youths and Brahmavādinīs.
Br. III. 10. 14; Vā. 72. 13-5.
text.5613:
Trikūṭa (I) — a mountain on the base of the Meru, in
Bhāratavarṣa;1 surrounded by Kṣīroda, and 10000 yojanas
high with three shining crests of silver, iron and gold;
served by Siddhas, Cāraṇas and others. In its valley was
Ṛtumat, the pleasure garden of goddesses, full of varied
trees.2 1) Bhā. V. 16. 26; 19. 16.
2) Ib. VIII. 2. 1-19.
text.5614:
Trikūṭa (II) — Here is Lankā in Malayadvīpa.
Vā. 48. 26.
text.5615:
Trikoṇa — one of the ten Pīṭhas for images, in the shape
of a trident.
M. 262. 7, 12, 18.
text.5618:
Trigartas — their king was Suśarma (s.v.). He was not
able to vanquish Arjuna, supported by Kṛṣṇa. He was
stationed by Jarāsandha at the Northern gate of Mathurā, as
also during the siege of Gomanta.1 A hill tribe;2 a hilly
country.3 1) Bhā. I. 15. 16; X. 50. 11 [7]; 52. 11. [14]; [50 (V) 3].
2) Br. II. 16. 68; 18. 53.
3) Vā. 45. 136; M. 114. 56.
text.5619:
Trigarta(ka) — a mountain kingdom of Trigartas visited
by Balarāma.
Bhā. X. 79. 19.
text.5622:
Triṇāciketas (Triṇāciketa-Vā. P.) the Brahmanas of
the Yajur Veda, fit for Śrāddha feeding.
Vi. III. 15. 2; Vā 79. 58; 83. 53.
text.5623:
Tritakūpa — a Tīrtha visited by Balarāma.
Bhā. X. 78. 19.
text.5624:
Tritā (I) — a sage who called on the dying Bhīṣma; was
invited for the Rājasūya of Yudhiṣṭhira; came to Syamanta
pañcaka to see Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. I. 9. 7; X. 74. 7; 84. 5.
text.5625:
Tritā (II) — a son of Cākṣuṣa Manu. A place sacred to
him on the Sarasvatī; a Mantrakṛt.
Bhā. IV. 13. 16; III. 1. 22; M. 145. 101.
text.5626:
Tridaṇḍī — a class of ascetics. In that guise Arjuna
spent four months in Dvāraka to marry Subhadrā;1 wearing
śikhā; specially fit for śrāddha;2 with three daṇḍas (res
traints) of Vāk, Karma and Manas.3 1) Bhā. X. 86. 3; Br. III. 11. 5-12; 15. 64.
2) Vā. 79. 90.
3) Ib. 17. 6.
text.5627:
Tridaśajyoti — a Tīrtham on the Narmadā.
M. 194. 11.
text.5628:
Tridivā (I) — a R. from the Himālayas.
Br. II. 16. 26.
text.5629:
Tridivā (II) — a R. from the Ṛkṣa.
Br. II. 16. 31.
text.5630:
Tridivā (III) — a R. in the Plakṣadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 19; Vi. II. 4. 11.
text.5631:
Tridivā (IV) — (Śivetikā) a R. of the Bhāratavarṣa
rising from the Mahendra mountain.
Vā. 45. 101, 106.
text.5632:
Tridivā (V) — a R. of the Śākadvīpam.
Vā. 49. 93.
text.5633:
Tridivācalā — a R. from the Mahendra mountain.
M. 114. 31.
text.5634:
Tridivābalā — a R. from the Mahendra mountain.
Br. II. 16. 37.
text.5637:
Tridhanvā (II) — the son of Vasumata, a righteous
king.
Vā. 88. 77.
text.5638:
Tridhanvā (III) — the son of Sumanā and father of
Trayyāruṇi.
Vi. IV. 3. 20.
text.5639:
Tridhanvā (IV) — a son of Sumati.
Br. III. 63. 76.
text.5640:
Tridhāmā — the name of Vyāsa in the tenth Dvāpara;
Bhṛgu, the avatar of the Lord;1 heard the Br. and Vāyu
Purāṇas from Sārasvata and narrated the former to Śarad
vān.2 1) Br. II. 35. 119; Vā. 23. 147; Vi. III. 3. 13.
2) Br. IV. 4.
61; Vā. 103. 61.
text.5641:
Trinābha — a son of Khaśa, and a Rākṣasa.
Br. III. 7. 135.
text.5642:
Trinetra (I) — see Śiva;1 constructed the Puṣpakam.2 1) Br. II. 27. 69; III. 23. 31; 24. 79; 25. 2; 32. 18.
2) M. 129.
36; 130. 12.
text.5643:
Trinetra (II) — the son of Nirvṛti; ruled for 28 years.
M. 271. 27.
text.5644:
Tripatha — the name of a horse of the Moon's chariot.
M. 126. 52.
text.5645:
Tripathagā(minī) — Gangā (s.v.) descended at the
Gaura hill;1 fell on Śiva's head;2 originating from the foot
of Soma;3 came to be divided into seven streams; flows
in Antarikṣa, Divam and Bhūmi; Śiva prevented her course
by yoga, when she grew angry and on account of which
drops of water fell on the ground and collected themselves
into a lake, Bindusaras; she resisted this and wanted to
enter the Pātāla when Brahmā consoled her and let her flow
in seven directions, three to the east, three to the
west and the seventh to the south; the last one is Bhā
gīrathī.4 Stopped in the sky above Mānasa.5 1) Br. II. 18. 27, 29, 30.
2) Ib. III. 13. 118; 25. 11.
3) M.
102. 8; 106. 51; 121. 28-9; 183. 7.
4) Vā. 47. 26-41.
5) Ib. 77. 111.
text.5646:
Tripuṇḍram — a mark on the forehead.
Br. IV. 38. 22.
text.5647:
Tripura (I) — a city built by Māyā, of gold, silver and
iron fortifications for the sake of Asuras.1 Really three
towns under Tāraka, Maya and Vidyunmāli; city described.
Battle of Tripuram; march of Śiva's army. First battle at
Tārakākhyapuram; non-combatants visiting it; fight be
tween Nandi and Vidyunmāli; Tāraka's fight with the
Gaṇas; actual battle on the shores of the western sea,
described; battle in the air and under water; Tāraka slain by
Nandi, as also Vidyunmāli; burning the city including
women and children by Śiva.2 1) Bhā. IV. 17. 13; V. 24. 28; VII. 10. 54 and 68. VIII. 6. 31;
XI. 16. 20; Br. III. 72. 82. Vā. 97. 82.
2) M. Chh. 129-130; Chh.
135-140; 187. 8, 14-6; 188. 9-10.
text.5648:
Tripura (II) — an Asura having his city in the third
Talam.
Br. II. 20. 27; III. 38. 4.
text.5649:
Tripurabhairavī — the second charioteer of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 20. 91.
text.5650:
Tripuram — a Tīrtham sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 43.
text.5651:
Tripurasundarī — is Lalitā.
Br. IV. 18. 14; 39. 76, 96 ff; 40. 1, 43 ff.
text.5652:
Tripurā — a name of Lalitā; worship of.
Br. IV. 5. 31.
text.5654:
Tripurāmbikā — a mother Goddess, see Lalitā.
Br. IV. 7. 72; 11. 1.
text.5655:
Tripurārī — an epithet of Rudra; Śiva with 16 hands
danced in joy at the ruin of the city, Tripuram (s.v.).
M. 179. 38; 259. 11.
text.5657:
Tripuropākhyāna — deals with the construction of Tri
pura by Maya; trouble to the world by the Asuras; Gods wait
on Rudra; the war chariot of Śiva; Nārada's mediation; Maya
gets ready for war; the war; the efforts of gaṇas, especially
Nandi's part in the battle; death of Tāraka; the second day
of the battle; Śiva's victory by burning the city.
M. Chh. 129-141.
text.5658:
Triplakṣa (I) — near the Dṛṣadvatī;1 like Śyāmaka and
Ikṣu being created by Gods;2 to be propitiated at the Parva
and at the Tithis.3 1) Br. III. 13. 69.
2) Ib. 14. 8.
3) Ib. 17. 6.
text.5659:
Tribandhana — the son of Aruṇa and father of Satya
vrata.
Bhā. IX. 7. 4-5.
text.5660:
Tribhāgā — a R. from the Mahendra hills.
M. 114. 31.
text.5661:
Tribhānu — the son of Bhānumat, and father of Karam
dhama.
Bhā. IX. 23. 17.
text.5662:
Trimadhu — the Brahmanas of the Sāma Veda fit for
feeding on the śrāddha occasions.
Vi. III. 15. 2.
text.5663:
Trimanā — a horse of the Moon's chariot.
Vā. 52. 53.
text.5664:
Trimātra — is Om; Praṇava constituted by Vaidyutī,
Tāmasī and Nirguṇi Mātras.
Vā. 20. 1.
text.5667:
Triloka — progress of, depends on the sun without
which there would be no reckoning of time and nothing
would go on.
Vā. 50. 60; 53. 34-41.
text.5668:
Trilocana (I) — Śiva known in Trayambaka Kṣetra;
meditation of.
M. 22. 47; 131. 35; 266. 36; Vi. V. 33. 1.
text.5669:
Trilocana (II) — a name of Vighneśvara.
Br. IV. 44. 67.
text.5670:
Trivakrā — a hunchback maid who supplied unguents
to Kamsa. For the mere asking she gave them away to
Kṛṣṇa and his brother. Pleased at this, Kṛṣṇa converted
her into a beautiful maid. She requested him to go to her
house and honour her with his company. He promised to
do so after his other engagements were over.1 Visited by
Kṛṣṇa with Uddhava. Her house was found filled with
pictures drawn according to the Kāmaśāstra. After spend
ing some time there, Kṛṣṇa left.2 Her son was Viśoka.3
Came to see Kṛṣṇa and Satyabhāmā returning from Indra's
abode.4 1) Bhā. X. 42. 1-12.
2) Ib. X. 48. 1-10.
3) Ib. X. 90. 34[1].
4) Ib.
X. [67 (V) 50].
text.5672:
Trivarga — three ends of human endeavour, Dharma,
Artha and Kāma; was taught to Prahlāda by his tutors.
This did not appeal to him. It should be a means to realise
Hari, according to Prahlāda.1 Even the householder, it is
said, should not exert himself too much for Trivarga. But
it is generally observed by householders.2 A Bhikṣu is
expected to discard it.3 To one devoid of Dharma, the other
two, Kāma and Artha, are of one use.4 1) Bhā. VII. 5. 52-53; 6. 26.
2) Ib. VII. 14. 10; VIII. 16. 11. Vi. III.
11. 6.
3) Bhā. VII. 15. 36; Br. III. 50. 52; 51. 15.
4) M. 29. 3;
53. 4, 45; 212. 3-9.
text.5674:
Trivāha — a group of mountains round Merumūla.
Vā. 35. 7.
text.5675:
Trivikrama — an avatār of Viṣṇu who conquered the
three worlds with three steps; the lustrous God with sword
as weapon;1 Mahātmyam of; in the Vāmana Purāṇa; icon
of;2 Brahma-Puruṣottama.3 1) Br. III. 3. 118; IV. 34. 79; M. 176. 59; Vi. V. 5. 17.
2) M. 53. 45; 260. 36.
3) Vā. 108. 38.
text.5676:
Triviṣṭa — heard the Brahmāṇḍa and Vāyu Puraṇas
from Śaradvān (Śaradvata) and narrated the former to
Antarikṣa.
Br. IV. 4. 61; Vā. 103. 61.
text.5677:
Trivṛt — a Sāma;1 created from Brahmā's face.2 1) Vā. 9. 48.
2) Br. II. 8. 50.
text.5678:
Trivṛtsoma — from the first face of Brahmā.
Vi. I. 5. 53.
text.5679:
Triśaṃku — Satyavrata (s.v): the son of Tribandhana
and father of Hariścandra; became a Caṇḍāla by the curse
of his Guru; three spikes meant for him by Vasiṣṭha. Result
of his three sins — displeasing his father, killing the Guru's
cow and eating unconsecrated flesh; banished from the
kingdom; seeing this Viśvāmitra consoled him and agreed
to be his Guru; the latter had him crowned after a purifica
tion bath in the river, Karmanāśā near the Vindhyas; this
enabled him to go to heaven bodily and get a place among
the planets all in the presence of Vasiṣṭha; though thrust
down headlong from heaven, he was stopped and given a
place in the sky.
Bhā. IX. 7. 5-7; Br. III. 63. 108; Vā. 88. 108-13. Vi. IV.
3. 21.
text.5680:
Triśaṅkugraha — the planet Triśaṅku or Satyavrata in
the moon's sphere, Cf. Rāmā. Yud., IV. 90.
Vā. 88. 115-6.
text.5681:
Triśaṃku(deśam) — the territory north of the Mahā
nadī and south of Vaikaṭa (Kaikaṭa-Vā. P.) unfit for
Śrāddha.
Br. III. 14. 31-2; M. 16. 16; Vā. 78. 21. 2.
text.5683:
Triśikha (I) — was Indra of the Tāmasa epoch.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 28.
text.5684:
Triśikha (II) — the Veda-Vyāsa of the eleventh Dvāpara,
see Trivarṣa.
Vi. III. 3. 14.
text.5685:
Triśikharam — a Mt. sacred to Śiva.
M. 183. 2.
text.5687:
Triśira (I) — a son of Tvaṣṭa and Yaśodharā;1 his mother
was a sister of Virocana;2 a Rākṣasa killed by Rāma.3 His
city was in the third Talam.4 1) Br. III. 1. 86; Vā. 65. 85.
2) Vā. 84. 19.
3) Bhā. IX. 10. 9;
Vā. 69. 167.
4) Br. II. 20. 26; Vā. 50. 26.
text.5688:
Triśira (II) — a son of Khaśa and a Rākṣasa.
Br. III. 7. 135.
text.5689:
Triśira (III) — a son of Viśravas and Vākā.
Br. III. 8. 56; Vā. 70. 50.
text.5690:
Triśira (IV) — a son of Prahrādi and Tvaṣṭā ?.
Br. III. 59. 19-20.
text.5691:
Triśūlam — the trident of Śiva;1 made from the Vaiṣ
ṇava tejas of the sun filed off by Tvaṣṭa.2 1) Br. III. 32. 14; IV. 19. 6, 85; 20. 81; Vā. 101. 271.
2) M. 5.
31; 11. 29; 217. 31 Vi. III. 2. 11.
text.5692:
Triśṛṃga — a Mt. on the north of Meru;1 west of the
Śitoda.2 1) Bhā. V. 16. 27; M. 163. 86; Vi. II. 2. 44.
2) Vā. 36. 29;
42. 72.
text.5693:
Triṣavaṇasnāta — one who performs the three ablutions,
at dawn, noon and sunset; fit for performing Śrāddha.
Vā. 74. 12.
text.5694:
Triṣṭubh — a poetic metre;1 a Chandas serving as a horse
in the Sun's chariot,2 with Gāyatri and Jagati forms the Tri
varṇam or Praṇava.3 1) Bhā. III. 12. 45; XI. 21. 41; M. 125. 47.
2) Br. II. 22. 72;
Vā. 51. 64; Vi. II. 8. 5.
3) Br. II. 13. 145; Vā. 31. 47.
text.5695:
Trisandhyā (I) — The goddess enshrined at Godāśrama.
M. 13. 37.
text.5696:
Trisandhyā (II) — a Tīrtham sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 46.
text.5697:
Trisānu — the son of Gobhānu, and father of Karan
dhama.
Br. III. 74. 1; Vā. 99. 1.
text.5698:
Trisāmā — a R. in Bhāratavarṣa, from the Mahendra hill.
Bhā. V. 19. 18; Br. II. 16. 37; Vā. 45. 106; Vi. II. 3. 13.
text.5700:
Trisuparṇa — the Brahmanas versed in Suparṇa sec
tions;1 eligible for Pārvaṇa Śrāddha.2 1) Vā. 83. 53.
2) M. 16. 7; Vi. III. 15. 2.
text.5701:
Tristhāna — of the lord — Divya, Āntarikṣa and Bhauma.
Vā. 23. 104, 107.
text.5702:
Truṭi — a Śakti resident of Ṣoḍaśapatrābja.
Br. IV. 32. 14.
text.5703:
Tretā — at the commencement of this Yuga, Brahmā
established the social polity of castes and orders; long life,
learning, strength, beauty, health and righteousness were
common; in course of time moha made men irreligious and
prejudiced; they appealed to Manu who created two sons,
Priyavrata and Uttānapāda through Śatarūpā; they were the
first kings of the earth; here was the division of the Śamhitā,
Mantra, Ṛṣi and Brāhmaṇa; the dharma meant truth, japa,
tapas and dānam; the kings were Cakravartins;1 the dharma
of;2 see Tretāyuga. 1) Vā. 32. 57-8; 57. 25, 54-60; 78. 36.

text.5722:
Tvaṣṭa (Tvaṣṭri) — a son of Aditi, and an Āditya.1
Presented Pṛthu with a good chariot.2 His wife was Racanā,
and sons were Sannivasa and Viśvarūpa (s.v.);3 when the
latter was lost, he offered a sacrifice to destroy Indra. From
the fire rose a dreadful figure known as Vṛtra. The Gods
were frightened and prayed to Hari. The lord revealed Him
self and asked them to meet the sage Dadhyañja with whose
support Vṛtra could be vanquished. Dadhyañja initiated
them into Nārāyaṇavarma;4 was propitiated by An
giras for blessing Citrākṣa with a son.5 His con
templation.6 The name of the Sun in the month of Iṣa
(Āśvina).7 (Māgha and Phālguna) (Vā. P. and Vi. P.)
Fought with Śambara in the Devāsura war.8 Out of the
tejas came Viṣṇu's cakra, Indra's vajra, and Rudra's śūlam;
all limbs except the feet of Vivasvan were operated upon,
and hence feet amangala and not to be worshipped; pre
sented Kumāra with a hen that could assume any form at
will.9 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 39; III. 6. 15; M. 6. 4; 171. 56; Vā. 66. 66;
Vi. I. 15. 130.
2) Bhā. IV. 15. 17.
3)Ib. VI. 6. 44.

(whole).
5)Ib. VI. 14. 27.
6)Ib. XI. 15. 20.

9)M.
11. 3. 22-32; 159. 10.
text.5723:
Tvaṣṭā (I) — one of the four sons of Śukra;1 married
Yaśodharā — Vairocinī, daughter of Virocana; father of

of Śacipati.7 1) Br. III. 1. 78, 86; Vā. 65. 77, 85; Vi. I. 15. 121.
2) Br. III.
14. 6; 59. 17.
3) Ib. II. 24. 34, 39.

44 and 65.

Thuklasa (Puklasa?) — a commander of Bhaṇḍa to aid

text.5734:
Dakṣa (I) — a Mind-born son of Brahmā, born of his
thumb, and father of Mūrti. A progenitor and guardian of
the world, born for the creation of worldly beings.1 Married
Prasūtī, daughter of Svāyambhuva Manu. Had sixteen
daughters of whom he gave thirteen to Dharma, one to Agni,
one to Pitṛs, and one to Śiva.2 To the Satra of Viśvasṛk
Dakṣa came and was welcomed by all standing, except
Brahmā and Śiva. On this Dakṣa burst into anger against
Śiva and insulted him saying he had eyes like a monkey, was a
breaker of law and convention, lord of the Bhūtas and Gaṇas;
he then cursed that Śiva should have no more share in sacri
fices and went away. Nandi got enraged at this and im
precated a curse on Dakṣa that he would lose all knowledge
of Ātman, and assuming the face of a sheep, would become
dull-witted. Bhṛgu then pronounced a counter-curse that
those propitiating Śiva shall become Pākhaṇḍas.3 Appointed
by Brahmā as the overlord of all Prajāpatis, Dakṣa began
the sacrifice of Bṛhaspatisava to which all gods went in
groups. Satī also expressed her desire to go and requested
permission of Śiva, who reminded her of the insult offered to
him.4 As she was persistent, she was allowed to attend.
Going, she found that she was not properly welcomed by her
father. The enraged Satī sat facing the northern direction
in yoga and cast off her body by means of the fire of Samādhī
to the distress of gods and others. On this the Gaṇa followers
of Satī attacked Dakṣa, when Bhṛgu created a class of gods,
Ṛbhus who vanquished these Gaṇas.5 Having heard of all
this from Nārada, Śiva grew angry; out of his anger sprang
Vīrabhadra who was ordered to ruin Dakṣa's sacrifice. The
beard of Bhṛgu was cut off, and Dakṣa's head was severed
from his body and thrown into the Dakṣiṇāgni.6 The Gods
waited upon Brahmā who proceeded to Kailāsa. He conciliat
ed Śiva and pleaded for the revival of Dakṣa and continuation
of his Yajña promising a share to him.7 Śiva agreed but
said that Dakṣa should have the face of the sheep, Bhaga,
Mitra's eye, and Bhṛgu the beard of a sheep. Agreeing to this
Brahmā went with Śiva to the sacrificial hall of Dakṣa. Now
Dakṣa began to praise Śiva. When Viṣṇu's offering was
poured to secure the continuation of the sacrifice, Viṣṇu
presented himself in person when Dakṣa, Ṛtviks, Sadasyas,
Rudra and others present, spoke in his praise. Pleased at
this, Hari remarked there was no difference among the
Trimurtīs. Dakṣa brought the yajña to a successful end.8
Another account.
Dakṣa son of Varkṣī (Māriṣā-Vi. P.) and Pracetas (Prā
cetasaṣ-Vi. P.); a Prajāpati. He first created the Devas,
Asuras, men and others inhabiting the sky, earth
and water. Finding the creation incomplete, he went
to the Vindhyas for tapas by bathing in the Agha
marṣaṇa and propitiating Hari with the hymn of
hamsaguhya. To him the Lord appeared and urged
him to marry Asiknī, daughter of Pañcajana and
thus increase the created beings.9 Of Asiknī he begot 10,000
sons called Haryaśvas. The latter proceeded to the western
direction to the sacred lake Nārāyaṇasaras at the estuary
of the Indus. Purified by the bath and instructed by Nārada
on the bondage of Samsāra, these took to the path of ‘not
returning’ (anvartana). Dakṣa lamented and begot by the
same wife a thousand sons, Śabalāśvas. These again followed
the path trodden by their elder brothers, advised by Nārada.
The enraged Dakṣa cursed that Nārada, the corrupter
of youth, was ever to be a wanderer and to have no settled
home. The sage submitted to it without retaliating.10 Con
soled by Brahmā, Dakṣa further begot sixty daughters of
Asiknī (Vairinī-M. P.). He bestowed ten on Dharma,
twelve on Kaśyapa, twenty-seven on Soma, two each for
Bhūta, Angiras, and Kṛśāśva, and the remaining five, of
whom only four seem to be named (in v. 21) on Tārkṣyā.11
Elsewhere it is said that thirteen daughters were given in
marriage to Kaśyapa.
Went with Brahmā to meet Hiraṇyakaśipu; was
present at the anointing of Vāmana; father of Aditi;13 cursed
Moon god with consumption (yakṣma).14 Wondered at
Mārkaṇḍeya's vrata;15 had not yet seen the Supreme Being;
identified with Hari.16
Drank of the Saubhāgya from the thigh of Hari and
brought forth a daughter Satī married by Śiva;17 a Mahaṛṣi;
heard the Purāṇa from Brahmā along with other sages;18
son of Brahmā, married Ūrjā.19
^12) M. 23. 15; 1) Bhā. III. 12. 22-3; Ib. II. 6. 42; 7. 6; Br. II. 32. 96; 36. 84;
Ib. III. 3. 30; 65. 21; Ib. IV. 2. 33, 47; M. 3. 9; 8. 4; 154. 353; 171.

2) Bhā. III. 12.

text.5735:
Dakṣa (II) — in previous birth son of Brahmā, now
born of Māriṣā and Pracetasas. Was made a chief progeni
tor on the eve of the Cākṣuṣa epoch;1 a grandson of Soma;
created men with two feet and four feet, of different faces,
ears, etc., also mlecchas and women; also produced 1000
sons with Pāñcajani, named Haryaśvas. Nārada asked them
to go into the world over but they perished in their sojourn.
So he begot another 1000 of Vairiṇī, and these were Śabalas
set by Nārada in quest of the whereabouts of their brothers.
They also perished.2 1) Bhā. IV. 30. 49-51; Br. IV. 1. 24, 39-44.
2)M. 4. 49-55; 5.
2-14.

Dakṣa (III) — the son of Citrasena, and father of
Mīḍhvān.

Dakṣa (IV) — a son of Uśīnara.
Bhā. IX. 23. 3.

and half of Soma; created creatures, two-legged and four

Prācetasatvam in the epoch of Cākṣuṣa by the curse of
Trayambaka; father-in-law of the seven sages.3 1) Br. I. 5. 70; Vā. 63. 35-48; 65. 121-158.
2) Vā. 70-5; 101.
35, 49.

Three groups of twelve gods in each of Pāra, Mārīcigarbha

timan and others were seven sages. Father of Dhṛtiketu
and other sons.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 13. 18.

text.5769:
Daṇḍa (II) — (see also daṇḍanīti): the rod of punish

2) Br. II. 19. 120.
3) Br. II. 7.
161 and 168; III. 28. 56.
4) M. 122. 44; 148. 66 and 76; 222. 2; 225.
1-18. 227. 217.

Budha approached Ilā.

text.5789:

M. 261. 5.

Vā. 108. 56.
text.5793:
Datta (Atri) (I) — the son of the sage Atri and Ana
sūyā and an avatār of Viṣṇu according to Paurāṇikas;
brother of Durvāsa; by worshipping him, the Yadus, Haiha
yas, etc., got knowledge of yoga.1 He knew Hari yoga,2 and
followed Hari going to Pṛthu's sacrifice.3 A Siddha;4
worshipped by Arjuna (Haihaya), to whom he imparted
yoga;5 in the tenth Tretāyuga the 4th incarnation with
Markaṇḍeya as Purohita;6 was worshipped by Arjuna who
got four boons from him one of which was 1000 hands;7
Śyāmas, Mudgalas, Gaviṣṭhias and others belong to this
Vamśa.8 1) Bhā. II. 7. 4; IV. I. 15 and 33; XI. 4. 17; Br. III. 8. 82;
IV. 28. 89; Vā. 70. 76-8.
2) Bhā. II. 7. 45.
3) Ib. IV. 19. 6.
4) Ib.
VI. 8. 16; 15. 14.
5) Ib. IX. 15. 17; 23. 24; Br. III. 30. 35; 34. 4;
38. 14; 40. 43, 57, 66; 69. 10; M. 43. 15.
6) Br. III. 73. 88; M. 47.
242; 99. 14; Vā. 98. 89.
7) Vā. 94. 10-11; Vi. IV. 11. 12.
8) Ib.
I. 10. 8.

Br. III. 10. 18.
text.5796:
Dattāli: (Dattoli) — a son of Prītā and Pulastya; an
Agastya in previous birth.
Vā. 28. 22; Vi. I. 10. 9.
text.5797:
Dattotri (I) — a Paulastya and one of the 7 sages of the
Svārociṣa epoch.
Br. II. 36. 18.
text.5798:
Dattotri (II) — given by Manu to Ahi as son; see Uttāna
pāda.
Br. II. 36. 85; III. 47. 65.
text.5801:
Dadhipañcamukha — a Ṛtvik at Brahmā's yajña.
Vā. 106. 37.
text.5802:
Dadhimaṇḍoda — a sea that surrounds the Śākadvīpa.1
(Krauñcadvīpa Br. P.) also Dadhisindhu.2 1) Bhā. V. 1. 33; 20. 24.
2) Br. II. 19. 77; IV. 31. 19; M. 122.
92. Vi. II. 4. 57.
text.5803:
Dadhimukha — a Kādraveya Nāga.
Br. III. 7. 35; Vā. 69. 72.
text.5804:
Dadhivāhana — the son of Bali and king of Anga, born
without apāna, due to the blunder of Sudeṣṇa; hence
Anapāna; father of Diviratha (see Sudeṣṇa).
Br. III. 74. 102-3; M. 48-91; Vā. 99. 100.
text.5805:
Dadhīca (I) — a Ṛṣika, who became a sage by satya;1
a Mantrakṛṭ2 Heard the Viṣṇu Purāṇa from Stambhamitra
and narrated it to Sārasvata.3 1) Br. II. 32. 102.
2) M. 145. 98.
3) Vi. VI. 8. 44.
text.5806:
Dadhīca (II) — urged Dakṣa to invite Paśupati to the
sacrifice.
Vā. 30. 103-7.
text.5807:
Dadhīci (I) — (also Dadhyañja, Dadhyanga) the son of
Atharvan and Citti.1 A sage of much eminence. Taught
Aśvāśiras mantra to Aśvins and Nārāyaṇa varma to Tvaṣṭri,
who gave it to Viśvarūpa. The Lord advised Indra to meet
the sage whose bones would serve as best weapons to cut
Vṛtra's head. When the gods waited on him with this desire,
he argued at first that no one would be willing to part with
his life. But, he would agree for their sake to sacrifice his
life. When he cast off his body, Viśvakarma made it a Vajra
for the use of Indra.2 Dadhīci's is an example of one, who
gave up life in service.3 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 42.
2) Ib. VI. 9. 51-55; 10. 2-13; 11. 20.
3) Ib.
VIII. 20. 7.
text.5808:
Dadhīci (II) — the son of Cyavana Bhārgava; married
Sarasvatī and father of Sārasvata;1 Sage by garbha;2
a Mantrakṛt.3 1) Br. III. 1. 93-4; Vā. 65. 90.
2) Ib. 54. 94.
3) Ib. 59. 96.
text.5809:
Dadhīci (III) — the son of Vairāja Manu.
Vā. 21. 41; 30. 102.
text.5810:
Dadhyanca (ga) — the son of Atharva Agni.
Br. II. 12. 10; Vā. 29. 8.
text.5811:
Danāyuṣā — had five sons; all powerful.
Vā. 68. 30.
text.5812:
Danu (I) — a son of Kāśyapa and Diti; appointed
Purohita.
Br. IV. 9. 3.
text.5816:
Danu (V) — one of Kaśyapa's wives and a daughter of
Dakṣa. Had Dvimūrdhā and sixty other sons;1 Māyāśitā;2
also mother of 100 sons of whom Vipracitti was the chief;
mother of the Dānavas; a mother-goddess.3 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 25; 29-31; Vā. 66. 55; Vi. I. 5. 124.
2) Br. III.
3. 56; 6. 1-2; 7. 466.
3) M. 6. 1 and 16; 146. 18; 171. 29 and 58;
179. 19.
text.5817:
Danuputras — the great Asuras, 100 in number, chief of
them being Vipracitti; all resolute and bold; blessed after
long and severe penance; truthful, powerful, cruel, magical;
not performers of sacrifice; unbrahmanical; a list of the chief
names; some of them took to human dharma.
Vā. 68. 1-16.
text.5819:
Dantakāṇvośana — a son of Umā and Mahādeva.
Vā. 72. 16.
text.5820:
Dantapavanam — cleaning the teeth with sticks of six trees
like the Aśvattha and the banyan; part of Kṛṣṇāṣṭamī vrata.
M. 56. 8.
text.5822:
Dantavaktra (I) — a son of Yudhiṣṭhira's aunt and
brother of Caidya, (s.v.).1 Helped Jarāsandha in his siege
of Mathurā and Gomanta by guarding the eastern
gate of the former, and the western gate of the
latter with his brother.2 Attended the conference
summoned by Śālva to defeat the Yadus, and got
angry at Śālva's death.3 Arrival at Kuṇḍina;4 was the
king of Kalinga; when he heard that Kṛṣṇa was returning
from the Yamunā to Dvārakā, he waylaid him to discharge
the debt he owed to his friends. He struck Kṛṣṇa on the
head but was himself hit on his chest; when he fell dead,
a spark entered Kṛṣṇa's body and he became one with the
Lord.5 1) Bhā. VII. 1. 32-46; 10. 38.
2) Ib. X. 50. 11 [2]; 52. 11 [11].
Vi. V. 26. 7.
3) Bhā. X. 76. 2 [10]; 77. 37.
4) Ib. X. 53. 17; 60. 18.
5) Ib. X. 78. 1-13; 37. 19; II. 7. 34; III. 3. 11; VII. 1. 17.
text.5823:
Dantavaktra (II) — (Dantavakra-Vā. P.) — a son of
Diti, and cursed by a sage; was born of Śrutadevā;1 and
Vṛddhadharma, the Kārūṣa king.2 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 37; Br. IV. 29. 122; Vā. 96. 155.
2) Br. III.
71. 156; Vi. IV. 14. 40.
text.5825:
Dandaśūka (I) — one of the 28 hells; the cruel and
merciless are tormented here by reptiles and others.
Bhā. V. 26. 7 and 33.
text.5826:
Dandaśūka (II) — the name of a serpent born of
Krodhavaśā.
Bhā. VI. 6. 28.
text.5827:
Dandaśūka (III) — a follower of Vṛtra in his battle with
Indra.
Bhā. VI. 10. [20].
text.5828:
Dama (I) — a son of Marutta, and father of Rājya
vardhana.
Bhā. IX. 2. 29.
text.5829:
Dama (II) — a son of Kriyā.
Br. II. 9. 60.
text.5831:
Dama (IV) — a god of the Ābhūtaraya group.
Br. II. 36. 55.
text.5833:
Dama (VI) — a son of Nariṣyanta, a daṇḍadhara and
father of Vikrānta. (Rāṣtravardhana-Br. P.; Rajavardhana
Vi. P.).
Br. III. 61. 8; Vā. 86. 12; Vi. IV. 1. 36.
text.5834:
Dama (VII) — an Ārṣeya pravara of Bhārgavas.
M. 195. 36.
text.5838:
Damaghoṣa — a king of the Cedis; queen Śrutaśravā;1
(Paṭuśravā and Rujakanyā) father of Śiśupāla (Caidya:2
s.v.), performed preliminaries to the marriage of his son
with Rukmiṇī; when he went to Kuṇḍina, he was entertain
ed by her father Bhīṣmaka.3 He was stationed on the south
during the siege of Gomanta by Jarāsandha;4 went to
Syamantapañcaka for the solar eclipse.5 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 39. Br. III. 71. 159. Vi. IV. 14. 44.
2) Bhā.
VII. 1. 17. Vā. 96. 158.
3) Bhā. X. 53. 14-16.
4) Ib. X. 52. 11 [8].
5) Ib. X. 82. 26.
text.5839:
Damana (I) — a son of Vasudeva and Rohiṇi.
Br. III. 71. 165; M. 46. 12. Vā. 96. 163.
text.5840:
Damana (II) — a commander to aid Viṣanga, killed by
Kāmesvarī.
Br. IV. 25. 30, 46, 94.
text.5842:
Damana (IV) — the avatār of the Lord in the third
Dvāpara; had four sons, Viśoka, Vikeśa, etc.
Vā. 23. 123.
text.5843:
Damana (V) — a Ṛtvik at Brahmā's sacrifice.
Vā. 106. 36.
text.5844:
Damavāhya — a sage; exclusion of marriage with the
Angirasas.
M. 196. 29.
text.5845:
Damina — the Brahmana caste of Kuśadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 38.
text.5846:
Dambha (I) — a son of Adharma.
Bhā. IV. 8. 2.
text.5848:
Dambhā — a R. in Kuśadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 62.
text.5849:
Daṃṣṭrā — a daughter of Krodhavaśa and a wife of
Pulaha;1 gave birth to lions, tigers, elephants, etc.2 1) Br. III. 7. 172; Vā. 69. 205.
2) Br. III. 7. 412.
text.5852:
Dayā — a daughter of Dakṣa, and a wife of Dharma;
mother of Abhaya;1 a śakti.2 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 49-50.
2) Br. IV. 44. 89.
text.5853:
Darada (I) — a Mahāratha; was stationed on the
southern gate of Mathurā, and on the western gate of
Gomanta by Jarāsandha when he besieged them.
Bhā. X. 50. 11 [3]; 52. 11 [12].
text.5854:
Darada (II) — a northern kingdom noted for horses;1 a
tribe.2 1) Br. II. 16. 49; 18. 47; 31. 83; IV. 16. 17; M. 121. 46; 144. 57.
2) Vā. 45. 118; 47. 44-5; 58. 83; 98. 108.
text.5855:
Daridyota — (Aridyota-Br. P.) — the son of Dundubhi
and father of Punarvasu.
Bhā. IX. 24. 20.
text.5857:
Daridrāntaka (II) — a son of Balarāma.
Br. III. 71. 167.
text.5860:
Dardura (II) — a Mt. of the Bhāratavarṣa.
Vā. 45. 90.
text.5861:
Darpa (I) — born of Dharma and Unnati.
Bhā. IV. 1. 51.
text.5862:
Darpa (II) — a son of Lakṣmī.
Br. II. 9. 8; Vā. 10. 34.
text.5863:
Darpaṇam — a looking-glass to be installed by the side
of a deity.
M. 57. 18; 265. 19; 289. 10.
text.5865:
Darbhaka (I) — a son of Ajātaśatru and father of Ajaya.
Bhā. XII, 1. 6.
text.5867:
Darbhāvatī — a R. of the Ketumāla country.
Vā. 44. 17.
text.5868:
Darvas — a hill tribe;1 a mountain kingdom.2 1) Br. II. 16. 67.
2) M. 114. 56; Vā. 45. 136.
text.5869:
Darvā — one of the wives of Uśinara and mother of
Suvrata.
Br. III. 74. 18 and 20. Vā. 99. 19.
text.5870:
Darśa (I) — the son of Dhātā and Sinīvāli.
Bhā. VI. 18. 3.
text.5871:
Darśa (II) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Kālindi.
Bhā. X. 61. 14.
text.5872:
Darśa (III) — a son of Brahmā and Mantrasarīra: a
Jayadeva.
Br. III. 3. 6; 4. 2; Vā. 66. 6; 67. 5.
text.5873:
Darśaka — a king of Magadha; ruled for 25 years.
Vā. 99. 318.
text.5874:
Darśanīya — a Yakṣa; son of Puṇyajanī and Maṇi
bhadra.
Br. III. 7. 125.
text.5875:
Darśapūrṇamāsa — a sacrifice performed by Bharata.
Bhā. V. 7. 5.
text.5876:
Darśam — a name for the 27th Kalpa; here Soma became
Paurṇamāsi.
Vā. 21. 67, 69.
text.5877:
Darśā — one of the five queens of Uśīnara; father of
Suvrata.
M. 48. 16, 18.
text.5878:
Dala (I) — a son of Pratyuṣa and a Devaṛsi.
Br. II. 35. 94.
text.5879:
Dala (II) — a son of Pariyātra (Pāripātra-Vā. P.) and
father of Bala.
Br. III. 63. 204: Vā. 88. 204.
text.5881:
Daśakandhara — Rāvana killed by Rāma.
Bhā. II. 7. 23-25.
text.5882:
Daśakṛtva — the Yāma gaṇas who stand in ten parts in
the Vairāja.
Vā. 101. 64.
text.5883:
Daśagrīva (I) — Rāvana (s.v.).1 Śiśupāla in previous
birth.2 1) Bhā. VII. 10. 36; Br. III. 7. 262; 71 159.
2) Vā. 96. 153.
text.5884:
Daśagrīva (II) — an Asura in the sabhā of Hiraṇya
kaśipu.
M. 161. 81.
text.5885:
Daśatāla — the images of Rāma and Bali.
M. 259. 1.
text.5889:
Daśaratha (I) — a son of Mūlaka, and father of Aiḍa
viḍa. (Ilīvila-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 9. 41; V. IV. 4. 75.
text.5890:
Daśaratha (II) — a son of Aja (Pāla) and of Indumatī;
and father of Śrī Rāma (Dāśarathi Rāma-Vā. P.) and three
other sons, being the amśas of Hari.1 A friend of Roma
pāda to whom he gave his daughter Śāntā in adoption.2 King
of Ayodhyā. Having no sons worshipped Tripurasundarī at
the capital and spent seven days at Kāñcī praying to
Kāmākṣī who blessed him with four sons.3 1) Bhā. IX. 10. 1-2; Br. III. 63. 184; IV. 40. 100; M. 12. 49-50;
Vā. 88. 183-4; 111. 64; Vi. IV. 4. 86-7.
2) Bhā. IX. 23. 7-8; Vi. IV.
18. 17-8.
3) Br. III. 37. 31; 63. 184; IV. 40. 88.
text.5891:
Daśaratha (III) — a son of Navaratha, and father of
Śakuni (Ekādaśaratha-Br. P.).
Bhā. IX. 24. 4-5; Br. III. 70. 43-4. Vā. 95. 42; Vi. IV. 12. 41.
text.5892:
Daśaratha (IV) — a son of Satyaratha (Citraratha:
Vā. P.). (Known also as Lomapāda).
M. 48. 94; Vā. 9. 103.
text.5893:
Daśaratha (V) — a Maurya king who ruled for eight
years; son of Suyaśā and father of Samyuta.
M. 272. 25; Vi. IV. 24. 30.
text.5894:
Daśavarṇadhanu — the bow of Śiva with ten colours.
Vā. 101. 270.
text.5896:
Daśārṇas — a Vindhya tribe enlisted by Jarāsandha
against the Yadus.
Bhā. X. [50. (v) 3]; Br. II. 16. 64; Vā. 45. 132.
text.5897:
Daśārṇā — a R. in Bhāratavarṣa from the Rkṣa; sacred
to Pitṛs.
Br. II. 16. 30; III. 13. 100; M. 22. 34; Vā. 45. 99. M. 144. 25.
text.5898:
Daśārha (I) — the son of Nirvṛt(t)i, (Nidhṛti-V. P.,
Vīdūratha, M. P.), and father of Vyoma;1 a man of much
prowess.2 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 3; X. 36. 33; M. 44. 40.
2) Br. III. 70. 41; Vi.
IV. 12. 41.
text.5900:
Daśārhas — (also Daśārhakās) a tribe related to the Pāṇ
ḍavas. They defended Dvārakā when attacked.1 Praised
Kṛṣṇa's heroism.2 Felt relieved at Kamsa's death as they
heard of his plan to vanquish them.3 Followed Balarāma
to Dvārakā and fought their own kinsmen.4 1) Bhā. I. 11. 11; 14. 25; III. 1. 29.
2) Ib. IX. 24. 63.
3) Ib. X.
36. 33; 39. 25; 45. 15.
4) Ib. X. 61. 40; XI. 29. 39; 30. 18.
text.5901:
Daśāśvamedhajananam — a Tīrtha on the Narmadā; west
of Gangeśvaram.
193. 20-2.
text.5902:
Dāśāśvamedham — a Tirtham in Benares;1 fit for
śrāddha.2 1) M. 185. 68.
2) Vā. 77. 45.
text.5904:
Dasyahantama — the name of Budha, son of Tārā and
Soma who forcibly seized her from Bṛhaspati;1 called Budha
after Tārā revealed his real father.2 1) Br. III. 65. 41; Vā. 90. 37.
2) Vā. 90. 43.
text.5905:
Dasyu — The Ābhiras and Mlecchas; unfit for śrāddha;1
checked by Yayāti;2 dharma of the;3 seized 16000 ladies of
Kṛṣṇa due to a curse by the Lord;4 cudgels as chief weapons
of;5 killing milch cows.6 1) Br. III. 14. 43; Vi. V. 38. 13; 25. 27. 497.
2) Br. III. 68. 67.
3) Ib. III. 63. 194; Vā. 49. 55; 78. 34; 88. 105.
4) M. 70. 7.
5) Vi.
V. 38. 51, 70, 82, 84.
6) Vā. 93. 66.
text.5906:
Dasyumān — an Āngirasa and Mantrakṛt.
Br. II. 32. 108.
text.5907:
Dasra — a son of Mārtāṇḍa or the Sun;1 one of the
Aśvins.2 1) Vā. 84. 24. Br. III. 59. 25;
2) Vā. 84. 77.
text.5908:
Dahana — one of the eleven Rudras.
M. 171. 39.
text.5909:
Dahrāgni — born as Agastya to Pulastya.
Bhā. IV. 1. 36.
text.5912:
Dākinis — evil spirits injuring children.
Bhā. X. 6. 27; 63. 10.
text.5914:
Dākṣāyaṇi (I) — a son of Dāruka, an avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 196.
text.5915:
Dākṣāyaṇi (II) — the previous avatār of Umā; stars
regarded as her daughters;1 a daughter of Dakṣa;2 became
Hiṃavān's daughter by worshipping Śiva.3 1) M. 13. 10; 128. 50; 199. 20.
2) Br. I. 1. 59.
3) Ib. III. 7. 472;
IV. 11. 2-5.
text.5916:
Dākṣi — a sage; a Trayārṣeya pravara.
M. 196. 25; 197. 6.
text.5917:
Dākṣiṇātyas — (Drāviḍas); southerners;1 to be conquer
ed by Kalki.2 1) Br. II. 31. 82; Vā. 58. 82; 98. 107.
2) Br. III. 73. 107.
text.5918:
Dātā — a Mukhya gaṇa of the Sāvarṇya epoch;1 a Sukha
God. 2 1) Vā. 94. 56; 100. 18;
2) Br. IV. 1. 19.
text.5922:
Dāna — a dharma;1 a śiṣṭācāra;2 three kinds of; superior,
middling and inferior; the first and last of which are called
respectively jyeṣṭha and kaniṣṭha; the lower and the higher
not fit for one's own welfare; the middling is the equal dis
tribution among the deserving; the superior gift leads to
Mokṣa and the inferior to one's own welfare;3 he who per
forms sacrifice by ill-gotten wealth does not attain the fruits
thereof; his gifts are not for dharma but only for show; but
well-earned money given to right men without expecting
fruits, merits Bhoga while Satya leads to heaven;4 the mak
ing of, in a śrāddha and the fruits thereof;5 one of the upāyas
of a king; even Gods are brought under control by gifts;
sixteen kinds of; done by Kāma, Ambarīṣa, Pṛthu, Prahlāda
and others;6 the vidhi of, enquired by Manu from the
Matsya.7 Incumbent on all castes8 useless if given to a non
śrotriya;9 conditions appropriate to.10 1) Vā. 23. 101.
2) Br. II. 32. 41.
3) Ib. II. 32. 54-56; Vā.
59. 49-50.
4) Ib. 67. 27; 91. 106-12; 104. 14.
5) Br. III. 4. 24; 16. 1.
6) M. 222. 2; 224. 1-4; 246. 25-7; 274 (whole).
7) Ib. 2. 23.
8) Vi.
III. 8. 22.
9) Ib. V. 38. 30.
10) Vā. 91. 107-13.
text.5924:
Dānavas — a class of demons from Danu residing in
Rasātala; Śvetaparvata their abode;1 were fascinated by Hari
but they hated him;2 Vipracitti was their overlord.3 1) Bhā. II. 7. 13; V. 24. 30. Vā. 39. 29; 46. 35; 66. 1.
2) Bhā. X.
40. 22; 85. 41; XI. 14. 5.
3) Br. III. 7. 255; 8. 7; 20. 3; IV. 4. 2.
text.5925:
Dānavratas — a class of people in Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 27.
text.5926:
Dānāgni — a son of Prīti and Pulastya; Agastya in pre
vious birth; wife Sujanghi, had many sons known as
Paulastyas.
Br. II. 11. 26.
text.5930:
Dāmodara — Kṛṣṇa;1 with the weapon pāśa;2 around his
belly Yaśodā bound a rope and fastened him to a mortar.3 1) Br. III. 36. 39;
2) Ib. IV. 34. 83.
3) Vi. V. 6. 20; 13. 34.
text.5932:
Dārika — (Dārakas-Vā. P.); a Pārāśara clan.
Br. III. 8. 95. Vā. 70. 87.
text.5933:
Dāruka (I) — the charioteer of Kṛṣṇa;1 went with
Kṛṣṇa to Śālva's station, and drove the chariot when Kṛṣṇa
gained Lakṣmaṇā by svayamvara;2 took Kṛṣṇa to Mithilā
and the Videha country.3 His son was the charioteer of
Pradyumna.4 Stood before Kṛṣṇa on the eve of His return
ing from the earth. Kṛṣṇa asked him to inform the Dvārakā
people of the position of the Yādavas at Prabhāsa and advise
them to go to Indraprastha with Arjuna. Returning to the
city, Dāruka informed Vasudeva and others accordingly.5 1) Bhā. X. 50. 16. 20 [5]. [8]; 64. [6]; 71. 12. Vi. V. 37. 51.
2) Bhā. X. 77. 9-11; 83. 33.
3) Ib. 86. 17; 53. 4.
4) Ib. 76. 27.
5) Ib. XI.
30. 41-50; 31. 15-17; Vi. V. 37. 57-64.
text.5934:
Dāruka (II) — the avatār of the Lord in the 21st Dvā
para with sons in the holy Dāruvana.
Vā. 23. 95.
text.5936:
Dāruvanam — on the Himālayan crests; the abode of
sages in Kṛtayuga engaged in severe austerities; Śiva
appeared before them naked and sometimes wept and some
times danced; the womenfolk were enchanted by him; the
angry sages cursed him to become an ass and at
tempted to cut off his lingam; the Lord disappear
ed; finding the world beset with difficulties and
dangers the sages appealed to Brahmā and learnt that it was
due to Śiva; hence they made images of Linga and offered
worship for a year; the Lord appeared before them, and was
praised by all;1 the sages were treated by Śiva on
Bhasmasnānavidhi.2 1) Br. II. 27. 2-90;
2) Ib. II. 27. 105, 128.
text.5937:
Dārvā — a degraded Kṣatriya clan.
Br. III. 63. 140.
text.5939:
Dālbhya (I) — a sage of the Auttama epoch.
M. 9. 14.
text.5940:
Dālbhya (II) — the sage who initiated the fallen wives
of Kṛṣṇa in the Anangadānavratam and thus rescued them.
M. 70. 10, 13.
text.5941:
Dāvika (c) — the country of, (Dārvika — Wilson) under
the mlecchas.
Vi. IV. 24. 69.
text.5942:
Dāśapuram — here were born as hunters the seven sons
of Kauśika. But they remembered their previous births
and refrained from cruel deeds.
M. 20. 12-4; 21. 9 and 28.
text.5943:
Dāśarathi — a name of Rāma, who destroyed Rāvana
and his clan.
Vā. 70. 48.
text.5944:
Dāśārṇas — Śatadhvaja (s.v.) was their king; when
they heard of Kṛṣṇa going to Mithilā they met him with
presents.
Bhā. X. 52. 11 [12]; 86. 25.
text.5946:
Dāśeyi — the fisher-woman, who took birth as Satyavatī
and begot Vicitravīrya by Śantanu.
M. 50. 45; Vā. 73. 21; 99. 240.
text.5947:
Dāsa — servants entertained in a śrāddha;1 appellation
of the Śūdras.2 1) M. 17. 57 and 62; Vā. 60. 37.
2) Vi. III. 10. 9.
text.5948:
Dāsi (I) — Slaves as present to learned men.
Br. II. 34. 39.
text.5949:
Dāsi (II) — of four kinds, devadāsi, brahmadāsi, sva-
tantra and Śūdradāsika; the first two occupy the status of
a Kṣatriya lady; the third enjoys the status of a dancing girl
(veśi), and the last that of a low caste (hīnajāti).1 A
synonym of Paricārika or a servant-maid.2 1) Br. IV. 8. 11-12.
2) M. 29. 17-23.
text.5950:
Dāsera — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 85.
text.5951:
Dāhakāla — the period at the end of a Kalpa.
Vā. 7. 15.
text.5953:
Dikgajas — the four elephants at the four quarters with
clouds; thrown about during Śiva's tāṇḍava.
Br. II. 22. 47, 51; Vā. 51. 43-5. M. 1. 1; 125. 17-21.
text.5954:
Dikpati — a Satya God.
Br. II. 36. 34; Vā. 62. 31.
text.5955:
Dikpālas — the guardians of the quarters; Sudharman,
Śankhapāda, Ketumān, and Hīraṇyaroman; destroy the
enemies and protect the earth. Invoked in the grahabali;1
worship of.2 1) M. 8. 9-11; 93. 52.
2) M. 67. 9-16; 69. 38.
text.5956:
Dikvāsasa — an attribute of Śiva.
Br. II. 27. 98.
text.5957:
Digaṅgana — These are Brāhmī, Āgneyī, Gādinī,
Naiṛṛti, Vāruṇī, Patākinī, Śankhini and Māheśvari.
M. 286. 5-11, 17.
text.5958:
Digīśvarās — Lords of the quarters; present at Varuṇa's
sacrifice.
Br. III. 1. 28.
text.5960:
Digvijaya — conquest of the quarters; of Sagara;1 of Ila.2 1) Br. III. 49. 47; 52. 41.
2) M. 11. 43.
text.5961:
Diṇḍipuṇyakaram — a Tīrtham sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 77.
text.5963:
Diti (I) — a daughter of Dakṣa, and wife of Kaśyapa.1
Her sons generally known as Daityas. Mother of
Hiraṇyākṣa and Hiraṇyakaśipu.2 Mother of Dantavaktra
by the sage's curse.3 Her sons Prahlāda and Hari were
devotees of Hari.4 Always set her mind on truth;5 daughter
Simhikā;5a (Ādity-Vā. P.). Finding her sons slain by
Hari to help Indra, she became enraged, and asked her
husband to bless her with a child to kill Indra. The un
willing husband offered it on condition of her observing
certain vows for 100 years. So she observed them and
Indra came to assist her. One day he found her sleep
ing in an unorthodox posture and entering her womb cut
the embryo into seven and then into 49 pieces; but
at her request he gave all of them the status of gods,
known as Maruts.6 Impelled by passion and desire for
children she approached her husband one evening for
sexual intercourse. Kaśyapa said that it was the hour
when Śivagaṇas moved about and for him, to offer the
Śandhya-prayer. But she persisted and gained her object.
She however requested to be redeemed of the sin. Kaśyapa
remarked that since she approached him at the wrong time,
her sons would have paiśāca-character and would be killed
by Hari. For her penitence she was blessed with a
righteous child among her grandsons.7 Held the tejas in
embryo for a hundred years when darkness enveloped all
directions. The two door-keepers of Vaikuṇṭha cursed by
seers for preventing them from having darsan of Hari were
born as her two sons, when there were evil omens.8 Prayed
for another son. This was Vajrānga who on his birth accord
ing to her orders bound Indra. The latter was released on
the mediation of Brahmā and Kaśyapa.9 Mother of Daityas;
a Mother Goddess to be worshipped in house and palace
buildings10 Yoganidrā addressed as;11 sons of, in the
seventh talam or Pātālam.12 1) Bhā. III. 14. 7; Vā. 66. 54; Vi. I. 15. 124, 140.
2) Bhā. VI.
6. 25; 18. 11; VII. 1. 39; Br. III. 3. 56; M. 6. 1-8; Vā. 67. 49.
3) Bhā.
IX. 24. 37.
4) Ib. VI. 18. 10.
5) Ib. VII. 2. 61.
5a) Vā. 67. 60.
6) Bhā. VI. 18. 23-77; Br. I. 1. 112; ch. 5 (whole); 7. 465; IV. 9. 3;
M. 6. 47; ch. 7 (whole); Vā. 67. 86, 135; Vi. I. 21. 30-41.
7) Bhā.
III. 14 (whole).
8) Ib. VI. 15. 1-10; 16. 35; 17. 2-15.
9) M. 146. 18-55;
171. 29.
10) Ib. 171. 58; 179. 15; 251. 29; 253. 27; 268. 19.
11) Vi
V. 2. 9.
12) Vā. 50. 43.
text.5966:
Dinanātha — a name of the Sun God.
Br. IV. 24. 61.
text.5967:
Dinamiśrā — a Sakti in the Ṣoḍaśapatrābja.
Br. IV. 32. 11.
text.5968:
Dilīpa (I) — a sage who knows the yoga power of
Viṣṇu.
Bhā. II. 7. 44.
text.5969:
Dilīpa (II) — a son of Amśuman and of Yaśodā; father
of Bhagīratha; tried to bring down the Gangā but died with
out success.1 After a long rule, he retired to the forest.2 1) Bhā. IX. 9. 2. M. 12. 44; 15. 19. Vā. 73. 42. 88. 167. Vi. IV. 4.
34-5.
2) Br. III. 10. 92; 56. 29, 32; 63. 166.
text.5970:
Dilīpa (III) — a son of Ṛṣya and father of Pratīpa.
Bhā. IX. 22. 11.
text.5971:
Dilīpa (IV) — (Khaṭvāṅga) the son of Kṛśaśarma;
comes down from heaven and resides here for a muhūrta;
a master of the three worlds by intelligence and honesty.
Br. III. 63. 182.
text.5973:
Dilīpa (VI) — a son of Bhīmasena and father of Pratīpa.
M. 50. 38; Vā. 99. 233; Vi. IV. 20 7-8.
text.5976:
Divam — Heaven; see also Suvarlokam; presiding deity
is Sūrya, who is therefore known as Divaspati; here live
Gandharvas, Rākṣasas, Apsarasas, Yakṣas, Nāgas, and men;
five-fold route to, from Pātālam; equal to earth in measure
ment of rotation or border.
M. 2. 32; 124. 20. Vā. 47. 9; 101. 19.
text.5977:
Divaṃjaya — a son of Udāradhi and Bhadra; husband
of Varāngi and father of Ripu.
Br. II. 36. 101; Vā. 62. 87.
text.5978:
Divavaṣṭā — a Kaśyapa and a Trayārṣeya.
M. 199. 13.
text.5979:
Divaspati (I) — the Indra of the epoch of the 13th
Manu (Ruci); a friend of Yogeśvara.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 31-32; Br. IV. 1. 101; Vā. 100. 105. Vi. III.
2. 39.
text.5980:
Divaspati (II) — Sūrya, Lord of Bhavya.
Br. II. 23. 50; Vā. 101. 22.
text.5983:
Divāka — (Divārka Br. P.) — son of Bhānu and father of
Sahadeva; leader of an army.
Bhā. IX. 12. 10-11.
text.5984:
Divākara (I) — the Sun god, king of the planets;1 is Agni;2
different positions of, in the sky in different lands;3 struck
by Svabhānu, fell on the earth;4 addressed by Kārttikeya to
whom he went as a Brahmana;5 at a distance of 1000×100
yojanas from the earth.6 1) M. 150. 151; 265. 38 and 41. 266. 38. 281. 12. Vā. 28. 32.
2) Ib.
53. 29, 30.
3) Br. II. 21. 37-43.
4) Br. II. 22. 12; III. 3. 110; 8. 76.
5) Ib. III. 70. 4.
6) Vā. 101. 129.
text.5985:
Divākara (II) — a son of Prativyoma (Prativyūha Vā.
P.); his capital Ayodhyā; (Vā. P.).1 Father of Sahadeva.2 1) M. 271. 5; Vā. 99. 282.
2) Vi. IV. 22. 3.
text.5986:
Divākara (III) — divided the earth into ten political
divisions and distributed them among Iksvāku and other
cognates. Sudyumna in woman's disguise did not get any
share; Vasiṣṭha got him Pratiṣṭā and he in turn offered
it to Pururavas.
Vā. 85. 20-23.
text.5987:
Divākīrtyas — a class of Pitṛs propitiated on every New
Moon Day;1 to them Kṛṣṇapakṣa is day and Śuklapakṣa is
night.2 1) Br. II. 28. 23, 93; Vā. 56. 21; 73. 62.
2) Vā. 56. 87.
text.5988:
Divākṛtyas — a class of Gods performing Śrāddha.
Br. III. 10. 110.
text.5989:
Divāvṛta — Mt. a hill of Krauñcadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 67; Vā. 49. 62. Vi. II. 4. 51.
text.5991:
Divinda — Mt. a hill of Krauñcadvīpa.
Vā. 49. 62.
text.5992:
Diviratha (I) — the son of Khanapāna (Anapāna Br. P.
and Vi. P.) and father of Dharmaratha.
Bhā. IX. 23. 6-7; Br. III. 74. 103; Vi. IV. 18. 15; Vā. 99. 101.
text.5993:
Diviratha (II) — the son of Dadhivāhana; his son was
Vidvan Dharmaratha.
M. 48. 92.
text.5994:
Divodāsa (I) — a son of Bhīmaratha and father of
Dyumat.
Bhā. IX. 17. 6.
text.5995:
Divodāsa (II) — son of Mudgala and father of Mitreyu.
Bhā. IX. 21. 34; 22. 1.
text.5997:
Divodāsa (IV) — a son of Vindhyāśva;1 a Mantrakṛt2 and
a Rājaṛṣi;3 excluded from marital alliances with Bhṛgus, etc.4 1) M. 50. 7.
2) Br. II. 32. 106; Vā. 59. 97.
3) M. 145. 100.
4) Ib. 195. 42.
text.5998:
Divodāsa (V) — a name of Bhīmaratha, king of Kāśi;
ruined by Rākṣasa Kṣemaka. Divodāsa established his head
quarters at the city of Gomati on the outskirts of the state;
a Rājaṛṣi, his wife Suyaśā prayed to Gaṇapati in the temple
at the city of Nikumbha for a son and as the God was not
pleased to grant her prayer even after a long time, Divodāsa
had the temple demolished and hence cursed; defeated
and slew the 100 sons of Bhadraśreni except the child
Durdama; through queen Dṛṣadvati he got a son Pratardana.
Vā. 92. 23-64; Vi. IV. 8. 11.
text.5999:
Divodāsa (VI) — the Rājaṛṣi, son of Badhyaśva and
Menaka.
Vā. 99. 201.
text.6000:
Divodāsa (VII) — the son of Haryaśva and father of
Mitrāyu.
Vi. IV. 19. 62, 69.
text.6001:
Divaukasas — a class of deities of the Cākṣuṣa epoch.
M. 9. 24.
text.6002:
Divya (I) — a son of Sātvata.
Bhā. IX. 24. 6; Br. III. 71. 1. Vi. IV. 13. 1.
text.6003:
Divya (II) — a son of Uttama Manu.
Br. II. 36. 39.
text.6004:
Divya (III) — a God of Sutāra group.
Br. IV. 1. 89.
text.6006:
Divyamahorātram — 360 days of human reckoning ac
cording to the sāvana calculation; ahas or day is udagāyanam
and rātri or night is dakṣiṇāyanam; māsam, 30 years of
human calculation; three months and ten days equal to 100
years of human counting; samvatsara = 360 years of human
years; 1000 years = 360000 years.
Vā. 57. 12, 19; 100. 224.
text.6007:
Divyamāna — a Pārāvata God of the Svarociṣa epoch.
Br. II. 36. 14.
text.6008:
Divyamānuṣas — divine men, the ten sons of Vaivasvata
Manu.
M. 11. 41.
text.6010:
Divyā (I) — a daughter of Hiraṇyakaśipu and wife of
Bhṛgu, the first Prajāpati; son Śukra; had also a daughter.
Br. III. 1. 74-6. 88; Vā. 65. 72.
text.6012:
Divyauṣadhi — a son of Uttama Manu.
Br. II. 36. 39.
text.6014:
Diśas (II) — directions as the wives of Bhīma; Ākāśa
tanu of the Lord; svarga as the sun.
Br. II. 10. 82; Vā. 27. 54.
text.6015:
Diśānām devānām — deities of quarters sculptured in the
pillars of the palace.
Vā. 101. 290.
text.6016:
Diṣṭa — a son of Vaivasvata Manu and father of
Nābhāga.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 2; IX. 1. 12; 2. 23; Br. II. 38. 31; III. 60. 3.
Vi. IV. 1. 7.
text.6017:
Dīkṣā (I) — wife of Ugra, (Dīkṣita) son Santāna.
Br. II. 10. 83; Vā. 27. 55.
text.6018:
Dīkṣā (II) — in connection with Lalitā's worship; Śām
bhavī Dīkṣā is the knowledge that comes at once by the
Guru's look, speech or touch; Mānasi Dīkṣā where the disciple
is initiated by the Guru in secret being pleased with his
conduct; first was Kriyā Dīkṣā which consists of purificatory
bath and recital of Devīsūkta and Puruṣasūkta with 16
upacāras; offering of the Puṣpāñjali with sahasrākṣara vidya;
samādhi; the poor and disabled worship with bhāvanadravyas
(i.e.) meditation in mind as if doing all of them; place of
meditation or japasthāna; thinking of Bhaitrarī, then the Śa
Ṣa-Sa group of 42 letters, Pañcākṣara, Caturakṣara, etc.; con
template on Varamūrtis and then Svaraśaktis and Varṇa
śaktis; installation of Cakreśvarī and of Ananga Kusuma
devī in the heart seeing the Mudrā; meditation of Manuja
pam pleases Devī.
Br. IV. 43 (whole) and 44, 1 to 151.
text.6019:
Dīkṣā (III) — as consort of a Brahmana Soma.
Vi. I. 8. 8.
text.6020:
Dīkṣita Brāhmaṇa — with Dikṣā a sthāna of Rudra; son
Santāna.
Vi. 1. 8. 7, 11.
text.6022:
Dīpapratiṣṭākhyavratam — performed by Dharaṇī and
got relieved of the distress caused by Paraśurāma.
Br. III. 47. 61.
text.6024:
Dīpeśvaram — a Tīrtham on the Narmadā (see Vyāsa
Tīrtha).
M. 191. 38.
text.6025:
Dīpta — a son of Uttama Manu.
Vi. III. 1. 15.
text.6026:
Dīptaketu — a son of Dakṣa Sāvarṇi.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 18; Vi. III. 2. 24.
text.6027:
Dīpti (I) — an Amitābha god; one of the twenty
Amitābha gaṇas.
Br. IV. 1. 17; Vā. 100. 16.
text.6028:
Dīpti (II) — the fruit of Prāṇāyāma; equal to the worship
of planets of Sun, Moon, and able to know the past, present
and future.
Vā. 11. 4, 9.
text.6029:
Dīptiketu — a son of the first Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 64.
text.6030:
Dīptimān (I) — one of the seven sages of the eighth
Manvantara.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 15. Vi. III. 2. 17.
text.6031:
Dīptimān (II) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Rohiṇi (Satya
bhāmā M. P.).
Bhā. X. 61. 18; 90. 33; M. 47. 17; Vi. V. 32. 2.
text.6032:
Dīptim (III) — (Ātreya) — a sage of the first epoch of
Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 11.
text.6033:
Dīptimedhā — a God of Sumedhasa group.
Br. II. 36. 59.
text.6034:
Dīptivratam — the gift of a light; leads to Rudraloka.
M. 101. 41.
text.6037:
Dīrghajihva — a commander of Bhaṇḍa to aid Viṣaṅga;
killed by Bhagamālā.
Br. IV. 21. 78; 25. 27. 94.
text.6039:
Dīrghatapa — (Saunahotra and Prakāśiraṭ) — the son of
Kāśa (Rāṣṭra Vi. P.) and the king of Kāśi; see Kāśipa;1 a
Mantrakṛt and of the Angirasa branch.2 Performed penance
for sons on account of which Arjadeva Dhanvantri became
his son; father of Dharma and Dhanvantri.3 1) Br. III. 67. 7. Vi. IV. 8. 7-8.
2) Vā. 59. 102.
3) Ib. 92. 6,
18-19.
text.6040:
Dīrghatama (I) — a son of Raṣṭra and father of Dhan
vantari.
Bhā. IX. 17. 4.
text.6041:
Dīrghatama (II) — a son of Uśija; cursed even in the
womb to lose consciousness by Bṛhaspati; learnt his Dharma
from Saurabheya Vṛṣabha; it was Godharma to do as they
pleased; once embraced in sexual love his brother's wife;
for this he was floated down the Ganges;1 met Vairocana
Bali who engaged him for Kṣetraja sons, five through
Bali's queen and one through her servant-maid. This
was Kākṣīvat.2 Surabhi warded him from the darkness
