clouding him; got the title Gotama;3 with Kākṣīvat he went
to Girivraja and after penance reached heaven;4 a Ṛṣika and
a Mantrakṛṭ.5 1) M. 48. 41-57; Vā. 99. 34-76.
2) Bhā. IX. 23. 5; M. 48.
58-78; Vā. 99. 92.
3) M. 48. 79-84.
4) Ib. 48. 85-86.
5) Br. II.
32. 101, 111; M. 145. 95 and 105.
text.6043:
Dīrghatama (IV) — a son of Utathya and Mamatā; father
of Anga and others. Half-brother of Bharadvāja.
Vi. IV. 18. 13; 19. 16.
text.6044:
Dīrghabāhu (I) — a son of Khaṭvānga (Dilipa) and
father of Raghu.
Bhā. IX. 10. 1; Br. III. 63. 183; Vā. 88. 183; Vi. IV. 4. 83-4.
text.6047:
Dīrghā — a Kalā of Viṣṇu.
Br. IV. 35. 95.
text.6048:
Dundu — the Asura who insulted the sage Udaka and
met with death at the hands of Kuvalayāśva.
Vi. IV. 2. 40.
text.6049:
Dundubhi (I) — the son of Andhaka and father of
Daridyota (Aridyota-Br. P.).
Bhā. IX. 24. 20.
text.6050:
Dundubhi (II) — a son of Dyutimān; a Janapada in
Krauñcadvīpa called after him; Dundubhideśa.
Br. II. 14. 23, 26; Vā. 33. 21, 23. Vi. II. 4. 48.
text.6051:
Dundubhi(svana) (III) — Mt. a hill of Krauñcadvīpa;
also a region, a varṣa of the dvīpam.
Br. II. 14. 26; 19. 69, 73; Vā. 49. 63, 68; Vi. II. 4. 51.
text.6052:
Dundubhi (IV) — Mt. one of the seven hills of Plakṣa
dvīpa where Dundubhi and the Asura Candramṛtyu were
beaten by the Devas.
Br. II. 18. 75; 19. 10; Vi. II. 4. 7; Vā. 47. 72; 49. 9; 96. 145;
M. 122. 13.
text.6053:
Dundubhi (V) — one of the Danu's sons; a Dānava.
Br. III. 6. 4; Vā. 68. 4.
text.6054:
Dundubhi (VI) — a son of Maya and Rambhā.
Br. III. 6. 29; Vā. 68. 28.
text.6055:
Dundubhi (VII) — a musical instrument whose sound
causes death; used in the Tārakāmaya.
M. 177. 26.
text.6056:
Dundubhi (VIII) — Mt. in Śākadvīpa; here the Devas
once beat the drum, the sound of which caused death to
Dundubhi and from thence took this name.
M. 122. 13-14.
text.6057:
Dundubhi (IX) — a son of Sutāra, the Lord of the sacred
Dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 121.
text.6058:
Dundubhi (X) — (Sata Dundubhi?) a son of Jambha.
Vā. 67. 78.
text.6059:
Dundumāra — a name of Kuvalayāśva, (s.v.).
Vi. IV. 2. 40.
text.6060:
Duratikrama — a son of Suhotri, the avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 127.
text.6061:
Duritakṣaya — a son of Mahāvīrya and father of Tray
yāruṇi and others; attained Brahmaṇagati; see Durukṣaya.
Bhā. IX. 21. 19-20.
text.6062:
Durukti — born of Krodha and Himsā; sister and also
wife of Kali.
Bhā. IV. 8. 3-4.
text.6063:
Durukṣaya — see Duritakṣaya. According to Matsya
Purāṇa the name is Urukṣaya.
Vi. IV. 19. 24.
text.6064:
Durgati — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 86.
text.6065:
Durgamā — a R. from the Vindhyas.
M. 114. 28.
text.6066:
Durgas — fortified places unknown under Pṛthu; six
kinds of: Giridurga is the best; described.1 also four kinds of;
three natural and one artificial; contain different outways;
Kumāripuram, villages, towns surrounded by a moat, also
mountains and rivers;2 desert, mountain and water; man
left the tree home for this; last was artificial; made by man
with ramparts, moats and Kumāripuram;3 of the southern
country.4 1) M. 10. 32; 217. 6-87; V. I. 6. 18.
2) Vā. 8. 98, 108 ff.
3) Br.
II. 7. 92, 101 ff.
4) Vā. 45. 128.
text.6067:
Durgā (I) — one of the names of Yogamāya propitiated
by Devakī and others for Kṛṣṇa's safe return from the cave
of Jāmbavān;1 worship of;2 a Śakti;3 worshipped in the
grahabali: Icon of.4 1) Bhā. X. 2. 11; 56. 35.
2) Ib. XI. 27. 29.
3) Br. III. 32. 24,
48 and 59; IV. 19. 81; 39. 57.; 44. 76.
4) M. 93. 16; 260. 55-66.
text.6068:
Durgā (II) — a R. originating from the Vindhya Moun
tains.
Br. II. 16. 33; Vā. 45. 103.
text.6069:
Durgākhya — a commander of Bhaṇḍa; a son of
Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 83; 26. 49.
text.6070:
Durgādhyakṣa — the superintendent of fortresses; his
qualifications.
M. 215. 39.
text.6071:
Durgāla (c) — a territory to the west of the Vindhya
Mountains.
Br. II. 16. 60.
text.6072:
Durjaya — a son of Dana.
Bhā. VI. 6. 31.
text.6073:
Durja(e)ya — a son of Ananta (Ānarta-M. P.); a soldier
of great fortune.
Br. III. 69. 54; M. 43. 49; Vā. 94. 53.
text.6074:
Durdama (I) — (Durmada): a son of Vasudeva and
Rohiṇi and father of Abhibhūta.
Br. III. 71. 165, 171; M. 46. 12; Vā. 96. 163; Vi. IV. 15-22.
text.6075:
Durdama (II) — the son of Dhṛta and father of Pra
cetas.
Br. III. 74. 11. Vā. 99. 11.
text.6076:
Durdama (III) — a king and a son of Rudraśreṇi.
M. 43. 11.
text.6077:
Durdama (IV) — a son of Suhotrī, the avatār of the
Lord.
Vā. 23. 127.
text.6078:
Durdama (V) — the surviving son of Bhadraśreṇi out
of his hundred sons, who were put to sword by Divodāsa.
Vā. 92. 63.
text.6079:
Durdama (VI) — the son of Bhadraśreṇya and father
of Dhanaka.
Vi. IV. 11. 10.
text.6080:
Durdama (VII) — a son of Ghṛta and father of Pracetas.
Vi. IV. 17. 4.
text.6081:
Durdamana — the son of Śatānīka and father of Vahī
nara.
Bhā. IX. 22. 43.
text.6083:
Durdura — a Mountain in Bhāratavarṣa.
Br. II. 16. 20.
text.6084:
Durbhagā (I) — a name of the daughter of Kāla (time);
enjoyed Pūru and blessed him with a boon; offered herself
to Bṛhadratha and on his refusal cursed him to be ever wan
dering. She then approached Bhaya, the Yavana Lord
who adopted her as his sister; helped the Yavanas in over
coming the city of Purañjana;1 allegorically “old age”;2 a
Śakti.3 1) Bhā. IV. 27. 19-30; 28. 1, 3 and 10.
2) Ib. 29. 22.
3) Br. IV.
44. 75.
text.6086:
Durmada (I) — a companion of Purañjana, allegori
cally upastha.
Bhā. IV. 25. 52; 29. 14.
text.6087:
Durmada (II) — a son of Bhadrasenaka (or Bhadra
sena) and father of Dhanaka. (Kanaka-Br. P.).
Bhā. IX. 23. 23; Br. III. 67. 66; 69. 7.
text.6088:
Durmada (III) — (see Durdama) a son of Rohiṇī and
Vasudeva.
Bhā. IX. 24. 46-47.
text.6089:
Durmada (IV) — a son of Vasudeva and Pauravī.
Bhā. IX. 24. 47.
text.6090:
Durmada (V) — an Asura commander of ten akṣau-
hiṇis was sent against Lalitā accompanied by noisy paṭaha;
rode on the camel, succeeded in taking a jewel from the
crown of Sampatkarī-Sarasvati, who being enraged struck
him at the breast; he fell dead and his followers were mas
sacred. The rest fled to the Sūnyaka city in fear.
Br. IV. 22. 19, 28, 47.
text.6091:
Durmada (VI) — a name of Vighneśvara.
Br. IV. 44. 68.
text.6092:
Durmada (VII) — a son of Bhadraśreṇi; (see Dur
dama).
Vā. 94. 7.
text.6093:
Durmada (VIII) — of the Rohiṇi family; see also Dur
dama; a son of Rohiṇi and Ānakadundubhi.
Vā. 96. 169; Vi. 15. 19.
text.6094:
Durmana — the son of Dhṛta and father of Pracetas.
Bhā. IX. 23. 15.
text.6095:
Durmarṣa — fought with Kāmadeva in the Devāsura
war.
Bhā. VIII. 10. 33.
text.6096:
Durmarṣaṇa — a son of Śṛñjaya and Rāṣṭrapāli.
Bhā. IX. 24. 42.
text.6097:
Durmitra — the son of Puṣpamiṣṭa.
Bhā. XII. 1. 34.
text.6098:
Durmukha (I) — a Rākṣasa killed in the Laṅkā war.
Bhā. IX. 10. 18.
text.6099:
Durmukha (II) — a Kādraveya Nāga.
Br. III. 7. 35; M. 6. 41; Vā. 69. 71.
text.6100:
Durmukha (III) — a son of Khaśa and a Rākṣasa.
Br. III. 7. 136; Vā. 69. 167.
text.6102:
Durmukha (V) — a son of Suhotrī, the avatār of the
Lord.
Vā. 23. 127.
text.6103:
Duryodhana — the eldest of the hundred sons of Dhṛta
rāṣṭra and Gāndhāri;1 Subhadrā was intended by Rāma to
be given in marriage to him;2 was met by Kṛtavarman and
taken leave of;3 went from Balabhadra and learnt gadā from
Balarāma at Mithilā;4 mistook the colour of the flooring of
the Pāṇḍava's sabhā (built by Maya) for a sheet of water
and had a nasty fall at which Bhīma and the ladies laughed.
This enraged Duryodhana who was conciliated by
Yudhiṣṭhira who sent clothes to him through Kṛṣṇa.
He did not accept them, but went home downcast;5
kept under influence Vinda and Anuvinda of Avanti;6
banished the Pāṇḍavas and Draupadī to the forest
for defeat in the game of dice;7 resented Sāmba's
action in taking away his daughter Lakṣmaṇā in
svayamvara and wanted to punish him; heard of Rāma's
arrival and extended welcome to him; afraid of Rāma's
prowess agreed to the marriage of his daughter to Sāmba
and gave a rich dowry;8 did not feel happy over the success
of the Rājasūya, where he was in charge of the treasury;9
failed to hit the fish mark in Lakṣmaṇā's svayamvara;10
Jealous of Kṛṣṇa and Draupadī, his mind set on the latter;11
ordered Vidura's banishment for offering good counsel,
and insulted him as the son of a dāsi;12 met the Pāṇḍavas in
war at Kurukṣetra; arranged in vyūha at Syamanta
pañcaka; fought with Bhīmasena who killed him with his
gada; lay in the battlefield with his thigh fractured, along
with eleven Akṣauhiṇis.13 Built a house of lac to get the
Pāṇḍavas consumed by flames.14 1) Bhā. IX. 22. 26; X. 64. [4]; M. 50. 48; Vā. 99. 243; Vi. IV.
20. 39.
2) Bhā. X. 86. 3.
3) Ib. X. 52. (56. V. 12).
4) Ib. X. 57.
26; Br. III. 71. 84; Vā. 96. 83.
5) Bhā. X. 58. 27; 75. 34-39.
6) Ib. X.
58. 30.
7) Ib. X. 64. [4].
8) Ib. X. 68. (whole); Vi. V. 35. 4-5, 11.
9) Bhā. X. 74. 53; 75. 2 and 4.
10) Ib. X. 83. 23.
11) Ib. X. 75. 31-32.
12) Ib. I. 7. 14; III. 1. 14-15.
13) Ib. X. 78 (16 (V) 15, 18-19), 39; 79.
23; 80 [1]; III. 3. 13; M. 103. 3-5.
14) Vi. IV. 13. 70.
text.6104:
Durvasu — a son of Devayāni; cursed by his father for
refusing to part with his youth.1 Viceroy of south-east king
dom;2 line of; father of Vanhi; got merged into Puru's line
ultimately.3 1) Vi. IV. 10. 6, 13.
2) Ib. IV. 10. 31.
3) Ib. IV. 16. 2-6.
text.6105:
Durvārkṣī — (Dūrvākṣī-Br. P.) the queen of Vṛka.
Bhā. IX. 24. 43.
text.6106:
Durvāsa (I) — a son of Atri and an younger brother
of Dattātreya;1 an amśa of Śiva;2 appeared before Ambarīṣa
who was about to break his dvādasi fast; agreed to accept
his hospitality, went to the river for bath and tarried there;
finding the muhūrta for pāraṇa (break-fast) drawing to a
close, the king broke his fast with some water. Coming to
know of this on his return, the sage produced a flaming
spirit to attack him. But Hari's cakra burnt it down and
turned towards the sage, who ran for succour to Brahmā,
Śiva and Viṣṇu. All of them were unable to help; but Hari
advised him to meet Ambarīṣa and apologise to him.3 This
he did and was set at liberty. After partaking the meals with
him, he returned to Brahmaloka;4 blessed Pṛtha with secret
mantras to summon gods.5 Through him Duryodhana
planned to destroy the Pāṇḍavas by inciting him to go to
them and ask for a feast. But Kṛṣṇa protected them on the
occasion.6 In the course of his sojourn he met a Vidyā
dhara maid with a garland given to her by the Devī; took it
from her and presented it to Indra who put it on his elephant,
who in turn threw it on the ground and trampled upon it.
Enraged at this, the sage cursed him to be lost to all fortune.7 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 15; Br. III. 8. 82; Vā. 70. 76.
2) Bhā. IV. 1. 33.
3) Ib. IX. 4. 35-71.
4) Ib. IX. 5. 1-22.
5) Ib. IX. 24. 32; XI. 1. 12.
6) Ib. I. 15. 11.
7) Ib. VIII. 5. 16; Br. IV. 5. 16-20; 9. 31; 40. 120.
text.6108:
Durvāsa (III) — one of the Sages who left for Piṇḍā
raka.
Bhā. XI. 1. 12.
text.6109:
Durvinīta — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 87.
text.6111:
Dullola — a son of Saramā: had four sons.
Br. III. 7. 441.
text.6112:
Duśśaṭha — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 87.
text.6113:
Duśśalā — a daughter of Dhṛtarāṣṭra.
Bhā. IX. 22. 26.
text.6114:
Duśśāsana — a son of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, gave evil advice to
Duryodhana.
Bhā. III. 3. 13; Vi. IV. 20. 39; V. 35. 27.
text.6115:
Duṣkanta — of the Paurava line, adopted as son by
Marutta; father of Sarūpya.
Br. III. 74. 3-5.
text.6116:
Duṣṭaśekhara — an Asura; created by Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 10. 81.
text.6117:
Duṣpūra (Pūraṇa); one of the 16 classes of Piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 377.
text.6118:
Duṣyanta (I) — a son of Raibhya and Upadānavī; a
king; while out for hunting came to Kaṇva's hermitage, saw
the beautiful Śakuntalā, married her by the gāndharvavidhi
and left for his capital the next day. A son Bharata was
born to Śakuntalā and he was brought up by Kaṇva.
Śakuntalā came to his palace with the boy but Duṣyanta had
forgotten her. A voice from the air asked him to accept
them, his wife and son, which he did;1 removed from hell by
the son.2 1) Bhā. I. 12. 20; IX. 20. 7-22 [1-2]; M. 49. 10-11; Br. III. 6. 25;
Vā. 68. 24; 99. 133-6.
2) Vi. IV. 19. 9-10.
text.6119:
Duṣyanta (II) — of Puru's line, was adopted by
Marut(t)a as his son; returned to the line of Yadu, the
eldest son of Yayāti;1 through Yayāti's curse the Turvasu
and the Paurava dynasties became commingled.2 1) Bhā. IX. 23. 17-18; Vā. 99. 3; Vī. IV. 16. 5-6.
2) M. 48. 2-3.
text.6120:
Duḥka — sorrow: born of Vedanā.
Br. II. 9. 35.
text.6121:
Duḥśīla — killed Candragupta, a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 25. 99.
text.6122:
Dūta — a messenger: to report as he has been told and
to be skilled in languages of different countries; one who
can adjust according to time and place;1 of Indra to Tāraka
to get him ready for war after the birth of Kārttikeya;2 of
Pauṇḍraka.3 1) M. 215. 12-4; 254. 24.
2) M. 38. 19; 159. 24.
3) Vi. V. 34. 6.
text.6125:
Dūrva (I) — a plant sacred to Hari;1 from this Dūrvañ
janam, being an auspicious thing to be looked at in the
morning.2 1) Bhā. V. 3. 6.
2) Br. III. 28. 10.
text.6126:
Dūrva (II) — a son of Nṛpañjaya: his son Timi.
Bhā. IX. 22. 42.
text.6127:
Dūṣaṇa (I) — an Asura; was killed by Rāma.
Bhā. IX. 10. 9.
text.6128:
Dūṣaṇa (II) — a son of Viśravas and Vākā.
Br. III. 8. 56. Vā. 70. 50.
text.6129:
Dūṣaṇā — the queen of Bhauvana and mother of Tvaṣṭā.
Bhā. V. 15. 15.
text.6131:
Dṛḍhanemi — a son of Satyadhṛti and father of Supārśva
(Sudharma-M. P.).
Bhā. IX. 21. 27. M. 49. 70. Vi. IV. 19. 49.
text.6134:
Dṛḍharatha (II) — a son of Navaratha; father of Śakuni.
M. 44. 43.
text.6136:
Dṛḍharuci — a son of Hiraṇyaretas of Kuśadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 14.
text.6137:
Dṛḍhavrata — a son of Śikhaṇḍi, the avatār of the 18th
Dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 183.
text.6139:
Dṛḍhasena (I) — (future Bṛhadratha line) ruled for
58 years.
Br. III. 74. 118.
text.6140:
Dṛḍhasena (II) — the son of Suśravas and father of
Subala.
Vi. IV. 23. 7-8.
text.6141:
Dṛḍhahanu — a son of Senajit.
Bhā. IX. 21. 23. Vi. IV. 19. 36.
text.6143:
Dṛḍhāyu (II) — a son of Purūravas and Urvaśi.
M. 24. 33.
text.6144:
Dṛḍhācyuta — a Sage; a son of Agastya and father of Idh
mavāha.
Bhā. IV. 28. 32.
text.6145:
Dṛḍhāsya — a son of Agastya adopted by Pulaha; hence
Pulahas are Āgastyas.
M. 202. 11.
text.6146:
Dṛḍhāśva (I) — a son of Kuvalāśva.
Br. III. 63. 62.
text.6147:
Dṛḍhāśva (II) — a son of Kuvalayāśva (Dhundumāra)
and father of Haryaśva; swallowed the fire from Dhundhu's
mouth.
Bhā. IX. 6. 23-24. M. 12. 32: Vā. 88. 61-2. Vi. IV. 2. 42-3.
text.6148:
Dṛḍheṣudhi — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
Br. II. 36. 49.
text.6149:
Dṛśyāmeghās — a group of nāḍis pouring out dew from
fire (sun).
Br. II. 24. 28.
text.6150:
Dṛṣadaśva — a son of Pṛthu.
Br. III. 63. 27.
text.6151:
Dṛṣadvatī (I) — a R. from the Himālayas in Bhārata
varṣa, Kṛṣṇa crossed her on his way from Dvārakā to Hastinā
pura;1 on her banks is the Naimiṣāraṇya,2 Adhisīma Kṛṣṇa
performed a sacrifice for two years on her banks.3 1) Bhā. V. 19. 18; X. 71. 22; Br. II. 16. 26; III. 13. 69; Vā.
59. 128; 99. 259.
2) Vā. 1. 14.
3) M. 22. 20; 50. 67; 114. 22.
text.6152:
Dṛṣadvatī (II) — a queen of Samhatāśva.
Br. III. 63. 65; Vā. 88. 64.
text.6153:
Dṛṣadvatī (III) — the wife of Haryaśvā, son of Vasu
mata.
Br. III. 63. 75. Vā. 88. 76.
text.6154:
Dṛṣadvatī (IV) — the wife of Viśvāmitra and mother of
Aṣṭaka.
Br. III. 66. 75. Vā. 91. 103.
text.6155:
Dṛṣadvatī (V) — the queen of Divodāsa and mother of
Pratardana.
Br. III. 67. 67; Vā. 92. 64.
text.6156:
Dṛṣadvatī (VI) — one of the five queens of Uśīnara and
mother of Śibi.
Br. III. 74. 18, 20; M. 48. 16, 18; Vā. 99. 19, 21.
text.6157:
Dṛṣṭaketu (I) — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 86.
text.6158:
Dṛṣṭaketu (II) — the son of Sukumāra and father of
Vītihotra.
Vi. IV. 8. 20.
text.6159:
Dṛṣṭadharma — a son of Upamadga.
Vi. IV. 14. 9.
text.6160:
Dṛṣṭahāsa — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 86.
text.6161:
Dṛṣṭidevī — a Śakti in the Angadevyantaram.
Br. IV. 37. 42.
text.6164:
Deva (I) — the name of the 6th Kalpa.
M. 290. 4.
text.6165:
Deva (II) — with fourteen faces; born from the four
faced Brahmā with different colours and sounds; from these
were born 14 Manus.
Vā. 26. 27-30. Vi. I. 5. 33-4.
text.6167:
Deva (IV) — a son of Akrūra and Ugrasenī.
Vā. 96. 112.
text.6170:
Devaṛṣabha — a son of Bhānu and Dharma, and father
of Indrasena.
Bhā. VI. 6. 5.
text.6171:
Devarṣi (Nārada?) — the third avatār of Viṣṇu when
he expounded the Sātvata Tantra.
Bhā. I. 3. 8; XI. 16. 14.
text.6172:
Devaṛṣis — a list of;1 established in the Devaloka.2 1) Vā. 61. 83-85.
2) Br. II. 35. 89-98; Vā. 61. 80, 88.
text.6173:
Devaka (I) — a Bhoja, and son of Āhuka (Āhukāndha
Vā. P.); brother of Ugrasena, hated by Kamsa.1 Devakī was
one of his seven daughters, all of whom were married to
Vasudeva. Father of four sons Devavān and others.2 Gave
rich presents to his daughter Devakī when she was married.3 1) Bhā. I. 14. 27; III. 1. 33; X. 36. 24 [31] and 34; Br. III.
71. 129-30; M. 44. 71-2; Vi. IV. 14. 16-17.
2) Bhā. IX. 24. 21-23;
Vā. 96. 128-9; Vi. IV. 14. 18-19; V. 1. 5.
3) Bhā. X. 1. 32.
text.6174:
Devaka (II) — a son of Yudhiṣṭhira by Pauravī (Yau
dheyī-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 22. 30. Vi. IV. 20. 44.
text.6175:
Devakas — a class of people in Krauñcadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 22.
text.6176:
Devakī (I) — (Devakabhojaputrī Sunāmā) a Bhoja
princess; a daughter of Devaka, one of the wives of Vasu
deva and mother of eight sons of whom Kṛṣṇa was one, all
of them comparable to the eight Vasus;1 oppressed by Kamsa
and relieved by Kṛṣṇa; was about to be murdered by Kamsa
who heard a divine voice that her eighth child would be
the cause of his end; on Vasudeva's assurance to give up
the babies as they were born she was allowed to go. Her
first child Kīrtimat was taken to Kamsa who returned the
baby. She was imprisoned with Vasudeva to watch over
the birth of her sons. During her seventh pregnancy the
Dhāma of Hari in her womb was transferred by Yogamāyā
to that of Rohiṇī and it was said that Devakī aborted. Then
the amśa of Hari entered her womb and she grew beautiful
every day. Brahmā, Śiva and other Gods waited on her
on the eve of Kṛṣṇa's birth and said that her son was to kill
Kamsa: addressed the new-born Kṛṣṇa. In the Svāyam
bhuva epoch she was Pṛśni and Vasudeva was Sutapa. In
another epoch she was Aditi and Vasudeva was Kaśyapa.
Yaśodā's daughter exchanged for Devakī's son and Kamsa
was told of the birth of a girl; was released from prison
along with Vasudeva; forgave and advised Kamsa; was
saluted by Kṛṣṇa and Rāma.2
Yudhiṣṭhira asked Arjuna about her welfare.3 Kṛṣṇa's
respects to, after his return from Indra's abode.4 Devakī
came to Rukmiṇī's palace with Vasudeva and Kṛṣṇa;5 felt
concerned at Kṛṣṇa not returning from the cave of Jāmba
vān and aided by others prayed to Durgā for Kṛṣṇa's
return;6 wondered at the discourses between Nimi
and the sages, sons of Ṛṣabha;7 embraced Yaśodā
at Syamantapañcaka and enquired after her welfare;8
praised Kṛṣṇa and Rāma and desired to see her sons
who had been killed by Kamsa; saw them with joy when
taken back from Sutala by Kṛṣṇa; in her presence they left
for heaven.9 Her grief at the decease of Rāma, Kṛṣṇa and
others; entered fire.10 1) Bhā. I. 1. 12; III. 1. 33; 2. 25; IX. 24. 23, 45, 53; X. 1. 8
and 29; 36. 17; Br. I. 1. 125; M. 44. 73; 46. 13-15; 47. 2; Vā. 1.
148; 96. 163, 172-4; Vi. IV. 14. 18; 15. 18. 26-30.
2) Bhā. X. Chh.
1-4; 44. 50-51; 45. 1-12; Bhā. I. 8. 23. 33; 11. 28; X. 36. 20; 43. 24.
Vi. V. 2. 2; 4. 14; 18. 7-8.
3) Bhā. I. 14. 27.
4) Ib. X. [67 (V) 48].
5) Ib. X. 55. 35.
6) Ib. X. 56. 34-5.
7) Ib. XI. 5. 51.
8) Ib. X. 82. 37.
9) Ib. X. 85. 27-33, 52, 56-70.
10) Ib. XI. 31. 18; Vi. V. 38. 4.
text.6177:
Devakī (II) — a goddess enshrined at Mathurā.
M. 13. 39.
text.6178:
Devakī (III) — the mother of Yaudheya by Yudhiṣṭhira.
M. 50. 56.
text.6179:
Devakulam — Temples where dancing girls were enter
tained in service.
M. 70. 28.
text.6180:
Devakulyā — a daughter of Pūrṇiman and mother of
Prastāva; having washed Viṣṇu's feet became a celestial
river.
Bhā. IV. 1. 14; V. 15. 6.
text.6181:
Devakūṭa — (Davaśaila-Vā. P.). A Mt. to the cast of
Merumūla, full of Garuḍa birds.
Bhā. V. 16. 27; Br. III. 7. 452; Vā. 35. 8; 37. 28; 40. 1; 42,
21; 43. 12.
text.6182:
Devakṛtañjaya — the seventeenth Vyāsa; avatār of
Guhāvāsi.
Vā. 23. 174.
text.6183:
Devakṣa(e)tra — the son of Devarāta and father of
Madhu (Devana-Br. P.).
Bhā. IX. 24. 5; Br. III. 70. 45; M. 44. 43-4; Vā. 95. 44;
Vi. IV. 12. 42.
text.6185:
Devagarbha — a son of Hṛdika and father of Śūra.
Vi. IV. 14. 24-5.
text.6186:
Devagarbhā — a R. of Kuśadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 15.
text.6187:
Devagiri — Mt. a hill in Bhāratavarṣa.
Bhā. V. 19. 16.
text.6189:
Devaguhya — (Devaguhī-Br. P.); the husband of
Sarasvatī and father of Sārvabhauma Hari.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 17.
text.6190:
Devagṛhāṇis (Devālayas) — planets as houses of Gods
and which stand until Pralaya.
Br. II. 24. 2; Vā. 53. 2.
text.6191:
Devaja — the son of Saṃyama.
Bhā. IX. 2. 34.
text.6192:
Devajanī — (Devajananī-Vā. P.) the wife of Maṇivara,
the Yakṣa; gave birth to a number of sons who in their turn
became the fathers and grandfathers of several children.
Br. III. 7. 121, 127; Vā. 69. 153, 158-163.
text.6194:
Devatas — 33 crores;1 30 crores?2 Relations of, with
Sages and Pitṛs.3 1) Vā. 30. 160.
2) Ib. 61. 138.
3) Ib. 62. 21.
text.6195:
Devatājit — the son of Sumati and Vṛddhasenā and
father of Devadyumna.
Bhā. V. 15. 2.
text.6196:
Devatīrtham — founded by Brahmā on the Narmadā.
M. 191. 24; 193. 81.
text.6197:
Devadatta (I) — a chief Nāga of Pātāla.
Bhā. V. 14. 24; 24. 31; VI. 9. 35.
text.6198:
Devadatta (II) — the son of Uruśrava and father of
Agniveśa.
Bhā. IX. 2. 20-21.
text.6199:
Devadatta (III) — the horse of Kalki.
Bhā. XII. 2. 19.
text.6200:
Devadarśa — a pupil of Kabandha; he divided the Sam
hitas into four among his four pupils.
Br. II. 35. 57; Vi. III. 6. 9-10.
text.6201:
Devadāruvanam — a sacred place in Kālasarpī;1 on the
slopes of the Muṇḍapṛṣṭha;2 a Tīrtham sacred to Puṣṭi.3 1) Br. III. 13. 99.
2) Vā. 23. 195; 108. 66.
3) M. 13. 47.
text.6202:
Devadundubhis — musicians in heaven; were overjoyed
at the Devī's starting for war.
Br. III. 63. 53; IV. 20. 100.
text.6205:
Devadyumna — the son of Devatājit and Āsuri; husband
of Dhenumatī and father of Parameṣṭhī.
Bhā. V. 15. 3.
text.6206:
Devadhānī — the city of Indra on the Mānasottara, east
of Meru.
Bhā. V. 21. 7.
text.6207:
Devana (I) — the son of Devakṣatra, a true Kṣatriya;
father of Madhu.
Br. III. 70. 45; Vā. 95. 44.
text.6211:
Devaparvatas — eight in number; general description of.
Vā. 41. 73-80.
text.6212:
Devapaśus — animals intended for temples and other
religious purposes.
M. 227. 27.
text.6213:
Devapāla — a boundary hill of Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 26.
text.6215:
Devapratiṣṭha — rules relating to the consecration of
the Devas; see Pratima.
M. 266. 69.
text.6216:
Devaprastha — a playmate of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 22. 31.
text.6217:
Devapraharaṇas — a group of Gods, sons of the sage
Kṛśāśva. They appear and disappear in each Kalpa and
Manvantara.
M. 6. 6-7; Vā. 66. 79; Vi. I. 15. 137.
text.6218:
Devabāhu (I) — a son of Hṛdīka, and father of Kam
balabarhiṣa.
Bhā. IX. 24. 27; Br. III. 71. 141.
text.6219:
Devabāhu (II) — the second son of Prītī and Pulastya.
Br. II. 11. 27; Vā. 28. 22.
text.6220:
Devabāhu (III) — a Paulastya and a sage of the Rai
vata epoch.
Br. II. 36. 61. M. 9. 19.
text.6221:
Devabhāga (I) — a son of Devamiḍha and Māriṣā;
husband of Kamsā and father of Citraketu and Bṛhadbala.
Bhā. IX. 24. 28, 40.
text.6222:
Devabhāga (II) — a son of Śūra; father of Mahābhāga.
Br. III. 71. 149. 188.
text.6224:
Devabhāga (IV) — a brother of Vasudeva.
Vā. 96. 147. Vi. IV. 14. 30.
text.6225:
Devabhuja — the milkman who milked the cow-earth in
the epoch of Uttama Manu.
Vā. 63. 15.
text.6226:
Devabhūti — the son of Bhāgavata the last of the Śun
gas; killed by his amātya Vasudeva.
Bhā. XII. 1. 18-20. Vi. IV. 24. 36-7, 39.
text.6227:
Devabhūmi (I) — a Śuṅga ruler and son of Bhāgavata,
ruled for 10 years; killed by his minister Vasudeva who
became king. (Kṣemabhūmi-Vā. P.).
Br. III. 74. 155. Vā. 99. 344.
text.6228:
Devabhūmi (II) — the son of Samābhāga, ruled for ten
years.
M. 272. 31.
text.6231:
Devamātaras — the sixty daughters of Dakṣa collectively
known as.
M. 5. 15; Vā. 65. 29.
text.6232:
Devamātā — the goddess enshrined at Sarasvatī.
M. 13. 44.
text.6234:
Devamārga — a son of Sūra and Bhojā.
M. 46. 2.
text.6235:
Devamitra (I) — a pupil of Maṇḍūkeya; taught the
Samhitā to Saubhari and other disciples.
Bhā. XII. 6. 56.
text.6237:
Devamīḍha (I) — son of Kṛtaratha and father of
Vibudha.
Vi. IV. 5. 27.
text.6238:
Devamīḍha (II) — the son of Kṛtiratha and father of
Vistṛta (Vibudha-Br. P.).
Bhā. IX. 13. 16; Br. III. 64. 12; Vā. 89. 12.
text.6239:
Devamīḍha (III) — alias Śūra (father of Śūra-Bhā. P.)
the son of Hṛdīka, husband of Mārīṣā who gave birth to ten
good sons, Vasudeva and others; had five daughters Pṛthā
and others; gave Pṛthā in adoption to Kuntī, his friend who
had no children.
Bhā. IX. 24. 27-31.
text.6240:
Devamīḍhuṣa (I) — Śūra; a son of Mādrī and Vṛṣṇi;1 a
Rājaṛṣi.2 1) Br. III. 71. 145; M. 45. 2.
2) Vā. 1. 147.
text.6241:
Devamīḍhuṣa (II) — the son of Śūra and Māṣī.
Vā. 96. 143.
text.6242:
Devayātra — a festival being celebrated at Dvārakā
when Arjuna carried off Subhadrā.
Bhā. X. 86. 9.
text.6243:
Devayāna — as opposed to Pitṛyāna; the north road of
the sun, situated to the north of Nāgavīthi and south of
the Saptaṛṣiś; here live Siddhas and they have no rebirths;1
reached through the Pingala passage (on the right side of
the body);2 four roads to and the door of the sun leading to
them;3 Śibi's lavish gifts to attain Devayāna.4 1) Vā. 50. 216; Vi. II. 8. 90-7.
2) Bhā. II. 2. 24 [2]; Br. II. 21.
169.
3) Br. I. 7. 183.
4) M. 42. 19-20.
text.6245:
Devayānī (I) — the daughter of Śukra and Ūrjasvatī
(Yajanī, Jayantī); accompanied Śarmiṣṭhā, the Asura king's
daughter to water-sports; when Śarmiṣṭhā clothed herself
with Devayānī's dress by mistake, Devayānī treated her as
a slave, she being the daughter of a Brahmana Purohita. The
Princess became enraged, stripped her and cast her into a
well and went away; when she was crying helpless there
came Yayāti who was on a hunting expedition. He gave her
his upper cloth to wear and lifted her up. Devayānī request
ed him to be her husband, saying that she had been cursed
by Kaca, Bṛhaspati's son, to marry only a Kṣatriya. Yayāti
agreed and departed. Devayāni reported Śarmiṣṭhā's con
duct to her father Śukra who left the palace in disgust. The
king implored him on his knees, when Śukra agreed to stay
on if Śarmiṣṭhā would be appointed as servant of his
daughter. This was agreed upon, and Śarmiṣṭhā became her
servant. When Devayānī was married to Yayāti, Śukra
presented Śarmiṣṭhā as his daughter's maid. She had two
sons Yadu and Turvasu. Learning of her husband's connec
tion with Śarmiṣṭhā during her own pregnancy, Devayānī
left for her father's house. Yayāti followed her and was
cursed by Śukra to fall a prey to old age. Yayāti appealed
to him to mitigate the curse as his desire for enjoyment with
his daughter was still keen. Then Śukra said that if
anyone would give him his youth and take up old age then he
could regain his youth. His son Pūru agreed and once more
the king enjoyed the company of Devayānī;2 heard the story
of an ewe loved by a ram from Yayāti, and thought it was
an allusion to her; became detached and cast off her body
with her mind on Hari.3
^1 Bhā. V. 1. 34; M. 24. 52-3; Vā. 1. 155; 65. 84; 98. 20; Vi. IV.
10. 4, 20. 2) Bhā. IX. 18. 7-51; M. 25. 7; Chh. 26 to 32.
3) Bhā. IX.
19. (whole); Br. III. 1. 86; 68. 15; Vā. 93. 15-16.
text.6246:
Devayānī (II) — a daughter of Jayantī and a grand
daughter of Indra.
M. 47. 186.
text.6248:
Devayonaya — four; Gandharvās, Ādhyas, Piśācās and
Antās; their relative positions and powers.
Vā. 69. 203.
text.6249:
Devarakṣita — a son of Devaka.
Br. III. 71. 130; M. 44. 72. Vi. IV. 14. 17.
text.6250:
Devarakṣitā — one of the seven daughters of Devaka
and a queen of Vasudeva; mother of nine sons and a
daughter;1 Upāsangadhara was one of her sons.2 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 23 and 32; Br. III. 71. 131, 162, 181; Vā. 96.
130; Vi. IV. 14. 18.
2) M. 46. 16.
text.6251:
Devarakṣitas — the rulers of Kosala, Āndhra, Puṇḍra,
Tāmralipta and Samataṭa (Campa-Vā. P.).
Vā. 99. 385. Vi. IV. 24. 64.
text.6254:
Devarāta (I) — a name of Sunasśepa as he was given
back by the Gods to Viśvāmitra; (s.v.) father of Yājña
valkya; a Kauśika and a sage;1 a Brahmiṣṭha.2 1) Bhā. IX. 16. 30, 32, 36; XII. 6. 64; Br. II. 32. 117; III. 66.
67; Vā. 91. 95; Vi. IV. 7. 37.
2) M. 145. 113; 198. 3.
text.6255:
Devarāta (II) — the son of Karambhi(a); (Karam
bhaka-Br. P., Vā. P.) and father of Devakṣa(e)tra.
Bhā. IX. 24. 5; Br. III. 70. 44; M. 44. 42-3; Vā. 95. 43; Vi. IV.
12. 41-2.
text.6256:
Devarāta (III) — a son of Suketu; a great warrior.1
father of Bṛhadratha. (Bṛhaduktha.2 Br. P.). 1) Vā. 89. 8.
2) Vi. IV. 5. 25. Bhā. IX. 13. 14-15; Br. III. 64. 8.
text.6258:
Devarātas — the kings after Devarāta — Sunasśepa: of
Kauśikagotra.
Br. III. 66. 70; Vā. 91. 98.
text.6259:
Devarātapuram — also Devavrātapuram: town built by
the wood-cutter in honour of his Purohita in the latter's
name.
Br. IV. 7. 34, 37.
text.6261:
Devala (I) — a Siddha, and a son of Dhiṣaṇā and
Kṛśāśva, and identified with Hari;1 came to see Parikṣit
practising prāyopaveśa;2 knew the yoga power of Viṣṇu;3
told Śukra the story of Citraketu;4 cursed Hūhū to be born
a crocodile;5 did not comprehend Hari's māya,6 came to see
Kṛṣṇa at Syamantapañcaka;7 a Brahmavādin;8 exclusion of
marriage alliances with Kaśyapas and Asitas.9 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 20; 15. 12; XI. 16. 28.
2) Ib. I. 19. 10.
3) Ib. II.
7. 45.
4) Ib. VI. 14. 9.
5) Ib. VIII. 4. 3.
6) Ib. IX. 4. 57.
7) Ib. X.
84. 3.
8) M. 145. 107.
9) Ib. 199. 19.
text.6262:
Devala (II) — a son of Pratyūṣa and father of two sons;1
a Vasava.2 1) Br. III. 3. 27; Vā. 66. 26; Vi. I. 15. 117.
2) M. 5. 27; 203. 7.
text.6263:
Devala (III) — a son of Asita and Ekaparṇā;1 a Brahma
vādin and the best among the Śāṇḍilyas.2 1) Br. III. 8. 32; 10. 19; Vā. 70. 27; 72. 17.
2) Br. II. 32. 113;
III. 8. 32; Vā. 59. 103; 70. 28.
text.6264:
Devala (IV) — a son of Vasudeva and Upadevī; (Śiśirā
vatī-Br. P.).
Br. III. 71. 182; M. 46. 17.
text.6265:
Devala (V) — father of Sannati, a queen of Brahmadatta,
the Pāñcāla king.
M. 20. 26.
text.6266:
Devala (VI) — a son of the Śveta avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 205.
text.6267:
Devala (VII) — the son of Pāriyātraka and father of
Vaccāla.
Vi. IV. 4. 106.
text.6268:
Devalas — of Kauśika gotra.
Br. III. 66. 72. Vā. 91. 100.
text.6269:
Devalakas — people living in mleccha regions and ineligi
ble for śrāddhā purposes.
M. 16. 15.
text.6270:
Devalokas — seven in number — Bhū, Bhuva, Sva, Maha,
Jana, Tapa and Satya; sacred to Indrāṇī; residences of
Devaṛṣis.
M. 13. 52; 61. 1-2; Vā. 61. 88.
text.6272:
Devavarṇī(ā) — a daughter of Bṛhaspati (grand
daughter: Vā. P.), one of the wives of Viśravas and mother
of Vaiśravaṇa or Kubera and others.
Br. III. 8. 39-40; Vā. 70. 33.
text.6273:
Devavardhana — a son of Devaka.
Bhā. IX. 24. 22.
text.6274:
Devavarma — a Maurya king, who ruled for seven years.
Br. III. 74. 147; Vā. 99. 334.
text.6275:
Devavarṣa — a territorial division of Śālmalidvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 9.
text.6276:
Devavān (I) — a son of Rudra (putra) sāvarṇi (Ṛthusā
varṇa-Vā. P.) Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 27; Br. IV. 1. 94; Vā. 100. 98; Vi. III. 2. 36.
text.6277:
Devavān (II) — a son of Akrūra and Ugrasenī.
Bhā. IX. 24. 18; Br. III. 71. 113; M. 45. 31; Vi. IV. 14. 10.
text.6278:
Devavān (III) — a son of Devaka.
Bhā. IX. 24. 22; Br. III. 71. 130; M. 44. 72; Vi. IV. 14. 17.
text.6279:
Devavītī — a daughter of Meru and queen of Ketumālā.
Bhā. V. 2. 23.
text.6280:
Devavrata — a name of Bhīṣma (s.v.); knew the yoga
power of Viṣṇu;1 son of Śantanu and Jāhnavī.2 1) Bhā. I. 9. 1; II. 7. 44.
2) M. 50. 45.
text.6281:
Devavrāta — the chief among the Brahmanas who in
appreciation of the wood-cutter's charities renamed him
Dvijavarma and his wife Śīlavatī; for this the wood-cutter
had a town founded in the Brahmana's name, the Purohita
who honoured him with a high status.
Br. IV. 7. 31, 37.
text.6284:
Devaśrava (I) — a son of Devamīḍha and Mārīṣā;
husband of Kamsavatī and father of two sons.
Bhā. IX. 24. 28, 41. Vi. IV. 14. 30.
text.6285:
Devaśrava (II) — a Kauśika and a Sage.
Br. II. 32. 118.
text.6286:
Devaśrava (III) — a son of Śūra and Bhojā.
Br. III. 71. 149; M. 46. 2.
text.6287:
Devaśrava (IV) — the son of Devarāta according to the
learned.
Vā. 96. 185; Br. III. 71. 188.
text.6289:
Devaśreṣṭha — a son of Manu Rudrasāvarṇi (Ṛthusā
varṇa, Vā. P.).
Bhā. VIII. 13. 27; Br. IV. 1. 94; Vā. 100. 98; Vi. III. 2. 36.
text.6290:
Devasarga — is Vaikṛta: different species: Gods, Pitṛs,
Asuras, Gandharvas, Apsarasas, Siddhas, Yakṣas, Rākṣasas,
Caraṇas, Bhūtas, Preta-piśācas, Vidhyādharas, Kinnaras,
etc.1 The sixth sarga.2 1) Bhā. III. 10. 16, 26-8.
2) Vā. 6. 63.
text.6291:
Devasāvarṇi — the thirteenth Manu; father of Citra
sena, and others; Divaspati is Indra. Nirmoka and others
were sages; Yogeśvara is Hari's manifestation.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 30-32.
text.6292:
Devasūnavas — a class of Pitṛs among whom four divi
sions are distinguished; the past, the future, the elder and
the younger.
Vā. 71. 15-16.
text.6293:
Devasenā — a daughter of Indra, married to Kumāra.
Br. IV. 30. 105; M. 159. 8.
text.6294:
Devasenāpati — is Skanda;1 anointed by all the Devas
and their gaṇas;2 as Viṣṇu.3 1) Br. III. 10. 50; 73. 110.
2) Vā. 39. 33; 72. 49.
3) Vi. I. 8. 28.
text.6295:
Devasthānam (I) — heaven, etc. for varṇāśramis; eight
places beginning with Brahmā and ending with Piśāca; here
are aṇimā and seven other aiśvaryas; there are three guṇas
pervading here — Satva, etc.; realised not by eyes, but by
experience.
Vā. 102. 96-8.
text.6296:
Devasthānam (II) — Paiśāca, Rākṣasa, Gāndharva, Kau
bera, Aindra, Saumya, Prājāpatya, and Brāhma; a yogi must
give up all these sthānas to attain the Brahmanhood.
Vā. 12. 39-42; 61. 170; 102. 96-8.
text.6299:
Devahūḥ — the entrance on the north side of the city of
Purañjana,1 allegorically the left ear. 1) Bhā. IV. 25. 51; 29. 12.
text.6300:
Devahūtī (I) — a daughter of Svāyambhuva Manu, and
sister of Priyavrata and Uttānapāda; wife of Kardama and
mother of Kapila;1 heard of Kardama's greatness from
Nārada and fixed her mind on him; accepted by Kardama;
seeing her playing with balls in her mansion Viśvāvasu fell
down in a fit of stupour; married Kardama with gifts from
her parents; devoted herself to her husband's service like
Pārvatī to Śiva; enjoyed his company in an aerial car well
furnished with new cloths and ornaments after her bath in
the Sarasvatisaras, where she was attended by many maids;
roamed in all lovely parks throughout the earth. After a
hundred years of enjoyment Devahūtī gave birth to nine
daughters at a time, when Kardama told her of his depar
ture for yoga; Devahūtī requested means for protection of
herself and the new-born ones; was told that Viṣṇu would
be born in her womb and he would bring comfort to her.
Soon she gave birth to Lord Kapila when Brahmā and other
seers called on Kardama. After they left, Kardama got his
daughters married, and after praising Kapila, and with his
permission he went away for penance. Heard all relating
to the Sāṅkhya śāstra from Kapila and spoke in praise of him.
Following the path prescribed by Kapila she attained nir-
vāṇa. The place where she attained siddhi became known
as Śiddhapada.2 From her, Hari manifested Himself for
imparting dharma and jñāna.3 1) Bhā. II. 7. 3; III. 12. 27, 55-6; 21. 3; 22. 9; VIII. 1. 5.
2) Ib.
VIII. Chh. 22 to 24 (whole); 33. 1-31; IV. I. 1 and 10.
3) Ib. VIII.
1. 5.
text.6302:
Devahotra — the father of Yogeśvara.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 32.
text.6303:
Devahrada — in the Sālagrāma; here Nāgarāṭ takes the
piṇḍa of the deserving and rejects that of the undeserving.
Br. III. 13. 90.
text.6304:
Devākrīḍanakas — playing grounds of the Devas — four;
Caitraratha,^8 Nandana, Vaibhrāja and Saviturvana (garden
of the Sun).
Vā. 36. 10.
text.6305:
Devāgāras — abodes of the Devas; meddling with, was
punished by death.
M. 227. 174.
text.6306:
Devātithi (I) — a son of Krodhana and father of Ṛṣya.
Bhā. IX. 22. 11. Vi. IV. 20. 5.
text.6307:
Devātithi (II) — a son of Akrodhana.
M. 50. 37; Vā. 99. 232.
text.6308:
Devānīka (I) — a Mt. in Kuśadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 15.
text.6309:
Devānīka (II) — a son of Kṣemadhanva and father of
Anīha (Ahīnagu-Br. P., Ahīnaka-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 12. 2; Br. III. 63. 203; M. 12. 53; Vā. 88. 203;
Vi. IV. 4. 106.
text.6310:
Devānīka (III) — a son of (Dharma) Sāvarṇa Manu.
Vā. 100. 84. Vi. III. 2. 32.
text.6311:
Devānuja — a son of Auttama Manu.
Vā. 62. 34.
text.6312:
Devāntaka — a son of Kālanemi.
Br. III. 5. 39; Vā. 67. 80.
text.6313:
Devāpi (I) — a son of Pratīpa and brother of Śantanu;
renounced the home and turned muni; requested by Śantanu
to take up the throne; he spoke impeaching the Vedas. He
took to yoga living in Kalāpagrāma. He was to establish the
Lunar race in the Kṛta Yuga; Purohita of the Devas;1 un
acceptable to the people as he suffered from leprosy.2 A
Rājaṛṣi and a gotrapravartaka of the Treta yuga3 and a
Paurava. 1) Bhā. IX. 22. 12-18; XII. 2. 37; Vā. 99. 234.
2) M. 50. 39-41;
273. 56.
3) Vā. 32. 39.
text.6314:
Devāpi (II) — a Paurava king who continues to live in
Kali in Kalāpagrāma; Kṣatrapraṇetāra in the 24th Catur
yuga. Originator of Kṣatriyas in the Kṛta.1 A son of Pra
tīpa. Even as a child retired to forest. The famine in his
brother Santanu's (s.v) kingdom was said to be due to his
elder brother Devāpi having been passed over for succes
sion. Infected with heretical views through the minister
of Śantanu by means of ascetics in the forest; thus disquali
fied for the throne.2 1) Vā. 99. 437-8; Vi. IV. 24-118.
2) Vi. IV. 20. 9-30.
text.6315:
Devābhra — a Mt. with a Janapada on it; afraid of Hira
ṇyakaśipu's prowess.
M. 163. 88.
text.6316:
Devāmbuja — a son of Uttama Manu.
Br. II. 36. 39.
text.6317:
Devāraṇyam Viśokam — a great forest on the banks of
the Lauhityā lake.
Vā. 47. 11.
text.6318:
Devārha — one of the ten sons of Hṛdīka. Father of
Kambalabarhiṣa.
M. 44. 82-3; Vā. 96. 139; Vi. IV. 14. 24.
text.6320:
Devāvṛdha (I) — a son of Sātvata and father of Babhru;
equal to Gods;1 sonless he performed penance on the banks
of the Parṇāśā (s.v.) which became transformed into a maid,
married him and became mother of Babhru.2 The Vāyu
Purāṇa says that when he made austerities, he touched the
waters of the Savaṛṇā when Sāvitrī appeared as a lady,
received his tejas and brought forth a good son in the ninth
month. This was Babhru.2 Belonged to the Anu line and
was much praised by poets and scholars. 6608 disciples of
his, obtained immortality.3 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 6-10; Vi. IV. 13. 1-3.
2) Br. III. 71. 16-15;
M. 44. 47-59; Vā. 96. 6-15.
2) Br. III. 71. 16-15;
M. 44. 47-59; Vā. 96. 6-15.
3) Vi. IV. 13. 6.
text.6322:
Devālayas — the homes of the nine planets;1 temples
visited by Paraśurāma;2 see also Devagṛhas. 1) Br. II. 23. 95; Vā. 52. 85.
2) Br. III. 24. 41; 27. 11; IV. 38.
57; M. 96. 25; 257. 6.
text.6323:
Devālayakalpana — building of temples, an act of cha
rity.
Br. IV. 7. 33.
text.6324:
De(ai)vāsura Yuddha — consequent on the Asuras not
obtaining Amṛta for all their labours in the Amṛtamathana,
war broke out. It was on the seashore and mainly a hand
to-hand fight; description of; at last Indra invoked Hari, who
appeared on the scene and on him Kālanemi flung his śūla;
with the same weapon Hari flung him down; so also Mālya
van, Māli and Sumāli were put to death. Fight continued
till Nārada stopped it.1 Twelve in number, after which the
whole earth and yajña came over to the Devas.2 Hearing
the Asuras slain by Hari, Diti went to the earth and
performed Madanadvādaśi vratam to get able bodied
sons to kill Indra;3 one, of three hundred years between
Indra and Prahlāda. Indra with the help of Raji, a
son of Āyu vanquished him.4 Asuras under Hrāda
vanquished the Gods after the battle which continued
for a hundred divine years. The gods withdrew
to the north of the milky ocean and prayed to Viṣṇu for suc
cour. The latter deluded the Asuras in Māyāmoha form
and the Asuras were defeated.5 1) Bhā. VIII. 10. (whole); 11. 1-44; Vā. 92. 76.
2) Br. III. 72.
70, 106.
3) M. 7. 2-7.
4) M. 24. 37-8; 70. 26-32.
5) Vi. III. 17. 9-44;
18. 34-36.
text.6326:
Devikā (I) — a R. from the Himālayas;1 in the chariot
of Tripurāri.2 1) Br. II. 16. 25; M. 22. 20; 114. 21; Vā. 45. 96; 109. 17; 112. 30.
2) M. 133. 24.
text.6327:
Devikā (II) — a sacred Tīrtha, where there is a well by
name Vṛṣa;1 on her banks was Vīranagara.2 1) Br. III. 13. 41; Vā. 77. 41.
2) Vi. II. 15. 6.
text.6328:
Devikātaṭa — a Tīrtham sacred to Nandinī.
M. 13. 38.
text.6330:
Devī (I) — the first charioteer; a Śakti.
Br. IV. 6. 17; 20. 91.
text.6333:
Devīvratam — the observance of this vow leads to the
world of Lakṣmī.
M. 101. 59.
text.6334:
Devīsūktam — utterance of, in dīkṣā.
Br. IV. 43. 11.
text.6335:
Devendra — see Indra.
Br. III. 7. 269; IV. 12. 35; M. 146. 20; Vi. I. 8. 26; 9. 16, 139.
text.6336:
Devendras — Gods of prime importance, of secondary
importance; share in sacrifices; they are Gurus, Lords, Kings
and Forefathers; protect the subjects.
Vā. 64. 21-23.
text.6338:
Devodyānāni — Vaibhrāja, Surabhi, Caitraratha, Viśoka,
Sumana and Nandana gardens.
Br. III. 7. 101-2.
text.6339:
Devyālaya — in Siddhikṣetra; here Īśvara performed
austerities standing on one leg.
Vā. 77. 81.
text.6340:
Deśās — regions different from Rāṣṭras and Janapadas.
Br. III. 50. 6.
text.6341:
Deśarakṣita — a provincial or District Governor;
acquainted with the produce of the Deśa and expert in con
trolling officials and keeping accounts.
M. 215. 17.
text.6344:
Deha (I) — human body; as a temple; philosophical
interpretation of.
Br. IV. 43. 53-54 ff.
text.6345:
Deha (II) — one of the twenty Amitābha gaṇas.
Vā. 100. 17.
text.6349:
Daityas — the Asuras from Diti;1 one of the Marut
gaṇas.2 1) Vā. 66. 1.
2) Vā. 46. 35; 67. 129.
text.6351:
Doṣa — a Vasu; husband of Śarvarī and father of Śim
śumāra; a kalā of Viṣṇu.
Bhā. VI. 6. 11-14.
text.6352:
Doṣā — a queen of Puṣpārṇa and mother of Pradoṣa,
Niśitha and Vyuṣṭha.
Bhā. IV. 13. 13-14.
text.6353:
Daurgamantrā — in honour of Durgā.
Br. IV. 38. 5.
text.6354:
Dauvārika — to be worshipped in house-building.
M. 253. 26.
text.6356:
Dauṣyanti — is Bharata (s.v.) noted for his sacrifices
and love of people; Parīkṣit compared to him.
Bhā. I. 12. 20.
text.6358:
Dyuti (I) — a Yāma deva.
Br. II. 13. 92; Vā. 31. 6; 62. 61.
text.6359:
Dyuti (II) — (Vasiṣṭha): a Sage of the 4th Sāvarṇa
epoch;1 of the 12th epoch of Manu.2 1) Br. IV. 1. 91.
2) Vi. III. 2. 35.
text.6360:
Dyuti (III) — one of the 20 Sutapa gaṇas.
Vā. 100. 14.
text.6361:
Dyutimat (I) — a Sage of the ninth Manvantara.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 19; Vi. III. 2. 23.
text.6362:
Dyutimat (II) — a Yakṣa; a son of Puṇyajanī and
Maṇibhadra.
Br. III. 7. 125; Vā. 69. 156.
text.6363:
Dyutimat (III) — a Mt. in Kuśadvīpa; same as Balāhaka.
M. 122. 55; Vi. II. 4. 41.
text.6364:
Dyutimat (IV) — a son of Prāṇa and father of Rājavan.
Vi. I. 10. 5.
text.6365:
Dyutimat (V) — a son of Priyavrata; became king of
Krauñcadvīpa.
Vi. II. 1. 7, 14.
text.6367:
Dyutimān (I) — a son of Prāṇa (Pāṇḍu-Vā. P.) and
Puṇḍarīkā; father of two sons.
Br. II. 11. 40; Vā. 28. 7, 35.
text.6368:
Dyutimān (II) — one of the ten sons of Kardama and
king of Krauñcadvīpa which he divided among his seven
sons Kuśala, Manomaya, Uṣṇa, Pāvana, Andhakāra, Muni,
and Dundubhi; ruled kingdoms after their names.
Br. II. 14. 9, 13, 22-23; Vā. 33. 9.
text.6369:
Dyutimān (III) — Mt. a hill of Kuśadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 55; Vā. 49. 50.
text.6370:
Dyutimān (IV) — a God of the Ābhūtaraya group.
Br. II. 36. 56.
text.6371:
Dyutimān (V) — (Angiras); a Sage of the Rohita epoch.
Br. IV. 1. 63.
text.6372:
Dyutimān (VI) — a God of the Sutārā group (Supāra:
Vā. P.).
Br. IV. 1. 89; Vā. 100. 94.
text.6373:
Dyutimān (VII) — a son of Svāyambhuva Manu.
M. 9. 5; Vā. 31. 18. Br. II. 13. 104.
text.6374:
Dyutimān (VIII) — Mt. a hill in Yamadvīpa.
Vā. 48. 19.
text.6375:
Dyutī — left her consort Vibhāvasu and loved Soma
with eight other Devis.
M. 23. 24.
text.6376:
Dyumat (I) — one of the seven sons of Vasiṣṭha;1 a
friend who accompanied Purañjana when he went to Vibh
rājita.2 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 41.
2) Ib. IV. 25. 47.
text.6377:
Dyumat (II) — a son of Svārociṣa Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 19.
text.6378:
Dyumat (III) — a son of Divodāsa and father of Alarka
and others; (also known as Pratardana, Śatrujit, Vatsa,
Ṛtadhvaja, and Kuvalayāśva).
Bhā. IX. 17. 6.
text.6379:
Dyumat (IV) — the minister of Śālva, hit Pradyumna
with his gada, but killed by the latter.
Bhā. X. 76. 26. 27; 77. 1-3.
text.6380:
Dyumatsena (I) — Dṛḍhasena-Br. P.) the son of Śama,
and father of Sumati.
Bhā. IX. 22. 48.
text.6381:
Dyumatsena (II) — father of Satyavān; losing his eye
sight and consequently his kingdom, took to forest life; got
back his sight due to the grace of the God of death at the
request of Sāvitrī.
M. 208. 14-16; 214. 10.
text.6382:
Dyumatsena (III) — a son of Trinetra; ruled for forty
eight years.
M. 271. 27.
text.6383:
Dyumna (I) — a son of Cākṣusa Manu.
Bhā. IV. 13. 16.
text.6384:
Dyumna (II) — one of the ten branches of the Sukar
māna group of Devas.
Br. IV. 1. 88; Vā. 100. 92.
text.6386:
Dyūtam — gambling; an adharma and of Kali;1 of Bala
deva and Rukmin.2 1) Bhā. I. 17. 38;
2) Vi. V. 28. 12.
text.6387:
Dyotana — one of the twenty Sutapa Gods.
Br. IV. 1. 15; Vā. 100. 15.
text.6388:
Dyau — sky; presented flowers to Pṛthu on his accession.
Bhā. IV. 15. 18.
text.6389:
Draghaṇa — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 85.
text.6391:
Draviḍa (I) — the kingdom of Malayadhvaja Pāṇḍya;
the country in which there is Venkaṭa;1 praise of Hari pre
valent here in Kali;2 conquered by Kalki.3 1) Bhā. IV. 28. 30; VIII. 4. 7; X. 79. 13.
2) Ib. XI. 5. 39.
3) Br. III.
35. 10; 73. 107.
text.6392:
Draviḍa (II) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Jāmbavatī.
Bhā. X. 61. 12.
text.6393:
Draviḍas — people of Dravida; S. India; see Dakṣi
ṇātyās;1 ineligible for śrāddha;2 country of.3 1) Br. II. 31. 82; Vā. 58. 82; 98. 107.
2) M. 16. 16.
3) Ib.
144. 56.
text.6394:
Draviḍā — a daughter of Tṛṇabindu and mother of
Viśravas.
Vā. 86. 16.
text.6396:
Draviṇa (I) — a son of Pṛthu and Arcis; was entrusted
with the northern kingdom by his elder brother.
Bhā. IV. 22. 54; 24. 2.
text.6397:
Draviṇa (II) — Mt. a hill of Kuśadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 15.
text.6399:
Draviṇa (IV) — a son of Dhara, a Vasava.
Br. III. 3. 22; M. 5. 23; 203. 4; Vā. 66. 21.
text.6400:
Draviṇa (V) — a son of Dharma.
Vi. I. 15. 113.
text.6401:
Draviṇas — a class of people in Krauñcadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 22.
text.6402:
Draviṇaka — a son of Vasordhārā and Agni; a Vasu.
Bhā. VI. 6. 13.
text.6403:
Drāviṇa — Mt. in the west that entered the sea for fear
of Indra.
M. 121. 75.
text.6404:
Drāviṇī — a Varṇa Śakti;1 on the third parva of the
Geyacakraratha.2 1) Br. IV. 44. 58;
2) Ib. 19. 65.
text.6405:
Drāviṇīkā — a mudrā; here are Aṣṭa Śaktis commencing
with Kusuma praying to Lalitā.
Br. IV. 36. 73.
text.6406:
Druti — the wife of Nakta and mother of Gaya.
Bhā. V. 15. 6.
text.6407:
Drupada — a son of Pṛṣata and father of Draupadī,
Dhṛṣṭadyumna and others; king of the Pāñcālas;1 stationed
by Jarāsandha at the northern gate of Mathurā;2 stationed
at the southern gate during the siege of Gomanta;3 had been
bound by the young Pāṇḍavas;4 in the svayamvara he held,
Arjuna hit the mark in the form of a fish and won Drau
padī;5 joined the Pāṇḍavas in the Kurukṣetra battle;6 went
to Syamantapañcaka for solar eclipse.7 1) Bhā. IX. 22. 2; X. 52. 11 [8]. Vā. 99. 210; Vi. IV. 19. 73.
2) Bhā. X. 50. 11 [7].
3) Ib. X. 52. 11 [8].
4) Ib. X. [56 (V) 2].
5) Ib. I. 15. 7.
6) Ib. X. 78 [(95 V) 10].
7) Ib. X. 82. 25.
text.6408:
Druma — the king of the Kimpuruṣas and Kinnaras
(s.v.) stationed on the west during the siege of Gomanta;1
stationed by Jarāsandha at the western gate of Mathurā;2
attended the conference at Kuṇḍīna summoned by Śālva.3 1) Bhā. X. 52. 11 [11]. Vā. 41. 30.
2) Ib. X. 50 11 [5].
3) Ib.
X. 76. 2 [9-10].
text.6409:
Drumila — a Gandharva and a son of Ṛṣabha and a sage
who was a Bhāgavata; in the guise of Ugrasena became the
father of Kamsa;1 discoursed to Nimi on the avatārs of Hari
with different purposes.2 1) Bhā. V. 4. 11; XI. 2. 21; X. 36. 24 [10-26].
2) Ib. XI. 4.
(whole).
text.6411:
Druhyu — a son of Yayāti and Sarmiṣṭhā and father of
Babhru and Satu;1 after being refused by Yadu and Turvasu
approached by Yayāti; he also declined to part with his
youth to his father and was therefore cursed to have no
pleasures in life and to be wandering about the countries
and oceans with no settled kingdom;2 became over-lord of
the south-eastern (west Br. P., Vā. P. and Vi. P.) part of the
kingdom;3 from him begins the Bhoja line.4 1) Bhā. IX. 18, 33 and 41; 23. 14; Br. I. 1. 133; Vā. 1. 156; 93. 17;
99. 7; Vi. IV. 17. 1.
2) M. 24. 54; 32. 10; 23. 16-20; Vā. 45. 50; Vi.
IV. 10. 6, 13.
3) M. 34. 30; Vā. 45. 90; Vi. 10. 31.
4) M. 48. 6.
text.6412:
Droṇa (I) — married Kṛpī, and was the father of
Aśvatthāma.1 Taught Dhanurveda to the Pāṇḍavas but
served Duryodhana's army, succeeding Bhīṣma as com
mander, and after a five days' battle was killed by Dhṛṣṭad
yumna;2 met by Kṛtavarman, Kṛṣṇa and Rāma.3 Informed
by Uddhava of Rāma's visit to Hastināpura; invited for the
Rājasuya of Yudhiṣṭhira.4 Went to Syamantapañcaka for
solar eclipse and met there Kṛṣṇa and the Vṛṣṇis.5 Ācārya
of the Pāṇḍavas and the Kurus.6 Baladeva's respect for.7 1) Bhā. I. 7. 27; IX. 21. 36. Vi. IV. 19. 68; V. 35. 5, 27.
2) Bhā.
I. 15. 15-16; X. 78 [(95 (V) 16], 29-36.
3) Ib. X. 52. [56 (V) 4], 12;
57. 2.
4) Ib. X. 68. 17 and 28; 74. 10.
5) Ib. X. 82. 24; 84. 57, 69 [1].
6) M. 103. 5.
7) Vi. V. 35. 36; 38. 16, 47, 64.
text.6413:
Droṇa (II) — Mt. in Bhāratavarṣa, touching the sea;1
entered the waters for fear of Indra.2 1) Bhā. V. 19. 16; Br. II. 18. 76.
2) M. 121. 73.
text.6414:
Droṇa (III) — a Vasu born as Nanda; his wife was
Abhimatī, and sons were Harṣa, Śoka, Bhaya and others.
Bhā. VI. 6. 11; X. 8. 48-50.
text.6415:
Droṇa (IV) — Mt. a hill of Śālmalidvīpa (Kuśadvīpa
M. P.) noted for great medicinal plants, viśalyakaraṇī and
mṛtasanjīvini, capable of bringing back the dead to life.
Br. II. 19. 38-39; Vā. 49. 35; Vi. II. 4. 26; M. 122. 56.
text.6416:
Droṇa (V) — one of the seven Pralaya clouds.
M. 2. 8.
text.6418:
Droṇi (I) — (also Drauṇi) the future Veda Vyāsa in
Dvāpara yuga.
Br. II. 35. 125; Vi. III. 3. 21; Vā. 61. 104.
text.6419:
Droṇi (II) — a Sage of the 8th epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 17.
text.6420:
Drauṇāyana — an Ārṣeya pravara of Bhārgavas.
M. 195. 41.
text.6422:
Draupadī — the daughter of Yajñasena-Draupada, queen
of the Pāṇḍavas and mother of five sons born to five
brothers: Prativindhya to Yudhiṣṭhira, Śrutasena to Bhīma,
Śrutakīrti to Arjuna, Śrutānīka to Nakula and Śrutakarma
to Sahadeva;1 paid respects to Kṛṣṇa; being newly married
was bashful;2 consoled by Kṛṣṇa and Satyabhāmā when
banished to forest with her husbands;3 joy at Kṛṣṇa's visit
to Indraprastha; welcomed Rukmiṇī and the other wives of
Kṛṣṇa; served food, etc., in the Rājasūya; performed Avabhṛta
with Yudhiṣṭhira after the Rājasūya; Duryodhana's mind on;
laughed at Duryodhana's fall in the Sabhā of Maya;4 asked
Kṛṣṇa's wives about their marriage when all met at Syaman
tapañcaka and was lost in wonder.5 Her sons were killed
while asleep by Aśvatthāma; when the murderer was brought
before her, she ordered his release as he was a Brahmana
and the son of the preceptor; followed the funeral party to
the Ganges for the cremation of her dead sons;6 was one
among the party that welcomed Vidura;7 out of devotion to
Vāsudeva attained His lotus feet.8 Felt sorry for the loss of
Duryodhana and others.9 1) Bhā. IX. 22. 2, 28; M. 50. 51; Vā. 99. 246; Vi. IV. 20. 41-2;
2) Bhā. X. 58. 5.
3) Ib. X. 64. 10.
4) Ib. X. 71. 41-3; 75 (whole).
5) Ib.
X. 83. 6-7; 84. 1;
6) Ib. I. 7. 14 to the end; 8. 1 and 3, 17; 10. 9;
7) Ib.
I. 13. 4.
8) Ib. I. 15. 50.
9) M. 103. 12; 112. 1; 244. 4.
text.6423:
Dvayam — name and form; a vain Arthavāda.
Bhā. XI. 28. 37.
text.6424:
Dvādaśamūrti — an epithet of the Sun god.
Br. III. 59. 76; IV. 34. 75.
text.6425:
Dvādaśākṣara — Those who meditate on the 12 letters
are not re-born.
Vi. I. 6. 40; 12. 97.
text.6426:
Dvādaśi Vijaya — the day of the birth of Vāmana — Hari.
Bhā. VIII. 18. 6.
text.6427:
Dvādaśivratam — Ambarīṣa observed this vow for a year
and ended it in the month of Kṛttika by bathing in the
Yamunā.
Bhā. IX. 4. 29-30.
text.6428:
Dvāpara(yuga) — Its nature; worship of Hari by ser
vice;1 form of Hari as worshipped in;2 Parāśara taught
Bhāgavata to his son in this yuga;3 a Vaiśya among the yugas;
a period of wars.4 Here Vyasa incarnates; duration of;5
Yajña the chief thing besides war; a combination of rajas
and tamas;6 in the second Dvāpara Dhanvantari took birth
as a man;7 Dharma's state of anxiety; Śmṛti and Śruti quoted
as authorities; but different opinions advanced. Rise of
the Śākhas, and the Angas.8 1) Bhā. XII. 2. 39; 3. 22-52.
2) Ib. XI. 5. 27-31.
3) Ib. 1. 4.
14; II. 1. 8.
4) Vā. 78. 36-7.
5) M. 53. 9; 142. 17, 23 and 26;
144. 1-5; Vā. 3. 21; 32. 61.
6) Br. II. 7. 21; Vā. 8. 66.
7) Ib. 92. 17.
8) Ib. 58. 3-29.
text.6429:
Dvārakā — (also Dvāravatī and Kuśasthalī). Capital of
Kṛṣṇa, built for him by Revata in the midst of sea 1(1/2) miles
in circumference according to Vāstu rules and well furnish
ed, for fear from Kālayavana;1 sacred to Hari.2 Kṛṣṇa releas
ed Nṛga in;3 Kṛṣṇa carried the spoils of war with the Yava
nas to that place;4 return of Kṛṣṇa and Rāma to, after being
besieged by Jarāsandha at Gomanta.5 Left by Akrūra, when
the city had no rains; hence Kṛṣṇa sent for him;6 Kṛṣṇa and
Sātyakī returned from Hastināpura to;7 here were sent 16000
maidens of Naraka's harem and 64 elephants of the Airāvata
line;8 reached by Kṛṣṇa and Satyabhāmā after the fight for
the pārijātā;9 arrival of Aniruddha's marriage party from
Bhojakaṭa;10 visited by Citralekhā;11 besieged by Pauṇ
ḍraka;12 described when visited by Nārada, as containing
900,000 houses;13 Śamba and others reached Dvārakā after
Yudhiṣṭhira's Rājasūya.14 Blockaded by Śālva, and defended
by Pradyumna and others;15 reached by Kṛṣṇa after the
Kurukṣetra war; city described;16 reached by Kṛṣṇa and
his party after a long stay at Syamantapañcaka;17 Kṛṣṇa per
formed the aśvamedha here;18 visited by sages from Piṇḍā
raka, Kurukṣetra and other places and filled with Brahma
ghoṣa;19 Nārada lived there for a time to worship Kṛṣṇa;20
visited by Brahmā and other gods to invite Kṛṣṇa to go back
to Vaikuṇṭha;21 evil omens in the city; people, advised by
Kṛṣṇa, left for Prabhāsā.22 Dāruka informs Vasudeva and
others of Kṛṣṇa's condition and Rāma's entry to his Dhāma;23
swallowed up by the sea excepting Kṛṣṇa's mansion;24 a
Pitṛ Tīrtham;25 represents the neck of the Vedas.26 Pārijāta
of heaven taken to.27 1) Bhā. I. 8. 10-27; 11. 25; 12. 36; 13. 16; 14. 1-6; X. 50. 49-57;
IX. 3. 28; Br. III. 71. 62-85; M. 4. 18; 246. 89; Vi. IV. 1. 91; 13. 19;
V. 23. 13-15.
2) Bhā. VII. 14. 31.
3) Ib. X. 37. 17-20.
4) Ib. X. 52.
5;
5) Ib. X. 52. 13-14 [1]; [56 (V) 7].
6) Ib. X. 57. 29-34.
7) Ib. X. 58.
28.
8) Ib. X. 59. 36-7.
9) Ib. X. [67 (V) 38-40].
10) Ib. X. 61. 40.
11) Ib.
X. 62. 22. 64 [11]; Vi. V. 32. 28-30.
12) Bhā. X. 66. [1 and 13].
13) Ib.
X. 69. 3-7;
14) Ib. X. 75. 29.
15) Ib. X. 76. 8-14.
16) Ib. X. 80. [8-12];
82. 1.
17) Ib. X. 84. 70.
18) Ib. X. 89. 22. [1]; 90. 1.
19) Ib. X. 28.
1-13.
20) Ib. XI. 2. 1.
21) Ib. XI. 6. 1-4.
22) Ib. XI. 6. 33-35; 30. 1, 5,
10.
23) Ib. XI. 31. 15-17.
24) Ib. XI. 7. 3; 31. 23; XII. 12. 60; Vi. V.
37. 36; 30. 9-10.
25) M. 22. 38.
26) Vā. 96. 60; 104. 76.
27) Vi. V. 31.
10-11.
text.6431:
Dvārapāla — a description of, on the gate-way to Śiva's
abode; tiger's skin as clothing and holding triśūla and
paṭṭiśa;1 eight of them invoked in tank rituals.2 1) Br. III. 32. 12-16.
2) M. 58. 11-12.
text.6433:
Dvāravatī (I) — (Dvārakā s.v.); a great city of Vāsu
deva inhabited by Bhoja, Vṛṣṇi and the Andhakas;1 capital
of Kṛṣṇa;2 and abode of Rukmiṇī. 1) Br. III. 61. 23; Vā. 86. 27; 96. 46.
2) Br. III. 71. 48; M. 13. 38;
69. 9. Vi. V. 33. 10 ff.
text.6435:
Dvikalam — the duration of the New Moon day when
Pitṛs drink Sudhāmṛta.
Vā. 52. 38; 56. 27.
text.6438:
Dvijagrāma — the birth place of Purūravas as a Brah
mana in his previous birth. As a result of Dvādaśīvrata and
prayer to Janārdana he attained a kingdom in the next
birth.
M. 115. 10-12.
text.6439:
Dvijabandhu — (Brahmabandhu); debarred from Trayī;
exempt from capital punishment; subject to punishment of
Vapana, confiscation of property and banishment, but not
corporal punishment.
Bhā. I. 4. 25; 7. 53-57.
text.6440:
Dvijamīḍha — one of the three sons of Hastin and father
of Yavīnara.
V. IV. 19. 29, 48; Vā. 99. 166.
text.6441:
Dvijavarmā — the name given to the wood-cutter by the
Brahmanas for his great charities.
Br. IV. 7. 35.
text.6442:
Dvijā(ti) — the first three castes socalled for following
the common and special dharmas ordained.1 Insult among
themselves and to members of other castes punished;2 also
ruled as kings.3 1) Vā. 59. 21.
2) M. 227. 72.
3) Vi. IV. 24. 68.
text.6443:
Dvita — came to see Kṛṣṇa at Syamantapañcaka.
Bhā. X. 84. 5.
text.6444:
Dvidanta(ka) — a name of Vighneśvara.
Br. IV. 44. 66 and 69.
text.6445:
Dviparārdha — a period of Brahmā's life.
Bhā. XII. 4. 5.
text.6446:
Dvipāda — a name of Vighneśvara.
Br. IV. 44. 68.
text.6447:
Dvimīḍha — a son of Hastin and father of Yavīnara.
Bhā. IX. 21. 21, 27; M. 49. 43; Vā. 99. 166.
text.6449:
Dvimūrdha — an Asura, and a son of Danu; a follower
of Vṛtra; his battle with Indra; took part in the Devāsura
war between Bali and Indra;1 milkman of the Asuras to milk
the cow-earth; assisted in the churning of the ocean.2 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 30; 10. 19; VII. 2. 4; VIII. 10. 20. Vā. 68. 4;
Br. III. 6. 4; Vi. I. 21. 4.
2) M. 6. 17; 10. 21; 249. 67.
text.6450:
Dviyajña — a son of Yajñaśrī and father of Candaśrī.
Vi. IV. 24. 48.
text.6453:
Dvilavam — the New Moon day; two lavas with
Anumati in the evening and with Rāka in the afternoon;
the moon touches the sun for two lavas in one full day and
that period is fit for sacrificial rituals; the samudra of Kuhu
and Sinivāli.
Br. II. 28. 10, 38, 60. Vā. 56. 9, 35, 52, 55 and 57.
text.6454:
Dvivida (I) — an Asura, and a friend of Kamsa;
vanquished by Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. III. 3. 11; X. 2. 1; 36. 35; Br. III. 73. 99; Vā. 98. 100.
text.6455:
Dvivida (II) — a Vānara friend of Naraka; a minister
of Sugrīva and brother of Mainda; wanted to avenge his
friend's death; went about destroying Ānartas and cities
belonging to Kṛṣṇa and met Rāma at the Raivata hill. There
he offended him by grinning, breaking his wine pot and
insulting his fair companions. This resulted in battle in
which after a bold stand Dvivida fell dead.
Bhā. X. 67. 2-26; Br. III. 7. 242. Vi. V. Ch. 36 (whole).
text.6456:
Dvivida (III) — Mt. a hill in Krauñcadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 68.
text.6458:
Dvīpa — Island, as the cause of the Devāsura war;
thousands in number, but seven are distinguished;1 ety.
water on both sides.2 1) Br. III. 72. 71; M. 113. 4-5; 123. 35.
2)M. 123. 35; Vā. 49. 132.
text.6459:
Dvīpas — seven in number; Plakṣa, Śālmalī, Kuśa,
Krauñca, Śāka, Puṣkara and Jambu; description of.
Bhā. IV. 21. 12; VIII. 19. 23; V. 20 (whole); Br. II. 19. 136.
text.6460:
Dvīpina — born of Hari and Pulaha; a Vānarajāti.
Br. III. 7. 176, 319.
text.6462:
Dvaipāyana — (Kṛṣṇadvaipāyana) the name of Vyāsa
in the 28th Dvāpara; also Kṛṣṇa by the sixth amśa; the
avatār of the Lord. Yogātma; the son of Parāśara;1 called
his son Śuka when he renounced the world at an early age;2
invited for the Rājasūya;3 came to Syamantapañcaka to see
Kṛṣṇa and left the place;4 heard the Br. Purāṇa from Jātu
karṇi and narrated it to Sūta;5 the Purohita of Buddha, the
ninth incarnation of Hari.6 1) M. 164. 17; 171. 64; 201. 31; Vā. 60. 11.
2) Bhā. I. 2. 2; 19.
10; II. 1. 8; VI. 8. 19; 14. 9.
3) Bhā. X. 74. 7.
4) Ib. X. 84. 3
and 57.
5) Br. I. 1. 11-14; II. 35. 124; 34. 11; IV. 4. 66.
6) M. 47.
247; 69. 8.
text.6464:
Dvayāmuṣyāyana — (Kaulīnas) — belonging to two castes
like the Brahmanas and Kṣatriyas; a gotra.
M. 49. 33; 196. 52.
text.6465:
Dhanaka (I) — a son of Drumada and father of Kṛta
vīrya and others.
Bhā. IX. 23. 23.
text.6466:
Dhanaka (II) — a Sage of the Tāmasa epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 18.
text.6467:
Dhanaka (III) — a son of Durdama, and father of four
sons.
Vi. IV. 11. 10.
text.6468:
Dhanaṃjaya (I) — a name of Arjuna, son of Indra and
Pṛthā, equal to Śakra in prowess.
Bhā. I. 7. 50; Br. III. 71. 154; M. 46. 9; Vā. 96 153; 99. 245;
Vi. V. 38. 27.
text.6469:
Dhanaṃjaya (II) — a Kādraveya; an eminent Nāga of
Pātāla, presiding over the month, Tapas;1 in Tatvalam;2 used
for horses for Tripurāri's chariot; shaken by Hiraṇyakaśipu3
in the Atalam4 with the Sun in the Śarat.5 1) Bhā. V. 24. 31; XII. 11. 39; Vā. 69. 70; Vi I. 21. 22.
2) Br. II.
20. 18; 23. 14; III. 7. 34.
3) M. 6. 39; 126. 15; 133. 33; 163. 56.
4) Vā.
50. 18.
5) Vā. 52. 14; Vi. II. 10. 11.
text.6470:
Dhanaṃjaya (III) — a Kauśika and a Sage; the 16th
Veda Vyāsa:1 Heard the Br. Purāṇa from Trayyāruṇi and
narrated it to Kṛtamjaya;2 heard the Vāyu Purāṇa from
Trayyāruṇi.3 1) Br. II. 32. 118; M. 145. 113; Vi. III. 3. 15.
2) Br. II. 35.
120; IV. 4. 52.
3) Vā. 103. 63.
text.6472:
Dhanaṃjaya (V) — a son of Viśvāmitra.
Vi. IV. 7. 38.
text.6473:
Dhanada (I) — Kubera (s.v.) son of Viśravā.
Bhā. IX. 2. 32. Vi. III. 2. 11.
text.6475:
Dhanada (III) — a Marut of the III Gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 94.
text.6476:
Dhanadharma — the third king after Nakhavān of
Vidiśa.
Br. III. 74. 181; Vā. 99. 368.
text.6477:
Dhanam — wealth, acquired by industry and labour
stays long; a windfall should be spent righteously.
Br. IV. 7. 21; M. 31. 22.
text.6478:
Dhanādhipa — a name of Kubera.
Br. III. 24. 4.
text.6479:
Dhanādhyakṣa (I) — see Kubera1 (s.v.); the king of
the Yakṣas;2 gaḍā, his weapon; in charge of eight nidhis.3 1) M. 148. 85; 150. 12; 159. 9.
2) Vā. 41. 4.
3) Ib. 41. 10-11.
text.6481:
Dhanāyu — a son of Purūravas and Urvaśī.
M. 24. 33.
text.6482:
Dhaniṣṭhā — the constellation on the Simśumāra1 in the
Dhruva maṇḍala; good for śrāddha offering;2 inauspicious
for house-building.3 1) Bhā. V. 23. 6; Vā. 66. 51; 82. 12.
2) Br. II. 24. 134; III. 18.
11; Vi. III. 14. 16.
3) M. 257. 1.
text.6483:
Dhanu (I) — a son of Sṛnjaya, brother of Vasudeva.
Br. III. 71. 193.
text.6486:
Dhanudurga — one of six kinds of fortresses; others are
Mahīdurga, Naradurga, Vārkṣadurga, Ambudurga and Giri
durga.
M. 217. 6.
text.6487:
Dhanurdaṇḍa — equal in measurement to yuga and
nālika; four hastas.
Vā. 8. 102, 106; 101. 125.
text.6489:
Dhanurmaha — Festival of arms — arranged by Kamsa
to destroy Kṛṣṇa and Rāma.
Vi. V. 15. 8 and 15.
text.6490:
Dhanuryāga — (also Dhanurmakha) A sacrifice of the
bow in honour of Śiva; conducted by Kamsa at Mathurā,
visited by Kṛṣṇa and Rāma; Kamsa's. bow broken and the
guards killed.
Bhā. X. 36. 26-37; 42. 15-20.
text.6491:
Dhanurveda — the science of war; taught by Droṇa to
the Pāṇḍavas;1 Satyadhṛti well versed in;2 learnt by Kṛṣṇa
and Rāma;3 personified,4 knowledge of, essential to a king;
Prācetasas was an expert in;5 variety and detail of.6 1) Vā. 61. 79. 91. 91. Vi. III. 6. 28; IV. 19. 60. Bhā. I. 7.
44; III. 12. 38. M. 4. 47; 50. 9.
2) Bhā. IX. 21. 35; M. 215. 8.
3) Bhā. X. 45. 34; Br. II. 35. 88; 37. 27.
4) Ib. IV. 17. 38-41; M. 220. 2.
5) Vi. I. 14. 6.
6) Ib. V. 21. 21.
text.6493:
Dhanuṣkoṭi — the end of a bow;1 used by Vaiṇyapṛthu
to level the earth by removing mountains and make it
habitable.2 1) Vā. 62. 169.
2) Br. II. 36. 195; M. 10. 31.
text.6494:
Dhanus — a pole from the term dhanurdaṇḍa, 96 angulas
in measurement. Two of them measure one nāli, and 8000
one yojana.
Br. I. 7. 96, 100; IV. 2. 124-6; Vā. 101. 124.
text.6496:
Dhaneśa (II) — an epithet of Kubera.
Vi. V. 30. 61.
text.6497:
Dhaneśvarī — a Goddess of wealth.
Bhā. VI. 19. 26.
text.6498:
Dhantapāpā — a R. rising on the Himālayas.
M. 114. 22.
text.6499:
Dhanyā (I) — the Vaiśya caste of Krauñcadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 53.
text.6500:
Dhanyā (II) — a daughter of Manas; wife of Dhruva;
gave birth to a son Śiṣṭa.
M. 4. 38.
text.6501:
Dhanva (I) — a son of Dīrghatapas.
Br. III. 67. 7.
text.6502:
Dhanva (II) — the place with water at all times, suit
able for fortresses.
Vā. 8. 98.
text.6503:
Dhanva (III) — a country, the people of which met
Kṛṣṇa with presents on his way to Mithilā.
Bhā. X. 86. 20.
text.6504:
Dhanvakārā — a Rudra on the ṣoḍaśa cakra.
Br. IV. 34. 26.
text.6505:
Dhanvatīrūpā — a R. rising on the Ṛṣyavat hill.
M. 114. 24.
text.6506:
Dhanvantari (I) — an avatār of Viṣṇu; a son of Dīrghata
m(p)as, the originator of the Āyurveda, and the father of
Ketuman.1 According to one account he appeared during
the Amṛtamathana, when Hari called Dh. Abja (Aja-Vā. P.).
who wanted to be his son and blessed him to be a teacher
of Āyurveda and be born as the son of Kāśi's king Dīrgha
tapas; was king of Kāśi and cured all diseases.2 1) Bhā. I. 3. 17; II. 7. 21; IX. 17. 4-5; M. 47. 30.
2) Bhā. VIII.
8. 35; M. 251. 1 and 4: Br. III. 67. 7-10: 72. 3: IV. 9. 74-5; 10. 3-5;
20. 52; Vā. 92. 7-22; 97. 3; Vi. I. 9. 98-108; IV. 8. 8-11.
text.6507:
Dhanvi — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
M. 9. 17.
text.6508:
Dhama — a son of Śivadatta.
Br. III. 35. 12.
text.6509:
Dhamanī — the queen of Hrāda and mother of Vātāpi
and Ilvala.
Bhā. VI. 18. 15.
text.6511:
Dhara — one of the eight Vasus; a Vasava; father of
three sons. Dravīṇa, Hutahavya and Raja; (Dravīṇa and
Hutahavyavāha Vā. P.);1 according to M. P. he had two
sons by Kalyāṇi and three by Mandharā.2 1) Br. III. 3. 21-22; Vā. 66. 20, 21.
2) M. 5. 21-14; 203. 3 and 4.
text.6512:
Dharaṇī — Earth as the wife of Dhruva and the mother
of celestials;1 visits Meru and complains to gods of her tri
bulations from the asuras.2 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 12.
2) Vi. V. 1. 12-28; 29. 30.
text.6514:
Dharā (I) — the wife of Vasu Droṇa and born as
Yaśodā.
Bhā. X. 8. 48-50.
text.6515:
Dharā (II) — earth; one of the five elements; resultant
of the five elements. Janapadas, cities, etc., are found here.
Br. II. 20. 2.
text.6516:
Dharā (III) — the neck of the Veda.
Vā. 104. 73.
text.6517:
Dharāvratam — vow in honour of the earth; gift of golden
image of earth above 20 palas in weight leads to Rudraloka.
M. 101. 52.
text.6519:
Dhartā — one of the names in the third Marut gaṇa.
Vā. 67. 126.
text.6520:
Dharma (I) — with one foot in Kali (truth), the others
are austerity, purity and compassion which have dis
appeared;1 dialogue with Earth in the guise of a bull;2 con
fusion of, due to different schools of metaphysics.3 The
force of Dharma in administration;4 Sanātanadharma lost in
Kali.5 Vyavastha done by sages in different periods of
Manus.6 Thirty characteristics of. 1) Bhā. I. 3. 9; 16. 19; 17. 24-5.
2) Ib. I. 16. 20-36; 17. 7-16.
3) Ib. I. 17. 19-20.
4)Br. III. 50. 53-7.
5) M. 9. 28-31; 201. 6-8.
6) Bhā. VII. 11. 8-12.
text.6521:
Dharma (II) — the father of Nara, married Mūrtī.
Bhā. II. 7. 6; XI. 4. 6.
text.6522:
Dharma (III) — a son of Brahmā, born of the right
side of his chest; one of the first five created things for the
propagation of people; the first devata who married the
thirteen daughters of Dakṣa or the Dākṣāyaṇis (ten:
Vā. P.): each of whom had sons; they were Śraddhā,
Lakṣmī, Dhṛti, Tuṣṭi, Puṣṭi, Medhā, Kriyā, Buddhi, Lajjā,
Vasu, Śānti, Siddhi and Kīrti;1 in the Vaivasvata epoch had
for his wives Dākṣāyaṇī and Arundhatī;2 father of Kāma
and Lakṣmī;3 presented Pṛthu with a garland of fame.4 1) Bhā. III. 12. 25; IV. I. 48-50; Br. II. 9. 1, 49-50; IV. 1. 40;
M. 3. 10; 4. 34 and 55; 5. 13; 146. 16; Va. 1. 69; 10. 26; 100. 43;
Vi. I. 7. 24, 28-31; 15. 77, 103. Vā. 63. 41; 66. 2; 76. 3.
2) M.
203. 1-2.
3) Ib. 171. 42.
4) Bhā. IV. 15. 15; VI. 6. 2.
text.6523:
Dharma (IV) — a constellation which goes round
Dhruva keeping him to the right.
Bhā. IV. 9. 21; V. 23. 5; Br. II. 21. 176.
text.6524:
Dharma (V) — married Sūnṛtā and had sons like Satya
sena and others.
Bhā. VIII. 1 25.
text.6525:
Dharma (VI) — The god of righteousness and appointed
father of Yudhiṣṭhira;1 father of Dharmavratā, the future
Śila at Gayā;2 did not comprehend Hari's māya.3 1) Bhā. IX. 22. 27; M. 46. 9; 50. 49; 171. 26; Vā. 96. 153; Vi. IV.
14. 35; 20. 40.
2) Vā. 107. 2. 111. 23.
3) Bhā. IX. 4. 57.
text.6526:
Dharma (VII) — the son of Gāndhāra and father of
Dhṛta (Ghṛta: Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 23. 15; Br. III. 74. 10; M. 48. 8; Vā. 19. 10; Vi.
IV. 17. 4.
text.6527:
Dharma (VIII) — a son of Haihaya, and father of Netra.
Bhā. IX. 23. 22.
text.6528:
Dharma (IX) — a son of Pṛthuśravas and father of
Uśanas.
Bhā. IX. 23. 34.
text.6530:
Dharma (XI) — a Devaṛṣi and the 14th Vedavyāsa;
wife Lakṣmi and daughter Sūnṛtā; married ten daughters
of Dakṣa; father of 12 Sādhyas, 8 Vasavas, 10 Viśvedevas,
of Maruts, of Bhānus, of Muhūrtas and so on. Father of
Yudhiṣṭhira; cursed by Māṇḍavya the sage.
Vā. 10. 26; 63. 41; 66. 2; 76. 3. Br. II. 9. 1, 49-50.
text.6531:
Dharma (XII) — manifold and subtle; to understand
the truth is difficult; hence it is not possible to give a definite
lead in the Vedic laws; hence sages do not attach weight to
dānam and yajñam but to sanātanadharma which leads to
svarga; is knowledge of the Śrauta Smārta dharma and
following of Varṇāśrama for attainment of heaven; Iṣṭaprā
paka dharma introduced by the Ācāryas.1 Consists of ten
things: begging food, non-theft, purity, disinterestedness,
activity, sympathy, non-injury, avoidance of anger, service
of the guru, truthfulness;2 of four pādas;3 course of, in the
four yugas.4 1) Vā. 57. 112-8; 59. 21, 28.
2) Br. II. 7. 178; Vā. 8. 186.
3) Ib. 23. 81-2.
4) Ib. 58. 5.
text.6533:
Dharma (XIV) — one of the ten Sutapa gaṇas.
Vā. 100. 15.
text.6534:
Dharma (XV) — a son of Suvrata, and father of Śuśravas.
Vi. IV. 23. 6.
text.6536:
Dharma (XVII) — a son of Raucya Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 104.
text.6537:
Dharma (XVIII) — a Vasu; wife Manoharā; father of a
number of sons.
Vi. I. 15. 110, 113.
text.6538:
Dharma (XIX) — a son of Haihaya, and father of Dhar
manetra.
Vi. IV. 11. 8.
text.6539:
Dharmaketu — a son of Suketana (Suketu, Br. Vā. and
Vi. P.) and father of Satyaketu.
text.6540:
Dharmacakra — also Sunābha, was set in motion and
the place where its spokes were thrown out was spotted as
the sacred place fit for seers; it fell in the Naimiṣa region.
Br. I. 2. 8; Vā. 1. 183; 2. 8.
text.6542:
Dharmajñā — a daughter of Dakṣa, given to Kaśyapa.
Vā. 66. 55.
text.6543:
Dharmata — the Brāhma form of marriage.
Vā. 76. 3.
text.6544:
Dharmatantra — a son of Haihaya and father of Kīrti.
Vā. 94. 4.
text.6545:
Dharmadṛk — a son of Upamadgu.
Vi. IV. 14. 9.
text.6546:
Dharmadhṛta — a son of Raucya Manu.
Vā. 100. 108.
text.6547:
Dharmadhvaja — (Janaka) a son of Kuśadhvaja and
father of Kṛtadhvaja and Mitadhvaja (Amitadhvaja Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 13. 19; Vi. VI. 6. 7-8.
text.6548:
Dharmanetra (I) — a son of Haihaya and father of
Kunti.
Br. III. 69. 4; M. 43. 9.
text.6549:
Dharmanetra (II) — (Bārhadratha) ruled for 5 years.
Br. III. 74. 117; Vā. 99. 303.
text.6550:
Dharmanetra (III) — the son of Dharma and father of
Kunti.
Vi. IV. 11. 8.
text.6551:
Dharmapatnī — the wife, wedded according to prescribed
rites.
Vā. 107. 14.
text.6552:
Dharmaputra (I) — Manu II Sāvarṇa of the tenth
Paryāya.
Br. IV. 1. 66-72.
text.6553:
Dharmaputra (II) — see under Yudhiṣṭhira. Heard the
Narmadā māhatmya from Mārkaṇḍeya.
M. 112. 3; 186. 4-5.
text.6555:
Dharmaputras — the three gaṇas of the Sādhyas, Vasus
and the Viśvedevas collectively called.
Vā. 64. 3.
text.6556:
Dharmapautra — son of Viśvakarmā, the father of Sil
paśāstra.
Vā. 84. 17.
text.6559:
Dharmamūrti — a king in the Bṛhatkalpa; a friend of
Indra. His wife was Bhānumatī. He had the prowess to
vanquish even the Asuras. Asked as to the reason of his
strength, his Purohita, Vasiṣṭha explained that in the
previous birth he was a goldsmith in the service of a Śaivite
courtesan, Līlāvatī. She performed the gift of Lavanācala
when he helped her in making up the salt mountain in gold
without receiving anything as wages. The present position
was its consequence. Then he made gifts of ten Merus to
Vasiṣṭha.
M. 92. 17-33.
text.6560:
Dharmamūrtidhara — the Bhuta, Sarpa, and Piśāca
gaṇas collectively called as: their daughter Pīvarī.
Vā. 73. 26.
text.6561:
Dharmayāga — finding the Brahmanas avaricious,
Brahmā cursed them to become debtors, watery rivers,
stony hills therein, mud houses and earn their living at the
sacred places of pilgrimage.
Vā. 106. 78-83.
text.6562:
Dharmayuddha — no sin in waging this war.
Bhā. I. 8. 50.
text.6563:
Dharmaratha (I) — a son of Diviratha and father of
Citraratha;1 king and scholar;2 performed yajña at the Viṣṇu
Pada hill with Śukra;3 drank soma with Indra at the Viṣṇu
Pāda.4 1) Bhā. IX. 23. 7. Vi. IV. 18. 16-7.
2) Br. III. 74. 103.
3) M. 48. 92-3.
4) Vā. 99. 101-2.
text.6564:
Dharmaratha (II) — a son of Sagara.
Br. III. 63. 147; Vā. 88. 149.
text.6565:
Dharmarāja (I) — a name of Yudhiṣṭhira.
Bhā. I. 12. 4 ff; Vi. V. 38. 90.
text.6566:
Dharmarāja (II) — Yama with residence in Kuruk
ṣetra;1 son of Sūrya.2 1) Br. II. 29. 65; III. 13. 67; 59. 79; Vā. 108. 5, 106. 44;
111. 38.
2) Vā. 84. 80; Vi. III. 7. 19 and 35.
text.6567:
Dharmarājatīrtham — on the western side of the
Yamunā.
M. 108. 27.
text.6568:
Dharmarājaniveśana — a sacred spot in Kurukṣetra for
performing Śrāddhas.
Vā. 77. 65.
text.6570:
Dharmavarman (II) — a son of Rāmacandra and father
of Vanga.
Vi. IV. 24. 56.
text.6571:
Dharmavijayī — is Sagara, who conquered the whole
earth.
Br. III. 63. 142.
text.6572:
Dharmavṛddha (I) — a son of Akrūra;1 of Śvaphalka.2 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 16.
2) Br. III. 71. 112.
text.6574:
Dharmavratā — a daughter of Dharma and Viśvarūpa,
performed tapas; Marīci noticed her and desired to marry
her; she asked him to request her father Dharma; he went,
and on Dharma agreeing, marriage was celebrated; she lived
happily; after a sojourn in the woods, Marīci returned home
tired and wanted her to massage his legs during his sleep;
while she was so engaged, down came her father-in-law
whom she honoured; finding that she was not doing what
he desired her to do, the husband cursed her to become a
stone, and despite her severe austerities the curse became
true.
Vā. 107. 3-31.
text.6577:
Dharmaśāstrās — a Vidyā; Law books to be learnt by a
Prince;1 known to Sūta;2 learnt by Kṛṣṇa and Rāma;3 refer
to three tanus, Prājāpatyā, Raudrā and Vaiṣṇavī;4 said to be
Purātana or ancient.5 1) M. 53. 6; 215. 24; 220. 2; 225. 2 and 4. Vi. III. 6. 27.
2) Bhā.
I. 1. 6.
3) Ib. X. 45. 34.
4) Br. II. 33. 31; 35. 88; III. 3. 88;
19. 23.
5) Vā. 61. 78; 66. 109; 83. 53.
text.6578:
Dharmasarga — the sons of Dharma and the thirteen
daughters of Dakṣa.
Vā. 10. 38.
text.6579:
Dharmasāvarṇi(ka) — the eleventh Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 24-6; Vi. III. 2. 29-32.
text.6580:
Dharmasuta — the name of Viṣṇu engaged in perform
ing tapas at Gandhamādhana.
M. 61. 21.
text.6581:
Dharmasūtra — a son of Suvrata and father of Śama.
Bhā. IX. 22. 48.
text.6582:
Dharmasetu — a son of Āryaka and Vaidhṛtā; an amśa
of Hari in the epoch of the eleventh Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 26.
text.6586:
Dharmāraṇyam — in Gayā,1 here Dharma performed
sacrifice.2 1) Vā. 83. 23.
2) Ib. 111. 23.
text.6587:
Dharmārthakāma — served by Purūravas:1 expounded
with mokṣa in the Liṅga and Kūrma Purāṇas;2of the Asuras
in Tripuram.3 1) M. 24. 15-21.
2) Ib. 53. 37 and 47; 114. 13; 121. 64-81; Vā.
8. 26, ff.
3) M. 131. 16.
text.6589:
Dharmī (II) — a son of Bṛhadbhāja and father of Kṛtam
jaya.
Vi. IV. 22. 6.
text.6590:
Dharmey(u)a (I) — eighth son of Raudrāśva and the
apsaras, Ghṛtācī.
Bhā. IX. 20. 4; Vā. 99. 125.
text.6592:
Dharmeśvara — near the well in Brahmatīrtham.
Vā. 111. 26.
text.6593:
Dharmeṣu — a son of Raudrāśva.
Vi. IV. 19. 2.
text.6594:
Dharmonārāyaṇa — the Vyāsa of the 13th dvāpara; Vāli
avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 158.
text.6595:
Dhātaki (I) — a son of Vītihotra of Puṣkaradvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 31.
text.6596:
Dhātaki (II) — (Dhātuki-Vi. P.) a son of Savana,
after whom came Dhātakikhaṇḍa.
Br. II. 14. 15-6; Vā. 33. 14-15; Vi. II. 4. 73.
text.6597:
Dhātaki (III) — (Khaṇḍa) a division of Puṣkaradvīpa:
encircles Sumana hill on the southern side;1 named after
Dhātaki, son of Savana.2 1) Br. II. 14. 16; 19. 117-25: M. 123. 5-10, 26. Vā. 49. 113, 121.
2) Ib. 33. 15.
text.6598:
Dhātā (I) — a son of Bhṛgu and Khyātī, wife Niyatī,
(Āyati-Vi. P.) son Mṛkaṇḍu (Prāṇa-Vi. P.).
Br. II. 11. 5. Vā. 28. 1, 4, 5. Vi. I. 8. 15; 10. 2-4.
text.6599:
Dhātā (II) — a devata in the sun, in the spring season.
Vā. 52. 2.
text.6600:
Dhātu — a Marut of the III Gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 94.
text.6601:
Dhātṛ (I) — an Āditya — Icon of1 in the sun's chariot in
the months of Caitra and Madhu.2 1) M. 6. 4; 126. 3; 171. 56; 261. 6; Vā. 66. 66. Vi. I. 15. 130.
2) Vi. II. 10. 4; V. 18. 56.
text.6602:
Dhātṛ (II) — deserted by his wife Tuṣṭi for Soma:
created order in the Universe.
M. 23. 24; 38. 9.
text.6603:
Dhātra — the 10th of the twelve incarnations of Viṣṇu.
M. 47. 45.
text.6605:
Dhātri (II) — a son of Bhṛgu and Khyātī; married
Āyatī, a daughter of Meru.
Bhā. IV. 1. 43-4; Br. II. 13. 37; Vā. 30. 34.
text.6606:
Dhātri (III) — a son of Aditi. Had four wives, each of
whom brought forth a son;1 an Āditya of the Vaivasvata
epoch.2 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 39; 18. 3.
2) Br. III. 3. 67-69.
text.6607:
Dhātri (IV) — a name of Brahmā.
Bhā. X. 1. 50; Br. IV. 44. 88.
text.6608:
Dhātri (V) — the name of the sun in the month of
Caitra.
Bhā. XII. 11. 33.
text.6609:
Dhātrī (I) — wife of Bhava and mother of Uśanas.
Br. II. 10. 77.
text.6611:
Dhātrī (III) — a nurse of the Śūdra caste.
Vā. 88. 162; 96. 41; 99. 70.
text.6612:
Dhānuṣkarūpa — the form of bow with Kings.
Vā. 108. 70.
text.6613:
Dhānya — 18 kinds of corn mentioned for making gifts.
M. 276. 7; 277. 11.
text.6614:
Dhānyakam — one of the eight Saubhāgyams.
M. 60. 8 and 28.
text.6615:
Dhānyaśaila — a king of Merudāna to be given away
as gift.
M. 83. 4 and 12-13; 92. 32.
text.6617:
Dhānvantaramrūpam — the 12th avatār of Hari.
Bhā. I. 3. 17.
text.6618:
Dhāma (I) — came out of the eyes of Atri: her son was
Soma.
M. 23. 6-8. Vā. 62. 41.
text.6620:
Dhāma (III) — a sage of the Tāmasa epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 18.
text.6621:
Dhāmavratam — a vow in honour of Āditya.
M. 101. 79.
text.6623:
Dhāratīrtham — on the northern bank of the Narmadā.
M. 190. 6.
text.6624:
Dhāraṇā — a form of Yoga in which the mind is con
trolled; dhyāna; seeing in himself, the characteristic of
Siddhi; the time and place for doing it; not near fire,
forest, river-bed, burial place, Caitya; the performer should
not be hungry, careworn or be anxious; else the doer becomes
mad, deaf and dumb or blind; hence pure Dhāraṇā is requir
ed; one engaged in this Yoga could take curds and Yava
paste; enables Vāyu to go up and stand in its place; other
branches of; thinking. of the upper worlds, mountains and
oceans in his heart; eating mud from dried beans; 1000 pots
of water for bath;1 the dharma of the Yoga destroys sins;2
800 times in the head;3 Dhāraṇa Agneyī a special form of
samādhi practised by Sati, the daughter of Dakṣa.4 1) Br. I. 2. 42-3; III. 4. 26; 22. 75; Vā. 11. 22-64; Vi. VI. 7. 75-8.
2) Vā. 10. 76, 93.
3) Ib. 12. 17; 19. 41; 104. 24.
4) Ib. 30. 54.
text.6625:
Dhāriṇī — a Pitṛkanyā, a daughter of Svadhā;1 mind
born daughter of Barhiṣadas, became the wife of Meru; son
Mandara, and three daughters, Velā, Niyatī and Āyatī;2 a
Brahmavādinī.3 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 64.
2) Br. II. 13. 30ff; Vā. 30. 28; 33. 4; 62. 192.
3) Vi. I. 10. 19.
text.6626:
Dhārtarāṣṭras — a tribe;1 a dynasty of 100 kings; per
formed Aśvamedha.2 1) M. 273. 72.
2) Vā. 32. 51; 99. 454.
text.6627:
Dhārmikas — ^1 1000 of dvipadas; those who go to heaven.
Vā. 101. 203.
text.6628:
Dhārṣṭakam — the Kṣatram of Dhṛṣṭa; of 3000 Kṣatriyas
with the gaṇas.
Vā. 88. 4-5.
text.6629:
Dhārṣṭas — a race of warriors descended from Dhṛṣṭa;
attained Brahmanhood.
Bhā. IX. 2. 17.
text.6632:
Dhiṣaṇa — an expert in divine music.
Vā. 69. 46.
text.6633:
Dhiṣaṇā (I) — the wife of Kṛśāśva and mother of
Vedaśiras and others.
Bhā. VI. 6. 20.
text.6634:
Dhiṣaṇā (II) — the wife of Havirdhana Agni^1 and the
mother of Prācīnabarhis and five other sons.^2
