Niryantra — (Nirjatara Niryantara-Vā. P.) heard the
Purāṇa from Gautama and told it to Vājaśravas;1 heard the
Vā. P. from Gautama.2 1) Br. IV. 4. 63-4.
2) Vā. 103. 63.
text.7223:
Nirvāk — a blind citizen of the Purañjana city aiding
him in his work; allegorically the hands.
Bhā. IV. 25. 54; 29. 15.
text.7224:
Nirvāṇa — is mokṣa;1 gained by doing the vibhūtīdvā-
daśivrata on the Ganges;2 Prahlāda blessed with Nirvāṇa;3
of Śatānīka;4 Mucukunda's request to Kṛṣṇa for Nirvāṇa.5 1) Bhā. III. 25. 28-29; VI. 4. 28; IX. 7. 27; Br. III. 56. 10.
Vi. I. 20. 28 and 34; II. 8. 119; III. 18. 17; 8. 6.
2) M. 100. 33.
3) Vi. I. 19. 46.
4) Ib. IV. 21. 4.
5) Ib. V. 23. 47; VI. 7. 21. 2.
text.7225:
Nirvāṇaratis — the gods in the epoch of the III Śāvarṇa
Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 73, 75.
text.7226:
Nirvāṇarucis — Gods of the eleventh epoch of Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 25; Vi. III. 2. 30.
text.7227:
Nirvindhyā — a R. from the Vindhyas;1 in the Ṛkṣa Mt.
in Bhāratavarṣa;2 visited by Balarāma.3 1) M. 114. 27. Vā. 45. 102.
2) Bhā. IV. 1. 18; V. 19. 18; Br. II.
16. 32; Vi. II. 3. 11.
3) Bhā. X. 79. 20.
text.7228:
Nirvṛti (I) — the son of Dhṛṣṭā(i) (Vṛṣṇi-Br. P.) the
righteous, and father of Daśārha.
Bhā. IX. 24. 3; Br. III. 70. 40.
text.7229:
Nirvṛti (II) — the son of Sunetra, ruled for 58 years.
M. 271. 26.
text.7230:
Nirvṛti — a son of Dhṛṣṭa and father of Vidūratha.
M. 44. 39-40.
text.7232:
Nilāyanakrīḍā — a game of the Gopas in which the Gopas
put on the guise of thieves, watchmen, and goats; Vyoma
an Asura entered it in disguise and carried away almost all
the Gopas to a cave near by; seeing only few left, Kṛṣṇa
discovered the Asura and killed him at once.
Bhā. X. 37. 26-32.
text.7233:
Nivartanam — 30 daṇḍas by a daṇḍa of 7 hastas.
M. 283. 3, 14.
text.7234:
Nivāta — a son of Śūra.
Br. III. 71. 138; Vā. 96. 136.
text.7235:
Nivātakavacas — the sons of Samhlāda; could not be
slain by the Gods, Gandharvas, Nāgas and Rākṣasas;1
Flourished in the age of Prahlāda;2 A Dānava group of
Rasātala, resident in Hiraṇyapura;3 took part in the Devā
sura war between Bali and Indra: fought with the Maruts;4
defeated by Arjuna.5 1) M. 6. 28-9.
2) Vi. I. 21. 14.
3) Bhā. V. 24. 30; X. 89. 34 (5)
4) Ib. VIII. 10. 22, 34.
5) Ib. X. 89. 34. (5); Br. III. 5. 37.
text.7236:
Nivṛtti (I) — a R. in Śālmalidvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 47; Vā. 49. 42; Vi. II. 4. 28.
text.7239:
Niśaṭa — a son of Vasudeva and Rohiṇī.
Vā. 96. 162.
text.7240:
Niśaṭha(ta) — a son of Balarāma.
Br. III. 71. 166; Vi. V. 25. 19.
text.7241:
Niśā (I) — same as Sītā; a R. of the Kuśadvīpa.
M. 122. 71.
text.7243:
Niśākara — is Soma;1 full of ambrosia, the origin of
Tithi, Parvasandhi, and Ṛg and Yajur metres;2 1000 Yojanas
beyond the sun.3 1) Br. II. 28. 43.
2) Vā. 31. 40.
3) Ib. 101. 129.
text.7245:
Niśitha — a son of Doṣa and Puṣparṇā;1 stationed to
defend the E. gate of Mathurā;2 fought with his kinsmen at
Prabhāsa.3 1) Bhā. IV. 13. 14.
2) Ib. X. 50. 20 [2];.
3) Ib. XI. 30. 17.
text.7247:
Niśumbha — the son of Gaveṣṭhi;1 took part in the
Devāsura war between Bali and Indra;2 fought with Bhadra
kāli and was killed;3 killed by Yoganidrā.4 1) Vā. 67. 77.
2) Bhā. VIII. 10. 21, 31.
3) Br. IV. 29. 76.
4) Vi. V. 1. 82.
text.7248:
Niścara (Paulastya) — a sage of the epoch of the
III Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 79.
text.7249:
Niścala — a son of Atri, and one of the seven sages of
the Svārociṣa epoch.
Br. II. 36. 18.
text.7250:
Niścīrā — a R. of the Bhāratavarṣa.
Vā. 45. 96.
text.7251:
Niśravyavana — a sage of the Svārociṣa epoch.
M. 9. 8.
text.7252:
Niṣadavān — seventh note of the gamut;1 origin in
Niṣāda kalpa.2 1) Vā. 86. 37.
2) Ib. 21. 46.
text.7253:
Niṣadha (I) — a son of Atithi and father of Nabha.
(Anala-Vi. P.). The Br. P. makes him father of Nala.2
^1 Bhā. IX. 12. 1; M. 12. 52; Vā. 88. 201; Vi. IV. 4. 105. 2) Br. III. 63. 201-2.
text.7254:
Niṣadha (II) — a varṣaparvata;1 a mountain range on
the base of Meru and to the south of Ilāvṛta and a boundary
of Harivarṣa;2 migration of the Yadus to;3 residence of the
Vānaras and Nāgas;4 location of the Viṣṇu temple in.5 1) Br. I. 1. 69; M. 113. 12, 22; 121. 66; 183. 1; Vā. 1. 85. Vi. II.
2. 28 and 39.
2) Bhā. V. 16. 9, 26; Vā. 34. 14 and 25.
3) Bhā. 2. 3;
Br. II. 15. 15 and 28.
4) Ib. II. 17. 34; III. 7. 194; IV. 31. 16.
5) Vā. 35. 8; 36. 19; 37. 28; 41. 48.
text.7255:
Niṣadhas (I) — (also Naiṣadhas) contemporary rulers
of the Āndhras, Kauśalas, and Vidūrapatis.
Bhā. XII. 1. 35.
text.7256:
Niṣadhas (II) — a Janapada of the Maṇidhānya.1 On
the other side of the Vindhyas.2 1) Vā. 99. 384.
2) Ib. 45. 133.
text.7258:
Niṣadhā — a R. from the Vindhyas.
Br. II. 16. 32; Vā. 45. 102.
text.7259:
Niṣadhādhipati — an ally of Kārtavīrya, killed by Para
śurāma.
Br. III. 39. 2, 8.
text.7260:
Niṣadhāśva — a son of Kuru.
Bhā. IX. 22. 4.
text.7261:
Niṣāda (I) — the black and dwarfish man who came out
of the churning of the thigh of the dead Vena by the sages;
the ancestor of the Naiṣadas, the Vindhyan tribe.
Bhā. IV. 14. 45-46; Vi. I. 13. 35-6.
text.7262:
Niṣāda (II) — a son of Vasudeva; the first bowman;1
hunter.2 1) Vā. 96. 184, 187.
2) Ib. 47. 51.
text.7263:
Niṣāda (III) — 20th kalpa; Prajāpati Niṣāda performed
austerities controlling the senses for a thousand divine years;
seeing the son getting wearied by penance Brahmā said:
“refrain from it,” hence the name, Niṣāda. Out of him
came Niṣādavānsvara.
Vā. 21. 43.
text.7264:
Niṣādhavaṃśakarta — the dwarfed black male arising
out of the churning by the sages of the left hand of Vena;
the residuals of the Vindhyas belonged to this;1 born of him
were Dhīvara and others.2 1) Br. II. 36. 144-6.
2) Vā. 62. 123.
text.7265:
Niṣka — a gold coin for gifts;1 sin, a fine for wounding
or hurting;2 necklace?3 Bala staked 1000 at the first game
of gambling, another 1000 at the second and one crore at
the succeeding one.4 1) M. 77. 11; Vā. 80. 16.
2) M. 227. 86; Vā. 101. 160.
3) Bhā.
III. 23. 31.
4) Vi. V. 28. 13-14, 18.
text.7266:
Niṣkuṭa — groves as frequented by Piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 404.
text.7267:
Niṣkulāda — an asura who has his city in Tatvalam.
Br. II. 20. 17.
text.7268:
Niṣkulādapuram — the city in the first tala; of an Asura
chief.
Vā. 50. 16.
text.7269:
Niṣkriya — a class of ascetics.
Bhā. III. 12. 43.
text.7270:
Niṣṭakarman — a king who ruled for 25 years.
Br. III. 74. 164.
text.7271:
Niṣṭīvī — a R. from the Himālayas.
Br. II. 16. 26.
text.7272:
Niṣṭhā — in the Pāṇigrahaṇa mantra in the seventh
Pāda; known to Satyavrata.
Vā. 88. 97.
text.7273:
Niṣṭhura — a mantrakāra and an Ātreya.
Vā. 59. 104.
text.7274:
Niṣpāpā — a R. of the Plakṣadvīpa.
Vā. 49. 17.
text.7275:
Niṣpāva — one of the eight saubhāgyams.
M. 60. 8, 27.
text.7276:
Niṣprakam(p)ya — (Ātreya) a sage of the Raucya
epoch (XIII epoch Vi. P.).
Br. IV. 1. 103; Vi. III. 2. 40.
text.7277:
Nisunda — a son of Hrāda; had two sons Sunda and Upa
sunda.
Br. III. 5. 34; Vā. 67. 71.
text.7278:
Niśśeṣa Kalpa — of Brahmā; the period twice the thou
sand of 1000 yugas and all antaras.
Vā. 100. 212.
text.7279:
Nisvara — a sage of the XI epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 31.
text.7280:
Nīti — the policy taught by Śukra to the Asuras and
sought by him from Maheśvara;1 according to Bṛhaspati, it
commences with sāma for a conquering monarch; other
angas are bheda, dāna, and daṇḍa; but the application
depends on the place, time and resources of the enemy; in
the case of Asuras only daṇḍa can be recommended.2 1) M. 47. 74, 75; Vā. 97. 105.
2) M. 148. 65-71.
text.7282:
Nītiśāstram — of Śukra;1 Prahlāda trained in.2 1) Br. III. 7. 191; 72. 107.
2) Vi. I. 19. 26-28, 34-49.
text.7283:
Nīdāgha — son of Pulastya; initiated into jñāna by
Ṛbhu. Engaged himself in austerities for a thousand years
in a grove in Vīranagara on the banks of the Devikā. After
this period at the time of taking meals, Ṛbhu appeared
before him, but was not recognised. Being requested for
meals, Ṛbhu agreed on condition that he would be served
with sweet viands. After meals, he found that he was his old
master, and was overjoyed. He went away, and Nīdāgha
continued his austerities for another 1000 years. At the end
of this period Ṛbhu appeared and saw him standing aloof
from a crowd witnessing the king riding on his elephant.
Ṛbhu asked him who was the king and who was the elephant.
Nidāgha said that the man above was king and that below the
elephant. Ṛbhu asked him what he meant by above and
below. Little knowing that he was his master, Nīdāgha
jumped on him and remarked he was above and Ṛbhu below.
Finding that Nīdāgha had not attained full maturity in
advaita, Ṛbhu once again initiated him and departed. From
that day Nīdāgha looked upon anything without any distinc
tion.
Vi. II. chh. 15 and 16.
text.7284:
Nīpa (I) — a son of Pāra (Paura-M. P.) wife Kṛtvī;
father of 100 sons, Nīpās; Aṇuhasatyaka? was the eldest;
among the others were Srīmān who was well known and was
destroyed by Ugrasena (Ugrāyudha-Vā. P.) for the sake of
Janamejaya; Brahmadatta was another son.
Bhā. IX. 21. 24-25; M. 49. 52, 59; Vā. 99. 174-5.
text.7285:
Nīpa (II) — the son of Kṛtin and father of Ugrāyudha.
Bhā. IX. 21. 29.
text.7286:
Nīpas — 100 sons of Nīpa, among whom Srīmān was the
most celebrated; destroyed by Ugrāyudha for the sake of
Janamejaya;1 a tribe.2 1) M. 49. 53, 59; Vi. IV. 19. 54.
2) M. 273. 73.
text.7288:
Nīramitra — a son of Nakuli by Kareṇumatī.
M. 50. 55.
text.7289:
Nīrājana — (waving of lights) taken by the Apsarasas
at the marriage of Kāmeśvara and Devī; one way of honour
ing deity.
Br. IV. 15. 33; M. 267. 19.
text.7290:
Nīla (I) — a mountain range in Bhāratavarṣa and to the
north of Ilāvṛta; formed the boundary limit of Ramyaka;1
one of the six varṣaparvatas in Jambūdvīpa; diamond like;2
residence of the monkey tribes;3 the residence of Brahma
ṛṣis. 1) Bhā. V. 16. 8; 19. 16; M. 113. 22; Vā. 34. 20, 25; 35. 8.
2) Br.
I. 1. 69; II. 15. 22, 28; 17. 35; Vā. 1. 85; 42. 67; 46. 34.
3) Br. III. 7.
194; IV. 31. 17.
text.7291:
Nīla (II) — a monkey chief, a friend of Rāma; followed
Rāma in the Lankā expedition.
Bhā. IX. 10. 16, 19.
text.7292:
Nīla (III) — a Rākṣasa resident in Sutalam.
Br. II. 20. 22; Vā. 50. 22.
text.7293:
Nīla (IV) — one of the five sons of Yadu.
Br. III. 69. 2; M. 43. 7; Vā. 94. 2.
text.7294:
Nīla (V) — a king of Pāñcāla, slain by Ugrāyudha;1 son
of Ajamidha and Nīlinī; by great austerities Suśānti (Śanti
Bhā. P.) was born.2 1) M. 49. 78; Vā. 99. 192.
2) Bhā. IX. 21. 30; M. 50. 1; Vā. 99.
194; Vi. IV. 19. 56-7.
text.7296:
Nīlā (VII) — one of the eight nidhis of Kubera.
Vā. 41. 10.
text.7297:
Nīla (VIII) — a Kulaparvata of the Bhadrāśva;1 border
ing on Jambūdvīpa.2 1) Vā. 43. 14; 48. 8; Vi. I. 4. 26; II. 2. 39.
2) Ib. II. 1. 20; 2. 11.
text.7298:
Nīla (IX) — a son of Pāra; father of a hundred sons.
Vi. IV. 19. 38-39.
text.7299:
Nīla (X) — of Vānarajāti, born of Hari and Pulaha.
Br. III. 7. 176, 319.
text.7300:
Nīla (XI) — a Parāśara clan.
Br. III. 8. 95; Vā. 70. 87.
text.7301:
Nīlaka — the name of the Rākṣasas in the Vajraka hill.
Vā. 39. 31.
text.7302:
Nīlakaṇṭha — the God enshrined in Kālañjara hill; an
epithet of Śiva;1 narrated to Pārvatī that at the request of
Brahmā and other gods he devoured the Kālakūṭa poison
that came out of the churning of the ocean;2 praise of, by
Rāma;3 by gods.4 1) M. 20. 15; 157. 23.
2) Br. II. 25. 90; Vā. 54. 3-94.
3) Br. II.
24. 25-31.
4) Vā. 54. 97-101.
text.7303:
Nīlakuṇḍam — a tīrtham; sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 22. 22.
text.7305:
Nīlapatākā — an Akṣarādevī; killed Jambukākṣa a
commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 19. 59; 25. 98, 37. 34.
text.7306:
Nīlaparvatam — a tīrtham sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 22. 70; 121. 68.
text.7307:
Nīlam (I) — the kingdom of Ramya.
Br. II. 14. 50; 15. 33; Vā. 33. 44.
text.7308:
Nīlam (II) — to be uttered in installing an image.
M. 265. 28.
text.7309:
Nīlamukhāh (c) — a kingdom of the East watered by
the Hlādinī;1 a tribe.2 1) Br. II. 18. 54; M. 121. 53.
2) Vā. 47. 51.
text.7310:
Nīlalohita (I) — (Śiva, Mahādeva);1 praised by Śukra
by as many as 300 names for His blessings on him.2 1) Br. III. 72. 109; 73. 1; Vā. 21. 4; 31. 32 and 59.
2) M
47. 127-169.
text.7312:
Nilaśaileya — (Nīlamauleya) a Janapada of the Bha
dra continent.
Vā. 43. 19.
text.7313:
Nīlavat — a son of Anjanā, an elephant.
Br. III. 7. 339.
text.7314:
Nīlā — a daughter of Keśinī, and a low type of Rākṣasī;
gave birth to Kṣudra Rākṣasas called after her the Naila
clan.
Br. III. 7. 7. 147. Vā. 69. 178, 181.
text.7315:
Nīlinī (I) — one of the queens of Ajamīḍha.
M. 49. 44; Vā. 99. 167.
text.7317:
Nīlotpalā — a R. of the Bhāratavarṣa.
Vā. 45. 100.
text.7318:
Nīvāra — a kind of corn for śrāddha;1 used as food by
foresters and offered by Śakuntalā to Duṣyanta.2 1) M. 15. 35.
2) Bhā. IX. 20. 14.
text.7319:
Nīhāra — the place where elephants of the four quar
ters throw out the waters in different ways.
Br. II. 22. 52.
text.7321:
Nūtana — the name of the varṣanāḍi or ray of the sun.
Vā. 53. 20.
text.7322:
Nūpā — a R. from the Pāriyātra.
Br. II. 16. 28.
text.7323:
Nṛga (I) — a son of Śrāddhadeva and Śraddhā and
father of a son Sumati by name.
Bhā. IX. 1. 12; 2. 17.
text.7324:
Nṛga (II) — a son of Ikṣvāku; liberal in his gift of cows,
silver, etc. Once a cow of a certain Brahmana got mixed
up with his herd, and ignorant of this he made a gift of it
to another Brahmana. The owner charged him, and when
both went to the king, the owner was not prepared to take
anything in its place and he who got the gift would not
part with it for anything; when he went to Yama's abode
he sent him as a lizard for this unrighteous act; in that form
he lived in a well until Kṛṣṇa lifted it up when it became
transformed into a celestial, and blessed by Kṛṣṇa rode in
an aerial car to heaven;1 release of, by Kṛṣṇa at Dvārakā;2
his lust after more territory.3 1) Bhā. X. 64. 10-30, 43 and 44 [1].
2) Ib. X. 37. 17.
3) Ib. XII. 3. 10.
text.7325:
Nṛga (III) — a son of Vaivasvata Manu.
Br. II. 38. 30; III. 60. 2; Vi. III. 1. 33; IV. 1. 7.
text.7326:
Nṛga (IV) — a son of Uśīnara and Nṛgā (Bhṛśā, M. P.);
his capital, Yaudheya; became lord of the Kekayas.
Br. III. 74. 19, 21; M. 48. 18, 20, 20; Vi. IV. 18. 9.
text.7327:
Nṛgā — one of the wives of Uśīnara and mother of Nṛga.
Br. III. 74. 18-9.
text.7328:
Nṛcakṣus — a son of Sunītha and father of Sukhīnala.
Bhā. IX. 22. 41; M. 50. 82.
text.7329:
Nṛtya — dancing; part of Viśokadvādaśivrata;1 in con
nection with tree rituals;2 in connection with Vāstu for
palace building.3 1) M. 82. 29.
2) Ib. 232. 15.
3) Ib. 268. 34.
text.7330:
Nṛdeva — the father of Pramati, God incarnate.
M. 144. 59.
text.7331:
Nṛpacakṣu — son of Sunitha and father of Sukhibala.
Vi. IV. 21. 12.
text.7332:
Nṛpañjaya (I) — the son of Medhāvin and father
of Dūrva.
Bhā. IX. 22. 42.
text.7333:
Nṛpañjaya (II) — a son of Sunitha (Suvīra-Vā. P.).
M. 49. 79; Vā. 99. 193.
text.7335:
Nṛmṇā — a R. in Plakṣadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 4.
text.7336:
Nṛsimha — (Nṛhari and Narahari Narasimham (s.v.)
half man and half lion avatār of Viṣṇu, worshipped as such in
Harivarṣa;1 came out of a post which Hiraṇyakaśipu knocked
with his fist; a description of his form and how he killed
the demon;2 still his anger was not appeased; praised by
Brahmā, Rudra, Indra, Sages, Pitṛs, Siddhas, Vidyādharas,
Nāgas, progenitors, Gandharvas, Cāraṇas, Yakṣas, Kimpuru
ṣas, Vaitālikas, Kinnaras, and Viṣṇu's attendants;3 Śrī was
afraid to go near him;4 at the request of the Gods Prahlāda
praised the God for the welfare of the universe; offered
boons to Prahlāda and advised him to rule his father's
kingdom with his mind devoted to Hari until the time came
for him to cast off his body;5 Brahmā's praise of the Lord's
disappearance.6 God incarnate of Viṣṇu remembered by
Śiva for vanquishing mātṛgaṇa;7 created from out of his
limbs a number of goddesses who overcame the Rudra,
mātṛgaṇas and were blessed with divinity.8 1) Bhā. II. 7. 14; V. 18. 7-14; VII. 8. 15-16; X. 2. 40; Vi. V. 5. 16.
2) Bhā. VII. 8. 15-31; XI. 4. 19.
3) Ib. VII. 8. 34 and 40-56.
4) Ib.
VII. 9. 2.
5) Ib. V. 18. 7-14; VI. 8. 14; VII. 9 (whole); 10. 11-14.
6) Ib. VII. 10. 26-31; Br. III. 33. 26.
7) M. 179. 44-52, 76.
8) Ib.
245. 21.
text.7338:
Netiṣya — one of the Bhārgava gotrakāras.
M. 195. 27.
text.7339:
Netra — a son of Dharma and father of Kunti.
Bhā. IX. 23. 22.
text.7341:
Nepāla (c) — sacred to Lalitā and hence to be included
in the cakra.
Br. IV. 44. 93.
text.7342:
Nepālapītham — one of the eyes of the Veda personified.
Vā. 104. 79.
text.7344:
Nemi (I) — a Rākṣasa was asked by Bali to refrain from
battle with Vāmana.
Bhā. VIII. 21. 19.
text.7346:
Nemi (III) — one of the sons of Ikṣvāku; a righteous
king cursed by Vasiṣṭha to lose his body.
Vā. 88. 9; 89. 3-4.
text.7347:
Nemikṛṣṇa — a son of Āpādabaddha; ruled for 25 years.
Vā. 99. 352.
text.7348:
Nemicakra — the son of Āsīmakṛṣṇa and father of Ukta;
Hastināpura being washed away he changed his capital to
Kauśāmbī.
Bhā. IX. 22. 39-40.
text.7349:
Neṣṭā — one of the 16 Ṛtviks for yajña; created from the
thighs of Nārāyaṇa.
M. 167. 9.
text.7351:
Naikavaktra — the hump-backed Kubja in the employ
of Kamsa for preparing perfumes. Kṛṣṇa got some for the
mere asking. Pleased, Kṛṣṇa cured her deformity and made
her a lovely damsel. She requested Kṛṣṇa to go to her
residence, which he promised to do sometime later.
Vi. V. 20. 4-13.
text.7353:
Naikās (Nailās) — born of Nila; belong to a branch of
the Ālambeyas; invincible and bold.
Vā. 69. 179.
text.7354:
Naigameya — a son of Agni and brother of Kumāra; an
amśa of Skanda.
Br. III. 3. 25; M. 5. 26; Vā. 66. 24. 101. 280. Vi. I. 15. 115.
text.7356:
Naidunda(ka)s — a Gaṇa of Piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 383, 389.
text.7358:
Naimittika — a form of Pralaya, which is dissolution of
the universe after a kalpa;1 one of the three kinds of samcāra
(movements of creatures).2 1) Bhā. XII. 4. 4, 38; Vi. VI. 3. 1; 4. 7.
2) Vā. 1. 161; 100. 132.
text.7359:
Naimittikakalpa — a division of the Brāhmakalpa.
Vā. 100. 133, 196.
text.7360:
Naimittikam — one of the three kinds of Śrāddha.
M. 16. 5.
text.7361:
Naimiśa — a R.: a fit place for performing Śrāddha.
Vi. III. 14. 18.
text.7362:
Naimiṣa — the southern sun;1 a tīrtha for performing
Śrāddha.2 1) Vā. 109. 21.
2) Ib. 106. 67
text.7363:
Naimiṣakas — (c) country of: under Maṇidhānyaka
kings.
Vi. IV. 24. 66.
text.7364:
Naimiṣā — (also Naimiṣālaya s.v.) sacred to Viṣṇu; here
Śaunaka and other sages performed a satra extending over a
thousand years;1 visited by Balarāma who was honoured by
all except Śūta Romaharṣaṇa; Balarāma killed the Śūta in
anger thus committing brahmicide; then at the instance of
the sages and as an expiation for the offence he killed Asura
Balvala here;2 revisited by Balarāma who took part in the
sacrifices;3 sages of, visited Dvārakā.4 1) Bhā. I. 1. 4 and 21; III. 20. 7; VII. 14. 31; Br. IV. 4. 45.
2) Bhā.
X. 78. 20-32; 79. 5.
3) Ib. X. 79. 30-32.
4) Ib. X. 90. 28. [6]. Br. I.
1. 37; III. 13. 100; IV. 2. 111 and 246; 4. 41.
text.7365:
Naimiṣāraṇyam — a Kṣetra and forest; a tīrtha where
Goddess Lingadhāriṇī is enshrined;1 best in Kṛtayuga;2 sacred
to the Piṭrs; here the spokes of Haricakra (Dharmacakra
Vā. P.) fell to pieces; here is the image of Viṣṇu in Vārāha
form;3 the sage Pipplāda living there was questioned by
Yudhiṣṭhira about Aṅgārakavrata;4 the forest where the
seers performed sacrifices.^5 1) M. 1. 4; 13. 26.
2) Ib. 106. 57; 109. 3; 110. 1; 180. 55; 246.
93.
3) Ib. 22. 12, 14; Vā. 1. 15.
4) M. 72, 2, Br. I. 2. 8; Vā. 2. 8;
21. 1; 23. 206; 77. 93; 108. 40 and 42.
text.7366:
Naimiṣālaya — here Sūta expounded the Bhāgavata to
the sages and seers at the request of Śaunaka and others.
See Naimiṣā.
Bhā. XII. 4. 43.
text.7367:
Naimiṣeyas — the sages and performers of penance in
Naimiṣā forest.
Vā. 67. 1; 101. 111, 292, 309; 103. 40, 42 and 46.
text.7368:
Nairṛta — a Rākṣasa Gaṇa from Nirṛti; the followers of
Kubera; hence Devarākṣasas.
Vā. 69. 173.
text.7369:
Nairṛtas — one of the four Rākṣasa clans after Nairṛta,
moving about during nights: followers of Trayambaka:
Devarākṣasas, heroic and valourous, with their leader
Vīrūpākṣa: Alakādhipa was their king;1 sons of Revatī and
Pūtanā: overlord Skanda: gave trouble to babies.2 1) Bhā. XII. 11. 48; Br. III. 7. 141-4, 163; 8. 62.
2) Ib. III. 7.
439; Vā. 84. 14.
text.7370:
Nairṛti (I) — a town of Nirṛti;1 bali to be given to
Nirṛti in Śrāddha.2 1) Bhā. X. 89. 44.
2) Vā. 111. 40.
text.7375:
Nailas — a Rākṣasa clan of low type, born of Nīla.
Br. III. 7. 148.
text.7376:
Naiśreyasam — the name of a garden in Vaikuṇṭha.
Bhā. III. 15. 16.
text.7377:
Naiṣadha — Nala of the Kaśyapa family entitled as N.
Lust of, after more territory.
M. 12. 56; Bhā. XII. 3. 10.
text.7378:
Naiṣadham(c) — a kingdom of Harivarṣa;1 a division of
Jambūdvīpa;2 also Niṣadha.3 1) Br. II. 14. 49; 15. 32; 18. 53. Vā. 33. 42.
2) Vi. II. 1. 19.
3) Ib.
II. 2. 11.
text.7379:
Naiṣadhas (I) — a tribe whose ancestor was Niṣāda and
who made mountains and forests their home;1 a Vindhyan
tribe;2 kingdom of.3 1) Bhā. IV. 14. 46; Br. III. 74. 189 and 196; M. 114. 53.
2) Br.
II. 16. 65.
3) M. 121. 52.
text.7380:
Naiṣadhas (II) — the kings of the family of Nala;1 nine
kings of, under Maṇidhānyaka line.2 1) Vā. 99. 376-7.
2) Vi. IV. 24. 60, 66.
text.7381:
Naiṣṭhīya — the place of Kavi Agni (Uśīra).
Vā. 29. 29.
text.7382:
Nau — the boat in the Ocean; in the river;1 illustrative
of the earth floating on waters.2 1) Vā. 6. 27; 52. 86; 108. 37.
2) Vi. I. 4. 46.
text.7383:
Nau — (Mahīmayī) the divine boat given to Manu
(Vaivasvata) by Viṣṇu in the shape of a fish to be tied to its
horn;1 in the deluge it rescued the sun, moon, Brahmā,
Narmadā, sage Mārkaṇḍeya, Śiva, the Vedas, Purāṇas and
other Vidyas from ruin;2 Druhyu to ply the ocean with.3 1) M. 1. 30-32; Bhā. I. 3. 15.
2) M. 2. 10-15.
3) Ib. 33. 20.
text.7384:
Nyagrodha (I) — a son of Ugrasena;1 and brother of
Kamsa killed by Balarāma.2 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 24; Br. III. 71. 133; M. 44. 74; Vā. 96. 132; Vi.
IV. 14. 20.
2) Bhā. X. 44. 40-41.
text.7385:
Nyagrodha (II) — a son of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 90. 34.
text.7386:
Nyagrodha (III) — the banyan tree of Ramaṇaka; of
the shape of a lotus after which Puṣkaradvīpa is named;1
during the deluge, Lord Nārāyaṇa in the form of a baby
slept on a leaf of the tree.2 1) Br. II. 15. 63-4; 19. 140; III. 11. 36, 109; IV. 43. 17; M. 123.
39; Vi. I. 12. 65; II. 4. 85; IV. 3. 23.
2) M. 167. 31.
text.7387:
Nyagrodhā-rohiṇa — the city of the Yakṣas.
Br. III. 7. 118; Vā. 69. 149.
text.7389:
Nyāya — a Śāstra; a servant of the Veda;1 learnt by
Kṛṣṇa and Balarāma;2 by Asuras.3 1) M. 3. 4; 53. 5; Vā. 2. 33; 61. 78; 104. 85; Vi. III. 6. 27; V. 1.
38.
2) Bhā. X. 45. 34.
3) Br. II. 35. 87; IV. 12. 17.
text.7390:
Nyāsa(mantra) — in connection with the installation of
an image; eg. Ratnanyāsa for the eight directions: diamond,
pearl, vaiḍūrya, conch, spaṭika, puṣparāga, indranīla and
nīla; pastes of eight kinds: tālaka, śilāvajra, collyrium,
śyāma, kañji, kāśi, mākṣikam, and gairikam; grains of eight
kinds: wheat, barley, seasamum, mudga, nīvāra, śyāmaka,
sarṣapa, and vrīhirice, scents like sandal, red sandal, agaru,
añjanam, uśīram, vaiṣṇavī sahadevī, and Lakṣmaṇa; metals
of eight kinds: gold, vidruma, copper, bronze, ārakūṭaka,
silver, puṣpam and iron. Then the worship of the Lokhapālas
with Nyāsamantras.
M. 266. 9-29.
text.7392:
Nyāsi — see Yati and Bhikṣu.
Br. II. 7. 181; Vā. 106. 18.
text.7393:
Pakṣa (I) — a lunar period of 15 days; Śukla (white)
and Kṛṣṇa (dark).
Br. II. 21. 125; 24. 56; 28. 33; III. 1. 59; Vā. 30. 15; 49. 130;
50. 178; 56. 3 and 30.
text.7394:
Pakṣa (II) — a Maṇivara Yakṣa and son of Devajanī.
Br. III. 7. 129.
text.7398:
Pakṣi — a species of birds vanquished by Rāvaṇa; the
name of a mūrchana after their name.
Br. III. 7. 256, 307; 61. 52; IV. 4. 2.
text.7399:
Pakṣiṇī — a śakti on the ṣoḍaśa — patrābja.
Br. IV. 32. 11.
text.7400:
Paṃkajavanam — the name of a sacred forest; here is
Pāṇḍuśilā fit for the performance of śrāddha; Yudhiṣṭhira
performed śrāddha at the place; pleased at it Pāṇḍu blessed
his son to rule the kingdom and go to heaven.
Vā. 112. 43-49.
text.7401:
Paṃkti — a metre: a Chandas.
Bhā. XI. 21. 41; Br. II. 22. 72; M. 125. 47; Vā. 51. 65. Vi.
II. 8. 5.
text.7402:
Paṃktipāvana — Persons eminently fit to eat with; learn
ed in six Angas, given to dhyāna and yoga; learned in tantras,
and Yāyāvara: Also Sauparṇas, Pañcāgneyas, Sāmagas,
Trināciketas, Trayīs, learned in Bārhaspatyaśāśtra;1 unfit:
Anāśrami, Ayati, Mokṣavādi, Citravādi, heretics, atheists,
Sānkhyas, Muṇḍa, Jaṭila, Kāpāḷikas, Kārukas, Songsters,
sellers of Veda etc., persons not conforming to the rules of
varṇa and āśrama.2 1) Br. III. 15. 28-30.
2) Ib. III. 15. 39-55, 94; Vā. 79. 53-59; 83.
51-57.
text.7403:
Pañcakas — a royal line established by Viśvasphāṇi.
Vā. 99. 378.
text.7404:
Pañcakāmas — Kāmarāja, Kandarpa, Manmatha, Maka
radhvaja, and Manobhava; all decked with Kastūri tilaka
and pearls.
Br. IV. 19. 69.
text.7405:
Pañcakūṭa — a Mt. inside Kailāsa;1 the residence of the
Dānavas.2 1) Vā. 38. 33.
2) Ib. 39. 53; 42. 32.
text.7406:
Pañcagatayas — the Yajña leading to Devas; Tapas to
Vairāgya; Karmasannyāsa to Brāhmaṇya; Vairāgya to Laya;
Jñāna to Kaivalya.
Vā. 57. 117-18.
text.7407:
Pañcagavyam — a mixture of 5 secretions of the cow for
purifying the body;1 milk, curd, ghee, urine and dung of
the cow, constituents;2 a panacea for stealing eatables, fruits
and flowers, vehicles and beds;3 ablution of image to be
installed by.4 1) M. 56. 6; 57, 5; 60. 17; 62. 8.
2) Ib. 266. 6; 267. 5-6; Vā. 110.
15.
3) M. 227. 44.
4) Ib. 265. 8.
text.7408:
Pañcaguṇās — these are śabda, sparśa, rūpa, rasa and
gandha.
Vā. 4. 68.
text.7410:
Pañcajana (I) — an asura in the form of a conch in the
Prabhāsa. Son of Samhrāda and Kṛtī, and father of Asikni.
He seized the son of Sāndipana (or Sāndīpanī) and devour
ed him. Kṛṣṇa plunged into the sea and killing him, remov
ed the conch which covered his body.1 Killed in Prāg
jyotiṣa.2 1) Bhā. III. 3. 2; VI. 4. 51; 18. 14; X. 45. 40-42. Vi. V. 21. 27-8.
2) Ib. V. 29. 19.
text.7411:
Pañcajana (II) — a son of Sagara.
Br. III. 63. 147.
text.7412:
Pañcajana (III) — the father of Amśumān and father
in-law of Yaśodā.
M. 15. 18.
text.7413:
Pañcajanī — the daughter of Viśvarūpa and queen of
Bharata.
Bhā. V. 7. 1.
text.7414:
Pañcajanya — an Upadvīpa to Jambūdvīpa.
Bhā. V. 19. 30.
text.7415:
Pañcatīrtham — the name of a tīrtha in Kāñcī.
Br. IV. 40. 60; 71, 115.
text.7417:
Pañcadaśam — a svara variety of a sāma.
Br. II. 8. 51, 52; Vā. 9. 49.
text.7418:
Pañcadaśākṣarī — to be repeated 1008 times to get rid
of sins; of the mantraśāstra, non-Vedic.
Br. IV. 8. 36, 58.
text.7419:
Pañcadaśī (I) — the fifteenth day of the Māgha month
fit for performing sādhāraṇa śrāddha;1 of the Āṣāda month
for making gift of a cow.2 1) M 17. 2, 4.
2) Ib. 53. 24.
text.7420:
Pañcadaśī (II) — the day when the Pitṛs drink the rays
of the moon.
Vā. 52. 69; 56. 59.
text.7421:
Pañcadhārāśikṣas — the five modes of training horses
for war.
Br. IV. 16. 20.
text.7422:
Pañcanada — the sacred place for the performance of
śrāddha, at the confluence of the Sindhu and the ocean;1
Arjuna halted here on his way to Indraprastha from
Dvārakā.2 1) Br. III. 13. 57; Vā. 77. 56.
2) Vi. V. 38-12.
text.7423:
Pañcanadeśvara — stationed by Jarāsandha at the
southern gate of Mathurā.
Bhā. X. 50. 11. [4].
text.7424:
Pañcanidhanam — a sūkta of the Sāma Samhita to be
recited when a tank is dug.
M. 58. 36.
text.7425:
Pañcapañcātma — a reference to 25 truths (tatvas) (in
śloka 33) which arose out of the union of Devī with Puruṣa.
Br. IV. 8. 29.
text.7426:
Pañcapadī — a R. in Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 26.
text.7428:
Pañcabāṇa — a name of the God of love.
M. 20. 29.
text.7430:
Pañcama (I) — a pupil of Kṛta.
Br. II. 35. 51.
text.7431:
Pañcama (II) — outside the pale of the four āśramas:
a mixed caste.
Br. III. 15. 37.
text.7432:
Pañcama (III) — the twenty-first Kalpa; consisting of
Prāṇa, apāna, samāna, udāna, and vyāna; mind-born sons
of Brahmā.
Vā. 21. 47.
text.7433:
Pañcama (IV) — the fifth note in music.
Vā. 21. 49. 86. 37.
text.7434:
Pañcama (V) — a pupil of Hiraṇyanābha's son; a Sāmaga.
Vā. 61. 44.
text.7435:
Pañcamī — a name of Lalitā; a śaktī.
Br. IV. 17. 18; 36. 25.
text.7436:
Pañcamukha — a name of Brahmā: for saying that, he
saw the beginning of an effulgence of light in the form of
a sthambha, which Mahesvara assumed; for not seeing it,
Siva — Bhairava removed one of Brahmā's faces; hence
Caturmukha from that day onwards.
Br. IV. 40. 48, 56.
text.7437:
Pañcayāma — a son of Ātapa and grandson of the Vasu,
Vibhāvasu; it is on account of him that all creatures perform
their functions.
Bhā. VI. 6. 16.
text.7440:
Pañcaratha (II) — a title conferred on able warriors as
Surasena and others.
Br. III. 46. 17.
text.7441:
Pañcalakṣaṇam (I) — of a Purāṇa: Sarga, Pratisarga,
Manvantara, Vamśa and Vamśānucarita.
M. 53. 65. 70; Vā. 4. 11.
text.7442:
Pañcalakṣaṇam (II) — śabda, rūpa, rasa, gandha, and
sparśa; incidents relating to.
Vā. 8. 45.
text.7443:
Pañcalāṅgalakam — a gift of five ploughs and cattle both
in wood and gold as well as 100 nivartanas (or 50 or even
a small area enough for a house to stand on) of land on an
auspicious day leads one to heaven; rules relating to the
performance of.
M. 274. 9; ch. 283 (whole).
text.7444:
Pañcavanam — (Kauśiki tank): here is the tīrtha
of Pāṇḍuviśala.
Vā. 77. 99, 101.
text.7445:
Pañcavana — one of Sagara's sons who survived
Kapila's tejas.
Vā. 88. 149.
text.7446:
Pañcavarṇā — a R. of the Bhadra country
Vā. 43. 27.
text.7447:
Pañcavindhyas — Saptavindhyas excepting Hṛīnkāra and
Praṇava.
Br. II. 33. 39.
text.7448:
Pañcaviṃśaka Puruṣa — the Lord made of 25 truths
(tatvas).
M. 274. 62.
text.7449:
Pañcavīrās — the sons of Sāmba and Kāśyā.
M. 47. 24.
text.7450:
Pañcaśara — an epithet of the God of love; his dart is
the twig of the mango, and his standard, the fish; his wife,
Ratī and his friend, Madhu or the spring; also Pañcabāṇa and
Madana.
M. 154. 207-9, 212.
text.7451:
Pañcaśikha (I) — a Brahmaṛṣi1 of the eighth dvāpara.2 1) M. 102. 18.
2) Vā. 23. 141.
text.7453:
Pañcaśikhara — a mountain peak in Sālmalidvīpa.
Br. III. 7. 454.
text.7455:
Pañcaśaila — a Mt. south of the Meru.
Vā. 36. 24.
text.7456:
Pañcahasta — a son of Dakṣasāvarṇī.
Vi. III. 2. 24.
text.7458:
Pañcāgni — five fires eligible for Pārvaṇa śrāddha;1
performance of penance by Yayāti for a year in the midst
of five fires;2 created by Agniśarman from his face. These
are Dakṣināgni, Gārhapatya, Āhavanīya, Sabhya, and
Āvasathya.3 1) Vā. 83. 53; M. 16. 7.
2) Ib. 35. 16.
3) Vā. 106. 41. 2.
text.7460:
Pañcāgnimadhyastha — a kind of austerity performed
by Parasurāma standing in the midst of five fires.
Br. III. 22. 72.
text.7462:
Pañcāpsaras — sacred to Hari; visited by Balarāma
Bhā. X. 79. 18.
text.7463:
Pañcābdās — Pitṛs and sons of Brahmā1 limbs of the
five year yuga;2 known as Kāvyas.3 1) Br. II. 28. 17, 21; M. 141. 15, 19.
2) Ib. 141. 57.
3) Vā. 52. 68.
text.7464:
Pañcāyatanam — a sacred place on the Narmadā.
M. 191. 6.
text.7465:
Pañcāla (I) — (c) on the way from Dvārakā to Hasti
nāpura;1 migration of the Yadus to;2 the territory divided
among the five sons of Bheda.3 1) Bhā. IV. 25. 50; 27. 8; X. 71. 22.
2) Ib. X. 2. 3.
3) Vā. 99. 192.
text.7466:
Pañcāla (II) — a Yakṣa sent by Brahmā with the God
dess of Night to the Vindhyas to serve her as servant.
M. 157. 18.
text.7467:
Pañcālas — the 25 kings who were contemporaries of
the ten Śiśunāgas.
Br. III. 74. 136.
text.7469:
Pāñcāśvamedhika — a tīrtha fit for performing śrāddha.
Vā. 77. 45.
text.7470:
Paṭa — the painting canvas frame on which portraits
were drawn. Citralekhā drew a good number of portraits
for Uṣa's choice of a husband.
Vi. V. 32. 22-5.
text.7472:
Paṭaccaras — (c) a kingdom of Madhyadeśa; name of a
tribe.
Br. II. 16. 41; M. 114. 35.
text.7474:
Paṭuma — a king of the Śātakarni line; ruled for
twenty-four years.
Br. III. 74. 164.
text.7475:
Paṭuman — the son of Meghasvāti and father of Ariṣṭa
karman.
Vi. IV. 24. 45-6.
text.7476:
Paṭumitras — an Andhra line of rulers.
Vi. IV. 24. 58.
text.7477:
Paṭuśrava — a son of Damaghoṣa and Śrutaśravā.
Vā. 96. 159.
text.7478:
Paṭṭam — a plate or cloth or other substance to be pre
sented with prescribed mantras as gift during an eclipse.
M. 67. 21.
text.7479:
Paṭṭamitrās — a Māhiṣī line of 13 kings.
Vā. 99. 374.
text.7480:
Paṭṭavardhanam — mode of wearing the tilaka on the
forehead. Other modes are Ūrdhva puṇḍra, Tripuṇḍra
and Agastyapatrākāra.
Br. IV. 38. 22.
text.7481:
Paṭṭasena — a commander of Bhaṇḍa;1 a son of Bhaṇḍa.2 1) Br. IV. 21. 83.
2) Ib. IV. 26. 49.
text.7482:
Paṭṭiśa — one of the weapons of Śiva.
Vā. 55. 45; 101. 270.
text.7485:
Paṇava (II) — a musical instrument.
Vā. 45. 40; Bhā. V. 9. 15.
text.7487:
Paṇi (I) — a priest in a Kāḷi temple; the reference is to
the Paṇi of the Vṛṣala chief.
Bhā. V. 9. 15-16.
text.7488:
Paṇi (II) — a Dānava group of Rasātala.
Bhā. V. 24. 30.
text.7490:
Paṇḍārakavanam — in the Pāṇḍukula and near the
sea; a place fit for śrāddha.
Vā. 77. 37.
text.7491:
Pataṅga (I) — a Mt. on the base of Meru;1 on the south
of the Mānasa.2 1) Bhā. V. 16. 26. Vi. II. 2. 28.
2) Vā. 36. 22; 38. 2.
text.7492:
Patanga (II) — a class of people in Plakṣadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 4.
text.7493:
Pataṅga (III) — a son of Devakī killed by Kamsa; taken
to Dvārakā from Sutala by Kṛṣṇa, and after having been
seen by his parents, went to Heaven.
Bhā. X. 85. 51-6.
text.7494:
Pataṅga (IV) — the helpmate of the Vālakhilyas;1 the
Sun God.2 1) Vā. 28. 32.
2) Br. II. 21. 67. Vā. 52. 48; 54. 8.
text.7495:
Pataṅgī — the wife of Tārkṣya and mother of birds.
Bhā. VI. 6. 21.
text.7497:
Pataṃjali (II) — a pupil of Parāśarya Kauthuma.
Br. II. 35. 46; Vā. 61. 41.
text.7498:
Patākā — a R. of the Bhadra continent.
Vā. 43. 30.
text.7499:
Patākinī — a Śaktī of the Vāyudik; her riding animal
mṛga.
M. 286. 9.
text.7500:
Patita — a fallen person from the path of righteousness,
piṇḍa to be given in the evening and no pollution; whoever
he be, even the guru, he must be abandoned; but the fallen
mother must not be abandoned.
M. 227. 59, 150.
text.7501:
Pativratā — conjugal fidelity; the greatness of, illus
trated by the story of Sāvitrī and Satyavān; husband is the
lord, God, partner and not others.
M. 210. 16ff.
text.7502:
Pattallaka — ruled after the Andhra king Hāla, for five
years.
Br. III. 74. 166.
text.7503:
Patram — (likhitam) written message sent by Rukmiṇī
to Kṛṣṇa; text of the letter.
Bhā. X. 52. 36 [1 and 2]; 37-43.
text.7506:
Pathya (I) — learnt the Atharva Samhitā from a pupil
of Sumantu; Kumuda and others were his disciples.
Bhā. XII. 7. 1 and 2.
text.7507:
Pathya (II) — a disciple of Kabandha; he had three dis
ciples; Jājali (Jābāli-Vi. P.), Kumulādi and Śaunaka.
Br. II. 35. 56, 59; Vā. 61. 50; Vi. III. 6. 9-11.
text.7509:
Pathyā — a daughter of Maru and wife of Atharva An
giras; father of 101 sons of whom were Ayāsya, Vāmadeva,
Utathya, Uśiti, and Dhṛṣṇi.
Br. III. 1. 103-5; Vā. 65. 98.
text.7510:
Padgamās — a tribe of the Vindhya region.
M. 114. 53.
text.7511:
Padma (I) — a Yakṣa; a son of Puṇyajanī and Maṇi
bhadra.
Br. III. 7. 124; Vā. 69. 155.
text.7512:
Padma (II) — the name of the 7th kalpa.
Vā. 21. 12.
text.7513:
Padma (III) — a son of Bhadra; gave birth to eight kinds
of elephants;1 vehicle of Ailavila.2 1) Vā. 69. 213, 217.
2) Br. III. 7. 329. 331.
text.7514:
Padma (IV) — the forest of Padma between the Lau
hitya and the Sindhu.
Br. III. 7. 358.
text.7516:
Padmaka — a palace with three bhūmikas and sixteen
sides;1 also Śrivṛkṣaka; the toraṇa is of 20 hastas.2 1) M. 269. 39, 43.
2) Ib. 269. 49.
text.7518:
Padmagulma — a son of Mṛga elephant.
Br. III. 7. 332.
text.7520:
Padmadala — the vessel of the lotus leaf wherein the
Gandharvas milked the cow-earth.
M. 10. 24.
text.7521:
Padmadvayam — a snake used as balabandham for Tri
purāri's chariot.
M. 133. 33.
text.7522:
Padmanābha (I) — also Janārdana; the God who per
vades all the worlds; lustrous as the sun and with bow as
weapon.
Br. II. 19. 177-80; III. 33. 17; IV. 34. 81.
text.7523:
Padmanābha (II) — a Yakṣa; a son of Devajanī and
Maṇivara.
Br. III. 7. 130; Vā. 69. 161.
text.7524:
Padmapātras — the Gandharvas and the Apsarasas
milked the earth making Citraratha the calf; milkman Śucī
Viśvavasu.
Vā. 62. 187.
text.7525:
Padma(bhūḥ) — Brahmā; a thousand leafed lotus came
out of the navel of the Lord on the eve of the creation of the
universe; it resembled the earth in form; in it were found
all the countries, mountains, peoples, etc.
M. 4. 1; 168. 15; 169. 3 to 18.
text.7526:
Padmam (I) — 1000 billions; ten times the śanku.
M. 23. 39; Vā. 101. 101.
text.7527:
Padmam (II) — one of the eight nidhis of Kubera.
Vā. 41. 10.
text.7528:
Padmayoni — see Brahmā.
Br. II. 25. 62. Vi. VI. 4-9.
text.7529:
Padmavarṇa — a Yakṣa; a son of Devajanī and Maṇi
vara.
Br. III. 7. 129; Vā. 61. 190.
text.7530:
Padmavidhi — in the yajñas after the world lotus of the
Lord.
M. 169. 16 and 18.
text.7531:
Padmā (I) — a name of Śrī.
Bhā. X. 47. 13; Vi. I. 8. 24.
text.7532:
Padmā (II) — one of the ten pīṭhas for images; with
sixteen corners, a little short at the bottom; gives one good
luck (saubhāgya).
M. 262. 7, 16, 18.
text.7533:
Padmāvatī (I) — the city of Purañjaya the capital of the
Nāgas.
Bhā. XII. 1. 37. Vi. IV. 24. 63.
text.7534:
Padmāvatī (II) — a daughter of Bhaṅgakāra, who was
given in marriage to Kṛṣṇa.
M. 45. 21.
text.7535:
Padmāsana — a kind of āsana in yoga, once practised by
Paraśurāma; of Kapila.
Br. III. 24. 16; 53. 17.
text.7536:
Padmottama — a son of Mṛga elephant.
Br. III. 7. 332.
text.7538:
Panasa — A Vānara, whose daughter was Rumā;1 fol
lowed Rāma in his expedition to Lankā.2 1) Br. III. 7. 221, 231.
2) Bhā. IX. 10. 19.
text.7540:
Pannagās — semi-divine beings, see Sarpās.
Br. II. 32. 1, 2.
text.7541:
Pannāgāri — a sage; one of the three disciples of Rathī
tara.
M. 200. 12; Vā. 61. 3.
text.7542:
Paplavas — a tribe who were defeated by Sagara and
deprived of their Kṣatriya right of Vedic study and sacrifice;
became Mlecchas and were allowed to have long hair.
Vi. IV. 3. 42, 47-8.
text.7543:
Pampā (I) — a R. sacred to Hari; visited by Balarāma.
Bhā. VII. 14. 31; X. 79. 12.
text.7544:
Pampā (II) — a R. of the Bhadra country.
Vā. 43. 27.
text.7546:
Pampāvatī — a R. of the Bhadra country.
Vā. 43. 27.
text.7547:
Paya — (Gavya) cow's milk for śrāddha;1 not to be
taken during nights.2 1) M. 17. 34.
2) M. 131. 43.
text.7548:
Payasvinī — a R. flowing in Draviḍa in the Bhārata
varṣa.
Bhā. V. 19. 18; XI. 5. 39.
text.7551:
Payodam — a lake in the Nīla hill.
Br. II. 18. 69.
text.7552:
Payodā (I) — a R. from the lake Payodam.
Br. II. 18. 70. Vā. 47. 66.
text.7553:
Payodā (II) — a R. rising on the western side of the Meru
mountain.
Vā. 47. 67.
text.7555:
Payovrata — (also called Sarvayajña, Sarvavrata) a
votive offering of the essence of tapas, in honour of Hari to be
observed for twelve days and in which Hari is represented
in an image or in any other form; originally told about it
by Brahmā, Kaśyapa suggested to his wife Aditi to observe
it; Aditī observed it as instructed by Kaśyapa, when Hari
manifested Himself and promised to be born of her womb;1
observed by Śraddhā.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 16. 25-60; 17. 1-18.
2) IX. 1. 14.
text.7556:
Payoṣṇī — a R. from the Ṛkṣa hill in Bhāratavarṣa1
visited by Balarāma;2 sacred to Pingaleśvarī and the
Pitṛs.3 1) Bhā. V. 19. 18; Br. II. 16. 32; Vā. 45. 102; Vi. II. 3. 11.
2) Bhā. X. 79. 20.
3) M. 13. 44; 22. 33. 64; 114. 27.
text.7557:
Para (I) — that which is Pūrva in the Parārdha becomes
Para in Aparārdha;1 ety. the best.2 1) Vā. 7. 13.
2) Ib. 5. 37.
text.7558:
Para (II) — one of the three sons of Samara of Kampili.
Vā. 99. 177.
text.7559:
Parakṣaras — a tribe living in the Narmadā region.
Vā. 45. 129.
text.7564:
Parapuruṣa — the best of Puruṣas; worshipped by one
who has no desires and by one who desires everything includ
ing mokṣa.
Bhā. II. 3. 9, 10 and 12.
text.7566:
Para(m) (I) — twice the number of Parāṛdha;1 it is
Brahmā, knowledge, wealth and everything desirable;2
according to one mode of computation Para is itself Parār
dha which means anything above Parārdha, and is incal
culable.3 1) Br. IV. 2. 90; Vā. 101. 92 and 99.
2) Br. IV. 2. 99-102.
3) Ib. IV. 2. 105-7, 143.
text.7570:
Paramāṇuka — (Paramāṇu): (1/10) more than Bhūtādi;
is sūkṣma and cannot be ascertained by bhāva; that which
could not be consolidated; the first Paramāṇu of Pramāṇas
is the particle of dust seen through the inner window by the
sun's rays.
Bhā. III. 11. 1; XII. 4. 1; Vā. 101. 116-18. Br. IV. 2. 117, 227-9.
text.7571:
Paramārtha — illustrated by the life of Nidāgha, a pupil
of Ṛbhu.
Vi. II. 14. 16 and 31; chh. 15 and 16.
text.7572:
Paramāśrama — the fourth āśrama or sannyāsa; to be
with guru for a year and then to go about the country; leav
ing off congregation, subduing anger, eating light food, con
trolling the senses, and living in deserted places, forests,
caves and banks of rivers.
Vā. 17. 1-8.
text.7573:
Parameśvara — is Śiva;1 also an epithet of Viṣṇu.2 1) Br. III. 41. 50; 44. 30; IV. 10. 28; M. 12. 9.
2) Vi. V. 1. 60;
18. 52.
text.7574:
Parameśvarī — the chief Śakti, Lalitā;1 enshrined in
Pātāla.2 1) Br. IV. 6. 65; 16. 1; 18. 15; 19. 60; 22. 5.
2) M. 13. 39.
text.7575:
Parameṣu — a son of Anu.
M. 48. 10. Vi. IV. 18. 1.
text.7576:
Parameṣṭhi (I) — an attribute of Brahmā worshipped
for overlordship.
Bhā. II. 1. 30; 2. 22; 3. 6; Br. IV. 9. 27.
text.7577:
Parameṣṭhi (II) — a son of Devadyumna; his queen
Suvarcalā; father of Pratiha.
Bhā. V. 15. 3.
text.7578:
Parameṣṭhi (III) — a son of Indradyumna.
Br. II. 14. 65; Vi. II. 1. 36. Vā. 33. 55.
text.7579:
Parameṣṭhi (IV) — married the daughter of Dakṣa and
became the father of Nārada.
Br. III. 2. 13-18.
text.7580:
Paraṃtapa — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
M. 9. 17.
text.7581:
Paravṛt — a son of Rukmakavaca and father of five
sons.
Vi. IV. 12. 10-11.
text.7583:
Paraśu (I) — a son of Uttama Manu.
Br. II. 36. 39; Vi. III. 1. 15.
text.7584:
Paraśu (II) — also Paraśvadha: axe; the weapon
presented to Rāma by Śiva to put down the Asuras.
Br. III. 24. 74, 81; 32. 58; 39. 21, 31; 40. 13; IV. 19. 84.
text.7585:
Paraśu (III) — a son of Rukmiṇī and Kṛṣṇa.
M. 47. 16.
text.7587:
Paraśurāma (I) — a Siddha: the 16th avatār of Viṣṇu;
a foe of the Haihayas; rid the world of the Kṣatriyas twenty
one times; and made three pools of blood at Syamanta
pañcaka;1 defeated by Rama2 spoke highly of the valour
of Bhīṣma,3 while in tapas was met by Kṛṣṇa and Balarāma
on their way to Gomanta; he asked them to kill the king
of Karavīrapura at its foot and thus clear the way uphill;4
was met by Balarāma;5 son of Jamadagni with an amsa of
Nārāyana; a Bhargava;6 killed Kārtavīrya Arjuna.7 1) Bhā. I. 3. 20; II. 7. 22; VI. 15. 13; X. 40. 20; 82. 3; XI.
4. 21.
2) Ib. IX. 10. 7; chh. 15 and 16 (whole).
3) Ib. IX. 22. 20.
4) Ib. X. [52 (V) 18-30].
5) Ib. X. 79-12; Vi. IV. 4. 94.
6) Vā. 94.
38; Vā. IV. 7. 36.
7) Vi. IV. 11. 20.
text.7588:
Paraśurāma (II) — a Purohita of Kṛṣṇa in his Yajñas
at Kurukṣetra.
Bhā. X. 90. 46[2].
text.7590:
Parā or Pāra (II) — a Sāvarṇa Manu, with a gaṇa of
12, of which six names are mentioned.
Br. IV. 1. 55, 57.
text.7592:
Parā (IV) — the fourth stage of Kāmākṣī, of four arms
with Pāśa, Aṅkuśa, Ikṣukodaṇḍa, and Pañcabāṇa, in this
form Lalitā got established at Kāñci.
Br. IV. 39. 13; 44. 141.
text.7593:
Parā (V) — a R. rising from the Ṛkṣa hill of the
Bhāratavarṣa.
Vā. 45. 98.
text.7594:
Parākṣa — a son of Anu.
Br. III. 74. 13.
text.7595:
Parācaka — a Janapada of the Bhadra.
Vā. 43. 20.
text.7597:
Parāparā — the third stage of Kāmākṣī, the second being
Suddhaparā.
Br. IV. 39. 11.
text.7598:
Parāṃkuśa — a name of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 18. 14.
text.7600:
Parārdhakalpa — the preceding kalpa as opposed to
Aparārdhakalpa of which the first one is the present
Varāhakalpa.
Vā. 7. 11.
text.7601:
Parārdham — measurement of ten antas, (Vedic): two
Parārdhams constitute Brahmā's life (first Prajāpati);1 The
present Varāhakalpa is the second Parārdha;2 of Brahmā;3
a crore of 1000 crores.4 1) Vā. 100. 240. Vi. I. 3. 5.
2) Ib. I. 3. 27-8; VI. 3. 4.
3) Br.
I. 4-31.
4) Vā. 101. 92, 99.
text.7602:
Parāvasu (I) — the Gandharva who sang the glory of
Indra for defeating Namuci: with the śarat sun.
Bhā. VIII. 11. 41; Br. II. 23. 13; Vā. 79. 13.
text.7603:
Parāvasu (II) — an asura who entered the ocean.
M. 61. 4.
text.7604:
Parāvaha — one of the seven Maruts.
M. 163. 32.
text.7605:
Parāśakti — is Māyā;1 worship of, to get rid of Raurava
hell and of other sins.2 1) Vā. 104. 33.
2) Br. IV. 7-75; 8. 57-8; 10. 90; 12. 41-66; 14.
22; 15. 46.
text.7606:
Parāśara (I) — the son of Śakti and Adṛśyantī; wife
Kālyā (Satyavatī, Acchoda Matsya Gandhi) and son
Kṛṣṇadvaipāyana;1 a Ṛṣika became sage by satya;2 a pupil of
Yājñavalkya;3 of Bāṣkala, a Vāsiṣṭha;4 a Śrutaṛṣi;5 a Veda
vyāsa6 of the 26th dvāpara; heard the Br. Purāṇa (Vāyu P.)
from Śakti when in embryo and narrated it to Jātu —
karṇi;7 praised Śiva, out to destroy Tripura;8 invited for the
Rājasūya of Yudhiṣṭhira,9 came to see Parīkṣit preaching
prāyopavesa;10 questioned by Maitreya on the origin of the
world etc: narrated the Bhāgavata to the sage;11 recollected
Vasiṣṭha's narration to him of his father's death at the
hands of a Rākṣasa set up by Viśvāmitra: his anger and the
sacrifice he performed for the extinction of the Rākṣasas;12
The advice of Vasiṣṭha, his grand-father, to abate his anger
because fate must run its course and anger was unworthy
of the wise: his compliance;13 the arrival of Pulastya the son
of Brahmā, who granted P. boons comprising knowledge of
the sāstras, authorship of Viṣṇu Purāṇa and correct know
ledge of the truth about Gods and Karma: the conformation
of the boons by Vasiṣṭha: states that the Universe is born
of Viṣṇu, depends on him and is Sahiṣṇu avatār of the
Lord;14 praise of Hari having realised the Yoga power of
Hari.15 1) Bhā. I. 3. 21; 4. 14; VI. 15. (14); IX. 22. 21; XII. 6. 49, 55;
Br. I. 1. 9; 2. 12; III. 8. 91; M. 14. 15; 47. 246; 201. 31; Vā. 70. 83.
2) Br. II. 32. 102.
3) Ib. II. 35. 29; Vā. 77. 74; Vi. III. 4. 18.
4) Br.
II. 32. 115.
5) Ib. II. 33. 3; M. 145. 96, 109.
6) Br. II. 35. 124; Vā.
23. 212.
7) Br. IV. 4. 65-6; Vā. 61. 47; 103. 65; 106. 35.
8) M. 133. 67.
9) Bhā. X. 74. 8.
10) Ib. I. 19. 9; Vā. 1. 138; 2. 12.
11) Bhā. III.
8. 8; Vi. I. 1. 1-10.
12) Ib. I. 1. 11-14.
13) Ib. I. 1. 15-21.
14) Vā.
23. 212; Vi. I. 1. 22-31.
15) Bhā. II. 7. 45; Vi. II. 2. 7.
text.7607:
Parāśara (II) — the son and pupil of Kuśumi.
Br. II. 35. 42.
text.7608:
Parāśara (III) — a son of Ṛṣabha avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 144.
text.7609:
Parāśara (IV) — a Mantra-brāhmaṇa-kāraka and resident
of Brahmakṣetra.
Vā. 59. 105.
text.7611:
Parāsikas — people constituting the cavalry forces of
Lalitā.
Br. IV. 16. 16.
text.7612:
Parāhata — from the region of planets to that of ṛṣis or
sages; the sixth skandha.
Vā. 67. 119.
text.7615:
Parikṛṣṭa — a pupil of Kṛta.
Br. II. 35. 52.
text.7616:
Parikṣudrā — of the Taittirīya of the Yajur Veda.
Br. II. 35. 75.
text.7617:
Parikṣeptāpakañcuka — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 86.
text.7618:
Parigha — a son of Rukmakavaca, appointed over
Videha region with his brother Hari.
M. 44. 28. 29; Vā. 95. 28; Br. III. 70. 29.
text.7619:
Paricārayajñā — service being the sacrifice for Śūdras.
Vā. 57. 50.
text.7620:
Pariccheda — Pṛthvī, Ap, and Tejas, are Paricchinnas —
that could be distinguished; this is generally because of
amūrtatvam; while Vāyu and Ākāśa are Aparicchinnas on
account of amūrtatvam or sūkṣma, the characteristic of being
everywhere.
Vā. 49. 175.
text.7624:
Pariplava — the son of Sukhīnala and father of Sunaya.
Bhā. IX. 22. 42.
text.7627:
Parivan — one of the seven seers of the Svārociṣa epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 11.
text.7628:
Parivatsara (I) — the sun god;1 lord among the varṣas.2 1) Br. II. 21. 131; IV. 32. 15; Vā. 31. 38; 56. 20.
2) M. 141. 18;
167. 52.
text.7629:
Parivatsara (II) — the second year of the five year yuga,1
yuga of five years: Samvatsara, Parivatsara, Idvatsara,
Anuvatsara, and Vatsara;2 Agni, Surya, Soma, Vāyu and
Rudra respectively of the five years. 1) Vā. 31. 27; 50. 183; Br. II. 13. 114, 117, 126-7; Vi. II. 8. 72.
2) Bhā. III. 11. 14; V. 22. 7; M. 141. 18-19.
text.7630:
Parivaha (I) — a variety of wind controlling the Parjanya
clouds.
Vā. 51. 45.
text.7631:
Parivaha (II) — the sixth of the seven Maruts helping, the
Parjanya and Diggajas to rain dew;1 the chief of the seventh
Vātaskandha situated between the planets and Druva.2 1) Br. II. 22. 50; M. 163. 33; Vā. 67-120.
2) Br. III. 5. 89; Vā.
67. 120.
text.7632:
Parivāya — a Janapada of the Bhadra country.
Vā. 43. 20.
text.7633:
Parivitti — an unmarried man, when his younger
brother is married; ineligible for Śrāddha.
M. 16. 15.
text.7634:
Parivṛttā — a daughter of Ṛṣā brought forth oyster,
conch, aiṇeya, śambūka and different kinds of poison like
Kālakūṭa.
Br. III. 7. 414, 419-20; Vā. 69. 291, 296.
text.7635:
Pariveṣa — the circle round the sun and moon indi
cates danger to the Kingdom.
M. 233. 8.
text.7638:
Pariṣvaṅga — a son of Devakī killed by Kamsa; taken
to Dvārakā from Sutala by Kṛṣṇa, and after having been
seen by his parents, went to heaven.
Bhā. X. 85. 51-6.
text.7639:
Parīkṣit (I) — a son of Uttarā and Abhimanyu; birth of;
jātakarma by Yudhiṣṭhira by gifts of cows, gold and lands;
named Viṣṇurata as was born of Viṣṇu's grace; blessed by
Brahmanas to be like Ikṣvāku, Rāma, Śibi, Arjuna, and
so on;1 a great conqueror;2 with his capital at Hastināpura
was a sārvabhauma, a samrāṭ, and the foremost of the
Bhāgavatas;3 ruled the earth guided by Brahmanas; married
Irāvatī, daughter of Uttara and had four sons Janamejaya
and others; performed three aśvamedhas with Kṛpa as
preceptor; conquered Bhadrāśva, Ketumālā, and other coun
tries and took tributes from them; heard stories of Kṛṣṇa's
heroic deeds in those places; overheard conversation between
Dharma moving on one leg and the weeping Goddess of
Earth on the advent of Kali and at the departure of Kṛṣṇa
to Heaven; reached Sarasvatī where it flows towards the
east; saw a Vṛṣala in royal robes beating a white bull totter
ing on one foot and a cow bereft of calf shedding tears;
promised security of life to them; appreciation by Dharma
and Parīkṣit's answer; Kali in Vṛṣala's garb fell at his feet
and was asked to leave Brahmāvarta. But on request the
King permitted him to live in five unrighteous regions; dice,
wine, women, slaughter-house, and gold;4 once when he
went ahunting he felt thirsty and hungry and entered the
hermitage of a sage in meditation; As he was not welcomed
he threw a dead serpent on his neck and returned home;
the sage's boy got offended and cursed that the King be
dead by the bite of Takṣaka in a week; the sage who came
to know of it regretted his son's conduct as it was a great
punishment for a small offence;5 the King regretted his deed,
knew that the Brahmana's curse would come true and was
in a state of Prāyopaveśa, when he was visited by sages and
kings to whom he bowed; thither came Śuka whom the
king enquired as to the beneficial course to seek mokṣa;
requested Śuka to narrate the stories of Kṛṣṇa;6 heard the
whole of Bhāgavata Purāṇa from Śuka and thanked him for
enlightening him on nirvāṇa;7 knew of his coming death at
the hands of Takṣaka and prepared calmly to cast off his
body into Gangā to attain Hari's feet; sat in contemplation
in a detached spirit; bitten by Takṣaka, his body was reduc
ed to ashes by the poison; universal surprise and benediction
at the occurrence;8 from P. to Nanda's accession was a period
of 1500 years (1050 years Vi. P.: 1015 Wilson). Father of
Janamejaya and three other sons.9 1) Bhā. I. 4. 9-10; 7. 12; 12. 7-30; Br. III. 68. 21; Vā. 99. 249.
2) M. 50. 57.
3) Bhā. I. chh. 16 and 17 (whole).
4) Ib. ch. 18 whole.
5) Ib. ch. 19. 1-16, 32. 38; II. 8. 1-26; VIII. 1. 33.
6) Ib. XII. 6. 1-7.
7) Ib. II. 4. 2; XII. 6. 9-15; 12. 5-6.
8) Br. III. 74. 227, 230; M. 273.
36; Vi. IV. 19. 78; 20-1.
9) Vā. 99, 229, 423; Vi. IV, 19. 78; 20. I.
text.7640:
Parīkṣit (II) — a son of Kuru, childless.
Bhā. IX. 22. 4, 9; M. 50. 23; Vā. 99. 218.
text.7641:
Parīkṣit (III) — a son of Tāmasa Manu.
Br. II. 36. 49.
text.7642:
Parūṣaka — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 84.
text.7643:
Parūṣakasthali — between the hills Śamku, Kūṭa and
Vṛṣabha; Kinnaras, Caraṇas etc. live there.
Vā. 38. 63-5.
text.7644:
Parokṣa — a son of Anu.
Bhā. IX. 23. 1.
text.7645:
Parjanya(m) (I) — a name of Indra: God of rain (or
simply rain); created by Vāmadeva;1 to be worshipped in
house building.2 1) Bhā. I. 10. 4; II. 6. 7; IV. 14. 26. VI. 14. 35; X. 20. 5;
XII. 4. 7; M. 4. 29.
2) Ib. 253. 24.
text.7646:
Parjanya (II) — An Āditya and Lokapāla; the name of
the sun in the month of Tapasya (Phālguna): father of
Hiraṇyaroma.
Bhā. XII. 11. 40; Br. II. 21. 157; 23. 12; 30. 40; III. 3. 68;
8. 20; Vā. 50. 206; 66. 66; Vi. II. 10. 12.
text.7647:
Parjanya (III) — one of the important clouds raining
dew for the growth of corns;1 overlords of seas, rivers, clouds,
rains besides Āditya;2 they are under the control of wind,
Parivaha; they also carry the heavenly Gangā.3 1) Br. II. 22. 49.
2) Ib. III. 8. 14; Vā. 70. 13.
3) Ib. 51. 43-6.
text.7648:
Parjanya (IV) — a Parivaha and sage of the Raivata
epoch;1 attained heaven by tapas.2 1) Br. II. 36. 62; M. 9. 19; Vi. III. 1. 22.
2) M. 143. 39.
text.7650:
Parjanya (IV) — a son of Agni and Samhūti;1 his wife
Mānu and son Hiraṇyaroma.2 1) Vā. 28. 16.
2) Br. II. 11. 19.
text.7651:
Parjanya (VII) — a deity with the sun in the śarat season.
Vā. 52. 12.
text.7654:
Parṇacira — leaves as dress of mountain residents.
Vi. IV. 24. 96.
text.7655:
Parṇamāla — a Mt. in the Sālmalidvīpa: one of the
haunts of the Garuḍa family.
Br. III. 7. 453.
text.7657:
Parṇāśa — a R. from Ṛṣyavān;1 got transformed into a
girl and became the wife of Devavṛddha.2 1) M. 114. 23.
2) Br. III. 71. 7, 12.
text.7658:
Parṇinī — an apsaras coupled with Puñjikasthalā.
Br. III. 7. 14; Vā. 69. 4, 49.
text.7659:
Paryaṅka — 1000 hooded serpent shedding golden lustre
as bed of the Lord.
Vā. 24. 11, 17.
text.7660:
Paryāvartana — one of 28 hells for house-holders who do
not properly receive guests.
Bhā. V. 26. 7, 35.
text.7661:
Paryāsa — earth, equal to dyaus in size.
Vā. 50. 74-75.
text.7662:
Parvakāri — one who performs ceremonials intended for
festivals on ordinary days for gain.
Vā. 83. 64.
text.7663:
Parvata (I) — called on Bhīṣma lying on his death-bed.
Bhā. I. 9. 6.
text.7664:
Parvata (II) — a son of Kaśyapa; brother of Nārada and
a devaṛṣi;1 a sage born in Nārada hill in Plakṣa.2 1) Br. II. 19. 9; Vā. 61. 85; 70. 79.
2) Br. II. 35. 95; III. 7. 27;
8. 86; Vā. 30. 86; 49. 8.
text.7665:
Parvata (III) — a god of the Haritā gaṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 84.
text.7667:
Parvata (V) — the son of Paurṇamāsa.
Vi. I. 10. 6.
text.7668:
Parvatas — hills sprang out of the scatterings of the
Pralayāgni after the earth was rescued by the Varāha; for
having sat firm (acalās); Parvatas with slopes (Parvas)
swallowed in and hence giri; stony and hence śila.
Vā. 6. 30-32.
text.7669:
Parvatānucara — one of the ten branches of the Haritā
group of devas.
Vā. 100. 89.
text.7670:
Parvatāstram — used by the Matsya King against
Paraśurāma.
Br. III. 38. 44.
text.7672:
Parvaśa — a son of Pūrṇamāsa and Sarasvatī; the lord of
all gaṇas; his wife, Parvaśā; had Puṇyā and Sumatī as
daughters-in-law;1 father of Yajurdhāma and Stambha
Kāśyapa.2 1) Vā. 28. 10-12, 33.
2) Br. II. 11. 13.
text.7673:
Parvaśā — the wife of Parvaśa;1 mother of Yajurdhāma
and Stambha Kāśyapa.
Br. II. 11. 15. Vā. 28. 13. 1) Br. II. 11. 15.
text.7674:
Parvasandhi — the last day of the Kṛṣṇa and Sukla
Pakṣas;1 fit for the rituals of agniādhāna.2 1) M. 141. 28, 32.
2) Vā. 56. 34.
text.7675:
Palam — a measurement: thirteen palas make one
Māgadha measure, (jalaprastha-Vā. P.): [N.B. 40 palas
make at present one Madras measure.]
Br. IV. 1. 217; Vā. 100. 219; Vi. VI. 3. 8.
text.7676:
Palalaka — a son of Hālāhala and father of Pulindasena;
a King.
Vi. IV. 24. 47.
text.7678:
Palāśā — a R. of the Ketumālā country.
Vā. 44. 18.
text.7679:
Palāśinī — a R. of the Śuktimat.
Br. II. 16. 38; Vā. 45. 107.
text.7680:
Pallavas — a southern tribe.
M. 114. 40; Br. II. 16. 47.
text.7681:
Palhavas (Pahlavas) 1 — defeated by Sagara; allowed to
escape with moustaches.2 1) Vā. 88, 122; 136; 45. 118; 58. 82, 93, 107.
2) Br. III. 48. 26,
19, 44.
text.7682:
Pavana (I) — a Mt. on the west of Meru
Bhā. V. 16. 27.
text.7683:
Pavana (II) — a name of Vāyu;1 in Indraś host, with
Ankuśa for his weapon.2 1) Bhā. VI. 3. 14; Vi. V. 21. 16.
2) M. 148. 83.
text.7684:
Pavana (III) — a son of Uttama Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 23.
text.7685:
Pavana (IV) — a son of Vasiṣṭha and Ūrjā.
Br. II. 11. 41.
text.7687:
Pavanapuram — description of; here are Dvādaśārkas
Vālukeśvara, eleven Rudras, Hanumān and four Kuṇḍas; a
tīrtha; bath in which rids one of Brahmahatti doṣa.
Vā. 59. 110.-30; 60. 68.
text.7688:
Pavanam vratam — the performer of it becomes a Rāja.
M. 101. 78.
text.7691:
Pavamāna (Pāvamāna) — a son of Svāhā and a Lauki
kāgni; thought of as nirmanthya by poets; it is the gārha-
patya.
Bhā. IV. 1. 60. Br. II. 24. 15. Vā. 29. 2, 10. Vi. I. 10. 15.
text.7692:
Pavamāna (II) — a son of Vijitāśva and an Agni in
previous birth born thus because of Vasiṣṭha's curse.
Bhā. IV. 24. 4.
text.7693:
Pavamāna (III) — a son of Medhātithi of Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 25.
text.7694:
Pavarga (I) — Jayinī: a Śakti on Śarvarohaharacakra.
Br. IV. 37. 6.
text.7695:
Pavarga (II) — the right feet of the Veda.
Vā. 104. 72.
text.7696:
Pavitravatī — a R. in Krauñcadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 21.
text.7697:
Pavitras (I) — Gods of the epoch of 14th Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 34; Vi. III. 2. 43.
text.7698:
Pavitras (II) (Paritras) — one of the five devagaṇas of
the 14th Bhauta Manu: are the seven worlds.
Br. IV. 1. 106, 198. Vā. 100. 111-2.
text.7699:
Pavitrā (I) — a R. in Kuśadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 62. M. 122. 72.
text.7700:
Pavitrā (II) — a main stream of Kuśadvīpa.
Vi. I. 4. 43.
text.7701:
Paśu — born of Savitā: grāmya and āraṇya; killing of
except in Yajñas considered as himsā; sacrifice of, for preta,
bhūta, and gaṇas irreligious and sinful;1 the sages finding
many heads of cattle for sacrificial purposes by Indra com
plained about the himsā and said that himsā must be remov
ed from the sacrifices and that they could be performed only
with seeds and corns; there was a difference of opinion and
the sages referred the question to king Vasu; he called it
himsā and was punished; final conclusion that in killing
Paśu in a Yajña there was no himsā;2 fourteen kinds dis
tinguished.3 1) Bhā. VI. 18. 1; VII. 15. 7-10; XI. 10. 28; 21. 29-30; Vi. I. 5.
51-2.
2) Vā. 57. 92-114.
3) Br. IV. 6. 54; II. 32. 11-2, 16.
text.7703:
Paśupati (I) — fourth name of Śiva; the fifth tanu of
Agni; has pacikaśakti; wife Svāhā and son Skanda;1 hence
fire to be kept clean.2 1) Br. II. 10. 80; Vā. 27. 11, 53; 30. 89.
2) Br. II. 10. 13 and 45.
text.7704:
Paśupati (II) — see Rudra;1 the presiding deity of fire.2 1) M. 154. 485. Vi. I. 8. 6; V. 18. 56.
2) M. 162. 9; 265. 40.
text.7705:
Paśupāla — a name of Kārtavīrya.
M. 43. 27; Vā. 94. 24.
text.7706:
Paśubandham — Vedic sacrifices;1 in the chest of the
personified Veda.2 1) M. 246. 64.
2) Vā. 104. 83.
text.7708:
Paśuyajña — sacrifice incumbent on house-holders.
Br. IV. 6. 73.
text.7711:
Paśusoma — a sacrifice performed by Bharata.
Bhā. V. 7. 5.
text.7712:
Paśuhā — a son of Vṛṣa (Viṣa Vā. P.).
Br. III. 6. 34; 68. 33.
text.7713:
Paśuhiṃsā — in Yajña condemned by sages but justified
by Indra.
Br. II. 30. 17-18.
text.7715:
Paśvoṣadhi — Prajāpati after creating the eight deva
yonis with four kinds of serpents and of spirits, proceeded
to create birds and beasts; sheep from face, crows from
breast, cows from belly, and sides; from feet, horses,
elephants, śarabha, gavaya deer, camel, etc., from hairs,
vegetables, fruits and roots.
Vā. 9. 41-5.
text.7716:
Pahlavās — defeated by Paraśurāma;1 attacked by
Bāhu and defeated by Sagara;2 punished with wearing
moustaches;3 kingdom of4 1) Br. II. 31. 83; III. 41. 39.
2) Ib. III. 63. 120, 134.
3) Ib. III.
73. 108.
4) M. 121. 45; 144. 57; Vā. 45. 118; 58. 82.
text.7717:
Pāka — an Asura; resisted Indra and Mātali in Devāsura
war and was slain.
Bhā. VII. 2. 4; VIII. 11. 19, 22 and 28.
text.7718:
Pākayajña — Vidhāna of: to be observed by the husband
in his fire offerings in the Pumsavana (s.v.) vratam,1
prescribed for śūdras.2 1) Bhā. VI. 19. 22: Vā. 29. 38.
2) Vi. III. 8. 34; VI. 2. 23.
text.7719:
Pākaśāsana — Indra, the lord of rains;1 fought with the
Asuras and got the full share of Yajñas for devas and
deprived them of their place.2 1) Br. III. 63. 99; 66. 35; M. 7. 51. Vā. 88. 85.
2) Ib. 97. 93.
text.7720:
Pākhaṇḍas (also Pākhaṇḍins) — deities of: kites, vul
tures, cranes, and banyan trees, not accepted by Ārya reli
gion;1 Shine in Kali and oppose Vedic religion;2 created by
Indra; followers of Śiva according to the curse of Bḥṛgu.
Two kinds, one naked and the other wearing red clothes;3
Vṛddhaśrāvaka, Nirgrantha, Śākya, Ājivaka and Kārpaṭa
are some sects: vanquished by Pramati in a Devāsura war.4 1) Bhā. V. 14. 29.
2) V. 20. 8 and 23.
3) IV. 2. 28 and 30; 19.
24-25, 35-36.
4) Br. II. 31. 53, 66 and 80; III. 14. 39; 74. 207.
text.7722:
Pāñcajanī — one of the wives of Dakṣa who bore him
1000 sons, Haryaśvas (s.v.).
M. 5. 4.
text.7723:
Pāñcajanya — the conch of Kṛṣṇa, blown by him at the
siege of Mathurā by Jarāsandha.
Vi. V. 21. 30; Bhā. VIII. 4. 19; X. 50. 24[1-2]; 51 (v) 27; 59. 6;
XI. 27. 27.
text.7724:
Pāñcāla (I) — (c) a kingdom of the north.
Bhā. I. 10. 34. Br. II. 16. 46. M. 121. 50.
text.7725:
Pāñcāla (II) — a common name for the five sons of
Bharmyāśva (Haryaśva Vi. P.) and who were capable of
ruling five kingdoms.
Bhā. IX. 21. 32-33; 22. 3; Vi. IV. 19. 59.
text.7726:
Pāñcālas — their king was Drupada;1 enlisted by Jarā
sandha against the Yadus; placed on the south by Jarā
sandha in his siege of Gomanta,2 svayamvara of Draupadī
at their capital;3 Kṛṣṇa met the Pāṇḍavas in disguise at their
capital;4 heard of Kṛṣṇa going to Mithilā and met him with
presents.5 1) Bhā. X. 52. 11[8].
2) Ib. X. [50 (v) 2]; 52. 11[8].
3) Ib. X.
57. 10[1-2].
4) Ib. X. 58. 9. [1 and 2].
5) Ib. X. 86. 20.
text.7727:
Pāñcālādhipati — married Kṛtvī daughter of Śuka;1 Nīla
subdued by Ugrāyudha.2 1) M. 15. 9.
2) Ib. 49. 79. 78.
text.7728:
Pāñcālānvayam — the Pāncāla line of kings, 27 in
number.
M. 20. 20; 272. 15; 273. 73.
text.7729:
Pāṭalā (I) — the goddess enshrined at Puṇḍravardhana.
M. 13. 35.
text.7730:
Pāṭalā (II) — a tīrtha sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 33.
text.7731:
Pāṇigraha — the chief function in a marriage; Deva
yānī claims that this happened to her by Yayāti when he
rescued her from the well;1 reference to the marriage
between Śiva and Umā;2 according to fire rite;3 of Śiva at
Kāñci.4 1) M. 30. 21.
2) Ib. 60. 15.
3) Ib. 154. 484.
4) Br. IV. 39. 61.
text.7735:
Pāṇipātra(i) — a class of Piśācas eating bali with heads
of the elephants, camels and raised napes.
Br. III. 7. 379, 383, 394; Vā. 69. 264.
text.7737:
Pāṇḍara — a hill west of the Śitoda.
Vā. 36. 28; 38. 49.
text.7738:
Pāṇḍavas (Pāṇḍus) — The five sons of Pāṇḍu (s.v.);
rumour that they were burnt in the house of lac built by
Duryodhana; their escape in the disguise of Brahmanas; met
by Kṛṣṇa in a Potter's hall in Pāñcāla city;1 married
Draupadi;2 Kṛṣṇa sent Akrūra to Hastināpura to find out
their position; seen by Akrūra; Akrūra pleaded their cause
with Dhṛtarāṣṭra and reported his designs to Kṛṣṇa and
Rāma;3 praised the heroic exploits of Kṛṣṇa;4 Kṛṣṇa who
heard them burnt down, performed obsequies to.5 1) Bhā. X. 57. 1, 10[2-4]; Br. III. 71. 65.
2) Vā. 99. 240, 246.
3) Ib. X. 48. 32-25; 49. 2, 19 and 31.
4) Ib. IX. 24. 63; Vā. 77. 48.
5) Ib. 96. 63.
text.7739:
Pāṇḍaveśam — a tīrtham on the Narmadā.
M. 191. 61-2.
text.7740:
Pāṇḍu (I) — a Rājaṛṣi: one of the three sons of Vicitra
vīrya; (Kṛṣṇadvaipāyana — Vā. P.) born to Vyāsa; married
two wives, Kunti alias Prthā, sister of Vasudeva and Mādri;
father of the five Pāṇḍavas, who were born to Kunti by
favour of Gods, himself being prevented by a curse from
having sexual intercourse; on his death Pṛthā with the
young children underwent a lot of difficulties.
Bhā. I. 4. 7; IX. 22. 25, 27; 24. 36; I. 9. 13. M. 46. 8; 50. 47-9;
Vā. 96. 150; 99. 242-3; 112. 45; Vi. IV. 14. 34; 20. 38-42.
text.7742:
Pāṇḍu (III) — a son of Vidhāta and Āyatī; married
Puṇḍarīkā and had a son Dyutimān.
Vā. 28. 5, 35.
text.7743:
Pāṇḍukūpam — in the Piṇḍārakatata noted for śrāddha
offerings.
Br. III. 13. 37.
text.7744:
Pāṇḍubhūmi — the earth in the second talam.
Br. II. 20. 14, 25.
text.7745:
Pāṇḍura — a Mt. in the Bhāratavarṣa;1 residence of the
Vīdyādharas.2 1) Br. II. 16. 21; Vā. 45. 91.
2) Ib. 39. 60.
text.7746:
Pāṇḍuraka — a Nāga having his city in the third talam.
Br. II. 20. 29; Vā. 50. 28.
text.7748:
Pāṇḍuviśāla — a tīrtha in the Pañcavanam.
Vā. 77. 99.
text.7749:
Pāṇḍuśilā — on the slope of the Himālayas; sporting
ground of Skanda.
Vā. 41. 42; 112. 44.
text.7750:
Pāṇḍya (I) — a son of Āndira and chief of the Pāṇḍya
deśa.
Br. III. 74. 6; M. 48. 5.
text.7751:
Pāṇḍya (II) — one of the four sons of Janāpīḍa; his
state, Pāṇḍyadeśa.
Vā. 99. 6.
text.7752:
Pāṇḍyas — a southern tribe;1 Kingdom of.2 1) Br. II. 16. 56. M. 114. 46; Vā. 45. 124.
2) M. 163. 72.
text.7753:
Pāṇḍyaja — a Rājaṛṣi who attained heaven by tapas.
Br. II. 30. 40.
text.7754:
Pātakam — to kill one to advance one's own interest is
sin; but not so, if done for the sake of many.
Vā. 62. 161-2.
text.7755:
Pātālasthas — the Asuras whom Kārtavīrya defeated
by crossing the ocean; seeing him the great Uragas stood
dumb-founded like the plantain stem tossed about by the
winds.
Vā. 94. 30-4.
text.7756:
Pātāla — (Sutalam): the nether-world where live the
Lords of Nāgaloka with their hoods of jewels; at the bottom
of this region lives Śeṣa;1 of golden colour, residence of Bali
having been given by Vāmana as also of Mucukunda,
Daityas and Asuras; women of;2 sacred to Parameśvarī;3
when Śukra wanted to go to the camp of the Devas the
Asuras threatened to leave for P.;4 of seven regions below
the earth;5 destroyed by Rudra's flame in the dissolution.6 1) Bhā. II. 1. 26; 5. 41; V. 24. 7 and 31; 25. 1; M. 154. 197; 163.
91; 249. 16; Vā. 49. 164; 97. 18; 98. 80 and 86; 100. 157; Vi. II. 5.
13; VI. 8. 48.
2) Br. II. 19. 172; 20. 13-15; 42. 5; III. 36. 4; 53. 11;
54. 12; 69. 30; IV. 1. 153; 38. 35. M. 43. 33; 246. 69; Vā. 50. 12;
41 ff.
3) M. 13. 39.
4) Ib. 47. 68. Vi. I. 9. 111. IV. 4. 19.
5) Vi. II.
5. 1-12; IV. 4. 19; V. 1. 72;
6) Vi. VI. 3. 24-5.
text.7758:
Pātundhama — a Mt. of the Bhāratavarṣa.
Vā. 45. 91.
text.7759:
Pāthinam — a kind of fish used in the Śrāddhas.
M. 15. 34.
text.7760:
Pādapodyāpanam — (Vṛkṣotsava): dedication of trees
and shrubs; same as taḍāgavidhi; further oblations to Loka
pālas and Vanaspati, decoration of trees with golden fruits,
etc., to be given away to Brahmanas at the end; a festival in
honour of trees and plants; lasts four days; he who does it
attains heaven and is rarely returned to earth.1 If trees
laugh or weep or flower in a wrong season they should be
propitiated.2 1) M. 59. 1-18.
2) Ib. ch. 232 (whole)
text.7761:
Pādikas — the time of the night, calculated from the
moment of the moon.
Vā. 66. 45.
text.7762:
Pādukam — sandals to be given in vṛkṣotsavam; to be
given as gift along with light, umbrella, seat, etc.
M. 59. 14; 70. 48; 275. 25.
text.7763:
Pādma — a name of Brahmā.
Bhā. I. 18. 19.
text.7764:
Pādma kalpa — succeeds Brāhma kalpa, then the lotus
comes out of Hari's navel.
Bhā. II. 10. 47; III. 11. 35; Vi. I. 3. 27-8.
text.7765:
Pādmapurāṇa — (Pādmam): one of the 18 Purāṇas
and comprising 55000 ślokas;1 he who copies and presents
it with a golden lotus in the month of Jyeṣṭha (Āḍi) attains
the fruit of an aśvamedha sacrifice;2 contains a description
of Narasimha in 18000 slokas;3 to be read every parva.4 1) Bhā. XII. 7. 23; 13. 4; Vā. 104. 9. Vi. III. 6. 21.
2) M. 53.
14-15.
3) Ib. 53. 60.
4) Ib. 290. 17.
text.7767:
Pānam — the region of adharma and of Kali; drinking
liquor by a king is to be avoided.2
^1 Bhā. I. 17. 38. 2) M. 220. 8.
text.7768:
Pānam — the hamlet next in rank above kheta
Br. II. 7. 110.
text.7769:
Pānī — a R. of the Śālmalidvīpa.
Vā. 49. 42.
text.7770:
Pānnagāri — a pupil of Bāṣkali.
Br. II. 35. 6.
text.7772:
Pāpās — kinds of sins; Niryāsam (drinking of the milk
of trees) Kalamjam (taking opium), Kalingam, Gṛmyjanam
(eating garlic), Chatrākam (eating of mushroom?), Mahā
kośātakī, Mallika (dealing in jasmine), use of the nut of the
tree Katakam, and Umbaram (felling of fig trees), Kaya
kam? Vārtākam (eating brinjal), taking of pot-herbs, of
bimbi fruits, of lambika, misappropriation of public funds
(puragrāmanga), misuse of the special Vaiśya funds, resi
dence in a kugrāma, profession of a physician, trafficking in
women, living by arms, sale of oily foods, eating food from
cowherds,1 and eating without guest;2 brahmicide and teach
ing of Vedas for money;3 threefold, arising from speech, mind
and body.4 1) Br. IV. 8. 41-49.
2) Ib. IV. 2. 161; Vi. II. 6. 6-29.
3) Br. III.
14. 43; 15. 48.
4) Vā. 18. 2.
text.7773:
Pāmarācāra — the customs of barbarians; Asura Viśukra
spoke of Deva's ācāras.
Br. IV. 21. 32.
text.7774:
Pāṃśava (Pāmśus) — a clan of Piśācas having hands
above, as also hairs, and throwing out dust from their body.
Br. III. 7. 379, 383, 39. Vā. 69. 272.
text.7775:
Pāṃśumatī — a class of Piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 379.
text.7776:
Pāra (I) — a son of Rucirāśva and father of Nīpa and
Pṛthusena.
Bhā. IX. 21. 24-25.
text.7777:
Pāra (II) — one of the three sons of Samara
M. 49. 54; Vā. 99. 177; Vi. IV. 19. 41.
text.7778:
Pāra (III) — a son of Pṛthuṣeṇa, and father of Nīla
Vā. 99. 174; Vi. IV. 19. 37-8.
text.7779:
Pāras — Gods of the ninth Manvantara.
Bhā. VIII. 19. 19. Vi. III. 2. 21.
text.7780:
Pāraṇas — Trayārṣeyaṣ: no marriage alliances with
Paurṇamāsa and Agastya.
M. 202. 4.
text.7781:
Pāradas (I) — a tribe of a northern kingdom.
Br. II. 16. 48. M. 114. 41. Vā. 47. 47, 58. 82; 88. 122; 98. 107.
text.7782:
Pāradas (II) — a kingdom of the east watered by the
Ganges;1 noted for horses;2 defeated by Sagara;3 attacked
by Bāhu;4 punished with shaving of hairs5 and allowed to
have their beards; deprived of their Kṣatriya rights of Vedic
study and sacrifice; became Mlecchas.6 1) Br. II. 18. 50; M. 121. 45; 144. 57.
2) Br. II. 31. 83; III. 48.
26, 29.
3) Ib. III. 73. 108; IV. 16. 16; Vi. IV. 3. 42.
4) Br. III. 63.
120.
5) Ib. III. 63, 134. 139.
6) Vi. IV. 3. 47-8.
text.7783:
Pāraśarya — Kauthuma: composed of six samhitas.
Vā. 61. 41.
text.7787:
Pārāvata (I) — also Parāvatās: a deva gaṇa of Manu
Svārociṣa; 12 in number, Praceta, Viśvadeva, Samanja,
Ajihma, Arimardana, Āyurdāna, Mahāmanā, Divyamāna,
Ajeya, Yavīyam, Hotā and Yajva; these are all Vāsiṣṭhas
and drinkers of the soma juice.
Br. II. 36. 8, 14.
text.7790:
Pārāśara(i) — a disciple of Bhāṣkali who gave him the
third śākhā of the Ṛg Veda.
Br. II. 34. 27. Vā. 60. 26.
text.7791:
Pārāśarya — a pupil of Kṛta.
Br. II. 35. 54.
text.7793:
Pārijāta (I) — a heavenly plant; Satyabhāmā saw it in
Indra's Nandana and asked Kṛṣṇa to take it home; Kṛṣṇa
refused as it was once taken from the milk-ocean and by the
consent of the gods given to Indra and to remove it was to
face a war with him; still Satyabhāmā persisted and Kṛṣṇa
yielding to her placed it on the Garuḍa; took it to the earth
against Indra's will and placed it in Satybhāmā's garden; the
watchmen objected and reported to Indra; war about the
Pārijāta between the Gods and Kṛṣṇa; a compromise to be
returned after Kṛṣṇa's decease;1 rejoiced by Dvārakā
citizens.2 The tree in Śivaloka, that came out of the churn
ing of the ocean.3 1) Bhā. III. 15. 19; IV. 6. 14; 30. 32; VIII. 11. 10; X. 37. 16,
68. 35; 59. 39-40; [65 (v) 21-36], [37-51]; 66 (v); [67 (v) 1-16, 26],
[34,] [45,]; Ib. X. 68. 35. Vi. V. 30. 32, 80; 38. 7.
2) Ib. V. 31. 1-11;
35. 25:
3) Br. III. 32. 6; IV. 9. 70; Vā. 106. 74; Vi. I. 9. 95.
text.7794:
Pārijāta (II) — a monkey chief and son of Śveta.
Br. III. 7. 181 236.
text.7795:
Pārijāta (III) — (Pariyatra) a Mt. west of the Śitoda.
Vā. 36. 29; 42. 54.
text.7796:
Pārijātavanam — of Mahendra, in Śītānta Mt.; descrip
tion of.
Vā. 39. 10-26.
text.7799:
Pāriplava — the son of Śukhībala and father of Sunaya.
Vi. IV. 21. 12.
text.7800:
Pāribhadra — a territorial division of Śālmalidvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 9.
text.7801:
Pāriyātra (I) — Mt. a hill in Bhāratavarṣa and on the
west of the Meru; a Kulaparvata;1 the place where Tāraka
performed penance;2 gives rise to many rivers.3 1) Bhā. V. 16. 27; 19. 16; Br. II. 16. 19. M. 114. 18; 148. 7-10;
Vā. 45. 89; Vi. II. 2. 43; 3. 3.
2) M. 162. 6; 163, 80.
3) Vā. 45. 98.
text.7802:
Pāriyātra (II) — son of Anīha and father of Balasthala
(Bala Bhā. P.).
Bhā. IX. 12. 2.
text.7804:
Pāriyātra (IV) — the son of Ahīnaga and father of Dala.
Br. III. 63. 204.
text.7806:
Pāriyātraka — the son of Rūru and father of Devala.
Vi. IV. 4. 106.
text.7807:
Pārtha — Arjuna;1 married Subhadrā and got by her
Abhimanyu.2 1) Br. III. 71. 178; M. 50. 56; 246. 93; Vi. V. 12. 19 etc.
2) Vā.
96. 176; 99. 249.
text.7810:
Pārthiva (II) — one of the three fires; it was so called
when (1/4) of the night of Brahmā was remaining.
Vā. 53. 5-7.
text.7811:
Pārthivacchāyā — the shadow of the earth.
Vā. 53. 63.
text.7812:
Pārthivam — also Pavana; a kind of fire.
Br. II. 24. 6.
text.7813:
Pārthivam vratam — vow of kings to support all kinds
of their people.
M. 226. 8.
text.7815:
Pārvaṇam (śrāddham) — done in Parvas without the
invocation of deities; three fold; those eligible and those in
eligible to be fed on the occasion; of the eligibles the family
and gotra must have been known; they must be well
behaved and going in the path of virtue; friends and pre
ceptors, grandsons, sons-in-law, uncles and other relations,
somayājins, vaiyākaraṇas, mīmāmsakas, sāmaga Brahma
cāris are eligible; the ineligibles include the unrighteous, the
diseased, bastards, aśvapālas, the mad, the self-conceited,
the deceitful, the hypocritical, temple priests, etc., also
Mlecchas, Lingins, Triśaṅkus, Barbaras, Drāviḍas, etc.
They must be informed a day previous to the śrāddha; other
details;1 a dead person is entitled for share in the Pārvaṇa
after sapiṇḍīkaraṇam.2 1) M. 16. 5-51.
2) Ib. 18. 16.
text.7816:
Pārvatikā — a R. sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 56.
text.7817:
Pārvatī (I) — Umā, wife of Śiva, attained half body of
Śiva by virtue of the 108 names of the Devī;1 (Ambā), the
family deity of the Vidarbhas; present when Śiva gave his
missile to Arjuna;2 conceived true love even as a girl;3 went
with Śiva to have a look at the Mohinī form of Viṣṇu;4 once
when she was sitting unclad on the lap of Śiva there came
some sages to see the Lord; ashamed she got herself clothed;
to please her Śiva said that any male who entered that place
thereafter would become a female;5 presented Pṛthu with
a sword Śatacandra;6 prayed to by Rukminī to get Kṛṣṇa
for her husband; to her shrine Rukminī went by foot and
offered worship for the hand of Kṛṣṇa;7 Vṛka's aim to take
her after killing Śiva;8 prevented the enraged Śiva from
killing Bhṛgu;9 saw Mārkaṇḍeya engaged in tapas.10 A
Śakti;11felt for Vināyaka losing his teeth through Paraśurāma
and appealed to Śiva who remembered Kṛṣṇa. The latter
came with Rādhā and consoled her by addressing on
Gaṇeśa's greatness. 1) M. 12. 9; 13. 51 and 60; 85. 6; 183. 14; 187. 44; Vā. 54. 20;
108. 51; 112. 35; Vi. V. 32. 11-15.
2) Bhā. I. 15. 12; X. 52. 42.
3) Ib. X. 60. 47.
4) Ib. VIII. 12. 2 and 25.
5) Ib. IX. 1. 29-32.
6) Ib. IV. 15. 17; VI. 17. 11-12.
7) Ib. X. 53. 25, 39-40 and 44-49.
8) Ib. X. 88. 23.
9) Ib. X. 89. 7.
10) Ib. XII. 10. 3 and 35.
11) Br.
II. 25. 23; III. 41. 38, 50; 42. 7, 17; 44. 28; IV. 6. 8, 30, 38; 10. 41, 42.
text.7818:
Pārvatī (II) — a name of the R. Nandā.
Vā. 49. 92.
text.7819:
Pārvatī (III) — (alias Vijayā); wife of Sahādeva and
mother of Suhotra.
Bhā. IX. 22. 31.
text.7821:
Pārvatīpriya — is Śiva; with Rudra gaṇas.
Br. IV. 2. 258; Vā. 101. 321.
text.7822:
Pārvatīmāya — applied by Maya who noticed the
showers of snow and waters by moon and Varuṇa in the
Tārakāmaya; warded off by Gadādhara; to the solace of all
devas.
M. 176. 25, 34.
text.7823:
Pārvateyas — a tribe; enlisted by Jarāsandha against
the Yadus.
Bhā. X. [50 (v) 4]. Vā. 58. 81.
text.7825:
Pārśvamardi — a son of Balarāma.
Br. III. 71. 166.
text.7826:
Pārśvi (I) — a son of Balarāma.
Br. III. 71. 166.
text.7828:
Pārṣadas — Śivagaṇas with awkward forms; fought with
Tāraka and Māya in the battle of Tripuram.
M. 135. 51, 73.
text.7829:
Pārṣṇigrāha — the neighbour in the rear of the king's
enemy; attacking him gives a good occasion to the king to
start aggression; a king whose rear is not clear is not to
engage in an aggressive expedition;1 Śiva was to Bṛhaspati
during the Tārakā war;2 Viśanga in Bhaṇḍa's war;3 Uśana
acted to Soma, as in the Tārakāmaya war.4 1) M. 240. 2, 4;
2) Br. III. 65. 32.
3) Ib. IV. 25. 14.
4) Vi. IV. 6. 12.
text.7830:
Pālaka (I) — the son of Pṛadyota and father of Viśākha
yupa.
Bhā. XII. 1. 3.
text.7831:
Pālaka (II) — a son of Bālaka, ruled for 28 years
(24 Vā. P.).
Br. III. 74. 125; M. 272. 3. Vā. 99. 312.
text.7833:
Pālapañjara — Mt. where there is a place of pilgrimage
known as Kumāra Kośala.
Vā. 77. 37.
text.7834:
Pālamañjara — Mt. the hill with Sampāraka tīrtha.
Br. III. 13. 37.
text.7835:
Pālāśapātram — the vessel of palāśa wood used by the
trees for milking the cow-earth.
M. 10. 27.
text.7838:
Pāvaka (I) — (Agni) a son of Svāhā;1 as husband of
Gangā;2 Lord of Vasus;3 also known as Vaidyuta.4 1) Bhā. IV. I. 60; Br. III. 8. 5; Vā. 53. 97, 30; Vi. I. 9, 63;
10. 15.
2) Vā. 2. 17.
3) Ib. 70. 5; Vi. I. 22. 3.
4) Br. I. 2. 17;
II. 12 2 and 33.
text.7839:
Pāvaka (II) — a son of Vijitāśva and an Agni in pre
vious birth born thus through Vasiṣṭha's curse.
Bhā. IV. 24. 4.
text.7841:
Pāvana (I) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Mitravindā.
Bhā. X. 61. 16.
text.7842:
Pāvana (II) — a son of Dyutimān and king of Pāvana
deśa.
Br. II. 14. 22, 25.
text.7843:
Pāvanaka — a Mt. of the Krauñcadvīpa.
M. 122. 81. 85.
text.7844:
Pāvanī — Nandā, one of the three branches of the
Gangā going to the east;1 wife of Havyavāhana.2 1) Br. II. 12. 16; 18. 40, 56-7; M. 121. 40; 122. 31; Vā. 47. 38
and 53.
2) Ib. 29. 14.
text.7845:
Pāvamāna — a son of Svāhā.
Br. II. 12. 2.
text.7846:
Pāvamānam — the mantra of the Ṛg Vedins, to be
recited in tank ritual relating to the digging of tanks.
M. 58. 34.
text.7849:
Pāśā — a R. from the Pāriyātra.
Br. II. 16. 28.
text.7851:
Pāśupatam (I) — the astram of Śiva.
Br. III. 31. 39; 32. 57; 34. 34; 40. 65. IV. 29. 140.
text.7852:
Pāśupatam (II) — a tīrtha on the Pārvatīkā, sacred to
Pitṛs.
M. 22. 56.
text.7853:
Pāśupatayoga — the earliest form of yoga established;
even Gods like Indra practised this and got wealth consti
tuting aṇimā, mahimā, laghimā, prāpti, garimā, prākānujam,
īśitvam, vāśitvam, and amaratvam;1 one who practises it at
Benares is rid of the cycle of births and deaths.2 1) Br. II. 27. 116, 128; Vā. 1. 195.
2) M. 182. 12.
text.7855:
Pāśupatās — followers of the Pāśupata yogam.
Br. III. 32. 5.
text.7856:
Pāśupālyam — cattle raising and tending not in Puṣka
dvīpa;1 duty of the Vaiśyas.2 1) Br. II. 19. 121; Vā. 49. 117.
2) Br. II. 7. 162; Vi. III. 8. 30.
text.7857:
Pāṣaṇḍas — heretics in Kali;1 came out of the Devāśura
war — Nirgranthas, Kārpaṭas and Nagnas;2 not fit for ritual
purposes;3 one connected with temple worship must not be
a member of the Pāṣaṇḍa family;4 their deities not to be
honoured;5 quelled by Pramati, God incarnate;6 put down
by Kalki;7 sell Vedas and tīrthas;8 should be given up by a
tīrthayātri.9 1) Br. IV. 33. 60; M. 99. 14; 144. 40; Vi. III. 18. 22.
2) Vā.
78. 30.
3) M. 57. 6; 69. 34; Vi. III. 18. 70-103; VI. 1. 37 etc.
4) M.
265. 3.
5) Ib. 267. 34.
6) Ib. 144. 54.
7) Ib. 47. 249; 273. 27.
8) Vā.
58. 40, 52, 65.
9) Ib. 99. 396; 105. 42.
text.7860:
Piṅgala (I) — one of the eleven Rudras.
M. 153. 19; 171. 39.
text.7861:
Piṅgala (II) — a door-keeper of the Sun God.
M. 261. 5.
text.7862:
Piṅgala (III) — a Mt. west of the Śitoda.
Vā. 36. 27.
text.7863:
Piṅgalā (I) — an aged prostitute of the Videha city; her
story as narrated by Avadhūta to Yadu is as follows; she
spent her life as a public woman living by earning money
