M. 7. 7-26; 291. 3.
text.9989:
Madayantī — the queen of Sandāsa; gave birth to Aśmaka
through Vasiṣṭha with the assent of the King; prevented her
husband from returning the curse on Vasiṣṭha.
Bhā. IX. 9. 18, 24 and 38; Vi. IV. 4. 56, 67-72.
text.9990:
Madirā (I) — one of Vasudeva's wives and mother of
Nanda and other sons.
Bhā. IX. 24. 45, 48. Br. III. 71. 161, 171-2. Vā. 96. 160,
Vi. IV. 15. 18, 23.
text.9991:
Madirā (II) — came out of the churning of the ocean of
milk.1 Balarāma indulged in.2 1) M. 251. 2.
2) Vi. IV. 13. 157.
text.9992:
Madirā (III) — an epithet of Vāruṇi.
Vi. V. 25. 3.
text.9993:
Madirāsindhu — also Surāsindhu, Sindhurāja, Surām
budhi, Sudhāmbudhi: a deity in the Kiricakraratha.
Br. IV. 20. 73; 28. 57, 62, 87-8.
text.9994:
Madotkaṭa — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 88.
text.9995:
Madotkaṭā — a goddess enshrined at Caitraratha.
M. 13. 28.
text.9998:
Madyam — Liquor: Brahmanas forbidden to take it:
prāyascitta for it: used in the worship of the mother goddess
and the Śaktis.
Br. IV. 7. 66, 73-6; 8. 41.
text.9999:
Madras — an ancient tribe: enlisted by Jarāsandha
against the Yadus, their king went to Syamantapañcaka for
the solar eclipse
M. 208. 5; Bhā. X. [54 (V) 4] 82. 13.
text.10000:
Madraka — a son of Śibi; Kingdom of, Mādrakas.
Bhā. IX. 23. 3; Br. III. 74. 23; Vi. IV. 18. 10. Vā. 99.
23-24.
text.10001:
Madrakas — a tribe; turned into a ruling caste by
Purañjaya;1 followed Bhīma in his conquests;2 established
by Viśvasphāṇi.3 1) M. 114. 41; Bhā. XII. 1. 36.
2) Ib. X. 72. 13.
3) Br. III.
74. 191.
text.10002:
Madradeśa — ruled by Purūravas in the Cākṣuṣaman
vantara.
M. 115. 7; 118. 48 and 77.
text.10004:
Madrā (I) — one of the ten wives of Atri: mother of
Soma.
Br. III. 8. 75.
text.10005:
Madrā (II) — a R. originating from the Vindhyas.
Vā. 45. 102.
text.10006:
Madrā (III) — a daughter of Ghṛtācī and Bhadrāśva.
Vā. 70. 68.
text.10007:
Madrā (IV) — one of the ten daughters of Raudrāśva.
Vā. 99. 125.
text.10008:
Madreśa — in Duryodhana's army: went to Syamanta
pañcaka for the solar eclipse.
Bhā. X. 78. [95 (V) 16]; 82. 26.
text.10009:
Madhu (I) — a son of Bindumān and Sanghā; his son
was Vīravrata.
Bhā. V. 15. 15.
text.10010:
Madhu (II) — the father of Asura Lavaṇa;1 killed by
Hari.2 1) Bhā. IX. 11. 14.
2) Ib. VII. 9. 37; X. 40. 17. Br. II. 37. 2;
III 63. 38; IV. 29. 75.
text.10011:
Madhu (III) — a son of Kārtavīryārjuna; he had a
hundred sons of whom Vṛṣni was the eldest.
Bhā. IX. 23. 27, 29; Vi. IV. 11. 21.
text.10012:
Madhu (IV) — a son of Devakṣatra (Devakṣetra M. P.
and Vi. P.) and father of Kuruvaśa (Puravasa M. P.)
(Kumāravamśa-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 24. 5; M. 44. 44; Vi. IV. 12. 42.
text.10013:
Madhu (V) — a son of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 90. 33.
text.10014:
Madhu (VI) — a month sacred to Dhātā;1 good for the
gift of the Varāha P.;2 the king of seasons; generally spring,
a kin of the God of Love;3 the month of Citra (Veda), the
first of the six ṛtus.4 1) Bhā. XII. 11. 33; M. 53. 41.
2) Ib. 154. 211.
3) Ib. 154. 256;
Vā. 30. 4; 50. 201.
4) Br. II. 13. 4, 9; Vā. 30. 8; 31. 49; 45. 27;
50. 201; 52. 5.
text.10015:
Madhu (VII) — an Ātreya and a sage of the Cākṣuṣa
epoch.
Br. II. 36. 78; Vā. 62. 66.
text.10016:
Madhu (VIII) — a son of Praheti: a Rākṣasa.
Br. III. 7. 91; Vā. 69. 165.
text.10017:
Madhu (IX) — a son of Khaśā and a Rākṣasa.
Br. III. 7. 133.
text.10018:
Madhu (X) — a son of Devana and father of Nandana,
Puruvasu Manu, and Manuvaśa.
Br. III. 70. 46; Vā. 95. 45.
text.10020:
Madhu (XII) — a son of Auttama Manu.
M. 9. 12.
text.10021:
Madhu (XIII) — a Rākṣasa who attacked Nārāyaṇa; was
slain by Viṣṇu.
M. 135. 49; 178. 6, 18.
text.10022:
Madhu (XIV) — a mind-born son of Lord Viṣṇu born
with Kaiṭabha representing rajas and tamas qualities;1 with
Kaiṭabha shook the lotus stand of Brahmā in the navel of
Viṣṇu lying in waters after interview with Rudra; then
Brahmā appealed to Viṣṇu in fear; Bhū, Bhuva and
Suva entered Brahmā; Viṣnu and Jiṣṇu fought with Madhu
Kaitabha when Brahmā acted as arbitrator; the battle con
tinued for thousands of years; Brahmā entered into con
templation when Mohini or Viṣṇumāya appeared to the
great grief of the Asuras; both were killed when Brahmā
asked for permission to create four kinds of creatures; with
a view to this he performed austerities when he was filled
with rage and tears out of which came wind, bile and kapha
besides poisonous serpents; Brahmā's grief knew no bounds,
and he swooned and lost his life; when Rudra appeared in
eleven forms out of his face, revived him and helped him in
his creation as his son.2 1) M. 170. 1.
2) Vā. 25. 30-80.
text.10024:
Madhu (XVI) — honey fit for ceremonies;1 used for the
ablution of deities;2 fit for piṇḍa at Gayā.3 1) M. 204. 5 and 7.
2) Ib. 266. 51, 55.
3) Vā. 30. 151; 56. 12;
105. 34.
text.10025:
Madhu (XVII) — a son of Lāngalī, the avatār of the
Lord.
Vā. 23. 200.
text.10026:
Madhu (XVIII) — a son of Vṛṣa; had a hundred sons of
whom Vṛṣṇi was the eldest.
Vi. IV. 11. 26-7, 29.
text.10027:
Madhu (XIX) — a son of Cākṣuṣa Manu.
Vi. III. 1. 28.
text.10028:
Madhus — a tribe whose Lord was Kṛṣṇa;1 related to
the Pāṇḍavas;2 defended Dvārakā;3 relieved by Kamsa's
death;4 heard of Kṛṣṇa's going to Mithilā and met him with
presents;5 their praise of the heroic deeds of Viṣṇu;6 fought
with their kinsmen and ended themselves.7 1) Bhā. I. 8. 42; 10. 26.
2) Ib. I. 14. 25; IX. 24. 63.
3) Ib. I. 11.
11.
4) Ib. X. 45. 15.
5) Ib. X. 86. 20.
6) Ib. IX. 24. 63.
7) Ib. XI.
30. 18.
text.10029:
Madhuka — a Bhārgava and Madhyamādhvaryu.
Br. II. 33. 16.
text.10030:
Madhukulyā — R. in Kuśadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 15; Vā. 109. 17; 112. 30.
text.10031:
Madhukṛṣṇas — the 14 śaktis attached to Vāsanta cakra.
Br. IV. 32. 53.
text.10032:
Madhucchandas — the middle one of the 101 sons of
Viśvāmitra;1 invited for the Rājasūya of Yudhiṣṭhira;2 a
sage;3 a Kauśika Brahmiṣṭha.4 1) Bhā. IX. 16. 29; Vi. IV. 7. 38.
2) Bhā. X. 74. 9; Vā. 91. 96.
3) Br. II. 32. 117; III. 66. 68.
4) M. 145. 112.
text.10034:
Madhudhenu — fit for gift during Viśokadvādaśi vratam.
M. 82. 19.
text.10035:
Madhunandi — a king; among the Angas after Nandana,
he succeeded. His brother was Nandiyaśas.
Vā. 99. 369.
text.10036:
Madhupa — an Ajita deva.
Br. II. 13. 94; Vā. 31. 7.
text.10037:
Madhuparkam — an offering of milk and honey;1 Para
śurāma was treated with it by Agastya.2 1) M. 230. 11.
2) Br. III. 35. 52.
text.10038:
Madhupātram — a wedding present of Indra to Kāmeś
vara.
Br. IV. 15. 22.
text.10039:
Madhupuri (Mathurā) — sacred to Hari;1 the capital of
the Yadus.2 1) Bhā. VII. 14. 31.
2) Ib. X. 1. 10.
text.10040:
Madhuphalā — a mythical tree in Uttarakuru yielding
clothes, jewels, etc.
Br. II. 15. 72; Vā. 45. 12.
text.10041:
Madhubrāhmaṇam — to be recited in a śrāddha.
M. 17. 39.
text.10042:
Madhumān — a Mt. west of the Śitoda.
Vā. 36. 28.
text.10043:
Madhurā — also Mathurā (s.v.).
Br. III. 49. 6; Vi. I. 12. 4; IV. 4. 101.
text.10045:
Madhuripu — an epithet of Kṛṣṇa.
Vi. IV. 13. 48.
text.10046:
Madhuruha — a son of Ghṛta Pṛṣṭha.
Bhā. V. 20. 21.
text.10047:
Madhuvanam — the region of Asura Madhu and his son
Lavaṇa;1 sacred to Hari on the bank of the Yamunā; here
Ambarīṣa offered prayers to Hari by abhiṣeka according to
mahābhiṣeka vidhi: Here Śatrughna killed Lavaṇa and
founded the city of Madhurā.2 1) Br. III. 63. 186; Vā. 88. 185.
2) Bhā. IX. 4. 30-31; 11. 14;
Vi. I. 12. 2-4.
text.10048:
Madhuśuklas — the fifteen śaktis attached to Vāsanta
cakra.
Br. IV. 32. 49-53.
text.10049:
Madhuśrī — a queen of Vasanta ṛtu.
Br. IV. 32. 23, 46.
text.10051:
Madhuhan (Madhusūdana) — a name of Hari.
Bhā. X. 6. 23.
text.10052:
Madhorvanam — (Madhuvana s.v.); the forest of
Madhu; reference to the city of Mathurā on the Yamunā;
the place where Dhruva performed tapas; was visited by
Hari to see Dhruva.
Bhā. I. 10. 26; IV. 8. 42 and 62; 9. 1.
text.10053:
Madhaureyas — a Janapada of the Ketumālā continent.
Vā. 44. 14.
text.10055:
Madhyadeśa(ya) (c) — the middle country to be con
quered by Kalki; a kingdom of Ikṣvāku;1 under Divākara
its capital was Ayodhyā;2 one of the three divisions of India.3 1) Br. III. 73. 107. M. 12. 19; Vā. 58. 81; 98. 106.
2) M. 114. 36;
271. 5.
3) Br. II. 31. 81; 35. 11; Vi. II. 3. 15.
text.10056:
Madhyandina — a son of Puṣpārṇa and Prabhā;1 a
Vājin.2 1) Bhā. IV. 13. 13.
2) Vā. 61. 25.
text.10057:
Madhyam — 1000 crores × prayutam (ayuṭam-Vā. P.).
Br. IV. 2. 98 and 102; Vā. 101. 98.
text.10058:
Madhyama (I) — the eighteenth kalpa; the beginning
of madhyama svara.
Vā. 21. 38.
text.10059:
Madhyama (II) — a name of a svara sacred to Dhaivata.
Va. 21. 39.
text.10060:
Madhyamagrāma — the middle scale in music; consists
of Śārṅgi, Pāvani and dṛṣṭāka — 20 different kinds in it.
Vā. 86. 38, 49.
text.10061:
Madhyama mārga — the middle path consisting of Ārṣa-
bhi, Govīthi and Jāradgavi.
Br. III. 3. 51.
text.10062:
Madhyamdina — a pupil of Yājñavalkya.
Br. II. 35. 28.
text.10064:
Madhyāhnā (II) — 12 to 18 nālikas;1 when the sun
passes three muhūrtas from Samgava.2 1) Vā. 50. 99; 56. 46.
2) Ib. 50. 172.
text.10066:
Madhvī — a R. from the lake Jayā.
M. 121. 71.
text.10067:
Mana (I) — the eleventh organ partaking of the
character of karma and jñāna; proceeds to create induced by
a desire to produce.
Br. II. 9. 1, 7; IV. 3. 22; M. 3. 21.
text.10069:
Mana (III) — a Sādhya god.
Br. III. 3. 16; Vā. 66. 15.
text.10070:
Mana (IV) — a Tuṣita god.
Br. III. 3. 19; Vā. 66. 18.
text.10071:
Mana (V) — a śālā adjoining Sahasrastambha śālā in
Śrīpuram; reputed for its amṛtavāpika; by drinking its water
yogis and siddhas became strong in body.
Br. IV. 35. 2-24.
text.10075:
Manavas — twelve sons of Brahmā with mantraśarīras.
Vā. 67. 6.
text.10076:
Manasa — the lake of the south.
Vā. 36. 16.
text.10080:
Manasyu (III) — a son of Mahānta.
Vi. II. 1. 39.
text.10081:
Manasyu (IV) — a son of Pravīra; father of Abhayada.
Vi. IV. 19. 1.
text.10083:
Manasvinī (I) — R. from lake Varcovan. (Sāyana
Vā. P.).
Br. II. 18. 66; Vā. 47. 63.
text.10084:
Manasvi(a)nī (II) — a daughter of Uttānapāda and
the wife of Antināra.
Br. II. 36. 90; M. 49. 7; Vā. 62. 76.
text.10085:
Manasvinī (III) — the wife of Mṛkaṇḍu and mother of
Mārkaṇḍeya.
Vā. 28. 5; Br. II. 11. 7.
text.10086:
Manu (I) — a son of Dhiṣaṇā and Kṛśāśya.
Bhā. VI. 6. 20.
text.10089:
Manu (IV) — the author of a Dharmaśāstra; grass cut
for cow is not punishable; so also flowers plucked from
gardens other than those of temples for the worship of god.
M. 227. 27, 32, 113.
text.10090:
Manu (V) — approached by Varūtri's sons to ruin the
offerings to Gods but interrupted by Indra.
Vā. 65. 79.
text.10092:
Manu (VII) — a son of Śighraka; established himself in
Kalāpagrāma by yoga.
Vā. 88. 210.
text.10093:
Manu (VIII) — one of the sons of Madhu.
Vā. 95. 45.
text.10094:
Manu (IX) (Raivata) — the fifth Manu; son of Priya
vrata and brother of Tāmasa; Bali and others were his sons.
Vibhu was Indra; Bhūtarayas were the gods of the epoch;
Vaikuṇṭha was the manifestation of Hari in this manvantara.1
Devabāhu and others were the seven sages; served as calf
to milk the earth.2 1) Bhā. V. 1. 28; VIII. 5. 2-5.
2) Br. II. 36. 3, 51. 64; 37. 17. 8.
text.10095:
Manu (X) — (Cākṣuṣa) — a son of Viśvakarman (Viś
veśa-M. P.) and Kṛtī. Father of Viśvas and Sādhyas.
Bhā. VI. 6. 15; M. 171. 48.
text.10096:
Manu (XI) (Sāvarṇi) — the eighth Manu. A son of
Chāyā and Vivasvān. Father of Nirmoka and other sons.
In this epoch Sutapas, Virajas Amitābhas, Mukhyas were the
gods. Bali was Indra. Gālava, Kṛpa, Rāma and others were
the sages. Hari manifested himself as Sārvabhauma.1 Ini
tiated in the mystery of Lord's glories by Nārada, worship
ping Naranārāyaṇa;2 originally Śrutaśravas; performs aus
terities on the slopes of Meru even to-day.3 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 41; VIII. 13. 11-7; 22. 31; Vi. III. 2. 4; 13-19.
2) Bhā. V. 19. 10.
3) Br. IV. 1. 28; III. 59. 49 and 80.
text.10097:
Manu (XII) (Svāyambhuva) — the first son of Brahmā
and the first king (Samrāṭ) also Virāṭ. Ruled the earth,
girt by seven seas, occupying Brahmāvarta with Barhiṣmatī
as capital. A Viprarājaṛṣi. Learnt the Veda from his father,
who asked him to rule according to Dharma. Wife Śata
rūpā; sons Priyavrata and Uttānapāda besides eight more
through Anantā and a daughter, Devahūtī. Other daughters
were Ākūti and Prasūti1 who married Dakṣa and Ruci res
pectively. Met Kardama on the Sarasvatī, spoke of inter
dependence of the Kṣatriya and the Brahmana, and offered
his daughter Devahūtī in marriage to that sage.2 Another
daughter Dhanyā became the wife of Dhruva. Seeing
Dhruva fighting with the Yakṣas in utter wrath, Manu asked
him to cease slaughtering the innocents and to ask pardon
of Kubera, their chief.3
Appointed Priyavrata in charge of the kingdom and
retired to tapas. Spent 71 yugas meditating on Viṣṇu, and
gave Him the name, Hari. Did not take objection to Hara's
violation of dharma, though he was one of the twelve who
knew the dharma ordained by Hari.4 Served as calf for
Pṛthu to milk the earth.5 Formed one half of the Creator
and the other was Śatarūpā. Asked Brahmā for the earth
being lifted out of the waters to form an abode for him and
his subjects, when a Varāha issued from Brahmā's nostrils
to do the work.6
Renouncing the world, Manu stood on one leg medi
tating on the glory of Hari on the bank of the Sunandā for
a hundred years; when the Asuras tried to attack and devour
him, Hari in the form of yajña slew them.7 The first to give
out Smārta dharma, Varṇāśrama dharma and the first to
practice śiṣṭācāra; requested by Brahma to protect the
Vedas and consequently the yajñas. Divided the Vedas into
four sections.8 An Ādipuruṣa. From him were born
Vairājas.9 1) Bhā. VIII. 1. 1, 5 and 7, XI. 14. 4; III. 20. 1 and 10; 21. 1-3,
25-26; 22. 26-9; VI. 1. 1; 8. 6; Br. II. 13. 105; M. 3. 44-5; 4. 34;
145, 90; Vā. 3. 2, 36; 23. 47; 59. 56-7; Vi. I. 7. 14-19; III. 1. 6.
2) Bhā. III. 21. 45; 22. 3-14.
3) Ib. IV. 11. 6-34; M. 4. 38.
4) Bhā. V.
1. 21-2; XI. 2. 15; III. 22. 31-6; II. 7. 2; VI. 17. 12; 3. 20; IV. 21. 28.
5) Ib. IV. 18. 12; 29. 42.
6) Ib. III. 12. 53-4; 13. 3-18.
7) Bhā. VIII. 1.
7-10.
8) Br. II. 29. 46, 61-4; 30. 34; 32. 35-8, 96; 34. 2-8; 35. 175;
36. 3; 37. 14; IV. 1. 32 and 109; M. 142. 42.
9) Ib. 3. 45-6; 171. 27;
192. 10; 227. 32.
text.10098:
Manu (XIII) — (Svārociṣa) — the second Manu, and son
of Agni. Father of Dyumat and others. In this epoch Rocana
was Indra, Tuṣita and others were gods, Ūrjjastamba and six
others were the seven sages.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 19-20; Br. II. 36. 3, 23; 37. 15.
text.10099:
Manu (XIV) — (Vaivasvata) — the seventh Manu, also
known as ‘Śrāddhadeva’.1 Son of Samjñā and Vivasvat
(Sureṇu and Vivasvān Vā. P.): wife Śraddhā: father of ten
sons of whom Ikṣvāku was the eldest;2 in this epoch Puran
dara was Indra: Kaśyapa, Atri and others were sages: Ādit
yas and Vasus were gods: Vāmana was the manifestation of
Hari;3 a Kṣatriya mantravādin: His sacrifice was disturbed
by sons of Varūtri who were burnt by Indra in the vedi:
a Prajāpati: king and daṇḍadhara.4 Saved by the
Matsya Hari during the deluge. After anointing his son
on the throne, M. performed penance on the Malaya Mt.
for a lac of years when Brahmā blessed him as protector of
the universe after the pralaya. Once in making a water
oblation to his manes, a fish fell into his hand which he
put into his water vessel. Finding its rapid growth he
placed it in a well, tank, Ganges and the sea respectively.
From its abnormal growth he suspected it to be an asura
or Vāsudeva; on questioning it he found it to be the Lord
and was asked to use it (the fish) as the life boat when the
whole world went down in the deluge, saving at the same
time some lives;5 performed tapas on the Yamunā for one
hundred years with a view to get progeny;6 see Satyavrata;
celebrated an Aśvamedha in honour of Mitra and Varuṇa;
out came Ilā who went to them;7 the Lord of men, and seven
worlds with towns;8 divided the Vedas into four for the pro
gress of the world;9 in order to get sons he performed the
Mitrāvaruṇa ritual; owing to the hota's carelessness a
daughter Ilā came out; she became again a male Sudyumna
by name; by an imprecation of Śiva he again became a
woman near Budha's hermitage. Budha got by her a son
by name Purūravas;10 interpretation of Śabdabrahma by.11 1) Bhā. VIII. 13. 1-9; Br. II. 36. 4, 81; III. 59. 22 and 38; 63.
215; IV. 1. 6-28; Vā. 84. 22; Vi. IV. 1. 6-7.
2) Br. II. 38. 1.
3) Bhā.
VIII. 13. 1-9.
4) Br. II. 32. 120; 38. 26 and 32; III. 1. 3 and 6; 8. 21;
10. 98; 60. 7; M. 145. 115; 248. 15.
5) Ib. 1. 11 to the end; 2. 16;
9. 1; 16. 1; 52. 3.
6) Bhā. I. 3. 15; VIII. 24. 50; IX. 1. 3-12; 2. 1;
6. 4.
7) Br. III. 60. 1-10.
8) Vā. 70. 18.
9) Ib. 60. 8.
10) Vi. IV. 1.
8-12.
11) Ib. VI. 5. 64.
text.10100:
Manu (XV) (Dakṣa Sāvarṇī) — the ninth Manu. Born
of Varuṇa; father of Bhūtaketu and other sons. Pāras and
others were gods of his epoch, and Adbhuta was Indra; Dyu
timat and others were sages. During this period Hari mani
fested himself as Ṛṣabha.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 18-20.
text.10101:
Manu (XVI) (Rudrasāvarṇi) — the twelfth Manu; father
of Devavān and other sons. Ṛtadhāman was Indra. Hārita
and others were gods. Tapomūrti and others were sages.
Svadhāma was Hari manifesting in this epoch;1 the fourth
Sāvarṇa Manu in the 12th paryāya.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 13. 27-29.
2) Br. IV. 1. 82-93.
text.10102:
Manu (XVII) Sāvarṇa(i) — the second Manu in the
epoch of the Vaivasvata Manvantara; son of Sāvarṇa;1 in
his age Bali was to reign over the whole world.2 1) Br. IV. 1. 51-5, 73-81.
2) Ib. II. 36. 4; III. 73. 52.
text.10103:
Manu (XVIII) (Raucya) — a Sāvarṇa Manu of the XIII
paryāya; three groups of gods, all addicted to Soma and ghee
through yajñas.
Br. IV. 1. 95-116.
text.10104:
Manu (XIX) — (Cākṣuṣāntaram) — Bhṛgu and other
sages lived in this epoch.1 There were five classes of devas,
Lekha, Ṛbhava, Ṛbhādya, Vārimūla, and Divaukasa; Cāk
ṣuṣa had ten sons commencing with Ruru;2 King Purūravas
flourished in the same line in this epoch.3 1) M. 2. 14; 6. 3; 8. 12.
2) Ib. 9. 22, 25.
3) Ib. 115. 7-8.
text.10105:
Manu (XX) (Auttama) — the third Manu;1 father of
ten sons; the devas of the epoch are Bhāvanas and there were
also seven sages, Kaukuruṇḍi, etc., all engaged in yoga.2 1) M. 3. 47.
2) Ib. 9. 11.
text.10106:
Manu (XXI) (Cākṣuṣa) (VI) — the son of Cakṣu and
Vīriṇī; married a royal princess Naḍvalā and had ten sons.
M. 4. 40; Vi. I. 13. 4.
text.10107:
Manu (XXII) — the son of Haryaśva and father of Pra
tika.
Vi. IV. 5. 27.
text.10108:
Manus — worshipped with Devas for kingdom; their
duties in different epochs described.1 Fourteen in number;
went to Maharloka when their duties were over;2 in order:
Svāyambhuva, Svārociṣa, Auttama, Tāmasa, Raivata, Cāk
ṣuṣa; these six are past ones; the future are eight; Sāvarṇa,
Pañcaraucyas, Bhautya and Vaivasvata.3 1) Bhā. II. 3. 9; VIII. 14. 2-10
2) Br. IV. 2. 2 nad 5.
3) Vā.
62. 3-4.
text.10109:
Manukāla — the whole period of the fourteen Manus
covering a kalpa of one thousand yugas — the fourteen man
vantaras.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 36; 14. 11.
text.10110:
Manuga — a son of Dyutimān after whose name is a
Janapada.
Vā. 33. 21.
text.10112:
Manutīrtha — a tīrtha visited by Balarāma.
Bhā. X. 79. 21.
text.10113:
Manuttama (Manutta or Marutta) — a king equal to a
cakravartin, went to heaven with Samvarta, a sage; father
of Nariṣyanta.
Vā. 86. 9.
text.10114:
Manuvantī — a daughter of Tumburu.
Br. III. 7. 13.
text.10115:
Manuvaṃśadhara — an avatār of Hari.
Bhā. II. 7. 20.
text.10117:
Manuṣyas — created out of the rajas element;1 four
varṇas of.2 1) Vi. I. 5. 23, 37-8; 6. 1.
2) Ib. I. 6. 5.
text.10119:
Manojava (I) — a son of Medhātithi of Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 25.
text.10120:
Manojava (II) — a son of Īśāna and Śivā.
Br. II. 10. 79; Vā. 27. 52.
text.10122:
Manojava (IV) — the Indra of the Cākṣuṣa epoch.
Br. II. 36. 76; Vi. III. 1. 26.
text.10123:
Manojava (V) — a son of Anila (Anala-M. P.) a Vasava.
Br. III. 3. 26; M. 5. 25; Vā. 66. 25; Vi. I. 15. 114.
text.10124:
Manojava (VI) — a god of one of the ten branches of the
Harīta gaṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 84; Vā. 100. 89.
text.10125:
Manojavā — a R. in Krauñcadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 75; M. 122. 88; Vā. 49. 69; Vi. II. 4. 55.
text.10127:
Manonuga (I) — a son of Dyutimān after whom the
kingdom, Mānonuga took its name.
Br. II. 14. 22, 24.
text.10128:
Manonuga (II) (c) — a region of the Krauñcadvīpa
adjoining the Vāmana hill.
Br. II. 14. 24; 19. 71; M. 122. 84.
text.10129:
Manonuga (III) — a varṣa of the hill, Vāmanaka.
Vā. 49. 66.
text.10133:
Manovatī (I) — the sabhā of Brahmā on the first inner
slope of Meru in which reside Īśāna and Indra besides sages
and seers.
Vā. 34. 72-7.
text.10135:
Manoharam — a tīrtha on the Narmadā sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 194. 7.
text.10137:
Manoharā (II) — the wife of Dharma, the Vasu.
Vi. I. 15. 113.
text.10138:
Maṃkanam — the form of a Brahmana assumed by Gaṇeśa
Nikumbha when he appeared in a dream to Divodāsa.
Br. III. 67. 42.
text.10139:
Maṃkuti — a R. from the Ṛkṣa hill.
Br. II. 16. 31.
text.10140:
Mantradruma — Indra of the Cākṣuṣa epoch.
Bhā. VIII. 5. 8.
text.10141:
Mantra(i)nāthā — also Mantriṇī,1 and Mantriṇīśyāmā;
war master of Lalitā; residence at Kadambavanavāṭikā;2
helped Kumārī in vanquishing Bhaṇḍa's sons; rode on Kiri
cakra; consulted Daṇḍanāthā;3 invoked Madīrāsindhu
(s.v.).4 1) Br. IV. 17. 22, 27; 27, 58; 19. 61.
2) Ib. IV. 31. 82, 89.
3) Ib. IV. 26. 2, 83, 113; 27. 58.
4) Ib. IV. 28. 14, 48, 92, 103.
text.10143:
Mantrapravacanas — a branch of the Vedic literature.
Vā. 58. 14.
text.10144:
Mantrabrāhmaṇam — a branch of Vedic literature;1 ety.
of.2 1) Br. II. 31. 12; 33. 54; Vā. 59. 138.
2) Ib. 50. 141; 61. 102.
text.10145:
Mantram (I) — (also Mantrasthānam, Council Cham
ber) consultation to be held with many and individually and
with people in whom the king has confidence; at least one
expert must be consulted; generally with people learned in
the three Vedas, elders who have the ability to correct
the erring king;1 kingdom rests on mantra;2 king not
to decide alone nor to consult too many;3 Bhaṇḍa's War
Council.4 1) M. 215. 48-52.
2) Ib. 220. 33.
3) Ib. 220. 37.
4) Br. IV. 21. 21;
25. 3
text.10146:
Mantram (II) — a portion of the Pūrva samhitā.
Vā. 61. 65.
text.10147:
Mantras — take the food offered in sacrifices to the Pitṛs
as the calf finds out its mother among the lost cows;1 came
out of discontent, fear, difficulties, happiness and misery of
ṛṣis; later put into form and order by sages; differences in
mantras as many as twenty-four;2 the two major divisions
— grāmyam and āraṇyakam;3 Veda mantras, Viṣṇu mantra,
Durgā mantra, Gāṇapata mantra, etc.;4 ety of.5 1) Br. II. 28. 91; Vā. 59. 61.
2) Br. II. 32. 68; 33. 42; Vā. 59.
35-61; M. 145. 62-3.
3) Br. II. 35. 73, 85; IV. 8. 51-3, 57.
4) Ib. IV.
38. 4.
5) Vā. 59. 141.
text.10148:
Mantramālā — a R. in Kuśadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 15.
text.10150:
Mantravit — a son of Satyabhāmā and Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 71. 247.
text.10151:
Mantraśarīras — the 12 sons who came out of Brahmā's
face.
Vā. 67. 4.
text.10152:
Mantrātma śaktikā — a Varṇa śakti.
Br. IV. 44. 58.
text.10154:
Mantri (II) — the chief counsellor of the king;1 looks
after the kingdom in the absence of the king;2 to be consulted
before undertaking an expedition;3 residence of.4 1) Vā. 57. 70.
2) M. 115. 17; 217. 18.
3) Ib. 223. 9; 240. 27.
4) Ib. 254. 20.
text.10156:
Mantripravaram — the ministry which ruled the king
dom in the absence of king, Sagara.
Br. III. 50. 32.
text.10157:
Mantropaniṣad — a secret mantra in honour of Sankar
ṣaṇa, taught to king Citraketu by Nārada; its text.
Bhā. VI. 15. 27; 16. 18-25.
text.10158:
Manthu — a son of Vīravrata and Bhojā; his wife was
Satyā, and son Bhauvana.
Bhā. V. 15. 15.
text.10159:
Manda — a son of Abhramu elephant;1 also Padma; the
vehicle of Kubera.2 1) Br. III. 7. 330.
2) Vā. 69. 214, 216.
text.10160:
Mandaka — a son of Śrīdevā and Vasudeva.
Br. III. 71. 181.
text.10161:
Mandagas — the Śūdra caste of Śākadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 69.
text.10162:
Mandagā — a R. from the Śuktimat.
Br. II. 16. 38; M. 114. 32; Vā. 45. 107.
text.10163:
Mandagāminī — a R. from the Suktimat hill.
Br. II. 16. 38.
text.10164:
Mandanī — a mūrchana; the presiding deity of the Viś
vedevas.
Vā. 86. 63.
text.10166:
Mandabāhya — a son of Balarāma.
Br. III. 71. 167.
text.10167:
Mandara (I) — (Mt.) on one side of Meru; one of Viṣ
kambhagiris round the Meru; sacred to Śiva; in its valleys
Hiraṇyakaśipu performed austerities; used in churning the
milk ocean; lest it should sink in the sea Hari in the form of
Kūrma supported the mountain; was lifted up with great
difficulty by the Gods and Asuras, who could not carry it to
the ocean, when Hari asked Garuḍa to bear it on his back
to the sea and which he did.1 Recipient of mango fruits as
large as hill-tops falling from a divine mango tree, 1100 yoja
nas high (see Aruṇodā).2 Here Pṛthu died and was cre
mated.3 (Also known, Mandaragiri and Mandarācalam).
Bhadrāśva varṣa and Caitraratha park in;4 Śiva spent
his honeymoon here with Umā after marrying her; Umā's
delights in the woods.5 1) Br. IV. 9. 51, 56, 60; Bhā. I. 3. 16; III. 28. 27; V. 16. 11;
VII. 3. 2; 7. 2; VIII. 5. 10; 6. 33-9; X. 40. 18; XII. 13. 2; M. 69. 1;
249. 15; 250. 26; 251. 35; Vi. I. 9. 77, 84.
2) Bhā. V. 16. 16.
3) Ib.
IV. 23. 24.
4) M. 83. 20, 31.
5) Ib. 113. 45; 154. 496, 573; 163. 87;
183. 1.
text.10168:
Mandara (II) — a Mt. of Kuśadvīpa, from waters called
mandas;1 a son of Meru;2 on the other side of Gandhamā
dhana; its mahāvṛkṣa is Keturāṭ.3 1) Br. II. 13. 36; 19. 56; Vā. 36. 19; 42. 14; 45. 90; 49. 51; 101.
288.
2) Ib. 30. 33.
3) Ib. 35. 16.
text.10169:
Mandara (III) — a Mt. in Bhāratavarṣa.
Br. II. 16. 20; III. 27. 28.
text.10170:
Mandara (IV) — a tīrtha sacred to Kāmacāriṇī.
M. 13. 28; 184. 18.
text.10172:
Mandara (VI) — a palace of 12 floors; three-fourths of
Meru; the toraṇa is 45 hastas.
M. 269. 28, 32, 47.
text.10174:
Mandara (VIII) — a hill on the east of Ilāvṛta.
Vi. II. 2. 18.
text.10176:
Mandarahariṇa — an upadvīpa to Jambūdvīpa.
Bhā. V. 19. 30.
text.10177:
Mandarācala — a chief hill of Kuśadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 41.
text.10180:
Mandāki — a son of Bhavya of Śākadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 60.
text.10181:
Mandākinī (I) — a R. in Bhāratavarṣa; Gangā in Deva
loka;1 R. of the Kailāsa hill. Here Aila and Urvaśī lived
for sometime.2 Other rivers in Kailāsa are Alakanandā and
Nandā.3 1) Bhā. V. 19. 18; X. 70. 44; Vā. 45. 99.
2) Br. II. 18. 3; III. 66.
6; M. 121. 4; Vā. 41. 14-17; 91. 6.
3) Ib. 41. 18; 47. 3.
text.10182:
Mandākinī (II) — a R. sacred to the Pitṛs;1 rises from
Ṛṣyavān;2 water for bathing a deity.3 1) M. 22. 23.
2) Ib. 105. 10; 114. 25.
3) Ib. 267. 20.
text.10184:
Mandakūrī — a R. from the Ṛkṣa hill.
Br. II. 16. 30.
text.10186:
Mandāravatī — a division of Śrīpuram.
Br. IV. 32. 33.
text.10187:
Mandārasaptamī — the performance of, on the fifth day
of the bright half of the month of Māgha in honour of the
Sun God, gets one the desired objects.
M. 74. 3; 79. 1.
text.10188:
Mandulaka — an Andhra king who ruled for five years.
M. 273. 10.
text.10189:
Mandehas (I) — three crores of Rākṣasas who attack
the rising sun and who are disarmed by the sandhya
worship of gods and by the chanting of the Gāyatrī by the
Brahmanas.1 1) Br. II. 21. 110; Vā. 50. 163.
text.10190:
Mandehas (II) — the Śūdra caste of Kuśadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 38.
text.10191:
Mandodaka — the lake in the Kailāsa; the water in it
is like curd; the Nandana is on its bank, and the Mandākinī
rises from it.
M. 121. 4-5.
text.10192:
Mandodarī (I) — a daughter of Maya.
M. 6. 21; Vā. 68. 29.
text.10193:
Mandodarī (II) — a tīrtha sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 22. 41.
text.10194:
Manmatha — (Kāma); God of Love;1 on the third Parva
of the Geyacakra;2 recreated by Lalitā, who said he was her
son; went to Śiva's abode accompanied by his friend
Vasanta.3 Got burnt by Śiva and in effecting his revival
Māyavatī (Ratī) deluded Śambara by her charms; she
brought up Pradyumna who was a part of the Love God.4 1) M. 118. 13.
2) Br. IV. 19. 67.
3) Ib. IV. 30. 46.
4) VI. V. 27.
28-30.
text.10195:
Manmathā — a goddess enshrined at Hemakūṭa.
M. 13. 50.
text.10196:
Manyu (I) — a name of a Rudra.
Bhā. III. 12. 12.
text.10197:
Manyu (II) — the son of Vitatha (Bharadvāja); father
of Bṛhadkṣatra and four other sons.
Bhā. IX. 21. 1; Vi. IV. 19. 20, 21.
text.10198:
Manyumān — the son of Jāṭharāgni; see Vidvānagni.
Br. II. 12. 34; Vā. 29. 32.
text.10199:
Manvantaras — periods of Manus; seven in number and
seven to come, of Svāyambhuva, Svārociṣa, Auttama,
Tāmasa, Raivata, Cākṣuṣa, Sāvarṇi (after Vaivasvata in
M. P.), Raucya (Br. P.); Vaivasvata present according to the
M. P.) Ruci, Bhautya, Merusāvarṇi, Rta, Ṛtadhāmān and
Viṣvaksena; the last seven are future Manus;1 one of the
five characteristics of the Purāṇa;2 calculation of the duration
of the epochs of Manus;3 constitutes 71 yugas at the end of
which comes Kṣaya4 according to Mānuṣa and Divyavat
sara.5 1) Br. II. 6. 6, 20; 36. 1-4; M. 2. 22; 9. 2-36; Vā. 21. 11, 14, 19,
38, 44; 57. 33-6; Vi. I. 3. 18.
2) M. 53. 65; Br. I. 1. 37; Vā. 4. 10.
3) M. 142. 30.
4) Vā. 10. 12; 32. 41.
5) Ib. 61. 138-144; 150. 176.
text.10200:
Manvantara of Svāyambhuva Manu — the Gods of three
worlds, sages, pitṛs, and people help him; but finding
the diminished powers, go to Maharloka.
Vā. 61. 149-51.
text.10201:
Mamatā — the wife of the sage Uśija (Asija-Vā. P.),
(Utathya Vi. P.) whose younger brother Bṛhaspati wanted
sexual union with her when she was pregnant eight months;
he raped her, and cursed the baby in the womb which
obstructed the completion of the act, to be ever in darkness,
and hence the child was born blind, Dīrghatamas; the result
of the union was Bharadvāja; Mamatā, abandoned Bharad
vāja fearing divorce by her husband on account of the in
discret act of Bṛhaspati (s.v.) see also Dīrghatamas.
Bhā. IX. 20. 37-39; Br. III. 74. 36-7; M. 48. 32-41; 49. 17, 26;
Vā. 99. 36-8; Vi. IV. 19 16.
text.10202:
Maya (I) — The architect of the Asuras of the other
world, and a past master in the practice of māyā. Served as
calf for the Māyins to derive māyā from Earth. Built aerial
cities, three in number, of gold, silver and iron for the pro
tection of the Asuras, and constructed the divine sabhā. The
cities were well equipped and furnished, with paintings and
drawings of couples of Nāgas and Asuras, pigeons, parrots
and śārikas, interspersed by charming gardens of flowers
and fruits with lakes of crystal waters. Being the
Lord of Tripura which he built, he took part with Bali
in the Devāsura war, and also fought with Viśvakar
man;1 son of Viśvakarman; Sureṇu was his sister;2 had
an evil dream that a naked lady and a man of three eye
burning the city: reported it to the Sabhā: was explained by
Nārada: precautions for defence: army stationed at respec
tive places of vantage; Vidyunmāli was over-powered; Maya
constructed a tank of medicinal waters to make the dead
live and restored Vidyunmāli. Knowing this immortalising
fluid, Brahmā and Hari drank the whole of it; fierce war;
Śiva directed his arrows against the three cities and killed
the Asuras by destroying their cities. Maya's address to the
Asuras for a bold stand. Vidyunmāli and Tāraka were
killed. Maya was let off and asked to live in a special house
after burning the city. In the Tārakāmaya it is said he rode
on a golden chariot with arms and weapons.3 1) Bhā. I. 15. 8; II. 7. 37; IV. 18. 20; V. 24. 9-10; VII. 10. 22 and
29, 51-60.
2) Br. III. 59. 21; IV. 12. 3; 20. 46; 31. 7; Vā. 84. 20-1.
3) M. ch. 129; 131. 25-30; 134. 9-30; chh. 135-140. 173. 2-13;
177. 3-6.
text.10203:
Maya (II) — the Asura architect and a contemporary of
Kṛṣṇa. His son enslaved the gopas and hid them in a cave.
Kṛṣṇa recovered them;1 freed from the forest fire of Kāṇ
ḍava by Arjuna, he erected a sabhā for the use of the Pāṇ
ḍavas. Once Duryodhana (s.v.) mistook a floor of this for
a sheet of water and had a nasty fall;2 Supplied a magic car
to Śālva under orders of Śiva.3 1) Bhā. II. 7. 31.
2) Ib. X. 55. 21; 71. 45; 58. 27; 75. 34 and 37.
3) Ib. X. 76. 7; 77. 28.
text.10204:
Maya (III) — an Asura; Lord of Talātala region, won the
grace of Śiva and attained mokṣa by satsanga. A follower of
Vṛtra in his battle with Indra;1 wife Rambhā and father of
six sons;2 had daughters like Upadānavī.3 1) Bhā. V. 24. 28; XI. 12. 5; VI. 10. 31.
2) Br. III. 6. 5 and 28;
Vā. 68. 28-9.
3) M. 6. 21.
text.10207:
Mayā — a Śakti created from the heart of Nṛsimha.
M. 179. 64.
text.10208:
Mayūra (I) — the riding animal of Kārttikeya; several
on the Himālayas;1 a banner of Skanda presented to Vāyu.2 1) Br. II. 25. 16, 27; III. 10. 47. M. 160. 21. Vā. 36. 2; 54. 19.
2) Ib. 72. 46.
text.10209:
Mayūra (II) — a peak on the Varāha hill.
Vā. 42. 70.
text.10210:
Mayūradhvaja — Bāṇa with the peacock standard; the
breaking of the flag was a sign of impending war.
Vi. V. 33. 3.
text.10212:
Marīcaka — a son of Bhavya of Śakadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 60.
text.10213:
Marīca (i) Kaśyapa — a Prajāpati; husband of Aditī and
father of the Ādityas.
Vā. 30. 72; 50. 168; 52. 95; 67. 43; 100. 20; 101. 35 and 49.
text.10214:
Marīci (I) — a mind-born son of Brahmā born with
Nārada at the beginning of creation;1 married Kalā a
daughter of Kardama;2 father of Kaśyapa;3 came with
Brahmā to see Kapila born to Kardama;4 was present in
Dakṣa's yajña;5 directed the Aśvamedha of Indra;6 came to
see the Trivikrama avatār of the Lord;7 did not comprehend
Hari's māya.8
The chief sage of Vena's reign responsible for punishing
him. A sage in Dāruvana;9 one of the seven sages of
Svāyambhuva epoch: instructed by Brahmā on the eighteen
Purāṇas; praised Śiva, out to destroy Tripuram;10 had a
daughter Surūpā, whom Angiras got married.11 1) Bhā. I. 6. 31; III. 12. 22; IX. 1. 10; Br. II. 32. 96; III. 1. 21,
43-4; M. 3. 6; 4. 26; 195. 9.
2) Bhā. III. 24. 22; IV. 1. 13.
3) Ib. III. 14.
7; 20. 10.
4) Ib. III. 24. 9.
5) Ib. IV. 7. 43; 29. 43.
6) Ib. VI. 13. 21.
7) Ib. VIII. 21. 1.
8) Ib. IX. 4. 58.
9) Br. II. 21. 115; 27. 104; 36.
133; III. 10. 52; M. 145. 90; 154. 352; 171. 27.
10) Ib. 9. 4; 53. 12;
102. 19; 127. 24; 133. 67.
11) Ib. 196. 1; 245. 86; 250. 4.
text.10215:
Marīci (II) — a son of Samrāṭ and Utkalā. Father of
Bindumatī.
Bhā. V. 15. 15.
text.10216:
Marīci (III) — His wife was Ūrṇā; had six sons in the
first antara; then Gods laughed at Brahmā seeking connec
tion with his daughter; these were born of Hiraṇyakaśipu as
Asuras, but were taken away by Yogamāyā; then they were
born of Devakī and killed by Kamsa.
Bhā. X. 85. 47-49.
text.10217:
Marīci (IV) — created from the eyes; one of the Nine
Brāhmaṇas alluded to in the Purāṇas.
Br. I. 5; II. 9. 18 and 22; 11. 10; 13. 54.
text.10218:
Marīci (V) — a sage of the Svāyambhuva epoch;1 son-in
law of Dakṣa;2 married Sambhūtī;3 advised Dhruva to pray
to Viṣṇu.4 1) Vā. 3. 2; 31. 16; 62. 113; 65. 44.
2) Ib. 30. 48.
3) Br. II. 9.
55; Vā. 28. 8; Vi. I. 10. 6; 11. 43.
4) Ib. I. 12. 6.
text.10219:
Marīci (VI) — a son of Brahmā married Dharmavratā,
the daughter of Dharma whom he cursed for dereliction of
duty, to become a stone; got one hundred sons through her;
in turn cursed by her for the unjust curse.
Vā. 107. 7, 26; 112. 36.
text.10220:
Marīci (VII) — a mind-born son of Brahmā; married
Sannatī.
Vi. I. 7. 5, 7, 37.
text.10221:
Marīcigarbhas (I) — the gods of the ninth Manvantara;
a gaṇa of 12 gods.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 19; Br. IV. 1. 55, 58-9; Vi. III. 2. 21.
text.10222:
Marīcigarbhas (II) — the world of Haviṣmanta Pitṛs in
the Mārtāṇḍamaṇḍalam.
M. 15. 16.
text.10223:
Marīcigarbhas (III) — the world of Upahūta Pitṛs;
belonging to Kṣatriyagaṇa.
Vā. 73. 38-9.
text.10225:
Marīcipas — do severe austerities at Benares.
M. 183. 31.
text.10228:
Marīṣā — a daughter of trees given by Soma as wife of
Pracetasa for the generation of Dakṣa.
Vā. 63. 33-7.
text.10229:
Maru (I) — the name of a desert;1 water in, due to
ignorance.2 1) Bhā. I. 10. 35.
2) Vā. 104. 39.
text.10230:
Maru (II) — the son of Śighrarāja and father of Praśruta
(Prasuśraka-Vi. P.); having attained perfection in yoga: he
resides in Kalāpagrāma (still rooted in Yoga-Vi. P.): would
revive the solar race at the end of Kali.
Bhā. IX. 12. 5-7; Br. III. 63. 210-11. Vi. IV. 4. 108-11.
text.10231:
Maru (III) — a son of Haryaśva and father of Pratīpaka
(Pratyambaka Br. P.; Pratitvaka-Vā. P.).
Bhā. IX. 13. 15-6; Br. III. 64. 11. Vā. 89. 11.
text.10232:
Maru(c) (IV) — on the way from Dvārakā to Hāstina
pura.
Bhā. X. 71. 21.
text.10233:
Maru (V) — of the Ikṣvāku line, living in Kalāpagrāma
and endowed with Yoga.
Bhā. XII. 2. 37.
text.10234:
Maru (VI) — a son of the III Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 81.
text.10235:
Maru (VII) — the place sacred to Lalitā.
Br. IV. 44. 98.
text.10236:
Maruṇḍas — 13 Kings of this line ruled for 200 years
with Vṛṣalas.
Vā. 99. 360, 363.
text.10237:
Maruta (I) — a son of Karandhama; he had no son and
regarded Duṣyanta of Puru's family as his son.
Bhā. IX. 23. 17.
text.10238:
Maruta (II) — born of Marutvatī.
Br. I. 1. 112; 2. 41; Vā. 10. 71; 66. 33.
text.10239:
Maruta (III) — Mitrajyoti was his daughter.
Br. III. 68. 1, 4.
text.10240:
Maruts (I) — fortynine in number, born of Diti and
Kaśyapa; seven in each of the seven vātaskandhas; brothers
of Indra and participators in sacrifices;1 when Diti conceived
a son to be the slayer of Indra, the latter began to serve her
throughout her pregnancy. Once finding that she did not
keep to her vows he entered her womb and cut the foetus into
49 pieces, when they cried. He said to them mā ruda and
hence māruta: being divine, were born as 49 sons: at the
request of their mother Indra made them a devagaṇa, called
Marutgaṇa.2
Gods of the Vaivasvata epoch, Indra being their over
lord: requested Soma to give up Tārā to Bṛhaspati.3
Fought with Nivātakavacas in the Devāsura war:
mounted guards in Marutta's Yajñas: nourished Bharadvāja
abandoned by Mamatā and gave him to Bharata as his son;4
helped Indra in the heavy downpour on Nandavraja: went
with the gods to Dvārakā to request Kṛṣṇa to go back to
Vaikuṇṭha;5 Fathers of Śobhavatya group of Apsarasas;
presiding deity of Kālopanata mūrchana; line in Bhuvar
loka and Lokāloka: perform śrāddha;6 are worshipped for
lasting strength (ojas).7
Their service in the battle of Tripuram: Shaken by
Hiraṇyakaśipu; glad at Hari's attack on the Asuras;8 attain
ed siddhi at Siddeśvaram;9 companions of those who are
devoted to their brothers;10 brought up Bharadvāja, son of
Bṛhaspati.11 1) Bhā. VI. 18. 19, 23-77: VIII. 13. 4: Br. III. 5. 79, 90, 99,
104: M. 6. 47; 163. 22-3.
2) M. Ch. 7.
3) Ib. 8. 4: 9. 29: 23.
35: 36. 1.
4) Bhā. VI. 10. 17: IX. 2. 28; 20. 35-9: M. 49. 15, 25-30:
58. 33.
5) Bhā. X. 25. 7: XI. 6. 2.
6) Br. III. 7. 20: 61. 46:
IV. 2. 27, 197: III. 10. 110.
7) Bhā. II. 3. 8.
8) M. 58. 33: 132.
3; 137. 18; 172. 14-44; 174. 32.
9) Ib. 191. 117; 246. 60.
10) Bhā.
VI. 5. 31.
11) Vā. 99. 139-51.
text.10241:
Maruts (II) — one of the Marut gaṇas.
Vā. 67. 128.
text.10242:
Marutgaṇas (I) — the seven pieces of Diti's garbha be
came seven gaṇas in the Vāyu mārga; each originated seven1
gaṇas in turn and thus 49 Marut gaṇas are distinguished;
they partake in yajñas especially garuḍa śayana yajña;2
residents of Bhuvarloka;3 part of Viṣṇu;4 see Śakra. 1) Vā. 30. 99: 64. 2: Vi. I. 9. 64 and 70: 21. 40.
2) Vā. 67.
110, 123-29.
3) Ib. 101. 29.
4) Vi. V. 1. 17.
text.10243:
Marutta (I) — the son of Avikṣit, a cakravarti and father
of Dama; helped by Samvarta, he performed sacrifices; his
yajñas were of a high order; Indra was much pleased with
soma, and the Brahmanas with dakṣiṇā; Maruts were the
guards and Viśvedevas were members of the sabhā;1 still is
sung the glory of his sacrifice in which everything was of
gold; father of Nariṣyanta.2 1) Bhā. IX. 2. 26-9.
2) Vi. IV. 1. 31-4. Br. III. 61. 7; 8. 35.
text.10244:
Marutta (II) — a son of Karamdhama (Karamdana
Vi. P.): issueless, adopted Duṣkanta of the Paurava line and
thus Purvasu family got merged in the Paurava line. It was
a result of Yayāti's curse.
Br. III. 74. 2-4; Vā. 99. 2-4: Vi. IV. 16. 3-6.
text.10245:
Marutta (III) — a son of Uśanas, a great warrior and
Rājaṛṣi; father of Kambalabarhis.
Br. III. 70. 25: M. 44. 24: Vā. 95. 24.
text.10246:
Marutvatī — a mind-born daughter of Brahmā (a
daughter of Dakṣa, Bhā. P. and Vi. P.) and one of the ten
wives of Dharma; mother of the Maruts among whom were
Marutvān and Jayanta;1 other names of the Maruts.2 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 4 and 8: Br. III. 3. 2 and 32: M. 5. 15. 17:
171. 32, 51, 55; 203. 9. Vā. 66. 2: Vi. I. 15. 105.
2) M. 171. 52-5.
text.10247:
Marutvantas — sons of Marutvatī and Dharma;1 for
names of the gaṇas of the Maruts.2 1) M. 5. 17; 36. 1; 132. 3; 171. 51; Br. III. 3. 32; Bhā. VI.
6. 8; Vi. I. 15. 105.
2) M. 171. 52; 203. 9.
text.10248:
Maruts(t)oma — a sacrifice performed by Bharata
anxious to have a son;1 performed by Marutta for 60 years
to please the Maruts and get inexhaustible annam from
them.2 1) Bhā. IX. 20. 35: Br. III. 68. 2: M. 49. 28. Vā. 99. 153;
Vi. IV. 19. 6.
2) Vā. 93. 2-3.
text.10249:
Marudeva — a son of Supratīka (Supratīpa-M.P.) and
father of Sunakṣatra.
Bhā. IX. 12. 12: M. 271. 8; Vi. IV. 22. 4.
text.10250:
Maru(deśa) — also Marudhanva; arid tract1 where
Samjñā roamed in the guise of a mare;2 heaven became like
a desert by the havoc of Tāraka.3 (See Maru). 1) Vā. 86. 51.
2) Bhā. I. 10. 35. M. 11. 26. Vā. 8. 97; 88. 35.
3) M. 154. 34.
text.10251:
Marudvṛdhā (Marudvriddha-Br. P.) — a R in Bhārata
varṣa.
Bhā. V. 19. 18.
text.10252:
Marka — (Śaṇḍa) an Asura; one of the four sons of
Śukra and a tutor of Prahlāda;1 seen by the Gods at the
sacrifice;2 one of the two disciples the other being Śaṇḍa of
Śukra sent to help the Asuras; but he joined the camp of the
Devas, the latter offering him a place in sacrifices.3 1) Bhā. VII. 5. 1-2, 48-50; Br. III. 1. 78; 72. 72, 87; 73. 63-4;
M. 47. 41; Vā. 65. 77.
2) M. 47. 54.
3) Ib. 47. 224-31; Vā. 97.
72 and 86; 98. 63; 108. 60.
text.10255:
Maryādas (I) — thousands of mountains on all direc
tions of Merumūla, full of lofty buildings; boundary limits;1
transgression of, punished.2 1) Vā. 35. 3; 40. 1; 42. 72. Vā. 101. 157.
2) M. 227. 184.
text.10256:
Maryādas (II) — conventions of society for the welfare
of the world introduced after those of vārtā; establishment
of, by kings; for breaking them, a king goes to hell.
Br. II. 7. 153; 29. 89; 36. 133; IV. 2. 159; M. 225. 10; Vi. I.
6. 32.
text.10258:
Marṣanas — belonging to the Kauśika gotra.
Br. III. 66. 70; Vā. 91. 98.
text.10259:
Malaka (I) — was the Asura who entered heaven,
snatched away the nectar vessel from Dhanvantari: Mohinī
helped the gods in the scuffle that ensued and Malaka fled
to Pātālam.
Br. IV. 9. 38. 10. 2, 23.
text.10260:
Malaka (II) — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 85.
text.10261:
Malada — was attacked by Unmattabhairavī.
Br. IV. 28. 40.
text.10262:
Maladas — a Vindhyan tribe; an eastern kingdom.
Br. II. 16. 53 and 63.
text.10263:
Maladā (I) — one of the ten wives of Atri.
Br. III. 8. 75.
text.10264:
Maladā (II) — a daughter of Bhadrāśva and Ghṛtācī.
Vā. 70. 68.
text.10265:
Malandarā — a R. sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 22. 63.
text.10266:
Malaya (I) — a son of Ṛṣabha and Jayanti.
Bhā. V. 4. 10.
text.10267:
Malaya (II) — a Mt. (Kulaparvata Vā. P.) in Bhārata
varṣa;1 noted for sandal;2 sacred to Hari;3 the residence of
Agastya;4 visited by Balarāma;5 Manu performed tapas at.6 1) Bhā. V. 19. 16; Br. II. 16. 18; Vā. 45. 89, 105; Vi. II. 3. 3.
2) Bhā. I. 8. 32.
3) Ib. VII. 14. 32.
4) Ib. VI. 3. 35; X. 79. 17;
XII. 8. 16; M. 61. 37.
5) Bhā. X. 79. 16.
6) M. 1. 12.
text.10268:
Malayadvīpam — a pradeśa of Jambudvīpa of the Mlec-
chas; here is Mahāmalaya hill called second Mandaram as
also Agastya's āśrama and Lankā.
Vā. 48. 14, 20-30.
text.10269:
Malayadhvaja — the Pāṇḍya who married the daughter
of the Vidarbha King Rājasimha and became the father of
a daughter and seven sons; a Rājaṛṣi; divided his kingdom
among his sons and with his mind set on Kṛṣṇa retired to
Kulācala followed by his queen; after a period of strenuous
tapas he died and the queen wailed.
Bhā. IV. 28. 29-30, 33-34, 36-50.
text.10270:
Malayaparvata — sacred to Goddess Rambhā;1 rich with
tamāla trees.2 1) M. 13. 29.
2) Ib. 114. 17, 30; 163. 71.
text.10273:
Malina — a son of Trasu, a Brahmavādin.
Vā. 99. 132.
text.10274:
Malla (I) — Candraketu, a son of Lakṣmaṇa styled thus
or his country?
Vā. 88. 188.
text.10275:
Malla (II) — the Lord of Rājagṛha, vanquished by
Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 73. 100.
text.10276:
Mallas — a tribe and an eastern kingdom.
Br. II. 16. 55; M. 163. 67.
text.10277:
Mallakrīḍa — wrestling matches in ancient Mathurā in
which all the people from the peasant to the king took part;
described.
Bhā. X. 36. 24; 42. 32-38; 44. 2-5.
text.10278:
Mallaga — a son of Dyutiman after whom came the
kingdom of Mallagam.
Vi. II. 4. 48.
text.10282:
Masamūlika(c) — watered by R. Cakṣu.
Br. II. 18. 46.
text.10283:
Masūras — lentils unfit for śrāddha.
Vi. I. 6. 21; III. 16. 7.
text.10286:
Maha (II) — one of the twenty Amitābha gods.
Br. IV. 1. 17; Vā. 100. 16.
text.10287:
Maha (III) — (Maharloka) the fourth of the seven
worlds;1 Manus went to it after tapas at Meru; Manus retire
to this place when the periods of their duties are over; Gods
like Ajitas, Yāma gaṇas and Āyuṣmantas besides Śukra, Cāk
ṣuṣa and others live in Maharloka;2 the space between
Dhruva and Jana; the residents of this loka possess mental
powers to create any desired thing; even gods sacrifice to
each other;3 created from Vyāhṛti.4 1) Br. II. 19. 155; M. 60. 2; 61. 1; 184. 23; Vā. 101. 17.
2) Br.
II. 21. 22; 35. 179, 197; IV. 1. 25, 33, 122. Vā. 101. 41, 52, 208;
109. 48.
3) Br. IV. 2. 2, 21, 40, 42-3; Vā. 101. 44.
4) Br. IV. 2.
2, 21; Vā. 101. 23.
text.10288:
Mahat (I) — a tatva or principle;1 identified with
Brahmā;2 a name of Rudra;3 absorbs the ahankāra4 covered
by Pradhāna.5 Ten times greater than bhūtādi; the order
of evolution of the universe according to Sānkhya;6 evolu
tion of Prakṛti in its vikāras.7 1) Bhā. I. 3. 1; II. 1. 35; M. 3. 17.
2) Bhā. III. 6. 26; XI. 14.
14; 16. 37-8; 24. 25-26; 28. 16.
3) Ib. III. 12. 12.
4) Ib. XII. 4. 17.
5) Br. II. 21. 27; 32. 76; IV. 3. 6 and 21.
6) M. 123. 52-61.
7) Ib.
3. 17-26; Vā. 100. 243.
text.10289:
Mahat (II) — (a Rudra), son of Bhūta and Sarūpā.
Bhā. VI. 6. 18.
text.10290:
Mahatī (I) — a R. from Ṛṣyavān in Bhāratavarṣa.
M. 114. 23; Vā. 45. 97.
text.10291:
Mahatī (II) — a R. of the Kuśadvīpa.
M. 122. 74.
text.10292:
Mahatpaurava Nandana — of the family of Sārva
bhauma.
Vā. 99. 187.
text.10293:
Maharloka — the neck of the Puruṣa;1 due to fire of San
karṣaṇa sages leave this to Janaloka;2 the goal of yogins3
(see Mahat) above the Pole Star; the residence of Kalpa
people; at a distance of two crores of yojanas is Janaloka;
becomes devoid of all beings at the end of the kalpa but not
extinguished;4 burnt in the Pralaya.5 1) Bhā. II. 1. 28.
2) Ib. VIII. 20. 34.
3) Ib. XI. 24. 14.
4) Vi.
II. 7. 13.
5) Ib. VI. 3. 28-9.
text.10294:
Mahaṛṣis — mind-born sons of Brahmā, seven in num
ber, like Bhṛgu, Marīci, and Angiras;1 ety. from root ṛṣi
gatau — meaning knowledge; great jñānins;2 their role in
creation.3 1) Br. II. 32. 89, 97; M. 145. 85; 247. 10.
2) Br. II. 6. 71; Vā. 7.
74; 59. 82 and 89.
3) Ib. 7. 75-6.
text.10296:
Mahasvat — a son of Amarṣaṇa and father of Viśva
sāhvan.
Bhā. IX. 12. 7.
text.10297:
Mahākarṇa (I) — a Kādraveya Nāga.
Br. III. 7. 34; Vā. 69. 71.
text.10300:
Mahākāya — a son of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 26. 47.
text.10301:
Mahākāla (I) — a son of Guhāvasa, the avatār of the
17th dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 177.
text.10302:
Mahākāla (II) — a Gaṇeśvara; an attendant of Śiva; with
Mahākāli engaged in the service of Lalitā as one of her
guardsmen; he is served by servants like Kālamṛtyu; in
charge of the first entrance to Śrīpuram; other Śaktis attach
ed to him are Mahāsandhya and Mahāniśā in the Trikoṇa
and five Śaktis on the Pañcakoṇa as also those on the ṣoḍaśa
patra and nāga patra; his seat is Kālacakra.
Br. III. 41. 26; M. 183. 64; 192. 6; 266. 42; Br. III. 32. 23;
IV. 30. 75; 32. 2, 40; 34. 89.
text.10304:
Mahākālam — a place sacred to Śiva.
M. 181. 26.
text.10306:
Mahākālavanam — a garden in the country of Avantī.
M. 179. 5.
text.10308:
Mahākālī (II) — a mind-born mother.
M. 179. 14; Vi. II. 13. 49.
text.10309:
Mahākālī (III) — came out from the wrath of Śiva.
Vā. 101. 298.
text.10310:
Mahākūṭa — a sacred hill1 fit for śrāddha.2 1) Br. III. 13. 58.
2) Vā. 77. 57.
text.10311:
Mahākeśas — a Janapada of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 20.
text.10313:
Mahāgārgya — one of the sons of Danu.
Vā. 68. 5.
text.10315:
Mahāgirinagara — a city in the Himālayas.
M. 154. 469.
text.10316:
Mahāguru — he, who imparts Brahmopadeśa.
Br. IV. 8. 4.
text.10318:
Mahāgaurī — a R. from the Vindhyas.
Br. II. 16. 33; M. 114. 28; Vā. 45. 103.
text.10321:
Mahācakrā — a R. of Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 25.
text.10324:
Mahājambha — a Rākṣasa in Sutalam.
Br. II. 20. 21; Vā. 50. 20.
text.10327:
Mahājvāla — a hell for several offences detailed; such
as sexual intercourse with daughters and daughters-in-law,
selling or censuring the Vedas, insulting or assaulting the
ācāryas.
Br. IV. 2. 147, 151, 156-7; Vā. 101. 146, 155; Vi. II. 6. 2 and 12.
text.10328:
Mahāṃgas — a Janapada of the Ketumālā country.
Vā. 44. 14.
text.10329:
Mahāṇḍa — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 89.
text.10330:
Mahātala — the ankle of the creator;1 an underworld,
where a gaṇa of Nāgas by name Krodhavaśa live;2 of gravel
colour where are the cities of Virocana, the Asura chief and
eight others.3 1) Bhā. II. 1. 26; 5. 41.
2) Ib. V. 24. 7, 29.
3) Vā. 50. 12,
34-7.
text.10331:
Mahātripurasundarī — a name of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 18. 14.
text.10332:
Mahādanta — a Nāga in Vaidūrya śālā of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 33. 36.
text.10333:
Mahādaṃṣṭra — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 86.
text.10335:
Mahādruma — a son of Havya after whom the Mahā
druma varṣa.
Br. II. 14. 17. 21.
text.10336:
Mahādeva — an attribute of Śiva;1 presiding deity of the
moon;2 in one of his previous births was Kṛṣṇa;3 of the Kai
lāsa hill;4 drinks soma;5 worshipped by Lavaṇa Asura;6 wor
shipped by the followers of Bhaṇḍa;7 claimed Bhṛgu as his
son;8 made the mind-born creatures of Dakṣa not to grow;
blessed Surabhī with eleven sons, Rudras;9 Śukra went to,
for learning nītī;10 roamed about in the Mahākālavana with
Pārvatī;11 in his name Gārgya performed penance for a
son.12 Avatārs of, were in Kali and not in the previous
yugas;13 his mānasītanu, Candra;14 wife Rohiṇī and son
Budha.15 1) Br. II. 26. 1; M. 47. 75; Vi. I. 8. 6.
2) M. 246. 61; 265. 42.
3) Ib. 47. 1.
4) Ib. 54. 2.
5) Br. IV. 28. 89.
6) Ib. III. 3. 70; 7.
91-2.
7) Ib. III. 10. 17; 21. 76; 25. 14; 60. 28; 72. 3, 108, 116. IV.
10. 29; 11. 32; 12. 16.
8) Ib. III. 1. 38.
9) Ib. III. 2. 4.
10) M. 47.
75.
11) Ib. 179. 3.
12) Vi. V. 23. 3.
13) Vā. 26. 2.
14) Ib. 27.
16.
15) Ib. 27. 47, 56.
text.10337:
Mahādevābhiṣeka — from the anointment of Mahādeva
to the birth of Parīkṣit 1050 years lapsed; Parīkṣit to Mahā
padma, 836? Mahāpadma to Andhras 836?
Vā. 99. 415.
text.10338:
Mahādevā — a daughter of Devakā and Vasudeva.
Vā. 96. 130.
text.10339:
Mahādevī — a mother Goddess; a name of Lalitā, as ori
ginating from Agnikuṇḍa of Indra and gods who propitiated
Devī to get rid of Bhaṇḍa.1 The goddess enshrined at Śāla
grāma.2 1) Br. IV. 6. 3; 12. 74; 13. 29; 14. 26; 15. 3; 18. 15; 36. 4; M. 179.
31.
2) Ib. 13. 33.
text.10340:
Mahādyuti — a Yakṣa, and a son of Puṇyajanī.
Br. III. 7. 124.
text.10341:
Mahādruma (I) — (c) a kingdom of Śākadvīpa adjoin
ing Keśava(ra-Vā. P.) hill.
Br. II. 14. 21; 19. 93; Vā. 49. 87.
text.10342:
Mahādruma (II) — a continent around the Vibhrāja
hill.
M. 122. 25.
text.10344:
Mahādruma (IV) — a Kinnara with human face.
Vā. 69. 35.
text.10345:
Mahādruma (V) — a son of Bhavya of Śākadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 60.
text.10346:
Mahādrumam — a varṣa called after Mahādruma.
Vā. 33. 20.
text.10347:
Mahādṛti — a son of Vibudha, and father of Kīrtirāta.
Br. III. 64. 12.
text.10348:
Mahādhṛti — a son of Vistṛuta (Vibudha-Vi. P., Vis
ruta, Burnouf) and father of Kṛtirāta.
Bhā. IX. 13. 16-17; Vi. IV. 5. 27.
text.10349:
Mahān (I) — a son of Dhīmān.
Br. II. 14. 69; Vā. 33. 59.
text.10350:
Mahān (II) — one of the twenty Amitābha gods.
Br. IV. 1. 17; Vā. 100. 16.
text.10352:
Mahān (IV) — manas (mind); came out of Prakṛti
(sūkṣma śarīram); out of this mahas came other things;
mati or wisdom is Brahmā; buddhi is bhū; khyāti is Īśvara;
Prajña citti; smṛti, samvid; ety of; its two vṛttis sankalpa
and adhyavasāya;1 attains virāra during Pralaya;2 a pra-
dhāna tatva.3 1) Vā. 4. 24-30, 46; 102. 29-21.
2) Ib. 102. 6 and 12.
3) Vi. I.
2. 34-6, 54.
text.10353:
Mahānada — a R. from the Rkṣa hill.
Br. II. 16. 29.
text.10354:
Mahānadī (I) — a R. from the Pāriyātra hill; in Draviḍa.
Bhā. V. 8. 1; 19. 18; XI. 5. 40; Br. II. 16. 28.
text.10355:
Mahānadī (II) — a R. of the Bhadrā continent.
Vā. 43. 29.
text.10356:
Mahānandi — the son of Nandivardhana, the last of the
ten Śiśunāgas (Śiśunābhas) who ruled for a total period of
362 years; had a son, Mahāpadma by a Śūdra woman; ruled
for 43 years, 1050 years after Parīkṣit. The latter ruined
the Kṣatriya families; contemporaneous with them were the
Aikṣvākas 24, Pāñcālas 25, Kālakas 24, Haihayas 24, Kalin
gas 32, Śākas 25, Kuravas 36, Maithilas 28, Sūrasenas 23,
Vītihotras 20.
Bhā. XII. 1. 7-9; Br. III. 74. 227; M. 272. 12-18. Vā. 99.
320-25; Vi. IV. 24. 18-19.
text.10357:
Mahānasa — a boundary hill of Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 26.
text.10358:
Mahānāda (I) — an Asura residing in Tatvalam.
Br. II. 20. 16.
text.10359:
Mahānāda (II) — a name of Vighneśvara.
Br. IV. 44. 67.
text.10360:
Mahānādam — a tīrtha sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 22. 53.
text.10362:
Mahānābha (I) — a son of Hiraṇyākṣa;1 followed Vṛtra
in his battle with Indra.2 1) Bhā. VII. 2. 18; M. 6. 14; Vā. 67. 68; Vi. I. 21. 3.
2) Bhā.
VI. 10. [20]; Br. III. 5. 31.
text.10365:
Mahānāsas — a Janapada of the Ketumālā continent.
Vā. 44. 13.
text.10366:
Mahāniśā — a śaktī attached to Mahākāla.
Br. IV. 32. 9.
text.10367:
Mahānīla (I) — a Kādraveya Nāga.
Br. III. 7. 34; M. 6. 39; Vā. 69. 71.
text.10368:
Mahānīla (II) — (Mt.) a Parvata to the east of Aru
ṇoda;1 contains fifteen cities of the Kinnaras.2 1) Vā. 36. 19.
2) Ib. 39. 32; 42. 68.
text.10369:
Mahānetra — a Vidyādhara in the Veṇumanta hill.
Vā. 39. 38.
text.10370:
Mahānetras (I) — a Janapada of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 21.
text.10372:
Mahānta — a son of Dhīman.
Vi. II. 1. 39.
text.10373:
Mahāpathas — grand trunk roads as frequented by
Piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 405; 49. 14.
text.10374:
Mahāpadma (I) — a Kādraveya Nāga;1 with the
Hemanta sun;2 in the Vaiḍūryaśālā;3 shaken by Hiraṇya
kaśipu.4 1) Br. III. 7. 33; M. 6. 40; Vā. 69. 70. Vi. I. 21. 21.
2) Br. II.
23. 17; M. 126. 18; Vā. 52. 17; Vi. II. 10. 13.
3) Br. IV. 20. 54;
33. 36.
4) M. 163. 56.
text.10376:
Mahāpadma (III) — the son of Mahānandi by a Śūdra
woman; he was the universal emperor and brought the
earth under his umbrella; ruled for 88 (28 Vi. P.) years;
from him all kings became unrighteous; he was a scourge
of the Kṣatriyas, and just like Paraśurāma rooted out their
families; he had eight sons, Sumālya (Sumātī Vi. P.,
Sukalpa M. P.) and others, all of whom ruled altogether
for 100 (12 M. P.) years; then a Brahmana Kauṭalya M. P.)
brought about their fall;1 from Parīkṣit to Mahāpadma is
1050 years; from Mahāpadma to Puloma Andhra is 836
years.2 1) Bhā. XII. 1. 9-12; Br. III. 74. 139-42, 228; M. 272. 18-22;
Vā. 99. 326-31; Vi. IV. 24. 20-3 and 26.
2) M. 273. 36-37.
text.10377:
Mahāpadmam — one of the eight nidhis of Kubera.
Vā. 41. 10.
text.10378:
Mahāpadmāṭavī — in the Śṛngāra śālā of Śrīpuram;
detailed.
Br. IV. 35. 64, 69-80, 105.
text.10379:
Mahāparṇī — a R. in Muktāphalaśālā of Śrīpuram.
Br. IV. 33. 52.
text.10380:
Mahāpātakas — the murder of a Brahmana, taking of
liquor, theft and intercourse with preceptor's wife, for all
of which death is the punishment; the Brahmana culprits
were however, banished with different signs marked on their
faces.
M. 227. 161-165.
text.10381:
Mahāpāṃśu — a son of Viśravas and Puṣpotkaṭā.
Vā. 70. 49.
text.10382:
Mahāpārśva (I) — a son of Puṣpotkoṭā.
Br. III. 8. 55.
text.10383:
Mahāpārśva (II) — an Asura in the sabhā of Hiraṇya
kaśipu.
M. 161. 80.
text.10385:
Mahāpaurava (nandana) — in the family of Sārva
bhauma.
M. 49. 72.
text.10386:
Mahāprakāśā — a consort of Mārtāṇḍa bhairava.
Br. IV. 35. 47.
text.10387:
Mahāpralayam — the great deluge with darkness per
vading all round.
M. 2. 25.
text.10388:
Mahāphana — a Nāga in the Vaidūryaśālā of Śrīpuram.
Br. IV. 33. 36.
text.10389:
Mahābala (I) — an attendant on Hari.
Bhā. XI. 27. 28.
text.10390:
Mahābala (II) — a son of Danu.
M. 6. 16; Vā. 68. 7.
text.10391:
Mahābala (III) — one of the ten sons of Hṛdīka.
M. 44. 82.
text.10392:
Mahābala (IV) — an Asura in the sabhā of Hiraṇya
kaśipu.
M. 161. 80.
text.10395:
Mahābāhu (II) — a son of Hiraṇyākṣa.
Vi. I. 21. 3.
text.10396:
Mahābodhi — a tīrtha sacred to the Piṭrs.
M. 22. 33.
text.10397:
Mahābodhitaru — a prayer to the Aśvattha tree as the
king of trees, representing the Trinity.
Vā. 111. 26.
text.10398:
Mahābhadram — a lake in the north (in Ilāvṛta Vi. P.).
Vā. 36. 16. Vi. II. 2. 26.
text.10399:
Mahābhāga — a son of Devabhāga.
Br. III. 71. 188.
text.10400:
Mahābhāgā — a Goddess enshrined at Mahālaya.
M. 13. 44.
text.10401:
Mahābhārata — compiled by Vyāsa Kṛṣṇadvaipāyana;1
the moon of, arose from Vyāsa.2 1) Vi. III. 4. 5.
2) Vā. 1. 18, 45.
text.10402:
Mahābhiṣa — the name of Santanu in a previous life.
Bhā. IX. 22. 12; Vā. 99. 237.
text.10403:
Mahābhiṣeka — of Bali at the hands of Bhṛgu;1 its vidhi
observed by Ambarīṣa.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 15. 4;
2) Ib. IX. 4. 31.
text.10405:
Mahābhūtaghaṭa — the gift of a golden pitcher with
gems set; the giver is absolved of the cycle of births and
deaths and enjoys the world of Viṣṇu.
M. 274. 10; 289. 1-17.
text.10406:
Mahābhairavam — a place sacred to Śiva.
M. 181. 29.
text.10407:
Mahābhogapati — the great snake which is the Lord's
bed on the dark waters.
Vā. 24. 11.
text.10408:
Mahābhoja (I) — a son of Sātvata; a righteous King
and the originator of the Bhoja tribe: a Mahāratha who
killed Satrajit, and gave Syamantaka to Akrūra.
Bhā. IX. 24. 7, 11; Br. III. 71. 2, 17-71; Vi. IV. 13. 1, 7.
text.10410:
Mahābhaumas — a Janapada of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 22.
text.10413:
Mahāmanas — the worthy son of Janamejaya (Mahā
śālā Vi. P., M. P., and Vā. P.); according to Br. P. his father
was Purañjaya; his sons were Uśīnara and Titīkṣu: an
emperor; lord of seven worlds, and a cakravarti.
Bhā. IX. 23. 2; Br. III. 74. 15-17; M. 48. 14-15; Vā. 99.
16-8; Vi. IV. 18. 7-8.
text.10415:
Mahāmaha — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 86.
text.10416:
Mahāmātra — Kamsa addressed the hastipa thus;1 there
was more than one mahāmātra in charge of the elephant,
Kuvalayāpīḍa; all of them were killed by Kṛṣṇa.2 1) Bhā. X. 36. 24 [1-4] and 25;
2) Ib. X. 43. 12 and 14; Br. III.
38. 24.
text.10418:
Mahāmāya — a Dānava and a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. III. 6. 5; IV. 21. 81.
text.10419:
Mahāmāyā — a vidyā taught to Pradyumna by Māyā
vatī to vanquish Śambara; it was an astra and one which
could dispel all māyā.
Bhā. X. 55. 16, 22.
text.10420:
Mahāmāli — a Yakṣa King in Kailāsa.
Vā. 41. 25.
text.10422:
Mahāmuda — a Yakṣa, son of Devajanī.
Br. III. 7. 128.
text.10423:
Mahāmudrā — served by a number of Rudras: the
presiding deity of the cakra.
Br. IV. 42. 2.
text.10424:
Mahāmūla — a Mt. south of the Mānasa.
Vā. 36. 24.
text.10425:
Mahāmegha — a Rākṣasa having his city in the fifth
talam (Mahātalam, Vā. P.).
Br. II. 20. 37; Vā. 50. 36.
text.10428:
Mahāyajñas — five in number: could be done by śūdras
without mantras; fruitful in several ways; one failing to do
them becomes indebted; the oblation to be offered in the
North-east; first the offering of Piṇḍa and then the
feeding of guests; Dharmic guests not to be sent away and
useless ones fed.
Br. III. 12. 16-20; Vā. 76. 17, 26, 30.
text.10429:
Mahāyaśas — a son of Samkṛti; married Satkṛtī and had
two sons, Gurudhi and Rantideva.
M. 49. 36-7.
text.10431:
Mahāratha — a title earned by the five sons of Kārta
vīryārjuna;1 an epithet of a Rākṣasa in the army of
Bhaṇḍa.2 1) Br. III. 69. 49; Vā. 92. 70.
2) Br. IV. 29. 21.
text.10433:
Mahārājñī — a name of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 18. 14; 25. 108.
text.10434:
Mahārāṣṭra(c) — a southern kingdom.
Br. II. 16. 57; Vā. 45. 125.
text.10435:
Mahārudram — a mantra: sacred to the Piṭrs: an epithet
of Śiva.
M. 22. 34; Br. IV. 33. 84; 34. 1, 50-1.
text.10436:
Mahāroman — a son of Kṛtirāta (Kīrtirāja Vā. and Vi.
P.) and father of Svarṇaroman.
Bhā. IX. 13. 17; Br. III. 64. 13-14; Vā. 89. 13; Vi. IV. 5. 27.
text.10437:
Mahāraurava — one of the 28 hells (seven hells below
the earth Vā. P.); the place where a class of Rurus called
Kraśyādas torment one, who had been selfish all along.
Bhā. V. 26. 7, 12; Vā. 101. 177; Vi. I. 6. 41.
text.10438:
Mahālakṣmī — Kāmākṣī;1 mother of Brahmā, Viṣṇu and
Īśa;2 is Trīpurāmbikā;3 the goddess enshrined at Kara
vīra.4 1) Br. IV. 19. 8.
2) Ib. IV. 36. 58; 39. 21, 111; 40. 5; Vā. 109. 23.
3) Br. IV. 41. 3; 44. 111; 43. 85.
4) M. 13. 41.
text.10441:
Mahālaya (II) — a son of Guhāvāsa of the 17th dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 177.
text.10442:
Mahālayam (I) — a place sacred to Śiva.
M. 181. 29.
text.10443:
Mahālayam (II) — a name for the siddhakṣetram, the
residence of Maheśvara; a visit to the place relieves one of
his debts to ten generations above and below as well as his
own self.
Vā. 23. 175, 179.
text.10444:
Mahālayā — a R: a tīrtha.
Br. III. 13. 82, 88.
text.10445:
Mahāliṅgam — a tīrtha sacred to Kapila; sacred to the
Piṭrs.
M. 13. 33; 22. 34.
text.10446:
Mahāvajreśvarī — an Akṣarādevī: killed Kekivāhana, a
commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 19. 58; 25. 96; 37. 34.
text.10447:
Mahavarāha — an account of, in the Varāha Purāṇa.
M. 53. 39.
text.10448:
Mahāvāgvādinī — a Devī; is Lalitā.
Br. IV. 29. 89.
text.10449:
Mahāvidyā — a name of Lalitā;1 symbolical of Devī.2 1) Br. IV. 18. 16.
2) Vi. I. 9. 120.
text.10450:
Mahāviśva — one of the sons of Danu.
Vā. 68. 4.
text.10451:
Mahāvīta — the son of Savana and King of the Mahāvīta
Kingdom.
Br. II. 14. 14-15; Vā. 33. 14.
text.10452:
Mahāvītam — a Kingdom of Puṣkaradvīpa; after Mahā
vīta, son of Savana; adjoining the Mānasa Mt.
Br. II. 19. 117, 125; Vā. 33. 15; 49. 113, 121.
text.10453:
Mahāvīra — a son of Priyavrata, remained a bachelor
all through life engaged in ātmavidyā.
Bhā. V. 1. 25-6.
text.10454:
Mahāvīrya (I) — a son of Bṛhadratha, a bold warrior.
(Brhaduccha, Vā. P.); father of Sudhṛt.
Bhā. IX. 13. 15; Vā. 61. 44; 89. 9.
text.10455:
Mahāvīrya (II) — a son of Manyu (Bhuvamanyu Vā. P.,
and M. P.) and father of Duritakṣaya. (Durukṣaya Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 21. 1, 19; M. 49. 36; Vā. 99. 159; Vi. IV. 19. 21, 24.
text.10456:
Mahāvīrya (III) — a son of Virāṭ.
Br. II. 14. 69.
text.10457:
Mahāvīrya (IV) — a son of Raivata Manu.
Br. II. 36. 63.
text.10458:
Mahāvīrya (V) — the son of Bṛhadukta, and father of
Dṛtiman (Sudhṛti Vi. P.).
Br. III. 64. 9; Vi. IV. 5. 25.
text.10459:
Mahāvīrya (VI) — a son of Savana of Puṣkaradvīpa; the
kingdom bore his name.
Vi. II. 4. 73.
text.10460:
Mahāvyāhṛti — Mohini got the name from Brahmā; also
Sāvitrī.
Vā. 25. 50.
text.10461:
Mahāvratam — the performance of this vow leads one
to the world of Gaurī.
M. 101. 53.
text.10462:
Mahāśa (Mahīśa) — a son of Mitravindā.
Bhā. X. 61. 16.
text.10463:
Mahāśakti — a son of Mādrī.
Bhā. X. 61. 15.
text.10464:
Mahāśaṃkha — a chief Nāga of Pātāla; a thousand hood
ed snake; presiding over the month, saha.
Bhā. V. 24. 31; XII. 11. 41; M. 6. 40.
text.10465:
Mahāśana — an Asura friend of Kamsa.
Bhā. X. 2. 1.
text.10467:
Mahāśāla — a son of Janamejaya; a king equal to Indra
in fame; father of Mahāmanas.
M. 48. 13; Vā. 99. 15-6; Vi. IV. 18. 6-7.
text.10468:
Mahāśālanadī — a R. sacred to the Piṭrs.
M. 22. 42.
text.10470:
Mahāśāsta — originated from the vīrya dropped by Śiva
in his embrace of Mohiṇī — Viṣṇu.
Br. IV. 10. 75; 14. 7; 39. 57.
text.10473:
Mahāśī — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 88.
text.10474:
Mahāśīrṣa — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 88.
text.10475:
Mahāśīla — a son of Janamejaya and father of Mahā
manas.
Bhā. IX. 23. 2.
text.10476:
Mahāsatva — a god of the Prasūta group.
Br. II. 36. 71.
text.10477:
Mahāsandhyā — a śakti attached to Mahākāla.
Br. IV. 32. 9.
text.10481:
Mahāsenā — a name of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 17. 19.
text.10482:
Mahāsthalas — a Janapada of the Bhadrā continent.
Vā. 43. 20.
text.10483:
Mahāhanu (I) — a son and commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 81; 26. 47.
text.10484:
Mahāhanu (II) — a son of Rohiṇī and Ānakadundubhi.
M. 46. 12.
text.10486:
Mahāhaya — a son of Śatajit.
Bhā. IX. 23. 21
text.10487:
Mahāhavividhi — the other name for the Kālasūtra hell.
Vā. 101. 178.
text.10490:
Mahimā (II) — one of the eight Yogaiśvaryas; the third
Yoga.
Vā. 13. 3, 13.
text.10491:
Mahimān (I) — a son of Bhaga and Siddhī.
Bhā. VI. 18. 2.
text.10492:
Mahimān (II) — a son of Āyu Agni; also Śāvan.
Vā. 29. 37.
text.10493:
Mahiṣa (I) — a son of Anuhrāda and Sūrmyā: fought
with Vibhāvasu in the Devāsura war.
Bhā. VI. 18. 16; VIII. 10. 32.
text.10494:
Mahiṣa (II) — the son of Āyu and father of Sahasa.
Br. II. 12. 40.
text.10495:
Mahiṣa (III) — a Mt. of Kuśadvīpa (Śālmalidvīpam Br.,
Vā., and Vi. P.); here lives a fire called Mahiṣa, and born
of waters.
Br. II. 19. 40-41. M. 122. 59-60; Vā. 49. 37. Vi. II. 4. 27.
text.10496:
Mahiṣa (IV) — the name of a water-born fire in the
Mahiṣa hill of the Śālmalidvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 41; Vā. 49. 37.
text.10497:
Mahiṣa (V) — an Asura residing in Rasātalam;1 was pre
sent at Tāraka's coronation; a commander of Tāraka's force
and had a chariot drawn by camels;2 threw Sāvitram astram
against Kubera; defeated both Nṛṛti and Varuṇa and releas
ed Kujambha from the noose; somāstram and vāyavyāstram
throwing out snow and wind, were sent to disable the Asuras,
when Kālanemi created a glowing fire by māyā and removed
the snow and wind etc;3 found Mathana vanquished by
Janārdana and sent his Śūla against Janārdana and Śakti
against Garuḍa when Janārdana repelled him and said:
“You are to be killed by a woman; get away;4 killed by
Durgā.5 1) Br. II. 20. 39.
2) M. 147. 28; 148. 42, 50.
3) Ib. 150. 113,
135; 151. 13.
4) Ib. 152. 17-24.
5) Br. IV. 29. 75 and 88.
text.10498:
Mahiṣa (VI) — a son of Maya.
Br. III. 6. 29; Vā. 68. 28.
text.10499:
Mahiṣa (VII) — the kingdom of, to be ruled over by
Guha.
Br. III. 74. 198.
text.10500:
Mahiṣa (VIII) — born of Surabhī; Buffalo as the riding
animal of Yama; as also of Vārāhī;1 its flesh for śrāddha.2 1) M. 6. 44; 261. 13, 30.
2) Ib. 17. 33.
text.10502:
Mahiṣas (I) — a Vindhyan tribe: Puṣpamitra was a
king;1 born of Hamsa Kāli;2 the kingdom of.3 1) Br. III. 74. 187.
2) Ib. III. 3. 75.
3) Vā. 99. 386.
text.10503:
Mahiṣas (II) — a Janapada of the Ketumālā continent.
Vā. 44. 12.
text.10504:
Mahiṣikas — a tribe of the south;1 a kingdom of.2 1) M. 114. 47.
2) Br. II. 16. 57.
text.10505:
Mahiṣī — a R. of the Ketumālā country.
Vā. 44. 22.
text.10506:
Mahiṣmat (I) — the son of Sohañji and father of Bhadra
senaka.
Bhā. IX. 23. 22.
text.10507:
Mahiṣmat (II) — a son of Samjaya and father of the
powerful Bhadrasena.
Br. III. 69. 5; Vā. 94. 5.
text.10510:
Mahī (I) — a R. in Kuśadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 62; M. 163. 64; Vi. II. 4. 43.
text.10511:
Mahī (II) — Mādhavī, (Vasundharā);1 rescued by the
Lord in Vārāha disguise from Pātāla; earth addressed the
Lord in words of praise of his greatness;2 addressed by
Sananda and other sages; the earth was rescued with
mountains; and was divided into seven islands and created
the four; bhū and other worlds;3 see Bhūmī.4 1) Vi. I. 4. 7, 25-28.
2) Ib. I. 4. 12-24.
3) Ib. I. 4. 27-44.
4) Ib. V. 1. 57.
text.10512:
Mahī (III) — with Vikeśī: a sthāna of Rudra;1 his son
was Lohitānga.2 1) Vi. I. 8. 7.
2) Ib. I. 8. 11.
text.10513:
Mahīdurga — one of six kinds of fortresses.
M. 217. 6.
text.10514:
Mahīdhara — an epithet of Viṣṇu.
Vi. V. 5. 21.
text.10515:
Mahīnetra — a son of Dyumatsena, ruled for 33 years.
M. 271. 28.
text.10516:
Mahendra (I) — a name of Indra (s.v.);1 in the Simsu
māra.2 1) Bhā. I. 15. 12; Vā. 39. 10; 53. 33; Vi. I, 9. 18; V. 10. 36;
11. 14.
2) Vā. 52. 95; M. 127. 24.
text.10517:
Mahendra (II) — a Mt. a Kulaparvata of the Bhārata
varṣa;1 sacred to Indra and Hari and fit for śrāddha;2 Paraśu
rāma's penance here for 12 years, twice;3 aśvamedha at;4
during the war with Bhaṇḍa, the Devī enclosed M. all round
by a wall of fire;5 rivers taking their origin from.6 1) Bhā. V. 19. 16; VII. 14. 32; Br. II. 16. 18; M. 114. 17, 31;
124. 21; Vā. 45. 89; Vi. II. 3. 3.
2) Br. III. 13. 17.
3) Ib. III.
44. 36; 46. 29; Bhā. X. 79. 12; IX. 16. 26.
4) Br. III. 47. 39, 45;
56. 23; 57. 1; 58. 3; IV. 21. 2; 31. 17; 44. 99.
5) Ib. IV. 26. 17-32.
6) Vā. 45. 106.
text.10518:
Mahendranilayas — the people of a Janapada.
Vā. 99. 386; Br. III. 74. 198.
text.10519:
Mahendraparvata — a sacred place for śrāddha; resorted
to by Indra; noted for a bilvatree, the making of offerings
under which gives good eye-sight.
Vā. 77. 17-18.
text.10520:
Mahendrabhaumas — hill regions of Mahendra under
the Guhas.
Vi. IV. 24. 65.
text.10521:
Mahendram — a tīrtha sacred to the Piṭrs.
M. 22. 44.
text.10522:
Mahendravanālayam — the place where Vaivasvata
Manu performed austerities after retirement from rulership
of the world.
M. 11. 42.
text.10523:
Maheśvara (I) — (Śiva): cursed the seven sages to be
born in every epoch;1 got vṛṣa (bull) from Surabhī for his
standard;2 lived long in his father-in-law's house after
marriage; Meru insulted him as poor and useless when Umā
insisted on her husband to go to his house; he went to
Benares after which it became Avimukta;3 also Brahmā;4
Stambha; Kāpāli on earth for having removed one face of
Brahmā; to get rid of this brahmicide Śiva's service to
Kāmākṣī at Kāñcī; blessed for his samādhi; bathed in Pañ
casaras and found himself at Kāśi, from there to Kāñcī; Jyo
tirmayibhikṣa given; the Kapāla dropped out and he was
relieved;5 blessed Kubera to be the lord of the Yakṣas for
his penance at the confluence of the Narmadā and the
Kāverī.6 Praise of, by Kāvya.7 1) Br. II. 27. 47; III. 1. 9.
2) Ib. III. 3. 78-79.
3) Ib. III. 31.
35. 67. 32, 60.
4) Ib. IV. 1. 203; 2. 221, 257; 4. 35, 73; 7. 49; 14. 18.
5) Ib. IV. 40. 52-59.
6) M. 181. 3-5; 185. 12; 189. 10.
7) Vā. 97,
162-202.
text.10524:
Maheśvara (II) — as cosmos; hence acintyātma but the
source of all beings; Brahmanas from face, Kṣatriyas, from
breast, Vaiśyas from the thighs and Śūdras from the feet;1
created the world, men, devas, asuras, constellation, night,
day, Vedas, etc.;2 the smallest atom among the prakṛtis, never
failing, absolute; formless, and of form; the darkness becomes
illumination by the contact of tejas;3 the six angas of; all
wise, all satiating, ever arousing, all free, eternally powerful,
and of undiminished strength;4 a Mahāyogi;5 Lokeśa,
worshipped in different ways.6 1) Vā. 9. 122.
2) Br. I. 5. 95.
3) Vā. 101. 226.
4) Ib. 12.
31-3.
5) Ib. 21. 36.
6) Ib. 49. 171.
text.10525:
Maheśvarī — the Goddess enshrined at Mahākāla;1 a
name of Lalitā;2 Gā and Virūpā dropped out of the face of
Maheśvara; also Rudrāṇī and Mahādevī; was Mati, Smṛti,
and Buddhi; asked by Mahādeva to bring the world under
control by Yoga.3 1) M. 13. 41.
2) Br. IV. 10. 7; 14. 3; 28. 89; 29. 102; 40. 2.
3) Vā. 23. 5.
text.10526:
Mahogra — a son of Praheti, the Rākṣasa.
Br. III. 7. 91.
text.10527:
Mahotpalā — a Goddess enshrined at Kamalākṣa.
M. 13. 34.
text.10528:
Mahotsāha — a son of Auttama Manu.
Br. II. 36. 39; Vā. 62. 34.
text.10530:
Mahodayā — the sabhā of the Lord of the Nakṣatras, the
seats and altars of pure beryl.
Vā. 34. 90.
text.10531:
Mahodara (I) — a son of Puṣpotkaṭā and Viśravas;1 a
Dānava.2 1) Br. III. 8. 55; Vā. 70. 49.
2) Ib. 68. 10.
text.10532:
Mahodara (II) — a leader of Śiva Gaṇa ordered by Śiva
to fetch Paraśurāma to help the Devas in their war against
the Asuras;1 especially to fight Śūra.2 1) Br. III. 24. 50, 57; 25. 46.
2) Ib. III. 46. 11.
text.10535:
Mahoṣṇīṣa — a Rākṣasa residing in Sutalam.
Br. II. 20. 23; Vā. 50. 22.
text.10537:
Mahaujas (II) — a son of Bhadrā and Vasudeva.
Vā. 96. 171; Br. III. 71. 173.
text.10539:
Māgadha (I) — Jarāsandha who was vanquished by
Kṛṣṇa, see Magadha (s.v.).
Bhā. III. 3. 10; X. 2. 2; 83. 23.
text.10540:
Māgadha (II) — born of Pṛthu's sacrifice with Sūta;
panegyrised Pṛthu and got Māgadha country as gift;1 at
Kṛṣṇa's Jātakarma;2 in the royal household.3 1) Bhā. IV. 15. 20; X. 5. 5; 50. 37; 53. 43; 70. 20; 71. 29; 84.
46; Br. II. 36. 113, 159-160, 172; Vā. 62. 95, 137; Vi. I. 13. 52. 64.
2) Br. III. 28. 1 and 4; 27. 13; 49. 21; 55. 9 and 14; IV. 26. 62
3) M.
212. 14; Vā. 62. 147-148.
text.10541:
Māgadha (III) — (Paulastya) — a sage of the 14th epoch
of Bhautya Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 34; Br. IV. 1. 112; Vā. 100. 116; Vi. III. 2. 44.
text.10543:
Māgadha (V) — for Śrutaśravas, son of Somādhi.
Vā. 99. 228.
text.10544:
Māgadhas (I) — the people of the Magadha country
(eastern country M. P.); a Kingdom of Madhyadeśa;1
Kṣatriya caste of Śākadvīpa.2 1) Bhā. X. 2. 2; Br. II. 16. 42; M. 114. 45; 121. 50; 163. 66.
2) Vi. 11. 4. 69.
text.10545:
Māgadhas (II) — the royal line from Bṛahadratha to
Śrutaśravas.
M. 50. 27-34.
text.10546:
Māgadhamāna — a kind of measure.
Vi. VI. 3. 8.
text.10547:
Māgha (I) — considered as the first of months;1 gift of
Brahmavaivarta Purāṇa in this month leads one to Brahma
loka;2 Mahesvara to be worshipped in this month.3 1) Br. II. 24. 141.
2) M. 53. 36.
3) Ib. 56. 2; 60. 36; Vā. 50. 122;
53. 113.
text.10548:
Māgha (II) — (Pañcadaśi): a yugādi for śrāddha;
(saptami) a manvantarādi for śrāddha.
M. 17. 4, 7.
text.10550:
Māṅgali — (also Mangali) a pupil of Pauṣyañji, and who
learnt a hundred Sāma Samhitas.
Bhā. XII. 6. 79.
text.10551:
Maṃgalyasūtram — the sacred cord or tāli worn by a
married woman.
Br. IV. 39. 87.
text.10553:
Māṭhara (II) — the sacred forest in the Vindhyas fit for
śrāddha.
Br. III. 13. 33; Vā. 77. 33.
text.10555:
Māṇikandhara — a Yakṣa, devoted to Lalitā.
Br. IV. 33. 78.
text.10557:
Māṇḍavī — a Goddess enshrined at Māṇḍavya.
M. 13. 42.
text.10558:
Māṇḍavya (I) — a tīrtha sacred to Māṇḍavī.
M. 13. 42.
text.10559:
Māṇḍavya (II) — a Bhārgava gotrakāra.1 The sage
who cursed Yama to be born as Vidura.2 1) M. 195. 21.
2) Bhā. III. 5. 20; Br. II. 27. 25.
text.10560:
Māṇḍuka — a pupil of Kṛta.
Br. II. 35. 51.
text.10561:
Māṇḍuki — a Śrutaṛṣi; a pupil of Indrapramati in charge
of a part of the Ṛg Veda.
Br. II. 33. 3; 34. 28.
text.10562:
Māṇḍukeya — the sage-poet who was instructed in the
Ṛg Samhitā by Indrapramati; his pupil was Devamitra.
Bhā. XII. 6. 56; Vi. III. 4. 19.
text.10564:
Māṇḍvya — a Ṛtvik at the yajña of Brahmā.
Vā. 106. 35.
text.10565:
Mātaṅga (I) — a son of Khaśa and a Rākṣasa.
Br. III. 7. 134; Vā. 69. 165; 111. 53.
text.10566:
Mātanga (II) — a son of Matanga, and a sage; his wife
Siddhimatī gave birth to Laghuśyāmā or Mātangī.
Br. IV. 31. 89, 91-106.
text.10568:
Mātaṃgī — a mind-born mother; is Laghuśyāmā.
Br. IV. 19. 80; 31. 104; M. 179. 27.
text.10569:
Mātaras — Mother Goddesses present in Varuṇa's sacri
fice; nine in number; Lakṣmī, Sarasvatī, Gaurī, Caṇḍikā,
Tripurāmbikā, Bhairavā, Kālī, Mahāśāstri; use of liquor in
the worship of the deities;1 consorts of;2 Mātras: also Kīrti
(fame), Lakṣmī (riches), Dhṛtī (courage), Medhā (wis
dom), Puṣṭi (strength), Śraddha (faith), Kriyā (action),
Mati (Knowledge), Buddhi (intelligence), Lajjā (mo
desty), Vapu (body), Śānti (peace), Tuṣṭi (contentment)
and Kānti (beauty) invoked in Gṛahabali.3
A list of Mātaras created by Rudra to vanquish the
Andhaka Asuras; the mother-goddess felt hungry and
thirsty and asked Śiva for food; the pangs of hunger were
so keen that they ate of the worldly beings; Śiva then
thought of Nṛsimha and praised Him; he created a number
of mother-goddesses to overpower them; then all of them
were blessed to be divine beings and help people to tide
over difficulties when they would remember and pray to
them; seven mothers.4 1) Br. III. 1. 28; IV. 7. 72; 14. 6; 20. 46; 44. 111-12.
2) Ib. II.
25. 69.
3) M. 93. 53.
4) Ib. 179. 9-32, 41-89.
text.10570:
Mātariśva — is Vāyu; heard the Bṛahmāṇḍa Purāṇa
from the Creator and narrated it to Uśanas;1 related the
story in sweet words as seen and in logical order.2 1)Br. IV. 2. 112, 114, 259; 4. 58.
2) Vā. 1. 47; 59. 111; 101.
7 and 112, 114, 323; 103. 58.
text.10572:
Mātali — the charioteer of Indra;1 attacked by Jambha
in the Devāsura war; attacked by Pāka; in chariot, surround
ed by all the Devas against Tāraka on the other side;
wounded by three darts of Tāraka; his mudgara thrown on
the chariot, went to pieces. Mātali did not die;2 acted
as the charioteer of Rāma in his war with Rāvaṇa.3 1) M. 148. 81.
2) Bhā. VIII. 11. 16-18, 22; M. 153. 161, 181,
193; 174. 10.
3) Bhā. IX. 10. 21.
text.10573:
Mātā (I) — is Lalitā; the goddess enshrined at Siddha
pura, and at Kāyārohaṇa.
Br. IV. 29. 44, 142; M. 13. 46, 48.
text.10574:
Mātā (II) — the daughter of Ṛṣā; gave birth to Grahas,
Anujyeṣṭakas, Niṣkas, and Śiśumāras;1 different fishes; (the
word reads mīnā by mistake.)2 1) Vā. 69. 291.
2) Ib. 69. 293.
text.10575:
Māturaṃśa — the portion of a man's body, which he
derives from his mother; this part of Vena's body gave rise to
the Mlecchas.
M. 10. 8.
text.10577:
Mātulasambandam — marrying in maternal uncle's
family. Yayāti cursed his son Yadu to bring forth refrac
tory sons by such relationship.
M. 33. 8.
text.10579:
Mātṛs — a Deva gaṇa;1 fought with Utkala in the Devā
sura war, but were put to flight by Kṛṣṇa.2 1) Vā. 72. 50.
2) Bhā. II. 10. 38; VI. 8. 25; VIII. 10. 33;
X. 63. 11.
text.10580:
Mātṛkam — a mantranyāsa in Dīkṣa.
Br. IV. 43. 11.
text.10581:
Mātṛkā — the wife of Aryama and mother of Carṣaṇis.
Bhā. VI. 6. 42.
text.10584:
Mātṛgṛham — a tīrtha sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 22. 76.
text.10586:
Mātṛsāmānyas — the Rākṣasas who cause fear to
children.
Vā. 69. 190.
text.10587:
Mātrā — the shortest period of time.
Vi. VI. 3. 6.
text.10588:
Mātsya — a son of Vasu.
Vi. IV. 19. 81.
text.10590:
Mātsyanyāya — the small fish being eaten by big fish;
the rule of might.
M. 225. 9.
text.10591:
Mātsyam (Purāṇam) — originally told by Gadādhara;1
told by Janārdana in the guise of a fish to Manu consisting
of a description of Narasimha and an account of the seven
kalpas and consisting of 14,000 verses; he who gives it along
with a golden fish and a cow on the first day of the Caitra
month gets the benefit of the gift of the whole world.2 1) M. 1. 10.
2) Ib. 53. 50-2; Vā. 104. 3.
text.10592:
Mātsya Rūpa — (Matsya avatār) of Viṣṇu, being the
tenth avatār during the deluge in the epoch of Cākṣuṣa man
vantara for the protection of Vaivasvata Manu.
Bhā. I. 3. 15.
text.10593:
Māthuras — a tribe; ended their lives by killing their
own men.
Bhā. X. 1. 27; XI. 30. 18.
text.10594:
Māthailya — one of the seven sons of Vidyoparicara.
a Vasu and Girika.
Vā. 99. 222.
text.10596:
Mādravatī — (Mādrī) one of the two wives of Pāṇḍu,
gave birth to two twins, Nakula and Sahadeva by the grace
of Aśvins.
Bhā. IX. 22. 28; Br. III. 71. 155; M. 46. 10; 50. 48; Vā. 96.
154; 99. 243; Vā. 99. 243; Vi. IV. 14. 37-8; 20-40.
text.10600:
Mādrī (I) — see Mādravatī.
Bhā. IX. 22. 28; M. 50. 48; Vā. 99. 243.
text.10601:
Mādrī (II) — one of the wives of Dṛṣṭi; her sons were
Yudhājit, Midharāmsa, Animitra and Śinī.
Br. III. 71. 18-19.
text.10602:
Mādrī (III) — the second wife of Vṛṣṇi; gave birth to five
sons, Yudhājit (Devamiḍhuṣa), Anamitra, etc.
M. 45. 1-2; Vā. 96. 17-9.
text.10603:
Mādrī (IV) — a queen of Kṛṣṇa; mother of Vṛka and
other sons.
M. 47. 14; Vā. 96. 234; Vi. V. 32. 4.
text.10604:
Mādrī (V) — the mother of Suhotra by Sahadeva, the
Pāṇḍava.
M. 50. 55.
text.10605:
Mādreya — a kingdom of Madhyadeśa.
Br. II. 16. 40.
text.10606:
Mādhava (I) — a name of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. I. 15. 18; Br. II. 31. 77; III. 33. 18; 72. 140; IV. 9. 61;
34. 72 and 77; Vi. V. 20. 35.
text.10607:
Mādhava (II) — the month sacred to Aryaman;1 (Tamil
Vaikāśi); with the month of Madhu forms a ṛtu.2 1) Bhā. XII. 11. 34.
2) Br. II. 13. 9; Vā. 52. 5.
text.10608:
Madhava (III) — a son of Auttama Manu.
M. 9. 12.
text.10609:
Mādhava (IV) — with Vaṭeśvara in Prayāgā;1 forming
a part of the figure, Śivanārāyaṇa;2 in the middle of the Viś
vacakra.3 1) M. 22. 9;
2) Ib. 249. 48; 260. 22.
3) Ib. 285. 16.
text.10610:
Mādhava (V) — an Asura killed by Śatrughna.
