text.12837:
Videha (II) — a name of Janaka. He had realised the
Yoga power of Hari.
Bhā. XI. 2. 14; II. 7. 44.
text.12838:
Videha (III) — a name of Nimi.
Vi. IV. 5. 8.
text.12839:
Videhas — an eastern tribe;1 the kingdom of Janaka.2 1) M. 163. 67.
2) Vi. III. 18. 90.
text.12841:
Videhapurī — the capital of King Janaka; Balarāma
spent sometime there teaching mace warfare to Duryodhana.
Vi. IV. 13. 102, 106.
text.12842:
Vidyā (I) — leads to happiness: Role of teacher and
pupil. A means to attain final beatitude;1 of 18 groups — also
14 groups;2 survive antarkṣaya.3 1) Bhā. XI. 10. 12; 11. 4-7; VI. 16. 27.
2) Br. III. 35. 88-9; III.
15. 29; IV. 12. 57; 18. 46; 34. 69.
3) M. 2. 13.
text.12844:
Vidyās (I) — not to have marital alliances with Viśvā
mitras, Khili Khilis, etc.
M. 198. 21.
text.12845:
Vidyās (II) — 14 including Mimāmsa, Nyāya, Purāṇa,
Dharmaśāstra, — 18 in number, — also includes Āyurveda.
Dhanurveda, Gāndharva, and Arthaśāstra;1 four Anvīkṣikī.
Trayī, Vārta and Daṇḍanīti;2 another division — Parā and
Aparā.3 1) Vi. III. 6. 27-8;
2) Ib. V. 10. 27.
3) Ib. V. 1. 35.
text.12846:
Vidyācaṇḍa — a son of Sudaridra (s.v.) a poor Brahman
of Pāñcaladeśa.
M. 21. 3.
text.12848:
Vidyādharas — semi celestial beings: their creation;1
adore Indra;2 Cītraketu (Citraratha-M. P.) their chief;3
came to Dvārakā to see Kṛṣṇa;4 Sudarśana, a chief of;5
country of, watered by Nalinī;6 the path of.7 The performer
of Saubhāgyaśayanam is born as a Vidyādhara.8 1) Bhā. II. 1. 36. 6. 14; III. 20. 44; Br. III. 10. 38; 31. 23; IV. 20.
49; 39. 56.
2) Bhā. VI. 7. 4.
3) Ib. VI. 17. 1 and 3; VII. 8. 37; X. 3. 6;
34. 9; 62. 19; 85. 4; M. 4. 20; 8. 6; 80. 13.
4) Bhā. XI. 6. 3; 12. 4; 14. 5;
31. 2.
5) Ib. XI. 16. 29.
6) Br. II. 18. 60; M. 121. 48; Vā. 47. 47.
7) Br.
IV. 6. 13. and 22.
8) M. 60. 48.
text.12851:
Vidyādharapuram — the city of the Vidyādharas; in the
region between the Tāmravarṇa lake and the Patanga hills;
there dwells Pulomā, king of the Vidyādharas.
M. 66. 18; 78. 11; Vā. 38. 8-16.
text.12852:
Vidyādharādhipati — a title got by Citraketu when he
mastered the Vidyā imparted to him by Nārada.
Bhā. VI. 16. 27-8.
text.12853:
Vidyādharādhipatyam — the over-lordship of the Vidyā
dharas to be attained by Kāma.
M. 4. 20.
text.12855:
Vidyādharīs — the women of the Vidyādharas.
Bhā. III. 23. 37-8; Br. III. 50. 40.
text.12857:
Vidyāyoga — employed by Sunīthā in protecting the
corpse of her son.
Bhā. IV. 14. 35.
text.12858:
Vidyāvatī — a daughter of the Gandharvas.
Vā. 69. 10.
text.12859:
Vidyu — a R. from Kuśadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 62.
text.12860:
Vidyucchatru — the Rākṣasa presiding over the month.
Saha.
Bhā. XII. 11. 41.
text.12861:
Vidyujjihva (I) — a Rākṣasa of the fifth tala or Mahā
tala: a son of Vākā having his city in Arvāktalam.
Vā. 50. 35; 70. 50; Br. II. 20. 36; III. 8. 56;
text.12862:
Vidyujjihva (II) — a Rākṣasa; son of Khaśā.
Vā. 69. 195.
text.12863:
Vidyut (I) — a son of Yātudhāna: father of Rasana.
Br. III. 7. 89 and 95.
text.12864:
Vidyut (II) — a R. of the Kuśadvīpa.
M. 122. 73.
text.12865:
Vidyut (III) — a Rākṣasa, residing in the mārgaśīrṣa in
the sun's chariot.
Vi. II. 10. 13.
text.12866:
Vidyuta — a unit of time; also Vidyuti (Vā. P.)
Br. II. 21. 126; Vā. 50. 180.
text.12867:
Vidyutpatāka — one of the seven Pralaya clouds.
M. 2. 8.
text.12869:
Vidyutsphūrja — a Rākṣasa with the Hemanta sun.
Br. II. 23. 19.
text.12870:
Vidyudambā — a R. of Kuśadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 43.
text.12873:
Vidyunmālī (I) — one of Bhaṇḍa's eight councillors.
Br. IV. 12. 12.
text.12874:
Vidyunmālī (II) — the Asura of great penance who took
a glorious part in the Tārakāmaya war;1 on the side of Maya;
he received a deadly wound from Nandi and fell dead;
restored to life by Maya with the medicinal waters of the
tank;2 his battle with Nandi and death.3 1) M. 129. 5.
2) Ib. 131. 22.
3) Ib. 136. 16 f; 138. 47; 140. 18-36.
text.12876:
Vidyota — a son of Lambā and Dharma. Father of
Stanayitnus (clouds).
Bhā. VI. 6. 5.
text.12877:
Vidyoparicara — a Vasu: a son of Kṛta, the learned friend
of Indra, and a warrior.
Vā. 99. 220.
text.12880:
Vidruma — a Mt. of Kuśadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 54; Vi. II. 4. 41.
text.12881:
Vidrumoccaya — a Mt. of Kuśadvīpa.
M. 122. 52; Vā. 49. 49.
text.12883:
Vidvān (II) — Bṛhangiras and a son of Varūtri.
Br. III. 1. 79; Vā. 65. 78.
text.12884:
Vidvānagni — (Manyumān): a son of Hṛcchaya and
Jāṭharāgni and father of Samvartaka.
Br. II. 12. 34; Vā. 29. 32.
text.12885:
Vidhama — a son of Kali, with one leg: wife Revatī;
father of a number of sons; a cannibal.
Br. III. 59. 10; Vā. 84. 11-12.
text.12887:
Vidhātā (II) — one of the names in the third Marut
gaṇa.
Vā. 67. 126.
text.12888:
Vidhātri (I) — a son of Khyātī and Bhṛgu, married
Niyatī, (Āyatī-Vā. P.) a daughter of Meru. His place in the
Siśumāra; father of Pāṇḍu.
Bhā. IV. 1. 43-4; V. 23. 5; Br. II. 13. 37; 11. 6; Vā. 28. 1; 30. 34.
text.12889:
Vidhātri (II) — a son of Aditi.
Bhā. VI. 6. 39.
text.12890:
Vidhātri (III) — a name of Brahmā.
Bhā. X. 39. 19; Vā. 62. 193; Vi. V. 18. 56.
text.12891:
Vidhātri (IV) — a son of Mṛkaṇḍu.
Vi. I. 8. 15; 10. 2, 3.
text.12895:
Vidhārya — one of the names in the third Marut gaṇa.
Vā. 67. 126.
text.12896:
Vidhi (I) — a god of the ten branches of the Rohita
gaṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 86; Vā. 100. 91.
text.12897:
Vidhi (II) — a name of Brahmā.
Br. IV. 28. 89.
text.12898:
Vidhi (III) — Prescriptions in the Śāstras; they are two
fold, one with mantra, and the other without mantra.
M. 183. 44.
text.12899:
Vidhi (IV) — (ety) one of the ten lakṣaṇas of the
Brāhmaṇa.
Vā. 59. 136.
text.12901:
Vidhi (VI) — the araṇi from which to get sacred fire.
Vā. 112. 50.
text.12902:
Vidhivākyaviśārada — a skilled interpreter of injunc
tions, eligible for Pārvaṇa śrāddha.
M. 16. 8.
text.12903:
Vidhisāra — a son of Kṣetrajña, and the father of Ajāta
śatru: ruled for 38 years.
Bhā. XII. 1. 6; Br. III. 74. 130; Vi. IV. 24. 13-14.
text.12904:
Vidhu — a name of the moon; shone in ten directions
having got the over-lordship of the seven worlds by tapas.
M. 23. 28-31.
text.12905:
Vidhūtarajas — a class of celestials born with Viṣṇu in
the Vaikuṇṭha.
Br. III. 3. 117.
text.12906:
Vidhṛti (I) — the father of Vaidhṛtis, a group of gods.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 29.
text.12907:
Vidhṛti (II) — a son of Khagaṇa, and father of Hiraṇya
nābha.
Bhā. IX. 12. 3.
text.12908:
Vidhṛti (III) — a god of Ābhūtaraya group.
Br. II. 36. 55.
text.12911:
Vidhya — a Rākṣasa with the sun in Hemanta.
Vā. 52. 19.
text.12912:
Vinata (I) — a Vānara chief and son of Śveta.
Br. III. 7. 180.
text.12913:
Vinata (II) — a son of Sudyumna: Lord of Western
Kingdom.
Br. III. 60. 18.
text.12914:
Vinatā (I) — a daughter of Dakṣa and one of the wives
of Taikṣya, (Kaśyapa-M. P., Vā. P., Vi. P.), begot Garuḍa and
Aruṇa (see also Suparṇā);1 known for flying in the air;2 had
two sons and thirtysix daughters; they comprised the Gāyatrī
and other chandas and birds like Suparṇā;3 1) Br. III. 3. 56; 7. 29 and 468; 61. 42; Bhā. III. 15. 40; VI. 6. 21-2;
M. 6. 2, 33-4; 146. 18 and 22; 171. 29 and 62; Vā. 66. 54; Vi. I. 15. 125.
2) Vā. 69. 83.
3) Ib. 69. 66-7.
text.12916:
Vinatāśva — a son of Sudyumna, became the lord of
western territories.
Vā. 85. 19.
text.12917:
Vinaya (I) — a son of Lajjā.
Br. II. 9. 61; Vā. 10. 36.
text.12918:
Vinaya (II) — a son of Cancu.
Br. III. 63. 118.
text.12919:
Vinaya (III) — the discipline of mind and body important
to a king; ill-disciplined kings have lost their empires; while
disciplined kings leading a forest life attained kingdom
through vinaya;1 of a Prince.2 1) M. 215. 52.
2) Ib. 220. 4-7; 225. 7.
text.12921:
Vinaśana (I) — another name of Kurukṣetra.
Bhā. I. 9. 1.
text.12922:
Vinaśana (II) — the place where the Sarasvatī dis
appears: on the way from Dvārakā to Hāstinapura.
Bhā. X. 71. 21; 79. 23.
text.12923:
Vināyaka (I) — a name of Vighneśvara or Vighneśa
(s.v.)1 in charge of Kailāsa hill2 a graha.3 Asked Paraśu
rāma not to enter Śiva's abode as he was with Umā. When
he forced entry, Vināyaka made him wander all the
seven worlds. Paraśurāma knocked his teeth with
his axe to the enragement of Pārvatī. Śiva thought
of Kṛṣṇa who appeared on the scene with Rādhā.
Kṛṣṇa said that Vināyaka should be remembered on
all auspicious and other occasions to bring out the
desired results. The Śaiva Gaṇeśa became Vaiṣṇava:4 wor
shipped in all ceremonials as preliminary, in the Bhīṣma dvā
daśi, in grahabali;5 when Umā made out of earth an elephant
faced doll and threw it in the Ganges, it became a huge
figure, adopted as son both by Umā and Gangā; came to be
known as Gāngeya and Gajānana; invested with overlord
ship of all Vināyakas.6 Icon of, with mūṣika mount Ṛddhi
and Buddhi on either side; worship of;7 elephant shaped.8 1) Bhā. XI. 27. 29.
2) Br. II. 25. 30.
3) Ib. III. 7. 161.
4) Ib. III. 41.
17-32, ch. 42, 44. 23.
5) M. 58. 26. 69. 27; 93. 16.
6) Ib. 154. 505; 230.
8.
7) Ib. 260. 19, 52-5: 261. 38: 266, 42; 269. 56; 274; 15; 289. 7.
8) Vā.
30. 311; 54. 35; 106. 57; 109. 23.
text.12924:
Vināyaka (II) — a tīrtha sacred to Umā.
M. 13. 41.
text.12925:
Vināyakās (I) — a variety of evil spirits;1 a group of
Bhūtas, followers of Śiva2 1) Bhā. II. 10. 38; VI. 8. 24; X. 2. 33; 6. 27.
2) Br. II. 25. 114; III.
10. 52.
text.12926:
Vināyakās (II) — different gaṇas like Kūṣmāṇḍa,
Gajatuṇḍa and Jayanta; described as having faces of lion
and tiger, short and crooked, etc.1 a devagaṇa.2 1) M. 183. 63-4.
2) Vā. 72. 50.
text.12927:
Vinīta (I) — a son of Uttama Manu.
Br. II. 36. 40.
text.12928:
Vinīta (II) — the third son of Prītī and Pulastya.
Vā. 28. 22.
text.12930:
Vinda — a prince of Avanti, a son of Rājādhidevī and
brother of Anuvinda;1 under the influence of Duryodhana
(as also Anuvinda) the brothers wanted to give their
sister in marriage to Duryodhana, and not to Kṛṣṇa whom
she loved: stationed by Jarāsandha at the southern gate of
Mathurā and Gomanta during their respective sieges.2 1) Vā. 96. 157; Vi. IV. 14. 43.
2) Bhā. X. 58. 30; 50. 11[3]; 52.
11[9]; Br. III. 71. 158.
text.12932:
Vindhya (I) — a Mt. (Kulaparvata-Vā. P.) in Bhārata
varṣa. Here Dakṣa performed tapas;1 a Kulaparvata sacred
for Śrāddha offerings.2 Here Haihaya came for hunting:
Kṛṣṇa went there in search of Prasena;3 sacred to Vindyādhi
vāsinī and the Pitṛs;4 caused by Agastya to bow down and
not to rise in height;5 joining with the Ganges is more sacred
than Kurukṣetra;6 rivers originating from;7 obstructed by it
the Gaṅgā enters the sea;8 Goddess of night was asked to seek
shelter in the Vindhyas after she left Umā's body.9 1) Bhā. V. 19. 16; VI. 4. 20; Vi. II. 3. 3.
2) Br. II, 16. 19; III. 7.
356; 13. 34; M. 114. 18; Vā. 45. 89; 58. 81; 69. 239; 77. 34; 88. 199; 96.
38.
3) Br. III. 26. 25; 71. 39.
4) M. 13. 39; 22. 66.
5) Ib. 61. 51.
6) Ib.
106. 49.
7) Ib. 114. 27-8; Vā. 45. 103.
8) M. 121. 51; Vā. 47. 50.
9) M.
157, 17, 19.
text.12933:
Vindhya (II) — a son of Raivata Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 5. 2.
text.12934:
Vindhyakas — the tribes of the Vindhya region.
Br. III. 74. 186; M. 114. 51 and 54.
text.12939:
Vindhyaśakti — a son of Kilakila (Kaiṅkila Yavana
Vi. P.) succeeded by Vaidiśaka kings;1 ruled for 96 years;2
father of Purañjaya.3 1) Br. III. 74. 178.
2) Vā. 99. 365.
3) Vi. IV. 24. 56.
text.12940:
Vindhyasena — a son of Kṣemajit, ruled for 28 years.
M. 272. 8.
text.12941:
Vindhyādhivāsinī — the Goddess enshrined in the
Vindhyas.
M. 13. 39.
text.12942:
Vindhyānilayas — a tribe on the border of the Vindhyas.
Vā. 62. 124.
text.12943:
Vindhyāparānti (ta) kas — (c) people bordering the
Vindhyas on the western side.
Br. III. 73. 107; Vā. 98. 106.
text.12944:
Vindhyāre — one of the sixteen śaktis of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 35. 99.
text.12945:
Vindhyāvali — the queen of Bali, who participated in his
gift to Vāmana. Seeing Bali bound with cords, she appealed
to Hari;1 mother-in-law of Anaupamyā wife of Bāṇa; had a
daughter called Kumbhīnasī; both of them ill-treated Bāṇa's
wife.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 20. 17; 22. 19-20.
2) M. 187. 40.
text.12946:
Vindhyāśva — a son of Indrasena and father of twins by
Menakā.
M. 50. 6-7.
text.12948:
Vipaṇa — a companion of Puramjana, allegorically the
organ of speech (see Mukhyā).
Bhā. IV. 25. 49; 29. 11.
text.12949:
Vipaści — Devendra of Svārociṣa epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 10.
text.12950:
Vipaścita — a god of the ten branches of the Sukarmāṇa
group of devas.
Br. IV. 1. 88; Vā. 100. 92.
text.12952:
Vipāda(ka)s — a class of Piśācas: nude and drinkers of
blood in the field of battle.
Br. III. 7. 377 and 399.
text.12953:
Vipādāṃgārikas — a Piśāca gaṇa, drink the blood shed
in wars.
Br. III. 7. 382 and 399; Vā. 69. 263.
text.12954:
Vipādī — a group of Piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 377.
text.12956:
Vipāśā (I) — visited by Balarāma;1 R. of the Plakṣadvīpa,2
from the Himālayas,3 in Bhāratavarṣa;4 sacred to Amoghākṣī
and the pitṛs.5 1) Bhā. X. 79. 11.
2) Br. II. 19. 19; Vi. II. 4. 11; III. 14. 18.
3) Br.
II. 16. 25.
4) Ib. II. 12. 15; Vā. 45. 96, 99.
5) M. 13. 35; 22. 23.
text.12957:
Vipāśā (II) — one of the 16 wives of Havyavāhana;1 in
the chariot of Tripurāri.2 1) M. 51. 14; Vā. 29. 14.
2) M. 133. 23.
text.12958:
Vipuram — ety. one who is void of dvandva, happiness
and misery, cold and heat, etc.
Vā. 4. 28.
text.12959:
Vipula (I) — a son of Vasudeva and Rohiṇī.
Bhā. IX. 24. 46.
text.12960:
Vipula (II) — a Mt. sacred to Vipulā; a Viṣkambhapar
vata,1 to the west of Ilāvṛta.2 1) M. 13. 36; Vā. 35. 16.
2) Vi. II. 2. 18.
text.12962:
Vipulā (I) — the Goddess enshrined at Vipula.
M. 13. 36.
text.12963:
Vipulā (II) — the sabhā of Kubera; description of;
here is Puṣpaka, the Vimāna; around are the ten
cities of the Gandharvas in the east, thirty cities of the Yakṣas
in the west, and a hundred cities of the Kinnaras in the
south.
Vā. 41. 5-11, 20, 24, 27-8.
text.12964:
Vipṛthu (I) — a son of Citraka;1 stationed by Kṛṣṇa at
the northern gate of Mathurā for defence against Jarāsan
dha; was on the right detachment of Kṛṣṇa's army;2 killed
in the Yādava contest at Prabhāsā.3 1) Br. III. 71. 114; Vā. 96. 113; Vi. IV. 14. 11.
2) Bhā. X. 50. 20
[3]; [50 (v) 12].
3) Vi. V. 37. 46.
text.12965:
Vipṛthu (II) — a son of Aśvinī and Akrūra.
M. 45. 32.
text.12966:
Vipṛṣṭha — a son of Vasudeva and Dhṛtadevā.
Bhā. IX. 24. 50.
text.12967:
Vipra (I) — a son of Sṛtaṃjaya, and father of Śuci.
Bhā. IX. 22. 47; Vi. IV. 23. 5.
text.12968:
Vipra (II) — a son of Śiṣṭi and Succhāyā.
Vi. I. 13. 2.
text.12969:
Vipracit (Vipracitti) — chief among the 100 sons of Danu,
married Simhikā who bore one hundred and one sons col
lectively called Simhikeyas. Father of Rāhu; a follower of
Vṛtra in his battle with Indra. Took part in the Devāsura
war between Bali and Indra, but was asked by Bali to refrain
from battle;1 in the sabhā of Hiraṇyakaśipu;2 in the churn
ing of the ocean;3 in the guise of a standard killed by Mahen
dra in Kolāhalā war:4 the overlord of the Dānavas; the
brother of Dhvaja who was killed by Indra; had his aim in
the dhvaja or standard.5 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 31 and 37; 18. 13; 10. 19 and 31; VII. 2. 5; VIII.
10. 19; 21. 19; M. 6. 16, 25; Vi. I. 9. 107; 15. 141; 21. 6, 10-12.
2) M. 161. 79.
3) Ib. 245. 31; 249. 67.
4) Ib. 47. 52.
5) Br. III. 5. 13;
6. 1 and 18; 8. 7: 72. 85; Vā. 67. 60; 70. 7; 97. 85.
text.12970:
Vipracitti (I) — an Apsaras with the sun in Hemanta.
Vā. 52. 18.
text.12971:
Vipracitti (II) — a servant of Hiraṇyakaśipu.
Vi. I. 19. 52.
text.12972:
Vibudha — a son of Devamīḍha (ṭha, Vā. P.); father of
Mahādhṛti.
Br. III. 64. 12; Vā. 89. 12; Vi. IV. 5. 27.
text.12975:
Vibhā (varī) (I) — the city of Varuṇa, entered by Hira
ṇyakaśipu;1 sun sets here when it is mid-day in Amarāvatī,
and rises when it is mid-day in Saumyakam.2 1) Bhā. III. 17. 26.
2) Br. II. 21. 33-9.
text.12976:
Vibhāvarī (II) — the city of Soma in the Mānasa on the
north of Meru.
Bhā. V. 21. 7; Br. II. 21. 33; Vā. 50. 90; Vi. II. 8. 9; M. 124. 24.
text.12977:
Vibhāvarī (III) — same as Puṇḍra; a R. of Kuśadvīpa.
M. 122. 73.
text.12978:
Vibhāvarī (IV) — the Goddess of Night: invoked by
Brahmā to enter into Umā's body until she should be able
to beget Guha. By so doing, the Night could get an
amśa of the Devī and will be praised as Devī. She went to
Menā, entered her eyes when the latter gave birth to Umā
early in the morning; then entered Umā after her penance;
hence dark in colour; Brahmā asked the goddess to go with
the lion to the Vindhyas and reside there.
M. 154. 57-96; 426-588: chh. 155-6.
text.12979:
Vibhāvasu (I) — a Vasu worshipped for tejas;1 wife
Uṣā who bore three sons, Vyuṣṭha, Rociṣa and Ātapa;2 fought
with Mahiṣa in the Devāsura war.3 1) Bhā. II. 3. 3; XI. 26. 3.
2) Ib. VI. 6. 11 and 16.
3) Ib. VIII. 10. 32.
text.12980:
Vibhāvasu (II) — a son of Danu; a follower of Vṛtra in
his battle with Indra.
Bhā. VI. 6. 30; 10 [20].
text.12981:
Vibhāvasu (III) — a son of Mura (s.v.).
Bhā. X. 59. 12.
text.12982:
Vibhāvasu (IV) — a name of Sūrya.
Br. II. 21. 83.
text.12984:
Vibhāvasu (VI) — was abandoned by his wife Dyutī for
Soma;1 Yayāti of Kuruvamśa compared to.2 1) M. 23. 24.
2) Ib. 35. 8.
text.12988:
Vibhāsa (III) — one of the twenty Amitābha gaṇas.
Br. IV. 1. 16; Vā. 100. 16.
text.12989:
Vibhīṣaṇa (I) — one of Bhaṇḍa's eight councillors.
Br. IV. 12. 12.
text.12990:
Vibhīṣaṇa (II) — a son of Viśravas and Kaikaśī, and a
friend of Rāma. On the advice of Rāma, performed funeral
rites to his kith and kin, according to established conventions.
Was made king of Lankā by Rāma. Held the cāmara when
Bharata carried pādukā of Rāma;1 knew the yoga power of
Hari and attained salvation by satsanga; of superior bhakti;2 a brother of Rāvaṇa;3 was present at Rāma's abhiṣeka.4 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 37; IX. 10. 16, 29 and 43.
2) Ib. II. 7. 45; XI. 12. 5;
Br. III. 34. 39.
3) Ib. III. 8. 47.
4) Vi. IV. 4. 99.
text.12991:
Vibhu (I) — a name of Hari.
Bhā. III. 9. 16.
text.12992:
Vibhu (II) — a son of Dakṣiṇā and a Tuṣita god.
Bhā. IV. 1. 7-8.
text.12993:
Vibhu (III) — a name of Śiva.
Bhā. IV. 4. 9.
text.12994:
Vibhu (IV) — a son of Prastāva (i); wife Ratī, and son
Pṛthusena.
Bhā. V. 15. 6; Br. II. 14. 67.
text.12995:
Vibhu (V) — a son of Bhaga and Siddhi.
Bhā. VI. 18. 2.
text.12996:
Vibhu (VI) — a son of Vedaśiras and Tuṣitā. From him
88,000 sages learnt celibate life.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 21-22.
text.12997:
Vibhu (VII) — the Indra of the Raivata epoch.
Bhā. VIII. 5. 3; Br. II. 36. 61; Vi. III. 1. 20.
text.12998:
Vibhu (VIII) — a name of Brahmā.
Bhā. IX. 3. 29; X. 1. 18.
text.13001:
Vibhu (XI) — a sādhya god.
Br. III. 3. 17; Vā. 66. 16.
text.13002:
Vibhu (XII) — the son of Satyaketu; father of Suvibhu.
Br. III. 67. 75; Vā. 92. 71. Vi. IV. 8. 20.
text.13003:
Vibhu (XIII) — one of the twenty Amitābha gods.
Br. IV. 1. 16; Vā. 100. 16.
text.13004:
Vibhu (XIV) — a son of Pratyūṣa, a Vasava;1 a Sādhya.2 1) M. 5. 27.
2) Ib. 203. 12.
text.13005:
Vibhu (XV) — a son of Śrutamjaya, ruled for 28 years.
M. 271. 24.
text.13007:
Vibhu (XVII) — a son of Pratāvī (Prāstāvī-Vi. P.).
Vā. 33. 57; Vi. II. 1. 37.
text.13008:
Vibhūti — a name of Śrī (Lakṣmī). Her abode in the
chest of the Lord; wife of Hari.
Bhā. I. 18. 20; III. 16. 20; 28. 26; V. 20. 40; VI. 16. 25; 19. 8.
text.13009:
Vibhūtidhāri — is Śiva with the sacred ash smeared all
over his body.
Br. III. 32. 13; Vā. 55. 45.
text.13010:
Vibhūtidvādaśī — in honour of Viṣṇu; in the months of
Kārtika, Caitra, Vaiśākha, Mārgaśīrṣa, Phālguṇa and Āṣā
ḍha; gift of a gold fish recommended; the end of the year
must close with Lavana parvata dāna; the ten avatārs of
Hari with Dattātreya and Vyāsa to be worshipped;1 was
observed by the courtesan Anangavatī who became the
queen of God of Love;2 doing it on the banks of the Ganges
gives one nirvāṇa.3 1) M. 99. 1-21.
2) Ib. 100. 18-32.
3) Ib. 100. 33.
text.13011:
Vibhūtis — of Hari; Indra among gods, Viṣṇu among
Ādityas, Bhṛgu among Brahmaṛṣis and so on.
Bhā. XI. 16. 9-40; Vā. 101. 329.
text.13012:
Vibhṛta (I) — a son of Svārociṣa Manu.
Br. II. 36. 19.
text.13013:
Vibhṛta (II) — a god of Sukarmāṇa group.
Br. IV. 1. 88.
text.13015:
Vibhrāja (I) — the father of Brahmadatta, the king of
Pāñcāla; his name was Anagha; he had no son and so he per
formed austerities; and was blessed by Nārāyaṇa with Brah
madatta.
M. 20. 23; 21. 11-16.
text.13016:
Vibhrāja (II) — the son of Sukṛta (ti-Vā. P.), and father
of Aṇuha.
M. 49. 56; Vā. 99. 178; Vi. IV. 19. 42-3.
text.13017:
Vibhrāja (III) — the hill of Sākadvīpa; here there is
resplendent fire.
M. 122. 17-8.
text.13018:
Vibhrājās — the pitṛs in the Barhiṣada worlds.
M. 15. 1.
text.13019:
Vibhrājita — the kingdom to which Puramjana went
through the gates, Khadyota and Āvirmukhi, with his friend
Dyumat; allegorically bright colour.
Bhā. IV. 25. 47; 29. 10.
text.13022:
Vimala (I) — a son of Sudyumna and a Lord of Dakṣi
ṇāpatha.
Bhā. IX. 1. 41.
text.13023:
Vimala (II) — a son of Devayānī and a Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 128.
text.13024:
Vimala (III) — the son of Jīmūta and father of Bhīma
ratha.
M. 44. 41.
text.13026:
Vimalā (II) — the goddess enshrined at Puruṣottama
M. 13. 35.
text.13029:
Vimaleśvaram — a tīrtha on the Narmadā sacred to the
Pitṛs;1 Lord Vimaleśvara is enshrined here;2 here a devaśilā
was established by Rudra and death on it takes one to
Rudraloka.3 1) M. 22. 8.
2) Ib. 190. 14.
3) Ib. 194. 39.
text.13030:
Vimāna — a temple with eight floors and a number of
towers; the toraṇa is of 34 hastas.
M. 269. 28, 32, 47.
text.13031:
Vimānam — Indra took Ditī and the Maruts in it to
heaven;1 Vivasvān took Samjñā with him.2 1) M. 7. 64.
2) Ib. 11. 37.
text.13032:
Vimānas — vehicles of gods;1 built by Viśvakarma.2 1) Vā. 30. 96.
2) Br. III. 10. 119; 16. 14 and 51; 59. 18; IV. 17. 16;
Vā. 66. 30.
text.13033:
Vimocanā (nī) — R. a main stream of Sālmalidvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 28; Vā. 49. 42; Br. II. 19. 46.
text.13034:
Vimoha(na) — (Vimocana-Vā. P.) the name of a hell.
He who transgresses boundary limits goes to this as also
thieves.
Br. IV. 2. 147 and 159; Vā. 101. 146, 157.
text.13035:
Viṃśa (I) (Vivimśa) — the father of a son Kalyāṇa by
name.
Vā. 86. 6.
text.13036:
Viṃśa (II) — a son of Cakṣuṣa and father of Vivimśaka.
Vi. IV. 1. 26.
text.13037:
Viṃśaja — the fourth king of Vidiśa.
Vā. 99. 368.
text.13038:
Viya (yā) ti — a son of Nahuṣa.
Bhā. IX. 18. 1; Br. III. 68. 12; Vi. IV. 10. 1.
text.13039:
Virakṣa — a son of Danāyuṣa and father of two sons
Kālaka and Vara.
Vā. 68. 30, 33.
text.13040:
Viraja (I) — a son of Pūrṇiman.
Bhā. IV. 1. 14.
text.13041:
Viraja (II) — one of the seven sons of Vasiṣṭha — sage
of the Cākṣuṣa epoch;1 attained heaven by tapas.2 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 41; Br. II. 36. 77; M. 9. 22.
2) Ib. 143. 38.
text.13042:
Viraja (III) — a son of Tvaṣṭri, wife Viṣūci: father of a
hundred sons — Śatajit and others, besides a daughter; raised
the status of Priyavrata line as Hari did for the greatness of
gods.
Bhā. V. 15. 15-16; Br. II. 14. 70; Vi. II. 1. 40.
text.13043:
Viraja (IV) — a pupil of Jātūkarṇya.
Bhā. XII. 6. 58.
text.13044:
Viraja (V) — a Prajāpati who offered his daughter
Virajā to Ṛkṣa; father of Sudhanvan and Vairājas — pitṛs liv
ing by yoga;1 father of Naḍvalā, the queen of Cākṣuṣa Manu;
a Rājaṛṣi and a tapassiddha.2 1) Br. III. 7. 212; 8. 17; 10. 4.
2) Ib. II. 30. 40; 36. 105; Vā. 57. 122.
text.13045:
Viraja (VI) — a son of Sṛñjaya, brother of Vasudeva.
Br. III. 71. 193.
text.13046:
Viraja (VII) — one of the four sons in the 30th kalpa
of Śarva — red in colour, attire, etc.
Vā. 22. 30.
text.13047:
Viraja (VIII) — a disciple of Lokākṣi, an avatār of the
Lord.
Vā. 23. 135.
text.13048:
Viraja (IX) — a son of Vāli, the avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 160.
text.13049:
Viraja (X) — a son of Pūrṇamāsa and Sarasvatī; his
wife was Gaurī; son Sudhāmā.
Br. II. 11. 13; Vā. 28. 10-12; Vi. I. 10. 6.
text.13050:
Viraja (XI) — the name of a Lekha.
Vā. 62. 66.
text.13051:
Viraja (XII) — the adopted son of Vastāvana.
Vā. 96. 190.
text.13052:
Viraja (XIII) — a son of Sāvarṇi Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 19.
text.13053:
Virajaska — a son of Manu Sāvarṇi.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 11.
text.13054:
Virajā (I) — a daughter of progenitor, Viraja; wife of
Ṛkṣa; loved by Mahendra, became mother of Vāli; loved by
Sūrya, became mother of Sugrīva.
Br. III. 7. 212-15.
text.13055:
Virajā (II) — the mind-born daughter of Ājyapa pitṛs;
queen of Nahuṣa and mother of Yayāti; belonging to the
Vaiśya gaṇa.
Br. III. 10. 95; Vā. 73. 45; 93. 12.
text.13056:
Virajā (III) — a svara śakti.
Br. IV. 44. 55 and 96.
text.13057:
Virajā (IV) — a sacred place near Nābhikūpa in Gayā;1
no fasting or shaving here.2 1) Vā. 106. 85.
2) Ib. 105. 25.
text.13058:
Virajās — the gods of the Sāvarṇi epoch;1 Agniṣvātta —
pitṛs.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 13. 12.
2) Br. III. 10. 75-6; IV. 1. 22.
text.13059:
Virañci — introduced paśu himsa in sacrifices.
Br. II. 30. 21.
text.13062:
Virāj (Virāṭ-Puruṣa) — the form of the Lord during the
period of creation, just emerged from Aṇḍa.1 To rouse him
to activity gods were created; but he was not roused until
the Kṣetrajña along with citta entered the heart and roused
the Puruṣa from waters;2 is Hari who is described as Mahā
Puruṣa;3 son of Nara;4 Antarikṣa so called.5 1) Bhā. II. 1. 25; III. 6. 6-34; 7. 22-25; 26. 51.
2) Ib. III. 36. 54-70;
X. 3. 15; XI. 3. 11-12; 17. 13.
3) Ib. XII. 11. 5-26.
4) Br. II. 14. 68.
5) Ib. II. 16. 17; III. 43. 9.
text.13065:
Virāja (III) — (Virāṭpuruṣa; also Samrāt and Manu)1
married Śatarūpā; sons Priyavrata and Uttānapāda and two
daughters, Ākūtī and Prasūtī; the latter was given to Dakṣa
and the former to Ruci to whom twins, Yajña and Dakṣiṇa
were born.2 1) Vā. 10. 15.
2) Br. II. 9. 39.
text.13066:
Virāja (IV) — a Mt. north of the Mahābhadra lake.
Vā. 36. 33.
text.13069:
Virāṭ (II) — is a name of Svāyambhuva Manu.
M. 3. 45.
text.13070:
Virāṭ (III) — the son of Nara;1 a Pratardana god.2 1) Vā. 30. 260; 33. 58; Vi. II. 1. 38.
2) Vā. 62. 26.
text.13071:
Virāṭ (IV) — one of the twenty Sutapa gaṇas.
Vā. 100. 15.
text.13072:
Virāṭa — the father of Uttarā: the Matsya king; as a
friend of Jarāsandha, besieged the southern gate of Mathurā,
and the eastern gate of Gomanta.1 But he joined the
Pāṇḍavas against the Kurus, and went to Syamanta
pañcaka for the solar eclipse;2 in charge of Dakṣiṇāpatha.3 1) Bhā. I. 8. 14; 10. 9; X. 50. 11 [3]; 52. 11 [7].
2) Ib. X. 78
[95 (v) 9]; 82. 25.
3) Br. III. 63. 11.
text.13073:
Virāṭpuruṣa — Virāja created by Brahmā; Vairāja
Manu, his son by Śatarūpā.
Vā. 10. 15; Br. II. 9. 39.
text.13075:
Virādha — a Rākṣasa of the Vitalam.
Vā. 50. 28.
text.13077:
Viriñca — (Virañcya-Bhā. P.); also Viriñci, a name of
Brahmā.
Bhā. X. 9. 20; M. 154. 17-54.
text.13078:
Viriñcibhavanam — the abode of Brahmā.
Br. III. 52. 9; 58. 9; IV. 39. 66.
text.13079:
Viruddhas — the gods of the epoch of the Tenth Manu;1
a gaṇa of the Second Sāvarṇa Manu.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 13. 22.
2) Br. IV. 1. 67.
text.13080:
Virūpa (I) — a son of Ambarīṣa, and father of Pṛṣadaśva.
Bhā. IX. 6. 1; Br. III. 63. 6; Vā. 88. 6. Vi. IV. 2. 7-8.
text.13081:
Virūpa (II) — a son of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 90. 34.
text.13082:
Virūpa (III) — a mantrakṛt of the Angirasa branch.
M. 145. 103; Vā. 59. 100.
text.13083:
Virūpa (IV) — not to have matrimonial connections with
Angiras and Rathītaras.
M. 196. 38.
text.13084:
Virūpa (V) — the formless form attained by a mukta.
Vā. 102. 77.
text.13085:
Virūpaka — the leader of the Rākṣasa clan — Nairṛtas,
followers of Trayambaka: married Vikacā, daughter of
Nīla: their issues were the awkward, disfigured and short
figures known as Bhūmirākṣasas.
Br. III. 7. 143; Vā. 69. 174.
text.13086:
Virūpā — came out of the face of Mahādeva.
Vā. 23. 5.
text.13087:
Virūpākṣa (I) — a son of Danu, and a follower of Vṛtra
in his battle with Indra.
Bhā. VI. 10. [20]; Br. III. 6. 11; Vā. 68. 11.
text.13088:
Virūpākṣa (II) — another name for Śiva having the sun,
moon and fire for eyes.
Br. II. 25. 64.
text.13090:
Virūpākṣa (IV) — one of the 11 Rudras; as a lokapāla.
M. 5. 29; 153. 19; 194. 19; 266. 27.
text.13092:
Virūpākṣa (VI) — the lord of the south-west direction.
Vā. 34. 87.
text.13093:
Virūpāśva — an Angirasa and mantrakṛt.
Br. II. 32. 109.
text.13094:
Virocana (I) — a son of Prahlāda, and father of Bali.
Took part in the Devāsura war between Bali and Indra, and
fought with Savitā;1 the Daitya king residing in the fifth
talam: served as calf for the Asuras to milk the earth: killed
by Indra in the Tārakāmaya war.2 Laughed at by Śukra: in
the sabhā of Hiraṇyakaśipu.3 1) Bhā. V. 24. 18; VI. 18. 16; VIII. 10. 20 and 29; M. 6. 10; Vi.
I. 21. 1.
2) Br. II. 20. 35; 36. 210; III. 5. 41; 72. 79 and 105; M. 10. 21;
47. 48 and 72; 172. 14; 178. 67: 245. 12 and 45.
3) Ib. 61. 4-5; 72. 6-10;
161. 78.
text.13095:
Virocana (II) — an Asura of the Mahātalam.
Vā. 50. 34.
text.13096:
Virocanakula — the family of Bali sent to Pātāla by
Vāmana.
Vā. 98. 86.
text.13097:
Virocanā — the queen of Tvaṣṭri, and mother of Viraja.
Bhā. V. 15. 15; Vā. 84. 19.
text.13098:
Virodha (I) — a son of Vāta, the Rākṣasa.
Br. III. 7. 96.
text.13100:
Viloman — a son of Vanhi, and father of Kapotaroman.
(Br. and Vi. P. make him a son of Kapotaroman).
Bhā. IX. 24. 19-20; Br. III. 71. 117; Vi. IV. 14. 13.
text.13103:
Vilohita (III) — the second son of Khaśā (s.v.) with
three heads, three feet, three hands, black eyes, etc.
Vā. 69. 76, 80-3.
text.13104:
Vilohita (Viloha) (IV) — a hell, to which go the thieves
and those who transgress established rules.
Vi. II. 6. 2 and 14.
text.13105:
Vivakṣu — a son of Adhisomakṛṣṇa; when Nāgasāhvaya
was washed away by floods, he made Kauśāmbī his capital;
father of eight powerful sons.
M. 50. 78-9.
text.13106:
Vivarṇa — a kingdom of the east watered by Hlādinī.
Br. II. 18. 55; Vā. 47. 52.
text.13108:
Vivasvat (II) — the name of the sun in the month of
Nabhasya (Bhādrapada).
Bhā. XII. 11. 38; Br. II. 23. 9; Vi. II. 10. 10. M. 126. 10.
text.13109:
Vivasvat (III) — a son of Aditi: Āditya of the month
Śrāvaṇa: a Prajāpati: born of Kaśyapa and Dākṣāyaṇī — see
Sūrya;1 worship in buildings;2 father of Manu.3 1) Br. II. 24. 34, 88, 129; III. 1. 6 and 54; 3. 68; 71. 23; M. 6. 4;
11. 2-8; Vā. 52. 91. 65. 53.
2) M. 253. 43; 268. 21.
3) Vi. IV. 1. 6.
text.13110:
Vivasvat (IV) — a sage of the Cākṣuṣa Manu.
M. 9. 23.
text.13112:
Vivaha — the chief of the fifth Vātaskandha, situated
between the Nakṣatras (Ṛkṣa-Vā. P.) and the planets;1 one
of the seven Maruts.2 1) Br. III. 5. 86; Vā. 67. 118.
2) M. 163. 32.
text.13113:
Vivāha — one of the four sons in the 30th Kalpa of
Śarva, red in colour, attire, etc.
Vā. 22. 30.
text.13114:
Vivāhas — eight-fold: Brāhma, Daiva, Ārṣa, Prājāpatya,
Āsura, Saindhava, Rākṣasa, and Paiśāca;1 Kṛṣṇa married
Rukmiṇī by the Rākṣasa form;2 the marriage day fit for meru
dāna: gṛhabali recommended in.3 1) Vi. III. 10. 24;
2) Ib. V. 26. 11.
3) M. 83. 8; 93. 83.
text.13115:
Vivikta — (Viviktanāman-Bhā. P.) — a son of Hiraṇya
retas of Kuśadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 14.
text.13116:
Vivici — (Vividha-Br. P.): a son of Adbhuta Agni.
Vā. 29. 39.
text.13119:
Vividha — (Vivici-Vā. P.): son of Adbhuta Agni,
tutelary deity of expiatory penances (prāyaścitta): Father
of Arka.
Br. II. 12. 41; Vā. 29. 39.
text.13120:
Viviṃśa (ka) — a son of Vimśaputra (Vimśa-Vi. P.) and
father of Khaninetra.
Vā. 86. 6; Vi. IV. 1. 27.
text.13121:
Viviṃśati — a son of Cākṣuṣa, and father of Rambha.
Bhā. IX. 2. 24-25.
text.13123:
Vivṛtta — by the passage of time Kṣetrajña becomes
vivṛtta by a single reason; it is likened to a light of Khadyota
in extreme darkness; he returns from Avyakta; he is a
śarīri and a mahān.
Vā. 59. 70-2.
text.13126:
Viśaṭha — a son of Revatī and Baladeva.
Vi. IV. 15. 20.
text.13128:
Viśada — a son of Jayadratha, and father of Senajit.
Bhā. IX. 21. 23.
text.13129:
Viśaṃsana — a hell, intended for makers of kāṇḍa,
carpenters, potters, and robbers of gold, physicians, those
that burn gardens.
Br. IV. 2. 147 and 162; Vā. 101. 147 and 160.
text.13130:
Viśalyakaraṇi — a medicinal herb in Droṇa hill of
Śālmalidvīpa; has the power to bring the dead back to life.
Br. II. 19. 39; M. 122. 56; Vā. 49. 35.
text.13131:
Viśalyakaraṇī — R. in Kalingadeśa near the Amara
kaṇṭaka hills also Viśalya,1 a great and holy river serving
the Narmadā.2 1) Br. III. 13. 12; Vā. 77. 12.
2) M. 186. 43.
text.13132:
Viśalyātīrtham — in the Daṇḍaka forest.
Br. III. 13. 107.
text.13133:
Viśasa (na) — one of the twenty-eight hells — a slaughter
house for hypocritical sacrificers of animals; makers of
lances, swords and other implements.
Bhā. V. 26. 7 and 25; Vi. II. 6. 2 and 17.
text.13134:
Viśākha (I) — a son (brother Vā. P., Vi. P.) of Skanda:
an amśa of Skanda-Vā. P. [a son of Agni (Br. and M. P.)];1
from him originated the planet Sūrya;2 an epithet of
Kumāra;3 commander.4 1) Br. III. 3. 25; M. 5. 26. Vā. 53. 104; 66. 24; 101. 280. Vi. I.
15. 115.
2) Br. II. 24. 129.
3) M. 159. 3.
4) Ib. 230. 7.
text.13135:
Viśākha (II) — a Mt. on the south of the Mānasa;1 tem
ple of Guha at.2 1) Vā. 36. 23;
2) Ib. 39. 55.
text.13136:
Viśākha (III) — when the sun is in Viśākha, fourth
amśa, the moon is then at the head of Kṛttikā.
Vā. 50. 196; Br. II. 21. 145; Vi. II. 8. 76-7.
text.13138:
Viśākhayūpa (I) — a son of Pālaka and father of Rājaka:
ruled for 50 years (53 years M. P.).
Bhā. XII. 1. 3; Br. III. 74. 125; M. 272. 4; Vā. 99. 312.
text.13139:
Viśākhayūpa (II) — a son of Balāka and father of
Janaka.
Vi. IV. 24. 4-5.
text.13140:
Viśākhā — a constellation: Śrāddha performance on that
day leads to birth of sons.
Br. III. 18. 8; Vā. 66. 50; 82. 9.
text.13141:
Viśāpa — a son of Damana, an avatār of the lord in the
third dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 124.
text.13142:
Viśāla (I) — a son of Tṛṇabiṅdu and father of Hema
candra. Founder of Vaiśāli.
Bhā. IX. 2. 33-34; Br. III. 61. 12.
text.13143:
Viśāla (II) — a playmate of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 22. 31.
text.13144:
Viśāla (III) — a tīrtha visited by Balarāma.
Bhā. X. 78. 19.
text.13146:
Viśāla (V) — a nāga of the Vitalam.
Vā. 50. 29.
text.13147:
Viśāla (VI) — a very righteous king, a son of Viśravas
(Tṛṇabiṅdu-Vi. P.) and Ālambuṣa, the Apsaras; father of He
macandra; built the city of Viśālā;1 having no sons, consulted
the Brahmans who advised him to give Piṇḍa in Gayā; he
did so and got a son; once he saw three men white, red and
black in colour in the clouds and asked them who they were;
the white man said that he was his father coming from Indra
loka, the red was his father who had slain Brahmans and
the black was his grand-father who had slain a number of
sages; the latter two were in Avīcinaraka and now got
released by the Gayāpiṇḍa of Viśāla; then blessed him with
a long life of prosperous reign, sacrifices and attainment of
Viṣṇuloka2 in the end. 1) Vā. 86. 16-7; Vi. IV. 1. 49-50.
2) Vā. 112. 7-14.
text.13150:
Viśālā (I) — (Badarikāśrama). To this Dhruva went for
meditation in the evening of his life. Similarly Nābhi and
Merudevī spent their last years here.
Bhā. IV. 12. 16; V. 4. 5; XI. 29. 47.
text.13151:
Viśālā (II) — a R. from the Ṛkṣa hill.
Br. II. 16. 31.
text.13152:
Viśālā (III) — (Viśālayā) city founded by Viśāla, son
of Tṛṇabindu;1 no shaving or Upavāsa, at.2 1) Br. III. 61. 12; Vā. 86. 17; 112. 7; Vi. IV. 1. 49.
2) Vā. 105. 25.
text.13153:
Viśālā (IV) — the wife of Urukṣava (ya): had three sons.
M. 49. 39; Vā. 99. 162.
text.13154:
Viśālā (V) — a R. issuing from the Himālayas.
M. 114. 21.
text.13155:
Viśālā (VI) — a R. of the Ketumālā country.
Vā. 44. 21.
text.13156:
Viśālā (VII) — a daughter of Suyaśā: the most beautiful.
Vā. 69. 14.
text.13157:
Viśālākṣa (I) — the king of Mithilā: went to Syamanta
pañcaka for the solar eclipse.
Bhā. X. 82. 26.
text.13158:
Viśālākṣa (II) — a Nāga in the third Talam.
Br. II. 20. 30.
text.13159:
Viśālākṣa (III) — the name of a Śiva gaṇa.
Br. III. 41. 27.
text.13160:
Viśālākṣa (IV) — a Mt. the abode of the Nāgas.
M. 163. 79.
text.13161:
Viśālākṣa (V) — one of the 18 authors on architecture.
M. 252. 2.
text.13163:
Viśikha — a son of Śukī and Garuḍa.
Br. III. 7. 450.
text.13165:
Viśukra — a younger brother of Bhaṇḍa spoke of Devas
as Pāmaras (uncivilised) and of the invasion of a woman.1
His battle with the Śaktis.2 1) Br. IV. 10. 80; 21. 25.
2) Ib. IV. 27. 10-56; 28. 3-106.
text.13166:
Viśuddhagāndhārī — a special rāga; presiding deity,
Gandharva.
Vā. 86. 65-6.
text.13167:
Viśuddhās — a group of gods of the X epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 25.
text.13168:
Viśeṣas — Mahat and others; from them came the aṇḍa
or universe; all water; from this came the fish (Puruṣa) with
body. Hiraṇyagarbha with four faces.
Vā. 4. 75-8.
text.13169:
Viśoka (I) — a son of Trivakrā by Kṛṣṇa, and devoted
to him; the author of Sātvata Tantra for the good women,
Śūdras and slaves. A disciple of Nārada.
Bhā. X. 90. 34 [1-2].
text.13170:
Viśoka (II) — one of the four sons in the 30th kalpa of
Śarva, red in colour, attire, etc.
Vā. 22. 30.
text.13171:
Viśoka (III) — a son of Damana, an avatār of the Lord
in the 3rd dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 124.
text.13172:
Viśokadvādaśīvratam — removes one's difficulties and
prepares the way for the final bliss; performed in honour of
Keśava or Lakṣmī in the month of Āśvayuja: gift of bed with
guḍadhenu after the pūja and other observances in the
prescribed manner; the gift of guḍa-dhenu on the beginning
day of the ayana or days of Viṣu or eclipse, attended by
music and dancing; the gift of a sugar cow.
M. chh. 81 and 82.
text.13173:
Viśokam — a divine forest in the Lohita hill; a garden
of the gods.
Br. II. 18. 12; III. 7, 102.
text.13174:
Viśokasaptamī — to be observed on the sixth day of the
white half of Māgha month.
M. 74. 2; 75. 1-2.
text.13176:
Viśravas (I) — a son of Pulastya and Iḍivilā and of
great tapas. Father of Kubera through Iḍaviḍā (Iḍivilā) one
of his four wives. By another wife he had sons — Rāvaṇa,
Kumbhakarṇa and Vibhīṣaṇa. Ceḍaviḍā was the name of one
of his wives.1 Son of Ilavilā (Iḍaviḍā, Iḍivilā) and a sage by
tapas. Married Bṛhaspati's daughter.2 Wives of: Devavarṇanī,
Puṣpotkaṭā, Vākā and Kaikasī; the first brought Vaiśravaṇa
whom the father named Kubera; Kaikasī gave birth to
Rāvaṇa, Kumbhakarṇa, Śūrpanakhā and Vibhīṣaṇa; Puṣ
potkaṭa's sons — Mahodara, Prahasta, Mahāpāmśu, Khara;
daughter, Kumbhīṇasī; Vākā's sons Triśiras, Dūṣaṇa, Vidh
yutjihva; daughter Asalikā.3 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 36-37; VII. 1. 43; IX. 2. 32; 10. 15.
2) Br. II. 32. 99;
III. 8. 38; 61. 11; M. 145. 93.
3) Vā. 70. 32-35, 41, 49, 50.
text.13177:
Viśravas (II) — a Ṛṣi by tapas.
M. 145. 93. Vā. 59. 91.
text.13178:
Viśravas (III) — a son of Draviḍā; had a son Viśāla.
Vā. 86. 16.
text.13179:
Viśravas (IV) — the father of two gaṇas, Śiva and
Sumanas.
Vā. 69. 28.
text.13181:
Viśruta (I) — (Viśruti-Br. P.): a Yāmadeva.
Br. II. 13. 92. Vā. 62. 12.
text.13182:
Viśruta (II) — one of the twenty Amitābha gaṇas.
Vā. 100. 17.
text.13183:
Viśrutavat — a son of Sahasvat, and father of Bṛhad
bala; a king.
Br. III. 63. 212; Vā. 88. 212.
text.13184:
Viśva (I) — a name of Hari.
Bhā. XII. 11. 22.
text.13185:
Viśva (II) — the Gandharva presiding over the month,
Tapasya.
Bhā. XII. 11. 40.
text.13186:
Viśva (III) — a branch of the Bhārgava gotra.
Vā. 65. 96.
text.13187:
Viśva (IV) — a son of Upamadgu.
Vi. IV. 14. 9.
text.13189:
Viśvakarmā (I) — a Prajāpati. His daughter Barhiṣ
matī was the wife of Priyavrata.1 A son of Vāstu and Ān
girasī; wife was Kṛti (Akṛti-Bhā. P.). Father of Manu Cāk
ṣuṣa.2 The divine architect skilled in making weapons.
Made vajra of Dadhīci's body and built Indra's abode and
erected Sutalam.3 Fought with Maya in Devāsura war.
Two more daughters of his were Samjñā and Chāyā who
were married to the Sun god.4 Was ordered by Kṛṣṇa to build
a city for the Pāṇḍavas;5 built Garuḍa's abode;6 an author
on architecture;7 father of four sons; originator of all śilpas,
arts and crafts;8 presented Śrī with jewels.9 1) Bhā. V. 1. 24.
2) Ib. VI. 6. 15.
3) Ib. VI. 9. 54: 10. 13.
VII. 4. 8; VIII. 15. 15; 22. 32. M. 5. 27-8; 58. 33.
4) Bhā. VIII. 10. 29;
13. 8. Vi. III. 2. 2, 8, 10-12.
5) Bhā. X. 58. 24.
6) M. 163. 68: 203. 7.
7) Ib. 252. 2; Br. IV. 31. 6-7.
8) Vi. I. 15. 119-20; III. 2. 11.
9) Ib. I.
9. 104; Br. IV. 9. 81; 14. 4; 15. 20; 20. 46; 29. 84.
text.13190:
Viśvakarmā (II) — a son of Tvaṣṭā and Yaśodharā;
father of Maya, and his daughter was Sureṇu; originator of
arts and crafts.
Br. I. 2. 19; 5. 27. III. 1. 87. 7. 195; 32. 7: 59. 17-21: Vā. 65.
85.
text.13191:
Viśvakarmā (III) — divided the earth into seven islands,
oceans and hills, Bhūḥ and other worlds; created the people
as in the previous kalpas; but the whole was clouded in
smoke, in five forms like a light enveloped by a pot; finding
no light and all in their place (Nyāsa) was pondering over
when a cross current passed that way and resulted in a
second universe.
Vā. 6. 33-45. 109. 4.
text.13192:
Viśvakarmā (IV) — one of the seven important rays
of the sun on the south; helps the growth of the Budha
planet.
Br. II. 24. 66-69.
text.13193:
Viśvakarmā (V) — a Vamśavartin god; a son of Pra
bhāta and Bhuvanā; Lord of Prajāpatis.
Br. II. 36. 29; III. 3. 29.
text.13194:
Viśvakāyā — the goddess enshrined at Ambarā.
M. 13. 27.
text.13195:
Viśvakjyoti — the first of the 100 sons of Śatajit.
Vi. II. 1. 41.
text.13196:
Viśvaga (I) — a son of Pūrṇiman.
Bhā. IV. 1. 14.
text.13197:
Viśvaga (II) — a son of Pṛthu and grandson of Suyo
dana.
M. 12. 29.
text.13198:
Viśvacakram — a gift; a wheel of the world in gold
(20 palas to 1000) with Jalaśāyi Viṣṇu and His avatārs, the
sages, the four Vedas, the Pañca Bhutās, the Rudras and the
Lokapālās placed thereon; to be given as a gift on an auspi
cious day; daily worship of the cakra yields one plenty of
wealth and long life.
M. 274. 9: 285. 1-23.
text.13199:
Viśvajit (I) — a sacrifice performed by Bali with the
aid of Bhṛgu Brāhmaṇas.
Bhā. VIII. 15. 4.
text.13200:
Viśvajit (II) — a son of Satyajit, and father of Ripum
jaya; a link in the line.1 A Bṛhadratha king who ruled for
25 years.2 1) Bhā. IX. 22. 49; Vi. IV. 23. 11-12.
2) Br. III. 74. 120.
text.13202:
Viśvajit (IV) — Janamejaya: a son of Dṛḍharatha.
Vā. 99. 111.
text.13204:
Viśvajit (VI) — a son of Jayadratha; father of Senajit.
Vi. IV. 19. 34-5.
text.13209:
Viśvadha — a Vamśavartin god.
Br. II. 36. 29; Vā. 62. 26.
text.13210:
Visvadhāra — a son of Medhātithi of Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 25.
text.13213:
Viśvabhava — a son of Sahasvān and father of Bṛhad
bala.
Vi. IV. 4. 111-12.
text.13214:
Viśvabhāvana — one of the four sons in the 30th kalpa
of Śarva, red in colour, attire, etc.
Vā. 22. 30.
text.13215:
Viśvabhuk — Indra of Śukra devas whose cognates are
Asuras.
Vā. 31. 11; 57. 91 and 102.
text.13216:
Viśvabhṛta — a group of nāḍis of the sun pouring out
heat.
Br. II. 24. 29; Vā. 53. 22.
text.13217:
Viśvam — false; like a serpent in rope, and water in the
desert, etc.
Vā. 104. 39.
text.13219:
Viśvamahat — a son of Viśvaśarma; his wife, Yasodā,
the mānasī kanyā of the Pitṛs.
Vā. 73. 40.
text.13220:
Viśvamālā — a R. from the Vindhyas.
M. 114. 27.
text.13221:
Viśvamukhī — the Goddess enshrined at Jālandhara.
M. 13. 46.
text.13222:
Viśvamohinī — the form which Viṣṇu assumed, and
embraced by Śiva, resulting in the birth of Mahāśāsta.
Br. IV. 10. 77.
text.13223:
Viśvambharā — the earth which covers the whole uni
verse, etc. Its manifestations are Dhṛti, Sthiti, Kṣamā,
Kṣoṇī, Pṛthvī, Vasumatī and Rasā.
M. 284. 16.
text.13225:
Viśvaratha — another name for Viśvāmitra.
Br. III. 66. 65; Vā. 91. 93.
text.13226:
Viśvarandhi — (Viṣvagandhi) — son of Pṛthu and father
of Candra.
Bhā. IX. 6. 20.
text.13227:
Viśvarūpa (I) — a son of Tvaṣṭri and Rocanā (Yaśo
dharā-Br. P.) adopted by Suragaṇas when their guru
Angiras left them. At first he did not agree as Paurodhasa
was not a coveted profession. Finally he accepted and
initiated Indra into a mantra known as Varma Nārāyaṇāt-
makam; with this Indra enjoyed once more the Trailokya
lakṣmī: Father of Pañcajanī.1 Viśvarūpa had three heads
Somapīṭḥa, Surāpīṭḥa, and Annāda. Finding the ācārya
giving a part of his sacrificial offerings to Asuras, Indra cut
off his heads which became Kapiñjala, Kalavinka and Tittiri
birds. His vadha,2 in the sabhā of Hiraṇyakaśipu.3 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 44-5; ch. 7-8 (whole); V. 7. 1; Br. III. 1. 86.
2) Bhā. VI. 9. 1-5; 13. 5.
3) M. 161. 80.
text.13229:
Viśvarūpa (III) — a son of Rūpavatī, and devoted to
Nārāyaṇa: elected Purohita in the absence of Bṛhaspati
who went to the earth due to a curse by sages: Indra
quarrelled with him, and the latter repaired to spend his life
in penance. Sages cursed Indra for this.
Br. IV. 9. 4-8.
text.13230:
Viśvarūpa (IV) — a name of Triśiras, a son of Tvaṣṭa.
Vā. 65. 85.
text.13231:
Viśvarūpā (I) — in the 33rd Kalpa Sarasvatī became
Viśvarūpā with four hands, four feet, four teeth, four eyes,
etc. Brahmā prayed to Viśveśa who explained the nature
of Sarasvatī as Prakṛti and made aṭṭahāsa when Jati, Muṇḍi
and other sons came; after performing austerities for 1000
years they attained Rudrahood.
Vā. 23. 36-61.
text.13232:
Viśvarūpā (II) — wife of Dharma and mother of Dhar
mavratā.
Vā. 107. 2.
text.13233:
Viśvavyaca — the agni in Brahmasthāna.
Br. II. 12. 24.
text.13236:
Viśvaśravas — one of the seven important rays of the
Sun; helps the growth of the planet, Śukra.
Br. II. 24. 66; Vā. 53. 45, 48.
text.13237:
Viśvasaha (I) — a son of Aiḍaviḍa (Ilivila-Vi. P.) and
father of Khaṭvānga.
Bhā. IX. 9. 41; Vi. IV. 4. 75-6.
text.13238:
Viśvasaha (II) — a son of Vyuṣitāśva, (Yuṣitāśva-Vi.
P.), (Dhyuṣitāśva-Vā. P.), and father of Hiraṇyanābha
Kauśalya: a king.
Br. III. 63. 206-7; Vā. 88. 206; Vi. IV. 4. 106-7.
text.13239:
Viśvasahasra — His daughter married Iḍaviḍa.
Br. III. 63. 181.
text.13240:
Viśvasāhvan — a son of Mahasvat and father of Prasena
jit.
Bhā. IX. 12. 7-8.
text.13241:
Viśvasṛja — another name for Viśvakarmā.
Bhā. X. 75. 32.
text.13242:
Viśvasṛjas — the sacrifice of creation; continued
for thousands of years in the Naimiṣa region (see for a
description Yajurveda Brāhmaṇa).
Vā. 2. 5-7.
text.13243:
Viśvasṛjām satra — the sacrifice of the Prajāpatis. Here
Dakṣa insulted Śiva. The sacrifice lasted for a thousand
years. The avabhṛta was at the confluence of the Gangā
and the Yamunā.
Bhā. IV. ch. 2 (whole); 3. 24.
text.13244:
Viśvasphāṭika — the king of Magadha who introduced
new varṇas for Kṣatriyas and also kingship.
Vi. IV. 24. 61.
text.13245:
Viśvasphāni — a Māgadha king equal to Hari in battle:
cut at the root of the Kṣatriya order and established his own
castes: viz. Kaivartas, Madrakas, Pulindas, Brāhmaṇas, and
Pañcakas; said to be an eunuch; offerings of, to devas, pitṛs,
and Brahmans; died on the banks of the Ganges as an ascetic
and went to Indraloka.
Br. III. 74. 190-3. Vā. 99. 377-82.
text.13246:
Viśvasphūrji — a king of Magadha.
Bhā. XII. 1. 36.
text.13247:
Viśvasya — the place of Samudra agni.
Vā. 29. 22.
text.13248:
Viśvā (I) — a R. in Bhāratavarṣa.
Bhā. V. 19. 18.
text.13249:
Viśvā (II) — a daughter of Dakṣa and one of the ten
wives of Dharma married by Brāhma form; her sons were
Viśvedevas.
Bhā. VI. 6. 4. and 7; Br. III. 3. 3 and 30. M. 5. 16-17; 203. 12;
Vā. 66. 3, 31; 76. 3; Vi. I. 15. 105.
text.13250:
Viśvā (III) — one of the 13 wives of Kaśyapa; mother of
Yakṣas and Rākṣasas.
M. 6. 2; 146. 18.
text.13251:
Viśvā (IV) — the Goddess enshrined at Viśveśvara.
M. 13. 29.
text.13252:
Viśvāci — an Apsaras, coupled with Pūrvaciti: with her
Yayāti enjoyed in Vaibhrāja nandana: Danced at the
appearance of Śrī from the milk-ocean; went with Māyā to
counteract Bhaṇḍa's imperialism;1 with the Śarat sun;2 in
the sabhā of Hiraṇyakaśipu;3 resides in the sun's chariot in
Kārtika.4 1) Br. III. 7. 15; 68. 70; IV. 9. 78; 12. 25; 33. 19; Vā. 69. 49.
93. 69. Vi. IV. 10. 20.
2) Br. II. 23. 13.
3) M. 161. 74.
4) Vi. II. 10. 12.
text.13253:
Viśvāmitra (I) — A sage of the Vaivasvata epoch;1 was
invited for the Rājasūya of Yudhiṣṭhira;2 came to see Kṛṣṇa
at Syamantapañcaka3 and Parikṣit practising prāyopaveśa.4
Acted as Purohita at Kṛṣṇa's sacrifice in Kuruk
ṣetra, left Dvārakā for Piṇḍāraka;5 Purohita of Jamadagni;
the 6th incarnation of Viṣṇu to do away with the Kṣatriyas;
became a Brāhmaṇa by tapas.6 1) Bhā. VIII. 13. 5. M. 9. 27.
2) Bhā. X. 74. 8.
3) Ib. X. 84. 3;
4) Ib. I. 19. 9.
5) Ib. XI. 1. 12; X. 90. 46 [2].
6) M. 47. 244; 198.
2 and 3.
text.13254:
Viśvāmitra (II) — (Viśvaratha-Vā. P.): a son of Gādhi
and Kuśika (Kucika gotra-Vā. P.). Though born a
Kṣatriya, by his tapas he obtained brahmanhood. He had
101 sons. The middle one was known Madhucchandas and
hence all sons bore that common name. He asked his sons
to regard Sunaśśepa as their eldest brother. The first fifty
refused and were cursed to become mlecchas. Madhucchan
das and the younger fifty agreed to adopt Śunaśśepa. Visvā
mitra blessed them. He had eight other sons like Aṣṭaka.
Owing to divisions among his sons, the Kauśika family be
came different from the Viśvāmitras. There was a change
of pravara since adoption was introduced. Father of Śakun
talā through Ūrvaśī.1 Helped Triśanku to go to heaven with
the mortal body and secured for him a place in the sky.
Fought Vasiṣṭha in the guise of a bird concerning Hariś
candra, son of Triśanku. Acted as hotri to Hariścandra
and was pleased with the fervour of the king and his queen;2
when he performed a Yajña, Rāma, son of Daśaratha killed
Rākṣasas who disturbed it;3 officiated as hota in Paraśurāma's
aśvamedha;4 a Kṣatriyadvija — sons and family of.5
Performed tapas near the sea; his wife had her son bound
to her neck and sold him for a hundred cows; Satyavrata
released the son to earn the goodwill of Viśvāmitra: Helped
by Satyavrata — Triśanku during the 12 years famine,
he took him bodily to heaven for it;6 in Dāruvana;7 a
Brahmiṣṭa.8 1) Bhā. IX. 16. 28-37; Br. I. 2. 11; II. 32. 117; 38. 26. III. 66.
58; Vā. 1. 177; 64. 25; 91. 87, 93, 95-6.
2) Bhā. IX. 7. 5-26.
3) Ib.
IX. 10. 5.
4) Br. III. 47. 46; 73. 91.
5) Ib. III. 66. 86; 63. 85-90.
6) Vā. 88. 86-8; Br. III. 63. 112.
7) Ib. I. 1. 149; II. 27. 103.
8) M. 145. 111.
text.13255:
Viśvāmitra (III) — the sage presiding over the month of
Ūrja;1 with the Śiśira Sun;2 with the sun in Phālguna.3 1) Bhā. XII. 11. 44.
2) Br. II. 23-20.
3) Vi. II. 10. 18.
text.13256:
Viśvāmitras — (also Kauśikas): Brahmarākṣasas; one of
the four clans moving about in the night;1 against Vedas and
Yajñas.2 1) Br. III. 8. 59-61; Vā. 69. 195.
2) Ib. 70. 53.
text.13259:
Viśvāyu (II) — one of the six sons of Purūravas.
Vā. 91. 52.
text.13260:
Viśvāvasu (I) — a Gandharva got infatuated at the sight
of Devahūti playing on the terrace of her house: served as
calf for Gandharvas and Apsarasas to milk Gandharva
Madhu from earth;1 praised Hīraṇyakaśipu, the over lord of
all worlds: sang the glory of Indra defeating Namuci.2 1) Bhā. III. 20. 39; 22. 17; IV. 18. 17. Br. III. 7. 12. IV. 14. 4.
2) Bhā. VII. 4. 14; VIII. 11. 41; XI. 16. 33.
text.13261:
Viśvāvasu (II) — the Gandharva presiding over the
month of Nabha; in the sun's chariot, with the sun in
Āvaṇi and Puraṭṭāśi, (śarat season);2 in the sun's chariot
during the month of Kārtika.3
^1 Bhā. XII. 11. 37; Br. II. 23. 10; Vi. II. 10. 9. 2) Vā. 52. 10,
13; 62. 188.
3) Vi. II. 10. 12.
text.13262:
Viśvāvasu (III) — a son of Krodhā and a Deva
gandharva.
Br. III. 6. 39.
text.13263:
Viśvāvasu (IV) — a son of Purūravas and Ūrvaśī;1 the
Gandharva who brought back Ūrvaśī to heaven from earth.2 1) Br. III. 66. 23; IV. 20. 48 and 101; Vi. IV. 7. 1.
2) Br. III.
66. 16.
text.13265:
Viśvāvasu (VI) — a Vasu, a son of Dharma and Sudevī.
M. 171. 46.
text.13266:
Viśvāvasu (VII) — a Gandharva and the best of
speakers; deprived Ūrvaśī and Purūravas of the two sheep.
Vā. 91. 16-22; Vi. I. 9. 102; IV. 6. 51.
text.13267:
Viśvāvasu (VIII) — a Gandharva;1 an expert in divine
music.2 1) Vā. 30. 86.
2) Ib. 69. 47.
text.13268:
Viśvāvasus — a class of musicians who sang the Sāma
Veda.
Br. III. 1. 25.
text.13270:
Viśvās (I) — the sons of Cākṣuṣa Manu.
Bhā. VI. 6. 15.
text.13271:
Viśvās (II) — the ten sons of Dharma and Viśvā. As a
result of their penance in the Himālayas, they were blessed to
enjoy a part of the Śrāddha offerings: Their duty was to
protect the Śrāddha and be its guests. (see Viśvā).
Br. III. 3. 80; 12. 3-14.
text.13273:
Viśvedevas — Dharmaputras: (see Viśvāndevas). Ten
sons of Viśvā and Dharma: these are childless gods: wait on
Indra; worshipped for gain of a kingdom.1 Fought with
Paulomas in Devāsura war: gods of Vaivasvata epoch.2
Formed the Sadas of Marutta's yajñas: blessed Jyāmagha
with a son: sūktas sacred to;3 came with other gods to
Dvārakā to ask Kṛṣṇa to go back to Vaikuṇṭha;4 Kratu,
Dakṣa, Śrava, Satya, Kāla, Kāma, Muni, Purūravas, Ārdra
vasa, and Rocamāna are their names, live in Bhuvarloka;5 see
Viśvas, ten in number, were Camasādhvaryavas for Soma's
rājasūya;6 performed austerities in the Himālayas, and Pitṛs
pleased with them blessed them; Brahmā gave them the first
place of honour in the Śrāddha and the second to devas.7 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 7; 7. 3; 10. 17; II. 3. 4; M. 171. 48; 217. 48; 246.
54; 247. 10; 5. 17; Vā. 21. 23; 66. 31, 32; Vi. I. 15. 105; Br. II. 38.
2-3; III. 3. 30; 8. 4; 10. 109; 15. 35.
2) Bhā. VIII. 10. 34; 13. 4;
M. 9. 29.
3) Bhā. IX. 2. 28; 23. 39. 4. 4.
4) Ib. XI. 6. 2.
5) Br.
IV. 2. 28; 20. 46.
6) M. 17. 14 and 52; 23. 22; 203. 12.
7) Vā. 76.
3, 12-14; 106. 59.
text.13274:
Viśveśa — description of: nirindriya, alingi, nirguṇa,
cetana, etc. Cf. Gītā.
Vā. 14. 6-11, 13.
text.13275:
Viśveśā (I) — a mind-born daughter of Brahmā.
M. 171. 32.
text.13276:
Viśveśā (II) — her sons by Dharma.
M. 171. 48 and 51.
text.13279:
Viśveśvara (II) — the God enshrined at Benares.
M. 184. 69.
text.13280:
Viśveśvara (III) — a name of Hari.
Bhā. II. 2. 14; Br. III. 41. 42.
text.13282:
Viśve sādhyas — the sons of Cākṣuṣa Manu (s.v.).
Bhā. VI. 6. 15.
text.13284:
Viṣa (II) — an Asura, attacked by Nakuli Devī.
Br. IV. 28. 39.
text.13285:
Viṣa (III) — a son of Danāyuṣa; father of four sons all
bent on doing cruelty.
Vā. 68. 30, 33.
text.13286:
Viṣaghnāni — details of preparations of antidotes to
poisons to ward off evils in the palace.
M. 218. 1-38.
text.13287:
Viṣaṅga — a younger brother of Bhaṇḍa well read in
nīti treatises, advised that even a woman should not be neg
lected and war to be embarked upon after proper consulta
tion.1 His fight; took to kūṭayuddha and fled for life.2 1) Br. IV. 20. 30; 21. 25; 27. 10; 28. 3 and 37.
2) Ib. IV. 28.
106 and 114; 25. 14 and 33, 104.
text.13288:
Viṣadhāra — a Mt. south of the Mānasa.
Vā. 36. 23.
text.13289:
Viṣam — produced by the churning of the ocean by the
Devas and Asuras.
Vā. 54. 49; 62. 180.
text.13290:
Viṣaya — a kingdom in general; qualities of a good one;1
gift of.2 1) M. 217. 1-5.
2) Ib. 275. 25.
text.13291:
Viṣayāviṣayatvam — Viṣaya is Brahmā and aviṣaya is
kṣetra.
Vā. 102. 36.
text.13292:
Viṣuvatta — Brahmam attained through Suṣumnā situ
ated between Iḍa and Piṅgala.
Bhā. II. 2. 24[2]
text.13293:
Viṣu (vam) — see Vaivasvatagati; equinox, distance of;
fit time for making gifts;1 occurs between the spring and
winter.2 1) Br. II. 21. 68, 72-3; M. 124. 93; 187. 37; 274. 19; Vā. 50.
125; Vi. II. 8. 74 and 78.
2) M. 17. 2; 82. 25; 83. 7; 98. 2. 124. 47.
text.13294:
Viṣūci — queen of Viraja, and mother of a hundred sons
and one daughter.1 Mother of Viṣvaksena.2 1) Bhā. V. 15. 15.
2) Ib. VIII. 13. 23.
text.13295:
Viṣeṇa — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 84.
text.13297:
Viṣkambhaparvatas — hills round about Meru; these are
Mandara, Gandhamādhana, Tilācala, (Vipula) and Supārśva.
M. 83. 11, 19, 36; 113. 45.
text.13298:
Viṣṭarāśva — a son of Pṛthu; and father of Cāndra-yuva
nāśva.
Vi. IV. 2. 35-6.
text.13299:
Viṣṭākīrṇa — also Viḍbhuk — a hell.
Br. IV. 2. 148 and 170.
text.13300:
Viṣṭi (I) — a daughter of Vivasvān and Chāyā; became
Kāla of cruel deeds.
M. 11. 9, 39.
text.13302:
Viṣṇu (I) — the name of the sun in the month of Ūrja
(Kārtika);1 an Āditya and Lord of Ādityas;2 in the sun's
chariot in Phālguna.3 1) Bhā. XII. 11. 44; Br. II. 23. 20; Vā. 66. 61, 66.
2) Br. II.
24. 34; III. 3. 68; M. 6. 4; 171. 56. Vi. I. 15. 130.
3) Ib. I. 22. 3;
II. 10. 18.
text.13303:
Viṣṇu (II) — a god of Ābhūtaraya group.
Br. II. 36. 56.
text.13304:
Viṣṇu (III) — (Uttamaśloka) worshipped for dharma.
His abode above the position of seven sages, where is found
the great Dhruva with others;1 different forms of; as Trivik
rama broke aṇḍakaṭāha and let the Ganges in; as Sankar
ṣaṇa, worshipped by Śiva in Ilāvṛta; as Hayagrīva in Bha
drāśva country; as Nṛsimha in Harivarṣa; as Kāmadeva in
Ketumālā; as Matsya in Ramyaka; as Kūrma in Hiraṇmaya;
also Sānkhyanidarśana; as Varāha in Uttara Kuru country;
also in the form of both Yajña and Kratu; as Sītārāma in Kim
puruṣa; as Naranārāyaṇa in Bhāratavarṣa; as Sūrya in Plak
ṣadvīpa; as Soma in Śālmali; as Agni in Kuśadvīpa; as a
form of water in Krauñcadvīpa; as Vāyu in Śākadvīpa; as
Brahmā in Puṣkaradvīpa.2
Propitiated by Dakṣa after his reconciliation with Śiva,
Viṣṇu came to receive offerings in person in the form of
yajña and was praised by all present including Brahmā and
Śiva. He told Dakṣa that he was not different from Śiva or
Brahmā.3 presented Pṛthu with Sudarśana and addressed
him to befriend Indra, to be devoted to Him and to conduct
himself righteously.4 His residence near Kṣīroda where he
sleeps in yoga: vanquisher of Bali; saw a linga of efful
gence and with Brahmā went down and up to know its origin
and end, but could not get at that. Śiva's remark that his
right and left arms were Brahmā and Viṣṇu. This is Mahā
yāgam and Māheśvaram balam;5 cursed by Bhṛgu to take 10
(7 M. P.) incarnations on the earth; called Puruṣa and Yajña.6
In Svāyambhuva epoch was born of Ākūtī, in Svārociṣa,
born of Tuṣitā as Ajita, in Uttama epoch, born of Satyā as
Satya, in Tāmasa born of Hariṇī as Hari, in Vaivasvata, born
of Kaśyapa and Aditī with the name Vaikuṇṭha.7 Overlord
of Ādityas; gave peacock and fowl to Kumāra.8 Killed
Daityas in Tārakāmaya and especially Kālanemi. Aided
Indra against Asuras. Introduced yajña and other rites,
divisions of time, three castes, three Vedas, three guṇas and so
on.9 Got Indra redeemed of the sin of hitting his Purohita Viś
varūpa, by distributing it among the women, trees and earth.
When Durvāsa cursed Indra for refusing to accept Devī's
garland, the Asuras destroyed the Devas and entered heaven.
Then Hari suggested churning of the ocean and distributed
as Mohinī nectar to Devas making them invincible.10 Gave
his sister Devī in marriage to Śiva with wedding presents.11
Fond of soma drink. Got Viṣṇutvam by meditating upon
Lalitāmantra.12 Reflections of Kālanemi on his eternal enmity
to Asuras. Killed Kālanemi after a fierce fight, described;
re-establishes order and goes back to his abode.13 Lord of
Ravis; as Kapila destroyed the Sagaras.14 Born in the family
of Kroṣṭhu, helped the Vṛṣṇis;15 helped Indra by killing
Kāvya's mother;16 worship of, in the Vibhūti dvādaśi
vratam;17 Icon of, with different postures described;18
Viṣṇu (Janārdana);19 blessed Vaibhrāja of Pāñcāla with
a son, Brahmadatta;20 in Nārasimha form;21 in Meghakara
tīrtham;22 blessed Soma with fulfilment of all his desires;23
regained the jewel Syamantaka from the bear and gave it
to Satrājit;24 spoke of Ādisarga and Pratisarga;25 worshipped
by Purūravas when he was a Brahman in previous birth;26
came out of the arrow of Tripurāri and drank of the medi
cinal tank of Tripuram;27 overwhelmed by Asuras on all
sides broke the chariot of Kālanemi who escaped;28 cut off
Grasana's neck by the cakra;29 disabled in fight with other
Rākṣasas especially Jambha and Nimi, fled with Garuḍa;30
Indra met him and praised his past exploits and promised
to help himself with 11 Rudras; with Indra's army Janār
dana went to war once more;31 vanquished the Asuras at
Bhārgaveśa;32 residence of, in the Mandara hill;33 meditation
of;34 spoke of the 16 gifts to Manu;35 fish form of.36 1) Bhā. II. 3. 22; III. ch. 13 (whole); V. 22. 17; 23. 1.
2) Ib. V.
17. 1 and 16; chh. 18-20 (whole);
3) Ib. IV. 7. 18-54; 14. 26.
4) Ib.
IV. 15. 16; 20. 2-16, 31 [1-2].
5) Br. II. 26. 2; 27. 22.
6) Ib. III.
3. 85-106; 72. 3-17; M. 47. 99-103.
7) Br. III. 107-122.
8) Ib.
III. 10. 46; 24. 6; 33. 15; 42. 48; 71. 176 and 262. M. 6. 4; 171. 56.
9) Br. III. 72. 18-64, 133. 142; M. ch. 172.
10) Br. IV. 9. 23-81; 10.
4-5; 14. 2.
11) Ib. IV. 15. 15-23; 28. 89; 30. 8; 31. 6; 34. 71-2;
12) Ib. IV. 38. 39.
13) M. 178. 5-80; 87. 1.
14) Ib. 8. 4; 12. 41-3;
17. 1.
15) Ib. 44. 15; 47. 29, 33.
16) Ib. 47. 99.
17) Ib. 174. 51;
225. 14; 246. 41, 69. 248. 40.
18) Ib. 258. 4-15; 266. 42.
19) Ib. 7.
20; 154. 351.
20) Ib. 9. 1; 21. 11-6.
21) Ib. 22. 17.
22) Ib. 22. 40.
23) Ib. 23. 17-19.
24) Ib. 45. 16-17.
25) Ib. 52. 2.
26) Ib. 65. 7;
115. 12.
27) Ib. 136. 58.
28) Ib. 136. 65; 150. 222.
29) Ib. 150.
243; 151. 34.
30) Ib. ch. 152.
31) Ib. 153. 1-4.
32) Ib. 192. 1-2.
33) Ib. 206. 18; 245. 9; 246. 24, 30f; 249. 32.
34) Ib. 266. 35.
35) Ib.
274. 16.
36) Ib. 290. 23.
text.13306:
Viṣṇu (V) — one of the nine sons of Sāvarṇi.
Vā. 100. 22.
text.13307:
Viṣṇutīrtham — of Yodhanīpuram; where the Asuras
were slain by Vāsudeva in large numbers;1 more efficacious
than the Ganges.2 1) M. 191. 99-101.
2) Vā. 111. 41. 2.
text.13308:
Viṣṇudūtas — met Yamadūtas at the death of Ajāmila
and argued that the uttering of Hari's name before his
death was an expiation for all sins committed. Yama's tri
bute to them as objects of worship for they go about protect
ing the votaries of Hari.1 Residents of Viṣṇuloka.2 1) Bhā. VI. 1. 20; 2. 2-39; 3. 17-18.
2) Br. IV. 7. 38.
text.13309:
Viṣṇupadam (I) — a lake in the Niṣadha hill;1 sacred to
Pitṛs;2 the place where Dhruva is located.3 1) Br. II. 18. 67; III. 43. 14; M. 121. 66; Vā. 47. 64.
2) M. 22. 25.
3) Vā. 50. 222.
text.13310:
Viṣṇupadam (II) — the path where Dharma, Dhruva
and others take their stand above the seven sages; the region
between the seven ṛṣis and Dhruva where live ascetics and
yogis of a high order; the source of rain and the stay of the
three worlds; from this proceeds the Gangā; issuing from the
nail of the great toe of Viṣnu's left foot;1 the third division
of the celestial region.2 1) Br. II. 21. 176; Vi. II. 8. 98-109;
2) Ib. II. 8. 122.
text.13311:
Viṣṇupadam (III) — a Mt. in Gayā; a hill where Dhar
maratha performed a sacrifice.
M. 48. 93; Vā. 99. 102; 105. 26; 109. 18; 111. 46-7 and 56.
text.13312:
Viṣṇupadī — a R. of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 29.
text.13313:
Viṣṇupāda — the celestial regions where Dhruva holds
the Bhagavatpadī on his head with intense devotion;1 sacred
for Gangā.2 1) Bhā. V. 17. 1-2.
2) Br. III. 13. 118.
text.13314:
Viṣṇupuram — sacred to Viṣṇu; attained by Heti after
having been killed by Viṣnu.
Vā. 109. 25; 274. 76.
text.13315:
Viṣṇupurāṇa — one among the eighteen Purāṇas; com
prises 23,000 ślokas.
Bhā. XII. 7. 23. 13. 4.
text.13316:
Viṣṇu Māyā — incarnation of, at the time of Kṛṣṇa's
birth. See Yogamāyā.
Bhā. X. 1. 25.
text.13317:
Viṣṇuyaśas — another name of Kalki to be born to a
Brahman of Śambhalagrāma.
Bhā. I. 3. 25; XII. 2. 18; Vi. IV. 24. 98. Br. III. 73. 104; Vā.
98. 104.
text.13318:
Viṣṇurāta — a name of Parikṣit.
Bhā. I. 12. 17.
text.13319:
Viṣṇulokam — the abode of Viṣṇu1 in Pāṇḍaveśam; at
tained by one who bathes in cakratīrtham;2 he who does
tulāpuruṣa goes to Viṣṇulokam.3 1) Vā. 108. 19; 111. 67; Vi. V. 38. 94.
2) M. 191. 21, 62.
3) Ib. 193. 74.
text.13320:
Viṣṇuvṛddhas (I) — Kṣatriyas who became dvijas.
Br. III. 66. 88; Vā. 91. 117.
text.13321:
Viṣṇuvṛddhas (II) — the descendants of Viṣṇuvṛddha,
cognates of Angiras; Brahmans with Kṣatriya dharma.
Vā. 65. 107; 88. 79.
text.13322:
Viṣṇuvratam — in honour of Viṣṇu, leads to Parama
pada.
M. 101. 37, 64.
text.13323:
Viṣṇu Śakti — three-fold; ability to perceive the abso
lute truth, ability to perceive the nature of the embodied soul
and thirdly inability to know one's nature; the technical
terms used are parā, kṣetrajñā or aparā and avidyā karma-
samjñā.
Vi. VI. 7. 60-1.
text.13325:
Viṣṇusthānam — here Gangā was born and here are the
footprints of Vāmana.
Br. III. 37. 4.
text.13326:
Viṣṇorārādhanam — once asked of it by Sagara the
sage Aurva narrated it to him; was repeated by Parāśara to
Maitreya.
Vi. III. 8. 3-5.
text.13327:
Viṣvaksena (I) — is Viṣṇu;1 a son of Brahmadatta and
Go; author of yogatantra under the guidance of Jaigīṣavya;
the concrete form of the Pāñcarātra and other Tantras.
Father of Udaksvana;2 worship of;3 Brahmadatta anointed
him king and left for yoga practice. 1) Bhā. I. 2. 8; III. 13. 3.
2) Ib. IX. 21. 25-26;
3) Ib. XI. 27.
29; XII. 11. 20. M. 21. 35; Vi. IV. 19. 46.
text.13328:
Viṣvaksena (II) — forms one of the retinue of the Lord
on the Lokāloka mountain.
Bhā. V. 20. 40.
text.13329:
Viṣvaksena (III) — born of Viṣūcī; to be friendly to Śam
bhu, the Indra of the Tenth Manu; attacked Asura followers
of Bali.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 23; 21. 16.
text.13330:
Viṣvaksena (IV) — an attribute of Hari, Vāsudeva, Ma
dhusūdana and Janārdana.
Br. III. 71. 50 and 245; Vā. 96. 48, 236; 106. 50; Bhā. VI. 8. 29.
text.13331:
Viṣvaksena (V) — the future Manu, and the last (14th)
in number.
M. 9. 36.
text.13332:
Viṣvaksena (VI) — a son of Yugadatta; was born again
as Vibhrāja on account of his good deeds.
M. 49. 58.
text.13335:
Viṣvaksena (IX) — a name of Kṛṣṇa.
Vi. V. 38. 20.
text.13338:
Visarjanas — a Yadu tribe; ended their lives by killing
their kinsmen.
Bhā. XI. 30. 18.
text.13339:
Visarjama — a kingdom of the west watered by the
Sindhu.
Br. II. 18. 48.
text.13340:
Vistṛta (Viśruta) — a son of Devamīḍha and father of
Mahādhṛti.
Bhā. IX. 13. 16.
text.13341:
Visphūrjana — a son of Khaśā and Rākṣasa.
Br. III. 7. 134.
text.13344:
Visvacī — an Apsaras with the sun in the śarat.
Vā. 52. 13.
text.13345:
Vihamgamās (I) — the gods of the epoch of the eleventh
Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 25; Vi. III. 2. 30.
text.13348:
Vihas — a Janapada of the Ketumālā.
Vā. 44. 11.
text.13349:
Vihīnara — a son of Udayana and father of Daṇḍapāṇi.
Vi. IV. 21. 15.
text.13350:
Vīci — the name of a hell.
Br. IV. 2. 150.
text.13351:
Vīcya — a name of a hell.
Vā. 101. 149.
text.13353:
Vīṇā — Lute;1 presented by Sarasvatī to Skanda;2 in the
garland of Umeśa, figures of apsaras with vīṇās3 in Pātālam4 in Rāma's abhiṣeka.5 1) Vā. 54. 35.
2) Ib. 72. 46.
3) M. 260. 20.
4) Vi. II. 5. 11.
5) Ib. IV. 4. 100.
text.13354:
Vīṇāvatī — a name of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 17. 34.
text.13355:
Vītahavya (I) — a son of Śunaka (Sunaya-Br. & Vā. P.)
and father of Dhṛti.
Bhā. IX. 13. 26; Br. III. 64. 23; Vā. 89. 22; Vi. IV. 5. 31.
text.13356:
Vītahavya (II) — a mantrakṛt.
Br. II. 32. 105; M. 145. 99; Vā. 59. 97.
text.13359:
Vītihavya — a Bhārgava gotrakṛt; an ārṣeya pravara.
M. 195. 18, 36.
text.13360:
Vītihotra (I) — a son of Priyavrata: appointed Lord of
Puṣkaradvīpa. Father of Ramaṇaka and Dhātakī. After
dividing the kingdom among his sons he became religiously
devoted.
Bhā. V. 1. 25 and 33; 20. 31.
text.13361:
Vītihotra (II) — a son of Indrasena and father of Satya
śravas.
Bhā. IX. 2. 20.
text.13362:
Vītihotra (III) — a son of Sukumāra and father of
Bharga.
Bhā. IX. 17. 9.
text.13363:
Vītihotra (IV) — the eldest son of Tālajangha; father of
Ananta; escaped to Himālayas from Paraśurāma's attack.
Bhā. IX. 23. 29; Br. III. 46. 26; 47. 67; 69. 53; M. 43. 49;
Vi. IV. 11. 24.
text.13364:
Vītihotra (V) — invited for Yudhiṣṭhira's Rājasūya.
Bhā. X. 74. 9.
text.13365:
Vītihotra (VI) — a son of Dṛṣṭaketu and father of Bhārga.
Vi. IV. 8. 20.
text.13366:
Vītihotras — a Vindhya tribe: one of the five gaṇas of
the Haihayas;1 twenty kings of these, contemporaneous with
ten of Śiśunāgas, ruled from Avanti.2 1) Br. II. 16. 65; III. 69. 52; 74. 138; M. 43. 48; 114. 54; Vā. 45.
134.
2) M. 272. 1, 17.
text.13367:
Vidūratha (I) — a son of Bhajamāna and father of Rājā
dhideva.
M. 44. 77.
text.13369:
Vidūratha (III) — the king and ally of Bhīṣmaka and
Jarāsandha.
Vi. V. 26. 7.
text.13370:
Vīdyutvanta — Mt. a kulaparvata in the south of Bhā
rata varṣa.
Vā. 48. 3.
text.13371:
Vīra (I) — a son of Pṛthu; pursued Indra at the instance
of Atri when Indra walked away with Pṛthu's sacrificial
horse.
Bhā. IV. 19. 17; 20. 21.
text.13372:
Vīra (II) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Satyā.
Bhā. X. 61. 13-14.
text.13373:
Vīra (III) — a son of Satrajit.
Br. III. 71. 55.
text.13374:
Vīra (IV) — a name. of Vighneśvara.
Br. IV. 44. 68.
text.13375:
Vīras (I) — the gods of Tāmasa epoch.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 28.
text.13376:
Vīras (II) — a class of Piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 378.
text.13377:
Vīraka (I) — (Virāka-Bhā. P.) a sage of the Cākṣuṣa
epoch.
Bhā. VIII. 5. 8.
text.13378:
Vīraka (II) — the head of a Śiva gaṇa.
Br. III. 41. 28.
text.13379:
Vīraka (III) — the door-keeper of Śiva, with the cane in
hand; directed the Devas to their proper seats in the marriage
of Umā and Śiva; adopted as son by Umā who brought him
up tenderly, played with Vidyādharas; appointed to guard
the harem by Umā when she went for penance; when he
allowed Āḍi in the guise of a woman to enter, he was curs
ed to be born as man and join the gaṇa afterwards.
M. 154. 230, 383, 445-54, 465-577; chh. 155-158.
text.13380:
Vīrakambalabarhis — (also Kambalabarhis) — son of
Marutta and father of Rukmakavaca.
Br. III. 70. 25.
text.13381:
Vīrajā — a mind-born daughter of Ājyapa pitṛs; married
Nahuṣa and became the mother of Yayāti.
M. 15. 23.
text.13382:
Vīrajās — a sage of the Cākṣuṣa epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 28.
text.13383:
Vīraṇa — a progenitor; father of Asiknī and father-in
law of Dakṣa (Cākṣuṣa-Vi. P.);1 his daughter Vīriṇī married
Cakṣus.2 1) Br. III. 2. 5; Vā. 65. 128; Vi. I. 13. 3.
2) M. 4. 40.
text.13385:
Vīradatta — the name of the wood-cutter who became
Dvijavarma.
Br. IV. 7. 32.
text.13386:
Vīranagaram — the city in whose grove Nidāgha engaged
himself in austerities for a 1000 divine years.
Vi. II. 15. 6-7.
text.13388:
Vīrabhadra (I) — created out of anger of Śiva on his
hearing of Satī's self-sacrifice to destroy Dakṣa's yajña; seized
Dakṣa, cut off his head and offered it to Dakṣiṇāgni, and then
set out for Kailāsa. After reconciliation with Śiva, Viṣṇu
was propitiated with Puroḍāśa to get rid of pollution due to
Vīrabhadra's interference in the Yajña;1 after destroying the
sacrifice was about to destroy the world; Śiva stopped him
and blessed him to be the first of all grahas by name Aṅgā
raka;2 hearing that he came out of the wrath of Paśupati
Dakṣa appeased him by prayers. Śiva rose from the fire
altar and granted him his request that his sacrifice be fruit
ful when Dakṣa praised him with 1008 names.3 1) Bhā. IV. ch. 5 (whole); 7. 17; Vā. 30. 130-160; 101. 299.
2) M.
72. 13-6; 192. 6.
3) Vā. 30. 161-180.
text.13389:
Vīrabhadra (II) — one of the Śiva's attendants; the head
of a Śiva gaṇa.
Br. III. 32. 23; 41. 28; IV. 14. 8.
text.13392:
Vīravatī — the wife of Satrājit; mother of Bhangakāra,
Satyabhāmā and others.
Br. III. 71. 56.
text.13393:
Vīravān — one of the nine mind-born sons of Sāvarṇi.
Vā. 100. 21.
text.13394:
Vīravrata — a son of Madhu and Sumanas; wife Bhojā;
Father of Manthu and Pramanthu.
Bhā. V. 15. 15.
text.13395:
Vīravratam — in honour of Śiva; here a golden lion is
offered as present.
M. 101. 28.
text.13396:
Vīrasena (I) — a Brahman sage who was invited for the
Rājasūya of Yudhiṣṭhira.
Bhā. X. 74. 9.
text.13397:
Vīrasena (II) — a son of Ṛtuparṇa, and father of Sudāsa.
Br. III. 63. 174.
text.13398:
Vīrasena (III) — his son Nala, to be distinguished from
the friend of the Ikṣvākus.
Vā. 88. 175.
text.13399:
Vīrahatti — the sin of killing Kṣatriyas.
Br. III. 47. 26.
text.13400:
Vīrahantras — succeeded the Bṛhadratha kings. Śunaka
killed the reigning king and anointed his son, Pradyota.
Br. III. 74. 122.
text.13401:
Vīrahotras — a Haihaya clan beginning with Vīrahotra.
Vā. 94. 52.
text.13402:
Vīrāsana — the posture in which Pṛṣadhra sat and pro
tected the cattle of his preceptor during nights.
Bhā. IX. 2. 3.
text.13405:
Vīriṇī (II) — a wife of Dakṣa, and mother of Suvrata.
Br. IV. 1. 39.
text.13406:
Vīriṇī (III) — from her the dharmasarga of Kaśyapa
originated.
Vā. 1. 131.
text.13407:
Vīriṇī (IV) — a daughter of Vīrasena; grand-daughter of
Brahmā and wife of Cakṣus.
M. 4. 39.
text.13408:
Vīrudhā — a daughter of Irā and mother of creepers and
bushes.
Br. III. 7. 460-2.
text.13409:
Vīreśvara — Icon of; seated on the bull, with plaited tuft,
and trident and Vīṇā in his hands; generally in the pre
sence of mātṛgaṇa images.
M. 261. 39.
text.13411:
Vīryadharas — a class of people in Śālmalidvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 11.
text.13415:
Vīryaśulka — prize of Valour in svayamvara.
Bhā. I. 10. 29.
text.13416:
Vīryās — the Kṣatriya Brahmans of Angirasa line.
Vā. 99. 164.
text.13418:
Vṛka (I) — a son of Pṛthu and Arcis: was entrusted with
the western part of the kingdom by his elder brother.
Bhā. IV. 22. 54; 24. 2.
text.13419:
Vṛka (II) — an Asura who followed Vṛtra against Indra;
a son of Hiraṇyākṣa.
Bhā. VI. 10. [20]; VII. 2. 18.
text.13420:
Vṛka (III) — a son of Bharuka and father of Bāhuka.
Bhā. IX. 8. 2.
text.13421:
Vṛka (IV) — a son of Devamīḍha and Māriṣā; married
Durvārkṣī and had Takṣa and other sons.
Bhā. IX. 24. 29 and 43.
text.13422:
Vṛka (V) — a son of Vatsaka and Miśrakeśī.
Bhā. IX. 24. 43.
text.13423:
Vṛka (VI) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Mitravindā.
Bhā. X. 61. 16.
text.13424:
Vṛka (VII) — a son of Śakuni and an Asura; met Nārada
who advised him to perform tapas in honour of Śiva. He
did so by cutting his own flesh for six days and on the seventh
was about to cut off his head when Śiva appeared and blessed
that whosesoever head he touched that person should die. He
attempted it on Śiva who ran to Vaikuṇṭha. Hari in the
form of a Brahmacārin asked him to try the boon on him
self. The wicked Asura did so and met with his death.
Bhā. X. 88. 13-36.
text.13425:
Vṛka (VIII) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Satyā (Mādrī-Vi. P.).
Bhā. X. 90. 33; Br. III. 71. 252; Vi. V. 32. 4.
text.13426:
Vṛka (IX) — sonless, adopted Saumi and Kauśika.
Br. II. 71. 192.
text.13428:
Vṛka (XI) — a son of Ruruka and father of Bāhu.
Br. III. 63. 119; Vi. IV. 3. 25-6.
text.13429:
Vṛka (XII) — a son of Śūra.
Br. III. 71. 149.
text.13432:
Vṛka (XV) — a son of Chāyā and Puṣṭi (Sṛṣti-Br. P.).
Vā. 62. 83; Br. II. 36. 98.
text.13433:
Vṛka (jit) (XVI) — one of the sons of Nāganajit.
Vā. 96. 243.
text.13434:
Vṛkajit — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Satyā.
Br. III. 71. 252.
text.13435:
Vṛkatejasa — a son of Śiṣṭa (i) and Succhāyā.
M. 4. 39; Vi. I. 13. 2.
text.13436:
Vṛkadevā — one of the seven daughters of Devaka;
married Vasudeva.
Vā. 96. 130; Vi. IV. 14. 18.
text.13437:
Vṛkadevī — one of the wives of Vasudeva and mother
of Agāvaha (Avagāha, M. P.) and Nandaka.
Br. III. 71. 180; M. 46. 18; Vā. 96. 180.
text.13438:
Vṛkala (I) — a son of Sṛṣṭi (Puṣṭi-Vā. P.) and Chāyā
(Succhāyā-Vi. P.).
Br. II. 36. 98; Vā. 62. 83; Vi. I. 13. 2.
text.13440:
Vṛkavaktra (I) — a Rākṣasa living in Atalam.
Br. II. 20. 33.
text.13441:
Vṛkavaktra (II) — an Asura of the fourth tala or
gabhastala.
Vā. 50. 32.
text.13442:
Vṛkāśva — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Satyā.
Br. III. 71. 252; Vā. 96, 243.
text.13444:
Vṛkodara — a name of Bhīmasena;1 son of Vāyu and
Pṛthā;2 Bhīma, son of Vāyu through the God Marut;3 fire
called Vṛka, in his stomach.4 1) Bhā. I. 7. 13; Br. III. 71. 154.
2) M. 46. 9; Vā. 96. 153;
99. 244.
3) M. 50. 49.
4) Ib. 69. 14.
text.13445:
Vṛkṣavīrut — milked the earth in Palāśapātra.
Vā. 62. 191.
text.13446:
Vṛkṣās — sacred as houses for the primitive man and
supplied him with honey, fruits and clothing; Gandharvas
live in them; these kalpavṛkṣās deteriorated and man who
took to caves began to build houses on the model furnished
by the trees with the upward, downward and crosswise
trees;1 milked the cow-earth; the essence was tender leaves;
the vessel was of pālāśa wood and the plakṣa tree acted as
the calf.2 1) Br. II. 7. 75-91, 117-20.
2) M. 10. 27.
text.13448:
Vṛkṣotsavam — (Pādapodyāpana): festivities connected
with the planting of trees and the laying out of gardens.
M. 59. 17.
text.13449:
Vṛja — a son of Havirdhāna.
Vi. I. 14. 2.
text.13450:
Vṛjinī (I) — a daughter of Kṛṣṇa and Satyā.
Br. III. 71. 252.
text.13452:
Vṛjinīvat — a son of Kroṣṭu, and father of Svāhi.
Bhā. IX. 23. 31; Br. III. 70. 15-16; M. 44. 15; Vā. 95. 15.
text.13454:
Vṛttā — a daughter of Ṛṣā; mother of Tortoise, śankha,
etc.
Br. III. 7. 414-17; Vā. 69. 291-92.
text.13455:
Vṛtti (I) — means of living by Ṛta, Amṛta, Mṛta
Pramṛta and Satyāmṛta or Satyānṛta; never by śvavṛtti.
Bhā. VII. 11. 18-20.
text.13456:
Vṛtti (II) — transformation of Jayādevas in the seven
epochs of Manu.
Br. III. 4. 12, 37.
text.13458:
Vṛttirūpavatī — a R. of Krauñcadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 21.
text.13459:
Vṛtra (I) — a son of Tvaṣṭri, created out of a sacrificial
offering with an ugly appearance to avenge Indra, the mur
derer of Viśvarūpa. Hari advised Indra on the means to
end Vṛtra. In the battle Vṛtra encouraged his soldiers and
uttered words of heroism. Ran towards Indra as Kaiṭabha
against Hari and had one hand cut off. But in the contest
the Vajra of Indra slipped and Vṛka asked him to take up
the weapon and fight. He had his other arm cut off. But
Vṛka swallowed Indra into his stomach from which Indra
escaped and cut off his head. Vṛtra attained Aloka due to
his faith in Hari having been born as Citraketu (s.v.) in his
previous birth.1 Attained release by satsanga. His greed for
more territory.2 Killed by Hālāphala avatār. An account of
the death in the Bhāgavata; an Asura of Kṛtayuga.3 Brought
forth sons from his terrible breathing during his fight with
Indra in thousands. All followers of Mahendra, those who
have realised Brahmā, are happy, dharmic and live in
small bodies.4 1) Bhā. VI. chh. 9-12 (whole); ch. 14 (whole); 17. 38-39; X. 77.
36; Br. III. 72. 83.
2) Bhā. XI. 12. 5; XII. 3. 11.
3) M. 47. 51; 53.
20; 249. 67.
4) Vā. 68. 34-6.
text.13460:
Vṛtra (II) — a son of Anāyuṣa. Father of Bakas in hun
dreds who followed Mahendra.
Br. III. 6. 31.
text.13461:
Vṛtraghātaka — the ninth of the twelve incarnations of
Viṣṇu.
M. 47. 44.
text.13462:
Vṛtraghnī — a R. from the Pāriyātra hill; from Ṛṣyavān;
in Bhāratavarṣa.
Br. II. 16. 27; M. 114. 23; Vā. 45. 97
text.13463:
Vṛtraripu — an epithet of Indra.
Vi. V. 1. 58.
text.13464:
Vṛtrahā — is Indra;1 got frightened at the prolonged love
of Umā and Śankara and asked Agni to disturb their sport.2 1) Br. III. 10. 23.
2) Vā. 72. 21.
text.13465:
Vṛddhagarga — taught Atri the consequences of dis
astrous signs in a state.
M. 229. 2.
text.13466:
Vṛddhagārgya — a contemporary of Mucukunda; told
the latter that towards the end of Dvāpara he would have
the darśan of Kṛṣṇa Viṣṇu.
Vi. V. 23. 258.
text.13467:
Vṛddhaśa (dha) man — of Kārūṣa line, married Śruta
devā, sister of Vasudeva. She gave birth to Dantavaktra;1
son of Āyu.2 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 37; Br. III. 71. 156; Vā. 96. 155; Vi. IV. 14. 39.
2) M. 24. 34.
text.13468:
Vṛddhasena — a queen of Sumatī and mother of Deva
tājit.
Bhā. V. 15. 2.
text.13470:
Vṛddhiśrāddham — done prior to maṅgala occasions such
as festivals, sacrifices, marriages, etc.; here prayers offered
first to mātṛs, then to pitṛs, maternal grandfather, and Viś
vedevas; in it yava is used for tila and prefaced by Nāndi
śabda;1 a house-holder is eligible to perform it after the
sapiṇḍi karaṇam of the deceased.2 1) M. 17. 65 9; Vā. 110. 17.
2) M. 18. 16.
text.13471:
Vṛndāvanam — sacred to Rādhā.
Br. III. 33. 24; 36. 32. M. 13. 38; Vi. V. 25. 4.
text.13472:
Vṛṣa (I) — a son of Śṛnjaya and Rāṣṭrapāli.
Bhā. IX. 24. 42.
text.13473:
Vṛṣa (II) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Satyā.
Bhā. X. 61. 13.
text.13474:
Vṛṣa (III) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Kālindī.
Bhā. X. 61. 14.
text.13475:
Vṛṣa (IV) — one of the ten horses of the moon's chariot.
Br. II. 23. 56; M. 126. 52; Vā. 52. 53.
text.13477:
Vṛṣa (bha) (VI) — the milk-white humped bull born of
Surabhī and the standard of Śiva;1 taught Godharma to
Dīrghatamas;2 gift of, in a Śrāddha.3 1) Br. III. 3. 78-79; 74. 48-51; IV. 14. 2.
2) Ib. III. 74. 47;
3) Ib. III. 19. 15.
text.13478:
Vṛṣa (VII) — a son of Anāyuṣā: Father of Śrāddhāda,
Yajnahā, Brahmahā and Paśuhā, all cruel minded.
Br. III. 6. 31.
text.13479:
Vṛṣa (VIII) — the sacred well in Devikā. Here is the
Jātavedaśilā.
Br. III. 13. 41; Vā. 77. 41-4.
text.13480:
Vṛṣa (IX) — the Vedic lore rooted in Brahmacarya.
Br. III. 14. 36-7.
text.13481:
Vṛṣa (X) — a son of Kārtavīrya who escaped Paraśu
rāma: a mahāratha.
Br. III. 41. 13; 69. 50; Vā. 94. 49.
text.13482:
Vṛṣa (XI) — the Indra of the epoch of the III Sāvarṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 77; 18. 8.
text.13484:
Vṛṣa (XIII) — a palace in the form of a bull
M. 269. 36, 45.
text.13485:
Vṛṣa (XIV) — Dharma;1 a son of Maya.2 1) Vā. 78. 27; Br. III. 14. 36.
2) Vā. 68. 28.
text.13487:
Vṛṣa (XVI) — a son of Bharata and father of Madhu.
