Vi. IV. 11. 25-6.
text.13488:
Vṛṣaka — a son of Chāyā and Puṣṭi.
Vā. 62. 83.
text.13490:
Vṛṣaketana — a name of Vighneśvara.
Br. IV. 44. 70.
text.13491:
Vṛṣadakṣa — a son of Surabhī and Kaśyapa with a
jewelled necklace given by mother for the use of Maheś
vara as dhvaja.
Vā. 66. 75-6.
text.13492:
Vṛṣadarbha — a son of Śibi, after whom came the Jana
pada Vṛṣadarbha.
Br. III. 74. 23; Vā. 99. 23.
text.13493:
Vṛṣadhvaja (I) — a follower of Vṛtra in his battle with
Indra.
Bhā. VI. 10. [20].
text.13494:
Vṛṣadhvaja (II) — Śiva as overlord of the Rudras;1
prayer to.2 1) Br. III. 8. 6; M. 180. 89-90; 189. 14.
2) Ib. 266. 47.
text.13496:
Vṛṣaparvan — a son of Danu. Father of Śarmiṣṭhā
whom Yayātī married. Sudarī and Candrā were his other
daughters. Helped Vṛtra against Indra, and fought with
Aśvins in the Devāsura war.1 Heard of Śukra's anger on
account of the offence given by his daughter to Devayānī
and requested Śukra to stay on, promising to make his
daughter a servant of Devayānī.2 Attained salvation by
satsanga. 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 31-2; 10. 20; VIII. 10. 30; Vi. I. 21. 5; Vā. 68. 8;
93. 16; Br. III. 6. 8, 23; 68. 15; M. 6. 20-22; 24. 52; 25. 6.
2) Bhā. IX.
18. 4 and 6, 26-28; XI. 12. 5; M. chh. 27 and 29.
text.13497:
Vṛṣaparvans — not to marry with Aṅgiras and Virūpas.
M. 196. 40.
text.13498:
Vṛṣabha (I) — a son of Kārtavīryārjuna.
Bhā. IX. 23. 27.
text.13499:
Vṛṣabha (II) — a playmate of Kṛṣṇa. Being a victor in
a game was carried on his back by Bhadrasena.
Bhā. X. 18. 23-24.
text.13500:
Vṛṣabha (III) — a son of Sṛṣṭi and Chāyā.
Br. II. 36. 98.
text.13501:
Vṛṣabha (IV) — the Asura vanquished by Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 36. 37; 73. 100; Vā. 98. 100.
text.13502:
Vṛṣabha (V) — a god of the Sukarmāṇa group.
Br. IV. 1. 88; Vā. 100. 92.
text.13503:
Vṛṣabha (VI) — a son of Anamitra, married Jayanti the
daughter of the Kāśirāja.
M. 45. 25-6.
text.13504:
Vṛṣabha (VII) — a son of Kuśāgra and father of Punya
vān (Puspavān-Vi. P.).
M. 50. 29; Vi. IV. 19. 82.
text.13505:
Vṛṣabha (VIII) — the Lord of cattle: dedication of a
dark Vṛṣa is equal to going to Gayā for Śrāddha.
M. 8. 8; 22. 6.
text.13506:
Vṛṣabha (IX) — the Mt. Sumana in Plakṣa; to the east
of Aruṇoda;1 north of the Mahābhadra lake.2 1) Vā. 36. 18.
2) Ib. 36. 20.
text.13507:
Vṛṣabhadhvaja — Śiva with the standard of the bull; also
Vṛṣavāhana;1 prayed to by Kāma and others;2 see Vṛṣadhvaja
the Lord of Rudras.3 1) M. 1. 8; 133. 13; Vā. 30. 180, 261; Vi. V. 33. 50; 34. 35.
2) M.
140. 85; 191. 115; 192. 27; 206. 27 and 28.
3) Vā. 70. 6.
text.13508:
Vṛṣala — see Śūdra;1 unfit for Pankti feeding.2 1) Br. II. 31. 89; III. 14. 38.
2) Ib. III. 19. 31; IV. 8. 19;
Vā. 78. 29.
text.13509:
Vṛṣalas — rule with Guruṇḍas (Maruṇḍas-Vā. P.); both
Mlecchas;1 joined with the Mlecchas;2 to be put down by
future Kalki.3 1) Br. III. 74. 177; Vā. 58. 88; 99. 363.
2) M. 273. 22.
3) Ib.
47. 252; Vā. 98. 114.
text.13510:
Vṛṣalapati — the chieftain of the Vṛṣalas: offered human
sacrifice to Kālī for getting a son.
Bhā. V. 9. 12.
text.13512:
Vṛṣasena (I) — a son of Karṇa; with him comes to an
end the Anga line.
Bhā. IX. 23. 14; M. 48. 102.
text.13513:
Vṛṣasena (II) — a son of the II Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 72.
text.13514:
Vṛṣasena (III) — a son of Kārtavīryārjuna.
Vi. IV. 11. 21.
text.13515:
Vṛṣākapi (I) — a Rudra, and a son of Bhūta and Sarūpā:
Fought with Jambha in the Devāsura war.
Bhā. VI. 6. 17; VIII. 10. 32; Vi. I. 15. 122.
text.13516:
Vṛṣākapi (II) — a name of Indra.
Bhā. VI. 13. 10.
text.13517:
Vṛṣākapi (III) — a name of Hari.
Bhā. X. 1. 20.
text.13519:
Vṛṣāṅka — a name of Śiva.
Bhā. VIII. 8. 1; M. 154. 196.
text.13520:
Vṛṣādarbha — a son of Śibi;1 an Angirasa and mantra-
kṛṭ.2 1) Bhā. IX. 23. 3.
2) Br. II. 32. 109.
text.13521:
Vṛṣās — a line of kings in Vidiśa.
Vā. 99. 366.
text.13522:
Vṛṣāsya — a son of Kārtavīrya who escaped Paraśurāma:
a Mahāratha.
Br. III. 41. 13; 69. 50.
text.13523:
Vṛṣotsarga — rules for the dedication of a bull; the
characteristics and adornments of the bull intended for gift
and of the cow, its mother; intended for all castes; different
coloured bulls and their significance; gift of nīla bull best
for pitṛs;1 at Gayā.2 1) M. 18. 14; 207. 1-41; Vā. 83. 12, 45-6.
2) Ib. 112. 58.
text.13524:
Vṛṣṭa — (Dhṛṣṭa): his line was Vārṣṭaka.
Vi. IV. 2. 4.
text.13525:
Vṛṣṭi (I) — a son of Sāvarṇi Manu.
M. 9. 33.
text.13527:
Vṛṣṭinemi — a son of Aśvinī and Akrūra.
M. 45. 33.
text.13528:
Vṛṣṭimat — a son of Kaviratha, and father of Suṣeṇa.
Bhā. IX. 22. 41.
text.13529:
Vṛṣṭī — a daughter of Marīci.
Br. II. 11. 12.
text.13530:
Vṛṣṭyādya — one of the sons of Kārtavīrya and a Mahā
ratha.
Vā. 94. 49.
text.13531:
Vṛṣṇi (I) — the eldest of Madhu's hundred sons. After
him the line became famous, a gotra name.
Bhā. IX. 23. 29; Vi. IV. 11. 27-8.
text.13532:
Vṛṣṇi (II) — a son of Sātvata and father of Sumitra and
Yujājit;1 darling of the Yadus; had two wives, Gāndhārī and
Mādrī; the former bore Sumitra and the latter, five children;2
suspected Kṛṣṇa of having appropriated the syamantaka
gem from which he honourably redeemed himself;3 belonged
to the Kṛoṣṭhu line;4 originator of the Vṛṣṇi kula.5 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 6 and 12.
2) M. 44. 48; 45. 1-2.
3) Br. III. 71.
1, 36, 102.
4) Ib. III. 70. 15; 73. 91.
5) Vā. 95. 14.
text.13533:
Vṛṣṇi (III) — a son of Anamitra (a member of that
family, Vi. P.) and father of Śvaphalka and Cītraratha.
Bhā. IX. 24. 15. Vi. IV. 14. 5.
text.13534:
Vṛṣṇi (IV) — a son of Bhajamāna.
M. 44. 50; Vi. IV. 13. 1-2.
text.13535:
Vṛṣṇi (V) — a son of Kukura and father of Kapotaroman
and Dhṛti.
Br. III. 71. 117; M. 44. 62.
text.13536:
Vṛṣṇi (VI) — the best of the Yadus and a son of Kausalyā.
Vā. 96. 2.
text.13537:
Vṛṣṇi (VII) — a son of Bāhyaka — two queens Gāndhārī
and Mādrī.
Vā. 96. 4, 17.
text.13538:
Vṛṣṇi (VIII) — a son of Satvata; had two sons Sumītra
and Yudhājit.
Vi. IV. 13. 1, 8.
text.13539:
Vṛṣṇis — the community of Dvāravatī in which Bala
rāma and Kṛṣṇa were born;1 Kuntī was attached to these
people while Kamsa devised means to vanquish them. Were
relieved at Kamsa's death.2 Its name derived from Vṛṣṇi.3 They praised the heroic deeds of Kṛṣṇa who was their Lord
and who lived with them. But they did not recognise in Him
the Almighty Lord;4 ended their lives by fighting their
kinsmen at Prabhāsā. Attained Hari through relationship.5 1) Bhā. I. 3. 23; 11. 11; 14. 25; Br. III. 61. 23; 71. 85; Vā. 1.
145; 96. 84, 175; 86. 28.
2) Bhā. I. 8. 41; X. 36. 33; 39. 25; 45. 15;
3) Ib. IX. 23. 30.
4) Ib. I. 9. 18; II. 4. 20; IX. 24. 63; X. 1. 11 and 62;
90. 46.
5) Ib. XI. 30. 18; VII. 1. 30.
text.13540:
Vṛṣṇikulam — its old fame was raised by the birth of
Lord Viṣṇu.
M. 44. 15; 47. 12 and 33; 69. 10.
text.13541:
Vṛṣṇimān — a son of Śucidrava (Śuciratha-Vi. P.) and
father of Suṣeṇa.
M. 50. 80; Vi. IV. 21. 12.
text.13543:
Vegavat (I) — a son of Bandhumat and father of
Bandhu. (Budha-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 2. 30; Br. III. 8. 36; 61. 10; Vi. IV. 1. 44-5.
text.13544:
Vegavat (II) — a son of Nāgnajit.
Bhā. X. 61. 13.
text.13545:
Vegavat (III) — the father of a son Budha.
Vā. 86. 14-5.
text.13546:
Vegavatyas — one of the 14 gaṇas of Apsaras, born of
Ṛiṣtā.
Br. III. 7. 18.
text.13547:
Vegavanta — an Apsara gaṇa from Variṣṭa or Ariṣṭa.
Vā. 69. 54.
text.13548:
Veginī — a Śakti on the Drāviṇikā Mudrā.
Br. IV. 36. 76.
text.13549:
Veṃka — (c) a kingdom through which Ṛṣabha passed.
Its king was Arhat.
Bhā. V. 6. 7 and 9.
text.13550:
Veṃkaṭa — a Mt. in Bhāratavarṣa: visited by Balarāma.
Its sages visited Dvārakā.
Bhā. V. 19. 16; X. 79. 13; 90. 28[3].
text.13551:
Veṇā (I) — a tīrtha sacred to Amṛta;1 sacred to the
Pitṛs.2 1) M. 13. 49.
2) Ib. 22. 34.
text.13552:
Veṇā (II) — a R. from the Vindhyas; visited by
Balarāma.
M. 114. 27. Bhā. X. 79. 12.
text.13553:
Veṇī — a R. in Bhāratavarṣa, from the Vindhyas.
Bhā. V. 19. 18; Br. II. 16. 33.
text.13555:
Veṇu — flute;1 in Rāma's abhiṣeka;2 in Pātālam.3 1) Vā. 45. 40; 56. 32; 104. 48; Vi. II. 14. 32.
2) Ib. IV. 4. 99.
3) Ib. II. 5. 11.
text.13556:
Veṇudāri — an ally of Jarāsandha: attacked the eastern
gate of Mathurā and the northern gate of Gomanta during
their siege by Jarāsandha.
Bhā. X. 50. 11[2]; 52. 11[14].
text.13557:
Veṇumaṇḍalam — (c) a kingdom of Kuśadvīpa after
Veṇumat.
Br. II. 14. 28; 19. 57; Vā. 33. 25; 49. 52.
text.13558:
Veṇumat (I) — a son of Jyotiṣmat after whom Veṇu
maṇḍalam took its name.
Br. II. 14. 27-8; Vā. 33. 24; Vi. II. 4. 36.
text.13559:
Veṇumat (II) — a Mt. to the east of Aruṇoda;1 the cities
of Vidyādharas in.2 1) Vā. 36. 19.
2) Ib. 37. 3, 26.
text.13560:
Veṇumatī — a R. rising from the Pāriyātra hills.
M. 22. 20.
text.13561:
Veṇuhaya — one of the three sons of Śatajit.
Bhā. IX. 23. 21; Br. III. 69. 4; M. 43. 8; Vā. 94. 4; Vi. IV. 11. 7.
text.13562:
Veṇuhotra — a son of Dhṛṣṭaketu.
Br. III. 67. 77; Vā. 92. 72.
text.13563:
Veṇvā — a R. originating from the Vindhyas.
Vā. 45. 102.
text.13564:
Vetālas — (also Betālas) a class of spirits, a gaṇa, largely
followers of Śiva;1 Vampires: dance and feast on flesh and
blood on the field of battle;2 images of, attending on Śiva.3 1) Bhā. II. 10. 39; VII. 8. 38; X. 63. 10; Br. III. 41. 29; IV. 14.
10; 24. 55; M. 8. 5; 23. 39.
2) Ib. 149. 16.
3) Ib. 259. 24.
text.13565:
Vetālī — a R. of the Bhadrā.
Vā. 43. 30.
text.13566:
Vetravatī (I) — a R. from the Pāriyātra hill.
Br. II. 16. 28; Vā. 45. 98.
text.13567:
Vetravatī (II) — a R. from the mountain Ṛṣyavān;1 sacred
to the Pitṛs.2 1) M. 114. 23.
2) Ib. 22. 20. 163. 63.
text.13568:
Vetravatī (III) — a R., a mahānadī summoned to Gayā by
Lomeśa.
Vā. 108. 78.
text.13569:
Vetrasaṃkhupathas — the kingdom of the; the R. Pāvanī
flows through.
M. 121. 56; Br. II. 18. 57.
text.13570:
Veda (I) — the science of Dharma together with the
ācāra of those who know it.
M. 52. 7; 164. 16.
text.13571:
Vedas — First came nāda from the Supreme Brahman,
then Omkāra and then mantropaniṣad. Brahmā created
Akṣaras, and out of his four mouths appeared the four Vedas,
which were taught to his sons. This was handed down by
tradition through the ages.1 Originally one, rearranged by
Vyāsa into four Samhitās — Ṛg, Yajus, Sāman and Atharvan:
distribution among his pupils done by Kṛṣṇadvaipāyana with
the help of Paila, Jaimini, Sumantu, and Vaiśampāyana:
growth of Śākhās. Lost in a deluge. Then Hari. taught
them to Brahmā who taught in his turn to his sons. A three
fold division of the Vedas conveys the truth of Brahman
and Ātman. In these Hari manifests himself: its metres are
Gāyatrī, Uṣṇik and so on.2 Symbolised by Garuḍa: do not
shine in Kali.3 Personified: These with Upavedas came to
see the Trivikrama form of Hari.4 Learnt by Balarāma and
Kṛṣṇa.5 Twenty-eight Vedavyāsas rearranged them in the
28 periods: compiled into four by Parāśara's son, originally
one;6 served as vessel for Bṛhaspati to milk the cow-earth;7
restored by Matsya after deluge.8 1) Bhā. XII. 6. 36-46; III. 12. 36-37; IV. 24. 62; M. 2. 13; 3. 2;
4. 7; 285. 8.
2) Bhā. I. 4. 19-23; XI. 14. 3-6; 21. 35-43; XII. 6. 49-50;
Vi. III. 3. 20; 4. 7-9.
3) Bhā. XII. 11. 19; X. 20. 8.
4) Ib. VIII. 21. 2;
IX. 22. 37.
5) Ib. X. 45. 33.
6) Br. II. 34. 2, 12-30; 35. 116-26; III. 10.
69; IV. 1. 30; 6. 64; M. 14. 16.
7) Ib. 10. 17.
8) Ib. 53. 5; 83. 3; 172. 50.
text.13572:
Vedakauṇḍilya — a Ṛtvik at Brahmā's yajña.
Vā. 106. 34.
text.13573:
Vedacintakas — those that have not understood the
Vedas as Vedavits do.
Vā. 83. 100.
text.13574:
Vedadarśa — learnt the Atharva Samhitā from a pupil
of Sumantu. Śauklāyani and others were his disciples.
Bhā. XII. 7. 1-2.
text.13575:
Vedanā — married Raurava Naraka; son born of Vedanā
and Māyā was Duhkham.
Vā. 10. 40-1; Br. II. 9. 64.
text.13576:
Vedabāhu (I) — a son of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 90. 34.
text.13577:
Vedabāhu (II) — a sage of the Raivata epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 22; Vā. 62. 53.
text.13578:
Vedamitra — Śākalya learnt the Samhitā entrusted by
Indrapramati to his son and re-arranged it into five with his
pupils.
Vi. III. 4. 21.
text.13580:
Vedavatī (I) — a R. from the Pāriyātra hill.
Br. II. 16. 27; Vā. 45. 97.
text.13581:
Vedavatī (II) — an Apsaras (Suranārī); from the vedi
tala of Brahmā.
Vā. 69. 60.
text.13582:
Vedavadanam — a tīrtha sacred to Gāyatri.
M. 13. 51.
text.13583:
Vedavit — one who knows the Veda and understands it
for yoga; understands it in the right direction as pre
scribed; distinct from Vedacintaka;1 eligible for Pārvaṇa
śrāddha.2 1) Vā. 83. 99, 100.
2) M. 16. 8.
text.13584:
Vedavedāṃgapāraga — one fully versed in the Vedas and
Vedāngas.
Vā. 34. 94; 109. 54.
text.13585:
Vedavyāsa (I) — (Vyāsa) a sage; twenty-eight Veda
vyāsas for twenty-eight dvāparas of the Vaivasvata epoch;
Svayambhuva, Vedavyāsa, Uśanā, Bṛhaspati, Savitā, Mṛtyu,
Indra, Vasiṣṭha, Sārasvata, Antarikṣa, Dharma, Traiyāruṇi,
Dhanañjaya, Kṛtamjaya, Ṛjīṣa, Bharadvāja, Gautama,
Uttama, Haryavana, Vena, Vājaśrava, Arvāk, Somamukhyā
yana, Tṛṇabindu, Tataja, Śakti, Parāśara, Jātūkarṇa, and
Dvaipāyana; in the future Dvāparadroṇi (more names are
given);1 son of Parāśara born in the 28th dvāpara; eighth
human incarnation of Viṣṇu with Jātūkarṇi (ja) as purodha
(purohita).2 1) Br. II. 33. 33; 35. 117-125.
2) Ib. III. 73. 93; M. 47. 246;
Vā. 98. 93.
text.13586:
Vedavyāsa (II) — Kṛṣṇadvaipāyana; he who split the
one Veda into four parts;1 different Vedavyāsas are said to
be compilers of the Veda in different Yugas.2 1) Vā. 1. 17, 179.
2) Ib. 58. 11; 61. 104.
text.13587:
Vedaśabda — with the aid of which Maheśvara created
the universe.
Vā. 9. 63.
text.13588:
Vedaśākhās — 10 Purāṇa variations; 4000 verses each
except Śāmśapāyikas; each in four parts and all conveying
the one meaning.
Vā. 61. 58, 59; 110. 7.
text.13589:
Vedaśira — a tīrtha sacred to the pitṛs.
M. 22. 71.
text.13590:
Vedaśiras (I) — a son of Prāṇa.
Bhā. IV. 1. 45.
text.13591:
Vedaśiras (II) — a son of Kṛśāśva and Dhiṣaṇā.
Bhā. VI. 6. 20.
text.13592:
Vedāśiras (III) — a sage and a siddha. His wife was
Tuṣitā. Father of Vibhu, a manifestation of Hari.
Bhā. VI. 15. 14; VIII. 1. 21.
text.13593:
Vedaśiras (IV) — a sage of the Raivata epoch.
Bhā. VIII. 5. 3.
text.13594:
Vedaśiras (V) — the avatār of the lord in the 15th
dvāpara; the name of a weapon sacred to Parameśvara in
the hill of Vedaśīrṣa on the slopes of the Himālayas.
Vā. 23. 166-68.
text.13595:
Vedaśiras (VI) — a son of Mārkaṇḍeya and Mūrdhani
(Dhūmrapatni-Br. P.); married Pīvarī; his sons Mārkaṇ
ḍeyas.
Vā. 28. 6; Br. II. 11. 7.
text.13596:
Vedaśiras (VII) — heard from the Nāgas at Pātālam the
Viṣṇu Purāṇa; he communicated it to Pramati.
Vi. VI. 8. 48.
text.13597:
Vedaśīrṣa — a Mt. on the slope of the Himālayas near the
Sarasvati hills.
Vā. 23. 168.
text.13599:
Vedaśrī — a Bhārgava and a sage of the Raivata epoch.
Br. II. 36. 62; Vi. III. 1. 22.
text.13600:
Vedaśrutas — the gods of the Uttama epoch.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 24.
text.13601:
Vedasparśa — a disciple of Kabandha divided the portion
received of Atharva into four parts.
Vā. 61. 50.
text.13602:
Vedasmṛtī — a R. in Bhāratavarṣa from the Pāriyātra hill
(from the mountain Ṛsyavān-M. P.).
Bhā. V. 19. 18; Br. II. 16. 27; M. 114. 23; Vā. 45. 97; Vi. II. 3. 10.
text.13603:
Vedānaga — from Viṣṇu.
Vā. 54. 82; Vi. I. 22. 83-84; Vi. 17. 5.
text.13604:
Vedāntaśāstram — the Vedānta to be loved by the
Gṛhasthas: Vedāntadarśanam being the end of a student's
life.
Br. IV. 2. 85; 8. 4; M. 52. 26; Vā. 101. 87-91; 104. 42.
text.13605:
Vedi (I) — a R. served by the Siddhas.
Br. III. 13. 81.
text.13606:
Vedi (II) — one of the ten pīṭhas for images, oblong;
unfit for installing lingas; this gives abundant riches.
M. 262. 6, 17.
text.13607:
Vedi (III) — (also Veditalam) the place of the fire altar
in the sacrifice.
Vā. 69. 60; 97. 25.
text.13608:
Vedyardha — in Jambūdvīpa, south of Meru;1 three
varṣas to the south of it, and three to its north.2 1) Br. II. 15. 36; Vā. 34. 23.
2) Ib. 34. 32.
text.13609:
Vedhas (I) — a name of Hari.
Bhā. I. 5. 31.
text.13610:
Vedhas (II) — a measure of time.
Bhā. III. 11. 6.
text.13611:
Vedhas (III) — a name of Brahmā1 (s.v.). He created
a daughter Śatarūpā (Sāvitrī); she was so charming
that he himself fell in love with her; her brothers like
Vasiṣṭha and she herself deplored the absurdity of a father
marrying his daughter; the creator turned a deaf ear and all
his attention became centred on her; to see her wherever
she was he created more eyes on all his five faces; after order
ing his sons to take up the work of creation, he lived with
Śatarūpā for years in the midst of the lotus flower unseen by
others, like an ordinary human being. To him was born
Manu Svāyambhuva also known as Virāṭ and Ādipuruṣa;
from him were born the Vairāja devas and others;2 grand
father of all the worlds.3 1) Bhā. VIII. 5. 24; Br. III. 21. 59.
2) M. 3. 29 to the end.
3) Vā. 106. 40; 108. 42; 109. 26.
text.13613:
Vedhaka — a hell for the maker of arrows.
Vi. II. 6. 16.
text.13614:
Vedhasa — a mantrakṛt and of Angira branch.
M. 145. 99; Vā. 59. 98.
text.13615:
Vena — a son of Anga, of cruel and wrong beha
viour; fell dead due to the curse of sages who churned his
right arm out of which came Pṛthu; born after aśvamedha
of his father. The twenty-third Vedavyāsa.1 Brought up in
the house of his grandfather who was an amśa of Mṛtyu
(adharma) Vena acquired bad conduct, killed his playmates
like animals and became a source of vexation to his father
who left the kingdom in disgust and distress. Vena was
crowned. Blinded by pride he proclaimed that there should
be no more yajñas or gifts in his kingdom. Lost it through
pride of power. He did not listen to the words of sages and
asserted he was the highest of all gods. Seeing him perverse
and vile, the sages slew him; Sunīthā protected his body by
mantra. To avoid anarchy and to preserve the line of Anga,
the sages churned the thigh of the dead prince and there
came a black dwarfish man, the ancestor of the Niṣādha race.2
They continued to churn the two arms out of which came a
male and female child, being the amśa of Viṣṇu and Lakṣmī.3
Thrown into hell by Brāhmaṇas, was saved from hell by
Pṛthu.4 Pṛthu was the father's part of Vena's body; from
the mother's part of his body came the Mlecchas.5
Another version: A son of the daughter of Kāla; took to
kāma and covetousness; founded an adharma sthāpana, gave
up Veda śāstras; subjects of, did not learn Vedas or performed
ceremonials or yajñas; made himself the object of sacrifice
and worship; enraged by the ṛṣis led by Marīci who advised
him to take up the right path; ridiculed them and said he was
a mahātmā and could burn the whole world or flood it; hence
the sages held him down and had his left hand churned by
force; there came out a short black figure who stood trem
bling; the sages said niṣīda, the forerunner of the niṣāda
vamśa; then they churned his right hand and Pṛthu was born;
Vena died; Pṛthu crowned by all; a good king; his rule and
achievements, including the milking of the earth by all
beings.6 1) Bhā. IV. 13. 18-20; 35. 38; Br. II. 35. 122; M. 4. 44.
2) Bhā.
IV. 13. 39, 42 and 47; ch. 14 (whole).
3) Ib. IV. 15. 1-3; 16. 11;
X. 73. 20.
4) Ib. II. 7. 9; VII. 1. 16; Br. II. 36. 108-12, 121-27, 150.
5) M. 10. 4-10.
6) Vā. 62. 108-193.
text.13616:
Venukā — a R. of the Śākadvīpa.
M. 122. 33. Br. II. 19. 96; Vi. II. 4. 65.
text.13617:
Velā (I) — a daughter of Meru and Dhāraṇi; married
Sāgara and brought forth a daughter. Savarṇā;1 she was
married to Prācīnabarhis to whom were born ten sons collec
tively known as Pracetas versed in Dhanur Veda.2 1) Vā. 30. 35.
2) Br. II. 13, 37, 39-40.
text.13618:
Velā (II) — a daughter of Bhadrāśva and Ghṛtāci.
Vā. 70. 69.
text.13619:
Veśa — married Nadhi; father of Marīca-Kaśyapa.
Vā. 65. 112.
text.13620:
Veśyādharmam — the life and duties of a dancing girl;
Ūrvaśī suffered for adopting it;1 to serve as courtesans in the
palace, temples and also those who are prepared to spend
money on them. They in turn were to give gifts in days of
festivals;2 residence of, plan for.3 1) M. 6. 1. 31.
2) Ib. 70. 19, 28-33.
3) Ib. 254. 23.
text.13622:
Vaikaṃka — a Mt. on the base (east) of Meru;1 residence
of Sugrīva, son of Garuḍa.2 1) Bhā. V. 16. 26; Vi. II. 2. 27.
2) Vā. 37. 16; 39. 39-41; 42. 19.
text.13625:
Vaikārika — the Sun and the son of Brahmā with rajo-
guṇa.
Vā. 31. 36.
text.13626:
Vaikārikas — a group of ten devas, born of Vaikārika,
called generally digdevatas.
Bhā. II. 5. 30; Vā. 4. 61.
text.13627:
Vaikārikasarga — explains the five buddhi and the five
karma senses and manas the eleventh.
Vā. 4. 60.
text.13628:
Vaikuṇṭha (I) — a name of Hari.
Bhā. I. 15. 46.
text.13629:
Vaikuṇṭha (II) — the abode of Viṣṇu, established by Him
at the request of Śrī in his manifestation as Vaikuṇṭha:
Famous for Naiśreyasa vana, filled with different trees and
birds. It had seven enclosures into which sin had no free
entrance. On the seventh were stationed two guardian
deities. These once prevented Lakṣmī from entering in
during the yoganidrā of Hari;1 happiness (saubhāgya) of
beings retired to, during the burning of the worlds.2 1) Bhā. III. 15. 13-27; 16. 27-30; VIII. 5. 5.
2) M. 60. 2; 245.
34; 285. 19.
text.13630:
Vaikuṇṭha (III) — a manifestation of Hari born of Vai
kuṇṭhā and Śubhra in Cākṣuṣa epoch. At the request of his
spouse Śrī, Vaikuṇṭha (Heaven) came into existence in the
Vaivasvata epoch, to the right of Śivaloka.
Bhā. VIII. 5. 4-6; Br. III. 3. 117; 32. 3; IV. 29. 136; 40. 9;
Vi. III. 1. 41; V. 5. 21.
text.13632:
Vaikuṇṭha (V) — in the Cyavana āśrama of Gayā;1 the
abode of Viṣṇu.2 1) Vā. 108. 74.
2) Ib. 24. 20; 109. 16.
text.13633:
Vaikuṇṭhas — a class of gods,1 Jayādevas, fourteen in
number in the epochs of Raivata Manu and Svāyambhuva.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 5. 4; Vi. III. 1. 21.
2) Br. II. 36. 51 and 58; III. 3. 9,
58 and 67; 4. 31; Vā. 66. 9; 67. 40-41.
text.13635:
Vaikuṇṭhā — the mother of Vaikuṇṭha devas.
Vā. 67. 40.
text.13636:
Vaikṛta — a Mt. noted for śrāddha offerings.
Br. III. 13. 28; Vā. 77. 28.
text.13637:
Vaikṛta sargas — five: Mukhya sarga, Tiryak yoni sarga,
Deva Sarga, Mānuṣa sarga, and Anugraha sarga; three Prā
kṛta sargas; these are the conscious creations of the spirit
(Brahmā).
Vā. 6. 65. 6.
text.13640:
Vaikharīvāk — one of the four tongues of the Veda.
Vā. 104. 74.
text.13641:
Vaikhānasa (I) — a Vaiṣṇava of the ardent type.
Br. IV. 8. 44
text.13642:
Vaikhānasa (II) — practices for a Brahmacārin before
becoming a full fledged mendicant.
Vi. III. 10. 15; IV. 2. 130.
text.13643:
Vaikhānasas — a class of seers, born on vyapohini rite on
ashes. Pṛthu became a Vaikhānasa in the evening of his
life; a son of Nahuṣa;2 Agastya followed the system;3 tapas in
the forests.4
^1 Bhā. III. 12. 43; IV. 23. 4; Br. I. 2. 27; II: 32. 25; III. 1. 57;
Vā. 65: 56. 2) M. 24. 51.
3) Ib. 61. 37.
4) Ib. 145. 24; Vā. 2. 27; 59. 24.
text.13645:
Vaijayanti — the garland worn by Arjuna (Haihaya)
and by Ananta;1 presented by sages to Balarāma after he
killed Balavala.2 The garland of Harī.3 1) Bhā. IX. 15. 20; V. 25. 7.
2) Ib. X. 79. 8.
3) Vi. I. 22. 72.
text.13646:
Vaiḍūrya — a hill range on the west of Meru.
Vi. II. 2. 29.
text.13647:
Vaiṇi — of the Sahya hills in the Dakṣināpatha.
Vā. 45. 104.
text.13649:
Vaiṇoya — a pupil of Yājñavalkya.
Br. II. 35. 29.
text.13650:
Vaitaṇḍa — a son of Āpa.
Vi. I. 15. 111.
text.13651:
Vaitaṇḍya — a son of Āyu (Āpa-Vā. P.).
Br. III. 3. 24; Vā. 66. 23.
text.13652:
Vaitaraṇī (I) — (Vaitaraṇam) one of twenty-eight hells.
Intended for the mad, and for those fallen from character
and conduct, those that spoil makha or devastate villages.
Bhā. V. 26. 7; Br. II. 28. 83; IV. 2. 149-171; M. 141. 69; Vā. 56.
78; 101. 148, 169; Vi. II. 6. 3 and 24.
text.13653:
Vaitaraṇī (II) — a R. in hell. For transgressing law and
convention one gets drowned in this river of refuse and
urine, etc.
Bhā. II. 2. 7; V. 26. 22; VII. 9. 43.
text.13654:
Vaitaraṇī (III) — a R. from the Vindhyas; fit for Śrād
dha offerings;1 a deva nadī; gift of a cow here secures release
for twenty-one generations.2 1) Br. II. 16. 33; III. 13. 103; M. 114. 27; Vā. 45. 102; 77. 95.
2) Vā. 105. 44; 108. 80; 109. 17; 112. 26.
text.13655:
Vaitasena — a name of Purūravas.
Bhā. XI. 26. 35.
text.13656:
Vaitāna — a portion of Atharva Samhitā.
Br. II. 35. 61; Vā. 61. 53.
text.13657:
Vaitānikas — the name of planets in the Vaivasvata
epoch.
Br. II. 24. 87, 111.
text.13658:
Vaitāla (I) — a pupil of Jātūkarṇya.
Bhā. XII. 6. 58.
text.13660:
Vaitālika — a pupil of Śākapūrṇa.
Vi. III. 4. 24.
text.13662:
Vaidarbha — a southern country; a tribe;1 on the other
side of the Vindhyas.2 1) Br. II. 16. 58; M. 114. 47; Vā. 45. 126.
2) Ib. 45. 133.
text.13663:
Vaidarbhā — a R. sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 22. 64.
text.13664:
Vaidarbhī — a name of Rukmiṇī.
Bhā. X. 52. 16-17.
text.13665:
Vaidikas — on the other side of the Vindhyas.
Vā. 45. 133.
text.13667:
Vaidiśa — the capital of Bhūtinanda ?
Br. III. 74. 182.
text.13668:
Vaidiśakas — the kings after Vindhyaśakti.
Br. III. 74. 179; Vā. 99. 366.
text.13669:
Vaidiśas — a Vindhyan tribe.
Br. II. 16. 64; M. 114. 53.
text.13670:
Vaidiśapuram — the city of Vidiśā where Puṣpavāhana
met Anangavatī in his previous birth.
M. 100. 14.
text.13671:
Vaidurikam — the nīti discourse of Vidura to Dhṛta
rāṣṭra.
Bhā. III. 1. 10-13.
text.13672:
Vaidūrya (I) — a Mt. on the base of Meru, and west of
Śitoda.
Bhā. V. 16. 26; Vā. 36. 27; 42. 50.
text.13673:
Vaidūrya (II) — an Asura of the Mahātalam.
Vā. 50. 35.
text.13676:
Vaidehyam — Subāhu and Śūrasena, son of Śatrughna.
Vā. 88. 186.
text.13677:
Vaidya (I) — a son of Varuṇa and Sunādevī; father of
Ghṛṇi and Muni, both of whom ate each other and died.
Br. III. 59. 6; Vā. 84. 6-8.
text.13679:
Vaidya (III) — the king's physician skilled in aṣṭāṅga;1
residence of.2 1) M. 215. 34.
2) Ib. 254. 26.
text.13681:
Vaidyaga — an Angirasa and mantrakṛt.
Br. II. 32. 107.
text.13682:
Vaidyanātham — a tīrtha sacred to Aroga and the Pitṛs.
M. 13. 41; 22. 24.
text.13683:
Vaidyuta (I) — a king of fire originating in waters, and
hence cannot be quenched by waters. (Pāvaka Agni); a son
of Brahmā.
Br. II. 12. 2; 24; 11; Vā. 29. 7; 51. 26; 53. 8.
text.13684:
Vaidyuta (II) — a son of Vapuṣmat after whom came
the kingdom Vaidyuta.
Br. II. 14. 32-4; 33. 29-30; Vi. II. 4. 23, 129.
text.13685:
Vaidyuta (III) — a Mt. in India.
Br. II. 16. 21; Vā. 45. 90; 47. 14.
text.13686:
Vaidyuta (IV) — Mt. near Kailāsa, noted for lake
Mānasa. It has the stream Sarayū and forest Vaibhrāja.
Here lives Prahati's son, being a follower of Kubera.
Br. II. 18. 14-16.
text.13687:
Vaidyuta (V) — a Daitya in the fifth talam.
Br. II. 20. 36.
text.13688:
Vaidyuta (VI) — a son of Sahiṣṇu, an avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 213.
text.13689:
Vaidyuta (VII) — a hill near Kakudman.
M. 121. 16; Vā. 47. 14.
text.13690:
Vaidyutam — a region of Śālmalidvīpa adjoining the hill
Kanka.
Br. II. 19. 45; Vā. 49. 40.
text.13691:
Vaidyutī — one of the three mātras of Om.
Vā. 20. 2.
text.13692:
Vaidhṛta — Indra of the eleventh epoch of Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 25.
text.13693:
Vaidhṛtā — the wife of Āryaka, and mother of Dharma
setu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 26.
text.13694:
Vaidhṛtis — sons of Vidhṛti. These were gods who trea
sured up the Vedas in their minds.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 29.
text.13695:
Vaidhṛtivāsara — a yugādi for śrāddha; fit for sixteen
kinds of gifts.
M. 17. 3; 274. 20.
text.13696:
Vaidheya — a pupil of Yājñavalkya.
Vā. 61. 24; Br. II. 35. 28.
text.13697:
Vaina — a pupil of Langākṣī.
Br. II. 35. 41, 45.
text.13698:
Vainateya — the Garuḍa;1 abode of, as tall as the Kailāsa
hills;2 city of, in the fourth talam or gabhastalam.3 1) M. 150. 214; Br. I. 1. 116; Vā. 1. 137.
2) M. 163. 67-8.
3) Br. II.
20. 34; III. 7. 229; Vā. 50. 33.
text.13700:
Vaināyakam (I) — a tīrtha sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 22. 32.
text.13701:
Vaināyakam (II) — the vrata in honour of Vināyaka;
gift of a golden elephant on Caturthi.
M. 101. 61.
text.13703:
Vainya (I) — see Pṛthu; a mantrakṛt;1 introduced yajña
in Vaivasvata epoch when Brahmā was Purohita.2 1) M. 145. 100; Vā. 1. 33; 59. 97.
2) Br. III. 73. 72-73.
text.13704:
Vainya (II) — a son of Vena (s.v.), got by ṛṣis from his
arms;1 story of, narrated in detail;2 milking of the earth by.3 1) Vā. 62. 94.
2) Ib. 62. 103-193.
3) Br. I. 1. 105.
text.13705:
Vainyas — a branch of the Bhārgavas.
Br. III. 1. 100.
text.13706:
Vaibhrāja (ka) (I) — a pleasure garden of gods;1 here
Yayāti enjoyed with Viśvācī.2 1) Bhā. V. 16. 14; Br. II. 18. 16; Vā. 36. 11.
2) Br. III. 7. 101;
Vā. 47. 16.
text.13707:
Vaibhrāja (II) — a Mt. of Plakṣadvīpa, the residence of
Bhrājiṣṇu;1 shining like quartzite (sphātika).2 1) Br. II. 19. 13; Vi. II. 4. 7.
2) Vā. 49. 12.
text.13708:
Vaibhrāja (III) — a forest in the Ketumālā continent
(on the west of Ilāvṛta).
M. 83. 33; 131. 48; Vi. II. 2. 25.
text.13709:
Vaibhrāja (IV) — a forest on the shore of the Sarayū
river.
M. 121. 17; Vā. 47. 15.
text.13710:
Vaimānikas — gods like Ādityas, Visvedevas, Sādhyas,
Pitṛs, sages like Angiras and so on at the beginning of
dāhakala;1 residents of tāra and gṛhas;2 at the commence
ment of Pralaya spring forth these gods, with planets and
stars, with no social restrictions of caste or orders; went to
Maharloka, Janaloka and lastly to Brahmaloka never to come
back; appointed by the creator in different stations.3 1) Br. IV. 2. 29; Vā. 7. 15.
2) Vā. 101. 31.
3) Br. II. 6. 16, 21.
text.13712:
Vairatha — a son of Jyotiṣmat after whom came the
Rathākāra kingdom (a part of the Kuśadvīpa).
Br. II. 14. 27; Vi. II. 4. 36.
text.13714:
Vairā — a R. sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 22. 64.
text.13715:
Vairāgyam — detachment and devotion to jñānam; leads
to purification of body and mind. One such person becomes
a nirmama.
Br. III. 4. 10; IV. 3. 45, 60; Vā. 57. 117; 102. 66, 82; 104. 15.
text.13716:
Vairāja (I) — father of Ajita Hari;1 a Lokapāla.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 5. 9.
2) Br. II. 21. 157; Vā. 50. 206.
text.13717:
Vairāja (II) — a Prajāpati, whose Pitṛs are formless.
M. 13. 3.
text.13718:
Vairāja (III) — same as Sudhāman;1 a son of Viraja, the
lord of Prācidik; a Lokapāla;2 married Śatarūpā whose sons
were Priyavrata and Uttānapāda and whose daughters were
Ākūtī and Prasūtī;3 grandfather of Cākṣuṣa Manu.4 1) M. 124. 95; Br. II. 11. 14.
2) Vā. 28. 11.
3) Br. II. 9. 39.
4) Vā.
62. 90.
text.13719:
Vairāja (IV) — the 27th kalpa;^1 (19th kalpa-Vā. P.);
the period of Vairāja Manu, son of the Creator.
M. 290. 10; Vā. 21. 40-2; Br. IV. 2. 65.
text.13721:
Vairāja (VI) — father of Nadvalā; a progenitor and
father-in-law of sixth Manu.
Vi. I. 13. 4.
text.13722:
Vairāja (VII) — also a vīrapuruṣa from whom was born
Śatarūpā and two sons Priyavrata and Uttānapāda as also
two daughters Ākūtī and Prasūtī.
Vā. 10. 15-7.
text.13723:
Vairājam (I) — got by tapas;1 a loka.2 1) M. 93. 133; 143. 33; Br. II. 30. 44; IV. 2. 60.
2) Ib. IV. 2. 141.
text.13727:
Vairājās (I) — the first gods created by Brahmā to
occupy the first worlds by name Samtānakas; among them
seven groups are distinguished, three formless and four with
form; then earth, rains, food, worship of moon for rice; the
formless attain absolution through yoga power;1 the three
formless groups are Pitṛs engaged in yoga;2 Ṛbhu and Sanat
kumāra come under this class; they attained Brahmaloka or
siddhi.3 1) Br. III. 9. 52-62; Vā. 71. 52.
2) Br. III. 10. 4.
3) Ib. IV. 2. 35, 70 ff.
text.13728:
Vairājās (II) — a class of formless Pitṛs: Fallen from
Yoga, they attain eternal worlds (lokān sanātanān) and are
reborn as Brahmavādins at the end of a day of Brahmā:
they then gain their old memory and by sānkhya and yoga
they attain final release. Their mind-born daughter Menā
is the wife of Himavān.
M. 13. 3-6.
text.13729:
Vairājās (III) — the Brahmans living in the Virajasa
world; this is said to be the first Kalpa of the Vairājās.
Vā. 72. 4; 101. 61-4.
text.13730:
Vairājyas — (see Vairājās): performers of austerities;
stand ten times until ābhūtasamplava, after Pralaya, enter
ing Praṇava aimed at Brahmaloka through Yogadharma
and attained the ānanda of Brahmā; six characteristics of;
deprived of three bhāvas (body, mind and speech) do not
regard dvandva (sukha duhkha, etc.); reach buddhāvasthā.
Vā. 101. 37, 71, 80, 81, 140.
text.13731:
Vairājyam — a Sūktam of the Sāma Samhitā to be recit
ed in the ritual associated with the digging of a tank.
M. 58. 36.
text.13732:
Vairiṇā — the daughter of Dakṣa so-called.
Br. I. 1. 112.
text.13733:
Vairiṇī — one of the wives of Dakṣa, mother of 1000 sons
and 60 daughters.
M. 5. 8; 146. 15.
text.13734:
Vairūpam — created from the west face of Brahmā.
Vi. I. 5. 55.
text.13735:
Vairūpya — a Sāma;1 from the face of Brahmā,2 helped
Supratīka elephant to get sārūpyam.3 1) Vā. 9. 51.
2) Br. II. 8. 52.
3) Ib. III. 7. 341.
text.13737:
Vailāṭasi — a crest on the Mahendra hill.
Br. III. 13. 18.
text.13738:
Vaivartajñānam — said to be the cause of nivṛtti.
Vā. 24. 83.
text.13740:
Vaivasa — a Pravara of the Bhārgavas.
M. 195. 39.
text.13741:
Vaivasvata (I) — Seventh Manu, see under Manu; epoch
of;1 a son of Brahmā from the seventh face;2 from Ṛkāra
Svara — the 7th face of the 14 faced god;3 eight devagaṇas
born of Mārīca and Kaśyapa;4 sons of, nine.5 The great Śrād
dhadeva.6 1) Bhā. I. 1. 109; 3. 15; Br. II. 13. 67; Vā. 21. 15; 62. 4; 64. 1-2;
98. 71.
2) Vā. 1. 127; 23. 114.
3) Ib. 21. 39; 26. 39; 31. 15.
4) Br. I.
1. 109; Vā. 64. 1-2.
5) Ib. 64. 29-30.
6) Vi. III. 1. 30-33.
text.13742:
Vaivasvata (antaram) (II) — the epoch of Vaivasvata
Manu in the Vārāha Kalpa; the seventh Manu; Atri and six
others are sages who re-establish dharma and reach the final
beatitude; here are seven devagaṇas, Sādhyas, Viśvas, Rud
rās, Maruts, Vasus, Aśvins and Ādityas. Ikṣvāku and 9 others
are the sons of Vaivasvata Manu; the reference is to the
present manvantara by the term sāmpratam;1 having ap
pointed Ilā, his eldest son, he went to Mahendravana for
penance;2 heard from the Matsya the end of kalpa and ruled
his territory; he belonged to the solar race; this is the current
epoch.3 1) M. 4. 17; 6. 3; 8. 12; 9. 26-30; 69. 6; 124. 22.
2) Ib. 11. 40-42.
3) Ib. 246. 72; 290. 24; Vi. III. 1. 7. 8.
text.13743:
Vaivasvata (III) — Yama, the God of death; overlord of
the Pitṛs;1 offering of piṇḍas in śrāddha to;2 resident of Sam
yamana.3 1) M. 174. 49; 213. 7; Vā. 70. 8; Vi. V. 21. 30.
2) Br. III. 8. 8;
11. 94; 12. 39; Vi. III. 15. 28.
3) Vā. 50. 88; 108. 30; 111. 39.
text.13744:
Vaivasvata (IV) — temple of, in Supakṣa hill.
Vā. 39. 63.
text.13745:
Vaivasvata (V) — the planet Śanaiścara with Prakṛti of
Rudra.
Vā. 53. 32.
text.13746:
Vaivasvata (VI) — a son of Samjña; learned and great;
antara of, constituting 28 yugas when rājaṛṣis rule at the end
of which a period of 40 yugas set in;1 offered the kingdom
of earth after the epoch of Cākṣuṣa Manu; the first Manu
had nine sons; finding at first that he could not create beings
he caused a sacrifice in honour of Mitra and Varuṇa out of
which came Iḍā or Ilā.2 1) Vā. 100. 56; 99. 435, 457-60; Vi. III. 2. 2.
2) Vā. 85. 1-7.
text.13747:
Vaiśa — also Vidarbha; the son of Saivyā and Jyāmagha
after the former's severe austerities; married Snuṣā; got two
sons and a third Lomapāda.
Vā. 95. 36.
text.13748:
Vaiśampāyana (I) — a pupil of Vyāsa in charge of the
Yajus; was taught Nigada (Yajurveda). His pupils were Ca
rakādhvaryus. Yājñavalkya was one of the pupils; was also a
Paurāṇika.1 A Śrutaṛṣi, divided the Yajur Veda into 86 parts
and distributed them among his 86 pupils;2 did not attend
the Meru conference and ordered his pupils to take to
Brahma vidyā.3 1) Bhā. I. 4. 21; XII. 6. 52 and 61; XII. 7. 5. Vā. 60. 13; 61. 5.
2) Br. II. 1. 13; 33. 5; 34. 13; 35. 8-9, 20-22.
3) Vā. 61. 14-16.
text.13749:
Vaiśampāyana (II) — a sage who was invited for the
Rājasūya of Yudhiṣṭhīra.
Bhā. X. 74. 8.
text.13750:
Vaiśampāyana (III) — the sage who cursed king Jana
mejaya; questioned by Śaunaka for light on rituals condu
cive to realisation of one's desires.
M. 50. 58; 93. 1; Vā. 99. 251.
text.13752:
Vaiśasa — the kingdom to which Puramjana went with
his companion Lubdhaka; allegorically Naraka.
Bhā. IV. 25. 53; 29. 15; V. 26. 25.
text.13753:
Vaiśākapūrṇimā — the full moon day of the Vaiśākha
month; good for gift of the Brāhma Purāṇa.
M. 53. 13.
text.13755:
Vaiśākha śukla dvādaśi — the 12th day of the bright half
of Vaiśākha, the day on which Uṣā dreamt of her future
husband.
Vi. V. 32. 14.
text.13756:
Vaiśākhī — one of the 13 wives of Vasudeva, the son of
Kauśika.
Vā. 96. 160, 172.
text.13757:
Vaiśākhya — a pupil of Parāśara Kauthuma.
Br. II. 35. 46.
text.13758:
Vaiśālī (I) — founded by king Viśāla.
Bhā. IX. 2. 33; Vā. 61. 46.
text.13759:
Vaiśālī (II) — one of Vasudeva's queens and mother of
Kauśika.
Br. III. 71. 174; Vi. IV. 15. 25.
text.13762:
Vaiśyas — created from the thighs of Brahmā; the less
powerful, but are engaged in agriculture and commerce;1 for
doing their svadharma they go to the abode of Vāyu.2 pro
pitiate Ājyapa Pitṛs;3 selling and buying, their duties;4 pro
tected by Yayāti;5 for the sake of 100 Vaiśyas one Brahman
may be killed;6 profession originated in the time of Pṛthu;7
meditate on Devī's 108 names;8 observe 15 days' pollution
for father's death;9 to be much in numbers in a State.10 1) Vā. 30. 232; 34. 17; 45. 83 and 117; 54. 111; 57. 52; 78. 29;
93. 66; 100. 246; 101. 5 and 352; 104. 13; Vi. I. 6. 6, 35.
2) Br. I. 5.
108; 7. 157, 166; Vi. III. 8. 30-31, 39.
3) Br. III. 10. 94; M. 15. 21.
4) Br. III. 15. 51.
5) Ib. III. 68. 67.
6) Ib. IV. 6. 43.
7) Ib. II. 37. 10.
8) M. 13. 63.
9) Ib. 18. 2.
10) Ib. 114. 12; 217. 2.
text.13764:
Vaiśrambhaka — a pleasure garden to which Kardama
and Devahūti went.
Bhā. III. 23. 40.
text.13765:
Vaiśravaṇa (I) — a Ṛṣika and a king who became sage
by satya.
Br. II. 32. 102; M. 145. 96; Vā. 59. 94.
text.13766:
Vaiśravaṇa (II) — served as calf when the Yakṣas milked
the earth;1 overlord of the Yakṣas and the Rākṣasas; the first
son of Viśravas and Davavarṇinī; seeing the Rākṣasa form
and asura prowess he got the name Kubera;2 defeated by
Kālanemi.3 1) Br. II. 36. 216; M. 10. 22.
2) Br. III. 8. 7, 40-46; M. 8. 3;
154. 338.
3) Ib. 174. 49; 177. 49.
text.13768:
Vaiśravaṇa (IV) — (Kubera: Kuśarīram beram); the
first son of Viśravas and Devavarṇinī; in form a Rākṣasa and
in strength an Asura; description of; three feet, big head,
eight teeth, yellow moustache, ears like śanku, short hands;
full of the knowledge of Vaivarta; and in the guise of Viśva
rūpa or various forms;1 the king of Yakṣas.2 1) Vā. 70. 35-40; Vi. I. 22. 3.
2) Vā. 30. 84-5; 41. 26; 62. 182;
70. 7.
text.13769:
Vaiśravaṇālaya — a tīrtha sacred to Nidhi.
M. 13. 51.
text.13770:
Vaiśvadeva (ka) (I) — Agni also known as Brāhmaṇa
chamsi.
Br. II. 12. 29; Vā. 62. 137.
text.13771:
Vaiśvadeva (II) — a muhūrta of the afternoon.
Br. III. 3. 39; Vā. 66. 40.
text.13772:
Vaiśvadeva (III) — is a homa, generally before the prin
cipal meals of the day;1 food to Vāstu follows this;2 done in
evenings also.3 1) Br. III. 14. 5; M. 16. 55; 17. 61; Vi. II. 15. 9; III. 11. 47-57.
2) M. 252. 17;
3) Vi. III. 11. 105; 15. 16 and 50.
text.13773:
Vaiśvadaiviki — the eighth day in the dark half of
Māgha.
Vā. 81. 3.
text.13774:
Vaiśvānara (I) — a name of Agni;1 to be propitiated by
eight oblations or Vaiśvadeva and five others. Prāṇa, apāna,
samāna, udāna and vyāna.2 1) Bhā. II. 2. 24.
2) Vā. 15. 3-8.
text.13775:
Vaiśvānara (II) — a son of Danu, and father of four
daughters, Upadānavī and others.
Bhā. VI. 6. 33; Br. III. 6. 7; Vā. 68. 7.
text.13776:
Vaiśvānara (III) — father of two daughters, Pulomā
and Kāla (li) kā who were married to Mārica; from them
74,000 Dānavas; lived in Hiraṇyapura; slain by Arjuna.
M. 6. 22; Vā. 68. 23-27.
text.13778:
Vaiśvānara (V) — a son of Bharatāgni.
Vā. 29. 8; Br. II. 12. 8.
text.13779:
Vaiśvānarapatha — outside it was Pitṛyāna.
Vi. II. 8. 85; Br. II. 21. 103, 159; M. 124. 80.
text.13780:
Vaiśvānaram — the Dakṣiṇasthānam, which has three
roads or vīthis.
Br. I. 2. 28; Vā. 45. 91; 50. 156; 66. 47, 52.
text.13781:
Vaiśvānaravratam — leads to the world of Brahmā.
M. 101. 57.
text.13784:
Vaiśvānari (vīthi) (III) — in Dakṣiṇa mārga; Mūlam
and Pūrvottarāṣāḍhas are the nakṣatras.
M. 124. 59; Vā. 66. 52.
text.13785:
Vaiṣuvatīgati — vernal equinox;1 day and night equal;
this viṣuvam takes place during the spring and autumn
when the sun enters the signs of Aries (Tulām) and Libra
(Meṣa).2 1) Vi. II. 8. 29.
2) Ib. II. 8. 65-7.
text.13786:
Vaiṣṭhiya — the place of Angāri Agni.
Br. II. 12. 30.
text.13787:
Vaiṣṇava — a muhūrta of the night.
Br. III. 3. 43; Vā. 66. 44.
text.13789:
Vaiṣṇavam (I) — the Purāṇa of 23,000 ślokas compiled
by Parāśara; he who copies this and makes a gift of it on
the āṣāḍha full moon day reaches the world of Varuṇa; gives
an account of Varāha kalpa.
M. 53. 16-17.
text.13790:
Vaiṣṇavam (II) — one of the six darśanas;1 the heart of
the personified Veda.2 1) Vā. 104. 16.
2) Ib. 104. 82.
text.13793:
Vaiṣṇavī (I) — a name of Yogamāyā;1 Sātvikī śakti;2 a
mind-born mother;3 makes the sun shine radiant.4 1) Bhā. X. 2. 11.
2) Br. IV. 19. 7; 36. 58; 44. 111; Vi. II. 11. 14.
3) M. 179. 11.
4) Vi. II. 11. 20.
text.13794:
Vaiṣṇavī (II) — a goddess among the mātṛs; Icon of,
after the manner of Viṣṇu; Garuḍa is the riding animal; four
hands in the varada pose.
M. 13. 52; 261. 28.
text.13795:
Vaihāyasa — an aerial car constructed by Maya.
Bhā. VIII. 10. 16.
text.13796:
Vaihāyasī — a R. in Bhārata varṣa.
Bhā. V. 19. 18.
text.13797:
Vaihāra — a Mt. in Bhārata varṣa.
Br. II. 16. 20; Vā. 45. 90.
text.13803:
Vyakta — the second form of Parabrahmam.
Vi. I. 2. 15, 18.
text.13804:
Vyaktam — the absolute, developed out of avyakta;1
swallowed by avyakta in the stage of Pratyāhara;2 of five
characteristics;3 seen by tarka and yoga as also by pratyā
hara, dhyāna and tapas.4 1) Vā. 101. 211.
2) Ib. 102. 2.
3) Ib. 34. 37.
4) Br. IV. 2. 115,
213; 3. 107-8; 4. 71.
text.13806:
Vyatīpāta — (of full moon) when the sun and moon look
at each other; when they stand equally at one point it is
Vyatīpāta day; it is reckoned to be Vaṣaṭkriyākāla;1 a
yugādi fit for śrāddha;2 inauspicious for building houses.3 1) Br. II. 28. 40-44; Vā. 56. 37-8.
2) M. 17. 3; 82. 25.
3) Ib. 83.
7; 141. 35; 253. 7.
text.13807:
Vyapohini — a special rite in the sacrifice.
Vā. 65. 56.
text.13809:
Vyavadhāraṇa kalpana — (ety.) one of the ten lakṣaṇas
of the Brāhmaṇas.
Vā. 59. 138.
text.13810:
Vyavasāya — a son of Vapu.
Vā. 10. 36; Br. II. 9. 61.
text.13812:
Vyaṣṭi — individuality as opposed to samaṣṭi or
Brahmam.
Vā. 3. 10.
text.13813:
Vyasanāni — the difficulties and dangers of a kingdom;
the king must avert them.
M. 220. 25.
text.13814:
Vyākaraṇa — Pāṇini's grammar.
Br. III. 19. 22; Vā. 83. 52; Vi. V. 1. 38.
text.13815:
Vyākhyāna vedikā — the place where sages expound
the Vedic lore.
Br. III. 21. 52.
text.13816:
Vyāghra (I) — a son of Yātudhāna and father of Nirā
nanda.
Br. III. 7. 89 and 96.
text.13817:
Vyāghra (II) — one of the five sons of Ūrddhvadṛṣṭi and
father of Śarabha.
Br. III. 7. 205.
text.13818:
Vyāghra (III) — the tiger, said to have eaten Garga's
cow;1 its skin, the dress of Śiva.2 1) M. 20. 10.
2) Ib. 217. 5; 259. 6.
text.13819:
Vyāghra (IV) — a snake with the sun in Āvaṇi and
Puraṭṭāśi.
Vā. 52. 11.
text.13821:
Vyāghra (VI) — the Rākṣasa residing in the sun's chariot
in the Bhādrapada month.
Vi. II. 10. 10.
text.13822:
Vyāghra (VII) — the Rākṣasa presiding over the month
of Nabhasya.
Bhā. XII. 11. 38; Br. II. 23. 11.
text.13823:
Vyāghras — born of Hari and Pulaha; a vānarajāti and
son of Jāmbavān;1 could be killed as wild animals.2 1) Br. III. 7. 176, 304, 319; 51. 9.
2) Ib. IV. 6. 50; 29. 41.
text.13825:
Vyāghrī — wife of Jāmbavat; mother of Jāmbavatī.
Br. III. 7. 301.
text.13826:
Vyāja — a son of Bhṛgu; a deva.
Br. III. 1. 89.
text.13827:
Vyādha — a hunter who attained permanent fame.
Bhā. X. 72. 21.
text.13832:
Vyāna (II) — a mind-born son of Brahmā in the 21st
Kalpa.
Vā. 21. 47; 31. 41.
text.13833:
Vyāpaka — all pervadingness from apavarga; from that
comes Puruṣa.
Vā. 13. 23.
text.13835:
Vyāpṛta — a god of Sutāra group.
Br. IV. 1. 90.
text.13836:
Vyāpṛtha — one of the ten branches of the Supāra group
of devas.
Vā. 100. 94.
text.13837:
Vyāla — from the hairs of the head of Prajāpati. ety. ahi,
the vilest of creatures; Pannaga. ety. creeping on the ground;
sarpa, from escaping or fleeting nature; all have their abode
in the earth under the sun and moon; out of anger came viṣa
or poison; then airy beings were created; cūṭas, piśācas from
eating flesh, Gandharvas sucking cows.
Vā. 9. 34-40.
text.13839:
Vyāsa (I) — an amśāvatāra of Viṣṇu; also known as Dvai
pāyana and Kṛṣṇa; son of Parāśara and Vāsavī (Satyavatī)
in Dvāpara yuga. Father of Śuka; appointed by his mother,
he begot three sons on his brother's wife being childless
Dhṛtarāṣṭra, Pāṇḍu and Vidura.1 Rearranged the Vedas
into four parts, and taught each of them to four respective
pupils — Paila, Vaiśampāyana, Jaimini and Sumantu. Re
arranged Itihāsa-Purāṇas also; composed the Bhārata for
Strīśūdra-dvijabandhus; composed also the Bhāgavata and
taught it to his son Śuka, having heard it from Nārada.2
When he felt a mental dissatisfaction, Nārada met him and
was praised. Asked as to the reason for his uneasiness,
Nārada emphasised devotion to Hari as the means of release
and proceeded to narrate the story of his previous birth.
When the sage left Vyāsa retired to his hermitage Śamyā
prāsa on the Sarasvatī and meditated on the Lord who
appeared before him with māyā depending on him. Learnt
devotion as the means of ending samsāra.3 One of Yudhiṣ
ṭhira's party on a visit to Bhīṣma; was a Purohita at Kṛṣṇa's
sacrifice at Kurukṣetra; told the history of Citraketu to Śuka
who bowed to him.4 Heard Śrutigītā from Nārāyaṇa. Faith in
Kriyāyoga; a siddha.5 Taught Lomaharṣaṇa about the future
of the world and its history.6 An incarnation of the Lord in
every dvāpara;7 took a vow of silence and fasting for 12 years
after which he wandered for food but could not get any in
Benares; when he was about to curse the city, Śiva and Umā
took the guise of householders and offered him rich food. So
he blessed it.8 A tīrtha in his honour.9 1) Bhā. I. 2. 4; 4. 14-15; IX. 22. 22-25; XII. 6. 36; III. 5. 19-20;
M. 15. 8; 180. 64; Br. III. 10. 79-80; 13. 77.
2) Bhā. XII. 6. 49-53;
I. 4. 16-25; 7. 1-8; II. 9. 44; III. 5. 10 and 12; XII. 4. 42; 13. 19;
Br. I. 1. 25; II. 31. 28; 33. 32-3; 34. 11-12; III. 17. 295.
3) Bhā. I. 4.
30-33; chh. 5 and 6 (whole); 7. 1-4;
4) Ib. I. 8. 46; 9. 2; X. 90. 46[2];
VI. 14. 9; VII. 1. 5.
5) Ib. X. 87. 47-8; XI. 27. 2; VI. 15. 12.
6) M. 50.
72.
7) Ib. 53. 9.
8) Ib. 185. 17-38.
9) Ib. 191. 41; 203. 14.
text.13840:
Vyāsa (II) — a sage of the eighth manvantara.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 15; Vi. III. 2. 17.
text.13841:
Vyāsa tīrtham — near Dṛṣadvati;1 in Dīpeśvara, a tīrtham
of the Narmadā sacred to Vyāsa.2 1) Br. III. 13. 69, 80.
2) M. 191. 38-42.
text.13842:
Vyāsa saras — the sacred lake near Śiva lake.
Br. III. 13. 52; Vā. 77. 51.
text.13843:
Vyāhṛtis — daughters of Savitā;1 three in number.2 1) Bhā. VI. 18. 1; III. 12. 44.
2) Vā. 64. 19.
text.13844:
Vyucchinna Pratisandhi — complete extermination be
tween one kalpa and the next one, while the sandhis or con
nections between the manvantaras or yugas is not broken
(avyucchinna sandhi).
Vā. 7. 8-9.
text.13845:
Vyuṣitāśva — a son of Śankhaṇa and father of Viśva
saha.
Br. III. 63. 206.
text.13846:
Vyuṣṭa (I) — a son of Doṣā and Puṣpārṇa; wife Puṣka
riṇī and son Sarvatejas.
Bhā. IV. 13. 14.
text.13847:
Vyuṣṭa (II) — a son of Vibhāvasu, and a Vasu.
Bhā. VI. 6. 16.
text.13848:
Vyuṣṭi — one of the ten branches of the Rohita clan of
devas.
Vā. 100. 91.
text.13850:
Vyoma (I) — a son of Daśārha, and father of Jīmūta.
Bhā. IX. 24. 3-4; Br. III. 70. 41; M. 44. 40; Vā. 95. 40; Vi. IV.
12. 41.
text.13851:
Vyoma (II) — a son of Maya and follower of Kamsa,
came to Vraja in the guise of a Gopa, and mixed in a game
with Gopas. Removed a good number of them to a cave near
by. Finding the numbers reduced, Kṛṣṇa spotted out the
mischievous foe and killed him on the spot.
Bhā. X. 37. 28-32.
text.13852:
Vyoma (III) — one of the ten horses of the moon's
chariot.
Br. II. 23. 57.
text.13853:
Vyoma (IV) — the intervening space between heaven
and earth.
M. 2. 32.
text.13854:
Vyomacāriṇī — the goddess from the back portion of
Nṛsimha; follower of Vāgiśī.
M. 179. 68.
text.13855:
Vyomamṛga — a horse of the moon's chariot.
M. 126. 52.
text.13857:
Vyomī — a horse of the moon's chariot.
Vā. 52. 53.
text.13859:
Vraja (II) — (Gokulam) the residence of cowherds.1
Here lived Rohiṇī, Nanda and others. Keśin was killed in
this place. Visit of Akrūra to. Nanda's return to Vraja
after Kamsa's death. Visited by Uddhava at Kṛṣṇa's
request. Visited by Balarāma.2 Deserted by the cowherds
after their supposed ill omens, the boy sports of Kṛṣṇa.3 1) Vi. V. 5. 11.
2) Bhā. IX. 24. 66; X. 1. 9; 2. 7; 5. 6 and 18;
37. 1 [1]; 38. 1 and 24, 28; 45. 25; 46. 3 and 7; 47. 9 and 55; 65. 1.
3) Vi. V. 6. 27; 7. 8.
text.13860:
Vrajakas — a Janapada of the Bhadrā continent.
Vā. 43. 19.
text.13863:
Vrajājinau — sons of Ūru and Āgneyī.
Br. II. 36. 108.
text.13864:
Vrata (I) — a son of Cākṣuṣa Manu.
Bhā. IV. 13. 16.
text.13865:
Vrata (II) — a god of the Ābhūtaraya group.
Br. II. 36. 56.
text.13868:
Vratinī — a daughter of Bhangakāra and queen of Kṛṣṇa.
M. 45. 21.
text.13870:
Vrateyu — a son of Raudrāśva.
Bhā. IX. 20. 4.
text.13872:
Vrātapati — a son of Śakrajit and a great warrior.
Vā. 96. 53.
text.13873:
Vrātinī — a second daughter of Bhangakāra given to
Kṛṣṇa in marriage.
Vā. 96. 55.
text.13874:
Vrātyas — a stage devoid of varṇa and āśrama conduct;1
the rule of, in the south and north.2 1) Br. III. 48. 47.
2) Vi. IV. 24. 68-69.
text.13875:
V (B) rindāvanam — the Gopas immigrated to this forest
region from Vraja to avoid omens that threatened that place.
Vi. V. 6. 24 ff; 16. 1.
text.13876:
Vrīhi — a kind of paddy.
Br. II. 7. 144; M. 34. 11; 239. 22; Vā. 93. 96.
text.13878:
Śaka (II) — the tree after which the Śākadvīpa takes its
name.
Br. II. 19. 94, 140.
text.13879:
Śaka (III) — a son of Bṛhadratha Maurya, ruled for
36 years; his grandson ruled for 17 years. (?)
M. 272. 24.
text.13880:
Śakas (I) — a hill tribe;1 were defeated by Paraśurāma,
Sagara and Bharata; punished with half shaving;2 were
denied the Vedic study and sacrifice and hence reduced to
Mlecchahood.3 1) Br. II. 16. 67; III. 48. 23, 44 and 49; Vā. 88. 122; 98. 107.
2) Bhā. IX. 8. 5; 20. 30; III. 41. 39; Vi. IV. 3. 42;
3) Ib. IV. 3. 48.
text.13881:
Śakas (II) — the 18 kings (ten-Vā. P.) of, ruled for 380
years;1 kingdom of;2 contemporaries of the Śiśunāgas, and
after Gardabins; to be conquered by Kalki.3 1) M. 50. 76; 273. 18; Vā. 99. 268, 324, 359, 361.
2) M. 114. 41;
121. 45; 144. 57.
3) Br. III. 63. 120, 134; 73. 108; 74. 137. 172 and
175; Vi. IV. 3. 47.
text.13882:
Śakaṭa — (cart) upturned by Kṛṣṇa as a baby. (Taken
generally to be an Asura)1 of Nanda, apparently his waggon
or cart, which was then a means of transport.2 1) Bhā. X. 7. 7-10; Br. IV. 29. 124.
2) Vi. V. 5. 1 and 6: 5. 22;
6. 1 and 23 ff; 15. 2.
text.13885:
Śakavarṇa — a son of Śiśunāka; ruled for 36 years; con
quered Girivraja.
Vā. 99. 315, 316.
text.13886:
Śakuna (i) (I) — an Asura follower of Hiraṇyakaśipu,
and a son of Hiraṇyākṣa.
Bhā. VII. 2. 5 and 18; Br. III. 5. 30; M. 6. 14; Vā. 67. 67; Vi.
I. 21. 3.
text.13888:
Śakunajñānam — the science of birds, etc;1 in connec
tion with founding temples.2 1) M. 215. 9;
2) Ib. 240. 15; 264. 9.
text.13889:
Śakuni (I) — (saubala) a prince of Gāndhāra and an
evil adviser to Duryodhana; joined him in insulting Vidura;
attacked the northern gate of Mathurā, and the eastern gate
of Gomanta when they were besieged by Jarāsandha.
Bhā. III. 1. 14; 3. 13; VII. 2. 18; X. 50. 11 [7]; 52. 11. [6].
text.13890:
Śakuni (II) — father of Asura Vṛka; took part in the
Devāsura war between Bali and Indra.
Bhā. VIII. 10. 20; X. 88. 14.
text.13891:
Śakuni (III) — a son of (Ekā) Daśaratha and father of
Karambhi (aka).
Bhā. IX. 24. 4-5; Br. III. 70. 44; Vā. 95. 43; Vi. IV. 12. 41.
text.13892:
Śakuni (IV) — a son of Vikukṣi.
Br. III. 63. 9.
text.13893:
Śakuni (V) — a son of Sanadvāja; father of Svāgata.
Br. III. 64. 20.
text.13895:
Śakuni (VII) — a son of Dṛḍharatha and father of
Karambha.
M. 44. 42.
text.13896:
Śakuni (VIII) — had 500 brothers who were rulers of
Uttarāpathadeśa; of these 48 had sovereignty over the south;
all sons of Ikṣvāku.
Vā. 88. 9.
text.13898:
Śakunī (I) — a daughter of Bali.
Br. III. 5. 43; Vā. 67. 84.
text.13899:
Śakunī (II) — the wife of Nāka.
Br. III. 59. 13; Vā. 84. 13.
text.13901:
Śakuntalā — the daughter of Viśvāmitra and Menakā;
was brought up in Kaṇva's āśrama with nīvāra food; Duṣ
yanta who came there was entertained and was accepted as
her Lord by Gāndharva vidhi. Gave birth to the future
Bharata and came to the king's palace with the child; was
refused admission by the king who had forgotten her. A
voice in the air urged the king to accept her and he did
so;1 a queen of Duṣyanta and mother of Bharata.2 1) Bhā. IX. 20. 8-22 [1-2]; M. 49. 11; Cā. 99. 134.
2) Vi. IV.
19. 12-13.
text.13902:
Śaktas — a devagaṇa, mind-born sons of Brahmā, in the
Svāyambhuva epoch.
Br. II. 13. 90.
text.13903:
Śakti (I) — (Śaktri-Br. P.) the eldest of the 100 sons of
Vasiṣṭha and Arundhatī. Father of Parāśara through Adṛ
śyanti;1 a sage by tapas; a Vedavyāsa. Heard the Vāyu
Purāṇa from Dakṣa and narrated it to Parāśara in embryo;2 a
resident of Brahmakṣetra;3 cursed king Kalmāṣapāda in
Naimiṣa.4 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 41; Br. I. 1. 9; III. 8. 91; 36. 6; M. 201. 30;
Vā. 1. 174; 70. 83.
2) Br. II. 32; 99 and 115; 35. 124; IV. 4. 65;
M. 196. 26; Vā. 103. 65.
3) Vā. 59. 91, 105.
4) Ib. 2. 10-11.
text.13904:
Śakti (II) — the principle identified with Śiva;1 urges
creation by Brahmā.2 1) Bhā. IV. 6. 43.
2) Vi. I. 5. 47.
text.13905:
Śakti (III) — as a daughter of Vasiṣṭha and Arundhatī.
Br. I. 2. 10.
text.13906:
Śakti (IV) — (Parāśakti): the Goddess as potency in all
creatures; by worshipping her in any manner one gets sal
vation;1 by worshipping her Śiva became Ardhanārīśvara; as
also other Gods like Brahmā; known as Tripurā;2 mind-born
daughter of Brahmā by name Prakṛti; was born during
the course of the churning of the ocean; known
also as Bhagavatī and Māyā; angry at not getting
a share in the yajña of Yuvanāśva but appeased by
Brahmā that she may be propitiated with paśu offer
ings.3 A number of Śaktis mounted on cuckoos, swans,
mungooses followed Lalitā's army.4 1) M. 13. 53.
2) Br. IV. 5. 29.
3) Ib. IV. 6. 6, 53, 67.
4) Ib. IV.
17. 23.
text.13907:
Śakti (V) — the tula or balance of scale, addressed as.
M. 274. 59.
text.13908:
Śakti (VI) — the name of Vyāsa in the 25th (27th-Vi. P.)
Dvāpara; Muṇḍīśvara avatār of the lord.
Vā. 23. 208; Vi. III. 3. 18.
text.13911:
Śakti (IX) — the wife of Gods generally.
Vā. 106. 59.
text.13912:
Śakti (X) — of Viṣṇu; is Pradhāna puruṣātmaka; this
energy separates at the deluge and unites at the time of
creation;1 something like fire in wood or oil in sesamum;
from Pradhāna germinate intellect and rudiments of things
and from them Asuras;2 Pradhāna compared to a tree; Viṣṇu
is mūla-prakṛti or the primary nature in whom all beings
exist and all finally immerse;3 is three-fold made up of the
three energies of Hari.4 1) Vi. II. 7. 31-2.
2) Ib. II. 7. 33-9.
3) Ib. II. 7. 42-3.
4) Ib. VI.
8. 7.
text.13913:
Śakti (XI) — of Guha, created by Viśvakarma from the
Vaiṣṇava effulgence of Sūrya.
Vi. III. 2-12.
text.13914:
Śaktimārga — leads all to prosperity and heaven irres
pective of caste or sex.
Br. IV. 43. 79-81.
text.13916:
Śaktivardhana — (Śakti); a sage by tapas; a Brahma
vādin.
M. 145. 93, 109.
text.13919:
Śakra (I) — (Śatakratu) a son of Aditi, and surname of
Indra (s.v.); his brother Upendra;1 deceived Rāji accepting
him to be his son in the first instance and finally contrived
to oust him from Indrahood.2 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 39; 10. 18; Br. II. 6. 11; Vā. 30. 95, 109; 61.
30; 96. 196; 97. 23.
2) Vā. 92. 88.
text.13923:
Śakra (V) — Indra;1 attended on Diti and cut the embryo
in seven parts and later into forty-nine pieces; these are the
Maruts;2 city of Vaśankasāra;3 joined Bṛhaspati in the Tāra
kāmaya;4 father of Arjuna.5 1) Vi. V. 11. 1; 29. 1; 30. 4 and 26; 34. 1.
2) Ib. I. 21. 33, 40.
3) Ib. II. 8. 9.
4) Ib. IV. 6. 16.
5) Ib. IV. 20. 40.
text.13925:
Śakrak (m) ośāntaram — a distance equal to 1000
yojanas.
Br. IV. 2. 127; Vā. 101. 127.
text.13926:
Śakrajit (I) — a son of Nighna; to him the sun was a
great companion; once he visited him and wanted to see his
form; for this the sun handed over Syamantaka the best of
gems wearing which he saw his form distinctly; it was so
beautiful that he desired to keep the gem himself to which
the sun agreed; then he returned to his city with the jewel;
he shone like the sun himself and entered the harem to the
wonderment of his people.1 Śakrajit received back the maṇi
from Vāsudeva; he had 100 sons by his ten wives; of these
three were famous, Bhangakāra, Vratapati and Apasvān.2 1) Vā. 96. 20-9.
2) Vā. 96. 50, 53.
text.13928:
Śakratīrtham — on the southern bank of the Narmadā;
sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 191. 20; 22. 73.
text.13931:
Śakramaha — (Śakrapūja) a festival in honour of Indra;1
being the Lord of rains he was expected to shower seasonal
rains.2 1) Vi. V. 10. 18 and 25.
2) Ib. V. 10. 23.
text.13933:
Śaṃkamāna — a son of Pravīra, the King of the Mahiṣas.
Br. III. 74. 187.
text.13934:
Śaṃkara (I) — a name of Śiva; four kalās of;1 also Śam
bhu, Umāpati, Sūlapāṇi, Vṛṣabhadhvaja and Hara; fight of,
with Kṛṣṇa for Bāṇa; bound by Jṛmbāstra he became dis
abled; asked Kṛṣṇa to spare the life of Bāṇa.2 Also (Śaṃ
kara) — an epithet of Mahādeva;3 the āśrama of;4 approached
Vāsudeva to aid him to put down the Asura Andhakas;5
remembered Nṛsimha to vanquish the mātṛgaṇa.6 1) Bhā. II. 4. 19; Br. II. 9. 90; 13. 62; IV. 35. 97; Vā. 21. 10; 24.
62. 43. 38; 54. 48; 112. 35; Vi. I. 9. 2; V. 34. 29.
2) Ib. V. 32. 8;
33. 21.
3) M. 154. 235.
4) Ib. 154. 381.
5) Ib. 154. 437, 514; 179. 35.
6) Ib. 179. 54; 180. 20.
text.13935:
Śaṃkara (II) — a son of Danu.
Vi. I. 21. 4.
text.13938:
Śaṃkarī — the devī; became twins in the 26th kalpa.
Vā. 21. 59.
text.13939:
Śaṃku (I) — a son of Ugrasena;1 a follower of Bali.2 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 24; Br. III. 71. 33; M. 44. 74; Vi. IV. 14. 20.
2) M. 245. 31.
text.13940:
Śaṃku (II) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Satyā.
Bhā. X. 61. 13.
text.13941:
Śaṃku (III) — a son of Ūrjā and Vasiṣṭha.
Br. II. 11. 42.
text.13943:
Śaṃkukarṇa (I) — the Asura in Tatvalam (Atalam
Vā. P.);1 one of Danu's sons.2 1) Br. II. 20. 16; III. 6. 4; Vā. 50. 16.
2) Ib. 68. 4.
text.13944:
Śaṃkukarṇa (II) — (Vighneśvara); informed Maheś
vara of the medicinal tank of waters created by Maya.
Br. IV. 44. 66; M. 136. 48, 51.
text.13946:
Śaṃkukarṇam — a place sacred to Śiva.
M. 181. 27.
text.13948:
Śaṃkukūṭa — (Śankhakūṭa) a Mt. north of the Mahā
bhadra lake.
Vā. 36. 31; 42. 65.
text.13952:
Śaṃkuśiras — a son of Danu; a follower of Vṛtra in his
battle with Indra; joined Bali in the Devāsura battle.
Bhā. VI. 6. 30; 10. 19; VIII. 10. 21; Vi. I. 21. 4.
text.13954:
Śaṅkoddhāra — a tīrtha sacred to Dhvani and the Pitṛs.
M. 13. 48; 22. 69.
text.13955:
Śaṃkha (I) — a mountain on the base of Meru.
Bhā. V. 16. 26.
text.13956:
Śaṃkha (II) — an eminent Nāga of Pātāla;1 a Kādraveya
nāga;2 a thousand-hooded snake.3 1) Bhā. V. 24. 31; Vā. 69. 70.
2) Br. III. 7. 34.
3) M. 6. 39.
text.13957:
Śaṃkha (III) — to be killed by Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 37. 16.
text.13958:
Śaṃkha (IV) — a mind-born son of Jaigīṣavya and Eka
pāṭalā; attained heaven by tapas.
Br. II. 30. 40; Vā. 72. 19.
text.13959:
Śaṃkha (V) — a Yakṣa; a son of Puṇyajanī and Maṇi
bhadra.
Br. III. 7. 123.
text.13960:
Śaṃkha (VI) — one of the eight nidhis of Kubera.
Vā. 41. 10.
text.13961:
Śaṃkha (VII) — the conch of Viṣṇu;1 in Rāma's abhi
ṣeka;2 sounded by Kṛṣṇa on the eve of his battle with Indra.3
Was invoked to protect the baby Kṛṣṇa.4 Blowing of it indi
cated Kṛṣṇa's arrival in Ānarta; was a sign of auspiciousness;5
one of the gifts to please the planet moon;6 war music in the
Tārakāmaya war;7 discovered at the confluence of the Tām
raparṇī and the ocean with pearls.8 1) Vi. IV. 15. 3.
2) Ib. IV. 4. 100.
3) Ib. V. 30. 56.
4) Bhā. X.
6. 23.
5) Ib. I. 11. 1 and 18.
6) M. 57. 21; 93. 60.
7) Ib. 135. 83;
136. 53; 138. 3; 149. 2; 174. 16; 177. 24; 192. 28.
8) Vā. 77. 25.
text.13962:
Śaṃkhakūṭa — Mt. a hill range on the north of Meru.
Vi. II. 2. 30.
text.13964:
Śaṃkhacūḍa (I) — a chief Nāga of pātāla.
Bhā. V. 24. 31; Br. IV. 33. 36.
text.13965:
Śaṃkhacūḍa (II) — a follower of Kubera. He seized
certain gopis whom Kṛṣṇa recovered. He was pursued and
his head cut off. His cūḍāmaṇi was presented to Balarāma.
Bhā. X. 34. 25-32.
text.13966:
Śaṃkhaṇa — a son of Vajranābha and father of Vyuṣi
tāśva.
Br. III. 63. 205-6; Vā. 88. 205.
text.13967:
Śaṃkhadvīpam — a region of Jambudvīpa; here is Eka
rājyam or rule by one, of Mlecchas; here is the hill Śankha
giri from which flows the Śankhanāgā river; the residence
of Śankhamukha, the king of Nāgas.
Vā. 48. 14, 31-3.
text.13968:
Śaṃkhanāgā — a R. in the Śankhadvīpam.
Vā. 48. 33.
text.13969:
Śaṃkhapada — a son of Kardama Prajāpati and Śruti
anointed king of the south;1 lord of the south direction;2
attained heaven by tapas;3 a Ṛṣika who became ṛṣi by satya.4 1) Br. III. 8. 19; Vā. 28. 19; Vi. I. 22. 12.
2) M. 8. 10; Vā. 28.
27-29; Br. II. 11. 22 and 33.
3) M. 143. 38.
4) Ib. 145. 96.
text.13970:
Śaṃkhapadma — Royal symbols in the arms of a cakra
vartin.
Br. II. 29. 86; Vā. 57. 79.
text.13971:
Śaṃkhapāt (I) — a disciple of Lokākṣi, an avatār of the
Lord;1 a Rājaṛṣi.2 1) Vā. 23. 135.
2) Ib. 57. 122.
text.13972:
Śaṃkhapāt (II) — a son of Kardama, and Lokapāla of
the Lokāloka hill.
Vi. II. 8. 83.
text.13973:
Śaṃkhapāla — the Nāga presiding over the month
of Nabhasya;1 a 1000 hooded snake; lives with the sun for a
part of a year;2 with the sun in Āvaṇi and Puraṭṭāśi;3 with
the sun in the Bhādrapada month.4 1) Bhā. XII. 11. 38; Br. II. 23. 9; IV. 20. 54.
2) M. 6. 40; 126. 10.
3) Vā. 52. 10.
4) Vi. II. 10. 10.
text.13975:
Śaṃkhamukha — the king of the Nāgas in Śankhadvīpa.
Vā. 48. 33.
text.13977:
Śaṃkhā — the city of the second talam.
Vā. 50. 21.
text.13978:
Śaṃkhākhya — a daitya in Sutalam.
Br. II. 20. 22.
text.13979:
Śaṃkhākhyas — a Janapada of the Bhadrā continent.
Vā. 43. 22.
text.13980:
Śaṃkhini — a śakti on the fourth parvan of the Kiri
cakra.
Br. IV. 20. 15; 44. 60; M. 286. 10.
text.13981:
Śaṃkhinī — the Goddess from the back portion of
Nṛsimha; follower of Vāgīśī.
M. 179. 23. 68.
text.13982:
Śaṅga — a sage of the epoch of Auttama Manu
M. 9. 14.
text.13983:
Śacī — a daughter of Puloma, consort of Indra and
mother of Jayanta.
Br. II. 13. 79; III 6. 23; M. 6. 21; Vā. 68. 22, 24.
text.13985:
Śacīpati — Indra;1 adhidevata for Śukragraham;2 see
Indra. 1) Vi. I. 9. 7; V. 21. 16; 34. 24.
2) Br. III. 67. 95; M. 93. 14;
251. 4.
text.13987:
Śaṭha — went with Kṛṣṇa to Upaplāvya to see the Pāṇ
ḍavas;1 a son of Vasudeva and Rohiṇī; father of several sons.2 1) Bhā. X. 78. [95 (V) 3].
2) Br. III. 71. 164, 169-70; Vi. IV.
15 19.
text.13989:
Śaṇḍa (I) — a son of Śukra and a tutor of Prahlāda;
reported with Marka to Hiraṇyakaśipu of their inability to
bring the boy to his way of thinking and advised him to keep
him in custody until Śukra's arrival.
Bhā. VII. 5. 1-2, 48-50; Br. III. 1. 78; Vā. 65. 77.
text.13990:
Śaṇḍa (II) — a Kūṣmāṇḍa Piśāca, one of the two sons
of Kapi; father of Brahmadhāmā.
Br. III. 7. 74-84.
text.13991:
Śaṇḍa (III) — an Asura; seen in the bathing ceremony
of the sacrifice of the gods;1 one of the disciples of Śukra
given to the Asuras to guide them; but he was bought off
by the gods by giving him a place in sacrifices.2 1) M. 47. 41, 54.
2) Ib. 47. 224-36.
text.13994:
Śatakesara — a boundary hill of Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 26.
text.13995:
Śatakratu (I) — a name of Indra;1 killed the pupils of
Sukarma for adhyaya during anadhyaya.2 1) Bhā. IV. 19. 2; Br. II. 24. 38; Vā. 91. 63; Vi. I. 9. 134;
V. 10. 19.
2) Vā. 61. 29.
text.13996:
Śatakratu (II) — the name of Vyāsa in the 7th dvāpara;
his original name, Vibhu; the avatār of the lord Jaigiṣavya.
Vā. 23. 135.
text.13997:
Śatakratu (III) — Nara, a brother of Ādityas.
Vā. 66. 61.
text.14000:
Śataguṇa — a son of Krodhā and a devagandharva.
Br. III. 6. 39.
text.14002:
Śataghna — a son of Upamadgu.
Vi. IV. 14. 9.
text.14003:
Śatajit (I) — one of the hundred sons of Viraja.
Bhā. V. 15. 15.
text.14004:
Śatajit (II) — a son of Sahasrajit (Sahasraji-M. P., Saha
rajit-Vā. P.) and father of Mahāhaya and two other sons,
(three famous sons, Haihaya, Haya and Veṇuhaya, Vi. P.
and M. P.);1 a king.2 1) Bhā. IX. 23. 21; M. 43. 7-8; Vā. 94. 3-4; Vi. IV. 11. 6-7.
2) Br. III. 69. 3.
text.14005:
Śatajit (III) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Jāmbavatī (Sudevī ?);1
got killed in Prabhāsā.2 1) Bhā. X. 61. 11; Br. III. 71. 25.
2) Bhā. XI. 30. 17.
text.14006:
Śatajit (IV) — the Yakṣa presiding over the month of
Iṣa.
Bhā. XII. 11. 43.
text.14007:
Śatajit (V) — a son of Rajas; had a hundred sons, all
kings and responsible for world's progress;1 Viṣvagjyoti, the
chief among them, held the whole of Bhāratavarṣa with
credit and success; his descendants continued to the Vārāha
kalpa.2 1) Br. II. 14. 70-72; Vā. 33. 60; Vi. II. 1. 40.
2) Ib. II. 1. 41-3.
text.14008:
Śatajit (VI) — a son of Upavātyaka.
Br. III. 71. 5.
text.14009:
Śatajit (VII) — one of the two sons of Sudevī and Viṣ
vaksena.
Vā. 96. 242.
text.14010:
Śatajit (VIII) — a son of Bhajamāna.
Vi. IV. 13. 2.
text.14011:
Śatatejas — the name of Vyāsa in the 12th dvāpara;
avatār of the Lord as Atri.
Vā. 23. 154.
text.14012:
Śatadaṃṣṭra — a son of Khaśā and a Rākṣasa.
Br. III. 7. 135; Vā. 69. 167.
text.14013:
Śatadundubhi (I) — a son of Bāṣkala.
Br. III. 5. 38-9.
text.14015:
Śatadṛkśakra — Indra of 1000 eyes; adopts Yoganidrā as
his sister.
Vi. V. 1. 81.
text.14016:
Śatadyumna (I) — a son of Bhānumat and father of
Śucī.
Bhā. IX. 13. 21-22; Vi. IV. 5. 30.
text.14017:
Śatadyumna (II) — a son of Cākṣuṣa Manu and Nāḍvalā.
Br. II. 36. 79, 106; M. 4. 41; Vā. 62. 91; Vi. I. 13. 5; III. 1. 29.
text.14018:
Śatadrī — a R. in Bhāratavarṣa, flows from the Himā
layas.
Bhā. V. 19. 18; Br. II. 12. 15; 16. 25; Vā. 45. 95; Vi. II. 3. 10;
III. 14. 18.
text.14019:
Śatadru — in the chariot of Tripurāri.
M. 114. 21; 133. 23.
text.14020:
Śatadrutī — a queen of Barhiṣat; Agni fell in love with
her.
Bhā. IV. 24. 11.
text.14021:
Śatadrusalilam — (Śatadru): a tīrtha sacred to Pitṛs;
one of the sixteen rivers married to Havyavāhana.
M. 22. 12; 51. 14.
text.14023:
Śatadhanus (I) — a son of Hṛdīka.
Bhā. IX. 24. 27; Vi. IV. 14. 24.
text.14024:
Śatadhanus (II) — a son of Devavarman Maurya.
Br. III. 74. 148.
text.14025:
Śatadhanus (III) — a king of yore; his wife Śaivyā, a
woman of piety; both worshipped Janārdhana; after fasting on
the Kārttika full moon day and bath in the Bhāgīrathī, they
met a heretic, a friend of the king's military preceptor; he talk
ed to him but she looked at the sun; soon the king died and she
ascended the funeral pyre; for the sin of talking to a heretic
he was born as a dog in Vidiśa and his wife as a daughter
of the king of Kāśī; she had a knowledge of her former birth
and accepted the dog for her husband; when the dog remem
bered his former condition, he fell dead in a forest and was
born as a jackal in the Kolāhala hill; the daughter of the king
of Kāśī repaired to the mountain when he remembered his
previous birth and was born as a wolf; again the daughter
of the king of Kāśī met him; remembering his former state
he was born as a vulture, crow and a peacock; when she
bathed him during the sacrificial bath of Janaka he was born
as the son of Janaka. Then a svayamvara was held, she
married him, lived as his queen and attained heaven. See
Śaivyā.
Vi. III. 18. 53-95.
text.14026:
Śatadhanvan (I) — the wicked; of the race of Bhojas,
and king of Mithilā; set up Akrūra and Kṛtavarman who
were displeased with Satrājita for not giving his daughter in
marriage to them; Śatadhanvan killed Satrājita while asleep,
and walked away with the jewel; when Kṛṣṇa heard of this
from Satyabhāmā, he came back to Dvārakā from Hāstina
pura to kill Śatadhanvan. Knowing this, the latter requested
Kṛtavarman and Akrūra for help and they refused; placing
the jewel under Akrūra's custody he rode one hundred
yojanas and on reaching Mithilā, his horse fell tired. Then
he ran on foot pursued by Kṛṣṇa. Kṛṣṇa got his head cut off
but found no jewel. His death was known in Dvārakā;
knew the yoga power of Hari.
Bhā. X. ch. 57 (whole); 58. 9 [4]; II. 7. 44; Vā. 96. 56-74; Vi.
IV. 13. 67-100.
text.14027:
Śatadhanvan (II) — the son of Somaśarman and father
of Bṛhadratha.
Bhā. XII. 1. 15; Vi. IV. 24. 30-1.
text.14028:
Śatadhanvan (III) — the fifth son of Hṛdīka;1 the middle
(second ?) among the ten sons of Hṛdīka;2 performed sau
bhāgyaśayanam.3 1) Br. III. 71. 140; Vā. 96. 139.
2) M. 44. 81.
3) Ib. 60. 49.
text.14029:
Śatadhanvan (IV) — a Maurya king, ruled for six years.
M. 272. 23.
text.14030:
Śatadhanvan (V) — a son of Pracetas; overlord of nume
rous Mlecchas of the north.
Vi. IV. 17. 5.
text.14031:
Śatadhara — a son of Devavarma, ruled for eight years.
Vā. 99. 335.
text.14032:
Śatadhṛti (I) — a name of Indra.
Bhā. IX. 10. 34.
text.14033:
Śatadhṛti (II) — a name of Brahmā.
Bhā. XI. 4. 5.
text.14034:
Śatadhvaja (I) — of Dāśārṇas; was stationed by Jarā
sandha on the west of Gomanta fort during its siege.
Bhā. X. 52. 11[12].
text.14035:
Śatadhvaja (II) — a son of Ūrja and father of Kṛti.
Vi. IV. 5. 31.
text.14038:
Śatabalā — a daughter of Śāraṇa.
Br. III. 71. 169; Vā. 96. 167.
text.14039:
Śatabalāka — a pupil of Rathītara.
Br. II. 35. 4.
text.14044:
Śatamanyu — a name of Indra.
Bhā. I. 8. 6.
text.14046:
Śataratha — a son of Mūlaka.
Br. III. 63. 180; Vā. 88. 180.
text.14047:
Śatarudras — a class of Rudras fit to receive oblations at
sacrifices.
Vā. 10. 59; 30. 244.
text.14048:
Śatarudrīyam — a portion of the Vedic (Yajus) litera
ture except which the Trayī exists until the pralaya;1 here
the Rudras partake of the offerings;2 sacred to pitṛs;3 Citra
karma, the Gaṇeśvara taught this to Madana;4 japa at Benares
leads one to eternal beatitude;5 identified with Śiva.6 1) Vā. 59. 57.
2) Br. II. 9. 84.
3) M. 22. 35.
4) Br. II. 32. 63; IV.
7. 49; 11. 30-33; 34. 52.
5) M. 184. 56.
6) Vā. 30. 244.
text.14049:
Śatarūpa — a son of Sutāra, the lord of the II dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 121.
text.14050:
Śatarūpā (I) — the female half of Brahmā's body — spread
over all the worlds; performed austerities for a lakh of years
and became queen of Svāyambhuva Manu as Rati; gave mar
riage presents to her daughter Devahūtī; mother of three
daughters,1 and of sons Priyavrata and Uttānapāda;2 a tapas
vinī.3 1) Bhā. III. 12. 54; 21. 26; 22. 23; IV. 1. 1; 8. 7; VIII. 1. 7; XI.
16. 25; Vā. 10. 8-13; 57. 57; Br. II. 9. 15 and 33.
2) Ib. II. 1. 57; II.
29. 62-3.
3) Vi I. 7. 17.
text.14051:
Śatarūpā (II) — daughter of Brahmā whom the father
married and brought forth Svāyambhuva Manu; other sons,
seven in number.
M. 3. 31, 43; 4. 24-5.
text.14052:
Śatavalśa — the mythical banyan tree on the mount
Kumuda. From its joints flow rivers capable of fulfilling all
desires in Ilāvṛta.
Bhā. V. 16. 24-25.
text.14053:
Śataśa(i)lāka — the father of Jaigīṣavya who married
Ekapāṭala.
Br. III. 10. 20; Vā. 72. 18.
text.14054:
Śataśṛṃga — a Mt. in Śālmalidvīpa;1 north of the Mahā
bhadra, has 100 cities.2 1) Bhā. V. 20. 10; Br. III. 7. 453.
2) Vā. 36. 32; 39. 54; 42. 69.
text.14055:
Śatasaṃkhyā — a group of gods of the X epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 25.
text.14056:
Śatasena — a son of Śāntasena.
Bhā. X. 90. 38.
text.14058:
Śatahradā — a R. of the Bhadrā continent.
Vā. 43. 26.
text.14059:
Śatājit — a son of Bhajamāna.
Bhā. IX. 24. 8.
text.14060:
Śatānanda (I) — a son of Ahalyā and Gautama, (Śarad
vān-M. P.). Father of Satyadhṛti.
Bhā. IX. 21. 34-35; M. 50. 8; Vi. IV. 19. 63.
text.14061:
Śatānanda (II) — came to see Kṛṣṇa at Syamanta
pañcaka.
Bhā. X. 84. 3.
text.14062:
Śatānanda (III) — a sage of the period of Sāvarṇi.
M. 9. 32.
text.14063:
Śatānanda (IV) — a son of Śāradvata, a great seer.
Vā. 99. 202.
text.14065:
Śatānīka (I) — a son of Nakula and Draupadī.
Bhā. IX. 22. 29; M. 50. 53.
text.14066:
Śatānīka (II) — a son of Janamejaya, versed in Trayī,
and a pupil of Yājñavalkya, and also of Śaunaka; learnt the
science of arms from Kṛpa; father of Sahasrānīka (Aśvame
dhadatta-Vi. P.);1 performed Aśvamedha;2 asked Śaunaka
about Yayāti and his reply;3 anointed by Brahmans;4 realis
ed ātmajñāna from Śaunaka and attained nirvāṇa.5 1) Bhā. IX. 22. 38-39.
2) M. 50. 65-6.
3) Ib. 25. 3.
4) Vā. 99. 256.
5) Vi. IV. 21. 3-5.
text.14067:
Śatānīka (III) — a son of Sudāsa and father of Durda
mana.
Bhā. IX. 22. 43.
text.14068:
Śatānīka (IV) — a son of the second Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 72.
text.14070:
Śatānīka (VI) — a son of Bṛhadratha.
Vi. IV. 21. 14.
text.14072:
Śatāyu (I) — a Rākṣasa with the Hemanta sun.
Br. II. 23. 19.
text.14073:
Śatāyu (II) — one of the six sons of Purūravas and
Ūrvaśī.
M. 24. 34; Vā. 91. 52; Vi. IV. 7. 1
text.14074:
Śatāhvā — a tīrtha sacred to the pitṛs.
M. 22. 35.
text.14076:
Śatrughna (I) — a son of Daśaratha; bore the bow and
quivers when Bharata carried the Pādukā. Father of
Subāhu and Śrutasena (Sūrasena-Vi. P.); killed the Rākṣa
sas Mādhava and Lavaṇa; seized Madhuvana and founded
the city, Mathurā.
Bhā. IX. 10. 3 and 44; 11. 13-14; Br. III. 63. 185; 71. 111;
Vā. 88. 184-5; Vi. I. 12. 4; IV. 4. 87. 101, 104.
text.14077:
Śatrughna (II) — a son of Śvaphalka.
Bhā. IX. 24. 17.
text.14078:
Śatrughna (III) — a son of Bhangakāra and Narā; killed
by Akrūra.
Br. III. 71. 86-8; Vā. 96. 85.
text.14080:
Śatrughna (V) — a son of Aikṣvākī and Anādhṛṣṭi.
M. 46. 24.
text.14082:
Śatrughna (VII) — the great-grandson of Sātvata, killed
by the Bhojas.
Vi. IV. 13. 111.
text.14085:
Śatrujit (III) — a son of Śūra.
Br. III, 71. 138.
text.14088:
Śatrujit (VI) — a name of Pratardana.
Vi. IV. 8. 12.
text.14089:
Śadhīya — a pupil of Kṛta.
Br. II. 35. 53.
text.14090:
Śanatkumāra — a son of Anala;1 sacred to Kurukṣetra;2
discovered yoga;3 attended Soma's rājasūya.4 1) Vā. 66. 24; 101. 26, 37, 75, 212; 105. 2; 112. 68.
2) Ib. 77. 64.
3) Ib. 83. 84.
4) Ib. 90. 23.
text.14091:
Śani — a son of Vivasvat and Chāyā; attained the status
of a planet by penance; see Śanaiścara.
M. 11. 9 and 38.
text.14092:
Sanaiścara (I) — (Saturn) Śrutakarma, traverses each
sign of the zodiac in thirty months — generally an evil
planet.1 A son of Chāyā and Vivasvat (Mārtāṇḍa-Vi. P.);2
fought with Naraka in the Devāsura war;3 fed by the svarāṭ
ray of the sun; above the Bṛhaspati planet; goes on in an iron
chariot.4 One of the nine grahas;5 found on the side of Soma;6
rise of, reddish in colour, a bad omen;7 stands above Bṛhas
pati;8 in the chariot of Tripurārī;9 chariot of, drawn by
horses.10 1) Bhā. V. 22. 16.
2) Ib. VI. 6. 41; VIII. 13. 10; Br. II. 24. 50, 71,
83, etc; III. 59. 32, 49, 82; Vā. 84. 31; Vi. I. 8. 11; III. 2. 4.
3) Bhā.
VIII. 10. 33.
4) Br. III. 23. 87; IV. 2. 133.
5) M. 93. 44; Vā. 84. 83.
6) M. 23. 40.
7) Ib. 133. 21.
8) Vā. 101. 133.
9) M. 127. 8; 128. 49;
133. 21.
10) Vā. 52. 79; 53. 32; Vi. II. 12. 20.
text.14093:
Śanaiścara (II) — a son of Rudra and Suvarcalā.
Vā. 27. 49; Br. II. 10. 76; 11. 23.
text.14095:
Śaṃtanu — a son of Pratīpa and a brother of Devāpī;
was a great king learned and a specialist in medicine (mahā
bhiṣak); it is said that a touch of his hand cured people of
any disease and made them youthful again; hence his
name Śamtanu; married Jāhnavī; father of Devavrata
(Bhīṣma); from the dark fisherwoman he got Vicitravīrya.
Another son was Citrāngada; a Paurava with an amśa of
Samudra.1 Came upon the twins of Satyadhṛti, in the
course of a hunting, Kṛpa and Kṛpi and took them by grace;
greed for more territory.2 1) Bhā. IX. 22. 12-21; XII. 2. 37; Br. III. 10. 69, 70; M. 14, 17;
50. 11, 39. 45; Vā. 73. 18; 99. 234, 237-41; 111. 70; Vi. IV. 20. 9. 34.
2) Bhā. IX. 21. 36; XII. 3. 10; Vā. 1. 158; 99. 204; Vi. IV. 19. 67-8.
text.14096:
Śapharī — the form taken by Harī.
Bhā. VIII. 24. 9.
text.14098:
Śabaras — an inferior class of people;1 on the Himālayas;
their country unfit for śrāddha performance; to be conquered
by Kalki;2 kings of.3 1) Bhā. II. 7. 46; M. 114. 47; Vā. 78. 69; 99. 268.
2) Br. III. 14.
80; 22. 22; 73. 108; IV. 29. 131.
3) M. 50. 76.
text.14099:
Śabala (I) — a son of Sarama.
Br. III. 7. 312.
text.14100:
Śabala (II) — a hell, reached by those who indulge in
unrighteous sexual unions
Br. IV. 2. 147, 158; Vā. 101. 146, 157.
text.14101:
Śabala (III) — one of the two dogs of the family of Vai
vasvata to whom Bali is to be offered at Gayā.
Vā. 108. 30; 111. 39.
text.14103:
Śabalas (II) — the 1000 sons of Dakṣa through Vairiṇī
who died in the attempt to get at the measurement of the
earth by following their elder brothers.
M. 5. 9.
text.14104:
Śabalāśvas — the second one thousand sons of Asiknī
and Dakṣa. Advised by Nārada they took to the path of
‘Not returning’, taken by their elder brothers; went to differ
ent parts of the world in search of their brothers, Haryaśvas
and were lost.
Bhā. VI. 5. 24; Br. III. 2. 24-5; Vā. 65. 152-4; Vi. I. 15. 97-100.
text.14106:
Śabdabrahmā — the name of the Creator during Brāhma
kalpa; possesses both vyakta and avyakta forms; two forms
of spirit; the word and the supreme God; this is the inter
pretation of Manu, and also the Atharva Veda; the word is
the Vedas as distinguished from and leading to Parabrah
man (Supreme).
Bhā. III. 11. 34; 12. 48; Vā. 104. 94, 110; Vi. VI. 5. 64-5.
text.14107:
Śabdam — the guṇa of ākāśa; swallowed by Bhūta and
others.
Vā. 102. 17.
text.14110:
Śama (I) — a son of Dharmasūtra and father of Dyumat
sena.
Bhā. IX. 22. 48.
text.14111:
Śama (II) — a son of Kriyā.
Br. II. 9. 60.
text.14112:
Śama (III) — a son of Āyu.
Br. III. 3. 24.
text.14114:
Śama (V) — the regulation of senses on one's own
account and on account of others.
Vā. 59. 47.
text.14117:
Śamṛtha — a kingdom of the west watered by the
Sindhu.
Br. II. 18. 48.
text.14119:
Śami (I) — a son of Uśīnara.
Bhā. IX. 23. 3.
text.14120:
Śami (II) — a son of Śoṇāśva (Śūra-Br. P.) and father
of Pratikṣatra.
M. 44. 79-80; Br. III. 71. 138.
text.14121:
Śami (III) — a son of the daughter of the Kāśi king and
Satyaka.
Vā. 96. 115.
text.14124:
Śamī (I) — a son of Śūra, and father of Pratikṣatra.
Vā. 96. 137; Vi. IV. 14. 23.
text.14125:
Samī (II) — the principal tree of the Kali age.
Vi. VI. 1. 53.
text.14126:
Śamīka (I) — a son of Devamīḍha and Māriṣā; queen
Sudāminī; father of Sumitra and other sons.
Bhā. IX. 24. 29 and 44.
text.14127:
Śamīka (II) — a son of Śūra and Bhoja, and father of
four sons; became a Rājaṛṣi.
Br. III. 71. 150, 194; M. 46. 3, 27, 28.
text.14129:
Śamba — a Dānava with manuṣya dharma.
Vā. 68. 15.
text.14130:
Śambara (I) — a son of Danu, and a follower of Vṛtra
in his battle with Indra.
Bhā. VI. 6. 30; 10. 19 [3]; M. 6. 17; 249. 67; Vā. 68. 11; 98.
81; Vi. I. 19. 14; 21. 4.
text.14131:
Śambara (II) — a son of Hiraṇyākṣa;1 a Dānava king;
taken to Pātāla with Bali by Vāmana;2 guiles of, towards
Prahlāda at the instance of Hiraṇyakaśipu.3 1) Bhā. VII. 2. 4 and 18; Br. III. 5. 30.
2) Ib. III. 6. 4 and 11;
IV. 29. 123; 73. 81.
3) Vi. I. 15. 153; 16. 9.
text.14132:
Śambara (III) — a resident of Tripura; participated in
the Devāsura war between Bali and Indra; fought with
Tvaṣṭri.
Bhā. VIII. 6. 31; 10. 19 and 29.
text.14133:
Śambara (IV) — a companion of Kamsa; walked away
with child Pradyumna within ten days [six days (Vi. P.)]
of its birth. He knew that the baby was his enemy but he
threw it into the sea and went away. Māyāvatī, the super
intendent of his kitchen discovered a child in a fish brought
to the kitchen, and hearing from Nārada that it was Kāma
reborn, and that she herself was Ratī, she brought up the
child and when he came of age, she told him the truth and
asked him to fight Śambara with the aid of mahāmāyā vidyā.
His head was cut off by Pradyumna.
Bhā. X. 36. 36; 55. 3. 24; II. 7. 34; III. 3. 11; Vi. V. 26. 12;
Ch. 27 (whole).
text.14134:
Śambara (V) — (Śabara-Bhā. P.); his greed for more
territory.
Bhā. XII. 3. 11.
text.14135:
Śambhalagrāma — (Śambala-Bhā. P.); the birth place of
Kalki-Viṣṇu.
Bhā. XII. 2. 18; Vi. IV. 24. 98.
text.14136:
Śambhu (I) — the Indra of the epoch of the Tenth Manu,
and a friend of Viṣvaksena.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 22-23.
