text.14750:
Śailarājasutā — resides in Jyotiṣka on Meru with Śiva,
and worshipped by all.
Vā. 30. 83.
text.14751:
Śailaśriśikhara — a Mt. on the south of the Mānasa lake.
Vā. 36. 22.
text.14753:
Śailūja — a Mt. in the Gajāśilā.
Vā. 108. 48.
text.14755:
Śailoda(kā) — takes its source in the lake Śailodam;
enters western sea between Cakṣu and Sītā.
M. 121. 23; Vā. 47. 21.
text.14756:
Śailodam — lake, giving rise to R. Silodā in the Aruṇa
hill; at the foot of the Varuṇa hill.
Br. II. 18. 21. 22; M. 121. 22; Vā. 47. 20.
text.14757:
Śaiva — the sin of being of an ardent type.
Br. IV. 8. 44.
text.14758:
Śaivam (I) — one day of Śiva equals 100 years of
Brahmā.
M. 290. 21.
text.14759:
Śaivam (II) — one of the six darśanas.
Vā. 104. 16.
text.14760:
Śaivam (III) — in the Sīmantasīma of the personified
Veda.
Vā. 104. 81.
text.14761:
Śaivālinī — a R. of the Bhadrā continent.
Vā. 43. 29.
text.14762:
Śaiveya — a Rākṣasa clan, following Śiva.
Br. III. 7. 141; Vā. 69. 172.
text.14763:
Śaiveyas — one of the Vidyādhara ganas.
Vā. 69. 29.
text.14764:
Śaivyā — a devī and wife of Kṛṣṇa.
Vā. 96. 234.
text.14765:
Śaiśavam — a sūktam of the Sāma samhitā to be recited
in tank ritual.
M. 58. 36.
text.14767:
Śaiśira (II) — a Kāśyapa and a Trayārṣeya.
M. 199. 12.
text.14770:
Śaiśireya (I) — a pupil of Śākalya.
Br. II. 35. 2.
text.14773:
Śaiśitas — a Janapada of the Maṇidhānya.
Vā. 99. 384.
text.14774:
Śaiśumāracakra — the topmost region where Hari is
the presiding deity — see Śiśumāra.
Bhā. II. 2. 24; Br. II. 22. 6.
text.14775:
Śoka (I) — a son of Droṇa and a Vasu.
Bhā. VI. 6. 11.
text.14779:
Śoṇa (I) — one of the 7 pralaya clouds.
M. 2. 8.
text.14780:
Śoṇa (II) — a R. from the Ṛṣyavān.
M. 114. 25; 163. 62; Vā. 45. 99.
text.14781:
Śoṇaka — in the Cyavana āśrama of Gayā.
Vā. 108. 74.
text.14782:
Śoṇasamgama — a tīrtha sacred to Subhadrā.
M. 13. 45.
text.14783:
Śoṇā — a R. from the Ṛkṣa hill in Bhāratavarṣa, visited
by Balarāma;1 sacred to Pitṛs.2 1) Bhā. V. 19. 18; X. 79. 11; Br. II. 16. 29.
2) M. 22. 35.
text.14784:
Śoṇāśva — a son of Rājādhideva; had five sons, all heroic
warriors.
M. 44. 78-9.
text.14785:
Śoṇita — a son of Śūra.
Br. III. 71. 138; Vā. 96. 136.
text.14786:
Śoṇitapura — built by Maya at the command of Bhaṇḍa;
a city of Bāṇa; visit of Jarāsandha to: Aniruddha taken to;
besieged by the Vṛṣṇis when Bāṇa had imprisoned Anirud
dha, and Nārada reported it to them. Bāṇa's army beaten
back into the city.
Br. IV. 12. 4; Bhā. X. [5. (v) 1], [21 & 65]; 62. 4 and 23;
63. 2-4; Vi. V. 33. 11.
text.14787:
Śobhayanta — a clan of Apsaras from Kāma.
Vā. 69. 58.
text.14788:
Śobhayantis — one of the fourteen gaṇas of apsaras
born of Kāma.
Br. III. 7. 20.
text.14789:
Śobhavatis — an Apsarasa gaṇa, daughters of Marut.
Br. III. 7. 18.
text.14791:
Śoṣaṇa — to be worshipped in house-building.
M. 253. 26.
text.14792:
Śoṣiṇī — a śakti on the Geya cakra.
Br. IV. 19. 65.
text.14794:
Śaukram — the place of Śukra in the maṇḍalam.
Vā. 53. 60.
text.14795:
Śauklāyani — (Saulkāyani-Bhā. P.); a pupil of Veda
darśa.
Bhā. XII. 7. 2.
text.14796:
Śaṃkhaṇa — a son of Vajranābha, and father of Yuṣi
tāśva.
Vi. IV. 4. 106.
text.14798:
Śaucam (I) — the vidhi in a śrāddham; other aspects of
śauca; touching dogs; human bones aśauca; pollution of
death to Brahmans 10 days, Kṣatriyas 12 days, Vaiśyas
15 days, and Śūdras one month; ācamanam is śaucam; dis
regard of, leads to mlecchahood; three kinds of.
Br. III. 14. 62-70.
text.14800:
Śaucācāram — characteristics of yogins; udaka or water
important; then māna which is amṛta and avamāna which
is poison; service to guru for one year with niyama and
yama; then wandering about on clean roads, drinking filtered
clean water and speaking truthful words and begging food
especially from Śālina householders.
Vā. 16. 1-14; 78. 76.
text.14801:
Śauṇḍa — the goldsmith artist in the service of the cour
tesan Līlāvatī; he helped her in making the Lavaṇācala dāna
without wages and consequently was born as Dharmamūrti,
king of Bṛhatkalpa.
M. 92. 24.
text.14802:
Śaunaka (I) — a son of Śunaka; a great sage of the Ṛg
Veda school. A kulapati; addressed Sūta as to the circum
stances of the composition of the Bhāgavata Purāṇa;1 had his
residence in Naimiṣālaya; taught knowledge of astra and
kriyā to Śatānīka;2 a pupil of Pathya; divided the Atharva
Samhitā between his two disciples Babhra and Saindhavā
yana.3 A Kṣatropetadvija; four castes were formed under
him;4 a mantrakṛt and a madhyamādhvaryu;5 asked Vai
śampāyana for a śānti ritual;6 initiated Śatānīka into ātma
jñāna.7 1) Bhā. IX. 17. 3; I. 1. 4; 4. 1-13; M. 1. 5; Vā. 93. 24.
2) Bhā. XII. 4.
43; IX. 22. 38; M. 25. 3; 43. 1-2; Vā. 104. 19; 106. 39.
3) Br. II. 35.
59-60; Vā. 61. 52-3; Vi. III. 6. 11-12.
4) Br. III. 67. 4. 66. 88;
Vā. 92. 4-5.
5) Br. II. 32. 106; M. 145. 100; 244. 3.
6) Ib. 93. 1.
7) Vi. IV. 21. 4.
text.14804:
Śaunaka (III) — one of the eighteen teachers of the
Vāstu śāstra.
M. 252. 3.
text.14805:
Śaunaka (IV) — a son of Gṛtasamada; a propagator of
varṇa dharma.
Vi. IV. 8. 6.
text.14806:
Śaunakas — a branch of the Bhārgavas; Kṣatropeta
dvijas.
Br. III. 1. 100; 67. 6; Vā. 92. 6.
text.14809:
Śaura — a name for Śuci Agni.
Vā. 29. 2.
text.14811:
Śauriṣu — a sage of much tapas.
Br. II. 35. 43.
text.14812:
Śaurpāraka — a tīrtha in Phālamañjira hill.
Br. III. 13. 37.
text.14813:
Śaulkāyaṇi — a pupil of Devadarśa.
Br. II. 35. 58 Vi. III. 6. 11.
text.14815:
Śmaśānam — the burning ground; the name of Avi
mukta; those who regard Benares as such will be deluding
themselves; those who die there attain release.
M. 184. 5, 19-21, 63.
text.14816:
Śmaśāna vāsin — an attribute of Śiva.
Br. II. 27. 79.
text.14818:
Śyamika — a brother of Vasudeva.
Vi. IV, 14. 30.
text.14820:
Śyāma (I) — Mt. a hill of the Śākadvīpa; here people are
of Śyāma colour.
Br. II. 19. 88; M. 122. 12; Vā. 49. 82; Vi. II. 4. 62.
text.14821:
Śyāma (II) — a son of Sarama.
Br. III. 7. 312.
text.14822:
Śyāma (III) — a son of Śūra and Bhojā; had no son.
Br. III. 71. 150, 194; M. 46. 3.
text.14823:
Śyāma (IV) — a son of Śamika; had no issue;1 adopted
as son the son of Vastāvana; went to the forest; became
Bhoja and a Rājaṛṣi.2 1) M. 46. 27-8.
2) Vā. 96. 190.
text.14824:
Śyāma (V) — a brother of Vasudeva.
Vā. 96. 148 Vi. IV. 14. 30.
text.14825:
Śyāma (VI) — one of the two dogs of the family of Vai
vasvata to whom bali is to be offered in yajña.
Vā. 108. 30; 111. 39.
text.14826:
Śyāmaka — a son of Devamīḍha and Māriṣā; married
Śūrabhū and had two sons, Harikeśa and Hiraṇyākṣa.
Bhā. IX. 24. 29 and 42.
text.14830:
Śyāmas (II) — belonging to the Dattātreya gotra.
Vā. 70. 77.
text.14832:
Śyāmā (I) — a daughter of Meru and wife of Hiraṇ
maya.
Bhā. V. 2. 23.
text.14833:
Śyāmā (II) — a name of Lalitā; appeared before the sage
Mātanga and agreed to be his daughter. Hence Mātangī.
Br. IV. 17. 83; 28. 37; 31. 84, 93.
text.14835:
Śyāmā (IV) — a R. of the Ketumālā continent.
Vā. 44. 17.
text.14838:
Śyāmāyana — of Kauśika gotra.
Br. III. 66. 72; M. 196. 46; 198. 4.
text.14839:
Śyāmāyani (I) — the chief author of Yajurveda, of the
northern recension.
Br. II. 35. 12.
text.14841:
Śyāmāyani (III) — a chief of the Udīcyas.
Vā. 61. 8.
text.14842:
Śyāmāvān — a mantrakāra and an Ātreya.
Vā. 59. 104.
text.14844:
Śyāla — ridiculed Garga as impotent in an assembly of
the Yādavas.
Vi. V. 23. 1.
text.14845:
Śyāvāśva — of Ātreya gotra and a sage.
Br. II. 32. 113; M. 197. 5.
text.14847:
Śyenas — eagles, born of Syenī;1 of the Tāmara line.2 1) M. 6. 31.
2) Vi. I. 21. 16.
text.14848:
Śyenajit — the Senāni with the Śarat Sun.
Br. II. 23. 14.
text.14849:
Śyenabhadra — a god of Prasūta group.
Br. II. 36. 70; Vā. 62. 60.
text.14850:
Śyenā — a R. of the Ṛkṣa hill.
Br. II. 16. 30.
text.14851:
Śyenābhicāra — intended to bring one under control, to
root out the enemy, etc.
M. 93. 152.
text.14852:
Śyenī (I) — a daughter of Tāmrā and Kaśyapa; married
Gautamān; and mother of kururas, sārasa cranes, hawks,
etc.
M. 6. 30-31; Vi. I. 21. 15-16.
text.14853:
Śyenī (II) — a R. from the Ṛṣyavān.
M. 114. 25.
text.14854:
Śyenī (III) — the wife of Aruṇa and mother of Sam
pāti and Jaṭāyu.
Vā. 69. 325-26.
text.14855:
Śraddhā (I) — a daughter of Kardama married to An
girasa. Mother of four daughters — Sinīvālī, Kuhū, Rākā
and Anumatī and sons Utathya and Bṛhaspati.
Bhā. III. 24. 22; IV. 1. 34 and 35.
text.14856:
Śraddhā (II) — a daughter of Dakṣa and wife of
Dharma; mother of Śubha and Kāma.
Bhā. IV. 1. 49-50; Br. II. 9. 49 and 58; Vā. 10. 25, 35; Vi. I.
7. 23 and 28.
text.14857:
Śraddhā (III) — a wife of Śrāddhadeva and mother of
ten sons; observed payovrata and wanted the birth of a
daughter. Ilā was born.
Bhā. IX. 1. 11, 14-16.
text.14858:
Śraddhā(devī) (IV) — one of the wives of Vasudeva
and mother of Gaveṣavān.
M. 46. 20.
text.14859:
Śrama (I) — a son of Śāntideva and Vasudeva.
Bhā. IX. 24. 50.
text.14860:
Śrama (II) — a son of Āpa.
Vi. I. 15. 111.
text.14861:
Śramaṇa — a sage; nine sons of Ṛṣabha became this.
Bhā. V. 3. 20; XI. 2. 20.
text.14863:
Śramiṣṭa — a son of Aśvinī and Akrūra.
M. 45. 33.
text.14865:
Śravaṇa (I) — the constellation;1 importance of Śrāddha
that day.2 1) Bhā. IV. 12. 48; Vā. 50. 127; 53. 116; 66. 51; 82. 11.
2) Br.
III. 18. 11.
text.14866:
Śravaṇa (II) — a son of Mura.
Bhā. X. 59. 12.
text.14867:
Śravaṇa (III) — a son of Aśvinī and Akrūra.
M. 45. 33.
text.14868:
Śravaṇas — a Janapada of the Ketumālā.
Vā. 44. 15.
text.14869:
Śravaṇā — a daughter of Citraka.
Br. III. 71. 115; Vā. 96. 114.
text.14872:
Śraviṣṭha — the best among the stars.
Br. II. 24. 140; Vā. 53. 112, 116.
text.14873:
Śraviṣṭhaka — a son of Gautama, an avatār of the 14th
dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 164.
text.14874:
Śraviṣṭhā — a daughter of Citraka.
Br. III. 71. 115; Vā. 96. 114.
text.14875:
Śrāddha — a son of Śatrughna, the son of Anādhṛṣṭhi.
M. 46. 24.
text.14876:
Śrāddham (I) — certain days considered good for the
performance of; sumptuous feeding of many people on the
day; no offering of or eating of flesh.1 Feeding of yogins
recommended; presiding deity is Ravi.2 1) Bhā. III. 7. 33; VII. 14. 19-26; 15. 3-7.
2) M. 13. 6; 15. 43.
text.14877:
Śrāddham (II) — a karma;1 the wherefrom and why of
the ceremony is questioned for answer; ceremony for dis
liked Pitṛs will be enjoyed by the Rākṣasas and Dānavas;
tends to the growth of Soma who is the cause of the world
growth; three piṇḍas according to name and gotra; Pitṛs give
all including knowledge; at the tīrthas and rivers; Bṛhaspati
on śrāddha; once there was a thick haze of darkness in all
worlds when Brahmā engaged himself in yoga and created
the worlds, Santānaka and the first gods Vairājās; the form
less groups of Gods attained absolution through yoga which
is the strength of the Pitṛs; and through this yoga Soma
increases in power; hence feed thousands learned in the
Vedic lore; feeding of a snātaka equals that of many; atheists
and the unrighteous should not be fed;2 to be performed with
faith using silver or silver-coated vessels and the Purodha to
be given svadhā; health and wealth are the fruits; superior
to deva worship; even gods propitiate the Pitṛs as also sages
and other semi-divine beings; for yogaiśvarya or mokṣa
dharma;3 details of the vedi and offerings during srāddhas;
Pitṛs eat in the guise of Vāyu; offerings in Agni when it
burns, otherwise it will lead to the blinding of eyes;4 the
ruling of Bṛhaspati that first offerings are to be made to
piṇḍa and then feeding Brahmans; by offering once the Pitṛs
become pleased;5 the eclipse day good for; a list of articles
to be used or discarded; women in their period unfit for
śrāddha; Triśaṅku country, that of Kāraskara, Kaliṅga and
that of North of Sindhu unfit for śrāddha; naked persons
must not be seen in a śrāddha; those who have no āśramas
are not fit for śrāddha; unfit to be seen then are dogs, fowls,
hermaphrodites, etc.; importance of śaucam in a śrāddha;6
who are eligible to be fed and those who are not; Grahasta,
Vānaprastha, Yati and Vālakhilya are eligible; those beyond
the āśramas are not eligible; the leavings of śrāddhas not to
be given to women and Śūdras but to sons,7 gifts of rice,
kamaṇḍalu, fans, slippers, cloths and gems, silver and gold
vessels, fuel, bed, silk, etc., made on the occasion will result
in long life, health, wealth, children, cattle, conveyance, etc.,8
either it is kāmya or naimittika and ajasra; to be done on
all the 15 days of the dark half of the month including the
amāvāsya and its effects;9 the śrāddha performed under every
nakṣatra and its results as narrated by Yama to Śaśabindu;10
havis of sesamum, rice, fruits and roots, flesh of animals and
birds like fish, deer, hare, parrots, hog, chāgala, gavya, aura
bhra, khaḍga, etc.; three Brahmans to be fed representing
the trinity; not to feed those addicted to liquor, cattle rear
ing, and are messengers of villages, merchants; also one who
picks up quarrels with parents, whose wife is in periods, a
thief, one insulting friends, mad, hermaphrodite, culpable of
child murder, defiler of preceptor's bed, physician, adulterer,
seller of Vedic Niyamas, dogs and brahmicides not to be seen
in a śrāddha; the sprinkling of seasamum is to ward off
Asuras and Rakṣasas from taking part; the time is the fore
noon of Śuklapakṣa and afternoon of Kṛṣṇapakṣa;11 offering
of Piṇḍas; thus said Bṛhaspati to his son in the śrāddha
kalpa;12 ordained for Pitṛs; places for oblations in the absence
of fire; articles fit and unfit for;13 kinds of, and details relat
ing to;14 sādhāraṇa śrāddha described;15 tīrthas for perform
ance of.16 1) Br. III. 4. 24.
2) Ib. III. 9. 4; M. 20. 6; 21. 33.
3) Ib. III. 10. 100;
M. 15. 31.
4) Ib. III. 11. 6, 49, 100.
5) Ib. III. 12. 26; 13. 1; M. 10.
34.
6) Ib. III. 14. 3-86.
7) Ib. III. 15. 3, 38, 59.
8) Ib. III. 16. 1.
9) Ib. III. 17-1, 10-20.
10) Br. 18. 2-14.
11) Ib. III. 19. 2.
12) 20. 10;
IV. 4. 53.
13) M. 15. 30-38; 204. 1.
14)
15) Ib. ch. 17.
16) Ib. ch. 22.
text.14878:
Śrāddhakalpa — the rituals prescribed as due to Pitṛs.
M. 2. 23.
text.14879:
Śrāddhada — a son of Vṛṣa.
Br. III. 6. 34.
text.14880:
Śrāddhadeva (I) — a tīrtha on the Sarasvatī.
Bhā. III. 1. 22.
text.14882:
Śrāddhadeva (III) — (Manu: a son of Vivasvata and
Samjñā: Seventh Manu (s.v.) Manu Vaivasvata.
Satyavrata in previous birth.
Bhā. VI. 6. 40; VIII. 13. 1 and 9; 24. 11; Br. III. 63. 215;
Vi. III. 1. 30.
text.14883:
Śrāddhadeva (IV) — Yama; the former birth of
Gaveṣuṇa; a destroyer of Indra; father of Ekalavya.
Vā. 96. 182.
text.14884:
Śrāddhadevī — one of Vasudeva's wives: mother of
Ganeṣa.
Br. III. 71. 184.
text.14886:
Śrāvaṇa (I) — the name of the month and Nakṣatra;
god for gift of the Vāyu Purāṇa;1 Kṛṣṇāṣṭamī of this month
good for śrāddha.2 1) M. 53. 19; 56. 4; 57. 17; 60. 34; 124. 50.
2) M. 17. 8.
text.14887:
Śrāvaṇa (II) — a son of Gautama, an avatār of the 14th
dvāpara.
Vā. 23, 164.
text.14888:
Śrāvasta — a son of Yuvanāśva and the founder of the
city of Śrāvasti; the father of Brahmadaśva.
Br. III. 63. 27; M. 12. 30; Vā. 88. 26-7.
text.14889:
Śrāvasti — the city built by Śrāvasta of the Ikṣvāku
line; capital of Uttarakośala where Lava ruled;1 in Gauḍa
deśa built by Vatsaka son of Śrāvasta.2 1) Br. III. 63. 28, 200; Vā. 88. 200.
2) M. 12. 30.
text.14891:
Śriṃgavān — a varṣa parvata north of the Śveta of three
tops of which one is Iṣuvatam śringa;1 residence of Pitṛs.2 1) Vā. 1. 85; 50. 189.
2) Ib. 46. 35.
text.14893:
Śrī (I) — (Khāyāti), a daughter of Bhṛgu and Khyāti
devoted to Bhagavān;1 requested by Devas to approach
Nṛsimha with a view to appease his wrath, she dared not go
near him;2 elder sister of Dhātā and Vidhātā; married Nārā
yaṇa and gave birth to Bala and Unmāda (utsāha) besides
mind-born sons;3 alias Mahālakṣmī or Lakṣmī.4 1) Bhā. I. 10. 26; 11. 26 and 33; IV. 1. 43; 24. 49.
2) Ib. VII. 9. 2;
VIII. 4. 20; 5. 40; 23. 6; IX. 4. 60; X. 3. 50; 9. 20; 29. 37; 31. 17;
XI. 14. 15 & 39; XII. 11. 20.
3) Br. II. 11. 2; 13. 78; Vā. 28. 2.
4) Br. IV. 39. 70-71. 44. 71; Vā. 37. 38.
text.14894:
Śrī (II) — came out of the churning of the milk ocean,
whom Viṣṇu placed on his breast: the dweller in the lotus:
also Śrīdevī.
Br. IV. 9. 76, 79; 33. 46; 36. 21, 31 and 90.
text.14895:
Śrī (III) — a Kala of the moon.
Br. IV. 35. 92.
text.14899:
Śrīgiri — sages of this Mt. visited Dvārakā.
Bhā. X. 90. 28[3].
text.14900:
Śrīguru and Gurupatnī — represent Brahmam.
Br. IV. 43. 7.
text.14901:
Śrīcakram — the mantra of: is Mahālakṣmī: worshipped
by Viṣṇu, Śiva and Brahmā: propitiation of, makes one
learned: Icon of: the mudras in connection with the worship
of; Dīkṣa and its methods.
Br. IV. 41. 3-5; chh. 42-3.
text.14903:
Śrīcīntāmaṇimantra — to be uttered in Devi's offering.
Br. IV. 43. 19.
text.14904:
Śrītalam — of rocky earth; here are cities of Kesari,
Suparvaṇa, Vāsuki, the king of the Nāgas.
Vā. 50. 12, 38-40.
text.14905:
Śrīdaṇḍanāthā — the leader of Lalitā's hosts against
Bhaṇḍa; also Potrinī; her march described; in Kiricakra
ratha: Her mount was the lion Vajraghoṣa;1 hit Kuṭalākṣa,
the chief commander of Bhaṇḍa: consulted Mantrinī: helped
Kumārī in her expedition against sons of Bhaṇḍa: ascended
Geyacakra and fought with Viṣanga: became happy at the
end.2 1) Br. IV. 16. 31; 17. 8, 27; ch. 21.
2) Ib. IV. 26. 1-113; 27.
45 and 58; 28. 14-20; 34. 55.
text.14906:
Śrīdāman — a playmate of Kṛṣṇa in his Hariṇākāiḍana
sport. Expressed to Kṛṣṇa the desire to rid the palmyra
grove of Asura Dhenuka. Being victor in a game, he had
the honour of being borne on the back by Kṛṣṇa;1 was
placed by Śiva on his lap as a token of affection.2 1) Bhā. X. 15. 20; 18. 23-4; 22. 31; Vi. V. 9. 13-14.
2) Br. III.
42. 55; 43. 29.
text.14907:
Śrīdevā — a daughter of Devaka; a queen of Vasudeva
and mother of six sons of whom Nandaka was one.
Bhā. IX. 24. 23 & 51; Br. III. 71. 131, 162 and 181; IV. 29. 2;
Vā. 96. 130; Vi. 14. 18.
text.14910:
Śripati tīrtham — sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 22. 74.
text.14911:
Śriparṇi — a R. sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 22. 49.
text.14912:
Śriparvatam — Mt. a hill in India, fit for Śrāddha offer
ings;1 sacred to Śiva.2 1) Br. II. 16. 23; III. 13. 28, 31; Vā. 45. 92; 77. 28.
2) M. 181. 28.
text.14913:
Śrīpādukāsmṛti — superior to mahādānas and mahā
yajñas.
Br. IV. 43. 57.
text.14915:
Śrīpāśāyudhasambhava — he who came out of the Pāśa
of Lalitā rode on a superior horse.
Br. IV. 16. 14 and 29.
text.14917:
Śripuram — (Śrīnagara) the city of Lalitā: built by
Viśvakarman and Maya; in the Ṣoḍaśakṣetra madhya: Of
this nine were bhauma and the seven waters: It is called
Kāmeśvarīpurī, Bhayamalīpuri, Nityaklinnapuri: surround
ed by Brahmā, Viṣṇu and Śiva lokas: seven prākāras, all
of metal.
Br. IV. 30. 106-7; 31. 1, 106; 32. 1-10.
text.14918:
Śrīpūrti — a devī in Cintāmaṇi gṛha.
Br. IV. 36. 26.
text.14919:
Śrībhānu — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Satyabhāmā.
Bhā. X. 61. 11.
text.14921:
Śrimadbhāgavata — produced by the great sage Vyāsa;
taught by him to Śuka who narrated it to Parīkṣit, when
Sūta heard it.
Bhā. I. 1. 2; 3. 40-44.
text.14922:
Śrimallakarṇi — a son of Kṛṣṇa, ruled for 10 years.
M. 273. 3.
text.14923:
Śrīmahāpādukā — in the Cintāmaṇi gṛha.
Br. IV. 36. 26.
text.14924:
Śrīmān (I) — the most celebrated among the Nīpas.
M. 49. 53.
text.14925:
Śrimān (II) — a son of Āpa, the Vasava.
M. 203. 6.
text.14926:
Śrīmūrti — the manifestation of Hari in the epoch of the
tenth Manu: born of Viśvasrk.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 21[1].
text.14927:
Śrīraṅga — visited by Balarāma;1 sacred to Pitṛs.2 1) Bhā. X. 79. 14.
2) M. 22. 44.
text.14928:
Śrīvatsa — the jewel of Kṛṣṇa;1 of Pauṇḍarīka Vāsudeva.2 1) Vā. 96. 204.
2) Vi. V. 34. 17.
text.14929:
Śrīvanam — a bilvavanam east of Ś(r)īsaras; served by
the Gandharvas, Kinnaras, Yakṣas, Siddhas; the residence
of Śrī.
Vā. 37. 13-15.
text.14931:
Śrīvṛkṣa — near the Cītrakūṭa hill fit for Śrāddha.12 1) Br. III. 13. 38.
2) Vā. 77. 38.
text.14933:
Śrīśāntakarṇa(i) — a son of Kṛṣṇa, and father of Paurṇa
māsa: ruled for 56 years.
Bhā. XII. 1. 23; Br. III. 74. 162.
text.14934:
Śrīsūktam — in honour of Śrī;1 to be uttered when found
ing temples.2 1) Br. IV. 9. 77; Vi. I. 9. 101.
2) M. 265. 24.
text.14935:
Śrīśaila — a Mt in Bhārata varṣa, sacred to Śiva. Rukmī
addressed himself to this god: visited by Balarāma;1 sacred
to Lalitāpīṭha;2 sacred to Goddess Mahādevī and the Pitṛs;3 a
part of the burning Tripura fell there.4 1) Bhā. V. 19. 16; X. 61. 23[1]; 79. 13.
2) Br. IV. 44. 98.
3) M.
13. 31; 22. 43.
4) Ib. 188. 79.
text.14936:
Śrīsomanātha — Candra (s.v.) arising out of Atri's eyes:
27 nakṣatras being his śaktis.
Br. IV. 35. 54-5.
text.14937:
Śruta (I) — a son of Bhagiratha (Suhotra-Vi. P.) and
father of Nābha(ga).
Bhā. IX. 9. 16; Br. III. 63. 169; Vā. 88. 160; Vi. IV. 4. 36.
text.14938:
Śruta (II) — a son of Subhāṣaṇa, and father of Jaya.
Bhā. IX. 13. 25.
text.14939:
Śruta (III) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Kālindī.
Bhā. X. 61. 14.
text.14940:
Śruta (IV) — a son of Medhā.
Br. II. 9. 59; Vā. 10. 35.
text.14941:
Śruta (V) — a son of Svārociṣa Manu.
Br. II. 36. 19.
text.14944:
Śrutaṛṣis — 8000 in number, are born again and again
and take up the arrangement of the Śamhitās;1 remembered
88,000 Samhitās which return again and again.2 1) Br. II. 33. 2; 35. 146; M. 145. 88.
2) Vā. 59. 86; 61. 122.
text.14945:
Śrutakarman (I) — a son of Sahadeva and Draupadī.
Bhā. IX. 22. 30; M. 50. 52; Vi. IV. 20. 42.
text.14946:
Śrutakarman (II) — a son of Chāyā and Mārtāṇḍa
(sun); became later Śanaiścara.
Br. III. 59. 48; Vā. 84. 50.
text.14947:
Śrutakīrti (I) — a son of Arjuna and Draupadī.
Bhā. IX. 22. 29; M. 50. 52; Vi. IV. 20. 42.
text.14948:
Śrutakīrtī (II) — a daughter of Sura1 (Śūra and Bhojā
M. P.) and queen of Dhṛṣṭaketu Kaikeya; a paternal aunt
of Kṛṣṇa, and mother of Bhadrā, married to Kṛṣṇa; also
mother of Anuvrata (Santardanā-Vi. P.) besides four other
sons; a viramātā.2 1) Br. III. 71. 150 & 57;
2) Bhā. IX. 24. 30 and 38; X. 58. 56; M. 46.
4-5; Vā. 96. 149; 156. 7; Vi. IV. 14. 31, 41-2.
text.14949:
Śrutadeva (I) — a Brahman follower of Kṛṣṇa; knew
his yoga power; lived as householder in Mithilā, earning
bread for the day and contented; was visited by Kṛṣṇa and
was happy at the honour done to him.
Bhā. I. 14. 32; II. 7. 45; X. 78. [95 (v) 1]; 86. 13 to 57.
text.14950:
Śrutadeva (II) — a siddha; attacked the Asura followers
of Bali.
Bhā. VI. 15. 15; VIII. 21. 17; X. 86. 13.
text.14951:
Śrutadeva (III) — a son of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 90. 34.
text.14952:
Śrutadevā — a daughter of Śūra; a sister of Vasudeva;
wife of Vṛddhaśaman Kārūṣa (Vṛddhadharma, the kārūśa
king-Vi. P.) mother of Dantavaktra (the great Asura).
Bhā. IV. 24. 30 and 37; Br. III. 71; 150 and 156; Vā. 96. 149,
155; Vi. IV. 14. 31, 39, 40.
text.14953:
Śrutadevī — a daughter of Devaka and one of the seven
wives of Vasudeva.
M. 44. 73.
text.14954:
Śrutadhara — the companion who followed Puramjana
to Uttara and Dakṣiṇa Pāñcāla; allegorically, the hearing.
Bhā. IV. 25. 50-51; 29. 13.
text.14955:
Śrutadharas — a class of people in Śālmalidvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 11.
text.14956:
Śrutaṃjaya (I) — a son of Satyāyu.
Bhā. IX. 15. 2.
text.14957:
Śrutaṃjaya (II) — a Bṛhadratha; ruled for 24 years.
Br. III. 74. 114.
text.14959:
Śrutavarman — a minister of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 12. 53.
text.14960:
Śrutavindā — a R. in Kuśadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 15.
text.14961:
Śrutaśravas (I) — a son of Somāpī;1 ruled for 67 years;2
father of Ayutāyu.3 1) Bhā. IX. 22. 9.
2) Br. III. 74. 111.
3) Vi. IV. 23. 4.
text.14962:
Śrutaśravas (II) — a son of Mārjāri, and father of Ayu
tāyu.
Bhā. IX. 22. 46.
text.14963:
Śrutaśravas (III) — a daughter of Śūra and Bhojā;1 a
sister of Vasudeva and queen of Damaghoṣa, the Cedi king;2
mother of Śisupāla; a Vīramātā.3 1) M. 46. 4, 6.
2) Bhā. IX. 24. 30 and 39; Br. III. 71. 150 and
158; Vi. IV. 14. 31, 44-5.
3) Vā. 96. 149, 157-8.
text.14964:
Śrutaśravas (IV) — a son of Chāyā and the Sun god; was
Sāvarṇi Manu.
Br. III. 59. 48; Vā. 84. 50.
text.14966:
Śrutaśravas (VI) — (Māgadha) in the line of Somādhi
(tasyānvaya) ruled for 64 years; this gap between Somādhi
and Śrutaśravas seems to account for the discrepancy be
tween the names given and the total No. 32 of the kings.
M. 271. 20; Vā. 99. 228, 297.
text.14967:
Śrutasena (I) — a son of Śatrughna.
Bhā. IX. 11. 12.
text.14968:
Śrutasena (II) — a son of Bhīma and Draupadī.
Bhā. IX. 22. 29; M. 50. 52; Vi. IV. 20. 42.
text.14969:
Śrutasena (III) — a son of Parīkṣit.
Bhā. IX. 22. 35; Vi. IV. 20. 1; 21. 3.
text.14970:
Śrutādevī — a daughter of Śūra and Bhojā, wife of Kṛta,
and mother of Sugrīva.
M. 46. 4-5.
text.14971:
Śrutānīka — a son of Nakula by Draupadī.
Vi. IV. 20. 42.
text.14972:
Śrutāyus (I) — a son of Ariṣṭanemi and father of Supār
śva(ka).
Bhā. IX. 13. 23; Vi. IV. 5. 31.
text.14973:
Śrutāyus (II) — a son of Purūravas and Ūrvaśī. Father
of Vasumat.
Bhā. IX. 15. 1 and 2; Br. III. 66. 23; Vi. IV. 7. 1.
text.14975:
Śrutāyus (IV) — a son of Bhānuścandra, was slain in
the Bhārata battle.
M. 12. 55.
text.14976:
Śrutārthakṛt — a son of Jāmbavān.
Br. III. 7. 303.
text.14977:
Śruti (I) — the Vedas: interpreted in two ways in the
Dvāpara;1 the same, Ṛg, Yajus, and Sāma in every manvan
tara though in different redactions; here are four stotras —
Dravyastotram, Guṇastotram, Karmastotram, and Abhi
janastotram; above all these is Brahmastotram; mantras
were originally five fold;2 having learnt the Śrauta from their
predecessors the seven sages repeated the same.3 1) Br. II. 31. 6, 72; 32, 35; IV. 6. 64; M. 52. 12; 144. 7; Vā. 34.
95; 39. 11; 41. 90; 55. 7; 61. 75; 76. 3; 100. 33; 101. 9, 22, 57.
2) M.
145. 58-63.
3) Vā. 3. 8; 32. 44; 59. 31.
text.14978:
Śruti (II) — a son of Uttama Manu.
Br. II. 36. 40.
text.14979:
Śruti (III) — a daughter of Anasūyā and mother of
Śankhapadā, wife of Kardama, Pulaha Prajāpati.
Vā. 28. 18, 27; Br. II. 11. 22.
text.14980:
Śrutis — awaken the Lord sleeping after a pralaya, as
bards the emperor from his bed. Śrutigītā on the greatness
and glory of Lord.
Bhā. V. 87. 1, 12-41; XI. 5. 5.
text.14981:
Śrutikevala — a ṛtvik at Brahmā's sacrifice.
Vā. 106. 35.
text.14982:
Śrutiparāga — one of Bhaṇḍa's eight men.
Br. IV. 12. 12.
text.14985:
Śrutiśravas — a son of Somapa; the last of the Māgadhas.
Vi. IV. 19. 84-5.
text.14987:
Śṛṃgavat — a Mt. range to the north of Ilāvṛta; a
boundary limit of Kuru; from it descends the stream
Bhadrā.
Bhā. V. 16. 8; 17. 8.
text.14988:
Śreṇis — military republics;1 treated with respect by
Pṛthu; help kings.2 1) M. 273. 68.
2) Bhā. IV. 17. 2; Br. III. 7. 264.
text.14991:
Śroṇī — a R. of the Bhāratavarṣa.
Vā. 45. 100.
text.14992:
Śrota — the Yakṣa presiding over the month, Nabha.
Bhā. XII. 11. 37.
text.14994:
Śrotāmanta — a god of Ādya group.
Br. II. 36. 69.
text.14995:
Śrotoguṇātmakas — the three guṇas, satva, rajas and
tamas revolve round and round among all worldly creatures.
Vā. 102. 56.
text.14996:
Śrotram — a Tuṣita god.
Br. III. 3. 19. Vā. 66. 18.
text.14997:
Śrotri — guides the month of Nabhas.
Bhā. XII. 11. 37.
text.14998:
Śrotrīya — eligible for Pārvaṇa śrāddha, as also his son.
M. 16. 8; 105. 17; Vi. III. 15. 2.
text.14999:
Śrauta — from śravaṇa — to hear or heard; principally of
the sacrifice and Veda.
Vā. 59. 38.
text.15000:
Śrautagepi — an Ārṣeya Pravara of the Bhārgavas.
M. 195. 38.
text.15001:
Śrautam Dharmam and Smārta — promulgated by the
seven sages and Manu at the commencement of the Tretā
yuga;1 two-fold, dhārāgnihotrasambandham said in four days;
hearing is śrauta;2 lost in Arājaka;3 the śruta consists of mar
riage, agnihotra, and Vedic studies; this is according to the
Sapta ṛṣis.4 1) Br. II. 29. 44-51; 32. 33-5.
2) Ib. II. 32. 33-5, 43, 44; III. 21.
47.
3) Ib. II. 31. 95.
4) Vā. 57. 39-40.
text.15002:
Śrautasmārtam — commences with Tretāyuga; originally
told by seven sages;1 it is called jñānadharma; characteristics
of; the one deals with sacrifices and the other with Var
ṇāśrama;2 is lost towards the close of Kali (in Kali).3 1) M. 142. 40.
2) Ib. 144. 96; 145. 22, 30-31, 40.
3) Ib. 273.
46; Vi. IV. 24. 98.
text.15004:
Śvapākas — Caṇḍālas; with minds controlled and resign
ed to Hari are better than Brahmans not devoted to God;
were honoured by Kṛṣṇa; become pure by bhakti (also
śvāda s.v.);1 meat eaters with whom Satyavrata-Triśanku
lived.2 1) Bhā. I. 11. 22; VII. 9. 10; XI. 14. 21.
2) Br. III. 63. 81;
Vā. 88. 82.
text.15005:
Śvaphalka — a son of Vṛṣṇi; elder brother of Citraka;
married Gāndinī, daughter of a Kāśī king. Akrūra was the
foremost of his twelve sons. Kāśī, not visited by rains for
long had a heavy shower just at his marriage, and during his
stay at the invitation of the Kāśī king, whose daughter he
married. A righteous king in whose kingdom there was
neither famine nor disease.
Bhā. III. 1. 32; IX. 24. 15; X. 38. 24; 57. 32; XI. 12. 10; Br. III.
71, 102; Vi. IV. 13. 115-16; 15. 5-7.
text.15006:
Śvabhojana — a hell; the abode of Vratins and Brahma
cārins with an uncontrolled body, taught and disciplined by
sons, and Brahmacāris that sleep during day time.
Br. IV. 2. 149, 176; Vā. 101. 148, 173; Vi. II. 6. 5 and 29.
text.15007:
Śvamukhas — the country of, watered by Nalinī.
Br. II. 18. 60.
text.15011:
Śvā — unfit to be seen during a śrāddha; touching it is a
sin.
Br. III. 14. 48; 78, 88; 27. 15; Vi. III. 16. 12.
text.15012:
Śvājita (Ātreya) — a sage of the epoch of Bhautya
Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 114.
text.15013:
Śvāta — a son of Brahmadhāna.
Br. III. 7. 98.
text.15014:
Śvāda — (also Śvapaca) — see Śvapākas.
Bhā. III 33. 6 and 7.
text.15015:
Śvāna — a Rudra on the Ṣoḍaśa cakra.
Br. IV. 34. 26.
text.15016:
Śvānabali — oblation to dogs; Syāma and Śabala.
Vā. 111. 39.
text.15017:
Śvāpada — the Asura whose city is in Tatvalam.
Br. II. 20. 18.
text.15018:
Śvāpadanagaram — in the first tala of the Atalam.
Vā. 50. 17.
text.15019:
Śvāhi — a son of Vṛjinivata, and father of Ruśaku.
Bhā. IX. 23. 31.
text.15020:
Śveta (I) — (Varṣaparvata) a Mt. range to the north of
Ilāvṛta, and a boundary limit of Hiraṇmaya; residence of
Daityas and Dānavas; centres round the Kumuda hill of
Śālmalidvīpam; for Asuras.
Bhā. V. 16. 8; Br. II. 1. 69; II. 15. 22 and 28; 17. 35; 20. 52;
III. 7. 194; M. 113. 23, 84; 144. 57; Vā. 1. 85; 42. 68; 45. 2; 46. 35.
49. 39; 50. 50.
text.15021:
Śveta (II) — a chief Nāga of Pātāla;1 with the sun in
Āvaṇi and Puraṭṭāśi.2 1) Bhā. V. 24. 31.
2) Br. II. 23. 10; Vā. 52. 11.
text.15022:
Śveta (III) — a son of Vapuṣmat after whom came the
Śvetadeśa.
Br. II. 14. 32-3; Vā. 33. 28; Vi. II. 4. 23, 29.
text.15023:
Śveta (IV) — a son of Devajanī and a Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 128.
text.15024:
Śveta (V) — a son of Bṛhati.
Br. III. 71. 256; Vā. 96. 247.
text.15025:
Śveta (VI) — a son of Vipracitta the dānava in the Tāra
kāmaya war.
M. 173. 19; 177. 7.
text.15026:
Śveta (VII) — the form of a great seer which Śiva as
sumes at the end of the four Yugas of the Kalpa; (Vārāha)
in the Chagala hillock of the Himālayas;1 the avatār of the
23rd dvāpara in the Kalañjara hill.2 1) Vā. 23. 115.
2) Ib. 23. 203-4.
text.15027:
Śveta (VIII) — one of the four Vedic disciples of Śveta,
an avatār of the Lord Śiva.
Vā. 23. 117.
text.15029:
Śveta (X) — a ṛtvik at Brahmā's sacrifice.
Vā. 106. 36.
text.15030:
Śveta (XI) — a division of Jambūdvipa.
Vi. II. 1. 21. 2. 11.
text.15031:
Śvetakalpa — the first kalpa; explained in the Vāyavya
Purāṇa;1 Dharmavṛtā performed tapas in and became
turned to a stone;2 Vārāha in;3 Śiva takes the avatār of Sad
yojāta, all white, when Gāyatrī also is born with him.4 1) M. 290. 3; 53. 18.
2) Vā. 107. 6.
3) Ib. 105. 7; 106. 32; 109.
35.
4) Ib. 23. 63.
text.15033:
Śvetaketu (II) — a son of Lāngali, an avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 200.
text.15034:
Śveta cakṣu — a god of Prasūta group.
Br. II. 36. 70.
text.15035:
Śvetadvīpa — sacred to Hari, visited by Nārada.
Bhā. VIII. 4. 18; X. 6. 24; 87. 10; XI. 15. 18.
text.15036:
Śvetaparvā — burnt by Śiva's anger and reattained divi
nity with Cupid.
M. 191. 112.
text.15037:
Śvetam — a region of Śālmalidvīpa adjoining the
Kumuda hill;1 the kingdom of Hiraṇvān.2 1) Br. II. 19. 44.
2) Ib. II. 14. 50; 15. 34; 19. 44.
text.15038:
Śvetarata — a son of Hṛdika.
Br. III. 71. 14.
text.15039:
Śvetalohita (I) — 29th kalpa; out of contemplation of
Brahmā came into being Kumāra along with seers known as
śvetas, disciple of Brahmā, Sunanda, etc., besides the great
sage Śveta.
Vā. 22. 9-20.
text.15040:
Śvetalohita (II) — a disciple of Śveta avatār of Śiva.
Vā. 23. 117.
text.15041:
Śvetavarṇa — a Kulaparvata of the Bhadrāśva.
Vā. 43. 14.
text.15042:
Śvetavāhana (I) — a son of Śūra.
Br. III. 71. 138; Vā. 96. 136.
text.15044:
Śvetas (I) — a Parāśara clan; a dynasty of kings.
Br. III. 8. 95; 74. 268; Vā. 70. 89; 73. 62.
text.15045:
Śvetas (II) — the sages who sprang out of the side of
Kumāra (Deveśa) in the 29th Kalpa.
Vā. 22. 15.
text.15046:
Śvetas (III) — a Janapada of the Ketumālā.
Vā. 44. 11; 99. 455.
text.15047:
Śvetā (I) — a daughter of Krodhavaśā (Krodhā-Vā. P.)
and wife of Pulaha; mother of Vānaras;1 mother of four
Diggajas.2 1) Br. III. 7. 172, 180-203; Vā. 69. 205.
2) Vā. 69. 214.
text.15048:
Śvetā (II) — a daughter of Bṛhati.
Br. III. 7. 256; Vā. 96. 247.
text.15049:
Śvetāṃgas — a Janapada of the Ketumālā continent.
Vā. 44. 11.
text.15050:
Śvetāmbujas — a class of gods doing śrāddha.
Br. III. 10. 109.
text.15051:
Śvetāśva — one of the four learned Brahman disciples
of Śveta.
Vā. 23. 117.
text.15052:
Śvetodara — a Mt. on the south of the Mānasa.
Vā. 36. 23; 39. 56; 42. 30.
text.15053:
Ṣaṭketu — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 87.
text.15055:
Ṣaṭpriya — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 87.
text.15056:
Ṣaṭbrahmāṇa — Marīci, Kratu, Atri, Pulastya, Pulaha,
and Vasumat or Vasiṣṭha; these are known as Prajāpatis
as they are concerned with the increase of santāna to the
world.
Vā. 65. 43-48.
text.15057:
Ṣaṭsuras — on the other side of the Vindhyas.
Vā. 45. 133.
text.15058:
Ṣaḍaṅga — the six limbs of the state including the king
who must protect it with great care.
M. 220. 21; Vā. 30. 293; 99. 39.
text.15059:
Ṣaḍaṅgavid — one versed in the six supplementary
sciences of the Vedas, fit for śrāddha.
Vi. III. 15. 2.
text.15060:
Ṣaḍapāyas — a king to be expert in.
Br. IV. 21. 53.
text.15061:
Ṣaḍānana (Skanda) — born out of the left side of the
belly of Umā;1 born at Śaravaṇa in Kailāsa.2 1) Br. IV. 30. 101; M. 158. 48-49; 160. 23.
2) Vā. 41. 37.
text.15063:
Ṣaḍja — the sixteenth kalpa; the sages, called Ṣaḍjanas.
Vā. 21. 34.
text.15064:
Ṣaḍja(grāma) — a particular scale (music);1 fourteen
kinds of.2 1) Vā. 21. 37; 86. 39; 87. 28.
2) Ib. 86. 49; Vi. II. 14. 32.
text.15065:
Ṣaḍjanas — sages of the sixteenth kalpa; with these was
born Maheśvara.
Vā. 21. 34.
text.15066:
Ṣaḍdanta (I) — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 87.
text.15068:
Ṣaḍdarśanas — Brāhmam, Śaivam, Vaiṣṇavam, Sauram,
Śāktam and Ārhatam.
Vā. 104. 16.
text.15069:
Ṣaṇḍa — the asura; also Śaṇḍa, brother of Marka; one
of the disciples of Śukra. The Asuras were experts in the
magic of warfare and hence Devas won them over by offer
ing a graha to them in the sacrifices; thus the Asuras were
defeated.
Br. III. 72. 72, 87; 73. 63-4; Vā. 97. 72 and 86; 98. 63; 108. 60.
text.15071:
Ṣaṇmukha (I) — (Kumāra); anecdotes of, in the Skān-
dapurāṇa;1 a leader in the battle of Tripuram;2 all the wives
of the seven seers except Arundhatī served Kumāra as
mothers. Hence the six-faced.3 1) Br. III. 10. 42; M. 53. 42.
2) Ib. 136. 68; 137. 32; 159. 3;
160. 11 and 28.
3) Vā. 72. 40.
text.15072:
Ṣaṇmukha (II) — a name of Vighneśvara.
Br. IV. 44. 68.
text.15073:
Ṣaṣṭamāṃśam — one-sixth of their merit the Brahmans
give to righteous kings.
Bhā. V. 15. 11.
text.15074:
Ṣaṣṭimāyāpuram — sacred to Lalitā pīṭha.
Br. IV. 44. 98.
text.15075:
Ṣāḍguṇyavidhi — the six-fold policy of kings.
M. 215. 16.
text.15076:
Ṣoḍaśapatrābja — here were sixteen śaktis beginning
with Dinamiśrā; another group of 16 śaktis commencing with
Kalā is also said to reside here; these were also attached to
mahākāla.
Br. IV. 32. 11; 14-16, 19.
text.15077:
Ṣoḍaśāsra — a temple in different shapes; with shining
towers.
M. 269. 29, 34, 39.
text.15078:
Ṣoḍaśāhaphalam — by giving sarpi in the śrāddha.
Vā. 79. 11.
text.15079:
Ṣoḍaśi (I) — born from the eastern face of Brahmā.
Bhā. III. 12. 40.
text.15080:
Ṣoḍaśi (II) — the waxing and waning of the moon.
Vā. 52. 70.
text.15081:
Ṣoḍaśīkṣetram — of Lalitā; with nine hills and seven seas.
Br. IV. 31. 10-19.
text.15082:
Sakuliyā — gave birth to a class of piśācas by name adho
mukhas — fearful, hairy, cannibals, etc.
Vā. 69. 266-7.
text.15083:
Saketu — one of the sons of Sagara that survived Kapila's
tejas.
Vā. 88. 149.
text.15085:
Sakotiputra — a pupil of Laugākṣī.
Br. II. 35. 41.
text.15086:
Saktu — the flour of grain not to be taken during nights.
M. 131. 43.
text.15087:
Sagara — a son of Bāhu, (Phalgutantra) born with gara
(poison) administered to his mother by the co-wives of her
husband and after 7 years' stay in his mother's womb;
brought up by sage Aurva; Keśinī was one of his queens and
Sumatī was another. Prabhā, and Bhānumatī, mother of
Asamanjasa were also his queens. Father of Asamanjasa
who was abandoned by his father for misconduct.
A Cakravarti. His sons 60,000 in number by Sumati,
excavated the sea and dug all over the earth in their search
for the consecrated horse. Helped by Aurva, he propi
tiated Hari with sacrifices. Once Indra stole his sacrificial
horse, and this was discovered near Kapila's hermitage in the
N. E. by his sons who imputed the theft to the sage. The
latter burnt them to ashes. But Amśumat, son of Asaman
jasa got back the horse, and enabled his grandfather to com
plete the sacrifice. Anointed Amśumat on the throne in the
presence of Paurajānapada and devoted himself to attaining
salvation through the path prescribed by Aurva. Greed for
more territory; conquered Tālajanghas, Yavanas, Śakas,
Haihayas and Barbaras. On the advice of his guru, Vasiṣṭha,
he spared their lives but punished them by disfiguring them —
some wholly shaven, and some half-shaven. They became
ancestors of Mlecchas and Vrātyas.1 Realised the yoga power
of Hari.2 Addressed by him Vasiṣṭha narrated the story of
Paraśurāma. In the case of Haihayas, he conquered the
king and burnt the city. When he invaded the Vidarbhas,
its king sought alliance by offering his daughter in marriage;
was honoured by Śurasenas and Yādavas.3 During his rule,
nowhere was heard rāja śabdha; ruled like Dharma himself,
maintained castes and orders, earned the title of Aṣṭamaṇḍal
ādhipati; had an erudite assembly.4 The jewel of the solar
race. Sumatī brought forth a mass of flesh which ulti
mately through the blessings of Aurva was converted into
60,000 sons. 1) Bhā. IX. 8 (whole); X. 41. 15: XII. 3. 9: Br. III. 52. 37 Chh.
53 and 54 (whole) 55. 22: 58. 37. Vi. III. 8. 3: 17. 1: Vī. IV. 3. 35-41:
4. 1-29, 32. 63. 121-151: M. 12. 39-43.
2) Bhā. II. 7. 44.
3) Br. III.
31. 1: 47. 93-100: Chh. 48 (whole).
4) Ib. III. Chh. 49-51.
text.15088:
Sagaras — the sons of Sagara who created eight extra
countries (upadvīpas) near Jambūdvīpa, when they dug up
the earth in search of their father's sacrificial horse;1 purified
by the Ganges.2 1) Bhā. V. 19-29-30.
2) Vi. II. 8. 115.
text.15089:
Saṃkaṭa — the son of Kakubha and Dharma. Father of
Kīkaṭa.
Bhā. VI. 6. 6.
text.15090:
Saṃkarṣaṇa (I) — the fourth form of Hari worshipped
by Śiva in Ilāvṛta; another name of Ananta; the ruler of
Ahamkāra. A god of one thousand heads presiding over
bhūtas; by his fire was burnt the three worlds; his greatness;
mantra in honour of; Lord of serpents.1 Kṛṣṇa, one of the
vamśavīras.2 1) Bhā I. 5. 37: V. 17. 16: 25. 1: IV. 24. 35: III. 26. 25: 19. 29. V.
25 (whole) VI. 15. 27-8: 16. 18: M. 2. 5: 93. 51: 248. 47: 276. 8.
2) Br. III. 36. 51: 72. 1: Vā 97. 1: 111. 21.
text.15091:
Saṃkarṣaṇa (II) — Balarāma and Balabhadra;1 the
seventh conception of Devakī, transferred to Roḥiṇī; a por
tion of Śeṣa, an amśa of God Viṣṇu; a great hero, white in
complexion, like a mountain in size.2 killed Dhenuka;3 killed
Pralamba;4 taught the Bhāgavata to Sanatkumāra.5 1) Bhā X. 2. 13: 8. 12: 15. 10: 40. 21: 41. 39: 50. 12: 89. 31, 33:
Vi. IV. 15. 29: V. 18. 58: 37. 25.
2) Ib. V. 1. 73-6: Bhā. IX. 24. 54, 60:
3) Vi. V. 8. 5.
4) Ib. V. 9. 16.
5) Bhā. III. 8. 3.
text.15093:
Saṃkalpa (I) — a son of Saṃkalpā and Dharma; father
of Kāma.
Bhā. VI. 6. 10: Br. III. 3. 33; M. 5. 19: 203. 10: Vā. 66. 34.
Vi. I. 15. 108.
text.15095:
Saṃkalpa (III) — one of the two vṛttis of mahat.
Vā. 4. 46.
text.15096:
Saṃkalpā — a daughter of Dakṣa, and one of Dharma's
ten wives; mother of Samkalpa or pious determination.
Bhā. VI. 6. 4 and 10: Br. III. 3. 3 and 33. M. 5. 16, 19: 203.
10: Vā. 66. 3: Vi. I. 15. 105, 108.
text.15097:
Saṃkīrṇa — a son of Abhramu elephant, the vehicle of
Yama; (also Añjana) a Diggaja;1 a nāga with the sun in the
spring.2 1) Br. III. 7. 330: Vā. 69. 215.
2) Ib. 52. 3.
text.15098:
Saṃkīla — a Vaiśya mantrakṛt.
Br. II. 32. 121. M. 145. 116.
text.15099:
Saṃkucchāsa — a device to determine the time of the
day.
Vā. 66. 42.
text.15100:
Saṃkṛti (I) — a son of Jayasena, and father of Jaya.
Bhā. IX. 17. 18.
text.15101:
Saṃkṛti (II) — a son of Nara, (Nagara-Vi. P.) and
father of two sons Guru (Guruprīti-Vi. P.) Rantideva.
Bhā. IX. 21. 1-2: M. 49. 36. Vi. IV. 19. 22.
text.15102:
Saṃkṛti (III) — an Angirasa and mantrakṛt; a kṣatro
peta dvija.
Br. II. 32. 107: III. 66. 86. M. 145. 101: Vā. 91. 115.
text.15103:
Saṃkṛti (IV) — a son of Jāmbavat.
Br. III. 7. 302.
text.15104:
Saṃkṛti (V) — a son of Jayatsena and father of Kṛta
dharman (Kṣatradharma-Vi. P.).
Br. III. 68. 10: Vā. 93. 10: Vi. IV. 9. 27.
text.15105:
Saṃkṛti (VI) — a Pravara; no marital relations with
Angiras and Gauravītis.
M. 196, 30.
text.15107:
Saṃkrāntyudyāpanam — in the ayana of Viṣu; worship
of the sun; can be done every year and every month.
M. 98. 1-15.
text.15112:
Saṃkhyāvida — experts in the calculations of the
calendar.
M. 142. 15: Vā. 70. 46: 101. 97, 125.
text.15114:
Samgata — a son of Suyaśas, and father of Śāliśūka.
Bhā. XII. 1. 14.
text.15115:
Samgama — the period from six to twelve nālikas in the
day.
Vā. 56. 46.
text.15117:
Samgameśam — a tīrtha on the south bank of the
Narmadā.
M. 191. 55, 74.
text.15119:
Saṃgīta yoginī — (also Gīta yoginī); a name of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 17. 33: 19. 62.
text.15121:
Saṃgraha — a muhurta of the night.
Br. III. 3. 43: Vā. 66. 44.
text.15122:
Saṃgrāma — the most horrible war and Tārakāmaya in
the fifth avatār.
Vā. 97. 74.
text.15123:
Saṃgrāmajit (I) — a son of Bhadrā; fought with Subha
dra at Prabhāsa.
Bhā. X. 61. 17: XI. 30. 16.
text.15124:
Saṃgrāmajit (II) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Sudevī, a
daughter of king Śaibya.
Br. III. 71. 251: Vi. V. 32. 3.
text.15125:
Saṃgrāmajit (III) — one of the sons of Sudevī and Viṣ
vaksena.
Vā. 96. 242.
text.15126:
Sacivas — ministers, consulted by Tāraka before his war
with the devas;1 of a State.2 1) M. 148. 31.
2) Ib. 216. 25.
text.15127:
Sacī — Indrāṇī, took Satyabhāmā as a human being and
did not accord her due treatment; did not wish to part with
pārijāta which Satya wanted; induced Indra to fight Kṛṣṇa
who was taking the pārijāta.
Vi. V. 30. 29 and 52.
text.15128:
Sacīpati — see Indra; got Kṛṣṇa's promise of protection
to Arjuna.
Vi. V. 12. 15; 12. 16-20, 24.
text.15130:
Sajyoti — one of the names in the first marut gaṇa.
Vā. 67. 123.
text.15131:
Sañjaya (I) — also called Sūta; addressed as Gāvalgaṇa
by Yudhiṣṭhira, was not able to tell him where Dhṛtarāṣṭra
had gone; welcomed Vidura.
Bhā. I. 13. 3, 31-32.
text.15132:
Sañjaya (II) — the son of Raṇamjaya, and father of
Śākya.
Bhā. IX. 12. 13-14.
text.15133:
Sañjaya (III) — a son of Prati, and father of Jaya.
Bhā. IX. 17, 16.
text.15134:
Sañjaya (IV) — a son of Bharmyāśva.
Bhā. IX. 21. 32.
text.15135:
Sañjaya (V) — a son of Sātyaki, and father of Kuṇi.
Vi. IV. 14. 3.
text.15136:
Sañjīvini Vidyā — known to Śukra. By this Bali was
restored to life.
Bhā. VIII. 11. 47-48.
text.15140:
Satī (I) — (Lalitā) a daughter of Dakṣa, and wife of
Bhava or Śiva;1 see Pārvatī; expressed a desire to attend her
father's sacrifice to which Śiva was not invited. Permitted
to go, she went home but was not welcomed by her father.
Seeing the insult offered to her husband who was denied the
share due to him, she cast off her body by yoga. Born as
daughter of Mena.2 Drank the saubhāgya which came in
a blaze from Hari's chest3 became Umā, daughter of the
King of the Himālayas and married Rudra (Bhava).4 1) Bhā III. 14. 35 Vā. 1. 70: Vi. I. 7. 25-6:
2) Bhā. IV. 1. 65-66: 2.
1-3: 3. 5-25; 4 (whole): 7. 58 and 62: M. 13. 14-16: Vā. 10. 27: 30.
41-75:
3) M. 60. 10.
4) Ib. 154. 60, 69: 156. 15: Vā. 9. 52. 54, 69. 45-77.
71. 2; Vi. I. 8. 12-14.
text.15141:
Satī (II) — a wife of Angiras, and mother of Atharvan
giras; met by Citraketu.
Bhā. VI. 6. 19: 17. 16.
text.15144:
Satkarman — a son of Dhṛtavrata, and father of Adhi
ratha.
Bhā. IX. 23. 12.
text.15146:
Sattarāyana — the father of Bṛhadbhānu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 35.
text.15147:
Satya (I) — (Brahmaloka) see Satyaloka, one of the
heavenly worlds above it, nīrāloka; six crores of yojanas
above Tapoloka;1 residents of, do not return.2 1) Bhā. II. 1. 28: M. 184. 23: 248. 20: Vā. 100. 191: 101. 18. 27,
39, 141, 208.
2) Vā. 101. 27.
text.15148:
Satya (II) — a son of Havirdhāna.
Bhā. IV. 24. 8.
text.15149:
Satya (III) — a sage of the epoch of the Tenth Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 22: Vi. III. 2. 27.
text.15150:
Satya (IV) — a Sudhāmāna god;1 the name of Viṣṇu born
from Satyā in the Uttama epoch.2 1) Br. II. 36. 27.
2) Ib. III. 3. 115.
text.15151:
Satya (V) — a Tuṣita in the Svārociṣa and Nara in the
Cākṣuṣa epochs.
Br. III. 3. 15.
text.15152:
Satya (VI) — a Viśvedeva.
Br. III. 3. 30: M. 203. 13: 253. 24: Vā. 66. 31.
text.15153:
Satya (VII) — a Marut of the first gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 91.
text.15154:
Satya (VIII) — an Amītābha god.
Br. IV. 1. 17: Vā 100. 17.
text.15155:
Satya (IX) — a son of Angirasa.
M. 196. 2: Vā. 65. 105.
text.15156:
Satya (X) — a son of Devāpi, king of Ailas; will restore
Kṣatriya supremacy in the future caturyuga.
M. 273. 58.
text.15157:
Satya (XI) — the name of Vyāsa in the second dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 119.
text.15158:
Satya (XII) — one of the names for the third marut gaṇa.
Vā. 67. 126.
text.15159:
Satya (XIII) — a Rājaṛṣi becoming a Brahman.
Vā. 91. 116.
text.15160:
Satya (XIV) — a sage of the IX epoch of Manu.
Vi. III, 2. 23.
text.15161:
Satya (XV) — a son of Sāraṇa.
Vi. IV. 15. 21.
text.15162:
Satyas — a group of twelve Gods of the Uttama epoch;1
also of Tāmasa.2 1) Vi. III. 1. 14.
2) Ib. III. 1. 16.
text.15163:
Satyaka (I) — a son of (Chi) Śini, and father of Yuyu
dhāna or Sātyaki.1 Married the daughter of the king of Kāśi
and had four sons — Kukura, Bhajamāna, Suci and Kambala
barhis.2 Father of Satyaki.3 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 13-14: Vā. 96. 99: Vi. IV. 14. 2.
2) Br. III. 71.
100 and 116. Vā. 96. 115.
3) M. 45. 22.
text.15164:
Satyaka (II) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Bhadrā.
Bhā. X. 61. 17.
text.15165:
Satyaka (III) — a son of Raivata Manu.
Br. II. 36. 63: Vi. III. 1. 23.
text.15166:
Satyakas — gods of Tāmasa epoch.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 28.
text.15168:
Satyakarmā (II) — the son of Dhṛtavrata, and father
of Atiratha.
Vā. 99. 117: Vi. IV. 18. 26-7.
text.15169:
Satyaketu (I) — a son of Dharmaketu, and father of
Dhṛṣṭaketu (Vibhu-Br. P. and Vi. P.); a mahāratha.
Bhā. IX. 17. 8-9: Br. III. 67. 75: Vā. 92. 70: Vi. IV, 8. 20.
text.15170:
Satyaketu (II) — a sage of the X epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 27.
text.15171:
Satyajit (I) — the Indra of the Uttama epoch of Manu;
aided Satyasena in getting rid of the wicked.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 24 and 26.
text.15172:
Satyajit (II) — son of Sunitha(ta), and father of Viś
vajit.
Bhā. IX. 22. 49: Vi. IV. 23. 10-11.
text.15173:
Satyajit (III) — a son of Ānaka and Kankā.
Bhā. IX. 24. 41.
text.15174:
Satyajit (IV) — the Yakṣa presiding over the month of
Ūrja; resides in the sun's chariot during the Phālguna
(Vi. P.).
Bhā. XII. 11. 44; Vi. II. 10. 18.
text.15175:
Satyajit (V) — a Gandharva with the śiśira sun.
Br. II. 23. 23.
text.15176:
Satyajit (VI) — a Marut of the second gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 93: Vā. 67. 124.
text.15177:
Satyajit (VII) — the Grāmaṇi with the sun in Māśi and
Panguni.
Vā. 52. 22.
text.15179:
Satyajyoti — a Marut of the first gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 91: Vā. 67. 123.
text.15180:
Satyatara — a son of Satyahita who taught him the Ṛg
Samhitā as he learnt from his father.
Va. 60. 29.
text.15181:
Satyadevī — a daughter of Devaka and one of the 7 wives
of Vasudeva.
M. 44. 73.
text.15183:
Satyadharma — one of the ten sons of Dharmasāvarṇi.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 24.
text.15184:
Satyadhṛti (I) — the son of Kṛtimat (Dhṛtimat), and
father of Dhṛḍhanemī.
Bhā. IX. 21. 27: M. 49. 70 Vā. 99. 184: Vi. IV. 19. 49.
text.15185:
Satyadhṛti (II) — a son of Śatānanda, versed in Dha
nurveda. Father of Śaradvān;1 saw an apsaras and dropped
his semen on the kuśa bower; and it developed into
twins — Kṛpa and Kṛpi; king Śantanu in his hunting expedi
tion saw them and brought them up.2 1) Bhā. IX. 21. 35.
2) Vā. 99. 202-04. Vi. IV. 19. 64-8.
text.15186:
Satyadhṛti (III) — a son of Balarāma.
Br. III. 71. 166.
text.15188:
Satyadhṛti (V) — a son of Sāraṇa.
Vā. 96. 164: Vi. IV. 15. 21.
text.15189:
Satyanetra — an Ātreya and a sage of the Raivata epoch.
Br. II. 11. 23: 36. 63: Vā. 28. 20: 62. 54.
text.15190:
Satyabhāmā — (see Satyā) a daughter of Satrājit
(Bhangakāra-M. P.). The latter had mistakenly suspected
Kṛṣṇa of having murdered his brother, and to make amends,
gave his daughter in marriage to Kṛṣṇa though Akrūra and
others had sought her hand before. Mother of 6 sons and
4 daughters among whom were Bhānu and Bhaumarikā.
Terrified at the murder of her father by1 Śatadhanvan
(s.v.) she caused the dead body to be preserved in oil and
went to Hāstinapuram to inform Kṛṣṇa. Saw Syamantaka
with Akrūra and coveted it. Welcomed to Indraprastha by
Draupadī;2 narrated to her the circumstances under which
she married Kṛṣṇa;3 went with Kṛṣṇa during his expedition to
Naraka's city, and then to Indra's abode. Embraced and
blessed by Aditī; complained to Kṛṣṇa that Indrāṇī did not
accord her proper welcome and insisted on the Pārijāta
being taken to Dvārakā. Defeated Kubera who attracted her
husband and was praised by Kṛṣṇa for her valour;4 observed
Kalyāṇini vratam;5 took away the Pārijāta; Indra fought for
it but was defeated; Satyabhāmā gave it back to him saying
that she wanted to teach a lesson to Indrāṇī; returned to
Dvārakā with the Pārijāta presented by Indra.6 1) Bhā. X. 56. 39-44: Br. III. 71. 57-80. Vā. 96. 55-78, 233: Vi.
IV. 13. 71. 151, 154. M. 45-21: 47-13-19 Vi. IV, 13. 64-6: 32. 1.
2) Bhā. X. 57. 7-8, 41 [2]:
3) Ib. X. 71. 42-3: 83. 9, 14.
4) Ib. X. 59. 2; 38-40
[65 (v) 2, 9-10], [28-29], [66 (v) 11-20]: Vi. IV. 15. 35: V. 28. 5:
29. 14 and 35, 30. 26-7:
5) M. 69. 60.
6) Vi. V. 30. 36 to end; 31. 11.
text.15191:
Satyam (I) — one of the seven heavenly worlds;1 Brah
maloka, the 7th loka; equal to Bhūloka in circumference;
six crores of yojanas; in tapolokam; beyond is para and para
at long distance;2 those who go there do not return and are
rid of the samsāra wheel;3 after residing for several years
they get one with the deity Nārāyaṇa.4 1) Br. II. 19. 156: M. 61. 1.
2) Br. IV. 2. 13, 16, 25, 38, 141,
142-44.
3) Ib. IV. 2. 37.
4) Ib. II. 21. 22: 35. 206-08.
text.15192:
Satyam (II) — a god of Ābhūtaraya group.
Br. II. 36. 55.
text.15193:
Satyamitra — one of the names in the second Marut
gaṇa.
Vā. 67. 125.
text.15194:
Satyamedhas — a god of the Sumedhasa group.
Br. II. 36. 58.
text.15195:
Satyambharā — a R. in Plakṣadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 4.
text.15196:
Satyaratā — the Kaikaya princess married to Satya(v)
rata. Triśanku son of Hariścandra.
Br. III. 63. 115: Vā. 88. 117.
text.15197:
Satyaratha (I) — a son of Samaratha and father of Upa
guru.
Bhā. IX. 13. 24.
text.15200:
Satyaloka — (Brahmaloka) the residence of Brahmā
see Satya;1 above Tapoloka.2 1) Bhā. II. 5. 39: XI. 24. 14: Vā. 7. 30: 61. 177:
2) Vi. II. 7. 15.
text.15201:
Satyavatī (I) — a wife of Parāśara, and mother of
Vyāsa;1 in her previous birth Acchodā the mind-born daugh
ter of the Pitṛs; now born as a fisherwoman, of Adrikā
Matsya at the confluence of the Gangā and the Yamunā;2 her
son Vyāsa, compiled the 18 Purāṇas and the Bhārata.3 1) Bhā. II. 7. 36: I. 3. 21: XII. 6. 49: Vā. 1. 2:
2) Br. III. 10. 73-4:
M. 14. 19. Vā. 73. 21-2.
3) M. 53. 70.
text.15202:
Satyavatī (II) — (see Rūka) a daughter of Gādhi and
wife of sage Ṛcīka. As the caru intended for her was taken
by her mother, she gave birth to an unrighteous son, and on
her appeal the sage changed him to an unrighteous grandson.
Mother of Jamadagni; she became converted into the river
Kauśikī; other sons were Śunakśepa and Śunahpuccha;1 com
pared to Dakṣiṇā in yāga.2 1) Bhā. IX. 15. 5-12: Br. III. 66. 36-59: Vā. 65. 93: 91. 66, 85,
92. Vi. IV. 7. 12, 32, 33-4.
2) Br. III. 1. 96: 21. 22.
text.15203:
Satyavatī (III) — a daughter of Kratu and daughter-in
law of Parvaśa.
Br. II. 11. 38.
text.15204:
Satyavatī (IV) — the queen of Śantanu and mother of
Vicitravīrya and Citrāngada;1 at her command Kṛṣṇadvai
pāyana begot Dhṛtarāṣṭra and Pāṇḍu on the widows of Vici
travīrya.2 1) Vi. IV. 20. 34.
2) Ib. IV. 20. 38.
text.15205:
Satyavanta — (Satyavat-Bhā. P.) a son of Manu Cākṣuṣa.
Bhā. IV. 13. 16.
text.15206:
Satyavāk — a son of Cākṣuṣa Manu.
Br. II. 36. 79. M. 4. 41: Vā. 62. 67 and 91.
text.15207:
Satyavāk-kṛti — one of the nine sons of Sāvarṇi.
Vā. 100. 21.
text.15208:
Satyavādinī — the goddess enshrined at Mukuṭa.
M. 13. 50.
text.15209:
Satyavān (I) — a son of Dyumatsena and husband of
Sāvitrī; went to the wood, fell unconscious with head-ache
while cutting fuel; the God of Death appeared on the scene;
Sāvitrī noticed him; see Sāvitrī.
M. 208. 12, 210.
text.15210:
Satyavān (II) — a son of Manu and Naḍvalā.
Vi. I. 13. 5.
text.15211:
Satyavrata (I) — a Rājaṛṣi of Draviḍadeśa, born as the
son of Vivasvat, the future Vaivasvata Manu; once when he
was performing his ablutions a fish fell into his hands. He
reared it in a jar and as it grew big it was left in a pond.
It grew bigger and was taken to a number of lakes and rivers
and finally to the sea. Addressed by the king the fish
revealed his true form and warned him against the forth
coming deluge. During the floods Satyavrata, as directed by
Matsya Hari, got with the sages, into the ark, creepers and
plants and seeds and tied the ship to the horn of the fish.
His praise of Hari; heard the Matsya Purāṇa samhitā from
Hari and after the deluge became Vaivasvata Manu, (s.v.);1
a mahātmā.2 1) Bhā. VIII. ch. 24 (whole): IX. 1. 2-3.
2) Br. III. 11. 92.
text.15212:
Satyavrata (II) — a son of Tribandhana, celebrated as
Triśanku (s.v.).
Bhā. IX. 7. 5.
text.15213:
Satyavrata (III) — a son of Trayyāruṇi (Trayyāmuṇa
M. P.) who took to wife Vidarbha's queen; for this un
righteousness he was banished by his father to live with
Śvāpakas; when his father went to the forest there was no
shower for 12 years when Satyavrata performed austeri
ties and helped the sons and wives of Viśvāmitra in their
livelihood; Vasiṣṭha was in charge of the kingdom and did
not invite him; enraged at this he killed his cow and fed
Viśvāmitra's family; Viśvāmitra noticed three departures
from dharma and called him Triśaṅku; Viśvāmitra was
pleased with his aid and took him to heaven with his earthly
body to the wonder of even Vasiṣṭha; his wife was Satya
vratā and son Hariścandra.
Br. III. 63, 77-113: M. 12. 37: Vā. 88. 78-117. Vi. IV. 3. 21-4.
text.15214:
Satyavratas (I) — a class of people in Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 27.
text.15216:
Satyaśravas (I) — a son of Vītihotra and father of Uru
śravas.
Bhā. IX. 2. 20.
text.15217:
Satyaśravas (II) — the eldest son of Māṇḍūki, (Mar
kaṇḍeya-Vā. P.) initiated into the portion of the Ṛg Veda
left to him by Indrapramati.
Br. II. 34. 29: Vā. 60. 28.
text.15218:
Satyaśriya — a son of Satyahitā (tara-Vā. P.); had three
pupils Śākalya, Rathitara and Bāṣkali (Bharadvāja); these
in their turn hymned separate Śākhas.
Br. II. 34. 30: Vā. 60. 29-31.
text.15219:
Satyasaha — the father of Svadhāma.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 29.
text.15220:
Satyasena — born of Dharma and Sūnṛtā with the aid of
Satyajit, he got rid of the wicked Yakṣas, Rākṣasas and
others.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 25-26.
text.15222:
Satyahita (I) — a son of Ṛṣabha, and father of Puṣpavān.
Bhā. IX. 22. 7.
text.15223:
Satyahita (II) — a son of Satyaśravas who taught him
the Ṛg Samhitā as he learnt it from his father.
Br. II. 34. 29: Vā. 60. 28.
text.15224:
Satyahita (III) — a son of Puṣpavān and father of
Sudhanva.
Vi. IV. 19. 82.
text.15225:
Satyas — (Jayādevas) the gods of the epoch of Uttama
Manu; twelve in number;1 all sons of Satyā and Uttama.
These are the Yajñiyas of the Tāmasa epoch.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 1. 24: Br. II. 36. 27: III. 4. 29 and 318. Vā. 62,
24 and 37: 66. 8: 67. 37-8.
2) Br. II. 36. 36 and 43.
text.15226:
Satyā (I) — the mother of Hṛdīka-(Bhā. P.).
Bhā. III. 1. 35.
text.15227:
Satyā (II) — a queen of Manthu and the mother of
Bhauvana.
Bhā. V. 15. 15.
text.15228:
Satyā (III) — a daughter of Nagnajit (s.v.) and a queen
of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 58. 32-55: Br. III. 71. 242 and 52: M. 47. 13: Vi. V.
28. 3.
text.15229:
Satyā (IV) — the mother of Hari by name Satya (yajña)
in the Uttama epoch.
Br. III. 3. 115: Vi. III. 1. 38.
text.15231:
Satyā (VI) — a daughter of Śaibya, a queen of Bṛhan
manā and mother of Vijaya.
M. 48. 105: Vā. 99. 115-16.
text.15232:
Satyā (VII) — a daughter of Dakṣa and wife of Śiva.
Vā. 65. 20.
text.15235:
Satyāṅgas — a class of people in Plakṣadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 4.
text.15236:
Satyāyu — a son of Raudrāśva.
Bhā. IX. 20. 4.
text.15237:
Satyāyus — a son of Purūravas and Ūrvaśī; father of
Śrutamjaya.
Bhā. IX. 15. 1-2.
text.15238:
Satra (I) — a sacrifice in Naimiṣa extending over a thou
sand years;1 at Kurukṣetra;2 by Indra for 500 years.3 1) Bhā. I. 1. 4: Vā. 2. 13-14: 23. 19: 54. 2.
2) Br. II. 1. 17.
3) Vi.
IV. 5. 1, 3.
text.15239:
Satra (II) — a son of Svāyambhuva Manu.
Br. II. 13. 104.
text.15240:
Satra (III) — one of the ten sons of Kardama.
Br. II. 14. 9.
text.15241:
Satrājita — (Satrājit-M. P.) a son of Nimna (Nighna
Br. and Vi. P.) a friend of God Āditya; afraid of Kṛṣṇa, be
friended him by bestowing his daughter and the jewel Sya
mantaka on Kṛṣṇa. This jewel was given to him as a present
by the Sun god. Wearing it Satrājita made the citizens of
Dvārakā blind by its splendour. It was placed in a separate
house to be worshipped as God; refused to part with it
when Kṛṣṇa demanded it for the Yadu king. His brother Pra
sena while out a hunting took it to the forest where a lion
killed him. Jāmbavan killed the lion and took the jewel
and gave it to his daughter. Satrājita suspected Kṛṣṇa of
killing his brother and depriving him of the jewel. Kṛṣṇa
went to the forest, tracked the steps which led to the cave
of Jāmbavan, and after defeating him took his daughter and
the jewel to Dvārakā. In a public assembly Satrājita was
sent for and the jewel was given to him by Kṛṣṇa. Satrājita's
concern how to befriend Kṛṣṇa. He offered his daughter
and the jewel to him. He married the daughter Satyabhāmā
but returned the jewel to him;1 married the ten daughters of
Kaikeya who gave birth to 101 sons. the eldest of whom
was Bhaṅgakāra;2 other members of the family, Akrūra,
Śatadhanvā and others who wished to marry Satyabhāmā
became jealous and plotted to kill Satrājit; Śatadhanvā mur
dered him while asleep; in order to avenge his death and
also to take the jewel, Kṛṣṇa pursued him and killed him.3 1) Bhā X. ch. 56 (whole): IX. 24. 13; Br. III. 71. 21-60; Vi. V. 13.
10, 14.
2) M. 45. 17, 19.
3) Vi. IV. 13. 67-100.
text.15242:
Satrājitī — a queen of Kṛṣṇa.
Vi. V. 28. 5.
text.15243:
Satva (I) — a son of Purūdva(ha) and an Aikṣvāki;
father of Sātvata.
Br. III. 70. 48; Vā. 95. 47.
text.15244:
Satva (II) — a son of Raivata Manu.
M. 9. 21.
text.15245:
Satvajyoti — one of the names in the first Marut gaṇa.
Vā. 67. 123.
text.15246:
Satvata — a son of Amśu; the line of Sātvatas came after
him;1 father of a number of reputed sons like Bhajamāna.2 1) Vi. IV. 12. 43-4.
2) Ib. IV. 13. 1.
text.15247:
Satvadanta — a son of Vasudeva and Bhadrā.
Br. III. 71. 173; Vā. 96. 171.
text.15248:
Satvadaśva — one of the three sons of Samara.
Vā. 99. 177.
text.15250:
Satvam — the quality of jñānam.
Br. IV. 3. 32-3, 45.
text.15251:
(Sarva) Satvaruta — Language of all living beings known
to Brahmadatta by the grace of Cakrapāṇi.
M. 20. 38; 21. 1, 15.
text.15253:
Satsaṅga — the need for and value of; Kṛṣṇa's speech to
Uddhava on its importance.
Bhā. XI. 12. 2-7.
text.15258:
Sadaśva (II) — a son of Samara.
M. 49. 54: Vi. IV. 19. 41.
text.15262:
Sadasya — the father of Upadānavī.
Br. III. 6. 23.
text.15263:
Sadasyas — for a sacrifice; members of a sacrificial meet
ing; Sanaka and other sages formed the Sadasyas for Soma's
Rājasūya;1 in the army of the Devas at the Tārakāmaya.2 1) Vā. 1. 21; 97. 29.
2) M. 23. 21. Ib. 174. 5: 246. 42.
text.15265:
Sadasyu — not to marry with Angiras, Kutsas, etc.
M. 196. 37.
text.15266:
Sadasyumat — a mantrakṛt and of Angirasa branch.
Vā. 59. 99.
text.15267:
Sadācandra (I) — the king after Bhoga.
Br. III. 71. 181.
text.15268:
Sadācandra (II) — the first king of Vidiśa.
Vā. 99. 367.
text.15269:
Sadāmiṣā — a R. from the Pāriyātra hill.
Br. II. 16. 28.
text.15273:
Sadāśiva (I) — the Lord at Gokarṇam worshipped by
Bhagīratha.
Br. III. 56, 17, 39; IV. 8. 33; 39. 120.
text.15274:
Sadāśiva (II) — a name of Vighneśvara.
Br. IV. 44. 67; Vā. 62. 32.
text.15277:
Sadrama — a son of Kali and a cannibal; wife Tāmasī,
also known as Pūtanā; had one hand.
Vā. 84. 10-2.
text.15278:
Sadvatī — a daughter of Prītī and Pulastya; wife of Bha
ratāgni and mother of Parjanya.
Vā. 11. 19, 27; 28. 16.
text.15280:
Sadhyā — a wife of Dharma; sons known as Sādhyas,
participators in yajña.
Vā. 66. 2, 12.
text.15281:
Sanaka (I) — a mind-born son of Brahmā; went on a
visit to Vaikuṇṭha with his brothers; obstructed by Jaya and
Vijaya, cursed them; and this was approved by Kṛṣṇa. His
joy to see Hari; the avatār of Śiva; a son of Kanka; a celi
bate who waits on Hari; went with the latter to Pṛthu's sacri
fice; was taught the knowledge of yoga by Hari in the form
of a Hamsa and in the presence of Brahmā;2 entered Umā
vanam and seeing Śiva sporting with Umā, returned.3 He and
others formed the Sadasyas for Soma's Rājasūya;4 got mokṣa
through jñānam.5
^1 Bhā. III. 12. 4; 15. 12-13, 30 and 34; 16. 1-4, 25-28; Vā. 9. 72; 23.
131; 101. 337; 105. 2; Vi. VI. 4. 5. 2) Bhā. IV. 8. 1: 19. 6. 29 42; X.
39. 53; XI. 13. (whole).
3) Br. III. 36. 5 and 52; 60. 23; IV. 15. 8 and
40; 39. 56; 47. 66.
4) M. 23. 21; 102. 17; 245. 77.
5) Vā. 24. 79.
text.15284:
Sanatkumāra (I) — a son of Brahmā and elder brother
of Śiva; met by Pṛthu, he taught him ātmajñāna; one of the
twelve who knew of Hari's dharma; did not comprehend his
māyā; present at the anointing of Vāmana; praised the Lord
and Aditi;1 with other sages serve the Ganges;2 Bhagavān
asked Nandikeśvara about the shrines where Maheśvara
stands pillar like (Sthāṇu);3 created first with Ṛbhu and
Kratu; when born was called Kumāra;4 a son of Kanka, an
avatār of Śiva was under father's control;5 one of the chief
sages;6 spoke to Aila on the śrāddha.7 1) Bhā. I. 3. 6; III. 8. 3; 12. 4; IV. 16. 25; 17. 5. 22. 6, 18-40; 23. 9
and 41; VI. 3. 20; VIII. 23. 20, 26-7; IX. 4. 57; XI. 16. 25; M. 4. 27.
2) Ib. 160. 16.
3) Ib. 141. 77; 162. 13; 181. 2-4.
4) Vā. 9. 72, 106; Br. I.
5. 79.
5) Vā. 23. 132; 24. 79: 25. 92; 30. 85; 35. 45; 56. 86.
6) Ib. 5. 4.
7) Vi. III. 14. 11.
text.15285:
Sanatkumāra (II) — a son of Āyu;1 a Vairāja god in
Tapolokam;2 spoke of Mārtāṇḍa episode;3 in Kurukṣetra;4
present at Soma's Rājasūya.5 1) Br. III. 3. 24.
2) Ib. IV. 2. 214, 35.
3) Ib. III. 7. 296.
4) Ib. III:
10. 87; 13. 66.
5) Ib. III. 19. 54; 64. 24.
text.15286:
Sanadvāja (I) — a son of Śuci, and father of Ūrdhva
ketu.
Bhā. IX. 13. 22.
text.15287:
Sanadvāja (II) — an Angirasa and mantrakṛt; the 12th
Vedavyāsa.
Br. II. 32. 110; 35, 119.
text.15288:
Sanadvāja (III) — a son of Ūrjavaha and father of
Śakuni.
Br. III. 64. 20.
text.15289:
Sananda (I) — a mind-born son of Brahmā; his visit to
Viṣṇuloka.
Bhā. III. 12. 4; VII. 1. 35.
text.15290:
Sananda (II) — a Brahmaṛṣi; water oblation to, after
bath.
M. 102. 17.
text.15291:
Sanandana — a son of Brahmā; fit to contemplate on the
glory of Kapila; came to see Trivikrama avatār of Viṣṇu;
honoured for the Śrutigītā1 by the assembly members of
Brahmā;1 a son of Kaṅka an avatār of Śiva; got mokṣa by
jñānam;2 a perfect sage.3 1) Bhā. VIII. 21. 1; IX. 8. 24; X. 87. 12-13, 42; Vā. 9. 72; 101. 337.
Vi. II. 7. 13.
1) Bhā. VIII. 21. 1; IX. 8. 24; X. 87. 12-13, 42; Vā. 9. 72; 101. 337.
Vi. II. 7. 13.
2) Vā. 23. 131; 24. 79; Vi. I. 4. 27, 30; 7. 9; V. 18; 42;
3) Ib. VI. 7. 50.
text.15292:
Sanātana (I) — a mind-born son of Brahmā;1 a son of
Kaṅka, an avatār of Śiva; got mokṣa by jñānam;2 a Brahma
ṛṣi.3 1) Bhā. III. 12. 4; Vā. 9. 72; 101. 337.
2) Ib. 23. 131; 24. 79; 61. 155
and 161.
3) M. 102. 17.
text.15294:
Sanātanadharma — the eternal dharma of all1 comprises
being faithful, not being covetous, tapas, pity to creatures,
control, celibacy, truth, anukrośa, patience and courage.2 1) Vā. 57. 116.
2) Br. II. 30. 37-38; M. 143. 32.
text.15296:
Sanerujā — a R. from the Ṛkṣa hills.
Br. II. 16. 31.
text.15297:
Saṃtati — a son of Alarka, and father of Sunītha.
Bhā. IX. 17. 8.
text.15298:
Saṃtatī (I) — (see Sannatī); a daughter of Dakṣa and
wife of Kratu;1 gave birth to Vālakhilyas.2 1) Br. II. 9. 56; Vā. 28. 31; Vi. I. 7. 25.
2) Ib. I. 10. 11.
text.15299:
Saṃtatī (II) — a R. of Kuśadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 62.
text.15300:
Saṃtateyu — a son of Raudrāśva.
Bhā. IX. 20. 4.
text.15302:
Saṃtanu — rescued the Gautamas, twin children of
Satyadhṛti.
M. 50. 11.
text.15303:
Saṃtardana (I) — a son of Dhrṣṭaketu, and a Kekaya; a
brother of Bhadrā; took active part in the Rājasūya of
Yudhiṣṭhira.
Bhā. IX. 24. 38; X. 58. 56; 75. 6.
text.15304:
Saṃtardana (II) — a son of Kaikaya and Śrutakīrtī.
Br. III. 71. 157; Vā. 96. 156; Vi. IV. 14. 42.
text.15305:
Saṃtāna (I) — a son of Ugra Dīkṣita and Dīkṣā.
Br. II. 10. 83; Vā. 27. 55.
text.15306:
Saṃtāna (II) — a son of Brahman (Dīkṣita).
Vi. I. 8. 11.
text.15307:
Saṃtānakas — the first worlds created by Brahmā from
the gloomy mass. Here are Pitṛs, sons of the progenitor
Virājas.
Br. III. 9. 52: 10. 3.
text.15308:
Saṃti — appellation mahāprāñjña (very wise); honoured
for story-telling.
Vā. 103. 6.
text.15309:
Saṃtya — one of the days of sacrifice.
Vā. 29. 18 and 26; 62. 137; 67. 50.
text.15310:
Saṃtoṣa (I) — a son of Dakṣinā, and a Tuṣita god.
Bhā. IV. 1. 7-8.
text.15311:
Saṃtoṣa (II) — a son of Tuṣṭi.
Br. II. 9. 59; Vā. 10. 34.
text.15312:
Saindamśa — one of the 28 hells, where theft is punished;
visited by those who do not fulfill vows undertaken and
others who do not perform rituals.
Bhā. V. 26. 7; Br. IV. 2. 149, 173-6; Vā. 101. 148. Vi. II. 6. 5,
28.
text.15314:
Saṃdāsa (II) — a son of Sudāsa and father of Saha
deva.
Vi. IV. 19. 71.
text.15316:
Saṃdhi (I) — a diplomatic means; alliance with enemies
should be sought to gain one's object, even as the serpent
with rat.
Bhā. VIII. 6. 20.
text.15317:
Saṃdhi (II) — a son of Prasuśruta, and father of Amar
ṣaṇa.
Bhā. IX. 12. 7.
text.15318:
Saṃdhyā (I) — unfit for the procreative act. At this
time Śiva is said to move with his gaṇas to different places;
personified as woman; approached by Asuras lavishing
praises on her;1 The time between Uṣā and Vyuṣṭi; the time
for worship by means of Gāyatrī to relieve the sun from
being attacked by Mandeha Rākṣasas,2 worship of, twice by
householders.3 1) Bhā. III. 14. 23-24; 20. 29-37.
2) Br. II. 21. 108-13; 22. 11;
Vā. 30. 15; 50. 162; 51. 11.
3) Vi. III. 12. 1.
text.15319:
Saṃdhyā (II) — a R. of the Krauñcadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 75; M. 122. 88; Vā. 49. 69; Vi. II. 4. 55.
text.15320:
Saṃdhyāṃśa — a reckoning of time.
Bhā. III. 11. 20.
text.15322:
Saṃdhyopāsanakarmā — enjoined on the twice born, the
object being to kill the Mandehas (s.v.); non-performance
of sandhyā amounts to killing the sun.
Vi. II. 8. 57.
text.15323:
Sannati (I) — a son of Alarka and father of Sunītha.
Br. III. 67. 69; Vā. 92. 66; Vi. IV. 8. 18-19.
text.15324:
Sannati (II) — a daughter of Devala and queen of Brah
madatta, the Pāñcāla king; she was in one of her previous
births the cow of Garga killed by the sons of Kauśika for
food during famine. She had great attainments and was
a Brahmavādinī;1 once she went with the king to the pleasure
garden where the latter broke into laughter at the love
quarrel between two ants; the queen took it as an insult to
her and threatened to leave him; the king after a penance
came to recognise his previous birth by the grace of Viṣṇu
and leaving the kingdom to his son retired from the world;
the queen who caused all this fell, but ultimately got salva
tion due to her repentance.2 1) M. 20. 26.
2) Ib. 21. 19-24, 36-40.
text.15325:
Sannati (III) — a daughter of Dakṣa; wife of Kratu
(Marīci-Vi. P.) (see also Santati and Samtati);1 sons, Vāla
khilya sages, 6000 in number.2 1) Vā. 10. 28, 31; Vi. I. 7. 7, 25.
2) Br. II. 9. 52; 11. 36.
text.15326:
Sannatimat — a son of Sumati, and father of Kṛti(a).
Bhā. IX. 21. 28: M. 49. 74; Vi. IV. 19. 49-50.
text.15327:
Sannateṣu — a son of Raudrāśva.
Vi. IV. 19. 2.
text.15328:
Sanniveśa — a son of Tvaṣṭri and Racanā.
Bhā. VI. 6. 44.
text.15329:
Sannyāsa(yati) — giving up of karmas by.
Br. II. 32. 58; M. 145. 54.
text.15331:
Sannateyu — the ninth son of Raudrāśva.
Vā. 99. 125.
text.15333:
Sapiṇḍīkaraṇam — the ceremony usually done on the
12th day of one's death; after this the dead person becomes
eligible for pārvaṇa and the gṛhasta becomes eligible for per
forming nāndiśrāddha; in sapiṇḍīkaraṇa fresh invocation to
the devas;1 leads up to the cleansing of the pollution.2 1) M. 18. 15-17; Vi. III. 13. 26.
2) M. 16. 58.
text.15334:
Saptaṛṣis (I) — the sons of Brahmā who bear the Gaṅgā
in their locks; with the constellations traversing Maghas, com
menced the Kali age; when they move to Pūrvāṣāḍha, there
began the reign of Nanda;1 separate for every epoch; cursed
by Maheśvara were born in Janaloka, and born in Cākṣuṣa
epoch during the Vāruṇa sacrifice.2 Kuṇḍam of, near
Agastya's hermitage;3 look on the first Prajāpati emerging
out of Ekārṇava;4 residents of Brahmakṣetra.5 1) Bhā. V. 17. 3; XII. 2. 27-33.
2) Br. II. 36. 18; 23. 38; 26. 30;
III. 1. 13.
3) Ib. III. 5. 80; 13. 62; 35. 43.
4) Ib. I. 1. 185.
5) Vā: 59:
105-106.
text.15335:
Saptaṛṣis (II) — the seven sages born on the earth
in Dvāpara; conquered death by foregoing desire for
progeny; were followed in the path of Ūrdhvaretasas
by 88,000 others; all immortals decline after the
deluge;1 their permanent abode in front of Dhruva;2
a lakh of yojanas above Śanaiścara;3 lived with Magha
during the age of Parīkṣit;4 their one year = 3030 years
of our reckoning;5 gave out śrautadharma at the com
mencement of the Tretāyugam;6 remembered by Indra they
went to Umā and Śiva and got their marriage celebrated; they
tested Umā's firmness in her love in different ways and found
her not wanting at all.7 1) M. 124. 106-11.
2) Br. II. 21. 168; 24. 122; 29. 17, 45; IV. 2.
134. M. 4. 37: 128. 74. Vi. II: 9. 10.
3) Vā. 53. 97: 101. 134: Vi. II.
7. 9.
4) M. 273. 39, 44.
5) Ib. 142. 13. Vā. 57. 18.
6) M. 142. 40-41;
Br: II. 32. 34, 42, 91-4; 35. 103, 184, 189.
7) M. 154. 311-41.
text.15337:
Saptagaṇas — of the Sūryamaṇḍala in different months.
Vi. II. 10. 1-18.
text.15338:
Saptagodāvarī — a R. visited by Balarāma; fit for śrāddha
offerings.2
^1 Bhā. X. 79. 12. 2) Br. III. 13. 19; M. 22. 78; Vā. 77. 19.
text.15340:
Saptatāla — (śilpa) the images of Vārāha, Nārasimha
and Vāmana.
M. 259. 2.
text.15341:
Saptatuṃgama — an epithet of the sun.
M. 55. 8.
text.15342:
Saptadvīpas — the seven islands of the earth.
Vā. 33. 4; 34. 7; 70. 18; 93. 89; 94. 14. 99. 17-133; 102. 28; 110. 22.
text.15343:
Saptadhātu — a horse yoked to the moon's chariot.
M. 126. 52.
text.15344:
Saptanada — fit for śrāddha offering.
Br. III. 13. 58.
text.15346:
Saptamapadam — a rite in marriage.
Br. III. 63. 96.
text.15347:
Saptamīsnapanam — a vrata taught by the Sun god to
Kritavīrya of the Haihaya clan; sacred to Rudra; a pratimā
of Dharmarāja given as gift to the guru is good for the
children in a family.
M. 68. 3, 12-42.
text.15348:
Saptaratnas — (of emperors); cakra, chariot, precious
stones, consort, treasure, horses and elephants.
Vā. 57. 68.
text.15349:
Saptaraśmi — the sun;1 burns down the three worlds in
the pralaya.2 1) Br. III. 3. 10; IV. 1. 134.
2) Vā. 66. 127.
text.15351:
Saptavatī — a R. in Bhāratavarṣa.
Bhā. V. 19. 18.
text.15353:
Saptavindhyam — are Hrīmkāra Praṇava, Gīta, Pras
tāva, Pratihotra, Upadravam and nidhānam.
Br. II. 33. 39.
text.15354:
Saptaśrotas — the hermitage in the Himālayas where
Dhṛtarāṣṭra spent his last days.
Bhā. I. 13. 51.
text.15355:
Saptasapti — the Sun God with seven rays emitting fire
before the deluge.
M. 2. 4; 55. 8.
text.15356:
Saptasambhūti — the seven births of Jayādevas in
different manvantaras having seven characteristics.
Vā. 67. 46-7.
text.15357:
Saptasāgaradānam — a gift; seven gold kuṇḍas (7 palas
to 1,000) with salt, milk, ghee, jaggery, curd, sugar and
water with the respective deities, Brahmā, Keśava, Maheś
vara, Bhāskara, Niśādhipa, Lakṣmī and Pārvatī; the gift after
Vāruṇa homa; the giver attains Śivalokam.
M. 274. 10: 287. 1-15.
text.15358:
Saptasūryas — the seven Suns, burning up the universe.
Vā. 7. 52.
text.15359:
Saptaskandha — of Vāyu where live the seven gaṇas.
Vā. 2. 40.
text.15361:
Saptāṅga — the seven limbs of a kingdom; svāmi, amātya,
janapada, durga, daṇḍa, kośa and mitra.
M. 220. 19.
text.15362:
Saptārciṣam — mantra to be recited at the śrāddha; leads
to overlordship;1 to be recited daily in honour of Pitṛs and
their seven gaṇas; in nine verses.2 1) Br. III. 11. 22-33.
2) Vā. 74. 20-29.
text.15363:
Saptāśva — a sage of the Raivata epoch.
M. 9. 20.
text.15365:
Sabindu — a Mt. to the east of Aruṇoda.
Vā. 36. 19.
text.15366:
Sabhā — a Durbar; of the king,1 a description of Sagara's
assembly; composed of Brahmans, Kṣatriyas, Paurajānapada,
relatives and friends;2 of Kṛṣṇa where there were readings
of sacred texts and the Purāṇas;3 public halls of Tripuram;4
of Maya; respective seats for members; the address of the
chief;5 of Indra;6 of Tāraka; servants with canes illtreated
the devas where the seasons served him as also Siddhas, Kin
naras and Gandharvas the latter by music;7 of Hiraṇya
kaśipu; here were all trees plants and birds, animals, Apsaras
and other ladies, Asuras of distinction full of splendour and
wealth, the equal of which has neither been heard of nor
seen.8 1) Br. II. 25. 101: Vā. 30. 279; 54. 105; 96. 92.
2) Br. III. 49. 31;
50. 16, 17-20: 54. 24: 55. 20.
3) M. 69. 10-11.
4) Ib. 130. 5.
5) Ib. 131.
20f.
6) Ib. 148. 61: Vā. 1. 92.
7) M. 154. 39.
8) Ib. 161. 38-89.
text.15367:
Sabhānar(l)a — a son of Anu (4th son of Yayāti) and
father of Kālanara (Kālānala Br. and Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 23. 1: Br. III. 74. 13. M. 48. 10: Vā. 99. 13: Br. IV. 18.
1-2.
text.15368:
Sabhāsadasa — members of the assembly;1 residence of.2 1) Vā. 101. 283.
2) M. 215. 25: 246. 38: 254. 26.
text.15369:
Sabhya — a son of Śamsya agni.
Vā. 29. 12.
text.15370:
Sabhyās — members of the assembly, punished for con
scious misdirection of justice.
M. 227. 211-3.
text.15371:
Sabhyapadam — in Gayā; śrāddha here leads to the fruit
of jyotiṣṭoma.
Vā. 111. 51.
text.15372:
Sama — one of the 20 Amitābha gods.
Br. IV. 1. 17: Vā. 100. 17.
text.15373:
Samacetana — a Marut of the 6th gaṇa.
Br. III. 5-97.
text.15374:
Samañja — a Pārāvata god.
Br. II. 36. 13: Vā. 62. 12.
text.15376:
Samanantara — His wife was Kriyā. Father of Agnis
called Purīṣyas.
Bhā. VI. 18. 4.
text.15377:
Samantapañcakam — a lake of five ponds dug by Para
śurāma at Kurukṣetra to propitiate his Pitṛs.
Br. III. 47. 11-14.
text.15379:
Samabuddhi — a son of Atri, the avatār of the 12th
dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 157.
text.15380:
Samam — the eyes of the personified Veda.
Vā. 104. 82.
text.15381:
Samaya (I) — an agreement;1 of Sagara with conquered
chiefs;2 broken by Devas.3 1) Br. II. 26. 26: 35. 16: 36. 135: III. 48. 41. Vā. 55. 25: 88. 138:
91. 12: 96. 59: 100. 52.
2) Br. III. 48. 46.
3) Ib. III. 66. 12-13: 72. 126.
text.15384:
Samayeśvarī — a name of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 77. 18.
text.15385:
Samara (I) — a son of Kāvya; had three sons.
M. 49. 54.
text.15386:
Samara (II) — one of the lineal descendants of Nīpa;
capital Kampilya.
Vā. 99. 176.
text.15387:
Samara (III) — a son of Nīla and lord of Kāmpilya;
father of three sons, Pāra and two others.
Vi. IV. 19. 40-1.
text.15388:
Samaratha — a son of Kṣemādhi, and father of Satya
ratha.
Bhā. IX. 13. 24.
text.15389:
Samvṛtti — a Marut of the sixth gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 97.
text.15390:
Samākhyāta — one of the twenty of Amitābha gaṇa.
Vā. 100. 16.
text.15391:
Samājam — of Gods at Meru; visited by the Earth.
Vi. V. 1. 12.
text.15392:
Samādhi — honourable or āryam, explained by Yayāti
to Aṣṭaka;1 Bhṛgu in samādhi.2 1) M. 41. 4: Vā. 104. 25.
2) M. 193. 26.
text.15395:
Samāna (III) — the mind-born son of Brahmā in the
21st kalpa.
Vā. 21. 47.
text.15396:
Samābhāga — a son of Vajramitra, ruled for 32 years.
M. 272. 30.
text.15397:
Samāheyās — a western country; a tribe;1 of the south.2 1) Br. II. 16. 62: M. 114. 50.
2) Vā. 45. 130.
text.15399:
Samita — a marut of the fifth gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 96.
text.15400:
Samitā — one of the names in the Marutgaṇa.
Vā. 67. 128.
text.15402:
Samiti (I) — one of the names in the fourth Marutgaṇa.
Vā. 67. 127.
text.15404:
Samīcī — an Apsaras in the Sabhā of Hiraṇyakaśipu.
M. 161. 74.
text.15405:
Samīdṛkṣas — one of the names in the Marut gaṇa.
Vā. 67. 128.
text.15406:
Samīraṇa — is Vāyu.
Br. II. 25. 12 etc.: Vā. 101. 325: Vi. V. 1. 58: 18. 56.
text.15408:
Samudgaka (II) — 16 sided in the shape of a small box;
on its sides are candraśālas with two bhūmikas.
M. 269. 38.
text.15409:
Samudra (I) — gave śankha to Pṛthu; the lavaṇa samu
dra encircles Jambūdvīpa.
Bhā. IV. 15. 19: Br. II. 15. 13.
text.15410:
Samudra (II) — Agni at Viśvasya (Viśvavyaca-Br. P.)
located in Brahmasthāna.
Vā. 29. 22: Br. II. 12. 24.
text.15413:
Samudras — the seven seas; source of the waters;1 lord
of rivers;2 southern ocean sacred to Pitṛs;3 rise as the moon
waxes and go down as the moon wanes as also at moon rising
and setting every day; the rise is estimated to be about 115
inches in height;4 the residence of the Lord.5 1) M. 2. 34. Vā. 27. 26: 56. 57.
2) M. 8. 6.
3) Ib. 22. 39.
4) Ib.
123. 32-4.
5) Vā. 97. 22.
text.15414:
Samudramālā — a R. of the Ketumālā continent.
Vā. 44. 20.
text.15415:
Samudrayāyi — one who has crossed the seas.
Vā. 83. 62.
text.15417:
Samudrāntarakas — a Janapada of the Ketumālā con
tinent.
Vā. 44. 10.
text.15418:
Samūla — a Mt. south of the Mānasa.
Vā. 36. 23: 38. 23: 42. 30.
text.15420:
Sañjaya (II) — a son of Raṇejaya (Raṇamjaya-Vā. P.
and Vi. P.).
M. 271. 11: Vā. 99. 288: Vi. IV. 22. 8.
text.15421:
Sañjaya (III) — the name of Vyāsa of the sixteenth
dvāpara; Gokarṇa, the avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 171.
text.15425:
Saṃjīvini(vidyā) — a science which enables one to bring
the dead back to life; known to Śukrācārya and not known
to Bṛhaspati; learnt as a disciple from Śukra by Kaca son of
Bṛhaspati; revived Kaca done to death twice by the Asuras.
M. 25. 13, 36, 54, 65: 27. 19: 249. 4.
text.15426:
Saṃjeya — a son of Kūti; father of Mahiṣmat.
Vā. 94. 5.
text.15427:
Saṃjñā (I) — daughter of Viśvakarman (Tvaṣṭ(r)a-M.
and Br. P.); consort of Sūrya (Vivasvat-Bhā. P.) gave birth
to Manu, Yama and Yamī; unable to bear the effulgence of
her husband, she engaged Chāyā, her servant maid, to take
her place, and left for penance; to Chāyā were born Śanaiś
cara, Manu (Sāvarṇi), Tapatī; finding fault with Yama once
the Sun god discovered Chāyā's identity and after a search
found Samjñā doing penance as a mare in the plains of Utta
rakuru;1 he became a horse in turn and Samjñā as a mare
gave birth to three more children; the two Aśvins and Re
vanta; Viśvakarma filed off the Vaiṣṇava effulgence and
out of this he crafted the discus of Viṣṇu, the trident of Śiva,
the Puṣpakavimāna of Kubera the lance (Śakti) of Kārtikeya
and others.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 13. 8-9: VI. 6. 40: IX. 1. 11: M. 11. 2 and 24-37;
Vā 84. 21; 100. 31.
2) Br. II. 24. 90: III. 59. 22-3; IV. 1. 28: Vi. III.
2. 2-12.
text.15429:
Saṃjñeya — a son of Kunti and father of Mahiṣmat.
Br. III. 69. 5.
