text.15430:
Sampati — a son of Aruṇa and Gṛdhri; father of Vijaya
and Prasaha.
Br. III. 7. 447.
text.15431:
Sampatkarī — managed the elephant corps in the war
with Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 16. 7-13: 22. 37.
text.15432:
Sampatsarasvatī — offered fight to Durmada.
Br. IV. 22. 36-66.
text.15434:
Sampadvasu — one of the seven important rays of the
sun.
Br. II. 24. 66.
text.15436:
Sampāti (I) — a son of Supratīka elephant.
Br. III. 7. 341.
text.15437:
Sampāti (II) — a son of Aruṇa and Śyeni and father of
Babhru and Sighraga; a fabulous bird and brother of
Jaṭāyu.
M. 6. 35: Vā. 69. 327.
text.15441:
Sambuddhas — the enlightened like Ṛbhu and Sanat
kumāra.
Vā. 101. 212.
text.15442:
Sambūta — a son of Yuvanāśva and Narmadā; father of
Anaraṇya.
Br. III. 63. 73.
text.15443:
Sambūti — an elephant daughter of dig-nāgas.
Br. III. 7. 354.
text.15444:
Sambodha(i)nī — a daughter of Jāmbavatī and Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 71. 250; Vā. 96. 241.
text.15447:
Sambhava (II) — at the end of samhāra; impossible to
be told in detail; also nisarga.
Vā. 61. 136-7.
text.15448:
Sambhavakhas — a Janapada of the Bhadrā continent.
Vā. 43. 21.
text.15450:
Sambhāvya — a son of Raivata.
Vi. III. 1. 23.
text.15452:
Sambhūta — a son of Ṭrasadasyu and father of Anaraya.
Vā. 88. 74-75.
text.15454:
Sambhūtī (I) — a wife of Vairāja.
Bhā. VIII. 5. 9.
text.15455:
Sambhūtī (II) — a wife of Jayadratha.
Bhā. IX. 23. 12.
text.15457:
Sambhūtī (IV) (Sambhṛtī) — a daughter of Dakṣa and
wife of (Pulaha) (Vi. P.) Marīci; mother of Pūrṇamāsa and
four daughters.
Vi. I. 7. 7, 25; Br. II. 9. 52 and 55; 11. 11; Vā. 10. 27, 30;
28. 9; Vi. I. 10. 6.
text.15458:
Sambhūtī (V) — the mother of Hari in the Raivata
epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 40.
text.15459:
Sambhūtīs — divya avatārs; Nārāyaṇa, Narasimha and
Vāmana; manuṣya avatārs seven due to Bhṛgu's curse; Dat
tātreya, Māndhāta, Jamadagni, Rāma, Vedavyāsa, Kṛṣṇa
and Kalki.
Vā. 98. 88-104.
text.15460:
Sambhrama (I) — a gaṇa in the service of Kubera.
M. 180. 98.
text.15462:
Sammati — a main stream of Kuśadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 43.
text.15463:
Sammada — the King of fish with a number of children
and grandchildren, observed by sage Saubhari who turned
to the life of a house-holder from that of penance.
Vi. IV. 2. 70.
text.15464:
Sammardana — a son of Vasudeva and Devakī.
Bhā. IX. 24. 54.
text.15465:
Sammūha — a Marut of the 6th gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 97.
text.15466:
Samyadvasu — one of the best seven rays of the sun; the
root of Agni.
Vā. 53. 45, 48.
text.15467:
Samyama (I) — the son of Dhūmrākṣasa and father of
Kṛśāśva and Devaja.
Bhā. IX. 2. 34.
text.15469:
Samyamanī(ā) — the city of Yama, south of Meru;1
reached by Kṛṣṇa and Balarāma to recover the dead son of
Sāndīpani;2 visited by Arjuna to recover the dead child of
Dvārakā Brāhmaṇa.3 1) Bhā. V. 21. 7; VI. 3. 3; Br. II. 21: 31; M. 124. 22; Vā. 50. 88.
2) Vi. II. 8. 9; Bhā. X. 45. 42-46.
3) Ib. X. 89. 43.
text.15470:
Samyāti (I) — a son of Bahugaṇa (Bahugata-Vi. P.) and
father of Ahamyātī.
Bhā. IX. 20. 3; Vi. IV. 19. 1.
text.15471:
Samyāti (II) — a son of Nahuṣa;1 became a muni to
attain mokṣa and Brahmāhood.2 1) Bhā. IX. 18. 1; M. 24. 50; Br. III. 68. 12. Vi. IV. 10. 1.
2) Vā.
93. 13-14.
text.15472:
Samyuta — a son of Daśaratha and father of Śāliśūka.
Vi. IV. 24. 30.
text.15473:
Saṃyūpa — a son of Śūra and Bhojā.
M. 46. 3.
text.15474:
Samyogajam — a sin of four kinds; the doer, the aid,
cause of action and approver; each ten times greater than
the other.
Br. IV. 8. 39-40.
text.15475:
Samrambha — one of the names in the fourth Marut
gaṇa.
Vā. 67. 127.
text.15476:
Samrāṭ (I) — a son of Citraratha and Ūrṇā; had a son
Marīci on Utkalā.
Bhā. V. 15. 14-15.
text.15477:
Samrāṭ (II) — Vairāja Puruṣa; got that name as having
assumed the form of Sāma; also Vairāja Manu (see Vairāja).
Br. II. 9. 39; Vā. 10. 15; 94. 23.
text.15478:
Samrāṭ (III) — the daughter of Kardama, the pro
genitor.
Br. II. 14. 8.
text.15479:
Samrāṭ (IV) — the title of a king who conquers all Bhā
ratavarṣa;1 the title of Hariscandra after his Rājasūya,2 of
Kārtavīrya.3 1) Br. II. 16. 16; M. 114. 15. Vā. 45. 86;
2) Ib. 88. 118.
3) Br. III.
16. 23.
text.15480:
Samrāṭ (V) — a daughter of Priyavrata.
Vā. 33. 8; Vi. II. 1. 5.
text.15481:
Samrāṭ (ḍ) agni — also Kṛśānu — one of the 8 Agnis wor
shipped by Brahmans.
Br. II. 12. 21; Vā. 29. 19.
text.15482:
Samvatsara (I) — a sage in the Darūvana.
Br. II. 27. 104.
text.15483:
Samvatsara (II) — a part of the five-year yuga;1 a year,
the first among years; is Agni; represented by Kāvya pitṛs;2
of different kinds — dīvyasamvatsara, Dhruvasamvatsara,
Pitṛsamvatsara, and Saptaṛṣisamvatsara.3 1) Bhā. III. 11. 14; V. 22. 7; Vi. II. 8. 71-2.
2) Br. II. 21. 131; 24.
57, 141; 28. 15; III. 8. 17; 72. 30.
3) Ib. II. 28. 21; 29. 10, 16 and 18.
text.15486:
Samvatsara (V) — Vārāha Viṣṇu got the form of.
Vā. 23. 104.
text.15487:
Saṃvaraṇa — a son of Ṛkṣa; and husband of Tapatī, and
father of Kuru.
Bhā. VI. 6. 41; VIII. 13. 10; IX. 22. 3-4. M. 50. 20; Vā. 99. 214;
Vi. IV. 19. 75-6.
text.15488:
Samvarta (I) — a son of Angiras, and a yogin; helped
Marutta in his yajñas;1 enabled Prāmśu's son to go to
Heaven.2 1) Bhā. IX. 2. 26; Vā. 65. 101.
2) Br. III. 61. 5.
text.15489:
Samvarta (II) — a son of Svarūpa and a gotrakāra;1
attained salvation at Benares.2 1) M. 196. 4.
2) Ib. 180. 63.
text.15490:
Samvarta (III) — a priest of Maruttacakravarti who
went bodily to heaven with all his relations and Marutta
taking yajña with him; hence Bṛhaspati got angry with him
as he anticipated the destruction of the world.
Vā. 86. 9, 11.
text.15491:
Samvartaka (I) — a group of clouds ordered by Indra to
inundate Gokula;1 Pralaya clouds.2 1) Bhā. X. 25. 2-7.
2) M. 2. 8; Vā. 77. 7; 100. 156.
text.15492:
Samvartaka (II) — also Aurva and Vaḍavāmukha;1 the
fire that consumes waters; the pralaya fire;2 son of Manyu
mān Agni.3 1) Br. II. 7. 9; 12. 35-6; 22. 43; 25. 45, 55.
2) Ib. IV. 1. 152; 2. 50.
Vā. 6. 29; 54. 57
3) Ib. 29. 33.
text.15493:
Samvartta — a son of Pathya and Atharvāngiras.
Br. III. 1. 106.
text.15494:
Samvarttakas — massive clouds like elephants and of
different colours pouring down rain for 100 years during the
period of dissolution.
Vi. V. 11. 1; VI. 3. 31.
text.15495:
Samvaha — the chief of the fourth Vātaskandha.
Br. III. 5. 85; M. 163. 32.
text.15496:
Saṃvedhas — with Bṛhaspati in rāśi.
Br. II. 23. 87.
text.15497:
Saṃśaya — a son of Unmāda and grandson of Nārā
yaṇa and Śrī.
Br. II. 11. 4.
text.15500:
Saṃsāra — compared to an ocean; the evils of family life
as explained by the king of mountains; the necessity of
children, the difficulty and anxiety in procuring good hus
bands for daughters, etc;1 the duhham of, explained.2 1) M. 55. 27; 154. 145-174; Vā. 101. 195-204.
2) Vi. VI. 5. 10-56.
text.15501:
Saṃsāram — (tāmasa) of six kinds — man, animal
(paśu), beast (mṛga), bird (pakṣi), snake (sarīsṛpu) and
vegetation (sthāvara); sātvikam: Brahmā and others;
rājasam — the intervening viṣṭambhaka among the 14
sthānas.
Vā. 14. 35-41; 100. 203.
text.15503:
Saṃsāramocanam — a tīrtha sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 67.
text.15504:
Saṃsiddhakaraṇa — a son of Yakṣa and Kratusthali.
Vā. 69. 142.
text.15505:
Saṃskāras — purificatory rites for house-holders; these
do not help without the eight ātmaguṇas (s.v. Kriyā yoga).
M. 52. 17, 30.
text.15507:
Samhatāśva — a son of Nikumbha;1 well-versed and pos
sessed of prowess in war; had two sons Kṛśāśva and Akṣa
yāśva.2 1) Br. III. 63. 64. M. 12. 33
2) Vā. 88. 63.
text.15508:
Samhāra (I) — a Bhairava god on the sixth parva of
Geyacakra.
Br. IV. 19. 79.; 20. 92.
text.15509:
Samhāra (II) — the pralaya at the end of Kaliyuga; first
covering by waters, next by tejas, then by ākāśa, then by
bhūtadi, then by mahat, and lastly by avyakta;1 the period
ending all manvantaras, each continuing for several yugas;2
impossible to be told in detail.3 1) Vā. 21. 11; 102. 4, 27-31;
2) Vā. 100. 118;
3) Vā. 61. 126-27.
text.15510:
Samhāram pādam — the fourth pāda of the Purāṇa;1 of
the Vā. P. of 1,000 ślokas, represents the Kali yuga.2 1) Br. IV. 1. 2-5, 3. 4.
2) Vā. 32. 64; 100. 2 and 5.
text.15511:
Samhitā — Vedic texts;1 three Samhitās composed by
eight sages.2 1) Br. II. 29. 52; 31. 11-13. M. 264. 23; Vā. 58. 13; 104. 86.
2) Ib.
61. 1-2, 4, 121.
text.15512:
Samhūtī — (Sadvatī)? A wife of Agni and mother of
Parjanya.
Vā. 28. 16.
text.15513:
Samhṛti — a Mantrakṛt of the Angirasa branch.
Vā. 59. 98.
text.15514:
Samhrāda — a son of Hiraṇyakaśipu, wife Kṛti, and
father of Pañcajana.
Bhā. VI. 18. 13-14; Br. III. 5-34; Vā. 67. 70.
text.15515:
Samhlāda — a son of Hiraṇyakaśipu; his sons were
Nivātakavacās; not to be killed by Devas, Gandharvas,
Uragas, Rākṣasas; but killed by Arjuna by the grace of Śiva.
M. 6. 9, 28-9.
text.15517:
Saraghā — the queen of Bindumat and mother of
Madhu.
Bhā. V. 15. 15.
text.15518:
Saramā (I) — (Sārama); the messenger of Indra, of
whom the Dānavas were afraid.
Bhā. V. 24. 30.
text.15519:
Saramā (II) — one of Kaśyapa's wives. Her offspring
were beasts of prey.
Bhā. VI. 6. 26.
text.15521:
Sarayū — (Mahānadī) R. in Bhāratavarṣa; its source
was visited by Balarāma who then travelled to Prayāgā
along its bank. The river of Ayodhyā; Asamanjasa used to
throw into it the children who were his playmates.1 R. from
the Himālayas;2 sacred tīrtha;3 one of the 16 rivers married
by Havyavāhana;4 in the Vaidyuta hill and has its source
in the Mānasa lake;5 a Rākṣasa named Brahmapāda lived in
the forest here called Vaibhrājyam;6 in the chariot of Tripu
rāri.7 1) Bhā. V. 19. 18; IX. 8. 17; X. 79. 9-10; Br. III. 12. Ib. 15; III. 51.
65; 55. 11; Vā. 108. 79;
2) Br. II. 16. 25.
3) M. 22. 19.
4) Ib. 51. 14; Vā. 29.
14.
5) Br. II. 18. 15 and 70; M. 114. 21; 121. 17.
6) Vā. 45. 95; 47. 15.
7) M. 133. M; 163. 60.
text.15523:
Sarasvatī (I) — (Vāk Devī); Viśvarūpā, a mind-born
daughter of Brahmā who began to love her. Being criticised
by his sons for it, he gave up his body in shame. Presented
Pṛthu with a wreath, and was offered a wreath of pearls by
Viśvakarman. Gave away a string of beads to the Lord.
Gave Vīṇa to Kumāra; a Mother goddess.2 The Goddess of
Learning;3 enshrined in the faces of Brahmā,4 Gāyatrā5 in
the 23rd Kalpa; constitutes 32 akṣaras; is prakṛti and Gaulī,6
source of all worlds;7 of four feet.8 Presented to Skanda a
great vīra.9
^1 Bhā. I. 24; III. 12, 28 and 33; IV. 15. 16. VIII. 8. 16; Br. II.
26. 45, M. 3. 32. 171. 33; 260. 44. 2) Br. III. 10. 47; 35. 44. IV. 7. 72;
19. 70, 73; 20. 101; 36. 19; 40. 8;
3) M. 1. 2;
4) Ib. 13. 52;
5) Ib. 246.
57;
6) Vā. 23. 38;
7) Ib. 23. 54-5;
8) Ib. 23. 88;
9) Ib. 72. 45.
text.15524:
Sarasvatī (II) — (Mahānadī) R. in Bhāratavarṣa of
Brahmāvarta, in Kurukṣetra. Here Ūrvaśī enjoyed
water sports with her companions when Purūravas found
her a second time.1 The Brahmanadī; on its banks Vyāsa
composed the Bhārata, and his hermitage was on the western
bank. Here he heard the Bhāgavata from Nārada.2 Here
Paraśurāma had his avabhṛta bath.3 On its banks was the
Ambikāvana.4 Here sages practised tapas. At its source
Pṛthu performed a hundred aśvamedhas.5 Lies on the
way from Dvārakā to Hāstinapura. Flows west at
Prabhāsa; was made to flow back towards a desert
where Ambarīṣa performed sacrifices.6 When the sages per
formed yajña on its bank, a question arose as to who was
the superior god in the world. Bhṛgu, the son of Brahmā
was deputed to find this out.7 Here are eleven places sacred
to Trīta, Uśanas, Manu and others. Vidura had his ablu
tions in all of them.8 Kṛṣṇa sat under an aśvatta tree on its
banks preparing to leave off mortal coil and asked Uddhava
to go to Badarī.9 On its banks Kardama performed austeri
ties for 10,000 years. Its banks filled with hermitages, one
was Kardama's. In it Devahūtī bathed.10 Visited by Bala
rāma.11 Parīkṣit came to hear Dharma at the place where
the R. flows East, complaining to Earth on the advent of
Kali.12 Defined.13 From the Himālayas; fit for śrāddha
offerings;14 a holy river;15 sacred to pitṛs; flows from the
slopes of the Hemakūṭa hill;16 flows through Kurukṣetra;17
scene of talk between Garga and Atri.18 sacred to Devamāta;19
in the chariot of Tripurāri.20 1) Bhā. I. 4. 15; IV. 19. 1; V. 19. 18; IX. 14. 33. II. 9. 44; Br. II.
12. 16; Vā. 45. 95; 55. 43; 108. 59, 78; 109. 21;
2) Bhā. I. 4. 27; 7. 2.
3) Ib. IX. 16. 23.
4) Ib. X. 34. 2 and 4.
5) Ib. IV. 14. 36; 16. 24.
6) Ib. X. 71. 22; IX. 30. 6; IX. 4. 22.
7) Ib. X. 89. 1-2.
8) Bhā. III:
1. 21-22.
9) Ib. III. 4. 3-8.
10) Ib. III. 21. 6; 22. 27. 23. 25. 24: 9:
11) Ib. X. 78. 18-19.
12) Ib. I. 16. 37.
13) VIII. 4. 23-4.
14) Br. II. 16:
24: 27; III. 13. 69; 14. 83; Vi. III. 14. 18.
15) M. 7. 3.
16) Ib. 22. 23.
17) Ib. 121: 64-5; 186. 10; 229. 3.
18) Ib. 239. 18.
19) Ib. 13. 44;
20) Ib.
114. 20; 133. 24.
text.15525:
Sarasvatī (III) — a R. in Śālmalidvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 10.
text.15526:
Sarasvatī (IV) — the mother of Sārvabhauma — Hari.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 17.
text.15527:
Sarasvatī (V) — a wife of Pūrṇamāsa; sons, Viraja and
Parvasa.
Br. II. 11. 12; Vā. 28. 10.
text.15528:
Sarasvatī (VI) — a wife of Dadhīci.
Br. III. 1. 94; Vā. 65. 91.
text.15530:
Sarasvatī (VIII) — a Varṇaśakti; worships Kāmākṣī.
Br. IV. 39. 14; 44. 57 and 71.
text.15531:
Sarasvatī (IX) — the mother of Danu and Diti by
Āditya.
M. 171. 57.
text.15532:
Sarasvatī (X) — a Mt. in the Himālayas.
Vā. 23. 168.
text.15534:
Sarasvatī (XII) — the name of a tīrtha.
Vā. 77. 67.
text.15536:
Sariddhaja (Sīradhvajā) — a son Hrasvaroman dis
covered Sītā in the Agnikṣetra of his Aśvamedha.
Br. III. 64. 15-17.
text.15538:
Sarūpā — a wife of Bhūta; brought forth innumerable
Rudras.
Bhā. VI. 6. 17-18.
text.15539:
Sarūpya — a son of Duṣkanta and father of Aṇḍīra.
Br. III. 74. 5.
text.15540:
Sarga (I) — one of the five sections of the Purāṇa;1 deal
ing with creation of the universe;2 different kinds of;3 Prā
kṛta;4 of Brahmā.5 1) M. 53. 65; Vā. 4. 10; 9. 4; 100. 195. 53; 132; 103. 9.
2) Br. IV.
1. 37; 3 and 26. 31. 4. 5.
3) Ib. I. 153-54; II. 5. 55-8. Vā. 1. 63.
4) Ib. 4. 90; Vi. 1. 5. 19-20, 24.
5) Vā. 8. 36-40.
text.15541:
Sarga (II) — the order of creation; a form of Brahman
known as Puruṣa and Kṣetrajña with the aid of Pradhāna
originated mahat tatva out of which was born ahamkāra;
engaged further in creation, the creator engendered the rudi
ment of sound (śabdatanmātṛkam) from which was pro
duced, ākāśa or ether; it was invested with śabda or sound;
then was created Vāyu, invested with the rudiment of
touch, fire invested with the rudiment of rūpa or form,
waters invested with the rudiment of taste; and lastly an
aggregate of all this (earth) originates, of which smell is
the property; those rudimental elements are designated
aviśeṣas or devoid of qualities and this goes by the name of
elemental creation; from ahamkāra are again produced the
ten organs of sense and the ten divinities along with the
eleventh, mind. These several elements could not by them
selves produce and therefore there was a blending; and the
result of this compound was the formation of an egg-like
aṇḍa, where figures the Lord in vyakta rūpa; its womb being
Meru and its water being the oceans containing all worlds,
Gods and men, surrounded outside by seven envelopes like
elements of fire, water etc.; first was one of darkness of five
Parvas: darkness, illusion, blindness, ignorance, and of no
light; three prākṛta sargas — mahata, bhūta, and aindri-
yaka; three Vaikṛta sargas — mukhya sarga, Tairyakyoni,
deva sarga arvāksrotasa and anugraha sarga; the ninth
sarga was named Kaumāra; then came the creation of devās,
asuras, pitṛs and men.
Vi. I. 2-7, 29-60: 5. 4-5, 19-25; VI. 8. 2 and 13.
text.15542:
Sarga (III) — a son of Ākāśa.
Vi. I. 8. 11.
text.15543:
Sargas — (Vaikṛtas): created as distinct from Prākṛta;
five in number; these are mukhya sarga (sthāvara), tairyak
yoni (tiryaksrotas), deva sarga ūrdhvasrotas), mānuṣa
(arvāksrotasa) and anugraha (blend of sātvīka and
tāmasa).
Vi. I. 5. 21-24.
text.15544:
Sarpa (I) — a Rākṣasa with the sun in nabhonabha
months; a son of Yātudhāna.
Br. II. 23. 11; III. 3. 70; 7. 90; Vā. 69. 128.
text.15545:
Sarpa (II) — a son of Brahmadhāna.
Br. III. 7. 98; Vā. 69. 133.
text.15546:
Sarpa (III) — to be worshipped in house-building.
M. 253. 27.
text.15547:
Sarpa (IV) — one of the eleven Rudras.
Vā. 66. 69.
text.15548:
Sarpas (I) — a class of Rākṣasas sprung from Sarpa;
also Pannagas.
Br. II. 32. 1; 35. 191; III. 7. 97; 8. 70.
text.15549:
Sarpas (II) — snakes whose overlord is Takṣaka;1 mov
ing creatures, sarīsṛpās.2 1) M. 8. 7.
2) Ib. 38. 10.
text.15552:
Sarpayāga — (also Sarpasatra): performed by Jana
mejaya (s.v.).
Bhā. IX. 22. 36; XII. 6. 17.
text.15553:
Sarpiṇī — the māya goddess created by the five com
manders of Bhaṇḍa to counter attack śaktis: fought with
Nakuli who vanquished her.
Br. IV. 23. 16, 67; 24. 3; 25. 8.
text.15554:
Sarpimukhya — to be worshipped before building a
palace.
M. 268. 18.
text.15555:
Sarmā — a daughter of Krodhavaśa and a wife of
Pulaha: mother of Śyāma and Śabala, followers of Yama.
Br. III. 7. 172, 312, 441.
text.15556:
Sarya (sarpa?) — a son of Yātudhāna.
Br. III. 7. 90, 97.
text.15558:
Sarva (II) — a son of Atri, the avatār of the 12th
dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 157.
text.15559:
Sarva (III) — a grandson of Svāyambhuva Manu;
(but in 31. 18 putra is substituted for this name).
Vā. 33. 9.
text.15560:
Sarva (IV) — Sarvavit, Sarvātma, epithets of Viṣṇu
ety. of.2
^1 Vi. V. 17. 9. 2) Vā. 5. 37.
text.15562:
Sarvakāma (I) — the son of Ṛtuparṇa and father of
Sudāsa.
Bha. IX. 9. 17-18; Vi. IV. 4. 39.
text.15563:
Sarvakāma (II) — an Uttama siddhi.
Br. IV. 36. 57 and 88.
text.15566:
Sarvaga (I) — a son of Kāśī and Bhīma.
M. 50. 54; Vi. IV. 20. 46.
text.15568:
Sarvagata — a son of Bhīmasena by Kālī.
Bhā. IX. 22. 31.
text.15570:
Sarvajṛṃbhaṇa śakti — in the Cākraratha.
Br. IV. 19. 33; 36. 82.
text.15571:
Sarvajña — a son of Atri, the avatār of the 12th dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 157.
text.15572:
Sarvajñā — a śakti, in the Sarvajñādyantaram — a pro
tection of cakra.
Br. IV. 19. 42; 36. 92.
text.15573:
Sarvajñānamayī — a devī in the Sarvajñādyantaram.
Br. IV. 19. 43; 36. 93.
text.15574:
Sarvatejas — a son of Vyuṣṭa and Puṣkariṇī, married
Ākūtī: father of Manu (Cākṣuṣa).
Bhā. IV. 13. 14-15.
text.15575:
Sarvatobhadra (I) — a pleasure garden of gods.
Bhā. V. 16. 14.
text.15577:
Sarvatobhadra (III) — a palace or temple with a num
ber of towers, Citraśālā, five bhūmikas; the toraṇa is 30
hastas;1 Catusśālā in the temple or palace.2 1) M. 269. 34, 48.
2) Ib. 254. 2.
text.15578:
Sarvatraga — a son of Dharmasāvarṇi.
Vi. III. 2. 32.
text.15580:
Sarvadvandvakṣayaṃkarī — a Śakti in the Cakraratha.
Br. IV. 19. 34; 36. 84; 44. 131.
text.15582:
Sarvapāpaharā (I) — a devī in the Sarvajñadyantara.
Br. IV. 19. 43; 36. 94; 44. 138.
text.15583:
Sarvapāpaharā (II) — R. a main stream of Kuśadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 43.
text.15586:
Sarvaphalatyāgavratam — in the third day of the bright
half of Mārgaśīrṣa; the giving of fruits (16 varieties to be
made in copper) recommended. Sauras, Vaiṣṇavas, Yogis
and Bhāgavatas may do this.
M. 96. 5-11, 21.
text.15588:
Sarvamaṅgalakāriṇī — a devī in the Binducakra.
Br. IV. 19. 38; 36. 87; 44. 134.
text.15590:
Sarvamantramayī — a Śakti in the Cakraratha.
Br. IV. 19. 34; 36. 84; 44. 131.
text.15592:
Sarvamṛtyupraśamanī — a devī in the Binducakra.
Br. IV. 19. 40; 36. 88; 44. 134.
text.15593:
Sarvamedhas — a god of Sumedhasa group.
Br. II. 36. 60.
text.15595:
Sarvarakṣāsvarūpiṇī — a devī in the Sarvajñādyantaram.
Br. IV. 19. 44; 36. 94; 44. 138.
text.15597:
Sarvarogaharam — the cakra of Viśinyāntaram.
Br. IV. 37. 2.
text.15599:
Sarvavighnanivāriṇī — a devī in Binducakra.
Br. IV. 19. 40; 36. 88; 44. 135.
text.15600:
Sarvavidrāviṇī — a Mudrādevī.
Br. IV. 19. 13 and 32; 36. 81. 44. 113 and 128.
text.15601:
Sarvavṛka — a son of Bhīmasena and Kāśī.
Vā. 99. 247.
text.15602:
Sarvavega — a son of the III Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 80; Vā. 100. 84.
text.15603:
Sarvavyādhivināśiṇī — a devī in the Sarvajñadyantaram.
Br. IV. 19. 43; 36. 93; 44. 137.
text.15604:
Sarvasatvavaśaṃkarī — from the back of Nṛsimha; fol
lower of Vāgīśa.
M. 129. 67.
text.15606:
Sarvasampattipūraṇī — a Śakti in the Cakraratha.
Br. IV. 19. 34; 36. 83.
text.15607:
Sarvasampatpradā — a Śakti in the Binducakra.
Br. IV. 19. 38: 36. 87; 44, 143.
text.15608:
Sarvasammohinī — a Śakti in the Cakraratha.
Br. IV. 19. 33; 36. 82; 44. 128.
text.15609:
Sarvasiddhipradā — a Śakti in the Binducakra.
Br. IV. 19. 38; 36. 87; 44. 133.
text.15611:
Sarvasaubhāgyadhāyinī — a devī in the Binducakra.
Br. IV. 19. 40; 36. 89; 44. 135.
text.15612:
Sarvastambanāśaktikā — a Śakti in the Cakraratha.
Br. IV. 19. 33; 36. 82.
text.15613:
Sarvahlādinikā — a Śakti on the Cakraratha.
Br. IV. 19. 32; 44. 128.
text.15614:
Sarvākarṣaṇa kṛn mudrā — a Mudrā devī.
Br. IV. 19. 13.
text.15615:
Sarvākarṣaṇikā — a Śakti on the Cakraratha.
Br. IV. 19. 32; 36. 81.
text.15616:
Sarvāṅgasundarī — a Devī in the Binducakra.
Br. IV. 19. 40; 36. 89; 44. 135.
text.15624:
Sarvānubhūta — a son of Puṇyajanī and Maṇibhadra;
an Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 123; Vā. 69. 155.
text.15626:
Sarvārthasādhikā — a Śakti in the Cakraratha.
Br. IV. 19. 34; 36. 83.
text.15630:
Sarvepsitapradā — a devī in the Sarvajñādyantaram.
Br. IV. 36. 95.
text.15631:
Sarveśī (sarveśvarī) — a Rahasya yoginī śakti.
Br. IV. 19. 48; 44. 141.
text.15633:
Sarvonmādana mudrā — a Mudrā devī.
Br. IV. 19. 14.
text.15634:
Sarvonmādanaśaktikā — a Śakti in the Cakraratha.
Br. IV. 19. 33; 36. 83.
text.15637:
Salomadhi — a son of Candravijña.
Bhā. XII. 1. 27.
text.15638:
Savana (I) — a son of Priyavrata; remained a bachelor
all life and learnt Brahma vidyā; became lord of Puṣkara
dvīpa.
Bhā. V. 1. 25-26; Vi. II. 1. 7, 15.
text.15639:
Savana (II) — one of the seven sons of Vasiṣṭha and
Ūrjā.
Br. II. 11. 41; Vā. 28. 36; 29. 18 and 26; Vi. I. 10. 13.
text.15640:
Savana (III) — one of the ten sons of Kardama (Svā
yambhuva Manu) and king of Puṣkaradvīpa; father of
Mahāvīra and Dhātakī.
Br. II. 13. 104; 14, 9, 14-15; M. 9. 4; Vā. 31. 18; 33. 9, 14.
text.15642:
Savana (V) — the Agni formed of Pākayajñas.
Vā. 29. 38.
text.15643:
Savana (VI) — a sacrifice, the roots of which are
Gāyatrī, Tṛṣṭub and Jagatī.1 1) Vā. 31. 47.
text.15644:
Savana (VII) — a sage of the IX Dakṣasāvarṇi epoch.
Vi. III. 2. 23.
text.15645:
Savarṇā (I) — a daughter of Sāgara and Velā; married
by Prācīnabarhis and had ten sons called Pracetas.
Br. II. 13. 39.
text.15646:
Savarnik — a manvantara when Asuras will regain
lordship at the end of Śukra's curse.
Vā. 98. 52.
text.15647:
Savitā (I) — a name of the sun;1 garden of, in the north;2
protects the Yamunā;3 has seven horses as vāhanas;4 wor
shipped on the eve of palace building.5 1) Br. II. 13. 125.
2) Vā. 36. 11; 103. 59.
3) M. 253. 30, 42.
4) Ib.
104. 8.
5) Ib. 128. 36; 268. 21.
text.15648:
Savitā (II) — an Āditya;1 maṇḍala of; Viṣṇu Śakti; the
place where reside the chief Yakṣas, Gandharvas, Uragas,
Rākṣasas, sages, Apsaras, Grāmaṇi by turn during twelve
months in groups of seven causing snow, heat, rain, etc2 1) M. 6. 4; Vi. I. 15. 131.
2) Ib. II. 10. 19-22.
text.15649:
Savitā (III) — the name of Vyāsa in the 5th dvāpara;
Kanka the avatār of the Lord fifth Vedavyāsa.
Vā. 23. 129. Vi. III. 3. 12.
text.15650:
Savitā (IV) — the viṣkamba of the sun; is 9,000 yojanas;
thrice is the maṇḍala in measurement;1 of Vaiśākha in the
Cākṣuṣa epoch; the first planet of all;2 brought forth with
śravaṇa and placed in Dhruva;3 in the shape of a circle; the
lord of the world.4 1) Vā. 53. 54, 61.
2) Ib. 53. 104.
3) Ib. 53. 111.
4) Ib. 53. 118.
text.15651:
Savitri — a son of Aditi, married Pṛṣṇi in the Vaivas
vata and became father of Sāvitri and others. Fought with
Virocana in a Devāsura war; Āditya of the month Āṣāḍha;
the fifth Vyāsa; milkman of gods on the earth;2 heard the
Purāṇa from Bṛhaspati and narrated it to Mṛtyu.
^1 Bhā. VI. 6. 39; 18. 1; VIII. 10. 29; X. 58. 20; XII. 6. 68: Br.
II. 23. 24; 24. 76 and 99; III. 7. 288 and 93. Vā. 53. 79.
^3 Br. IV. 4. 59-60;
24. 59. 2) Br. II. 24.
34 and 39; 35. 118; 36. 206; III. 24. 78; 57. 22.
text.15652:
Savitṛmānam — time reckoned by the sun's movement.
Br. III. 3. 38.
text.15655:
Savya (I) — a son of Agnisamsya.
Br. II. 12. 13.
text.15657:
Savyasāci — Arjuna, in the disguise of a hunter killed
Mūka and three crores of Maṇivartana country;1 slew the
Dānavas known as Paulomas and Kālakeyas.2 1) Br. III. 5. 36; 6. 28; Vā. 67. 73.
2) Ib. 68. 27.
text.15659:
Sasmita — a sage of the Auttama epoch.
M. 9. 14.
text.15660:
Saha (I) — a son of Prāṇa, and a Vasu.
Bhā. VI. 6. 12.
text.15661:
Saha (II) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Mādrī.
Bhā. X. 61. 15.
text.15662:
Saha (III) — month (Tamil-Mārgali);1 sacred to Amśu.2 1) Br. II. 13. 10; Vā. 30. 9; 50. 201; 52. 19; 62. 49.
2) Bhā. XII.
11. 41.
text.15663:
Saha (IV) — a god of the Ābhūtaraya group.
Br. II. 36. 56.
text.15664:
Saha (V) — one of the ten sons of Svāyambhuva Manu.
M. 9. 4.
text.15665:
Saha (VI) — the last and tenth son of Auttama Manu,
generous and much reputed.
M. 9. 13.
text.15666:
Sahajanya — the Yakṣa presiding over the month, Śuci.
Bhā. XII. 11. 36.
text.15667:
Sahajanyā — an Apsaras in the sabhā of Hiraṇyakaśipu;1
with the sun for two months, Śuci and Śukra.2 1) Br. III. 7. 14; M. 161. 74; Vā. 69. 49.
2) Br. II. 23. 5; Vā. 52. 7.
Vi. II. 10. 8.
text.15669:
Sahajit — a son of Kuntī and father of Mahiṣmat.
Vi. IV. 11. 8-9.
text.15670:
Sahataṇḍiputra — a pupil of Laugākṣi.
Br. II. 35. 41.
text.15671:
Sahadeva (I) — a son of Divā(r)ka(ra) and a hero:
father of Bṛhadaśva.
Bhā. IX. 12. 11; M. 271. 6; Vā. 99. 283; Vi. IV. 22. 4.
text.15672:
Sahadeva (II) — a son of Jarāsandha of the Māgadha
line; father of Somāpi(a) and Mārjāspi;1 enthroned by
Kṛṣṇa; commanded by Kṛṣṇa, he arranged for the bath, dress
and meals of the released kings; honoured Kṛṣṇa when he
left the capital.2 Killed in Bhārata battle; his son Somāpi
(Somādhi-M. P.) ruled for 58 years, at Girivraja. The latter's
son was Śrutaśravas.3 1) Bhā. IX. 22. 9 and 46; M. 50. 33. Vi. IV. 19. 84; 23. 4.
2) Bhā.
X. 72. 48; 73. 24-6, and 31; Vā. 99. 227.
3) Br. III. 74. 109-11. M.
271. 18.
text.15673:
Sahadeva (III) — a son of Havyavana, and father of
Hīna.
Bhā. IX. 17. 17.
text.15674:
Sahadeva (IV) — a son of Sudāsa, (Sandāsa-Vi. P.), and
father of Somaka.
Bhā. IX. 22. 1; Vā. 99. 207; Vi. IV. 19. 71.
text.15675:
Sahadeva (V) — a son of Mādrī (Mādravatī-Br. P.), born
through the grace of the Aśvins. Father of Śrutakarman.
His other son was Suhotra by Vijayā;1 joy at Kṛṣṇa's visit
to Indraprastha; paid his respects to him; was consoled by
Kṛṣṇa when banished to the forest;2 was sent to southern
countries with Sṛñjayas.3 His suggestion that Kṛṣṇa should
be accorded the first honour among the Sadasyas in the
Rājasūya of Yudhiṣṭhira was accepted. Entertained guests
in that sacrifice. Approved of Draupadī's desire to release
Aśvatthāman.4 1) Bhā. IX. 22. 28-31; Br. III. 71. 155; M. 46. 10; 50. 50; Vā. 96.
154; 99. 245. Vi. IV. 14. 38; 20. 40.
2) Bhā. X. 71. 27. 58. 4; 64. 9.
3) Ib. X. 72. 13; 74. 18-25; 75. 4.
4) X. I. 7. 50; 10. 9.
text.15676:
Sahadeva (VI) — a son of Sṛñjaya and father of Kṛśāśva.
Br. III. 61. 15; Vā. 86. 20; Vi. IV. 1. 54-5.
text.15677:
Sahadeva (VII) — a son of Havyaśva; father of Ahīna.
Br. III. 68. 9.
text.15678:
Sahadeva (VIII) — a son of Tāmarā and Sahadeva.
M. 46. 16.
text.15679:
Sahadeva (IX) — a son of Haryadvata, a great soldier.
Vā. 93. 9.
text.15681:
Sahadeva (XI) — a son of Haryadhana and father of
Adīna.
Vi. IV. 9. 27.
text.15682:
Sahadeva (XII) — a son of Devaka.
Vi. IV. 14. 17.
text.15683:
Sahadevā — a daughter of Devaka, and a queen of Vasu
deva; mother of eight sons, of whom Bhayāsakha was one.
Bhā. IX. 24. 23 and 52; Br. III. 71. 131, 162 and 179; Vā. 96.
177; Vi. IV. 14. 18.
text.15684:
Sahaśrī — a queen of Hemanta ṛtu.
Br. IV. 32. 37.
text.15685:
Sahasa — the tutelary deity of Pākayajnas; father of
Adbhuta.
Br. II. 12. 40.
text.15688:
Sahasyaśrī — a queen of Hemanta ṛtu.
Br. IV. 32. 37.
text.15689:
Sahasrajit (I) — (Sahasrajiḥ-M. P.); the eldest of the
five sons of Yadu and father of Śatajit.
Bhā. IX. 23. 20. 21; Br. III. 69. 2. M. 43. 7; Vā. 94. 2; Vi. IV.
11. 5-6.
text.15690:
Sahasrajit (II) — a son of Jāmbavatī; got killed in Pra
bhāsa.
Bhā. X. 61. 11; XI. 30. 17.
text.15691:
Sahasrajit (III) — a son of Sudevī and Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 71. 251.
text.15692:
Sahasrajit (IV) — one of the sons of Sudevī and Viṣvak
sena.
Vā. 96. 242.
text.15693:
Sahasrajit (V) — a son of Bhajamāna.
Vi. IV. 13. 2.
text.15694:
Sahasradhāra — a Vamśavartin god.
Br. II. 36. 29; Vā. 62. 26.
text.15696:
Sahasraliṃgam — a tīrtha sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 60.
text.15697:
Sahasraśikhara — a Mt. for garuḍa birds;1 west of the
Śitoda;2 of Daityas.3 1) Br. III. 7. 453.
2) Vā. 36. 28.
3) Ib. 39. 61; 42. 53.
text.15698:
Sahasraśruti — a Mt. in Śālmalīdvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 10.
text.15699:
Sahasrastambakam — a thousand pillared maṇṭapa with
sculptured images of Hari.
Br. IV. 34. 85.
text.15700:
Sahasrasruti — (Sahasrastuti-Bhā. P.) a R. in Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 26.
text.15701:
Sahasrasrotas — a boundary hill of Śākadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 26.
text.15702:
Sahasrākṣa (|) — an attribute of Indra;1 served his
mother Diti (s.v.) during her penance to get a son to slay
him; later he cut her phoetus into seven parts; they became
Maruts.2 1) Br. III. 5. 75, 101 etc.; Vā. 39. 19; 64. 7; Vi. I. 9. 19: V. 14. 14.
2) Vā. 67. 95-6.
text.15703:
Sahasrākṣa (II) — the agni of the Asuras;1 the son of
Pāvaka (Vaḍavāmukha-Br. P.)2 1) Vā. 29. 41, 5 and 34.
2) Br. 12. 5, and 36.
text.15704:
Sahasrākṣa (III) — tīrtha sacred to Utpalākṣī;1 sacred to
Pitṛs.2 1) M. 13. 34.
2) Ib. 22. 52.
text.15705:
Sahasrājit (I) — a son of Bhajamāna.
Bhā. IX. 24. 8.
text.15706:
Sahasrājit (II) — a son of Upavāhyakā.
Br. III. 71. 5.
text.15708:
Sahasrānīka — a son of Śatānīka, and father of Aśva
medhaja.
Bhā. IX. 22. 39.
text.15710:
Sahasvān — a (Marṣa) son of Susandhi and father of
Visrutavān. Also called Marṣa.1 He is called the son of
Marṣa and father of Viśvabhava.2 1) Br. III. 63. 212; Vā. 88. 211.
2) Vi. IV. 4. 111.
text.15712:
Sahānandi — (Mahānandī?) ruled for 43 years; father
of Mahāpadma born of a Śūdra woman.
Br. III. 74. 134.
text.15713:
Sahāyas — king's advisers and servants; a cammander
in-chief either a Brahman or a Kṣatriya; Pratīhāra, dūta,
rakṣiṇs or bodyguards; a nārī or nurse; a sāṅdhivigrahika;
desarakṣita; a revenue minister; swordsmen and other
soldiers; a charioteer; sūdādyakṣa; judges; members of
assembly; Lekhaka; dauvārika; dhanādhyakṣa; vaidya;
ācārya; gajādhyakṣa; aśvādhyakṣa; durgādhyakṣa; sthapati;
astrācārya; Purādhyakṣa; āyūdhāgārādhyakṣa; mantrins;
upadhās; cārās.
M. ch. 215.
text.15714:
Sahiṣṇu — (Paulaha) a son of Pulaha and Gatī
(Kṣamā-Vā. P.); a sage of the Cakṣuṣa epoch.
Bhā. IV. 1. 38; Br. II. 11. 31; 36. 78; Vā. 28. 26. 62. 66; Vi. I.
10. 10; III. 1. 28. M. 9. 22.
text.15715:
Sahiṣṇu (II) — the avatār of the Lord of the 26th dvā
para in the holy Rudravaṭa with four sons.
Vā. 23. 212.
text.15717:
Sahaiṣikas — a southern country;1 a tribe.2 1) Br. II. 16. 57.
2) M. 114. 47.
text.15718:
Sahotkaca — a Janapada of the Ketumālā.
Vā. 44. 12.
text.15719:
Sahya — (also Sahyādri): a Kulaparvata; Mt. in Bhārta
varṣa; from this the Kāverī rises. Sages of this place visited
Dvārakā.1 A Kulaparvata where sages performed penance;
recovered from the sea with cities and villages.2 1) Bhā. V. 19. 16; VII. 13. 12; X. 90. 28 [4]; Vā. 45. 89. 104;
Vi. II. 3. 3.
2) Br. II. 16. 8; III. 56. 22 and 57; 57. 27; 58. 24; M. 114.
17, 29.
text.15720:
Sahyadhṛti — son of Śatānanda, expert in arms; he once
saw an Apsaras and dropped semen in a lake; it took the
shape of a mithuna who were rescued by Śantanu and became
Gautamas.
M. 50. 9-11.
text.15721:
Sahyādri — sacred to Ekavīra; see Sahya.
M. 13. 40.
text.15723:
Sāketa — is Ayodhyā; sometime ruled by the Nāgas.
Br. III. 54. 54; 74. 195.
text.15724:
Sāketa — a Janapada over which the Guptas ruled.
Vā. 99. 383.
text.15725:
Sākṣi — witness; the Devas as witnesses to piṇḍadāna.
Vā. 110. 59 and 60.
text.15726:
Sākṣipa — one of the names in the third Marutgaṇa.
Vā. 67. 126.
text.15727:
Sāgara (I) — (Sindhu): one of the principal kṣetrams.
M. 110. 1.
text.15728:
Sāgara (II) — the lord of rivers;1 married Velā, the
daughter of Meru;2 had a daughter Savarṇā married to
Prācinabarhis.3 1) Vā. 70. 9.
2) Ib. 30. 35.
3) Br. II. 13. 38.
text.15730:
Sāgaras — (also Sagaras s.v.) were purified by the
waters of the Ganges flowing from the foot of Viṣṇu. 60,000
sons of Sumatī who were unrighteous; sent by Sagara to
seize the sacrificial horse; finding it near Kapila they treated
him as thief but perished by the fire of his wrath; as they
dug up the earth, the sea got enlarged and came to be known
as Sāgara; ruled Campā.
^1 Bhā. X. 41. 15; Br. III. chh. 52-3; 54. 11; 56. 3. ^2 Ib. III.
74. 197.
text.15731:
Sāṃkāśyā — the capital of Kuśadhvaja;1 also the name of
the kingdom.2 1) Br. III. 64. 19.
2) Vi. IV. 5. 29.
text.15733:
Sāṃkṛtaya — the Kṣeropeta Brahmans; of Angirasa
line.
Vā. 99. 164.
text.15735:
Sāṃkṛtya — a Bhārgava gotrakāra; a śruta ṛṣi.
Br. II. 33. 2; M. 195. 23.
text.15737:
Sāṃkhya (Yoga) — Revealed by Viṣṇu: taught by Kapila
to Āsuri.1 Here tattvas or first principles are taught. Puruṣa
the eternal, acts as agent to get things done by the guṇas of
Prakṛti. Its relation to Bhaktiyoga.2 Its principles are
differently enumerated as eleven, five, three and so on; ac
cording to one's yuktī or reason. Creation of universe ac
cording to Sānkhya, and the place of Prakṛti and Puruṣa
therein.3 Followed by Kṛṣṇa while ruling from Dvārakā
and by Nārada in his worship of Naranārāyaṇa.4 Practised
by Vairājasas;5 is itself a kind of yoga;6 born out of the
creator.7 1) Bhā. I. 3. 10; II. 1. 6; V. 18. 33; M. 3. 29; Vā. 30. 293.
2) Bhā.
III. 24. 17; 25. 31; ch. 26 (whole); 29 2; Vā. 61. 111.
3) Bhā. XI. 22.
1-25; Bhā 24 (whole).
4) ch. III. 3. 19; V. 19. 10; IX. 8. 14; X. 8. 45;
XI. 14. 20.
5) M. 13. 5.
6) Ib. 52. 3; 110; 19; 182. 18; 183. 44; Vā. 66.
110.
7) M. 183. 50; 184. 24; 245. 87; 247. 9; 248. 17; 291. 2.
text.15738:
Sāṃkhyāyanas — sages of rigid vows: learnt the Bhāga-
vata from Kumāra and imparted it to Parāśara and Bṛhaspati.
Bhā. III. 8. 7-8; M. 200. 11.
text.15739:
Sātyaki (also Śaineya and Yuyudhāna) a son of
Satyaka;1 followed Kṛṣṇa to Hāstinapura and was welcomed.
Returned back to Dvārakā with him. Followed the Vṛṣṇi
host to the city of Bāṇa and fought with Kumbhāṇḍa, his
minister;2 learnt the secrets of archery from Arjuna;3 defend
ed the western gate of Mathurā, being on the right detach
ment of Kṛṣṇa's army: pursued the retreating enemy to five
yojanas and came out successful;4 entered Yādava sabhā
with Kṛṣṇa and Rāma and was honoured. Defended Dvā
rakā and expelled Sālva's army;5 went to see the Pāṇḍavas at
Upaplāvya; was consulted by Kṛṣṇa on the eve of his war with
Jarāsandha. Joined Yadus in defeating Pauṇḍraka;6 went
with the sacrificial horse of Kṛṣṇa; fought with Aniruddha
at Prabhāsa;7 survived Kurukṣetra war;8 was killed in
Yādava battle at Prabhāsa.9 1) Bhā. I. 10. 18; IX. 24. 13-14; M. 45. 22; Vā. 96. 63; Vi. IV. 14.
2.
2) Bhā. I. 13. 16 [1]; X. 58. 1 and 6, 28; 63. 3 and 8; [51 (v) 30
31; 59. 63].
3) Ib. III. 1. 31 and 35.
4) Ib. X. 50. 20 [4]; [50 (V) 12],
[30]; [51 (V) 25].
5) IbX. [42 (V) 13-14]; 52 [56 (V) 1]; 76. 14; 77. 4.
6) IbX. 78 [95 (V) 2]; [50 (V) 8 and 28].
7) Ib. X. 89. 22 [2]; XI. 30.
16.
8) Ib. X. 80. [3].
9) Vi. V. 37. 46.
text.15740:
Sātyamugri — a sage and a Trayārṣeya with Hiraṇyas
tambi and Mudgala.
M. 196. 41.
text.15742:
Sātrājitī — a devī and wife of Kṛṣṇa.
Vā. 96. 233.
text.15743:
Sātvakīvṛtti — that which is above and divine;1 the mind
becomes clean and the truth is open to him and leads to
jñānam or knowledge;2 of Viṣṇu.3 1) Vā. 102. 54.
2) Ib. 74. 76.
3) Ib. 66. 87, 104-6.
text.15744:
Sātvata (I) — a son of Āyu, and father of Bhajamāna
and six other sons. Attacked the Asura followers of Bali.
Bhā. VIII. 21. 17; IX. 24. 6-7.
text.15745:
Sātvata (II) — the son of Satva (Janhu M. P.); wife,
Kausalyā; father of four sons, Bhajamāna, Bhaji etc., who
founded four different dynasties.
Br. III. 70. 48; 71. 1, 2; M. 44. 46-8; Vā. 95. 47.
text.15746:
Sātvats (sātvatas) — a Yādava tribe related to the
Pāṇḍavas. Their overlord was Kṛṣṇa;1 knew how to read
others' minds and possessed high understanding and culture;2
ended their lives by fighting their own relations;3 are Bhāga
vatas;4 a line of Kings from Sātvata.5 1) Bhā. 1. 4. 7; 14. 25; II. 4. 20.
2) Ib. III. 2. 9.
3) Ib. XI. 30. 18.
4) Ib. XII. 8. 46.
5) Vi. IV. 12. 44.
text.15747:
Sātvatam Tantram — (sātvata śāstra) is Pāñcarātra?
Propounded by Viśoka, a means of obtaining mukti for
women, śūdras and slaves by the sāmpradāya given here;1
taught by Nārada.2 1) Bhā. X. 90. 34 [2]; VI. 16. 33.
2) Ib. I. 3. 8.
text.15748:
Sātvata — samhitā the Bhāgavatam a means to bhakti
(see Sātvati śruti).
Bhā. I. 7. 6-7.
text.15749:
Sātvatīyas — the followers of sātvatatantra.
Bhā. V. 25. 1.
text.15750:
Sātvatī Śruti — is Bhāgavata: a discourse between Śuka
and Parīkṣit at Hāstinapura.
Bhā. I. 4. 7.
text.15753:
Sādhakas — Dakṣa and other sons of Brahmā live in a
place two crores of Yojanas above Maharloka.
Vā. 101. 139.
text.15754:
Sādharmyavaidharmyakṛta — Sadasadātmaka in other
worlds: the eternal being.
Vā. 102. 34, 131.
text.15756:
Sādhu — (Brahmacāri): He who has the means of
vidyā; a Brahmacārin well disposed to a guru; (sādhugra
hasta) — the means of doing the Karmas ordained (sādhu
vaikhānasa) — by performing penance in the forest (sādhu
yati) by endeavouring to apply himself to yoga.
Vā. 59. 23-4.
text.15757:
Sādhya (I) (Gaṇa) — born of Sādhyā and Dharma:
their son was Arthasiddhi;1 created by Vāmadeva; of the
Tāmasa epoch;2 one of the 7 gaṇas of the Vaivasvata epoch.3 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 7; Br. II. 24. 27; 38. 3.
2) M. 4. 30; 5. 17; 9. 16.
3) Ib. 9. 29; Vā. 10. 71; 21. 22; 30. 99.
text.15758:
Sādhya (II) — Viṣṇu, Nārāyaṇa, lying in sleep in the
vast mass of water.
Vā. 23. 108.
text.15759:
Sādhya (III) — a son of Atri, the avatār of the 12th
dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 157.
text.15760:
Sādhyas (I) — the sons of Manu (Cākṣuṣa);1 worshipped
for control of subjects;2 came with other gods to Dvārakā to
ask Kṛṣṇa to go back to Vaikuṇṭha.3 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 15; 7. 3; 13. 17.
2) Ib. II. 3. 5; III. 20. 42; V. 1. 8.
3) Ib.
XI. 6. 2.
text.15761:
Sādhyas (II) — the twelve sons of Dharma and Sādhyā;
superior to Gods; first created as Jayādevas from the face of
Brahmā, again born in Svāyambhuva epoch as Jitas, in
Tāmasa epoch as Harayas, in Raivata epoch as Vaikuṇṭhas,
Svārociṣa epoch as Tuṣitas, in Uttama epoch as Satyas,
in Cākṣuṣa epoch as Chāndajas, and in the Vaivasvata epoch
as Sādhyas; Vasus are their brothers; Gods of Cākṣuṣa and
Vaivasvata epochs; their names are Mana, Anumanta,
Prāṇa, Nara, Apāna, Vīryavān, Vīti, Naya, Haya, Hamsa,
Nārāyaṇa, Vibhu, and Prabhu; live in Bhuvarloka; Nārā
yaṇa, their overlord;1 worship gau, the mind-born daughter
of the Mānasa manes;2 requested Soma to give up Jārā to
Bṛhaspati;3 with Angirasa's sons spread themselves in the
world of Marici Garbha.45 1) Br. III. 3. 4-20, 58, 67; 4. 33. 8 6; 10. 88; IV. 2. 28; 15. 24,
20. 46; 30. 8.; M. 36. 1; 132. 3; 171. 42; 203. 10-12; 246. 54; 247. 10;
Vā. 66. 4-12; 101. 30; Vi. I. 9. 64 and 70.
2) M. 15. 15.
3) Ib. 23. 35.
4) Vā. 73. 38.
5) Ib. V. 1. 17.
text.15762:
Sādhyā (I) — a daughter of Dakṣa and one of the 10
wives of Dharma: mother of Sādhya gaṇa.1 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 4 and 7; Br. III. 3. 3 and 8. M. 5. 16-17; 171. 42;
203. 10; Vā. 66. 2; Vi. I. 15. 105.
text.15763:
Sādhyā (II) — one of the mind-born daughters of
Brahmā.
M. 171. 32.
text.15765:
Sānandam (Saunanda-Wilson) — the musala or club of
Hari.
Vi. V. 22. 7.
text.15766:
Sānu — a son of Satyabhāmā and Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 71. 247; Vā. 96. 238.
text.15767:
Sāntānikalokas — the devas known as Vairājas live in.
Vā. 71. 52.
text.15768:
Sāntapanam — an expiation ceremony for ascetics guilty
of sexual act.
Vā. 18. 8.
text.15769:
Sāndīpani — (also Sāndīpana); of Kāśī, and a resident
of Avanti; was the preceptor of Kṛṣṇa and Balarāma. Taught
them all branches of learning in 64 days; got back his dead
son recovered from the world of Yama (from the sea Vi. P.)
by his pupils as gurudakṣiṇa; acted as purohita in the yajñas
performed by Kṛṣṇa at Kurukṣetra;1 his concern when
Kṛṣṇa and Kucela were caught once in storm and rain.2 1) Bhā III. 3. 2; X. 45. 31-49; 90. 46. Vi. V. 21, 19-31. [2] Vā. 98.
99.
2) Bhā X. 80. 39-40; Br. III. 73-79.
text.15770:
Sāndhivigrahika — one who has a knowledge of ṣāḍ
guṇya, knows the language of countries and is skilled in
policy.
M. 215. 16.
text.15772:
Sāpatya — a pupil of Yāñavalkya.
Br. II. 35. 28.
text.15773:
Sāma — one of the political expedients used by Ṛṣabha;1
two fold, the real and the unreal; the first to be applied to
the sādhus (good men); by this the righteous are brought
under control;2 there is no use applying it to the un
righteous. One of the four limbs of nīti, the others being
bheda, dāna (uppradāna-Vi. P.) and daṇḍa (daṇḍa pāta
Vi. P.).3 1) Bhā. V. 4. 16.
2) M. 222. 1-10.
3) Ib. 148. 65-77; Vi. V. 22. 17;
33. 40.
text.15774:
Sāmaga — eligible for Pārvaṇa śrāddha;1 best for a gift;2
to be sung in connection with the rituals in digging tanks,
wells, etc.3 1) Br. III. 15. 30; M. 16. 12.
2) Ib 54. 21.
3) Ib 58. 37, 43.
text.15775:
Sāmagas — Prācya and Kārtā;1 8014 sāmas, āraṇyaka
and homa.2 1) Vā. 30. 230; 32. 17-21; 99. 191.
2) Ib. 61. 47-8; 62. 137.
text.15776:
Sāmaghoṣa — chanting of Sāma Veda identified with
the voice of the Varāha (avatār);1 also Sāmaghoṣa.2 1) M. 248. 69.
2) Vā. 62. 137.
text.15778:
Sāma (samhitā) — a Veda imparted to Jaimini,1 who
arranged it under Vyāsa's guidance; present in Vāruṇi
yajña with Viśvāvasus and Gandharvas;2 gave birth to a
number of elephants;3 learnt by the Asuras;4 taught by Jai
mini to his son Sumantu and his grandson Sutavāna; the
latter's son Sukarma composed Sahasra samhitā and taught
to his pupils Hiraṇyanābha, Kausalya and Pauṣpiñji; 500
pupils of the latter were the northern chanters of the Sāma;
Hiraṇyanābha's disciples the eastern chanters of the Sāma;
one of his pupils, Kṛta, taught to his disciples 24 branches
of the Samhitā;5 part of Viṣṇu;6 served with other Vedas as
a horse of the chariot of Tripurāri.7 1) Bhā. I. 4. 21; IX. 11. 2; 21. 28; X. 7. 14; 53. 12; XI. 27. 31;
XII. 6. 76; 11. 47; 12. 62. Vā. 31. 33; 65. 26. Vi. III. 4. 9 and 13.
2) Br.
II. 34. 15; III. 1. 25.
3) Ib III. 7. 334, 339.
4) Ib IV. 12. 17.
5) M. 49. 76;
Vā. 99. 130. Vi. III. 6. 1-7.
6) Ib V. 1. 37.
7) M. 85. 5; 133. 31;
text.15779:
Sāmanta — neighbouring chieftains; their irritation
against the king is a case of internal dissension;1 they should
behave like fire towards refractory sāmantas;2 residence of;3
followed Haihaya in his hunting expedition;4 subordinate to
the Kauravas.5 1) Br. III. 27. 13, 39; 28. 12; 38. 20; 74. 124; M. 223. 8.
2) Ib.
226. 7.
3) Ib. 227. 168; 254. 21.
4) Br. IV. 14. 10.
5) M. 272. 37.
text.15780:
Sāmalanātha — a tīrtha sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 42.
text.15782:
Sāmavratam — in honour of Śiva or Keśava.
M. 101. 26.
text.15783:
Sāmāni — Vaiṣṇava sāmas for Bhīmadvādaśi;1 sung by
Gandharvas;2 Jaimini learnt them from Vyāsa;3 those learned
in, know the Brahmā.4 1) M. 69. 44.
2) Vā. 2. 31.
3) Ib 9. 50; 60. 15.
4) Ib 79. 95; 101.
346.
text.15785:
Sāmikā — a portion of the Pūrvasamhitā.
Vā. 61. 57.
text.15787:
Sāmudrī — a wife of Prācīnabarhiṣa (Sāvarṇi-Vā. P.)
(Prācīnabarhi-M. P.); mother of ten Prācīnabarhiṣas.
Br. II. 37. 27; M. 4. 47; Vā. 30. 36.
text.15789:
Sāmba (I) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Jāmbavatī; reincarna
tion of Guha;1 attended Aniruddha's marriage at Bhojakaṭa,
went with the Vṛṣṇi army to Bāṇa's city and fought with the
son of Bāṇa;2 went out to play and saw a huge lizard in a
well and reported it to Kṛṣṇa;3 took Lakṣmaṇā, daughter of
Duryodhana in a svayamvara. The Kurus imprisoned him.
Afraid of Balarāma's prowess, was released by Duryo
dhana and was given dowry. Went to Dvārakā after the
Rājasūya of Yudhiṣṭhira and defended the city against Śālva.4
Went to Syamantapañcaka for the solar eclipse.5 Went with
Kṛṣṇa's sacrificial horse. Fought with Pradyumna at Pra
bhāsa.6 Disguised as a pregnant lady by Yadu youths for fun,
approached a sage and asked him whether she would deliver a
male child. In anger the sage said that she would give birth
to a musala (iron rod) which would be death to the Yadu kula.
Divested of his attire, the musala was seen; causing distress
to the Yadus. The king ordered that it must be powdered
and thrown into the deep. A bit that was left unpowdered
was swallowed by a fish which was caught by a fisherman.
The latter fixed it at the tip of his arrow. The particles of
the musala were thrown ashore and grew to be eraka grass.7
Adopted by Gaṇḍūṣa; had five sons, all warriors, through
Kāśī; one of the five vamśavīras;8 married Kaśyā, daughter of
Supārśva, and mother of Pañcavīras and a number of sons, all
with divine sparks;9 was looked upon with love by the 16000
women of Kṛṣṇa and hence they were cursed by Kṛṣṇa to
be robbed and dishonoured by robbers. They were rid of
the curse by observing anaṅgadāna vratam as prescribed by
Dālbhya, the sage.10 Got killed in the Yādava struggle at Pra
bhāsa.11 1) Bhā. I. 10. 29; 11. 17; 14. 31; III. 1. 30; X. 61. 11; M. 46. 27;
47. 18; Vi. IV. 15. 37; V. 32. 2;
2) Bhā. X. 61. 26; 63. 3;
3) 64. 1-4;
4) Ib X
68. 1-12, 43-52; 75. 29; 76. 14; 77. 4. Vi. V. 35. 4-5.
5) Bhā. X. 82. 6.
6) Ib X. 89. 22 [2]: 90. 33; XI. 30. 16.
7) Ib XI. 1. 13-23; Vi. V. 37. 7-10.
8) Br. III. 71. 191 and 260; 72 1.
9) M. 47. 24.
10) Ib 70. 5-10, 17-19, 62.
11) Vi. V. 37. 46.
text.15792:
Sāmbam — the Upapurāṇa containing legends connected
with Sāmba.
M. 53. 62.
text.15793:
Sāmrājī — a name of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 18. 15.
text.15794:
Sāṃvartaka — the pralaya fire remembered by those
who witnessed the fight between Arjuna and Aśvatthāman.
Bhā. I. 7. 31.
text.15795:
Sāya — a son of Prabhā.
Bhā. IV. 13. 13.
text.15796:
Sāyanam — a lake on the slopes of the Hemakūṭa hill.
Vā. 47. 63.
text.15797:
Sāyakāyani — an Ārṣeya Pravara of Angiras.
M. 196. 21.
text.15798:
Sāyā(nha) — (Evening); born of Dhātrī and Kuhū
Bhā. VI. 18. 3; Br. II. 21. 121.
text.15799:
Sāraṇa (I) — a son of Vasudeva (Ānakadundubhi) and
Rohiṇī and father of Sārṣṭhi and others.1 Followed Vṛṣṇis
to Bāṇa's city. Was consulted by Kṛṣṇa on the eve of attack
on Jarāsandha; being on the left detachment of Kṛṣṇa's
army, defended Dvārakā against Śālva.2 Went to see the Pāṇ
ḍavas at Upaplāvya, and to Syamantapañcaka for the solar
eclipse.3 1) Bhā. I. 14. 28; IX. 24. 46. Br. II. 71. 164 and 168, M. 46. 11;
Vā. 96. 162;
2) Bhā. X. 63. 3; [50 (v) 8], [11]; 76. 14;
3) Ib. X. 78.
[95 (v) 3]; 82. 6.
text.15800:
Sāraṇa (II) — a son of Devajani, an Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 130.
text.15801:
Sārathi — an expert in the science of elephants, horses
and chariots; one possessing geographical knowledge of the
country, able to calculate the strength or weakness of the
army corps; loyal, etc.
M. 215. 20-21.
text.15802:
Sāramaya — a son of Śvaphalka.
Bhā. IX. 24. 16.
text.15803:
Sārameyas — lineal descendants of Saramā's two sons.
Br. III. 7. 313.
text.15804:
Sārameyadana — one of the twenty-eight hells; contains
720 hounds of adamantine teeth; setting fire, administering
poison, plundering of villages or caravans are punished here.
Bhā. V. 26. 7 and 27.
text.15805:
Sārasa — a kind of bird born of Jaṭāyu.
M. 6. 36.
text.15806:
Sārasas — sons of Śyeni and Garuḍa, in the Himālayan
lakes;1 cranes as born of Śuci.2 1) Br. III. 7. 456; 22. 65 etc.
2) M. 6. 32.
text.15807:
Sārasā — one of the six charioteers of Lalitā.
Br. IV. 20. 92.
text.15808:
Sārasvata (I) — a son of Dadhici and Sarasvatī; knew
the yoga power of Hari;1 a mantrakṛt and a sage. The 9th
Vedavyāsa; avatār of the Lord Ṛṣabha;2 heard the Vāyu
Purāṇa from Vasiṣṭha and narrated it to Tridhāman.3 1) Bhā. II. 7. 45; Br. II. 32. 105; Vā. 65. 91.
2) Br. II. 35. 119; III,
1. 94; M. 145. 99; Vā. 23. 143; 59. 96.
3) Br. IV. 4. 60-61 Vā. 103. 60.
text.15809:
Sārasvata (II) — the 12th kalpa;1 an account of it in the
Bhāgavata.2 1) M. 290. 5;
2) Ib. 53. 21.
text.15810:
Sārasvata (III) — a son of Jaigīṣavya, an avatār of the
Lord.
Vā. 23. 139.
text.15811:
Sārasvata (IV) — heard the Viṣṇu Purāṇa from Puru
kutsa (Dadhicī) and narrated it to Parāśara (Bhṛgu).
Vi. I. 2. 9. Vi. 8. 44.
text.15812:
Sārasvata (V) — a Vedavyāsa of the ninth dvāpara.
Vi. III. 3. 13.
text.15813:
Sārasvatas — a people; a western country.
Bhā. I. 10. 34; Br. II. 16. 62; M. 114. 50.
text.15814:
Sārasvata mantras — the best of mantras.
Br. IV. 38. 6.
text.15815:
Sārasvatam — a tīrtha sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 63.
text.15816:
Sārasvatam kuṇḍam — near the Agnidhārā R. of Gayā,
established by Sarasvatī. Here are Śukra, Saṇḍamarka and
others.
Vā. 108. 59-60.
text.15817:
Sārasvatavratam — sacred to Sarasvatī; worshipping of
Gāyatrī on the fifth day of every pakṣa for 13 months, the
performer attains Brahmaloka; he who listens to this reaches
Vidyādharapura.
M. 66. 3-18; 101. 18.
text.15818:
Sārāyaṇas — the gotrakāras of Atri family.
M. 197. 1.
text.15819:
Sārdhanemi — belonging to Ārṣeya Pravara of Angiras.
M. 196. 6.
text.15820:
Sārpa — one of the eight muhūrtas of the afternoon.
Br. III. 3. 39.
text.15822:
Sārva — a particular period of the day.
Vā. 66. 40.
text.15823:
Sārvabhauma (I) — a manifestation of Hari in the
Sāvarṇi epoch as the son of Devaguhya and Sarasvatī. He
deprived Purandara of Indrahood and made Bali Indra.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 17.
text.15824:
Sārvabhauma (II) — a son of Vīdūratha, and father of
Jayasena. (Jayatsena-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 22. 10; M. 50. 35; Vā. 99. 231. Vi. IV. 20. 4.
text.15825:
Sārvabhauma (III) — a son of Sudha(va)rma; an
Ekarāṭ.
M. 49. 71-2; Vā. 99. 186.
text.15826:
Sārṣṭhi — a son of Sāraṇa.
Vi. IV. 15. 21.
text.15827:
Sālagrāma — the place to which Āgnīdhra retired after
dividing Jambūdvīpa among his nine sons;1 yoga practised
by Bharata at.2 1) Vi. II. 1. 24.
2) Ib. II. 1. 34; 13. 4 and 34.
text.15831:
Sālavanam — in Bhadrāśva, where are mango trees;
complexion of men here is white, and women kumuda; their
age 10,000 years.
Vā. 43. 6-9.
text.15832:
Sālavalaya — of the city where were Kapiśīrṣaka houses.
Br. IV. 22. 26.
text.15833:
Sālokyatā — with om and its significance attained by
a yogi.
Vā. 20. 8.
text.15834:
Sālva — (also Śālva); in Duryodhana's army; was sta
tioned by Jarāsandha at the western gate of Mathurā, during
one siege, and at the Eastern gate during the other. Attacked
the south when Gomanta was besieged.1 Was defeated and
killed by Kṛṣṇa in Vaidarbhī svayamvara; arrived at
Kuṇḍina.2 1) Bhā. X. 78 [95 (v) 16]; 50. 11 [5], [2]; 52. 11 [8].
2) Ib. X. 52;
17 and 19; 42 [1]; 53. 17; Vā. 98. 100.
text.15836:
Sāvadyam — the truth of five-limbed bhūtas. An aiś
varya of yoga.
Vā. 13. 5.
text.15837:
Sāvarṇa (Manu) — a son of Prajāpati; 11th period.
Vā. 62. 4; 100. 85.
text.15838:
Sāvarṇa antara — (first): three gaṇas of seven ṛṣis are
distinguished, each of 20; he had nine mind-born sons; at the
end of Cākṣuṣa and the beginning of Vaivasvata Sāvarṇi
Manus come into being; sons of Dakṣa through his daughter;
son of Samjña. Sāvarṇa Manus.
Vā. 100. 9, 19-29, 31, 53.
text.15839:
Sāvana māsa — 12 months of 30 days each; year of 360
days.
Vā. 100. 223.
text.15840:
Sāvanam(mānam) — a kind of measurement.
Br. II. 21. 137; IV. 1. 221.
text.15841:
Sāvarṇi (Manu) (I) — s.v. 8th Manu of the future;1
Aśvatthāman and others are sages; he would have ten sons
like Dhṛti, Varīyan etc;2 a son of Vivasvān; engaged in
penance in Meru;3 Śukra Predicted Bali, a grandson of
Prahlāda as king in Savarṇi's Kingdom.4 1) Bhā. V. 19. 10.
2) M. 9. 31.
3) Ib. 11. 9, 38.
4) Ib. 47. 218; 247. 72;
text.15842:
Sāvarṇi (Srutaśrava) (II) — a son of Mārtaṇḍa and
Chāyā;1 pupil of Sūki, became Manu Prajāpati; had his
residence on the slopes of Meru.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 13. 10.
2) Vā. 84. 31; 100. 19.
text.15843:
Sāvarṇi (III) — a student of Atharva Samhītā.
Bhā. XII. 7. 3.
text.15844:
Sāvarṇi (IV) — a Paurāṇika: learnt the mūla samhitā
from the disciple of Vyāsa.
Bhā. XII. 7. 5 and 7; Br. II. 35. 64 and 66.
text.15845:
Sāvarṇi (V) — one of the sages of the Naimiṣa; learned
in Śruti; an able speaker, addressed Vāyu; wife Sāmudrī.
Vā. 1. 123; 21. 1; 30. 36; 34. 62.
text.15846:
Sāvarṇi (VI) — of śyāma colour; represents Ṛkāra.
Vā. 26. 40.
text.15847:
Sāvarṇi (VII) — a pupil of Romaharṣaṇa.
Vi. III. 6. 17.
text.15848:
Sāvarṇimanu — 14th Manu from औ of Kārbūra varṇa.
Vā. 26. 46.
text.15852:
Sāvitra (I) — a muhūrta of the night.
Br. III. 3. 43: Vā. 66. 44.
text.15853:
Sāvitra (II) — one of the eleven Rudras.
M. 5. 30; 253. 42.
text.15856:
Sāvitravanam — the forest in the region of the Uttara
kurus.
M. 83. 34.
text.15857:
Sāvitrī (I) — a R. in Plakṣadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 4.
text.15858:
Sāvitrī (II) — the daughter of Savitrī: Satī compared to
her by Dakṣa.
Bhā. VI. 18. 1; IV. 2. 11.
text.15859:
Sāvitrī (III) — the initiating mantra: the study of;1 the
sole property of Brahmans.2 1) Bhā. VIII. 18. 14; III. 12. 42; Vā. 77. 21.
2) Ib. 106. 58; 109.
21.
text.15860:
Sāvitrī (IV) — Brahmā contemplated her in his mind
when engaged in creation; at that time a being half male and
half female broke through his body and it was named
Śatarūpā;1 also called Sarasvatī, Gāyatrī and Brahmāṇī;2
Viśvarūpā with two feet; came out by cutting through the
head of Brahmā.3 1) M. 3. 30.
2) Ib. 4. 10; 187. 45; 260. 44.
3) Vā. 23. 78, 91.
text.15861:
Sāvitrī (V) — the Goddess worshipped by King Aśvapati.
M. 208. 6.
text.15862:
Sāvitrī (VI) — the daughter of Aśvapati and Mālatī, mar
ried Satyavān. Nārada spoke to her of his short life: Followed
him to the forest knowing that his end was nearing. Enjoyed
his company seeing the fauna and flora there: saw him un
conscious when cutting fuel,1 saw the Lord of death and
begged him on her knees to let him live. Yama granted her
a boon which she would desire. Her first was that her
father-in-law should get back his sight and his kingdom.
Though granted, she pursued Yama to free her husband and
praised the god's glory. She was asked to name another boon
and that was to bless her father with a number of sons. It
was granted. Yama asked her to get back. She did not feel
weary and pursued him. Her third request was to grant
her one hundred sons. Her continuous praise and earnest
ness pleased the god who restored her husband back to life.
She returned to the place where the body of Satyavān lay,
with him she went home, found Dyumatsena enjoying his
regained eye-sight and people requesting him to take up the
kingship again. Lived long and happy.2 1) M. Chh. 208-9.
2) Ib. Chh. 210-4.
text.15864:
Sāvitrītīrtham (I) — in the Narmadā. (Gayā-Vā. P.),
auspicious for bath and the offering of madhyānha sandhya
or noon prayers.
M. 194. 6. Vā. 112, 22.
text.15865:
Sāhari — belonging to ārṣeya pravara of Angiras.
M. 196. 23.
text.15867:
Sāhvaya — a Marut of the third gaṇa.
Br. III. 5-95.
text.15868:
Sikata — a class of gods performing śrāddha.
Br. III. 10. 109. Vā. 73. 61.
text.15869:
Sikatāparvatamaru — near the kingdom of Vidyādharas:
watered by the Nalinī.
Br. II. 18. 60.
text.15870:
Sita (I) — a sage of the Auttama epoch.
M. 9. 14.
text.15871:
Sita (II) — married Ekaparṇā, the daughter of Menā.
M. 13. 9.
text.15872:
Sita (III) — Śukra; one of the nine grahas; colour white.
M. 93. 10.
text.15873:
Sitakalpa — the thirty-second kalpa; Brahmā's mind
born is of kṛṣṇa colour; Brahmā called him Aghora; he had
from his side four sons, all black in colour, dress etc.; these
later worshipped the lord for 1000 years and attained
Rudrahood.
Vā. 23. 22-35.
text.15875:
Sitodam — a sacred lake in Meru.
M. 113. 46.
text.15876:
Siddha — a son of Krodha and a deva gandharva.
Br. III. 6. 38.
text.15877:
Siddhas — Invisible celestials;1 impart wisdom;2 and sing
in praise of Hari;3 came to see Kṛṣṇa;4 Kapila was the greatest
of siddhas;5 vanquished by Rāvaṇa in Jambūdvīpa;6 wander
in this world in the guise of Brahmans; hence guests must
be fed worthy of them; devas are Yogeśvaras and move for
the promotion of dharma in different guises.7 1) Bhā. II. 6. 13; III. 20. 44; V. 1. 8; VI. 2. 32; 7. 3-4; VII. 8. 37-8.
2) Ib. VIII. 14. 8; 23. 26.
3) Ib. X. 3. 6; 4. 11; 10. 28: 25. 31: 39. 44; 62.
19; 85. 41.
4) Ib. XI. 6. 3; 12. 3; 14. 5.
5) Ib. XI. 16. 15; 24. 12; 31. 2; XII.
12. 6.
6) Br. II. 15. 10; III. 7. 255; IV. 20. 46; 30. 9; 33, 3, 39. 56.
7) Vā.
23. 191; 30. 88, 34. 21; 38. 58. 47. 46; 71. 74; 72. 35.
text.15878:
Siddhakṣetram (I) — on the banks of the Ganges.
M. 110. 12.
text.15879:
Siddhakṣetram (II) — in the Himālayas;1 where Yogins
go with their very bodies or Kāyārohaṇam.2 1) Vā. 23. 175, 182.
2) Ib. 23. 222.
text.15880:
Siddhapadam — the holy spot on the Sarasvatī where
Devabhūti attained nirvāṇa.
Bhā. III. 33. 31.
text.15881:
Siddhapura — a tīrtha sacred to Mātā.
M. 13. 46.
text.15883:
Siddhaloka — (Svarga)1 the permanent residence of
Nārada.2 1) Vā. 41. 81-2.
2) Bhā. IV. 29. 80.
text.15884:
Siddhavanam — a tīrtha sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 22. 55.
text.15885:
Siddhā (I) — the presiding deity of Sarvarohahara
cakra.
Br. IV. 37. 9.
text.15887:
Siddhārtha (I) — a son of Maṇibhadra and Puṇyajanī:
an Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 122; Vā. 69. 154.
text.15890:
Siddhi (II) — a daughter of Dakṣa; married Dharma;
mother of Sukha.
Br. I. 9. 50, 61, 62; Vā. 10. 25, 37; Vi. I. 7. 23 and 31.
text.15891:
Siddhi (III) — the wife of Kāma.
Br. II. 9. 62.
text.15892:
Siddhi (IV) — a devī in the Cakrarājaratha.
Br. IV. 19. 4.
text.15893:
Siddhi (V) — a Kalā of Brahmā.
Br. IV. 35. 94.
text.15895:
Siddhi (VII) — of yoga; when one feels himself and the
earth all of tejas becomes a siddha;1 the state of attaining the
desired thing by means of vaivastya from the śarīrimahat;2
characteristics of: pratibhā, śravaṇa, darśan of devas and
brahmāvarta;3 eight fold.4 1) Vā. 11. 64.
2) Ib. 59. 75.
3) Ib. 12. 6 and 9.
4) Vi. I. 6. 16.
text.15896:
Siddhis — eighteen in number of which ten are the
principles of guṇas, and eight depend on Hari. These are
Aṇimā, Mahimā, Laghimā, Prākāśya, Īśitva, Vaśita: other
siddhis enumerated: All these are consequences of yoga.
Bhā. XI. 15. 3-34. Br. IV. 18. 18; 38. 38.
text.15897:
Siddhikṣetram — in the Amarakaṇṭaka hill.
Br. III. 13. 14.
text.15898:
Siddhimati — the wife of Matanga and mother of
Laghuśyāma.
Br. IV. 31. 103.
text.15899:
Siddheśvaram — a tīrtha sacred to Pitṛs.
M. 22. 43; 191. 108, 122.
text.15900:
Sinīvālī (I) — a daughter of Angiras and Smṛti, and
wife of Dhātri: mother of Darśa.
Bhā. IV. 1. 34; VI. 18. 3; Vā. 28. 15; Br. II. 11. 18. Vi. I. 10. 7;
text.15901:
Sinīvālī (II) — a R. in Śālmalidvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 10.
text.15902:
Sinīvālī (III) — the goddess of the New Moon day; a
Śakti, the New Moon day which ends in the Prathama day;1
the moon enters the sun on the New Moon day;2 a day for
meritorious gifts.3 1) Br. II. 11. 18; 26. 44; 28. 10, 59; IV. 32. 13; M. 133. 36; 141. 9,
50.
2) Vā. 50. 201; 55. 42; 56. 9, 54.
3) Vi. II. 8. 80.
text.15903:
Sinī(vālī) (IV) — left her consort Kardama and loved
Soma with 8 other Devis; a devī attending on Soma.
M. 23. 34; Br. III. 65, 26; Vā. 90. 25.
text.15905:
Sindhavas — The seas which issue from the urethra of
Brahmā.
Bhā. III. 12. 26.
text.15906:
Sindhu (I) — a R. in Bhārata varṣa: The region round
about fell into the hands of Vrātyas and others;1 a mahānadī:
falls into the western ocean: fit for śrāddha.2 1) Bhā. V. 19. 18; XII. 1. 39; Vā. 45. 97.
2) Ib. 47. 39; 69. 241;
77. 56, 113; 108. 79.
text.15907:
Sindhu (II) — (c). Its king was Jayadratha, who was a
contemporary of Jarāsandha: was stationed on the east of
Gomanta during the siege.
Bhā. X. 52. 11 [6].
text.15909:
Sindhu (IV) — one of the three branches of the Gangā
from the Pāriyātra hill flowing to the north;1 in the chariot
of Tripurāri;2 flows through the kingdoms of Darada,
Kāśmīra, Gāndhāra and others: falls into the western
ocean;3 noted for Padma elephants;4 north and south of, unfit
for śrāddha;5 confluence of, with the sea holy.6 1) M. 114. 20; 121. 40; Br. II. 16. 24, 27.
2) M. 133. 23; 163. 62.
3) Br. II. 18. 41, 46-7; III. 13. 121.
4) Ib. III. 7. 358.
5) Ib. III. 14.
33 and 81.
6) Ib. III. 13. 57.
text.15910:
Sindhuka — an Āndhra: overcame the Kaṇva Suśarman
(Śunga) and began the Āndhra line: ruled for 23 years.
Br. III. 74. 161; Vā. 99. 348-9.
text.15911:
Sindhutaṭa — the region of the Indus; ruled by Mlecchas.
Vi. IV. 24. 69.
text.15912:
Sindhudeśa — noted for war horses.
Br. IV. 16. 16.
text.15913:
Sindhudvīpa (I) — a son of Nābha, and father of
Ayutāyu.
Bhā. IX. 9. 16.
text.15914:
Sindhudvīpa (II) — a son of Ambarīṣa, and father of
Ayutāyu.
Br. III. 63. 170; M. 12. 45; Vā. 88. 171; Vi. IV. 4. 36.
text.15915:
Sindhunetra — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 82.
text.15917:
Sindhuyojana — a kind of measurement.
Br. IV. 31. 66.
text.15919:
Sindhusauvīra — (c) the country over which Rahūgaṇa
ruled.
Bhā. V. 10. 1; M. 114. 41; Vā. 45. 116.
text.15920:
Simha (I) — a son of Mādrī and Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 61. 15.
text.15921:
Simha (II) — a palace in the form of a lion; the toraṇa
is 16 hastas.
M. 269. 36, 49.
text.15922:
Simhas — born of Hari and Pulaha; as a son of Jām
bavān, a vānara jāti;1 a golden image of, as a gift for
vīravratam of women;2 the riding animal of Lalitā;3 born
out of the wrath of Śiva and destroyed Dakṣa's sacrifice.4 1) Br. III. 7. 176, 304, 319; 22. 19; 26. 30; IV. 6. 50.
2) M. 101. 28.
3) Br. III. 35. 38; 51. 10; IV. 17. 8; 29. 41.
4) Vā. 101. 295.
text.15923:
Simhaghoṣa — a son and commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 81; 26. 48.
text.15924:
Simhadvāra — the lion-gate in front of Śivaloka.
Br. III. 32. 11.
text.15925:
Simhanāda (also meghanāda) a war cry;1 made by
Kṛṣṇa on seeing the Ariṣṭa bull;2 before wrestling with
Cāṇūra.3 1) Br. IV. 29. 28;
2) Vi. V. 14. 8.
3) Ib. V. 20. 35.
text.15926:
Simharatha — the chariot of lion of Kārttikeya.
Vā. 41. 38.
text.15927:
Simhala — an Upadvīpa to Jambūdvīpa;1 the modern
Ceylon: to be conquered by Kalki.2 1) Bhā. V. 19. 30.
2) Br. II. 31. 82; III. 73. 107; M. 144. 56.
text.15929:
Simhastha Bṛhaspati — When Guru is in Simha (this
only once in every twelve years) Gayāśrāddham not to be
omitted.
Vā. 105. 19.
text.15930:
Simhāsana — the lion throne for kings;1 of Devī which
was placed in the Sabhā;2 of the Pāṇḍavas; Mārkaṇḍeya
seated by Yudhiṣṭhira on;3 of Tāraka Asura.4 1) Br. III. 26. 21.
2) Ib. IV. 14. 12.
3) M. 103. 18.
4) Ib. 148. 29;
text.15933:
Simhikā (I) — a daughter of Diti and Kaśyapa and
sister of Hiraṇyakaśipu: the wife of Vipracitti, and mother
of one hundred and one sons of whom Rāhu was the eldest;1
mother of 14 Rākṣasas;2 mother of grahas.3 1) Bhā. V. 24. 1; VI. 6. 37; 18. 13; Br. II. 24. 92; M. 6. 25;
Vā. 67. 60; 128. 50; Vi. I. 15. 141.
2) Br. III. 5. 12; Vi. I. 21. 10-11;
3) M. 171. 60.
text.15934:
Simhikā (II) — a daughter of Dakṣa;1 a goddess enshrin
ed at Kṛtaśauca.2 1) M. 171. 29.
2) Ib. 13. 45.
text.15935:
Sirālaka — a son of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 26. 48.
text.15936:
Silindhras — (c) a western kingdom watered by the
Sītā.
Br. II. 18. 44.
text.15937:
Sītā (I) — a branch of the Gangā issuing from the city
of Brahmā: descends Kesara and other hills, falls on the
summits of Gandhamādana, and traversing the continent of
Bhadrāśva, falls into the Eastern Ocean;1 rises out of the
Sitānta slopes of the Mukuñja hill, flows through Sumañjasa,
Mālyavata, Vaikanka, Maṇiparvatam, Ṛṣabham, Jaṭhara,
Devakūṭa, and reaches through the Gandhamādana and takes
the name of Alakanandā and enters the Mānasa lake. 1) Bhā V. 17. 5-6; Br. II. 12. 16; 18. 22, 41-5; 26. 44; III. 56. 52;
Vā. 42. 17-35; 47. 39, 43; 55. 42; Vi. II. 2. 34-5; 8. 113.
text.15938:
Sītā (II) — The goddess enshrined at Citrakūṭa.
M. 13. 39.
text.15941:
Sītā (V) — the supernatural daughter of Janaka;1 is
Lakṣmī; the wife of Rāma;2 was discovered by Sīradhvaja
when ploughing the earth for a sacrifice.3 In her svayam
vara, Rāma broke the dhanus of Śiva. Ravished by her
beauty Rāvaṇa took her to Lankā and kept her under a
śimśupa tree. Recovered by Rāma. Ever devoted to her
lord, enjoyed his company at the capital. In the sacrifices
she gave away all her things as gifts except saumāngalya.
Bore the water jar when Bharata carried the Pādukā.4 Respect
of, to Brahmanas and elders; was sent to Vālmīki's hermitage
though pregnant as Rāma heard a citizen speak ill of her
stay in Rāvaṇa's palace; gave birth to Kuśa and Lava. After
entrusting her sons to the care of the sage, she entered the
bowels of the earth.5 1) Vi. IV. 4. 92-3; 5. 28;
2) Vā. 106. 58; Vi. I. 9. 144;
3) Vā.
88. 195; 89. 15; 108. 19 and 25.
4) Bhā. V. 19. 1-5; IX. 10. 3; 13.
18; XI. 4. 21; Br. III. 63. 196; Bhā. IX. 10. 6-30. 44 & 56; 11.
4 and 35; X. 71. 9: 83. 10;
5) IX. 10. 41 and 47: 11. 10-15.
text.15944:
Sīterajā — a R. of the Bhāratavarṣa.
Vā. 45. 101.
text.15946:
Sītodāmpādikā — a R. of the Ketumālā continent.
Vā. 44. 21.
text.15947:
Sīmanta — one of the samskāras enjoined on a dvija.
Vi. III. 13. 6.
text.15948:
Sīradhvaja — a son of Hrasvaroman; when he was
ploughing the earth for an yajña, he discovered Sītā, and
hence her name. Father of Kuśadhvaja; (his brother, Kuśa
dhvaja and son Bhānumat-Vi. P.).
Bhā IX. 13. 18-19; Vā. 89. 15-17; Vi. IV. 5. 27-30.
text.15949:
Sīrāyudha — (Baladeva); had the ploughshare as his
weapon.
Vi. IV. 1. 94 and 96.
text.15951:
Sukanyā (I) — A daughter of Sayāti: when once she
went with her father to the hermitage of Cyavana, she saw
an anthill with two luminous objects in holes which she
pricked with a thorn. This resulted in blood-flowing from
the eyes of the sage Cyavana. The king asked the sage's
pardon by giving his daughter in marriage. Aśvins called
on them and made Cyavana look young to the puzzle of
Sukanyā. The Aśvins revealed to her of Cyavana's rejuvena
tion. Once her father came and seeing her with a young
man, he took him to be her paramour and scolded her. But
when he heard the truth of the matter he was pleased.
Bhā. IV. 3. 2-23; Br. III. 1. 93; 8. 31; 25. 80; 61. 19; M. 12. 21;
Vā. 65. 90; 86. 23. Vi. IV. 1. 62.
text.15953:
Sukamala — a son of Devayanī, and an Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 129.
text.15955:
Sukarman (I) — a son of Śvaphalka.
Bhā. IX. 24. 16; Br. III. 71. 112.
text.15956:
Sukarman (II) — A son of Sunvā(na): an illustrious
pupil of Jaimini and author of the Saman with a thousand
Samhitas. His pupils were Hiraṇyanābha and Pauṣyañji,
besides an Āvantya: Had 500 disciples from the north and
a good number from the east.1 The story goes that as he
taught the Samhitas on anadhyayana days, Indra killed his
pupils. At this the sage took to prāyopavesa, and Indra ap
peased him by saying that he would have two best pupils
alive, and these were Hiraṇyanābha and Pauṣyañji.2 1) Bhā. XII. 6. 76-78; Vā. 61. 27-32.
2) Br. II. 35. 32; Vi. III.
6. 2-3.
text.15957:
Sukarmas — gods of the epoch of the 13th Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 31.
text.15958:
Sukarmāṇa (I) — a group of gods of the epoch of Raucya
Manu: Gods of the fourth Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 84 & 88, 97, 100; Vā. 100. 87.
text.15959:
Sukarmāṇa (II) — one of the three devagaṇas of the
13th Manu; oblation given to them are curds and ghee.
Vā. 100. 101, 104; Vi. III. 2. 38.
text.15960:
Sukarmāṇa (III) — a group of Gods of the XII epoch
of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 34.
text.15962:
Sukalpa — one of the eight sons of Mahāpadma, all of
whom ruled only for 12 years.
M. 272. 21.
text.15963:
Sukāmas — a Janapada of the Bhadrā continent.
Vā. 43. 20.
text.15964:
Sukālas — the Pitṛs, sons of Vasiṣṭha — Hiraṇya garbha,
propitiated by śūdras in ceremonies: Mānasa is their king
dom: The R. Narmadā is their mind-born daughter (Mānasi
Kanyā Narmadā).
Br. III. 10. 96-7. Vā. 73. 46-8.
text.15966:
Sukīrti (Bhārgava) — a sage of the second Sāvarṇa
epoch.
Br. IV. 1. 69.
text.15967:
Sukumāra (I) — King: a son of Dhṛṣṭaketu and father
of Vītihotra.
Bhā. IX. 17. 9.
text.15968:
Sukumāra (II) — a son of Havya: after him Sukumāra
varṣa.
Br. II. 14. 17-19; Vā. 33. 16.
text.15969:
Sukumāra (III) — a son of Suvibhu and father of
Dhṛṣṭaketu.
Br. III. 67. 76; Vā. 92. 71; Vi. IV. 8. 20.
text.15970:
Sukumāra (IV) — a son of Bhavya of Śākadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 60.
text.15971:
Sukumāram — a kingdom of Śākadvīpa down the Jalada
hill; named after Sukumāra.
Br. II. 14. 19; 19. 91; M. 122. 21; Vā. 33. 18. 49. 86.
text.15972:
Sukumārī (I) — a R. of Śākadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 96; M. 122. 30; Vā. 49. 91. Vi. II. 4. 65.
text.15973:
Sukumārī (II) — a R. from Śuktimanta.
M. 114. 32; Vā. 45. 107.
text.15974:
Śukṛta (I) — a son of Vasiṣṭha and a Prajāpati of the
Svārociṣa epoch.
M. 9. 9.
text.15976:
Sukṛta (III) — a sage of the X epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 27.
text.15977:
Sukṛtā (I) — a R. of Plakṣadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 19; Vā. 49. 17; Vi. II. 4. 11.
text.15978:
Sukṛtā (II) — a R. of the Śākadvīpa.
M. 122. 33.
text.15979:
Sukṛti (I) — a sage of the epoch of the Tenth Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 22.
text.15981:
Sukṛti (III) — a son of Pṛthu and father of Vibhrāja.
Vi. IV. 19. 42.
text.15983:
Suketana — son of Sunītha, and father Dharmaketu.
Bhā. IX. 17. 8.
text.15984:
Suketu (I) — a son of Nandivardhana of Magadha, and
father of Devarāta; a bold and righteous king.
Bhā. IX. 13. 14; Br. III. 64. 7; Vā. 89. 7; Vi. IV. 5. 25. Br. III.
64. 7.
text.15985:
Suketu (II) — a son of Uttama Manu.
Br. II. 36. 40; Vā. 62. 35.
text.15988:
Suketu (V) — a son of Sagara.
Br. III. 63. 147.
text.15989:
Suketu (VI) — a son of Ketumān: father of Dharma
ketu.
Br. III. 67. 74.
text.15990:
Suketu (VII) — a son of Sunītha; a righteous monarch;
father of Dharmaketu.
Vā. 92. 69-70; Vi. IV. 8. 19.
text.15991:
Sukeśa (I) — a sage in Dāruvana.
Br. II. 27. 104.
text.15994:
Sukeśī(ā) — a daughter of Tumburu.
Br. III. 7. 13; IV. 33. 19; Vā. 69. 49.
text.15995:
Sukṣatra — a Bṛhadratha: ruled Magadha for 56 years.
Br. III. 74. 112.
text.15996:
Sukṣetra (I) — a son of the second Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 71.
text.15997:
Sukṣetra (II) — a son of Brahmasāvarṇi Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 28.
text.15999:
Sukha (II) — a son of Siddhi.
Br. II. 9. 61; Vā. 10. 37.
text.16000:
Sukha (III) — a son of Śuki and Garuḍa.
Br. III. 7. 450.
text.16002:
Sukhavratam — performer of the, becomes Yakṣarāja.
M. 101, 73.
text.16003:
Sukhā (I) — the city of Varuṇa to the west of Meru: on
the Mānasa: midnight here when midday at Amarāvatī.
Br. II. 21. 32. 38; Vā. 50. 89; Vi. II. 8. 9.
text.16004:
Sukhā (II) — one of the three Devagaṇas of the first
Sāvarṇi Manu: 20 in number.
Br. IV. 1. 12, 18-19.
text.16005:
Sukhā (III) — Ṛ. a mahānadī between the Nīlā and
Kumuñja hills; on its shores is a tālavana.
Vā. 37. 23.
text.16006:
Sukhī — a R. in Plakṣadvīpa.
Br. II. 19. 19.
text.16007:
Sukhīnala — a son of Nṛcakṣu and father of Pariplava.
Bhā. IX. 22. 41. 2.
text.16008:
Sukhībala — a son of Nṛcakṣu (Tricakṣu-Vā. P.), (Nṛpa
cakṣu-Vi. P.) and father of Pāriplava.
M. 50. 82; Vā. 99. 274; Vi. IV. 21. 12.
text.16009:
Sukhodaya — a son of Medhātithi and founder of the
Sukhodayam kingdom (Sukhānu kingdom in Plakṣadvīpa).
Br. II. 14. 36-8; Vā. 33. 32; Vi. II. 4. 4 and 5.
text.16010:
Sukhodayam — a varṣa adjoining the Nārada hill of
Plakṣa;1 same as the Kaumāram.2 1) Br. II. 14. 38; 19. 15; Vā. 49. 14;
2) M. 122. 22.
text.16011:
Sugati — a son of Gaya and Gāyantī.
Bhā. V. 15. 14.
text.16012:
Sugativratam — leads to the world of Indra.
M. 101. 56.
text.16013:
Sugandha — a son of Devajanī and an Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 130.
text.16014:
Sugandhā (I) — (Sugandhi) — a servant maid of Vasu
deva: gave birth to Punḍṛa and Kapila through Vasudeva.
Br. III. 71. 163, 185.
text.16015:
Sugandhā (II) — the Goddess enshrined at Mādhava
vana.
M. 13. 37.
text.16017:
Sugandhi — one of the 13 wives of Vasudeva; mother of
Puṇḍra.
Vā. 96. 161, 183.
text.16018:
Sugrīva (I) — a friend of Rāma. Dvivida was one of his
ministers. Helped Rāma in his expedition to Lankā. Held
the chauri when Bharata carried the Pādukā. Attained
salvation by satsanga;1 the son of Viraja and Sūrya: Rumā
was his queen: younger brother of Vāli;2 present at Rāma's
abhiṣeka;3 to be worshipped before commencing the construc
tion of a palace.4 1) Bhā. IX. 10. 16, 19 & 43; X. 67. 2; XI. 12. 6.
2) Br. III. 7. 215,
220 & 70.
3) Vi. IV. 4. 100.
4) M. 268. 15
text.16019:
Sugrīva (II) — the name of a horse of the chariot of
Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 53. 5; 70. 14; 89. 49.
text.16020:
Sugrīva (III) — a son of Śrutadevī and Kṛta.
M. 46. 5.
text.16021:
Sugrīva (IV) — the name of a son of Garuḍa on the
Vaikanka hill.
Vā. 39. 40.
text.16022:
Sugrīva (V) — a king of Kinnaras; a gaṇa, all of them
horse-faced, and going after his name
Vā. 41. 30; 69. 32.
text.16023:
Sugrīvi — a daughter of Tāmrā and Kaśyapa; mother of
sheep, horses, camels and asses.
M. 6. 30, 33; Vi. I. 21. 15, 17.
text.16024:
Sucakṣu — a branch of the Gangā.
Br. III. 56. 52.
text.16026:
Sucandra (I) — went to Syamantapañcaka for the solar
eclipse;1 an Andhaka.2 1) Bhā. X. 82. 6.
2) Br. III. 71. 143.
text.16027:
Sucandra (II) — a son of Krodhā and a Devagandharva;
father of Dhūmrāśva.
Br. III. 6. 39; Vā. 68. 39; 86. 18.
text.16028:
Sucandra (III) — a son of Devajanī: an Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 129.
text.16029:
Sucandra (IV) — of the solar race: an ally of Kārtavīrya:
an able soldier: Attacking him, Paraśurāma remembered
Bhadrakālī and vanquished him: father of Puṣkarākṣa.
Br. III. 39. 18, 50; 40. 1.
text.16030:
Sucandra (V) — a son of king Hemacandra.
Br. III. 61. 13.
text.16031:
Sucandra (VI) — a son of Kṛṣṇa given to the sonless
Karūṣa in adoption.
M. 46. 25.
text.16032:
Sucāru (I) — a son of Rukmiṇī and Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 61. 8; M. 47. 16; Vi. V. 28. 2.
text.16033:
Sucāru (II) — a son of Pratibāhu.
Vā. 96. 251; Vi. IV. 15. 42.
text.16038:
Suciratha — a son of Vicitraratha and father of Vṛṣṇimat.
Vi. IV. 21. 11-12.
text.16040:
Sucīrā (Sucārā B) — a daughter of Śvaphalka.
Bhā. IX. 24. 17.
text.16041:
Succhāyā — a daughter of Agni and wife of Śiṣṭa, (Śiṣṭi
Vi. P.).
M. 4. 38; Vi. I. 13. 1.
text.16042:
Sujaṃgha — the first of several sons of Dattāli; all known
as Paulastyas.
Vā. 28. 24.
text.16043:
Sujaṅghī — a wife of Dānāgni: many sons all Paulastyas.
Br. II. 11. 29.
text.16046:
Sujāta — a Vānara chief and a son of Śveta.
Br. III. 7, 181.
text.16050:
Sujyeṣṭha — a son of Agnimitra, and father of Vasu
mitra;1 ruled for seven years.2 1) Bhā. XII. 16. 17. Vi. IV. 24. 35.
2) Br. III. 74. 151.
text.16051:
Sutami — a son of Ugrasena.
Br. III. 71. 133. Vā. 96. 132.
text.16052:
Sutanū (I) — a daughter of Ugrasena, the Kāśi king, and
a wife of Vasudeva, mother of Pauṇḍraka.
Bhā. X. 66. [5]; Br. III. 71. 134; M. 44. 76; 46. 21; Vi. IV.
14. 21.
text.16053:
Sutanū (II) — a daughter of Yudhiṣṭhira; married
Aśvasuta, son Vajra.
Vā. 96. 250.
text.16054:
Sutapas (I) — the gods of the eighth manvantara: one
of the three devagaṇas of the first Sāvarṇi Manu, twenty in
number.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 12; Br. IV. 1. 12, 14 & 15. Vā. 100. 13-15.
text.16055:
Sutapas (II) — a son of Antarikṣa and father of
Amitrajit.
Bhā. IX. 12. 12.
text.16056:
Sutapas (III) — a son of Hema, and father of Bali.
Bhā. IX. 23. 4; Br. III. 74. 25; Vi. IV. 18. 12.
text.16057:
Sutapas (IV) — the progenitor and husband of Pṛśni of
the Svāyambhuva epoch.
Bhā. X. 3. 32.
text.16058:
Sūtapas (V) — one of the seven sons of Vasiṣṭha, and
Ūrjā;1 a sage of the Raucya epoch.2 1) Br. II. 11. 42; Vā. 28. 36; Vi. I. 10. 13.
2) Br. IV. 1. 103.
text.16060:
Sutapas (VII) — a Marut of the first gaṇa.
Br. III. 5-92.
text.16062:
Sutapas (IX) — (Paulapa) a sage of the Rohita epoch.
Br. IV. 1. 64.
text.16063:
Sutapas (X) — (Ātreya) a sage of the fourth Sāvarṇa
Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 91. Vā. 100. 96.
text.16065:
Sutapas (XII) — a son of Pariṣṇava or Pariplava.
M. 50. 83.
text.16066:
Sutapas (XIII) — Gods of the Sāvarṇi epoch.
Vi. III. 2. 15.
text.16067:
Sutapas (XIV) — a sage of the XII epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 35.
text.16068:
Sutapas (XV) — a sage of the XIII epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 40.
text.16069:
Sutaptā — a R. of the Plakṣadvīpa.
Vā. 49. 17.
text.16070:
Sutamitra — a Marut of the second gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 93.
text.16071:
Sutalam (I) — an under world and the residence of Bali:
represents the two knees of the Lord;1 Built by Viśvakarman.
Bali was sent to this as punishment but was pleased with
it: the great cave which Bali and Prahlāda entered;2 reached
by Kṛṣṇa and Rāma to recover their brothers killed by
Kamsa; Bali then as Indrasena welcomed them;3 Pātālam,
assigned to Bali by Vāmana.4 1) Bhā. II. 1. 27; 5. 40; V. 24. 7 & 18; VIII. 13. 14.
2) Ib. VIII. 22.
32; 23. 3 & 9, 11-12.
3) Ib. X. 85. 34-38.
4) M. 246, 69, 75-9; Vi. II.
5. 2-3.
text.16072:
Sutalam (II) — the second world of white soil: residence
of Brahmanas;1 here is the town of Mahājambha and other
Asuras and Nāgas.2 1) Br. II. 20. 11, 14, 25; Vā. 50. 11, and 13.
2) Vā. 50. 20-25.
text.16073:
Sutahotra — a son of Svarbhānu; had three sons Kāśa,
Śala, and Gṛtsamada.
Vā. 92. 2.
text.16074:
Sutāpī (I) — a daughter of Devakī and one of the seven
wives of Vasudeva.
M. 44. 73.
text.16075:
Sutāpi (II) — the avatār of the Lord in the second
dvāpara.
Vā. 23. 120.
text.16077:
Sutāra (II) (Sutara) — a gaṇa of the 4th Sāvarṇa Manu
of 10 gods.
Br. IV. 1. 84, 89.
text.16078:
Sutārā — a daughter of Upamadgu (Cal. Edṇ. and
Wilson-sister).
Vi. IV. 14. 9.
text.16079:
Sutāla — a ṛtvik at the Yāga of Brahmā.
Vā. 106. 36.
text.16080:
Sutuṣṭimat — a son of Ugrasena.
Vi. IV. 14. 20.
text.16082:
Sutyā — a special ceremonial of the Soma sacrifice (of
Pṛthu); the havis for Bṛhaspati offered to Indra, and hence
the Sūta — Bṛhaspati and Indra, master and disciple; the
wrong offering led to Sūta's varṇa vaikṛta.
Vā. 1. 34; 62. 137.
text.16083:
Sutrāmas (Sutrāman Bhā. P.) — (Sūtrāmaṇa-Vi. P.)
gods of the epoch of the thirteenth Manu, of the Raucya Manu
(Sutrāmaṇas).
Bhā. VIII. 13. 31; Br. IV. 1. 97-99; Vi. III. 2. 38.
text.16084:
Sutrāmāṇa — one of the three devagaṇas of the 13th
Raucya manu; these devas drink ghee given in Prayājya
homas.
Vā. 100. 101, 104.
text.16085:
Sutvat (Sunvān) — the son and pupil of Sumantu:
father of Sukarman.
Br. II. 35. 31; Vā. 61. 26.
text.16086:
Sutvāna (I) — the name of the daityas.
Br. III. 6. 14.
text.16087:
Sutvāna (II) — a grandson of Jaimini, taught by him one
Samhitā of the Sāma Veda; he taught his son Sukarma.
Vi. III. 6. 2-3.
text.16089:
Sudakṣiṇa — the son of Pauṇḍraka: King of Kāmbhojas:
attacked with Jarāsandha the western gate of Mathurā, and
the eastern gate of Gomanta, performed funeral rites to his
father. In order to take vengeance on Kṛṣṇa, he worshipped
Śiva who directed him to pray to Dakṣiṇāgni out of which
would spring up an abhicāra fire which would kill Kṛṣṇa.
He did so but the Agni was not able to meet Kṛṣṇa's cakra
and returned only to kill Sudakṣiṇa himself.
Bhā. X. 66. 27-40; 50 11[5]; 52. 11 [7].
text.16091:
Sudatī (II) — (Sadvatī) a daughter of Prītī and Pulastya,
mother of Parjanya and wife Agni.
Vā. 28. 23.
text.16093:
Sudaṃṣṭra (I) — a son of Ajāta and an Andhaka.
M. 44. 84; Vā. 96. 141.
text.16094:
Sudaṃṣṭra (II) — the adopted son of Asamanjasa.
Vā. 96. 141.
text.16095:
Sudaridra — an old poor Brahman of Pāñcala deśa who
had the four cakravākas (in previous birth sons of
Kauśika) as his sons, all learned Brahmans. The sons left
for yoga giving a verse (on their previous births) to their
old father to show it to the king and get money and land.
Thus he did and got much wealth including many villages.
M. 21. 3-10.
text.16097:
Sudarśana (I) — a weapon of Kṛṣṇa, known as Cakra;1
reached Kṛṣṇa when Mathurā was besieged by Jarāsandha,
and was used to kill Śatadhanvā;2 sent to the sun and moon
to ward off Rāhu's attack;3 presented to Ambarīṣa; fell upon
Durvāsa when he raised a spirit to attack Ambarīṣa who
begged to spare the sage and the Cakra did so;4 a weapon of
Hari, at Kāśī.5 1) Bhā. I. 8. 13; III. 19. 22; VIII. 4. 19.
2) Ib. X. 50 11[2]; 57. 21.
3) Ib. V. 24. 3.
4) Ib. IX. 4. 28 & 48; 52. 11 & 12; XI. 27. 27; XII. 11. 14;
Br. III. 5. 28. 40. 66.
5) M. V. 29. 17; 30. 67; 33. 35; 34. 37.
text.16098:
Sudarśana (II) — a son of Bharata.
Bhā. V. 7. 3.
text.16099:
Sudarśana (III) — the husband of Oghavatī and a sage,
called on the dying Bhīṣma.
Bhā. IX. 2. 18; I. 9. 7.
text.16100:
Sudarśana (IV) — a son of Dhurvasandhi and father of
Agni varṇa (of Kuśa vamśa).
