Bhā. IX. 12. 5; Br. III. 63. 209; Vā. 88. 209; Vi. IV. 4. 108.
text.16101:
Sudarśana (V) — a Vidyādhara who mocked at Angi
rasa's ugliness and was cursed to become a reptile until
released by Kṛṣṇa; when he seized Nanda, Kṛṣṇa came to
his rescue, and at his touch the serpent was transformed into
the Vidyādhara. He bowed to the Lord and went to his
region.
Bhā. X. 34. 12-18; XI. 16. 19.
text.16102:
Sudarśana (VI) — a tīrtha visited by Balarāma.
Bhā. X. 78. 19.
text.16103:
Sudarśana (VII) — a son of Puṇyajanī and Maṇibhadra;
an Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 125; Vā. 69. 156.
text.16104:
Sudarśana (VIII) — a Jambū tree (see V. P.).
M. 114. 74. Vā. 285. 22.
text.16105:
Sudas — an Apsara gaṇa from winds.
Vā. 69. 57.
text.16107:
Sudānta — a son of Hṛdīka.
Br. III. 71. 141; Vā. 96. 140.
text.16108:
Sudāman (I) — the florist of Kamsa: welcomed Kṛṣṇa
with Rāma and presented them with choice garlands; was
blessed with long life and happiness.
Bhā. X. 41. 43-52.
text.16109:
Sudāman (II) — defended the northern gate of Mathurā
when it was besieged.
Bhā. X. 50. 20[3].
text.16111:
Sudāsa (I) — a son of Sarvakāma, father of Kalmāṣa
nemi (Mitrasaha-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 9. 18; Vi. IV. 4. 39-40.
text.16112:
Sudāsa (II) — a son of Cyavana and father of Sahadeva
(Sandāsa-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 22. 1; Vā. 99. 208; Vi. IV. 19. 71.
text.16113:
Sudāsa (III) — a son of Bṛhadratha and father of
Śatānīka.
Bhā. IX. 22. 43.
text.16114:
Sudāsa (V) — a son of Vīrasena and father of Kalmāṣa
pāda: a friend of Indra.
Br. III. 63. 175.
text.16118:
Sudeva (I) — a son of Dakṣiṇā and Tuṣita god.
Bhā. IV. 1. 7-8.
text.16119:
Sudeva (II) — a son of Campa and father of Vijaya.
Bhā. IX. 8. 1.
text.16120:
Sudeva (III) — a son of Devaka.
Bhā. IX. 24. 22; Br. III. 71. 130; M. 44. 72; Vā. 96. 129.
text.16121:
Sudeva (IV) — a son of Cancu.
Br. III. 63. 118; Vā. 88. 120.
text.16122:
Sudeva (V) — a son of Rukmiṇī and Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 71. 245.
text.16124:
Sudevī (I) — the mother of Ṛṣabha.
Bhā. II. 7. 10.
text.16125:
Sudevī (II) — a devī and consort of Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 71. 251; Vā. 96. 234.
text.16127:
Sudeśa — (c) a Kingdom;1 the country of Janamejaya.2 1) Br. III. 68. 20.
2) Vā. 93. 21.
text.16128:
Sudeṣṇa — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Rukmiṇī: went with the
sacrificial horse of his father.
Bhā. X. 61. 8; 89. 22 [2]; M. 47. 16; Vā. 96. 237: Vi. 28. 1.
text.16129:
Sudeṣṇā — the queen of Bali Vairocana, son of Sutapa;
issueless Bali advised her to have intercourse with sage
Dirghatamas; finding him old and blind she sent her slave
girl (Nurse-Vā. P.) to whom were born Kakṣīvān and
Cakṣuṣa; the king found this out and persuaded the queen
and sage once again; the sage agreed on condition that she
smeared all his body with curds and salt and licked the
whole of it; she did so omitting the bottom portion; the sage
cursed that her first son would be without buttocks; on her
request he agreed that her first grandson would be born like
that and not her son; she got five sons, Anga, Vanga, etc.
Br. III. 74. 34-88; M. 48. 61-79; Vā. 99. 34, 68-86.
text.16130:
Sudyu (I) — the son of Cārupada and father of
Bahugava.
Bhā. IX. 20. 3.
text.16131:
Sudyu (II) — the son of Abhayada and father of
Bahugata.
Vi. IV. 19. 1.
text.16132:
Sudyumna (I) — one of the ten sons of Cākṣuṣa Manu;
Ilā converted into a male: (Kimpuruṣa); once when he rode
into a forest on a saindhava horse, he came upon Umā's
pleasure garden where he with his followers were trans
formed into females. This was due to a boon granted to
Pārvatī by Śiva. In this womanly form Budha saw and
embraced her. Aila Purūravas was born of this union.
Sudyumna wanted to regain his male form and prayed to
Vasiṣṭha. The latter waited on Śiva who allowed Sudyumna
to have male form and female form in alternate months.
Returning to his kingdom he was not liked by his subjects.
His three sons were in charge of Dakṣiṇāpatha. In the ful
ness of time Purūravas was placed in charge of Pratiṣṭhāna,
Sudyumna leaving for forest to perform penance; father of
three sons, Utkala, Gaya and Haritāśva (Kiratāśva-Vā. P.);
(Vinata-Vi. P.); being once a female had no share of the
kingdom; however got Pratiṣṭhāna, through Vasiṣṭha's help;
that was given to Purūravas.
Bhā. VIII. 5. 7; IX. 1 (whole); Br. II. 36. 79-106; III. 60. 14-27;
M. 4. 42; 12. 16-17; Vā. 62. 91; 85. 15-19; 25. 28. Vi. I. 13. 5. IV.
1. 10-16.
text.16134:
Sudhanus (I) — a son of Kuru, and father of Suhotra.
Bhā. IX. 22. 4 & 5; Vi. IV. 19. 78-9.
text.16135:
Sudhanus (II) — a son of the daughter of Yudhiṣṭhira.
Br. III. 71. 259.
text.16136:
Sudhanvan (I) — a son of Virajasa Prajāpati and king
of the East (West-Vi. P.).
Br. III. 8. 18; Vi. I. 22. 11.
text.16137:
Sudhanvan (II) — a son of Kuru.
M. 50. 23; Vā. 99. 217.
text.16138:
Sudhanvan (III) — a son of Dhiṣṇu and father of Ṛṣa
bha; a charioteer of the Devas.
Vā. 65. 102.
text.16139:
Sudhanvan (IV) — a son of Satyahita Vikrānta (Satya
hita-Vi. P.) and father of Jatu.
Vā. 99. 225; Vi. IV. 19. 82.
text.16141:
Sudharman (II) — a son of the III Sāvarṇa epoch.
Br. IV. 1. 80; Vā. 100. 84.
text.16142:
Sudharman (III) — the guardian deity of the East.
M. 8. 9.
text.16143:
Sudharman (IV) — a sage of the Cākṣuṣa epoch; attained
heaven by tapas.
M. 9. 22; 143. 38.
text.16144:
Sudharman (V) — a son of Aśvinī and Akrūra.
M. 45. 33.
text.16146:
Sudharman (VII) — a son of Dharmasāvarṇi.
Vi. III. 2. 32.
text.16147:
Sudharmā — the heavenly sabhā sent by Indra and
brought to Dvārakā by Kṛṣṇa, taken by Vāyu under orders
of Kṛṣṇa; in this Kṛṣṇa seated himself.1 It formed the council
hall of Dvārakā. Here Kṛṣṇa met the elders. Entered by
Kṛṣṇa after the Kurukṣetra war;2 went back to heaven after
Kṛṣṇa's departure to it.3 1) Bhā. I. 14. 34-38; X. Ib. 64 [1]; Br. IV. 9. 6; 10. 23.
2) Ib. X.
[67 (v) 42]; 68. 35; 70. 17; 80 [12]; XI. 30. 4.
3) Vi. V. 35. 24;
38. 7.
text.16148:
Sudharmāṇa (I) — a group of 12 gods of the Raucya
epoch;1 partake in upayājya sacrifices.2 1) Br. IV. 1. 55, 59-60, 97.
2) Vā. 100. 101-5.
text.16149:
Sudharmāṇa (II) — a group of gods of the IX Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 21.
text.16150:
Sudharmāṇa (III) — a group of Gods of XIII Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 38.
text.16151:
Sudhāman (I) — a son of Ghṛtapṛṣṭha.
Bhā. V. 20. 21.
text.16152:
Sudhāman (II) — (see also Vairāja): a son of Viraja
and Gaurī) a lokapāla; father of Vairaja.
Br. II. 11. 13; Vā. 28. 11; 50. 206; 62. 66.
text.16153:
Sudhāman (III) — (also Vairāja) a son of Kardama; a
lokapāla of Lokāloka hill; attained heaven by tapas.
Br. II. 21. 157; 30. 40; M. 124. 95. Vi. II. 8. 83.
text.16154:
Sudhāman (IV) — a Kaśyapa and a sage of the Cākṣuṣa
and Raivata epochs.
Br. II. 36. 61, 77.
text.16155:
Sudhāman (V) — a disciple of Lokākṣi, an avatār of the
Lord.
Vā. 23. 135.
text.16156:
Sudhāman (VI) — a son of Vāli, an avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 160.
text.16158:
Sudhāman (VIII) — a sage of the Raivata epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 22.
text.16159:
Sudhāmanas — a group of 12 gods of the epoch of Uttama
Manu and also of the II Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. II. 36. 26, 28; IV. 1. 55, 67; Vi. III. 1. 14.
text.16160:
Sudhāmāna (I) — a group of gods of the X epoch.
Vi. III. 2. 25.
text.16161:
Sudhāmāna (II) — a son of Prajāpati and lord of the
Eastern direction.
Vā. 70. 16.
text.16163:
Sudhāvantau — months of Iṣa and Ūrja.
Vā. 30. 9.
text.16165:
Sudhiya (I) — a group of gods of the Tāmasa Manu.
Br. II. 36. 43; Vā. 62. 37.
text.16166:
Sudhiya (II) — a group of gods of the Tāmasa epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 16.
text.16167:
Sudhīra — the son of Kṣemya, and father of Ripuñjaya.
Vi. IV. 19. 55.
text.16168:
Sudhṛti (I) — a son of Rājyavardhana and father of
Nara.
Bhā. IX. 2. 29; Br. III. 8. 35.
text.16169:
Sudhṛti (II) — a son of Rāṣṭravardhana.
Br. III. 61. 9.
text.16170:
Sudhṛti (III) — the son of Dhṛtimat and father of
Dhṛṣṭaketu.
Br. III. 64. 9; Vā. 89. 9.
text.16171:
Sudhṛti (IV) — a son of Vikrānta and father of Nara.
Vā. 86. 13.
text.16172:
Sudhṛti (V) — a son of Kevala and father of Nara.
Vi. VI. 1. 39-40.
text.16173:
Sudhṛti (VI) — a son of Mahāvīrya and father of Dhṛṣṭa
ketu.
Bhā. IX. 13. 15; Vi. IV. 5. 25-6.
text.16174:
Sunakṣatra (I) — a son of Manudeva and father of Puṣ
kara (Kinnara-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 12. 12; M. 271. 8; Vi. IV. 22. 4.
text.16175:
Sunakṣatra (II) — a son of Nirāmitra and father of
Bṛhatsena.
Bhā. IX. 22. 47.
text.16177:
Sunanda (I) — a chief attendant on Viṣṇu;1 a celibate
and devoted to Hari. Praised Dhruva and followed Hari go
ing to Pṛthu's sacrifice.2 Attacked Asura followers of Bali.3 1) Bhā. I. 14. 32; II. 9. 14; VII. 8. 39; VIII. 20. 32; 22. 15; X.
39. 53; 89. 57.
2) Ib. IV. 9. 30; 12. 22; 19. 5.
3) VIII. 21. 16.
text.16179:
Sunandaka — a gopa friend of Nanda.
Bhā. X. 34. 4.
text.16180:
Sunandana (I) — a son of Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 90. 34.
text.16181:
Sunandana (II) — a son of Purīṣabhīru and father of
Cakora.
Bhā. XII. 1. 25-26.
text.16182:
Sunandanam (I) — a Janapada of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 19.
text.16183:
Sunandanam (II) — a forest in the Brahmakṣetram.
Vā. 59. 129.
text.16184:
Sunandā (I) — R., on its bank Manu (Svāyambhuva)
practised tapas renouncing the world.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 8.
text.16185:
Sunandā (II) — a daughter of Sāraṇā.
Br. III. 71. 168; Vā. 96. 166.
text.16187:
Sunandī — a son of Nandana.
Vi. IV. 24. 56.
text.16188:
Sunaya (I) — a son of Pariplava (Paripluta-Vā. P., Pāri
plava-Vi. P.) and father of Medhāvi.
Bhā. IX. 22. 43; Vā. 99. 275; Vā. IV. 21. 12.
text.16190:
Sunaya (III) — a son of Kratu (Ṛtu-Vā. P.) and father
of Vītahavya.
Br. III. 64. 22; Vā. 87. 22; Vi. IV. 5. 31.
text.16191:
Sunaśśepa — a son of Viśvāmitra, conferred by Devas;
was the well-known Devasūta.
Vi. IV. 7. 37.
text.16192:
Sunaha — a son of Jambu and Kāverī.
Br. III. 66. 30.
text.16193:
Sunahdhya — a son of Kṣatravṛddha. Father of Kaśa and
two other righteous sons.
Br. III. 67. 3.
text.16194:
Sunābha (I) — a son of Ajāta and an Andhaka.
M. 44. 84.
text.16195:
Sunābha (II) — a son of Garuḍa in Śvetodara hill.
Vā. 39. 56.
text.16196:
Sunāman (I) — a son of Ugrasena;1 a brother of Kamsa;
on the latter's death came to encounter Kṛṣṇa and was killed.
^2 Vi. V. 20. 90. 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 24; Br. III. 71. 133; M. 44. 74; Vā. 96. 132; Vi.
IV. 14. 20.
text.16197:
Sunāman (II) — a pupil of Laugākṣī.
Br. II. 35. 41.
text.16198:
Sunāman (III) — a son of Devakī and Vasudeva.
Br. III. 71. 183.
text.16199:
Sunāman (IV) — an Asura in the Sabhā of Hiraṇya
kaśipu.
M. 161. 79.
text.16200:
Sunāmā — a name for Devakī, a daughter of Devaka.
Vā. 96. 131.
text.16201:
Sunāmnī — one of Vasudeva's wives.
Br. III. 71. 161.
text.16202:
Sunāsam — the city of Kālakeyas; on the Devakūṭa in
Maryāda parvata.
Vā. 40. 11-15.
text.16203:
Sunīti (I) — a queen of Uttānapāda and mother of
Dhruva. Not loved by her husband she was banished; wel
comed Dhruva returning after tapas, and embraced him with
affection; went to heaven in front of Dhruva;1 lament of, at
her child's severe penance;2 attained the status of Tāraka.3 1) Bhā. IV. 8. 8 & 65; 9. 41, 49-50; 12. 32-33; Vi. I. 11. 3.
2) Ib.
I. 12. 14-21.
3) Ib. I. 12. 94.
text.16204:
Sunīti (II) — a son of Sutala and father of Satyajit.
Vi. IV. 23. 9-10.
text.16205:
Sunītha (I) — a son of Santati and father of Suketana
(Suketu-Vā. P. & Vi. P.); a righteous king.
Bhā. IX. 17. 8; Vā. 92. 69; Vi. IV. 8. 19.
text.16206:
Sunītha (II) — a son of Suṣeṇa and father of Nṛcakṣu
(Nṛpacakṣu-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 22. 41; M. 50. 81; Vi. IV. 21. 12.
text.16207:
Sunītha (III) — a son of Subala and father of Satyajit.
Bhā. IX. 22. 49.
text.16208:
Sunītha (IV) — a son of Saunati and father of Kṣema.
Br. III. 67. 73.
text.16209:
Sunītha (V) — a son of Satyā and Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 71. 252.
text.16210:
Sunītha (VI) — a son of Nāgnajiti(jit) and Kṛṣṇa.
M. 47. 19; Vā. 96. 243.
text.16211:
Sunītha (VII) — a son of Śrutaśravas and Caidya; a
righteous monarch.
M. 46. 6.
text.16214:
Sunīthā — daughter of Mṛtya(u) (Pitṛs); queen of
Anga and mother of Vena; informed beforehand of Vena's
coronation; protected his dead body of mantras.
Bhā. IV. 13. 18; 14. 2 & 35; Br. II. 36. 108. M. 4. 44; 10. 3;
Vā. 62. 93, 108. Vi. I. 13. 7, 11.
text.16215:
Sunetra (I) — a son of Śukī and Garuḍa.
Br. III. 7. 450.
text.16216:
Sunetra (II) — a Bṛhadratha; ruled for 40 years.
Br. III. 74. 129; Vā. 99. 306.
text.16217:
Sunetra(ka) (III) — a son of Kauśika in previous births,
born as Cakravāka in Mānasa.
M. 20. 18.
text.16218:
Sunetra (IV) — a son of Anuvrata, ruled for 25 years.
M. 271. 26.
text.16219:
Sunetra (V) — a Yakṣa king in Kailāsa.
Vā. 41. 25.
text.16221:
Sunetra (VII) — a son of Niramitra and father of Bṛhad
karma.
Vi. IV. 23. 4.
text.16223:
Sunda — a son of Hrāda (Nisunda-Vā. P.) father of
Mārīca through Tāḍakā;1 an Asura.2 1) Br. III. 5. 34-5; Vā. 67. 71, 72.
2) Vi. V. 1. 24.
text.16224:
Sundanisunda — a tīrtha fit for śrāddha offering.
Br. III. 13. 47.
text.16225:
Sundara (I) — Śāntikarṇa, ruled for a year.
M. 273. 11.
text.16226:
Sundara (II) — a son of Pulindasena and father of Śata
karṇi.
Vi. IV. 24. 47.
text.16227:
Sundarī (I) — one of the four queens of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 12. 13.
text.16228:
Sundarī (II) — a name of Lalitā; a mother goddess;1 pre
siding deity of the Cakra-Guptatara.2 1) Br. IV. 18. 15; M. 179. 29.
2) Br. IV. 36. 78.
text.16229:
Sunvat — a son of Sumantu.
Bhā. XII. 6. 75.
text.16231:
Supakṣa (II) — a Mt. Temples of Vaivasvata, Soma,
Vāyu and Nāgadhīpa on.
Vā. 39. 63; 42. 48.
text.16232:
Supatha (I) — c. watered by Pāvani.
Br. II. 18. 56.
text.16234:
Suparṇa (I) — a name of Garuḍa;1 brother of Aruṇa;2
outwitted by Kālanemi in the Tārakāmaya;3 residence of, in
the Mārkaṇḍeya hill.4 1) Bhā. III. 1. 39; M. 8. 8; Vi. I. 21. 18.
2) M. 174. 47.
3) Ib. 173.
32.
4) Vā. 40. 1-2.
text.16235:
Suparṇa (II) — a boundary hill in Plakṣadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 4.
text.16236:
Suparṇa (III) — an Asura residing in Rasātalam.
Br. II. 20. 39.
text.16237:
Suparṇa (IV) — a son of Krodhā and a deva gandharva.
Br. III. 6. 39.
text.16239:
Suparṇa (VI) — a brother of Sumatī; wife of Sagara.
Br. III. 63. 158.
text.16241:
Suparṇa (VIII) — a son of Antarikṣa, and father of Ami
trajit.
Vā. 99. 286; Vi. IV. 22. 5.
text.16242:
Suparṇas — worship Pitṛs; Soma Samhitās are attri
buted to them.
Br. II. 35. 71; III. 10. 111.
text.16243:
Suparṇā — a name of Vinatā and mother of Garuḍa.
Bhā. VI. 6. 22.
text.16244:
Suparvān (I) — a god of Sukarmāṇa group.
Br. IV. 1. 88; Vā. 100. 92.
text.16248:
Supāra — a son of Samara and father of Pṛthu.
Vi. IV. 19. 41, 42.
text.16249:
Supāras (I) — one of the five devagaṇas of the epoch of
Ṛtusāvarṇi; mind-born son of Brahmā with ten branches.
Vā. 100. 87.
text.16250:
Supāras (II) — a group of 27 gods of Tāmasa epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 16.
text.16251:
Supārśva (I) — Mt. on one side of Meru; five currents of
honey produced by the celestial Kadamba tree flow down
from its tops; on the north Ilāvṛta;1 a Viṣkambha hill round
Meru;2 sacred to Nārāyaṇī.3 1) Bhā. V. 16. 11 & 22; Vā. 35. 16; Vi. II. 2. 18.
2) M. 83. 23;
113. 45.
3) Ib. 13. 36.
text.16252:
Supārśva (II) — a son of Dhṛta(ḍha)nemi, and father
of Sumati.
Bhā. IX. 21. 27; Vi. IV. 19. 49.
text.16253:
Supārśva (III) — the father of Kāśyā, wife of Sāmba.
M. 47. 24.
text.16254:
Supārśva (IV) — a son of Rukmaratha.
M. 49. 73; Vā. 99. 188.
text.16256:
Supārśva (VI) — son of Śrutāyu and Sṛñjaya.
Vi. IV. 5. 31.
text.16257:
Supārśvaka (I) — a son of Śrutāyus and father of Citra
ratha.
Bhā. IX. 13. 23.
text.16258:
Supārśvaka (II) — a son of Citraka.
Br. III. 71. 114; Vā. 96. 113.
text.16259:
Supārśvaka (III) — a son of Śaṭha.
Br. III. 71. 170.
text.16260:
Supārśvaka (IV) — a son of Aśvinī and Akrūra.
M. 45. 32.
text.16262:
Supālaka — a ṛtvik at the yajña of Brahmā.
Vā. 106. 38.
text.16265:
Supraketasa — a god of Prasūta group.
Br. II. 36. 70.
text.16266:
Supratīka (I) — a son of Pratikāśva (Pratitāśva-Vi. P.)
and father of Marudeva.
Bhā. IX. 12. 12; Vi. IV. 22. 4.
text.16267:
Supratīka (II) — the name of the elephant which
Bhagadatta got from Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 59. 37; Br. III. 7. 328.
text.16268:
Supratīka (III) — the city of, between the Ganges and
Vindhyas;1 a son of Pravīra, ruled for 30 years.2 1) Br. III. 7. 357.
2) Ib. III. 74. 186.
text.16270:
Supratīka (V) — the beautiful elephant born of Sāmna:
the pleasant, appearance from Vairūpya;1 three sons, Pra
hārī, Sampāti and Pṛthu by Citti.2 1) Br. III. 7. 328, 335-341.
2) Vā. 69. 225.
text.16272:
Supratīkavanam — the boundary between the source of
the Ganges and Karūṣa country.
Vā. 69. 239.
text.16275:
Supratīpa — a son of Pratipāśva (tāśva-Vā. P.).
M. 271. 7; Vā. 99. 284.
text.16277:
Supradam — a region in the Śālmalidvīpa adjoining the
Kakuda hill.
Br. II. 19. 45.
text.16278:
Suprabha — a son of Vapuṣmat and founder of the
Suprabha kingdom.
Br. II. 14. 32, 34; Vā. 33. 28, 30; Vi. II. 4. 23, 29.
text.16279:
Suprabham — a varṣa centering round Kakuda hill of
Śālmali.
Vā. 49. 41.
text.16280:
Suprabhā — a daughter of Svarbhānu, and wife of
Namuci.
Bhā. VI. 6. 32.
text.16282:
Suprayogā — R. originates from the Sahya hills of the
Dakṣiṇāpatha.
Br. II. 16. 35; M. 114. 29; Vā. 45. 164.
text.16285:
Subandhu (II) — a son of Aṭṭahāsa avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 193.
text.16286:
Subala (I) — a prince of Gāndhāra: his daughter was
Gāndhārī, and son Śakuni.
Bhā. I. 13. 28-29; III. 1. 14; X. 84. 1.
text.16287:
Subala (II) — a son of Sumati, and father of Sunītha.
Bhā. IX. 22. 48-49.
text.16288:
Subala (III) — a playmate of Kṛṣṇa: wanted to eat the
fruits of the palmyra grove then in possession of Dhenuka.
Bhā. X. 15. 20; 22 31.
text.16289:
Subala (IV) — a son of Bhautya Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 115.
text.16291:
Subala (VI) — Ojasvi of the 14th epoch of Bhautya
Manu.
Vā. 100. 116.
text.16292:
Subala (VII) — a son of Dṛḍasena and father of Sunīta.
Vi. IV. 23. 8-9.
text.16293:
Subālaka — in previous birth a son of Kauśika; born as
one of the ministers of the Pāñcāla king, Brahmadatta;1 son of
Babhru, also called Pāñcāla and author of Kāmaśāstra;
remembered his previous birth and retired from the world
for penance.2 1) M. 20. 24.
2) Ib. 21. 30.
text.16294:
Subāhu (I) — a son of Śatrughna;1 his capital was
Mathurā.2 1) Bhā. IX. 11. 12; Vā. 88. 186; Vi. IV. 4. 104.
2) Br. III. 63. 187.
text.16295:
Subāhu (II) — a son of Kālindī.
Bhā. X. 61. 14.
text.16296:
Subāhu (III) — a son of Pratībāhu, and father of Śānta
sena.
Bhā. X. 90. 38.
text.16298:
Subāhu (V) — a Gandharva born to Krodhā.
Br. III. 7. 8.
text.16300:
Subāhu (VII) — a son of Hṛdīka.
Br. III. 71. 141.
text.16301:
Subāhu (VIII) — a sage of the Raivata epoch.
M. 9. 19.
text.16302:
Subāhu (IX) — a son of Aśvinī and Akrūra.
M. 45. 32.
text.16303:
Subāhu (X) — a Gandharva king in Kailāsa.
Vā. 41. 21.
text.16304:
Subāhu (XI) — a Rākṣasa killed by Rāma.
Vi. IV. 4. 100
text.16305:
Subrahmaṇya (I) — fought with Pradyumna at Śoṇita
pura: defeated, returned from the field. Visited by
Balarāma.
Bhā. X. 63. 7 & 15; 79. 13.
text.16306:
Subrahmaṇya (II) — one of the 16 Ṛtviks for an Yajña;
from the knees of Nārāyaṇa.
M. 167. 10.
text.16307:
Subhagā (I) — a daughter of Risṭa.
Br. III. 7. 13.
text.16308:
Subhagā (II) — a Śakti;1 a mind-born mother.2 1) Br. IV. 44. 75;
2) M. 179. 14.
text.16310:
Subhadra (I) — one of the seven divisions of Plakṣa
dvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 3.
text.16311:
Subhadra (II) — a son of Pauravī and Vasudeva.
Bhā. IX. 24. 47.
text.16312:
Subhadra (III) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Bhadrā: fought
with Sangrāmajit deluded by Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. X. 61. 17; XI. 30. 16.
text.16313:
Subhadra (IV) — an Yakṣa; a son of Puṇyajanī and
Maṇibhadra.
Br. III. 7. 124; Vā. 69. 156.
text.16314:
Subhadrā (I) — a daughter of Vasudeva and Devakī:
queen of Arjuna, mother of Abhimaṇyu, and grandmother
of Parīkṣit, younger sister of Kṛṣṇa of dark complexion;1
taken by Kṛṣṇa to Dvārakā;2 heard from the wives of Kṛṣṇa
of their marriage and was in wonder;3 grieved at
Kṛṣṇa's departure from Hastināpura: welcomed Vidura;4 the
pride of the Vṛṣṇis.5 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 55; 22. 33; M. 46. 15; 50. 56; Vā. 96. 175-6; Vi.
IV. 20. 51. 99. 249.
2) Bhā. X. 64 [11];
3) Ib. X. 84. 1.
4) Ib. I. 10.
9; 13. 3.
5) Br. III. 71. 177-8.
text.16315:
Subhadrā (II) — the goddess enshrined at Śoṇasamgama.
M. 13. 45.
text.16316:
Subhadrā (III) — the wife of Aniruddha.
Vi. IV. 15. 40.
text.16317:
Subhānu — a son of Satyabhāmā: went with Kṛṣṇa's
sacrificial horse.
Bhā. X. 61. 10; 89. 22[3].
text.16319:
Subhāṣa — a son of Supārśva II and father of Suśruta.
Vi. IV. 5. 31.
text.16320:
Subhāṣaṇa — a son of Yuyudha, and father of Śruta.
Bhā. IX. 13. 25.
text.16322:
Subhūmi — a son of Ugrasena.
Br. III. 71. 133; Vi. IV. 14. 20.
text.16323:
Subhru — a son of Rohiṇī and Ānakadundubhi.
M. 46. 12.
text.16324:
Subhaumā — a Janapada of the Bhadrā continent.
Vā. 43. 23.
text.16325:
Sumaṅgalas — a Janapada of the Bhadrā continent.
Vā. 43. 19.
text.16327:
Sumati (I) — a son of Bharata, whom he succeeded.
Elevated as a deity by Pākhaṇḍas as he followed the path of
Ṛṣabha. His queen was Vṛddhasenā and son Devatājit.
Father of Devadyumna through Āsuri;1 father of Tejas(a).2 1) Bhā. V. 7. 3; 15. 1-3; Vā. 33. 53.
2) Br. II. 14. 62; Vi. II. 1.
33, 36.
text.16328:
Sumati (II) — a son of Nṛga and father of Bhūtajyotis.
Bhā. IX. 2. 17.
text.16329:
Sumati (III) — a son of Somadatta and father of Jana
mejaya; was invited for the Rājasūya of Yudhiṣṭhira.
Bhā. IX. 2. 36; X. 74. 8.
text.16330:
Sumati (IV) — a son of Rantibhāra, and father of
Raibhya.
Bhā. IX. 20. 6 & 7.
text.16331:
Sumati (V) — the son of Supārśva, and father of
Sannatimān.
Bhā. IX. 21. 28; M. 49. 74; Vā. 99. 188; Vi. IV. 19. 49.
text.16332:
Sumati (VI) — a son of Dyumatsena (Dhṛḍasena) and
father of Subala.
Bhā. IX. 22. 48.
text.16335:
Sumati (IX) — a son of Uttama Manu.
Br. II. 36. 40.
text.16336:
Sumati (X) — one of the twenty Amitābha gods.
Br. II. 36. 53; IV. 1. 17; Vā. 100. 16.
text.16337:
Sumati (XI) — a god of Ābhūtaraya group.
Br. II. 36. 55.
text.16338:
Sumati (XII) — a son of Haryaśva and Dṛṣadvatī.
Br. III. 63. 75.
text.16339:
Sumati (XIII) — a daughter of Ariṣṭanemi (of Kaśyapa
Vi. P.) and sister of Suparṇa (Garuḍa-Vā. P.);1 queen of
Sagara s.v., and mother of 60000 sons born by the grace of
Aurva and known as Sāgaras: out of long gourd; each of
them entrusted to a nurse; became developed in nine months
and in course of time attained youth.2 1) Br. III. 63. 159.
2) Bhā. IX. 8. 9 and 11; Br. III. 49. 59; 51
28 and 39: 52. Vā. 88. 159-164; Vi. IV. 4. 1-4.
text.16340:
Sumati (XIV) — a Bṛhadratha; for 33 years.
Br. III. 74. 119; Vā. 99. 305.
text.16341:
Sumati (XV) — a son of Sāvarṇi Manu.
M. 9. 33; Vā. 100. 22.
text.16342:
Sumati (XVI) — an Asura in the Sabhā of Hiraṇya
kaśipu.
M. 161. 79.
text.16343:
Sumati (XVII) — a pupil of Sūta, Romaharṣaṇa.
Vā. 61. 55; 62. 46 and 48; Vi. III. 6. 17.
text.16344:
Sumati (XVIII) — a son of Janamejaya; with him ends
the Vaiśāla line.
Vi. IV. 1. 58-9.
text.16345:
Sumati (XIX) — a son of Antināra.
Vi. IV. 19. 4.
text.16346:
Sumanas (I) — a son of Ulmuka and Puṣkariṇī.
Bhā. IV. 13. 17.
text.16347:
Sumanas (II) — a queen of Madhu and mother of
Vīravrata.
Bhā. V. 15. 15.
text.16348:
Sumanas (III) — a Mt. in Plakṣadvīpa. Here Vāraha
Viṣṇu killed Hiraṇyākṣa.
Br. II. 19. 12; Vā. 49. 11; Vi. II. 4. 7.
text.16349:
Sumanas (IV) — a god of the Prasūta group.
Br. II. 36. 70.
text.16350:
Sumanas (V) — a garden of the gods
Br. III. 7. 101.
text.16351:
Sumanas (VI) — a son of Maṇibhadra and Puṇyajanī; an
Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 122.
text.16352:
Sumanas (VII) — a son of Āgneyī and Ūru.
M. 4. 43.
text.16353:
Sumanas (VIII) — the name of Cakravāka in Mānasa;
in previous birth a son of Kauśika.
M. 20. 18.
text.16355:
Sumanas (X) — same as Āmbikeya of the Śākadvīpa.
M. 122. 16.
text.16357:
Sumanas (XII) — a gana attributed to Viśravas.
Vā. 69. 28.
text.16358:
Sumanas (XIII) — the son of Hasta and father of
Tridhanvā.
Vi. IV. 3. 26.
text.16359:
Sumanas (XIV) — Mt. hill of the Śālmalīdvīpa.
122. 94.
text.16360:
Sumanasa (I) — a son of Ūru (Kuru-Vi. P.).
Br. II. 36. 108; M. 4. 43; Vi. I. 13. 6.
text.16361:
Sumanasa (II) — a gaṇa of the IV Sāvarṇa Manu: in
cludes 33 Tuṣita gods.
Br. IV. 1. 83-7.
text.16362:
Sumanasa (III) — one of the five deva gaṇas of the
epoch of Ṛthu Sāvarṇa; a mind-born son of Brahmā with ten
branches.
Vā. 100. 87.
text.16363:
Sumanasa (IV) — a group of ten gods of the XII epoch
of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 34.
text.16367:
Sumantu (I) — a sage who was invited for the Rājasūya
of Yudhiṣṭhira.
Bhā. X. 74. 7.
text.16368:
Sumantu (II) — a son of Jaimini and father of Sutvan or
Sunvan; learnt a Samhitā of the Sāma Veda from him, divid
ed the Atharva Veda into two divisions;1 a pupil of Vyāsa,
helped him in arranging the Atharva Veda; in charge of the
Atharvāngiras (Atharva Veda); Kabandha, the pupil of, to
whom was given by him the whole of the Atharva Veda.
^2 Bhā. I. 4. 22; XII. 6. 53; 7. 1; Vā. 60. 13, 15; 61. 49;
Vi. III. 4. 9; 6. 8-9. 1) Bhā. XII. 6. 75; Br. II. 1. 13; 34. 13; 35. 31, 55; Vā. 61. 26;
Vi. III. 6. 2.
text.16369:
Sumantu (III) — a son of Aṭṭahāsa avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 193.
text.16370:
Sumantu (IV) — a son of Janhu; and father of Ajaka.
Vi. IV. 7. 7-8.
text.16371:
Sumahān (V) — a Mt. that entered the sea for fear of
Indra.
M. 121. 73.
text.16372:
Sumāli (V) — a follower of Vṛtra in his battle with
Indra. Slain by Hari;1 a son of Praheti, the Rākṣasa;2 the
Rākṣasa king in IV Talam; served as calf when they milked
the earth.3 1) Bhā. VI. 10. 21; VIII. 10. 57.
2) Br. III. 7. 90.
3) Ib. II. 20.
33; 36. 219.
text.16373:
Sumāli (II) — a son of Khaśa and a Rākṣasa.
Br. III. 7. 133.
text.16374:
Sumāli (III) — a son of Laṅku;1 resident of the fourth
talam or gabhastalam;2 milked both milk and blood in
Kapālapātra by which the Rākṣasas prosper;3 acted as calf
when the Rākṣasas milked the cow-earth.4 1) Vā. 69. 128, 165.
2) Ib. 50. 32.
3) Ib. 62. 184.
4) M. 10. 23.
text.16375:
Sumāli (IV) — a son of Mahāpadma; all the sons of
Mahāpadma ruled for a hundred years after which nine of
them were done away with by Kauṭalya.
Vi. 24. 23-6. Bhā. XII. 1. 11.
text.16376:
Sumitra (I) — a son of Suratha: the last of Bārhadbalas
and of Ikṣvākus of the Kaliyuga.
Bhā. IX. 12. 15-16; Br. III. 74. 106; 244; M. 271. 14. 16; Vā.
99. 290; Vi. IV. 22. 10-13.
text.16377:
Sumitra (II) — a son of Vṛṣṇi and Gāndhārī, had a son,
Anamitra.
Bhā. IX. 24. 12; Br. III. 71. 19; M. 45. 1; Vi. IV. 13. 8, 9.
text.16378:
Sumitra (III) — a son of Śamīka and Sudāminī.
Bhā. IX. 24. 44.
text.16379:
Sumitra (IV) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Jāmbavatī: fought
with Suratha at Prabhāsa.
Bhā. X. 61. 11; XI. 30. 16.
text.16380:
Sumitra (V) — a son of Uttama Manu.
Br. II. 36. 40.
text.16381:
Sumitra (VI) — a sage who waited among others on
Paraśūrāma for the reclamation of Gokarṇa.
Br. III. 51. 7.
text.16386:
Sumukha (IV) — a son of Suhotri, the avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 127.
text.16389:
Sumukhī (II) — a daughter of the Gandharvas.
Vā. 69. 10.
text.16391:
Sumuṣṭida — one of the 9 sons of Ugrasena.
M. 44. 75.
text.16392:
Sumūrdhajas — a Janapada of the Bhadrā continent.
Vā. 43. 20.
text.16393:
Sumūlā — a R. of the Ketumālā.
Vā. 44. 19.
text.16395:
Sumeka — the father of Ṛtus whose sons are five
known as ārtavas; considered as prapitāmaha, as by it people
die and are born.
Vā. 30. 16, 19.
text.16396:
Sumedha — a son of Jaigiṣavya, an avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 139.
text.16397:
Sumedha(ka) — a Mt. to the east of Aruṇoda where
Ādityas and Vasus live.
Vā. 36. 19; 37. 26; 39. 48.
text.16398:
Sumedhas (I) — a god of Sumedhasa group.
Br. II. 36. 60.
text.16400:
Sumedhas (III) — a sage of the Cākṣuṣa epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 28.
text.16401:
Sumedhasa (I) — a group of gods of Raivata Manu:
14 in number.
Br. II. 36. 51, 60.
text.16404:
Sumedhas — Medha, Medhatithi, Satyamedha, Pṛśni
medha, Alpamedha, Dīptimedha, Yaśomedha, Sthira
medha, Sarvamedha, Aśvamedha, Pratimedha, Medhavat
and Medhaharta.
Vā. 62. 51-2.
text.16405:
Sumedhā (I) — a daughter of Sukanyā and Cyavana:
wife of Nidhurva and mother of Kuṇḍa pāyins.
Br. III. 8. 31; Vā. 70. 26.
text.16406:
Sumedhā (II) — a R. of the Ketumālā country.
Vā. 44. 17.
text.16409:
Sumohinī — one of the four queens of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 12. 13.
text.16410:
Sumaulas — a Janapada of the Ketumālā country.
Vā. 44. 10.
text.16411:
Sumha (I) — (c) a northern kingdom;1 a tribe.2 1) Br. II. 16. 46; 18. 51.
2) M. 163. 67; Br. III. 74. 87.
text.16412:
Sumha (II) — a Kṣetraja son of Bali; after him came the
Sumhas;1 after him the name of the kingdom.2 1) Br. III. 74. 27, 87; M. 48. 25.
2) Vi. IV. 18. 13-14.
text.16413:
Suyajña (I) — An avatār of Hari as son of Akūtī and
Rucī: begot on Dakṣiṇā, gods called Suyamas.
Bhā. II. 7. 2.
text.16414:
Suyajña (II) — a king of Uśīnaras, fell in battle. His
relations and queens bemoaned his loss bitterly beating their
breasts. At this Yama appeared before them in the form of
a child and demonstrated the instability of life, comparable
only to a dream. Even ages of mourning will not help the
dead man to come back. Saying this he disappeared. This
impressed them so much that they retired to forest after
performing funeral obsequies.
Bhā. VII. 2. 28-59.
text.16415:
Suyajña (III) — the father of Nara.
Br. III. 71. 87.
text.16416:
Suyajña (IV) — a son of Akṣara and father of Uśanas.
Br. III. 70. 23.
text.16417:
Suyamas — sons of Suyajña, an avatār of Hari.
Bhā. II. 7. 2.
text.16418:
Suyaśas — a son of Aśokavardhana, and father of
Sangata (Daśaratha-Vi. P.).
Bhā. XII. 1. 14; Vi. IV. 24. 30.
text.16419:
Suyāśā (I) — a queen of Divodāsa who prayed at
Nikumbha's temple for a son but did not get: so her
husband got it destroyed.
Br. III. 67. 47-9; Vā. 92. 44. 51.
text.16421:
Suyāśā (III) — a daughter of Gandharvas; husband
Pracetas; sons Yakṣas and four daughters all Apsaras.
Vā. 69. 10. 11, and 13.
text.16423:
Suyodhana (II) — (see under Duryodhana);1 was the
Lord of 11 akṣauhinis.2 1) Vi. V. 35. 4.
2) M. 103. 3.
text.16425:
Suras (I) — the gods who adopted Surā of Vāruṇi Devī
which sprung forth from the churning of the ocean.
Br. IV. 9. 69.
text.16426:
Suras (II) — the names of gods during Manvantara.
Vā. 61. 76.
text.16427:
Surakṣa (I) — a son of Nirāmitra, ruled for 56 years.
M. 271. 22.
text.16428:
Surakṣa (II) — the 14th Vyāsa, Gautama, the avatār of
the Lord.
Vā. 23. 162.
text.16429:
Suratha (I) — the son of Raṇaka and father of Sumitra.
Bhā. IX. 12. 15.
text.16430:
Suratha (II) — a son of Janhu and father of Vidūratha.
Bhā. IX. 22. 9-10; M. 50. 34; Vā. 99. 230; Vi. IV. 20. 2-3.
text.16431:
Suratha (III) — a son of Kulaka.
M. 271. 13; Vā. 99. 230.
text.16433:
Suratha (V) — a son of Kuṇḍaka and father of Sumitra.
Vi. IV. 22. 9-10.
text.16436:
Surabhi (I) — the mythical cow: a daughter of Dakṣa
and one of Kaśyapa's wives; gave birth to cattle and those
with cloven hoofs;1 came with Indra to see Kṛṣṇa. Pleased
with his good will for the cattle kingdom, she told him that
he was chosen Indra of goloka. Then she bathed him in
her milk while Indra bathed him with Ganges water and
called him Govinda, to the singing and dancing of celestials;
a mother goddess; mother of eleven Rudras2 and two
daughters, Rohiṇī and Gāndhārī also was born Vṛṣodakṣa,
the latter presented as the banner of Maheśvara;3 blessed Dīr
gatamas who heckled her son for eating sacrificial grass to
get rid of all sins and to become the renowned Gautama. 1) Bhā. I. 17. 9; VI. 6. 26-27; M. 5. 32; 62, 44; Vā. 66. 55;
Vi. I. 15. 125; 21. 24.
2) Ib. X. 27. 1-24.
3) Br. III. 3. 56, 69, 78. 7: 466;
74. 49 and 90; M. 48. 43-84; 146. 18; Vā. 70-76.
text.16437:
Surabhi (II) — a son of Arkāgni.
Br. II. 12. 43; Vā. 29. 40.
text.16438:
Surabhi (III) — a forest garden on the banks of the Vam
śaukasārā;1 a garden of gods.2 1) M. 121. 61.
2) Br. III. 7. 101.
text.16439:
Surabhi (IV) — wife of Dharma; longed for union with
Brahmā; their children were Rudras, cattle, medicinal plants
and so on.
M. 171. 35-42; 277. 8.
text.16441:
Surabhi (VI) — a forest on the bank of Śailodā. R. in the
Aruṇa hill;1 fit for tapas.2 1) Vā. 47. 22.
2) Vā. 69. 94.
text.16443:
Surabhi (VIII) — a Gandharva with the sun in the Śarat
season.
Vā. 52. 13.
text.16444:
Suramāputra — a Nāga with one hundred heads resid
ing in Rasātalam; also Vāsukī, a friend of Indra.
Br. II. 20. 40.
text.16445:
Suramitra — a Marut of the second gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 93.
text.16446:
Surarāja — an image of Indra, with Indrānī.
M. 260. 66-70.
text.16447:
Suravinda — an Yakṣa lady of lustrous brightness; origi
nates gaṇa through Karālaka.
Vā. 69. 38.
text.16449:
Surasa (I) — Mt. in India.
Br. II. 16. 21; Vā. 45. 90.
text.16450:
Surasa (II) — a son of Śuki and Garuḍa.
Br. III. 7. 450.
text.16451:
Surasa (III) — a son of Raucya Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 104; Vā. 100. 109.
text.16452:
Surasa (IV) — a Mt. west of the Śitoda.
Vā. 36. 27.
text.16453:
Surasana — a pleasure garden to which Kardama and
Devahūtī went.
Bhā. III. 23. 40.
text.16454:
Surasā (I) — R. in Bhārata varṣa, from the Ṛkṣa hill;
(from the Vindhyas-Vi. P.).
Bhā. V. 19. 18; Br. II. 16. 29; Vi. II. 3. 11.
text.16455:
Surasā (II) — a daughter of Dakṣa and one of the
13 wives of Kaśyapa;1 mother of Yātudhānas and 1000
snakes, of which 26 are chiefs; all these had sons and
grandsons most of which were killed in the sacrifice of Jana
mejaya;1 in the chariot of Tripurāri.2 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 25, 28; M. 6. 1, 37-8, 42; Vā. 66. 54; Vi. I. 15.
124; 21. 19.
1) Bhā. VI. 6. 25, 28; M. 6. 1, 37-8, 42; Vā. 66. 54; Vi. I. 15.
124; 21. 19.
2) M. 133. 27; 146. 18.
text.16457:
Surasā (IV) — a daughter of Krodhavaśa (Krodhā
Vi. P.) and wife of Pulaha; mother of sarpas.
Br. III. 7. 173, 443; Vā. 69. 205.
text.16458:
Surasā (V) — a daughter of Sāraṇa.
Br. III. 71. 168; Vā. 96. 166.
text.16459:
Surasā (VI) — a daughter of Anāyuṣā, gave birth to
vyādhis.
M. 171. 59.
text.16461:
Surasā (VIII) — a R. of the Bhadra.
Vā. 43. 25.
text.16462:
Surasikā — a Rākṣasa who married Nīla, daughter of
Keśinī.
Br. III. 7. 147.
text.16463:
Surasundarī — a daughter of Varuṇa and Śunādevī.
Br. III. 59. 6; Vā. 84. 6.
text.16464:
Surā (I) — is Stutā; mother of Kali; as Vāruṇi devī.
Br. III. 59. 9; IV. 9. 65.
text.16465:
Surā (II) — six different varieties of liquor drunk by the
Śaktis on the third day of the war; gauḍī, paiṣtī, mādhvī,
kādambarī, Haitālī, lāṅgaleyā and tālajāta; also that from
kalpavṛkṣa; they were of different tastes, sweet, bitter,
saltish, etc., and of various colours;1 liquor with Kaca's
powdered body mixed in it taken by Śukrācārya and thus
deceived by the Asura; hence he ordained that no Brahman
should thereafter take liquor, and if he did he would fall
from his status and commit a sin equal to brahmicide and
would be despised by the world at large.2 1) Br. IV. 28. 71-6; Vā. 101. 162.
2) M. 25. 39, 60, 62-3; 76. 12.
text.16467:
Surā (IV) — the wife of Kali; son of Mada.
Vā. 84. 9.
text.16470:
Surahantā — an Asura in the sabhā of Hiraṇyakaśīpu.
M. 161. 79.
text.16472:
Surādevī — issued from the milk ocean when it was
churned.
M. 250. 3.
text.16473:
Surānandā — a Devī on the Geyacakra.
Br. IV. 19. 75.
text.16474:
Surānta — a Rākṣaṣa who was killed in Lankā war.
Bhā. IX. 10. 18.
text.16475:
Surāpa — the drinking of spirituous liquors leads to the
Sūkara hell.2
^1 Vā. 101. 152. 2) Br. IV. 2. 154, 167.
text.16476:
Surāpas — a group of gods of the XII epoch of Manu.
Vi. III. 2. 34.
text.16479:
Surāla (I) — a sage and a Samhitā kartā.
Br. II. 35. 45.
text.16482:
Surāvatī — a R. of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 30.
text.16483:
Surāṣṭra — a western kingdom visited by Vidura
from the Sarasvatī. Its king attacked the eastern side of
Gomanta with Jarāsandha.
Bhā. II. 16. 62; M. 163. 72. Bhā. III. 1. 24; X 52. 11 [5].
text.16486:
Surucī (I) — the Yakṣa presiding over the month of
Tapas.
Bhā. XII. 11. 39.
text.16487:
Suruci (II) — a Gandharva with the sun in the Śarat
season.
Br. II. 23. 13; III. 7. 11.
text.16489:
Suruci (IV) — the favourite wife of Uttānapāda and
mother of Uttama;1 took Dhruva to task for getting into his
father's lap and asked him to go to forest. It was predicted
that she would die falling into forest fire; welcomed Dhruva
returning from tapas;2 insulted Dhruva, the son of the king
by Sunīti.3 1) Vi. I. 11. 2
2) Bhā. IV. 8. 8-23, 41-7.
3) Vi. I. 11. 7, 10.
text.16490:
Suruci (V) — resides in the āśvayuja in the Sun's chariot.
Vi. II. 10. 11.
text.16492:
Surūpa (I) — a son of Śukī and Garuḍa.
Br. III. 7. 450.
text.16493:
Surūpa (II) — an Asura in the sabhā of Hiraṇyakaśipu.
M. 161. 80.
text.16495:
Surūpa (IV) — the adopted son of Asamanjasa.
Vā. 96. 141.
text.16497:
Surūpas — a group of gods of Tāmasa Manu.
Br. II. 35. 43.
text.16498:
Surūpā (I) — a daughter of Marīci and wife of Atharvan
Angīras; had ten sons.
Br. III. 1. 102; M. 196. 1; Vā. 65. 98, 105.
text.16499:
Surūpā (II) — a daughter of Rohiṇī; mother of two sons.
Br. III. 3. 74-5.
text.16500:
Surūpā (III) — a kala giving energy to Agni.
Br. IV. 35. 83.
text.16502:
Surecakas — (c) a Janapada of the Ketumālā continent.
Vā. 44. 14.
text.16503:
Sureṇu — a daughter of Viśvakarmā, sister of Maya;
wife of the Sun god; known as Samjñā; gave birth to Manu
and then to twins Yama and Yamunā! took the guise of a
horse and wandered in the Kuru country and became the
horse of Savitā; through her two nostrils were born Aśvins.
also known as Nāsatya and Dasra. Unable to bear the sun's
rays, she requested Chāyā to take her place and guise until
she returned; she went home, but after some time her father
turned her out.
Br. III. 59. 21, 34; Vā. 84. 21-24, 26-86.
text.16506:
Surocana — a territorial division of Śālmalidvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 9.
text.16507:
Suroci — one of the seven sons of Vasiṣṭha.
Bhā. IV. 1. 41.
text.16509:
Suroda — the sea of wine surrounding Śālmalidvīpa.
Bhā. V. 1. 33; 20. 7; M. 122. 104; 123. 1; Vi. II. 4. 33.
text.16510:
Suroṣā — the city of Rākṣasas in Rasātalam.
Br. II. 20. 40.
text.16513:
Suva — one of the seven worlds.
M. 60. 2.
text.16514:
Suvakṣas — a Mt. west of the Śitoda.
Vā. 36. 27.
text.16516:
Suvaprā — a R. of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 28.
text.16517:
Suvaṃśa — a son of Vasudeva and Śrīdevā.
Bhā. IX. 24. 51.
text.16519:
Suvarcas (I) — a son of Svāgata and father of Suśruta.
Br. III. 64. 21; Vā. 89. 20.
text.16520:
Suvarcas (II) — a son of the second Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 72.
text.16521:
Suvarcas (III) — a son of the IV Sāvarṇa Manu.
Br. IV. 1. 95.
text.16523:
Suvarcas (V) — a son of Soma; Kṣatrapraṇetara in the
24th Caturyuga.
Vā. 99. 438.
text.16524:
Suvarcas (VI) — a son of Ṛtusāvarṇa Manu.
Vā. 100. 99.
text.16525:
Suvarcalā (I) — a wife of Parameṣṭhi and mother of
Pratīha.
Bhā. V. 15. 3.
text.16526:
Suvarcalā (II) — (Arcalā?, Savālā?): wife of Pratīha
and mother of Pratiharta and two other sons.
Bhā. V. 15. 5.
text.16527:
Suvarcalā (III) — a consort of the Sun god.
Vi. I. 8. 8.
text.16528:
Suvarcas — a son of Manu, an Aikṣvāku; restored the
Kṣatriya supremacy as first king in the 29th Caturyuga.
M. 273. 57; Vā. 62. 85.
text.16530:
Suvarccalā — a wife of Rudra (Raudritanu) of the eight
fold body of Mahādeva-Br. P.); mother of Sanaiścara.
Vā. 27. 49; Br. II. 10. 76.
text.16531:
Suvarcā — a wife of Prācīna garbha.
Br. II. 36. 99.
text.16532:
Suvarṇa (I) — a son of Sāvarṇi Manu.
M. 9. 33.
text.16533:
Suvarṇa (II) — fire, the presiding deity of.
Vi. V. 1. 14.
text.16534:
Suvarṇakeṭakas — a Janapada of the Ketumālā.
Vā. 44. 11.
text.16536:
Suvarṇadhenu — fit for gift during Viśokadvādaśi.
M. 82. 20.
text.16537:
Suvarṇam — a gold coin; a fine of 100 Suvarṇas for one
who, having been paid a wage does not protect the cow or
milks it or uses it; besides he is liable to be bound by iron
chains and made to work for his master.
M. 227. 8, 22, 122.
text.16538:
Suvarṇasalilā — a sacred tīrtha attached to the Nar
madā; a bath there takes a man to the Rudraloka and makes
him a king in the next birth.
M. 191. 47-8.
text.16539:
Suvarṇā (I) — a R. of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 27.
text.16540:
Suvarṇā (II) — a R. of the Ketumālā country.
Vā. 44. 29.
text.16541:
Suvarṇākṣam — a place sacred to Śiva.
M. 181. 25.
text.16542:
Suvarman (I) — a son of Cītraka.
Br. III. 71. 115; Vā. 96. 114.
text.16544:
Suvaha — the fourth Skandha from Soma to Rakṣa
province.
Vā. 67. 117.
text.16545:
Suvahas — Prakṛtis as aid to the creator.
Vā. 103. 28.
text.16547:
Suvācā — a daughter of Sāsaṇa.
Br. III. 71. 168.
text.16548:
Suvāsana — the gods of the epoch of the Tenth Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 22.
text.16550:
Suvāhana — a son of Jaigīṣavya, an avatār of the Lord.
Vā. 23. 139.
text.16552:
Suvitti (I) — a mantrakṛt and of Angirasa branch.
Vā. 59. 101.
text.16553:
Suvitti (II) — Mantraśarīra and a son of Brahmā.
Vā. 67. 6.
text.16554:
Suvibhu — a son of Vibhu and father of Sukumāra.
Br. III. 67. 76; Vā. 92. 71; Vi. IV. 8. 20.
text.16555:
Suvīra (I) — a son of Kṣemya (Kṣema-Vā. P.) and father.
of Ripuñjaya.
Bhā. IX. 21. 29; Vā. 99. 193.
text.16556:
Suvīra (II) — a son of Śibi, after whom came the Suvīra
country.
Bhā. IX. 23. 3; Br. III. 74. 23; M. 48. 19; Vā. 99. 23-4; Vi.
IV. 18. 10.
text.16557:
Suvīra (III) — a son of Devaśravas and Kamsavatī.
Bhā. IX. 24. 41.
text.16558:
Suvīra (IV) — a son of Devajanī, and an Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 130.
text.16559:
Suvīra (V) — a Mt. to the east of Aruṇoda.
Vā. 36. 18.
text.16561:
Suvīras — their king was Śaibya.
Bhā. X. 52. 11 [12].
text.16563:
Suvṛtā — a daughter of Kakudmi, married Baladeva.
Vā. 86. 29.
text.16565:
Suvṛddhi — a son of Rājavardhana; father of Kevala.
Vi. IV. 1. 37-8.
text.16566:
Suveṇu — a king of the Ikṣvāku line; his daughter was
Reṇukā.
Vā. 91. 89.
text.16567:
Suvela — Mt. a hill near Kailāsa.
M. 121. 6.
text.16568:
Suvrata (I) — a son of Kṣema (Kṣemya-Vi. P.) and
father of Dhamasūtra (Dharma-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 22. 48; Vi. IV. 23. 6.
text.16569:
Suvrata (II) — a son of Śveta and a Vānara chief.
Br. III. 7. 180.
text.16570:
Suvrata (III) — a son of Darvā (Darśa-M.) and Uśīnara;
chief of the Ambaṣṭa Kingdom;1 ruled for 38 years.2 1) Br. III. 74. 20, 22; M. 48. 18, 21; Vā. 99. 20, 22.
2) Ib. 99. 304.
text.16571:
Suvrata (IV) — a Bṛhadratha; ruled for 64 years.
Br. III. 74. 116.
text.16572:
Suvrata (V) — a maṇṭapa with 60 pillars.
M. 270. 3 and 7.
text.16573:
Suvratā — a daughter of Dakṣa and mother of four
Manus;1 got four sons through Brahmā, and they became the
originators of four castes, hence Savarnas.2 1) Br. IV. 1. 39-42.
2) Vā. 100. 24, 42-52.
text.16574:
Suśarman (I) — a king of Trigarttas and the prince
a vassal of Yudhiṣṭhira: went to Syamantapañcaka for the
solar eclipse.
Bhā. X. 52. 11 [14]; 82. 26.
text.16575:
Suśarman (II) — a Kaṇva king after Nārāyaṇa was
killed by his servant, a Vṛṣala and Āndhra jātīya, who
usurped the kingdom. After some time his brother Kṛṣṇa,
became king: ruled for four years (ten years M. P.);1 a son of
Nārāyaṇa; with him the Kaṇva dynasty came to an end;
killed by his servant Balipucchaka, an Andhra.
^2 Vā. 99. 346-48; Vi. IV. 24. 41-3. 1) Bhā. XII. 1. 20, 22-3; M. 272. 35; 273. 1-2; Br. III. 74.
159.
text.16576:
Suśarman (III) — a pupil of Sūta;1 versed in the
Purāṇas.2 1) Vā. 61. 56.
2) Br. II. 35. 64.
text.16578:
Suśānti (I) — the son of Śānti and father of Puruja
(Puramjaya-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 21. 31; Vi. IV. 19. 57.
text.16579:
Suśānti (II) — Indra of the Uttama epoch of Manu.
Br. II. 36. 37; Vi. III. 1. 13.
text.16580:
Suśānti (III) — a son of Nīla.
M. 50. 1; Vā. 99. 194.
text.16581:
Suśīlā — a Devī; a daughter of the Madra king and a
queen of Kṛṣṇa; highly chaste.
M. 47. 14; Vā. 96. 234; Vi. V. 28. 4.
text.16582:
Suśrama — a Bṛhadratha; ruled for 38 years.
Br. III. 74. 118.
text.16583:
Suśravas (I) — a god of the Ābhūtaraya group.
Br. II. 76. 56.
text.16585:
Suśravas (III) — a son of Dharma and father of Dṛḍha
sena.
Vi. IV. 23. 6-7.
text.16586:
Suśrī — a Kala of Agni.
Br. IV. 35. 83.
text.16587:
Suśruta (I) — a son of Suvarcas (Subhāṣa-Vi. P.) and
father of Jaya.
Br. III. 64. 21; Vi. IV. 5. 31.
text.16591:
Suṣumnā (I) — one of the seven important rays of the
sun by which the waning moon is fed.
Br. II. 23. 38, 61, 74; 24. 66; 28. 28; Vā. 52. 37 and 57; 53. 46;
56. 27; Vi. II. 11. 22.
text.16592:
Suṣumnā (II) — a sacred pool in the Himālayas, fit for
śrāddha.
Br. III. 13. 123-4; Vā. 77. 115.
text.16593:
Suṣumnā (III) — a Śakti of Māruta.
Br. IV. 33. 70.
text.16594:
Suṣumnā (IV) — in the navel of Gayā.
Vā. 108. 66.
text.16595:
Suṣeṇa (I) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Rukmiṇī.
Bhā. I. 14. 31; Vi. V. 28. 1.
text.16596:
Suṣeṇa (II) — a chief of the Krodhāvaśa group of
serpents.
Bhā. V. 24. 29.
text.16597:
Suṣeṇa (III) — a son of Manu (Svārociṣa).
Bhā. VIII. 1. 19.
text.16598:
Suṣeṇa (IV) — a son of Vṛṣṭimat, and father of Sunītha
(Nṛcakṣu, B. P.).
Bhā. IX. 22. 41; M. 50. 81; Vi. IV. 21. 12.
text.16599:
Suṣeṇa (V) — a son of Vasudeva and Devakī; killed by
Kamsa.
Bhā. IX. 24. 54; Br. III. 71. 174; M. 46. 13. Vā. 96. 172;
Vi. IV. 15. 26-27.
text.16600:
Suṣeṇa (VI) — the Gandharva presiding over the month
of Tapas.
Bhā. XII. 11. 39.
text.16601:
Suṣeṇa (VII) — a grāmaṇi with the Śarat sun.
Br. II. 23. 14; Vā. 52. 14.
text.16602:
Suṣeṇa (VIII) — a marut of the second gaṇa;1 a kinnara
with a human face.2 1) Br. III. 5. 93; Vā. 67. 124.
2) Ib. 69. 35.
text.16603:
Suṣeṇa (IX) — the father of Tāra.
Br. III. 7. 219, 232.
text.16606:
Suṣeṇa (XII) — an Yakṣa who resides in the Sun's chariot
during the month of Āśvayuja.
Vi. II. 10. 11.
text.16609:
Susandhi (I) — a son of Prabhu or Maru: father of
Sahasvān.
Br. III. 63. 211.
text.16610:
Susandhi (II) — a son of Prasuśruta(ka) and father of
Amarṣa.
Vā. 88. 211; Vi. IV. 4. 111.
text.16611:
Susamaṃjas (I) — a son of Asamanja.
Br. III. 71. 142.
text.16613:
Susamedhasa — a group of Gods of the Raivata.
Vi. III. 1. 21.
text.16614:
Susambhāvya — a son of Raivata Manu.
Br. II. 36. 63.
text.16615:
Susamyamā — the sabhā of Vaivasvata, on the third
inner slope of Meru.
Vā. 34. 86.
text.16616:
Susaha — a pupil of Laugākṣi.
Br. II. 35. 41.
text.16617:
Susthalā — with the sun in the Madhu and Mādhava
months.
Br. II. 23. 4.
text.16618:
Susvadhas — Pitṛs who live in the region of Kāmadughā.
M. 15. 20.
text.16619:
Suhū — a son of Ugrasena.
Bhā. IX. 24. 24.
text.16620:
Suhotra (I) — a son of Kṣatravṛddha, and father of
Kāśya and two other sons — (Kāśyapa, Kāśa and Gṛtsamada
Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 17. 2-3; Vi. IV. 8. 4-5.
text.16621:
Suhotra (II) — a son of Sudhanus and father of Cyavana.
Bhā. IX. 22. 5; Vi. IV. 19. 79.
text.16622:
Suhotra (III) — a son of Sahadeva by Vijayā (Mādrī
M. P.), Vijayī-Vi. P.).
Bhā. IX. 22. 31; M. 50. 55; Vā. 99. 248. Vi. IV. 20. 47.
text.16624:
Suhotra (V) — a son of Kāñcanaprabha (or Kāñcana) a
brave king, married Keśinī and father of Janhu.
Br. III. 66. 24; Vā. 91. 53; Vi. IV. 7. 3.
text.16625:
Suhotra (VI) — a son of Janhu and Kāverī.
Vā. 91. 60.
text.16626:
Suhotra (VII) — a son of Bṛhadkṣatra, and father of
Hastin.
Vā. 99. 165; Vi. IV. 19. 27-8.
text.16627:
Suhotra (VIII) — the wise, the son of Sudhanva.
Vā. 99. 218.
text.16628:
Suhotra (IX) — a ṛtvik at Brahmā's yajña.
Vā. 106. 36.
text.16629:
Suhotra (X) — a son of Bhagīratha.
Vi. IV. 4. 36.
text.16630:
Suhotri — the avatār of the Lord in the fourth dvāpara
with four sons, Sumukha, Durmukha, etc.
Vā. 23. 126.
text.16631:
Suhma (I) — born of Dīrghatamas and Bali's wife.
Bhā. IX. 23. 5.
text.16632:
Suhma (II) — a Bālaya Kṣatra (Brahmā); a son of Bali.
Vā. 99. 28.
text.16634:
Sūkara — a kind of hell; here fall the slayers of
Brahmans, consumers of spirituous liquors, stealers of gold,
etc.
Vā. 101. 146, 152; Vi. II. 6. 2 and 9.
text.16635:
Sūkaramukha — one of the twenty-eight hells, intended
for the king or his officials who punish the innocent, and
Brahmans with corporal punishment.
Bhā. V. 26. 7 and 16.
text.16636:
Sūktāni — relating to Brahmā Viṣṇu, Arka, Rudra, Indra,
Agni, Soma; to be recited at the śrāddha.
M. 17. 37; 246. 60.
text.16638:
Sūkṣmam — a third Yogaiśvarya and Pañcabhūtāmtaka;
indriyas, manas, buddhi, and ahaṅkāra.
Vā. 13. 5.
text.16639:
Sūkṣmas — seven in number; these with the bhūta result
in aiśvarya and aiśvarya results in its turn in rāga or desire
while Brahmā is virāga or void of rāga the sūkṣma bhāva
is Prasthūla bhāva.
Vā. 12. 27-32.
text.16640:
Sūkṣmahṛdayā — the goddess following Bhava mālinī.
M. 179. 71.
text.16643:
Sūci (Sūcimukha) — a class of Piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 377, 383.
text.16644:
Sūcīmukha (I) — one of twenty-eight hells, intended for
the haughty and the miserly.
Bhā. V. 26. 7 and 36.
text.16645:
Sūcīmukha (II) — a commander of Bhaṇḍa: killed by
Tiraskarṇikā.
Br. IV. 21. 78; 24. 9, 44, 96.
text.16649:
Sūta (I) — versed in Purāṇas, Itihāsas, and Dharma-
śāstras, and their expounder addressed by Ṛṣis, Śaunaka and
others. Insulted by Balarāma;1 Romaharṣaṇa, the pupil of
Vyāsa narrated the Purāṇa to the sages assembled for the
sacrifice at Kurukṣetra;2 addressed as Muni, Sattama, Mahā
buddhi and Brahmasuta.3 1) Bhā. I. 1. 5-9; 22. 4. 2; X. 78. 23; M. 1. 4; 23. 1.
2) Br. II.
1. 15; 13. 41; 24. 3; 30. 5; III. 9. 36; 67. 2; IV. 1. 1; 2. 69, 7.
3) M.
113. 58; 125. 3; 146. 2; 180. 3.
text.16650:
Sūta (II) — The bard of Pṛthu born of his somayāga
(aśvamedha sūti-Vi. P.) on the sautya day: a caste formed
by the union of Kṣatriya with a Brahman woman: to train
horses and elephants and be in charge of chariots and act as
physicians to them;1 charioteer of Kārtavīrya;2 sang in praise
of Pṛthu.3 1) Br. II. 36. 113, 159-161, 172; Vi. I. 13. 51.
2) Br. III. 38. 19;
41. 21; 55. 9, 14; IV. 4. 8.
3) Vi. I. 13. 64.
text.16651:
Sūta (III) — a name of Adhiratha, and son of Satya
karmā; the foster father of Karṇa.
M. 48. 108: Vā. 99. 117, 118.
text.16652:
Sūta (IV) — an official in the royal household.
M. 212. 14.
text.16653:
Sūtaputra — the son of Sūta — Śāmśapāyana; tatvārtha-
darśivān.
Vā. 71. 1, 14.
text.16655:
Sūtās — minstrels who panegyrised Pṛthu — praised
Kṛṣṇa's birth and celebrated his victory: present at
Rukmīṇīs marriage;1 woke up Haihaya.2 1) Bhā. I. 15. 20; X. 5. 5; 50. 37; 53. 43; 70. 20; 71. 29; 84. 46.
2) Br. III. 28. 1-2.
text.16656:
Sūtikā — gra(ṛ)ham — Here bhasma forms amulet:
pollution of;1 the place of confinement from which Prad
yumna was stolen away by Śambara.2 1) Br. II. 27. 114; III. 14. 88.
2) Vi. V. 27. 3 and 10.
text.16659:
Sūtrakāra — got war elephants from gods.
Br. III. 7. 349.
text.16660:
Sūtranirṇaya — Brahmasuta establishing unity of Jīva,
Iśvara and Bhūta.
Vā. 104. 22.
text.16661:
Sūtram(ety) — definition of: few letters, free from doubt,
terse, and universal.
Vā. 59. 142; 104. 108.
text.16662:
Sūdādhyakṣa — the chief cook of the King; they should
have their hair and nails cleanly cut.
M. 215. 22-3.
text.16663:
Sūna — the region of adharma and Kali.
Bhā. I. 17. 38.
text.16664:
Sūnās — the five obstacles to the attainment of heaven
by a house-holder: Kaṇḍani, peṣaṇī, cullī, jalakumbhī,
pramārjanī, sins (husking, grinding, fire place, water pots
and cleaning). To get rid of these sins he performs the five
Yajñas.
M. 52. 15-16.
text.16666:
Sūnṛtā (I) — a wife of Dharma, and mother of Satyasena
and others.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 25.
text.16668:
Sūnṛtā (III) — a daughter of Dharma and Lakṣmī,
married Uttānapāda;1 mother of Dhruva.2 1) Br. II. 36. 87. M. 4. 34-5.
2) Vā. 62. 75-6.
text.16670:
Sūrasenas — praised the heroic exploits of Hari.
Bhā. IX. 24. 63.
text.16671:
Sūri — the last son of Śivadatta.
Br. III. 35. 13.
text.16673:
Sūrmyā — a queen of Anuhrāda.
Bhā. VI. 18. 16.
text.16674:
Sūrya (I) — is Mārtāṇḍa as he occupies the inanimate
globe; is Hiraṇyagarbha being born of the Golden Egg. By
his course are divided all the worlds: the Lord of all, animate
and inanimate: His movement among the Rāśīs in the sky.
Traversing the signs of Meṣa and Tulā (the Goat and
Balance) he makes days and nights of equal length: travers
ing the five signs commencing with Vṛṣabha (Bull) he makes
days longer and nights shorter in a month by 24 minutes:
traversing the five signs commencing with Vṛścika, he
reverses the process. Rides in a chariot of one wheel with
Aruṇa as charioteer. Sixtythousand Vālakhilyas go in front
of him singing the Vedas: is also served by other sages, Gan
dharvas, Apsaras, Nāgas, Yakṣas, Yātudhānas, and Gods;1 the
sun moves with Meru and Dhruva on his right and marches
towards the signs of the Zodiac. The twelve signs are the
twelve months of a year. If he traverses one-sixth of the
orbit, it is Ṛtu, and if he completes one-half of his heavenly
path it is ayana. Sometimes the velocity is slow, sometimes
rapid and moderate: the name of the year differs accord
ingly.2 also known as Divaspati and Divākara; 100 thousand
yojanas from the earth, and the same distance from moon;3
does not shine in Ilāvṛtam;4 protects the earth and hence
Ravi;5 cosmology of; sunrise at Samyamana, midday at Ama
rāvatī; evening for Vibhā and midnight for Sukhā. His rays
enter fire during nights and come back during mornings;
hence waters are warm during nights and cool during days;
in a muhūrta Sūrya spreads over a lakh and 81,000 yojanas;6
chariot of one wheel with vedic metres as horses; colour of
the sun in six seasons different; parent of the worlds, all birth
and devastation due to him.7 Twelve-fold ātma; instructed
Yājñavalkya in the form of a horse the Yajus;8 father of
the Yuvati class of Apsaras; a friend of king Satrājit.9
Relative size of sun, moon, etc.; relative splendours, motions
and qualities; different classes of rays named;10 survives
antara pralaya; came after Brahmā in the order of
creation;11 Śrāddha deva;12 Sunday sacred to:13 fight with
Kālanemi.14 1) Bhā. V. 20. 43-6; 21 (whole).
2) Ib. 22. 1-7.
3) Br. IV. 2. 20,
29.
4) Ib. II. 17. 10.
5) Ib. II. 20. 58; Ch. 21.
6) Ib. II. Ch. 22-3; M.
Ch. 128.
7) Br. II. Ch. 24.
8) Ib. II. 35. 23-5.
9) Ib. III. 7. 21, 215; 71.
21, 29.
10) M. Ch. 128. 13-74.
11) Ib. 2. 12 and 31.
12) Ib. 13. 1.
13) Ib.
70. 33.
14) Ib. 150. 151-179; 268. 11.
text.16675:
Sūrya (II) — a son of Kaśyapa and Aditi; wives Samjñā
and Chāyā; father of Manu, Śrāddhadeva and Yama and
Yami; see Vivasvan.1 Presented Pṛthu with arrows from his
rays; worship of: in Plakṣadvīpa,2 begot a son on Pṛthā, still
a maiden;3 presented his friend Satrājita with Syamantaka
(s.v.);4 propitiated by Yājñavalkya, imparted to him Vājasa-
myaṣṭa Yajus in the form of a horse.5 Pointed out with Soma,
Rāhu in deva's disguise. Hence Rāhu chases him in parvas.
Fought with Bāṇa in Devāsura war;6 Baḍavā was another
wife, and Tapati daughter;7 is Vibhāvasu ten Kalas of;8 gives
life to Agni.9 (Āditya): came to Kārtavīrya Arjuna in Brah
man's disguise and asked for a gift of all sthāvara for his food
and offered in turn bows ever effulgent to help in burning
down all sthāvaras;10 māhātmya of, in the Bhaviṣya;11 the
day sacred to the sun is the one when Hastam and Saptami
fall on the same day;12 is Rāhu's abode;13 knows what Śiva
did to Pūṣa and Bhaga;14 through Sarasvatī, got his two sons
(not named);15 worship of, by Brahmans.16 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 39-41; IX. 1. 10-11.
2) Ib. V. 15. 18; 20. 4-5.
3) Ib.
IX. 24. 32. 5.
4) Ib. X. 56. 3.
5) Ib. XII. 6. 66-74.
6) Ib. VIII. 9; 24-6;
10 30.
7) Ib. VIII. 13. 8-10; IX. 22. 4.
8) Br. I. 21. 83.
9) Ib. IV. 35.
81-3.
10) M. 2. 31; 44. 3-11.
11) Ib. 53. 31.
12) Ib. 5. 4.
13) Ib. 127. 10.
14) Ib. 155. 7.
15) Ib. 171. 57-8.
16) Ib. 184. 31.
text.16676:
Sūrya (III) — a son of Bali; a Dānava.
M. 6. 11; Br. III. 6. 8.
text.16678:
Śūryakānta — a Kulaparvata of the Uttara Kuru country.
Vā. 45. 25.
text.16680:
Sūryatejas — a son of Maṇibhadra and Puṇyajanī; an
Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 122; Vā. 69. 154.
text.16683:
Sūryamaṇḍalam — seen after 1000 years in the 27th
Kalpa; all yogas and mantras came out of this.
Vā. 21. 65.
text.16684:
Sūryaratha — the sun's chariot, made by Brahmā out of
the parts of the year with Vedic metres as horses; described;
equal to those Varuṇa; his attendant gaṇas in different
parts of the year (one gaṇa for every two months) and its
motion detailed; has only one wheel.
M. 125. 37-47; 126. 1-47; Vā. 51. 54-67. 52. 42-8.
text.16685:
Sūryalokam — for a bath in Sangameśvaram.
Vā. 111. 3-4, 10-11. M. 191. 78.
text.16686:
Sūryavaṃśa — to be revived by Manu at the end of Kali.
Bhā. IX. 12. 6.
text.16687:
Sūryavarcas — the Gandharva presiding over the month
of Ūrja; a Mauneya Gandharva;1 with the sun in the months
of Māśi and Panguni;2 in the sun's chariot during the Phāl
guna month.3 1) Bhā. XII. 11. 44; Br. III. 7. 2; 23. 21; Vā. 69. 2.
2) Ib. 52. 21.
3) Vi. II. 10. 18.
text.16688:
Sūryavratam — in honour of the Sun god.
M. 101. 36.
text.16689:
Sūryā — a daughter of Kālindī.
Bhā. X. 58. 20.
text.16691:
Sūryoparāga — observed by Kṛṣṇa and the other Yadus
by bathing in Syamantapañcaka and fasting.
Bhā. X. 82. 1-11.
text.16693:
Sṛñjaya (I) — a son of Uttama Manu.
Bhā. VIII. 1. 23.
text.16694:
Sṛñjaya (II) — a son of Kālanara(la) and father of Jana
mejaya; king vanquished by Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā. IX. 23. 1-2; II. 7. 35; Vā. 99. 14.
text.16695:
Sṛñjaya (III) — a son of Devamīḍha and Māriṣā; wife
Rāṣṭrapālī and father of Vṛṣa and other sons;1 went to Sya
mantapañcaka for the solar eclipse.2 1) Bhā. IX. 24. 29 and 42.
2) Ib. X. 82. 13 and 24.
text.16696:
Sṛñjaya (IV) — a son of Dhūmrāśva.
Br. III. 61. 14.
text.16697:
Sṛñjaya (V) — a son of Pratipakṣa and father of Jaya.
Br. III. 68. 8.
text.16698:
Sṛñjaya (VI) — a son of Bhajamāna.
Br. III. 71. 3.
text.16699:
Sṛñjaya (VII) — a son of Śūra and Bhojā; father of Dhanu
and Vajra.
Br. III. 71. 149, 193. M. 46. 3.
text.16700:
Sṛñjaya (VIII) — a son of Kālānala and father of Puran
jaya.
Br. III. 74. 14; Vi. IV. 18. 3-4.
text.16701:
Sṛñjaya (IX) — father of two daughters who became
queens of Bhajamāna.
M. 44. 49.
text.16703:
Sṛñjaya (XI) — the son of Dhūmrākṣa and the father of
Sahadeva.
Vā. 86. 19. Vi. IV. 1. 53-4.
text.16704:
Sṛñjaya (XII) — the adopted son of Vastāvara.
Vā. 96. 190.
text.16705:
Sṛñjaya (XIII) — a brother of Vasudeva.
Vi. IV. 14. 30.
text.16706:
Sṛñjaya (XIV) — a son of Haryaśva.
Vi. IV. 19. 59.
text.16707:
Sṛñjayas — praised the heroism of Kṛṣṇa;1 enlisted by
Jarāsandha against the Yadus. Took part in the festivities con
nected with the marriage of Rukmiṇī and Kṛṣṇa;2 welcomed
Kṛṣṇa, followed Sahadeva in his conquest of southern coun
tries; took part in Yudhiṣṭhira's Rājasūya; rose against Śisu
pāla.3 1) Bhā. I. 7. 13; II. 7. 35; IX. 24. 63.
2) Ib. X. [50 (v) 3]; 54. 58.
3) Ib. X. 71. 29; 72. 13; 74. 41; 75. 12.
text.16708:
Sṛtaṃjaya — the son of Karmajit and father of Vipra.
Bhā. IX. 22. 47.
text.16709:
Sṛpā — a R. in the Vindhyas.
Br. II. 16. 32.
text.16710:
Sṛṣṭi (I) — a son of Ugrasena.
Bhā. IX. 24. 24.
text.16711:
Sṛṣṭi (II) — creation is of three kinds in primitive times
— at will, at mere sight and at a simple touch. But after
Dakṣa's epoch creation by sexual union came into being;1
(in the Vaivasvata epoch, came sexual union Br. P.);1 crea
tion starting when the balance of the guṇas is disturbed;2
according to Sānkhya.3 1) Br. I. 4. 3; II. 37. 48; M. 5. 2; Vā. 63. 45.
1) Br. I. 4. 3; II. 37. 48; M. 5. 2; Vā. 63. 45.
2) Ib. 5. 9.
3) Ib.
4. 46-90.
text.16712:
Sṛṣṭi (III) — a son of Dhruva; asked his own shadow to
become a woman, and this was Chāyā, mother of five sons,
Prācīnagarbha and others.
Br. II. 36. 96-8.
text.16713:
Setu (I) — a son of Babhru and father of Ārabdha.
Bhā. IX. 23. 14-15; Vi. IV. 17. 2-3.
text.16714:
Setu (II) — the name of the bridge built by Rāma to go
to Lankā as testified by Jāmbavan; sacred to Hari. Visited by
Balarāma who made a gift of cows to Brahmans here.
Bhā. X. 56. 28; VII. 14. 36; X. 79. 15-16.
text.16715:
Setu (III) — a son of Svārociṣa Manu.
Br. II. 36. 19.
text.16716:
Setu (IV) — one of the two sons of Druhyu and father of
Aruddha.
Br. III. 74. 7; M. 48. 6; Vā. 99. 7.
text.16717:
Setukās — a southern country; a tribe.
Br. II. 16. 56; M. 114. 46; Vā. 45. 125.
text.16719:
Senājit (I) — a son of Kṛśāśva and father of Yuvanāśva.
Bhā. IX. 6. 25.
text.16720:
Senājit (II) — a son of Viśada and father of Rucirāśva
and three other sons.
Bhā. IX. 21. 23.
text.16721:
Senājit (III) — the Apsaras presiding over the month of
Tapasya.
Bhā. XII. 11. 40.
text.16722:
Senājit (IV) — a Marut of the second gaṇa.
Br. III. 5. 93; Vā. 67. 124.
text.16723:
Senājit (V) — a Bṛhadratha, the reigning king when the
Purāṇa was written by the term Sāmpratam.
Br. III. 74. 113.
text.16724:
Senājit (VI) — a son of Aśvajit; (Viśvajit-Vā. P.); father
of four famous sons.
M. 49. 49-50; Vā. 99. 172; Vi. IV. 19. 35-6.
text.16725:
Senājit (VII) — a son of Bṛhadkarma ruled with Sam
prayāta for 50 years (had just passed away when this
account was written);1 father of Śrutamjaya.2 1) M. 271. 23.
2) Vi. IV. 23. 5.
text.16726:
Senājit (VIII) — a grāmaṇi with the sun in Śarat.
Vā. 52. 14.
text.16727:
Senājit (IX) — (Sāmpratam); a great and bold warrior,
ruled for 35 years.
Vā. 99. 300-1.
text.16728:
Senājit (X) — an Yakṣa, who resides in the sun's chariot
during the Kārtika month.
Vi. II. 10. 12.
text.16729:
Senāni (I) — a commander-in-chief;1 an epithet of
Skanda;2 a number of them in Bhaṇḍa's army; also Cāmu
nātha;3 of Tāraka;4 see Senāpati. 1) Br. II. 29. 76.
2) Ib. III. 42. 9.
3) Ib. IV. 21. 76.
4) M. 148. 38;
text.16730:
Senāni (II) — a name of Vighneśvara.
Br. IV. 44. 69.
text.16732:
Senāni (IV) — one of the seven Prāṇins of a king.
Vā. 57. 70.
text.16733:
Senāpati — (Senāni) qualifications of; may be a Brahman
or Kṣatriya;1 residence of, with five courts (prākāras).2 1) M. 148. 79; 215. 8-10.
2) Ib. 223. 8; 254. 18.
text.16734:
Sendraphenā — R. sacred to Pitṛs; the place of Indra's
penance when he fell after killing Namuci.
M. 22. 60-61.
text.16735:
Saitya — a sage having no marriage alliances with Bṛhas
pati, Bharadvāja, Garga, etc.
M. 196. 24.
text.16739:
Saindhava (I) — the king of Sindhu country could not
defeat Arjuna supported by Kṛṣṇa;1 killed Abhimanyu
during the Kurukṣetra war but was slain by Arjuna; see
Jayadratha.2 1) Bhā. 1. 15. 16.
2) Ib. X. 78 [95 (v) 30], 35.
text.16740:
Saindhava (II) — the horse of the Sind on which Sud
yumna rode to the northern forests.
Bhā. IX. 1. 23.
text.16741:
Saindhava (III) — (c) a kingdom watered by the Sin
dhu; noted for horses.
Br. II. 18. 48; IV. 17. 27; M. 121. 47.
text.16742:
Saindhava (IV) — a disciple of Śaunaka; again divided
the Samhitā into two parts and gave to Muñjakeśa.
Vā. 47. 46; 61. 53; Vi. III. 6. 12.
text.16743:
Saindhavas — were enlisted by Jarāsandha against the
Yadus;1 country of the.2 1) Bhā. X. [50 (v) 3].
2) Vi. II. 3. 17.
text.16744:
Saindhavāyana — read Atharva Samhitā with Babhru
from Śuneka; a pupil of Śaunaka.
Bhā. XII. 7. 3; Br. II. 35. 60.
text.16745:
Saindhavāyanas — a Kauśika clan;1 Trayārṣeya.2 1) Br. III. 66. 74.
2) M. 198. 4.
text.16746:
Sainya — an army of four-fold forces and of six limbs; a
nuisance to peace.
Br. III. 26. 52-3; 27. 12-13; 38. 18; 48. 7.
text.16748:
Sainhlāda — a son of Hiraṇyakaśipu.
Vi. I. 15. 142.
text.16750:
Saimham — (Vapu) Viṣṇu in the body of a lion.
Vā. 97. 17.
text.16751:
Saimhikeya — is Rāhu who got a slap with the spoon of
Mohinī.
Br. IV. 10. 19.
text.16752:
Saimhikeyas — the fourteen sons of (Asura) Simhikā
and Vipracitti; however only 13 names are given;
they had their own sons and grandsons forming
groups in thousands (hundreds-Vā. P.); vanquished by
Bhārgava, son of Jamadagni;1 city of, in the northern slopes
of Maryāda hill.2 1) Br. III. 6. 18-22; M. 6. 25; 249. 51, 67; Vā. 68. 17-22.
2) Ib.
40. 11.
text.16753:
Sairandhrī — a Kaśyapa and a Trayārṣeya.
M. 199. 12.
text.16755:
Saivālas — a Janapada of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 21.
text.16757:
Saivyā (II) — one of the wives of Vasudeva.
Vā. 96. 182.
text.16760:
Sodakas — a Janapada of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 22.
text.16761:
Sopasangas — a Janapada of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 20.
text.16762:
Sopānapaṃktis — thirty-six of them lead to the cot of
Śrīpīṭha (named).
Br. IV. 37. 57-61.
text.16763:
Soma (I) — a son born of Atri's eyes; honoured at birth
by Śiva and Umā; borne for 300 years by diks (directions)
and when released became an amśa of Brahmā who took
him in his Vedic chariot of 1000 horses to his loka where
Brahmaṛṣis adored him as their king and was praised
by Mantras; nourished the crying Māriṣā in her babyhood
with nectar; presented Pṛthu with undying horses.1 Appealed
to Pracetas not to destroy trees and offered their daughter
Vārkṣī in marriage to him, married the twenty-seven
daughters of Dakṣa; Kṛttikā and other stars as his wives;
cursed by Dakṣa he had no issue and was struck with disease
propitiated Dakṣa and recovered.2 Appointed by Brahmā
as Lord of Plants, Brahmans and stars; worshipped
for a life of enjoyments; also called Rājā; father of Budha;3
got rid of his consumption by bathing in the Prabhāsā; wor
shipped largely in Śālmalidvīpa;4 conquered three worlds
and took Tārā, Bṛhaspati's wife by force. Tārā who was
pregnant was given back to Bṛhaspati through the
intervention of Brahmā. This was Budha.5 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 15 and 33; 14. 26; 30. 14; 15. 17; Br. III. 65. 1-20;
M. 4. 49; 23. 4-15; 198. 1;
2) Ib. 2. 12; 5. 13; 146. 16. Bhā. VI. 3. 14; 4.
6-16; 6. 2, 23-24; VIII. 4. 21; 5. 34.
3) Bhā. VIII. 18. 15; X. 84. 47;
XI. 16. 16; II. 3. 9; IX. 1. 35; Br. III. 65. 46. 48; M. 11. 53-4.
4) Bhā.
XI. 6. 36; V. 20. 11-12.
5) Ib. IX. 14. 2. 14; Br. III. 65. 28-44.
text.16764:
Soma (II) (Candra s.v.) — a Lokapāla with his city
Vibhāvarī on the north of Meru;1 Lord of stars, and one face
of Śiva: served as calf when sages and Pṛthu milked the
earth-cow;2 his rays gave rise to certain Apsara clans:
Kaśyapa made him king of Brahmans;3 a Śrāddhadeva:
Lord of Pitṛs: (1/8) amśa of Śiva coming out of the dhāma that
issued along with tears of Śiva: Nine women desired and
enjoyed his company;4 one of the nine grahas with white
colour;5 in the Devāsura wars, was vanquished by māyā of
Kālanemī, took part in the Tārakāmaya, helped Varuṇa at
the suggestion of Indra;6 the dot in him is the earth's
shadow;7 propitiated in the installation of an image and in
house building;8 born from the ocean of milk;9 world of;10
nectar of, drunk by Pitṛs and gods;11 feeds rivers by causing
rain.12 1) Br. II. 21. 33; 22. 14. 15; M. 266. 26.
2) Br. II. 24. 46; 26.
41; 27. 112 ff.; M. 10. 16.
3) Br. III. 5. 80; 7. 22; 8. 3. 77. 36. 204.
M. 11. 63.
4) Ib. 23-1, 8; 31. 12.
5) Ib. 93. 10-17.
6) Ib. 150. 153;
174. 24; 176. 1-33.
7) Ib. 176. 5.
8) Ib. 265. 39; 253. 27.
9) Ib. 250. 2;
268. 18.
10) Ib. 91. 1-10.
11) Br. II. 23. 39, 69-73.
12) Vā. 51. 14-21.
text.16765:
Soma (III) — a son of Sāvitrī and Pṛśni.
Bhā. VI. 18. 1.
text.16767:
Soma (V) — a Vasu: a son of Dharma and Sudevī; had
five sons Varca, Budha, Dhara, Urmī and Kalila.
Br. III. 3. 21; M. 5. 21, 23; 171. 46; 203. 3.
text.16769:
Soma (VII) — the temple of, in the Supakṣa hill.
Vā. 39. 63.
text.16771:
Soma (IX) — a son of Atri and Anasūyā.
Vi. I. 10. 8.
text.16772:
Soma (X) — a Vasu; the son of Bhagavān Varca.
Vi. I. 15. 110, 112.
text.16773:
Somaka (I) — a son of Sahadeva and father of Janhu
and 99 other sons of whom the youngest was Pṛṣarṭa, in
previous birth Ajamīḍha.
Bhā. IX. 22. 1-2; Vā. 99. 208; Vi. IV. 19. 71-2.
text.16774:
Somaka (II) — a son of Kṛṣṇa and Kālindī.
Bhā. X. 61. 14.
text.16775:
Somaka (III) — one of the seven mountains of Plakṣa
dvīpa (Śākadvīpa-M. P.) which enters the sea; from it
Garuḍa took amṛta for his mother.
Br. II. 18. 77; 19. 11-12; M. 122. 15; Vā. 47. 74; 49. 10; Vi.
II. 4. 7.
text.16776:
Somaka (IV) — a son of Sudāsa; Ajamīḍha was reborn
when the line was delayed.
M. 50. 15.
text.16778:
Somatanvi — belonging to the Pravara of Angiras.
M. 196. 15.
text.16779:
Somatīrtha — near the Yamunā; the best of all sacred
spots.
M. 109. 2; 191. 30 and 94.
text.16780:
Somadatta (I) — a son of Kṛśāśva: performed 100 Aśva
medhas and attained the goal of Yogins. Father of Sumati
(Janamejaya-Vi. P.);1 a Rājaṛṣi.2 1) Bhā. IX. 2. 35-36; Vi. IV. 1. 56-7.
2) Br. III. 61. 16.
text.16781:
Somadatta (II) — a son of Bāhlika and father of Bhūri
and two other sons. Attacked the northern gate of Mathurā,
and the eastern gate of Gomanta when they were besieged
by Jarāsandha. A Kaurava.
Bhā. IX. 22. 18; X. 50. 11[7]; 52. 11 [6]; Vā. 99. 235; Vi.
IV. 20. 31-2.
text.16782:
Somadatta (III) — versed in the Purāṇas.
Br. II. 35. 64; Vi. V. 35. 28.
text.16783:
Somadatta (IV) — an ally of Kārtavīrya killed by Paraśu
rāma.
Br. III. 39. 2-7.
text.16784:
Somadatta (V) — a Bāleya Gandharva; a Rājaṛṣi and
father of Janamejaya.
Vā. 69. 20; 86. 20.
text.16785:
Somapa (I) — a sage of the Raivata epoch.
M. 9. 19.
text.16786:
Somapa (II) — a son of Sahadeva and father of
Śrutaśravas.
Vi. IV. 19. 84.
text.16787:
Somapas (I) — sacrificers of Soma enjoy the world of
Moon.
Bhā. III. 32. 3.
text.16788:
Somapas (II) — Pitṛ (Barhiṣads) who live in mānasa
worlds; their mind-born daughter is Narmadā; they came
out of svadhā and are all yogins.
Br. III. 10. 53, 66; M. 15. 26; 141. 20, 57; Vā. 30. 100. 56. 16;
62. 15; 110. 10.
text.16789:
Somapathas — the world of Pitṛs where live the sons of
Mārīca.
Br. III. 10. 52-3; M. 14. 1.
text.16790:
Somapāda — the worlds where Marīci's descendants
reside; here Devapitṛs by name agniṣvāttas live; mind-born
daughter of R. Acchodā.
Vā. 73. 1-2.
text.16791:
Somapānam (I) — the Madirāsīndhu of gods.
Br. IV. 28. 87.
text.16792:
Somapānam (II) — tīrtha sacred to the Pitṛs; the resi
dence of Vaiśvānara.
M. 22. 62.
text.16793:
Somapāyinas — the Devas of the 13th epoch of Manu;
thirty-three are distinguished among them.
Vā. 62. 11; 100. 102; 101. 43.
text.16796:
Somaratha — the chariot of the Moon.
Vā. 52. 76.
text.16797:
Somarāja — compared to Pṛthu, see Soma (s.v.).
Bhā. IV. 22. 56; Vā. 61. 44.
text.16798:
Somarājāyana — a pupil of Kṛta.
Br. II. 35. 52.
text.16799:
Somalokam — a bath in the Kaṭheśvaram tīrtha and
Somatīrtha leads to.
M. 191. 65, 97.
text.16800:
Somavaṃśa — the lunar line of Kings;1 Ila common
ancestor;2 commences with the 29th Yuga.3 1) Bhā. IX. 14. 1-2; M. 11. 1.
2) Ib. 12. 14.
3) Vā. 99. 439.
text.16803:
Somavratam — the performer becomes a Rājarāja.
M. 10. 1. 81.
text.16804:
Somaśarman — a son of Śāliśūka and father of Śata
dhanva.
Bhā. XII. 1. 14-5; Vi. IV. 24. 30.
text.16805:
Somaśarmā — the avatār of the Lord of the 27th dvāpara
in the Prabhāsa tīrtha with four sons, all tapasvins.
Vā. 23. 215.
text.16806:
Somaśilā — in the Parijātaśilā of the Niṣadha hill where
the moon descends.
Vā. 41. 57.
text.16807:
Somaśuṣkāyaṇa — the Vedavyāsa of the 23rd dvāpara.
Vi. III. 3. 17.
text.16808:
Somaśuṣman — heard the Purāṇa from Vājaśravas and
narrated it to Tṛṇabindu;1 heard the Vāyu Purāṇa from
Vājaśravas.2 1) Br. IV. 4. 64.
2) Vā. 103. 64.
text.16809:
Somasaṃsthas — a kind of rituals for house-holders.
Vi. III. 11. 24.
text.16810:
Somasūktam — to be uttered on the occasion of found
ing temples.
M. 265. 24.
text.16811:
Somādhi — a son of Sahadeva ruled for 58 years in
Girivraja; a Rājaṛṣi.
M. 271. 19; Vā. 99. 228, 296.
text.16812:
Somāpi — a son of Sahadeva and father of Śrutaśravas;1
reigned at Girivraja for 58 years.2 1) Bhā. IX. 22. 9; Vi. IV. 23. 24.
2) Br. III. 74. 110-14.
text.16813:
Somāvarttā — a R. of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 26.
text.16814:
Someśvara — sacred to Varārohā; sacred to the Pitṛs.
M. 13. 43; 22. 29.
text.16815:
Sohāñji — a son of Kunti and father of Mahiṣmān.
Bhā. IX. 23. 22.
text.16816:
Saukaravapu — the second avatār of Hari (Vārāha).
Bhā. V. 3. 7.
text.16817:
Saugandhika — a forest in Kailāsa.
Bhā. IV. 6. 23 and 28.
text.16819:
Sauṭi — belonging to the Pravara of Angiras.
M. 196. 13.
text.16821:
Sauteya — a special day in a sacrifice.
Br. II. 36. 159; IV. 5. 4.
text.16822:
Sautrāmaṇi — a Yāga, the fruit of which is attained by
one fasting oneself, and feeding a number of Brahmans at
Benares.
Bhā. X. 23. 8; M. 183. 75.
text.16823:
Saudāmani — the lightning of the sky, a daughter of
Vinatā.
M. 6. 34.
text.16824:
Saudāsa — also called Mitrasaha and Kalmāṣānghri;
(Kalmāṣapāda-Vā. P.) son of Sudāsa; wife of Madayantī,
became a Rākṣasa through Vasiṣṭha's curse. Once as he was
hunting, he killed a demon. The latter's brother wanted to
wreak vengeance on the king and in the guise of a cook,
served human flesh to Vasiṣṭha. The sage knew this and
cursed him to be a demon for 12 years. The king wanted
to curse the sage in return but was stopped by his wife. The
consecrated waters fell on his feet and blackened them.
Wandering in the forest, he saw a Brahman couple engaged
in amorous sports. As a demon he seized the Brahman
and ate his flesh despite the lady's protest. She cursed the
demon to meet with death in the sexual act and joined her
husband on his funeral pyre: after 12 years he returned and
longed for union with his queen. She refused remembering
the curse of the Brahmana lady. So he appointed Vasiṣṭha
to beget a son on his queen. As the child was seven years
in pregnancy, Vasiṣṭha hit her stomach with a stone and the
child was born. This was Aśmaka.
Bhā. IX. 9. 18-39; Vā. 1. 175; 88. 176.
text.16828:
Sauparṇeyas — divine birds; sisters of Aruṇa and
Garuḍa.
Vā. 69. 67.
text.16829:
Saupuri — belonging to the Ārṣeya Pravara, Angiras.
M. 196. 7.
text.16833:
Saubha — the magic car of iron obtained by tapas from
Śiva by Śālva; made by Maya fitted with all illusory powers.
Bhā. X. 76. 1, 3-7; 78. 13.
text.16834:
Saubhaga — a son of Bṛhatśloka and the grandson of
Vāmana.
Bhā. VI. 18. 7-8.
text.16836:
Saubhari (I) — a Ṛg Vedic sage who got himself trans
formed into a youthful person and requested king Mān
dhātri for his daughter's hand; when he was asked to select
one from the harem, he went in, when all his fifty daughters
wanted to have him as their husband. So he agreed; after
enjoying worldly pleasure for long, he felt the urge for mukti
and retired to the forest, with his wives following and became
a Vaikhānasabhikṣu; lived with them; father of 150 sons;
when the sage was dead, all his wives burnt themselves on
his funeral pyre;1 before his marriage he was engaged in
penance. Once immersed under the waters of the Yamunā
in contemplation of the Lord, he saw a fish in sexual union
and felt a desire for home life; on another occasion he
noticed Garuḍa consuming a fish, and cursed on behalf of
the sages that Garuḍa's visit to Kālindi would be his death.2
Knew the yoga power of Hari.3 1) Bhā. IX. 6. 38-55; Vi. IV. 2. 69 to end.
2) Ib. X. 17. 9-11.
3) Ib. II. 7. 45.
text.16837:
Saubhari (II) — a pupil of Devamitra.
Bhā. XII. 6. 56.
text.16838:
Saubhari (III) — a son of Satyā and Kṛṣṇa.
Br. III. 71. 247.
text.16839:
Saubharikā — a daughter of Satyabhāmā.
Br. III. 71. 248.
text.16840:
Saubhāgyam — when pralaya went up to the mahar
lokam and when the whole world was overwhelmed by
ahamkāra there was a dispute between Brahmā and Kṛṣṇa
when out of the latter's chest a light in the shape of a Linga
came out. It was drunk by Dakṣa son of Brahmā and the
result was the birth of Satī. The rest of rasa became eight
fold, seven substances bringing fortune and salt.
M. 60. 6-10.
text.16842:
Saubhāgyaśayanam — in honour of Umā; to be begun
on Vasanta Śukla tritīyā and continued for a year
every tritīyā when Satī married Śiva; after purificatory
baths, offer prayers to Umā and also to Śiva in the midst
of the eight saubhāgyas by flowers, incense, etc.; at the
end a gift of a bed is prescribed; the performer gets desired
things and ultimately reaches heaven; he who does it for
12 years, or 7 or 8 lives a happy long life. Madana, Sata
dhanva, Kārtavīrya, Varuṇa and Nandi have done this.
M. 60. 1. 46.
text.16843:
Saubhāgyaṣṭakam — sugar cane, rasarāja, niṣpāva, jāji,
dhānyakam, gokṣīram, kurumbham and salt.
M. 60. 7-8, 28.
text.16846:
Saumanasya — a territorial division of Śālmalidvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 9.
text.16847:
Saumāṃgalya — the sacred thread worn by women after
their wedlock. It is said that Sītā retained this alone when
giving away the other jewels as gifts.
Bhā. IX. 11. 4.
text.16849:
Saumitri (I) — a composer of the Sāma Veda.
Br. II. 35. 44.
text.16850:
Saumitri (II) — Lakṣmaṇa, met his brother Rāma in the
R. Kadalī.
M. 22. 53.
text.16852:
Saumya (I) — the town of Soma visited by Arjuna in
search of the dead child of the Dvārakā Brahman.
Bhā. X. 89. 44.
text.16853:
Saumya (II) — one of the nine divisions of Bhārata
varṣa.
Br. II. 16. 9; M. 114. 8; Vā. 45. 79; Vi. II. 3. 7.
text.16854:
Saumya (III) — a muhūrta of the night.
Br. III. 3. 43; Vā. 66. 44.
text.16856:
Saumya (V) — Budha, the son of Rohiṇī; born in Nai
miṣa.
Vā. 2. 9.
text.16857:
Saumyam (I) — (Sauram Ucānam) — solar measure
ments.
Br. II. 21. 137; Vā. 50. 188.
text.16858:
Saumyam (II) — Sūkta of the Yajurvedins; to be recited
in tank rituals.
M. 58. 35; 93. 132.
text.16860:
Saumyam (IV) — the place of the moon in the maṇ
ḍalam.
Vā. 53. 59.
text.16861:
Saumyavratam — in honour of Śiva and Keśava.
M. 101. 14.
text.16862:
Saumyas (I) — a class of sacred fire.
Bhā. IV. 1. 63.
text.16863:
Saumyas (II) — a class of Pitṛs who drink Soma's sva-
dha; deities of Ṛtus and hence Ṛtvas; Pitṛs born of Soma.
Br. II. 23. 39, 75; 28. 4, 15, 18, 70; M. 102. 20; 126. 69; 141. 4,
13, 16. Vā. 52. 67; 56. 13, 16, 66; Vi. II. 12. 13.
text.16865:
Saura (I) — the fire originating in waters; light and heat
produced from;1 is Śuci agni;2 the Sun god.3 1) Br. II. 24. 12, 18; Vā. 53. 8, 13.
2) Br. II. 12. 3.
3) Vā. 1. 97.
text.16866:
Saura (II) — belonging to Ārṣeya pravara of Bhārgavas.
M. 195. 38
text.16867:
Saura (III) — Śanaiscara born of Revatī in Cākṣuṣa
epoch; (3/4) of Bṛhaspati in extent.
Vā. 53. 67, 109.
text.16868:
Saura Gaṇa — a group of seven in relation to Sūrya,
changing every month. While the sage chants the Vedas in
his praise, the Gandharva sings, the Apsarasas dance, the
Nāga makes fast his chariot, the Yakṣa makes his chariot and
the Rākṣasa pushes it from behind. Preceding the chariot
the Vālakhilyas move praising his glory.
Bhā. XII. 11. 27, 46-49.
text.16869:
Saurabha — the kingdom to which Puramjana went with
his friend Avadhūta; allegorically smell.
Bhā. IV. 25. 48; 29. 11.
text.16870:
Saurabheya — the bull from whom Asija learnt the go-
dharma; one day it ate of the grass kept for ceremonial and
was forcibly retained by Dīrghatamas who on hearing the
godharma from it left it go; Surabhi got him rid of all curses
including blindness and old age.
Vā. 99. 47, 88.
text.16871:
Sauram (I) — the sthānam of the sun in the maṇḍalam.
Vā. 53. 59.
text.16872:
Sauram (II) — one of the six darśanas.
Vā. 104. 16.
text.16873:
Sauramaṇḍalam — the solar region; 100,000 yojanas
from the earth.
Vi. II. 7. 5.
text.16874:
Sauram mānam — see Saumya mānam.
Br. II. 21. 137.
text.16875:
Saura Vratam — leads to the world of the Sun.
M. 101. 63.
text.16876:
Saurasūktam — in praise of the Sun god; Sūkta of the
Yajur Vedins; recited in tank ritual; of Atharva Veda.
M. 58. 35; 77. 6; 93. 134.
text.16877:
Saurabheyī — an Apsaras in the sabhā of Hiraṇyakaśipu.
M. 161. 74.
text.16878:
Saurāṣṭra — (c) the dvijas of, became Vrātyas, after
Puramjaya's time;1 attacked Paraśurāma and were defeated;2
ruled by a degraded caste.3 1) Bhā. XII. 1. 38; M. 114. 51.
2) Br. III. 39. 11.
3) Vi. IV. 24. 68.
text.16879:
Saurāṣṭras — the country of the.
Vi. II. 3. 16.
text.16880:
Sauri (I) — is Śanaiścara (planet) 250,000 yojanas
above Bṛhaspati; above are seven sages.
Br. II. 24. 105; Vi. II. 7. 9.
text.16881:
Sauri (II) — belonging to Ārṣeya pravara of Angiras.
M. 195. 43.
text.16882:
Sauri (III) — an adopted son of Vastāvana.
Vā. 96. 189.
text.16884:
Saurṇi — a son of Vasudeva adopted by his brother Vṛka.
Br. III. 71. 192.
text.16885:
Sauvarṇa — the earth of Pātālam.
Br. II. 20. 15.
text.16886:
Sauvarṇam (I) — gold vessels for śrāddha.
M. 17. 20; Vā. 74. 1.
text.16887:
Sauvarṇam (II) — a sūktam of the Sāma Samhitā; recited
in tank ritual.
M. 58. 36.
text.16888:
Sauvīra (c) — a country after Suvīra son of Śibi, visited
by Vidura;1 its people were enlisted by Jarāsandha against
the Yadus;2 lay between Dvārakā and Hāstinapura.3 1) Bhā. I. 10. 35; III. 1. 24; V. 10. 1; M. 48. 20.
2) Bhā. X. 50.
V. 3.
3) Ib. X. 71. 21; XI. 21. 8.
text.16889:
Sauvīras — a Janapada of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 19; Vi. II. 3. 17.
text.16891:
Sauvīrarāja — the gate-keeper of this king chose him for
sacrifice to Kāli, who knowing Bharata's spiritual eminence
turned against the servant of the king; then engaged Bha
rata born as Brahman, as palanquin bearer; when he went
to the hermitage of Kapila he did not bear it well, and when
asked once and twice the Brahman burst out into high philo
sophy which the king learnt from him and renounced all
