kinds of distinction.
Vi. II. 13. 48 to end; chh. 14-16.
text.16892:
Sauveṣṭi — belonging to the Pravara Angiras.
M. 196. 12.
text.16893:
Sauśalya — (c) a kingdom of Madhyadeśa.
Br. II. 16. 41.
text.16894:
Sauśrutas — a Kauśika clan.
Br. III. 66. 74; Vā. 91. 102.
text.16896:
Skanda (I) — a son of Agni and Kṛttikas; father of Niśā
kha and others;1 the presiding deity for the Angārakagraha;2
in the Tripuram battle;3 spoke in praise of Benares;4 in praise
of;5 a commander of gods;6 ety.7 also known Kumāra, Kārti
keya;8 Lord of Naiṛṛtas.9 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 14; Vi. I. 8. 11.
2) M. 93. 13; Br. II. 74. 48; 26. 33.
3) M. 138. 24: 181. 32.
4) Ib. 182. 1; 184. 74.
5) Ib. 185. 2-4; 192. 6.
6) Ib. 230. 7; 266. 45.
7) Ib. 159. 1-3.
8) Br. III. 10. 43 and 51; 32. 54,
59, IV. 14. 8; 30. 105.
9) Ib. III. 41. 17 and 52; 59. 14.
text.16897:
Skanda (II) — a son of Paśupati and Svāhā.
Br. II. 10. 81; Vā. 27. 53.
text.16898:
Skanda (III) — a son of Āyu.
Br. III. 3. 24.
text.16899:
Skanda (IV) — (Pārvatīya) a sage of the Rohita epoch.
Br. IV. 1. 62.
text.16903:
Skandamālā — a R. of the Bhadrā country.
Vā. 43. 30.
text.16904:
Skandina — a piśāca gaṇa, unclad and with hanging
hairs; eat the leavings of others.
Vā. 69. 263, 279.
text.16905:
Skandasa — an Ārṣeya Pravara belonging to Angiras.
M. 196. 23.
text.16906:
Skandasvāti — an Āndhra king who ruled for seven
years.
M. 273. 6.
text.16907:
Skandika — a class of Piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 380.
text.16908:
Skandins — a class of Piśācas.
Br. III. 7. 381. 400.
text.16910:
Skāndam, Skānda Purāṇa — one among the eighteen
Purāṇas; the Mahā-Purāṇa of 81,000 verses dealing with
Maheśvara dharmas and the anecdotes of Ṣaṇmukha;
he who gives it with a golden śūla when the sun is in Mīna
attains Śivahood.
M. 53. 42-4; Vā. 104. 10; Vi. III. 6. 23. Bhā. XII. 7. 23; 13. 7.
text.16914:
Stamba — a Kaśyapa and one of the seven sages of Svā
rociṣa epoch.
Br. II. 36. 17.
text.16915:
Stambha (I) (Kaśyapa) — a son of Parvaśa.
Br. II. 11. 16.
text.16916:
Stambha (II) — one of the seven sages of the Svārociṣa
epoch.
Vi. III. 1. 11.
text.16918:
Stambhas — the chief types of pillars are five;
rucaka (square), vajra (octagonal), dvivajra (sixteen
sided), pralīnaka (thirty-two sided) and vṛtta (round);
(Vāstu). If the measurements are incorrect there will be
fear from kings, thieves and other troubles. The woods
for the different sides of a house are vaṭa, udumbara,
pippala, plakṣa, etc. Other trees which can be grown
around a building are punnāga, aśoka, bakulu, śamī,
śilaka, campaka, dāḍimī, pippalī, drākṣa, jambīru, pūga,
panasa, ketaki, jāti-saroja, śatapatrika, mallika, nārikela,
kadalī, pāṭala, etc. These give auspiciousness to the house.
^1 M. 255. 1-4, 16. ^2 Ib. 255. 20-4.
text.16919:
Stambhamitra — heard the Viṣṇu Purāṇa from Bhāgini
and narrated it to Dadhīca.
Vi. VI. 8. 44.
text.16920:
Stambhini — a śakti in the Kiricakra, and a charioteer.
Br. IV. 20. 6, 25, 38, 57.
text.16921:
Stāvakas — a Janapada of the Ketumālā continent.
Vā. 44. 10.
text.16922:
Stutā (Surā?) — a wife of Varuṇa! her two sons were
Kali and Vaidya and a daughter Surasundarī.
Br. III. 59. 6.
text.16923:
Stutī — the wife of Pratihartā and mother of Aja and
Bhūman.
Bhā. V. 15. 5.
text.16924:
Stutyavrata — a son of Hiraṇyaretas of Kuśadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 14.
text.16925:
Steya — theft; one of the heinous sins; story of a thief
Vajra of Kāñcī is told.2
^1 Vā. 105. 13. 2) Br. IV. 6. 37; 7. 4, 10.
text.16926:
Stoka Kṛṣṇa — a playmate of Kṛṣṇa; wanted to go to the
palmyra grove then in possession of Dhenuka.
Bhā. X. 15. 20; 22. 31.
text.16927:
Stotra — of Gadādhara, by Brahmā;1 by Śiva.2 1) Vā. 109. 27-31.
2) Ib. 109. 43. 50.
text.16928:
Stotram — four-fold, dravya, guṇa, karma, and ābhi
janikam.
Vā. 59. 58.
text.16929:
Stotras (I)1 — of Brahmā by Gods oppressed by Tāraka;2
of Pārvatī by Vīraka;3 of Ṣanmukha before Tārakāvadha;4
same by Siddhas and Bandies;5 of Narasimha by Gods after
the death of Hiraṇyakaśipu;6 of Narasimha by Śankara;7 of
Hari by Aditi;8 of Hari by Prahlāda;9 of Vāmana by
Brahmā;10 of Mādhava by earth (Mādhavīya);11 of Viṣṇu by
Gods for Amṛthamathana.12 1) M. 61. 50-3.
2) Ib. 154. 7-15.
3) Ib. 158. 11-20.
4) Ib. 159.
13-17.
5) Ib. 169. 40-3.
6) Ib. 163. 98-103.
7) Ib. 179. 55-60.
8) Ib.
244. 12-34.
9) Ib. 245. 17-29.
10) Ib. 245. 67-80.
11) Ib. 248. 12. 56.
12) Ib. 249. 37-44.
text.16930:
Stotras (II) — of Viṣṇu by Prithivī;1 by Brahmā;2 by
other Gods;3 by Dhruva;4 by Pracetasas;5 by Prahlāda;6 by
Devas;7 by Brahmā;8 by Kāliya's wives (Kṛṣṇa);9 by Kāliya;10
by Nārada;11 by Akrūra;12 by Vāsudeva after Kamsa's fall;13
by Mucukunda;14 by Aditi after getting her kuṇḍala back.15 1) Vi. I. 4. 12-24.
2) Ib. I. 9. 40. 57.
3) Ib. I. 9. 69-74.
4) Ib. I.
12. 51-74.
5) Ib. I. 15. 23-43.
6) Ib. I. 19. 64-86; 20. 9-13.
7) Ib. III.
17. 11-34.
8) Ib. V. 1. 35-51, 55-9.
9) Ib. V. 7. 48-59.
10) Ib. V. 7.
61-76.
11) Ib. V. 16. 19-27.
12) Ib. V. 17. 3-17; 18. 48-58.
13) Ib. V.
20. 94-105.
14) Ib. V. 23. 29-47.
15) Ib. V. 30. 6-23.
text.16931:
Stotras (III) — of Lakṣmī, by Indra.
Vi. I. 9. 116-33.
text.16932:
Stotras (IV) — of Sūrya, by Yājñavalkya.
Vi. III. 5. 16-25.
text.16933:
Stomam — svara variety of a Sāma;1 saptadaśam, another
variety;2 Pañcadaśam, another variety;3 Pañcadaśam, from
the south face of Brahmā.4 1) Vā. 9. 49.
2) Ib. 9. 50.
3) Br. II. 8. 51. 52.
4) Vi. I. 5. 54.
text.16935:
Strimitra — a king who ruled for 13 years.
Br. III. 74. 187.
text.16937:
Strī (I) — the region of adharma, and of Kali;1 duties and
behaviour of; to be avoided by a Brahmacārin;2 becomes
Keśaśūla in Kali; more women than men; unfit for rule, if
there were no husband;3 killing a woman a heinous crime;
Hari cursed to be born on earth for having slain Bhṛgu's
wife.4 No śīla or vrata; but fond of wine and meat in the Kali
age;5 conditions making her unfit for intercourse;6 to be
honoured and not to be fully confided.7 1) Bhā. I. 17. 38.
2) Ib. VII. 11. 25. 29; 12. 7-9.
3) Br. II. 31. 51
and 54: IV. 14. 15.
4) Ib. II. 36. 181 and 185; III. 72. 138-40.
5) Vā.
58. 43.
6) Vi. III. 11. 115-17.
7) Ib. III. 12. 30.
text.16938:
Strī (II) — in Kali age; personal charm in the possession
of hair; deserts her husband for power; a wealthy man, con
sidered as husband; fickle, short of stature, and gluttonous,
speaks lies, is indecent and immoral; child bearing at the
age of 5 or 6;1 by honouring her husband she is elevated.2 1) Vi. VI. 17-18, 28-31, 41.
2) Ib. VI. 2. 28-9.
text.16941:
Strīvadham — a heinous offence;1 Viṣṇu slew Śukra's
mother and was cursed to be born as man on earth seven
times for the progress of the world;2 a rule in wars that the
women of the enemy's side must not be molested; but Bāṇa's
women were molested by the fire of Tripura.3 1) Vā. 62. 155.
2) M. 47. 103.
3) Ib. 188. 49.
text.16942:
Sthaṇḍilā — one of the 10 Pīṭhas for images, square and
with no mekhala; this leads to health, wealth and happiness.
M. 262. 6, 8, 16.
text.16943:
Sthaṇḍileyu(ṣu) — one of the ten sons of Raudrāśva.
Bhā. IX. 20. 4; Vā. 99. 124. Vi. IV. 19. 2.
text.16945:
Sthalapadmini — in Ekāśiladeśa between Kṛṣṇa and
Pāṇḍura Mts; in the middle is nyagrodhā below which is
anantasada, abode of Viṣṇu who is worshipped by Yakṣas,
Gandharvas, etc.
Vā. 38. 51-9
text.16948:
Sthaleyu(ṣu) (II) — the seventh son of Raudrāśva.
Vā. 99. 124. Vi. IV. 19. 2.
text.16949:
Sthaleśvaram — a place sacred to Śiva.
M. 181. 27.
text.16952:
Sthānānī — fourteen worlds of which seven were made
and seven mind-born. Bhū to Satya were created.
Br. IV. 2. 8, 18, 31.
text.16953:
Sthāṇu (I) — the name of Vāmadeva who was prevented
from proceeding with the work of creation;1 praised by the
Gods before the swallowing of Kālakūṭa.2 1) M. 4. 32.
2) Ib. 250. 41.
text.16954:
Sthāṇu (II) — ety. from sthā, to stand; after creating
Rudras, Mahadeva stood as ūrdva reta (brahmacāri's life)
upto the pralaya; his ten qualities are knowledge, vairāgya,
aiśvarya, tapas, satya, patience, courage, the quality of
creation, knowledge of self and the quality of establishing;1
gave up protection work and hence sthāṇu.2 1) Vā. 10. 64-7; 49. 28.
2) Br. I. 1. 129; 9. 88.
text.16956:
Sthāpaka — to be honoured with presents of golden beds
in connection with rituals for cutting canals, etc;1 to be
honoured in founding new temples;2 qualifications of; one
who is versed in his art and science, has faith, is skilled and
clever, an expert in Vāstuśāstra and is pure and clean —
performs homa at the topmost place of the deity to be
installed. Worship and gifts to, after the installation of a
deity.3 1) M. 58. 49.
2) Ib. 264. 31.
3) Ib. 265. 1-4, 30; 267. 31.
text.16957:
Sthāpathya — architectural science created by Brahmā.
Bhā. III. 12. 38.
text.16958:
Sthāli — a vessel of wood for Śrāddha; of Udumbara
tree.
Vā. 75. 67.
text.16959:
Sthālipākam — a ritual comprising an offering of rice
boiled in milk.
M. 230. 11.
text.16960:
Sthita — a son of Vasudeva and Madirā.
Vā. 96. 170.
text.16961:
Sthitī (I) — a Kalā of Brahmā.
Br. IV. 35. 94.
text.16962:
Sthitī (II) — a Kalā of Hari
Br. IV. 35. 95.
text.16964:
Sthiramedhas — a god of Sumedhasa group.
Br. II. 36. 59.
text.16965:
Sthūlakarṇa (I) — a son of Devajanī and an Yakṣa.
Br. III. 7. 128.
text.16967:
Snātaka (I) — eligible for Pārvaṇa śrāddha; feeding one
such, better than many a mantrayajña in the śrāddha.2
^1 Vā. 86. 63. 2) Br. III. 9. 68; M. 16. 7.
text.16968:
Snātapa — a Kaśyapa and a Trayārṣeya.
M. 199. 12.
text.16969:
Snānam — bath for purity; worship of the earth as a
preliminary; tarpaṇam after the bath; rules for rituals
after.
M. ch. 102 (whole).
text.16970:
Snūpā — one of the daughters of Rohiṇī; had two sons.
Vā. 66. 72.
text.16971:
Snehas — the Vaiśya caste of Kuśadvīpa.
Vi. II. 4. 38.
text.16973:
Sparśam — the guṇa of Vāyu devoured by Ākāśa when
Vāyu cools down.
Vā. 102. 15.
text.16976:
Sphūrja — the Rākṣasa presiding over the month of
Puṣya: a son of Yātudhāna and father of Nikumbha;1 with
the sun in the Hemanta;2 with the sun during the Pauṣya
month.3 1) Bhā. XII. 11. 42; Br. III. 7. 89, 95.
2) Vā. 52. 19.
3) Vi. II. 10. 14.
text.16977:
Smaya — a son of Vasiṣṭha and a Prajāpati of the Svāro
ciṣa epoch.
M. 9. 9.
text.16979:
Smara (I) — a son of Devakī killed by Kamsa: taken
back to Dvārakā: after embracing by mother goes to heaven
with his five brothers.
Bhā. X. 85. 51 and 56.
text.16980:
Smara (II) — is Manmatha.
Br. IV. 30. 65; M. 23. 30 ch.
text.16981:
Smārtadharmam (Smārtam) — promulgated by Manu at
the beginning of Tretāyuga; traditional dharma of the
family and precepts of conduct constituting varṇāśrama and
ācāralakṣaṇa; deals with varṇāśrama, yama and niyama;
remembrance is smārta;1 ety. introduced after the manvan
tara by remembering the old ācāras; by once more calling
to mind the practices of previous epochs principally of
varnāśrama.2 1) Br. II. 29. 44-60; 32. 33-44; III. 21. 47. M. 142. 42; Vā. 57.
39, 41-45.
2) Ib. 59. 32, 38.
text.16983:
Smṛti (II) — Law books; distinguished from śruti in
Dvāpara and interpreted in two ways;1 no more recognised
as authority in Kali.2 1) M. 52. 12; 144. 7; Vā. 58. 24; 23. 8; 32. 44.
2) Br. II. 31.
6, 34; IV. 1. 30; 6. 64; Vā. 58. 34.
text.16985:
Smṛti (IV) — a daughter of Dakṣa; wife of Angiras; a
gotrakāra;1 had two sons and four daughters — Sinīvāli, Kūhu,
Rāka, and Anumatī; sons Bharatāgni and Kīrtimat.2 1) Vā. 10. 27; 28. 14, 30; Vi. I. 7. 25.
2) Br. II. 9. 52, 55; 11. 17;
Vi. I. 10. 7.
text.16987:
Syamantaka — a jewel presented by the Sun god to Satrā
jita (s.v.) to enable him to see his form distinctly without be
ing blinded by his hallow; had the quality of yielding eight
loads of gold every day. Kṛṣṇa thought that Ugrasena was
worthy of having it; knowing this Satrājit gave it to his
brother Prasena. He placed it in a room and hedged it with
divinity. Kṛṣṇa asked for it and was refused. It was taken to
the forest by Prasena whom a lion killed. Jāmbavā killed the
lion and got the jewel. Kṛṣṇa fought with him and recover
ing the jewel, returned it to Satrājita in a public assembly.
Satrājita offered his daughter in marriage to Kṛṣṇa and
made a gift of the jewel. Kṛṣṇa returned it to Satrājita.
Śatadhanvan killed Satrājita and took it, and placed it with
Akrūra for safe custody. This led to some misunderstand
ing between Kṛṣṇa and Rāma, and at Kṛṣṇa's request,
Akrūra made it public that it was in his possession.
Bhā. X. 37. 18; cch. 56 and 57 (whole); Br. III. 71. 26, 52,
82, 98. M. 45. 4-17; Vā. 96. 25-58. Vi. IV. 3. 14-62, 151-161.
text.16988:
Syamantapañcaka — a place of pilgrimage near Kuruk
ṣetra where the rival armies met in battle. A kṣetra
sacred to Paraśurāma: Nine pools of blood were made
here by Paraśurāma after killing all the Kṣatriyas of the
earth twenty-one times. Here came Kṛṣṇa and the Yadus to
observe solar eclipse. After fasting and bathing, Brahmans
and other guests were fed. Thither came Nanda and the
Gopas as well as Bhīṣma, Droṇa and other sages and kings.
All of them exchanged greetings. Draupadī spent her time
with Kṛṣṇa's wives asking them about their marriages. Here
Kṛṣṇa and Vasudeva performed a sacrifice. A tīrtha on the
banks of the Sarasvatī where Ditī engaged herself in
penance.
Bhā. IX. 16. 19; X. 78 [95 (V) 19]; chh. 82, 83 and 84 (whole).
M. 7. 3.
text.16989:
Syānandura — sages of, visited Dvārakā.
Bhā. X. 90. 28 [4].
text.16990:
Sravasa (Srāsata-Br. P.) — a Yāmadeva.
Vā. 31. 6. Br. II. 13. 92.
text.16991:
Srīdevī (I) — a daughter of Devaka and one of the seven
wives of Vasudeva.
M. 44. 73.
text.16992:
Srīdevī (II) — born of milk ocean; image of: in the form
of a girl of nine years, youthful, with round neck, red lips
and charming brows and holding the lotus Śrīphalam in her
hands.
M. 250. 3; 261. 40.
text.16994:
Sruca — one of the 14 gaṇas of Apsaras born of Yajña.
Br. III. 7. 19.
text.16996:
Srotas — a Rākṣasa residing in the sun's chariot in the
month of Nabha.
Vi. II. 10. 9.
text.16997:
Sva — the third loka; Sva was uttered and divaloka
came of; where Gandharvas, Apsaras, Yakṣas, Guhyakas,
and Nāgas live; intervening between Sūrya and Dhruva.
Br. II. 19. 155; 21. 21; IV. 2. 26-7; Vā. 101. 17-41.
text.16998:
Svagāhava — a son of Vṛkadevī and Vasudeva.
Vā. 96. 180.
text.16999:
Svacaṇḍāla — to be fed on festival days.
Bhā. X. 24. 28.
text.17000:
Svacchodam — a lake in the Candraprabhā hill near
Kailāsa.
Br. II. 18. 6.
text.17001:
Svacchodā — a R. in the Candraprabhā hill.
Br. II. 18. 6.
text.17002:
Svatantreśvaram — a tīrtha on the Narmadā.
M. 191. 6.
text.17003:
Svadharma — practised in Śakadvīpa;1 Paraśurāma ac
cused by Śiva as lacking in the practice of;2 to be insisted
upon the subjects by the Kings;3 of castes; departure from,
leads to hell;4 Daityas routed for having departed from their
dharma.5 1) Br. II. 19. 106; Vā. 49. 103.
2) Br. III. 23. 71; 50. 2.
3) M.
215. 63; 225. 5.
4) Vi. I. 6. 9, 41-2.
5) Ib. III. 18. 12, 48.
text.17004:
Svadhā (I) — a daughter of Dakṣa and consort of Agnīs:
(Pitṛs-Vā. P., and Vi. P.) gave birth to two daughters
Vayunā (Menā-Vā. P.) and Dhāriṇī, who were Brahma
vadīns.
Bhā. IV. 1. 63-4; Vā. 1. 77; 10. 28; 52. 40; 55. 43; Br. II. 9. 57;
13. 29. Vi. I. 7. 25, 27; 10. 19.
text.17005:
Svadhā (II) — a wife of Angiras — mother of Pitṛs.
Bhā. VI. 6. 19.
text.17006:
Svadhā (III) — married Kavi Agni: her sons were
Kāvyas: her daughter the source of Pitṛs with forms.
^1 Br. I. 1. 62; III. 10. 85; Vā. 73. 35; 74. 3; 75. 56, 77.
text.17007:
Svadhā (IV) — a god of one of the ten branches of the
Harita Gaṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 85; Vā. 100. 89.
text.17008:
Svadhā (VI) — the essence milked by Antaka for Pitṛs;1
out of this came Pitṛs1 (Somapas).2 1) M. 10. 19.
1) M. 10. 19.
2) Ib. 15. 27, 31; 16. 44; 17. 52; 22. 88.
text.17010:
Svadhām — the exclamation or benediction used in
presenting oblation to departed ancestors.
Vā. 73. 52.
text.17011:
Svadhāmā — a manifestation of Hari in the epoch of
Manu Rudrasāvarṇi: born of Satyasaha and Sūnṛtā.
Bhā. VIII. 13. 29.
text.17012:
Svadhāmṛtam — the nectar of the moon in the Kṛṣṇa
pakṣa is svādha drunk by Pitṛs and low class of deities and
in the śuklapakṣa it is amṛta drunk by Gods.
Vā. 52. 38, 40; 62. 185.
text.17013:
Svanavāta — a son of Dyutimān.
Br. II. 11. 9.
text.17014:
Svapna — dreams, bad and good; ceremonies must be
performed for bad ones; after a bad dream, one must try to
sleep for sometime; after a good dream one must try to be
awake lest it should be followed by a bad one for the latter
will generally come true. Dream had in the first of the
four divisions of the night will come true in a year; that
had in the second will come true in six months; that had in
the third, will come true in three months and that had early
in the morning will come true in 10 days.
M. 242. 1-19.
text.17016:
Svapneśa — attacked Mangala the Daitya.
Br. IV. 28. 41; 34. 64.
text.17017:
Svaphalka — a son of Pṛśni — a righteous and great king;
no disease or famine during his reign; when the Kāśi
kingdom suffered from want of rain continuously for three
years Svaphalka was invited to live there and there were
rains; he then married Kāśirāja's daughter Gāndinī who
gave in gift, every day one cow for a Brahman;1 his daughter
Narā, was the wife of Bhangakāra.2 1) Vā. 96. 101-105.
2) Ib. 96. 86.
text.17018:
Svabala — an Asura in the sabhā of Hiraṇyakaśipu.
M. 161. 80.
text.17019:
Svamālinī — a queen of Varṣaṛtu.
Br. IV. 32. 28.
text.17020:
Svamūrdha — a son of Bhṛgu and a Deva.
Br. III. 1. 89.
text.17022:
Svayambhū (I) — the one god in three forms: creating,
protecting and destroying: only sectarians speak of each of
these as separate: the one of the three guṇas;1 not created and
the first.2 1) Br. III. 3. 82-131.
2) Vā. 4. 44.
text.17023:
Svayambhū (II) — the Vedavyāsa of the first dvāpara.
Vi. III. 3. 11.
text.17024:
Svayambhoja (I) — a son of Sini, and father of Hṛdīka.
Bhā. IX. 24. 46.
text.17025:
Svayambhoja (II) — a son of Pratikṣatra (Pratikṣipta
Vā. P.) and father of Hṛdīka.
Br. III. 71. 139; Vā. 96. 138; Vi. IV. 14. 23.
text.17026:
Svayamyuta — the Gāndharva form of marriage.
Br. IV. 15. 4.
text.17027:
Svayamvara — a form of marriage by which Kṛṣṇa mar
ried a good number of women;1 of Draupadī;2 of Lakṣmaṇā.
^3 Ib. X. 58. 57. 1) Vi. III. 18. 88; V. 28. 6; Bhā. I. 10. 29; X. 52. 16.
2) Ib. X. 57.
10 [1].
text.17028:
Svara-Brahman — Nārada set his mind on Viṣṇu as
revealed in Svara.
Bhā. VI. 5. 22.
text.17029:
Svara (Snigdha) — a son of Gāyatrī and Prajāpati.
Vā. 21. 42.
text.17030:
Svaras — seven (music);1 sixteen of the Vedas.
^2 Ib. 65. 28; 104. 71. 1) Vā. 86. 36.
text.17031:
Svarapurañjaya — a son of Śeṣa Nāgarāja.
Vā. 99. 366.
text.17032:
Svaramaṇḍalam — seven svaras, three grāmās, 21 mūr
chanas and 49 tānas (tālas-Vā. P.).
Br. III. 61. 29; Vā. 86. 36, 49.
text.17035:
Svarasvāra — a queen of Varṣaṛtu.
Br. IV. 32. 28.
text.17036:
Svarā (I) — a daughter of Uttānapāda.
Br. II. 36. 90; Vā. 62. 77.
text.17037:
Svarā (II) — a daughter of Kardama and one of the
wives of Atharva Angiras; son Gautama.
Br. III. 1. 102; Vā. 65. 98.
text.17039:
Svarāṭ (I) — he, who conquers this world and the anta
rikṣa.
Br. II. 16. 17. M. 114. 16.
text.17040:
Svarāṭ (II) — one of the seven rays of the sun helping
the planet Śanaiścara.
Br. II. 24. 67; Vā. 53. 49.
text.17042:
Svarociṣa — son of Tuṣita in the Uttama manvantara.
Vā. 67. 35.
text.17043:
Svarga (I) — a son of Jāmi and Dharma, father of Nandi.
Bhā. VI. 6. 6.
text.17044:
Svarga (II) — a son of Bhīma and Diks.
Br. II. 10. 82; 27. 54.
text.17045:
Svarga (III) — the heaven;1 seven gates for; tapas, dāna,
sāma, dama, hrīḥ, ārjavam, and sympathy for all creatures;2
all these possessed by Śibi;3 reached by Yayāti with his four
grandsons;4 for the worship of Agastya.5 1) Vā. 34. 96; 41. 82; 103. 42; 108. 76 and 84.
2) M. 39. 22.
3) Ib.
42. 20.
4) Ib. 42. 28.
5) Ib. 553. 29; 61. 55.
text.17046:
Svarga Kaṇṭaka — a son and commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 83; 26. 49.
text.17047:
Svargabala — a son and commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 83; 26. 49.
text.17049:
Svargamārgapradham — a tīrtha wherefrom the Sapta
ṛṣis reached heaven; noted for Nandi's shrine.
Br. III. 13. 61.
text.17050:
Svargamejaya — a commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 86.
text.17051:
Svargaloka — is Svarlokam as also divam; the space
between the sun and Dhruva; residents of, feed on soma and
ājya; attacked by Malaka and other Asuras; Devas defeated
them after refreshing themselves with nectar got by churn
ing of the ocean on the advice of Viṣṇu; see Svarga.
Br. IV. 2. 39; 9. 38 ff; Vā. 57. 115.
text.17052:
Svargavedī — a R. fit for śrāddha offering.
Br. III. 13. 103.
text.17053:
Svargaśatru — a son and commander of Bhaṇḍa.
Br. IV. 21. 83; 26. 49.
text.17054:
Svargasopānam — seen by Angiras on the hills of the
Amarakaṇṭaka.
Vā. 77. 9.
text.17056:
Svarṇadī — a R. in the Viṣṇusthānam.
Br. III. 37. 9.
text.17057:
Svarṇapāda — a god of one of the ten branches of the
Rohita gaṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 86; Vā. 100. 90.
text.17058:
Svarṇaprastha — an upadvīpa attached to Jambūdvīpa.
Bhā. V. 19. 30.
text.17059:
Svarṇabindu — a tīrtha on the Narmadā.
M. 194. 15.
text.17060:
Svarṇabhānu — a son of Danus, and father of a daughter,
Prabhā.
M. 6. 20-21.
text.17061:
Svarṇabhūmi — c. watered by Hlādinī.
Br. II. 18. 55.
text.17062:
Svarṇa roman — a son of Mahasoman (Mahāromṇa
Vā. P.) and father of Hrasvaroman.
Bhā. IX. 13. 17; Br. III. 64. 14; Vā. 89. 14. Vi. IV. 5. 27.
text.17063:
Svarṇā — a daughter of Samudra and wife of Prācīna
barhis.
Vā. 63. 25.
text.17065:
Svarbhānu (I) — a son of Danu, and father of Suprabhā
(Prabhā-Vā. P.);1 a Daitya;2 (see Rāhu) routed Sūrya and
caused him to fall on the earth when sage Atri saved him.3 1) Bhā. VI. 6. 30 and 32; Vā. 68. 8; Vi. I. 21. 5, 7.
2) Vā. 1.
188; 53. 83; 68. 14.
3) Ib. 70. 71.
text.17066:
Svarbhānu (II) — a son of Satyabhāmā.
Bhā. X. 61. 10.
text.17067:
Svarbhānu (III) — a son of Soma, also known as Budha.
Br. I. 1. 63; II. 23. 80-38.
text.17068:
Svarbhānu (IV) — a son of Simhikā and born in Bha
raṇi; vanquished the sun; his daughter Prabhā was married
to Āyu.
Br. II. 24. 83-97, 137; III. 6. 8, 23-4; 8. 77; 67. 1; Vā. 92. 1.
text.17069:
Svarbhānu (V) — Rāhu, the planet;1 has a dark chariot
drawn by eight steeds;2 in the army at Tārakāmaya;3 mahā
graha left unskilled with Virocana;4 comes out of the sun
and enters the moon in Parvas; then from the moon to the
sun; comes out from behind and crossing the shadow of the
earth forms a circle itself; its place is Bṛhadsthānam full of
darkness;5 has only one ray.6 1) M. 128. 50.
2) Ib. 127. 9; Vā. 52. 71.
3) M. 128. 62; 173. 23.
4) Ib. 177. 8; 178. 67.
5) Vā. 52. 80-81; 53. 63-65; Vi. II. 12. 21-22.
6) Vā. 53. 88.
text.17070:
Svarbhānu (VI) — a son of Vipracitti.
Vi. I. 21. 12.
text.17071:
Svarlokam — (Divam) burnt down by Pralaya fire; one
of the seven created worlds;1 between the sun and the pole
star.2 1) Br. IV. 1. 156; 2. 15; Vā. 23. 84; 30. 98; 49. 148; 100. 160;
Vi. VI. 3. 26.
2) Ib. II. 7. 18.
text.17072:
Svarvīthi — the queen of Vatsara, and mother of Pus
pārṇa and five other sons.
Bhā. IV. 13. 12.
text.17075:
Svasā (II) — gave birth to Yakṣas and Rākṣasas.
Vi. I. 21. 25.
text.17077:
Svastika — a Nāga in the fifth talam or mahātalam.
Br. II. 20. 37; Vā. 50. 36.
text.17080:
Svastivācakam — pronouncing a blessing;1 a function at
the end of the śrāddha.2 1) M. 16. 47.
2) Ib. 17. 55.
text.17081:
Svastyātreyas — a class of sages of Atreya fold; ten sons
of Atri by his ten apsara wives; famous for their learning in
the Vedas and knowledge of Brahman.
Br. III. 8. 81; Vā. 70. 75.
text.17082:
Svahna — a son of Dakṣina and a Tuṣita god.
Bhā. IV. 1. 7-8.
text.17084:
Svāgata — a son of Śakuni and father of Suvarcas.
Br. III. 64. 21; Vā. 89. 20.
text.17085:
Svātantryam — independence claimed by Jayadevas who
were punished for doing so.
Vā. 67. 18.
text.17086:
Svāti (I) — the performance of śrāddha in this nakṣatra,
gives one profits in trade.
Br. III. 18. 8; Vā. 50. 130; 66. 49; 82. 8.
text.17087:
Svāti (II) — a son of Meghasvāti (Andhra) ruled for
18 years.
M. 273. 6.
text.17088:
Svāti (III) — a son of Dhvajinīvan and father of
Ruśanku.
Vi. IV. 12. 2.
text.17089:
Svātivarṇa — an Āndhra, ruled for a year.
M. 273. 8.
text.17090:
Svādūdaka Udadhi — (samudra) sea of fresh (sweet
M. P.) water surrounding Puṣkaradvīpa;1 beyond it, the land
of gold where no creatures live; beyond that lokāloka; ten
thousand yojanas in length and breadth; beyond is darkness
encircled by aṇḍakaṭaha.2 1) Bhā. V. 20. 29; Br. II. 19. 115, 126 and 148; M. 123. 46; Vi.
II. 4. 86.
2) Ib. II. 4. 93-5.
text.17091:
Svādhyāyam — Vedic studies, neglect of, before Pṛthu's
advent;1 recitation of Veda on the occasion of the śrāddha.2 1) M. 10. 11; 16. 9.
2) Ib. 17. 37.
text.17093:
Svāyambhuva (I) — a name of Nārada.
Bhā. I. 6. 3.
text.17094:
Svāyambhuva (II) — (see Manu)1 the Devas are
Yāmas, the sages are Marīci and six others besides his ten
sons; all engaged in Pratisarga and attained the final bliss;2
Pṛthu milked the cow-earth with the help of Svāyambhuva
Manu in his hand; to his family belonged a Prajāpati Aṅga;3
came out of the first face and of white colour;4 married
Śatarūpā.5 1) Bhā. III. 12. 53-4; Vā. 61. 119; 109. 5.
2) M. 9. 3-6.
3) Ib. 10.
3, 15.
4) Vā. 26. 32; 61. 119; 109. 5.
5) Br. II. 9. 36; Vā. 10. 11-12.
text.17096:
Svārociṣa — (see Manu) second Manu; four sons, seven
sages of whom Datta was the first; the Devas of the epoch
were Tuṣitas; then lived the seven sons of the sage Vasiṣṭha,
all Prajāpatis; ākārarūpa.2
^1 Bhā. VIII. 1. 19-20; M. 3. 47. 2) Vā. 26. 33; 62. 3, 7, 18-19.
text.17097:
Svārociṣa (Manvantara) — the second one; creation of;1
Gods were Tuṣitas; Indra was Vipaścit; Ūrja and six others
formed the seven seers; Caitra, Kimpuruṣa and others were
the sons;2 belong to Priyavrata line.3 1) Vi. I. 21. 27.
2) Ib. III. 1. 6, 10-12.
3) Ib. III. 1. 24.
text.17099:
Svāhā (I) — a daughter of Dakṣa and the mother of
Pāvaka, Pavamāna and Śucī through Paśupati-Agni; from
these three have sprung up forty-five agnis. All of them
form a group of 49 agnis.1 Mode of offering in invoking
devas while svadhā for invoking Pitṛs.2 1) Bhā. IV. 1. 60-61; Br. I. 1. 62; II. 9. 52, 56; 10. 81. 12. 3; Vā.
1. 76; 10. 28, 32; 27. 53; 29. 1; Vi. I. 7. 25, 27; 8. 8; 10. 14-15.
2) Br.
III. 3. 25; 11. 18 and 116.
text.17100:
Svāhā (II) — a god of one of the ten branches of the
Harita gaṇa.
Br. IV. 1. 85; Vā. 100. 89.
text.17101:
Svāhā (III) — the goddess enshrined at Māheśvarapura.
M. 13. 42.
text.17103:
Svāhā (V) — for karmas associated with Devas and
yajñas like svadhā for Pitṛs.
Vā. 75. 77.
text.17104:
Svāhākāra — a name of Śiva.
Br. II. 26. 34.
text.17105:
Svāhāgni — Agni and Svāhā representing Brahman.
Br. IV. 43. 75.
text.17106:
Svāhi — a son of Vṛjinīvān and father of Ruśeku; the best
of the performers of fire oblations.
Br. III. 70. 16; Vā. 95. 15.
text.17107:
Svetam — a varṣa round the Kumuda hill in Śālmali
dvīpam.
Vā. 49. 39.
text.17108:
Svedaja — ants, worms, etc.
Br. III. 7. 424-6; Vā. 30. 101, 227.
text.17110:
Svairathākāram — a varṣa after Svairatha1 of Kuśa
dvīpam.2 1) Vā. 33. 25.
2) Ib. 49. 53.
text.17111:
Svairiṇī — a group of women who came out of the mouth
of Asura Bala when he yawned.
Bhā. V. 24. 16.
text.17113:
Hanana — one of the five heinous sins; Bṛhaspati nar
rates to Indra this to be the greatest sin; killing of the trusted
to whatever community he belonged is the most heinous.
Br. IV. 6. 37; 7. 2ff.
text.17114:
Hanumān (I) — a friend of Rāma; son of Marut and
Añjanā; took part in Lankā expedition; knew the yoga power
of Viṣṇu and worshipped along with Rāma in the Kimpuruṣa
country; attained final release by satsanga. Had the white
umbrella when Bharata took the pādukā.1 The best, the
wise, the learned brahmacāri, and warrior;2 present at
Rāma's abhiṣeka.3 1) Bhā. IX. 10. 16 and 19; II. 7. 45; V. 19. 1; XI. 12. 6; IX. 10.
43.
2) Br. III. 7. 225-26; IV. 29. 118.
3) Vi. IV. 4. 100.
text.17115:
Hanumān (II) — the residence of, protected by Rudra
on all sides; there are kuṇḍas special to Sūrya, Brahmā,
Rudra and Hari.
Vā. 59. 118; 60. 73.
text.17116:
Hantā — one of the 20 of Amitābha gaṇa.
Vā. 100. 16.
text.17118:
Haṃsa (I) — a son of Brahmā; remained a celibate.
Bhā. IV. 8. 1.
text.17119:
Haṃsa (II) — Mt. on the base (north-Vi. P.) of Meru.
Bhā. V. 16. 26; Vi. II. 2. 30.
text.17120:
Haṃsa (III) — an avatār of Hari in Kṛtayuga; taught
yoga to Śanaka and other sages in the presence of Brahmā;
called himself Yajña.
Bhā. X. 2. 40; XI. 4. 17; 5. 23; 13. 19-41; 17. 3, 11.
text.17121:
Haṃsa (IV) — a son of Brahmadatta and brother of
Śālva; killed on the Yamunā by Kṛṣṇa.
Bhā X. 76. 2 [8]; 52. [56 (v) 8]; 57. 14 [1].
text.17122:
Haṃsa (V) — the caste name of men in Kṛtayuga.
Bhā. XI. 17. 10.
text.17123:
Haṃsa (VI) — one of the ten horses of the moon's chariot.
Br. II. 23. 57; M. 126. 52; Vā. 52. 53.
text.17124:
Haṃsa (VII) — a Sādhya;1 an expert in divine music.2 1) Br. III. 3. 17; M. 203. 11; Vā. 66. 16.
2) Ib. 69. 46.
text.17127:
Haṃsa (X) — a temple with a toraṇa of 10 hastas.
M. 269. 30 and 51.
text.17128:
Haṃsas (I) — a class of ascetics.
Bhā. III. 12. 43.
text.17129:
Haṃsas (II) — a class of people in Plakṣadvīpa.
Bhā. V. 20. 4.
text.17130:
Haṃsas (III) — swans born of Śuci;1 afraid of clouds and
thunder;2 stumble in the presence of poisoned food.3 1) M. 6. 32; Vā. 111. 63.
2) M. 132. 6.
3) Ib. 219. 19.
text.17132:
Haṃsakālī — a daughter of Rohiṇī: mother of buffaloes.
Br. III. 3. 74-5.
text.17133:
Haṃsakīla — one of the daughters of Rohiṇī; gave birth
to Nṛmahiṣa.
Vā. 66. 72-3.
text.17134:
Haṃsaguhya — a sacred hymn of Dakṣa in praise of
Hari.
Bhā. VI. 4. 22.
text.17135:
Haṃsajihva — belonging to Ārṣeyapravara of Bhārgava;1
a Trayārṣeya.2 1) M. 195. 41.
2) Ib. 196. 43.
text.17138:
Haṃsaaparvata — a Mt. west of the Mahābhadra lake.
Vā. 36. 30.
text.17141:
Haṃsaprapatanam — north of Pratiṣṭhāna and west of
the Bhāgīratī; a Kṣetram in Prayagā.
M. 106. 32.
text.17143:
Haṃsamārgas — a hilly country;1 watered by the Nalinī;2
an eastern tribe.3 1) Vā. 45. 120, 135; 47. 56.
2) Br. II. 18. 59; M. 121. 58.
3) Br.
II. 16. 67; Vā. 45. 120.
text.17147:
Haṃsonārāyaṇa — Brahmā; comes out of the Ekārṇava;
the same as what the Āraṇyakas and the Upaniṣads say of
Puruṣoyajña; being a Vedamaya he introduces 16 Ṛtviks
required for a Yajña from the different limbs of a body;
Mārkaṇḍeya came out of his face and saw the world plunged
in waters and wondered at it. Once again he entered the
body of the Lord, and coming out again he saw a child sleep
ing on a branch of the banyan tree. He got afraid of his
loneliness when the baby Lord asked him not to be afraid of
him and told him that he was his father and Hṛṣikeśa, etc; con
versation between them; then he entered the bowels of the
Lord;1 after the stipulated period the Lord thought of the
universe and then came Vaiśvānara; then a thousand-leafed
lotus issued from his navel in the shape of the earth. There
appeared Brahmā, the different hills, countries, Mlecchas,
etc; from this originated Padmavīdhi in Yajñas;2 there also
came Madhu and Kaiṭabha, two representatives of the
qualities of rajas and tamas who invited the creator for
war. Then they sought and got death from Viṣṇu. Brahmā
created a number of mind-born sons as Progenitors of the
world.3 1) M. 167 (whole).
2) Ib. Chh. 168, 169.
3) Ib. Chh. 170, 171.
text.17148:
Haya (I) — one of the ten horses of the moon's chariot.
Br. II. 23. 56; M. 126. 52; Vā. 52. 53.
text.17150:
Haya (III) — one of the three sons of Śatajit (Śataji
M. P.).
Br. III. 69. 4; M. 43. 8; Vā. 94. 4.
text.17153:
Hayagrīva (I) — (Hayaśīrṣa) — a manifestation of Hari
worshipped as such by Bhadraśravas: Half-man and half
horse: got back to Brahmā the Vedas seized by Asura Madhu
of Rasātala;1 the form of Viṣṇu who appeared before Agastya
at Kāncī, having Śankha, Cakra, Akṣavalaya, and Pustaka
(book) in his hand;2 resides in Sutalam.3 1) Bhā. V. 18. 1-6; XI. 4. 17.
2) Br. IV. 5. 9, 35-40.
3) Ib. II.
20. 21; Vā. 50. 20.
text.17154:
Hayagrīva (II) — a son of Danu: followed Vṛtra in his
battles with Indra: a follower of Bali.
^1 Bhā. VI. 6. 30; 10. 19; VII. 2. 4; VIII. 10. 21; Vā. 68. 10.
text.17155:
Hayagrīva (III) — the demon who carried off the Vedas
during the pralaya: killed by Matsya Hari who recovered
them.
Bhā. VIII. 24. 8 and 57.
text.17156:
Hayagrīva (IV) — a Dānava in the Tārakāmaya.
M. 173. 15; 177. 6.
text.17157:
Hayagrīva (V) — an Asura killed by Kṛṣṇa in prāgjyotiṣa.
Vi. V. 29. 19.
text.17159:
Hayamedha — see Aśvamedha and Vājimedha;1 of
Brahmā over the Gayāśīlā; Viṣṇu and other Gods promised
to occupy the śilā for mokṣa of the Pitṛ;2 of Dakṣa, ruined;3
of Vaivasvata Manu;4 of Sagara.5 1) Br. III. 47. 45, 47.
2) Vā. 108. 9-10.
3) Ib. 30. 79, 110.
4) Br.
III. 60. 4.
5) Vi. IV. 4. 16.
text.17161:
Hayaśiras (I) — a daughter of Vaiśvānara and wife of
Kratu.
Bhā. VI. 6. 33-34.
text.17162:
Hayaśiras (II) — a sacred tīrtha for śrāddha.
Br. III. 13. 46; Vā. 77. 46.
text.17163:
Hayaśiras (III) — a daughter of Svarbhānu.
Vi. I. 21. 7.
text.17164:
Hayaśīrṣa — an avatār of Viṣṇu, who appeared in the
sacrifice of Brahmā.
Bhā. II. 7. 11.
text.17166:
Hayāyurveda — the science of medicine relating to
horses.
M. 15. 20.
text.17168:
Hara (II) — one of the eleven Rudras.
M. 5. 29; Vi. I. 15. 122.
text.17169:
Hara (III) — Śiva;1 with 18 hands;2 an ascetic according
to Kamsa.3 1) Vi. I. 8. 14.
2) M. 22. 14.
3) Vi. V. 4. 4; 23. 3; 33. 25.
text.17170:
Harakalpa — a Saimhikeya Asura.
Br. III. 6. 20; Vā. 68. 19.
text.17174:
Haraya (I) — a group of gods called Jayādevas of the
epoch of Tāmasa Manu.
Br. II. 36. 43; III. 3. 9 and 66; 4. 30; Vā. 66. 9; Vi. III. 1. 16.
text.17175:
Haraya (II) — Vānaras born of Harī and Pulaha.
Br. III. 7. 175.
text.17177:
Harahā — a son of Raivata Manu.
Br. II. 36. 63.
text.17178:
Hari (I) — praise of: by Arjuna;1 by Kuntī;2 by Bhīṣma;3
by women of Hāstinapura;4 by Śuka;5 by Brahmā;6 by Jīva
in embryo;7 by Devahūtī;8 by Dakṣa and others;9 by Sunīti;10
by Dhruva;11 by Pṛthu;12 by Pracetasas;13 by Nārada;14
Rudragītā in praise of: taught by Śiva to Pracetasas;15 praise
of Hari leads to attain divine knowledge and also to mokṣa;16
praise of, by Manu (Svāyambhuva),17 by Gajendra;18 by
Brahmā;19 by Śiva;20 by Aditi;21 by Bali in bondage, by
Prahlāda;23 and by Satyavrata;24 by Trayī and Upaniṣadic and
Yoga literature;25 praise of: by Garuḍa;26 by Mucukunda;27
by Jāmbavat;28 by Kṛtavarman, and Akrūra;29 by Bhūmi,
mother of Naraka;30 by Rukmiṇī;31 by Indra;32 by Nṛga;33 and
by Rudra;34 his deeds recalled by the citizens of Mathurā;35
praise of; nature of; much in evidence in Draviḍa;36 by
Nārada;37 by kings in Jarāsandha's prison, and after their
release;38 by Yudhiṣṭira;39 by Ṛṣis;40 by Vasudeva, Devakī
and Bali;41 by Bahulāśva;42 by Śrutadeva;43 by Śrutis
(Śrutigīti);44 by gods;45 by Brahmā;46 by Uddhava;47 by
Nalakūbara and Maṇigrīva;48 by Kāliya and his wives;49 by
Gopis (Gopigītā);50 by Indra.51
^22 Ib. 22. 2-11, 21-23. 1) Bhā. I. 7. 22-26.
2) Ib. 8. 18-43.
3) Ib. 9. 32-42.
4) Ib. 10. 21-30.
5) Ib. II. 4. 12-24; 9. 5-16.
6) Ib. 9. 24-29.
7) Ib. III. 12-21.
8) Ib. 33. 2-8.
9) Ib. IV. 7. 26-47.
10) Ib. 8. 19-3.
11) Ib. 9. 6-17.
12) Ib. 20. 23-31.
13) Ib.
30. 22-42.
14) Ib. 31. 9-22[4].
15) Ib. 24. 33-79.
16) Ib. VII. 1. 4-5 [1-2];
7. 31.
17) Ib. VIII. 1. 9-16.
18) Ib. 3. 2-29.
19) Ib. 5. 26-50; 6. 8-15;
17. 25-28.
20) Ib. 12. 4-13.
21) 17. 8-10.
23) Ib.
23. 6-8.
24) Ib. 24. 29-30, 46-53.
25) Ib. X. 8. 45.
26) Ib. X. [53v 14-16].
27) Ib. 51. 46-58.
28) Ib. 56. 26-8.
29) Ib. 40. 1-30; 57. 12-17.
30) Ib. 59. 25-31.
31) Ib. 60. 34-48.
32) [67 (v) 24-30].
33) Ib. 60. 44; 64. 10-29.
34) Ib.
